title: Vows: Aislinn and Jeffery
description: A chance encounter during N.Y.'s Santacon Event helped to rekindle romance between Jeffery Franklin Klier & Aislinn Weidele.

title: The Pregame Bluster
description: The Florida players came out of their locker room and stopped before entering the playing area at the Georgia Dome for their pregame ritual of gathering in a circle with their arms locked around their shoulders.

title: Here We Go Again
description: Ohio State and its fabulous freshmen will be playing Florida in the national title game on Monday night, a rematch of the football national championship game that the Gators won in January. Mike Conley Jr. led the Buckeyes with 15 points and all of Greg Odens 13 points came in the second half as Ohio State pulled away in the last seven minutes for a 67-60 victory against Georgetown in the first game Saturday night.

title: In Fine Print
description: Last Tuesday, the crocuses were in bloom, the temperature was in the mid-70s, and Bryant Park was overflowing with office workers at lunchtime. Many were wearing fashions first spring statement, the one-piece print dress, which women can put on in 30 seconds and be off to work. Black and white, stripes and also dots were popular, and low-key flower prints, along with more exuberant patterns and a few solid colors, were evident. There was even a tiny dog wearing a print.

title: Mother Wanted Her Infant Son to Disappear, Prosecutors Say
description: A Queens woman accused of smothering her 4-month-old son told investigators that she wanted the baby to disappear after becoming angry during an argument with her mother, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Toast of the Town
description: The movies have given us many catchphrases that seem to seep into the cultural idiom overnight: Go ahead, make my day, for one; Arnolds Ill be back is another. Fasten your seat belts and What a dump are compliments of Bette Davis, and lest we forget: Theres no place like home. You may not bless my all-time list of movie zingers, but frankly, my dear, I dont give a damn. The line that has me in thrall right now comes from Arthur Penns Night Moves. I saw a Rohmer film once, muses Gene Hackman. It was kinda like watching paint dry.

title: Design Within Reach
description: Japanese young people dont really enjoy creativity, says the fashion designer Issey Miyake, who seems determined to put the fun back into the banal, even if it means sugarcoating things a bit. He is the mastermind behind 21_21 Design Sight, a museum devoted to the design of daily life, which opened last month in Tokyo Midtown, a development in the Roppongi district conceived as a designer city-within-a-city. (The Tadao Ando-designed building is neighbor to Kengo Kumas new Suntory Musuem, and Jun Aoki is involved in creating a residential zone.) The inaugural show, curated by the industrial designer Naoto Fukusawa (who, with the graphic designer Taku Saito, is on the museums creative team), features 70 objects made of chocolate. They include the fashion designer Kosuke Tsumuras T-shirt as a Meiji candy bar and Gaku Otomos scale model of a human heart in white chocolate. Talk about good taste.

title: A Lyrical Approach to a Subject That Shocks
description: ZOO, the new film by the Seattle director Robinson Devor, arrived at this years Sundance Film Festival better known as the horse sex documentary. But as festival audiences discovered, this description, while not incorrect, was also misleading. The film revisits the true story of a man who died in July 2005 after a sexual encounter with a horse in rural Washington State but does so with a lyricism startlingly at odds with the sensational content.

title: With Heart, Williams Wins in 3 Sets
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 31  Serena Williamss physical strength is there for everybody to see  the muscles in her arms and legs about as subtle as an overhead smash. While the eye is drawn to Williamss brawn, her greatest asset goes largely unnoticed.

title: Japans Textbooks Reflect Revised History
description: TOKYO, March 31  In another sign that Japan is pressing ahead in revising its history of World War II, new high school textbooks will no longer acknowledge that the Imperial Army was responsible for a major atrocity in Okinawa, the government announced late Friday.

title: Theyre All Bad for You, but Should They Be Illegal?
description: IS it the governments job to prevent people from engaging in unhealthy behavior? Or is it to give them the best available information so they can decide for themselves what to do? A flurry of bills aimed at banning a range of habits  from smoking in cars with young children to serving partially hydrogenated foods in restaurants  have state lawmakers weighing privacy issues against public health concerns.

title: Rebecca Roses, Travis Harrison
description: Rebecca Jill Roses, the daughter of Helene Levy Roses and Dr. Daniel F. Roses of New York, and Travis Harrison, the son of Adrienne Harrison of East Moriches, N.Y., and Thomas J. Harrison of Naples, Fla., were married last evening at Guastavinos in New York. Rabbi Barton A. Shallat officiated.

title: Never Tell Our Business to Strangers
description: NINE years ago, when my mother suffered a minor heart attack, my father and I learned that for more than two decades she had been lying about her age. She was actually three years older than my father, not two years younger, as she had always said. Apparently sensing that her real age might be relevant to her treatment, she had given the nurse her actual birth date, and then my father and I saw it scrawled on her plastic hospital bracelet.

title: The Talk
description: gorgeois / (gor jzhwa) / adj. / a neologism to express newfound appreciation for things once considered conventional or bourgeois, like the various Palms (Beach, Springs), porcelain figurines and flowery fabrics, as in, Your poppy-print Oscar de la Renta is totally gorgeois.

title: Sweet Spot
description: Stop searching for the sweet spot in todays world of clich; you found it here.

title: Anne Healy, Robert Pollak
description: Anne Elizabeth Healy and Robert Michael Pollak were married last evening at the Chart House, a restaurant in Weehawken, N.J. Ethan Greenberg, an acting State Supreme Court Justice in the Bronx, officiated.

title: Way, Way Off Broadway, New York Auto Show Will Go On
description: THE cars and the styles may change and the fortunes of automakers may rise and fall. But one tradition remains sacrosanct at the New York International Auto Show: out-of-towners cracking jokes about how the only cars that matter to the locals are yellow taxicabs or black Town Cars.

title: The Mind Reader
description: Q: As a professor of cognitive science at Indiana University who spends his time thinking about the process of thinking, what do you make of Descartess famed pronouncement, I think, therefore I am? Who knows what that means? Its a tiny, little aphorism. You can interpret it any way you want and say, What a wise man he was!

title: Up Front
description: Jim Bouton, who went 21-7 for the Yankees in 1963 and won two games in the 1964 World Series, quit pitching altogether 10 years ago. Too many bulked-up kids with aluminum bats in dimly lit ballparks, he said in an e-mail message. The last game I pitched, I was wearing the uniform of the Saugerties Dutchmen. They got me in a trade with Mamas Pizza. Bouton, who reviews The Cheaters Guide to Baseball this week, is unforgiving when it comes to steroids: I cant stand it that Bonds is breaking all these records. A blue-ribbon panel should determine the impact of steroids on home runs and have the numbers adjusted accordingly, with the SAN (steroid-adjusted number) put in parentheses next to the actual number hit. Time will tell which number is legitimate and which one should end up in parentheses, just as history removed the imaginary asterisk from Roger Mariss 61 home runs. Leave the other records to the statisticians. He added that the innocent players can blame themselves for not demanding that their union protect them from the users.

title: Reader Response: School Drug Testing
description: Selected responses to last week's question about drug testing in schools.

title: A Victory on Main Street
description: The village of Greenport has come up with an intriguing model for creating affordable housing, one that seeks to level the villages badly tilted real estate playing field back in favor of regular working people. There is a dwindling number of those in Greenport, whose population of wealthy summer residents has grown significantly in recent years.

title: Baron Freytag von Loringhoven, Aide to Hitler, Dies at 93
description: Baron Bernd Freytag von Loringhoven, who as a young German Army officer was one of the last to flee Hitlers Berlin bunker as Soviet troops closed in, died on Feb. 27 in Munich. He was 93.

title: Gentlemen of the Road
description: Chapter 10: On the Belated Repayment of the Gift of a Pear

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: Push Comes to Shove for Control of Web Video
description: FOR now, the biggest news in the exploding realm of online video is not much more than a news release. Still, the recent announcement from the News Corporation and NBC Universal of a new online video venture shows a big change in how traditional media companies are trying to confront their digital futures without looking like dinosaurs dodging comets.

title: Logo a Go-Go
description: Why would a graphic designer ask a Yale theoretical physicist to calculate how many possible combinations there could be of 64 squares?

title: Invasor Wins in Dubai on Site of His Only Loss
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, March 31  The worlds richest race was supposed to be a showdown between brothers on their home racetrack Saturday. Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, the ruler of Dubai, had the undefeated Discreet Cat while Sheik Hamdan had Americas 2006 Horse of the Year, Invasor.

title: Former Microsoft Engineer Prepares to Blast Off
description: At 13, Charles Simonyi won a Junior Astronaut competition in Hungary that earned him a trip to Moscow to meet one of the first cosmonauts. This week, on Saturday, the former Microsoft engineer who oversaw the creation of the Word and Excel software programs is scheduled to depart on a roughly 12-day orbital flight to the International Space Station on a Soyuz TMA spacecraft, along with two cosmonauts. Having paid about $25 million to Space Adventures, a privately owned space tourism company, Mr. Simonyi will become the fifth civilian space tourist to pay for the out-of-this-world experience.

title: Beyond the Yankees and the Zoo
description: ARE you the kind of avant-garde tourist who lives to be the first outsider to find that charming little shop or try that new gem of a neighborhood bistro? If so, forget Manhattan. Unless you stumble across a place as the sign is going up, Google will show you that dozens of critics, bloggers and old-fashioned pundits have beaten you to it. That's the way things work on this overdocumented island.

title: A Cooks Tour of Milan
description: MOST visitors to Milan, Italy's center of finance, commerce and design, go looking for gold, literally or figuratively, and so do I. But the gold I search for is culinary. I first realized that is this city's favorite food color some 40 years ago when I found Vecchia Milano in Cucina, a small paperback devoted to the lore, history and traditional recipes of Milan and its region, Lombardy. It was printed on chrome-yellow paper to honor sunny local dishes like cornmeal polenta, veal cotoletta Milanese, with its crisp golden breading, and the many dishes sparked with orange squashes and zucchini blossoms. Egg yolks tint the hot consomm zuppa alla pavese as well as the high and airy sweet Christmas bread, panettone.

title: War Over a Building That Helped Win One
description: DAYTON, Ohio  Plans to demolish an Art Deco building where a top-secret program broke Nazi codes have prompted a battle between preservationists and the University of Dayton, which owns the building and intends to have it razed to make way for a 50-acre campus expansion.

title: New York:  The Bowery Hotel
description: BASICS

title: The Week in Connecticut
description: Coming Soon, the Noisy Skies of Fairfield?

title: Bumper to Bumper, and Here Come the Buses
description: Almost every day during the morning and afternoon rush, Pelham Parkway in the Bronx becomes ensnarled, with several lanes of car traffic crawling toward or away from Manhattan. On a recent morning, motorists gritted their teeth behind the wheels of delivery trucks and honking sedans. So a plan to seize one of those lanes and devote it during much of the day to buses has incensed some residents.

title: At a Longstanding Playground, Yet Another Plan to End the Games
description: The undistinguished little playground at First Avenue and 42nd Street, just south of the United Nations, has been tempting developers for years. Though it is called Robert Moses Playground, it is not much of a tribute to the master builder: a windswept 1.3-acre patch of painted asphalt, used by children, dog walkers and a roller hockey league.

title: Aislinn Weidele, Jeffery Klier
description: Aislinn Weidele and Jeffery F. Klier were married last evening at City Hall, a restaurant in New York. Judge Arlene Hahn of New York City Housing Court officiated.

title: A Lyric Lingers; a Superstar Still Satisfies
description: BRANDI CARLILE is a rough-and-tumble young woman of 25, most at ease at her home on the outskirts of Seattle with her Doberman, cat and horse, Sovereign. Alas, the road beckons. Starting Sunday Ms. Carlile, who has opened for Ray LaMontagne and Shawn Colvin on past tours, begins touring with her band, which includes two longtime collaborators, the twins, Tim and Phil Hanseroth. Her roots-rock second album, The Story (Sony), is out Tuesday. Ms. Carliles voice confidently flits from sturdy to raw, wavering over lyrics about the emotional minefields of loss and love. On the song Cannonball, she is joined by the Indigo Girls. She spoke recently with Winter Miller about what shes listening to now.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: Tribune Board Presses Zell to Raise His Bid
description: In last-minute negotiations, executives for the Tribune Company have been pushing Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate tycoon, to increase his bid for the company by late tonight, according to people close to the talks. If he does so, the company may announce that he won the bidding war.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: VIEWS OF VICTORIA FALLS

title: Palestinian Faction Aims to Unite Its Militias
description: JERUSALEM, April 1  Fatah, the mainstream Palestinian movement, announced Sunday that it was working to unify its armed groups under one command in an apparent effort to strengthen and impose discipline on its notoriously divided militias.

title: LIPA, National Grid and KeySpan Reach Deal
description: ENDING months of negotiations, National Grid and KeySpan have reached an agreement in principle with the Long Island Power Authority for operating its electric transmission and delivery systems for the next seven years.

title: Striving to Help War Veterans and Break a Social Stigma
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 29  As young veterans return from their dusty, nerve-racking tours in Iraq and Afghanistan, they are bringing home a host of psychological wounds, ones that neither show their face to the public nor rise to the level of a brain injury. It may be trouble reconnecting with high school buddies, difficulty focusing at work, flashbacks or grief.

title: Going Out With a Flurry
description: INSTEAD of dwelling on his impressive rsum as a choreographer, Randy James likes to talk about his stint dancing onstage in Atlantic City in the 1980s, recalling a sailor-type move called the bell kick that he worked into productions of The Wiz and Pinocchio.

title: Cuba and Venezuela, the Odd Couple
description: CARACAS, Venezuela

title: Glass Act
description: It used to be that the only way you could see Philip Johnsons Glass House was to make his acquaintance. Now all you have to do is make a reservation. The legendary Modernist architect, who died in 2005, donated his New Canaan, Conn., country retreat  which includes three vernacular buildings and 10 structures designed by Johnson in addition to the glass-and-steel pavilion that made him famous  to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, which will open the 47-acre site to the public (by appointment only) in June. The sites mission is to become a model for the preservation of Modernism and a laboratory for new talent, inspired by the example of Johnson and his companion, the curator David Whitney. Go to www.philipjohnsonglasshouse.org.

title: Plastic Fantastic
description: Intentionally or not, Wendell Castle took the advice whispered to Benjamin Braddock in The Graduate and went into plastics. From 1968 to 1973, the designer-craftsman  who was already famous for his laminated, surreally shaped wood furniture  made functional sculptures in plastic that look astonishingly fresh nearly 40 years later. When the New York gallery R 20th Century showed a limited reissue of some of these pieces at Design Miami last December, there was a palpable gasp. His bulbous extrusions and lumpy mounds, with names like Fat Albert and Roxanne, conjure everything from slugs-on-the-go to a torso by R. Crumb. There were stingray-shaped lights etched in neon that wobbled on the ground, tables with octopus legs and a group of furniture called the Molar collection.

title: Unsporting News
description: I can just imagine the marketing meeting for this book:

title: A Bridge Over the Atlantic, in Labor Policy
description: FROM issues of crime and punishment to the proper domain of the spiritual and temporal powers, Americans and Europeans have long cast a skeptical eye at one another across the Atlantic.

title: Amid Theft Charges, the Struggle to Lure Volunteers
description: HAD they been pictures in a childrens book, they would have been confounding: See the firefighters marching in the parade with their shiny trucks, cheered as heroes. See the firefighters marched into court wearing shiny manacles, charged as thieves.

title: Ex-Aide Says Hes Lost Faith in Bush
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 29  In 1999, Matthew Dowd became a symbol of George W. Bushs early success at positioning himself as a Republican with Democratic appeal.

title: Taking Time Out to Search for a Coastal Areas Past
description: Madison

title: For a Melting Pot, Scoops of Coconut Ice
description: It was a special kind of opening day yesterday. But there was no Carl Pavano, no Tom Glavine, no peanuts, no Cracker Jack, no opening pitch.

title: Free for All
description: The group of young intellectuals who often gathered at Ayn Rands Manhattan home in the early 1950s had a couple of different names for themselves. One was the Class of 43, after the year that Rand published her first successful novel, The Fountainhead. Another, with intentional irony, was the Collective.

title: The Cost of Living in Connecticut; UConn Hospital as Business Venture (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hurricanes Are Gone, but the Cars May Remain
description: EARL GRUBBS of Cranberry Township, Pa., hadnt even arrived home from the dealership with his new car before the air bag warning light came on. It was last October, and he had just bought a used 2005 Buick LaCrosse CSX with only 45 miles on the odometer for $20,000.

title: 25 Years After War, Wealth Changes Falklands
description: STANLEY, Falkland Islands  Twenty-five years ago, Argentina invaded this wind-swept cluster of British-controlled islands in the remote South Atlantic. After 11 weeks of combat that claimed nearly 1,000 lives, British troops drove off the occupiers, allowing the islanders to continue with their eminently British way of life.

title: Home Shopping
description: The fashion designer Dries Van Noten and his partner, Patrick Vangheluwe, spent much of last year scouring antique stores and flea markets to fill a pied--terre: a 1920s Venetian chandelier, a bridge table from the collection of Charles de Bestegui, a tufted sofa from the 50s covered in pale-blue Prelle silk. Their new Paris home, however, is in fact a boutique. Set up as a series of intimate rooms, the place feels like a well-appointed apartment  right down to the river views. Alas, only the clothes are for sale.

title: National League West
description: A.L: East | Central | West | N.L.: East | Central | West

title: The Air Is Full of Secrets
description: Elaine Equi has been publishing her observant, often playful poetry for some 30 years, extending and deepening the range of her intrinsically wry voice. Ripple Effect offers a broad sampling of Equis career, 159 poems, proving her as capable of a memorable four-line epigram as she is of an elegant pantoum, jokey self-interview, surreal meditation on the color yellow or tender lyric sequence. The book showcases a sensibility troubled by what happens around her, but capable of being charmed by the exotic way / everything normal / begins looking / in order to / win you back.

title: Australian Critics See Politics in Detainee Deal
description: LONDON, March 31  In Australia, Prime Minister John Howard is facing accusations that the relatively brief sentence and yearlong order of silence on Guantnamo detainee David Hicks resulted from governmental pressure, charges he dismissed as absurd.

title: Beyond Airbrushing
description: Rarely is the hand or touch of the artist visible in photography, in which mechanical reproduction is the norm. But an exhibition at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield suggests that this may be a thing of the past.

title: Timing Is Perfect for Oden and Buckeyes
description: ATLANTA, March 31  Georgetown Coach John Thompson III and Ohio State Coach Thad Matta say they do not use a handbook when managing players in foul trouble.

title: Busy Actors Long, Long Day: Shakespeare, Weill and Rock
description: THE alarm clock woke Michael Cerveris with a Kurt Weill recording at 7:30 a.m. on a recent, blustery Tuesday morning. By 9 Mr. Cerveris, the Sweeney Todd star, had showered, dressed, checked e-mail and was out walking his dog, Gibson. His distinctive shaved head covered by a stocking cap, he ducked into a deli and bought a healthful-looking green juice, which he consumed in his living room with a bowl of organic oatmeal and some vitamins. Crouching down, he gently fed Gibson a few vitamins of her own, dipping them in peanut butter.

title: Arm Candy
description: Baccarats latest designer collaboration represents a sea change for the 243-year-old company. At the trade show Maison et Objet in January, it unveiled a line of lighting and tableware by the Paris-based designer Arik Levy that is both intellectual and, in the case of the single-armed Fantome chandelier, frugal. In a quest to make the tony brand more accessible to those without high ceilings and higher budgets, Levy  whos known for his scientific approach to design  proposed chopping up the classic chandelier (figuratively, that is) and selling it by the piece. At $1,990, Fantme can be used as a design element, 55 lined up in a room, or as a complete object, he explains. The one arm brings the rest of the chandelier with it, psychologically. It feels like all the other arms are flying behind it, like ghosts.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday in T: Travel, about the resurgence of Dallas, misidentified a street that is known for its mansions. It is Swiss Avenue, not Swift. The article also referred incorrectly to a retail, office and hotel complex designed by Philip Johnson. It is the Crescent, not the Crescent Court, which is a hotel.

title: Some Bumps at Start of War Tribunals at Guantnamo
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, March 31  As the first of the war crimes cases under a new law began here a few days ago, a military law specialist said it was a test run to show that this plane will fly.

title: The Smart-Pill Solution
description: Boston

title: Meredith Evans, Matthew Raiford
description: Meredith R. Evans and Matthew L. Raiford were married yesterday  in Atlanta. The Rev. Timothy McDonald III performed the ceremony at the First Iconium Baptist Church, with the Rev. Chauncey Newsome, also a Baptist minister, taking part.

title: Arsenic and Old Photos
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Hiding in Plain, Padded Sight
description: WHEN Karen Russells mother, Janice, packed her daughter off to Northwestern University in September 1999, she was concerned for the girl. Having lived in Miami her entire life, the junior Ms. Russell had never seen snow or felt the icy breath of winter. And like overprotective mothers everywhere, she assuaged her anxieties by giving her daughter a little bit of overprotection.

title: Getting Serious About Sex Trafficking
description: Lawmakers in Albany have a bad habit of waiting until the chaotic closing days of the legislative session to focus on important legislation. A result is that useful measures that would benefit the citizens of New York often fall by the wayside.

title: Britain Adopts Conciliatory Tone With Iran
description: LONDON, March 31  After more than a week of mounting confrontation over its 15 captured sailors and marines held in Iran, Britain sounded a more conciliatory tone on Saturday, saying it had responded to a diplomatic message from Tehran and was ready to peacefully resolve the issue.

title: From City Drivers, Pleas for Country Signs
description: Dave Carman was driving home to City Island through Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx last Sunday night when he spotted a deer munching on grass beside a guardrail.

title: Obamas Online Strategy Seeks Big Bonus From Small Turnout
description: Justin Neely is a dream of a supporter, so committed to Senator Barack Obamas presidential bid that he stayed up until 2 a.m. using the campaigns social networking site the night it went online.

title: Inside the List
description: GREATER SAINTS: Mother Angelica, the jowly Franciscan nun who became an unlikely cable broadcasting star  Time magazine once compared her to Benny Hill in a wimple  has the No. 8 book on the hardcover advice extended list. Its Mother Angelicas Little Book of Life Lessons and Everyday Spirituality, edited by Raymond Arroyo.

title: Sand Box
description: The previous house the architect Steven Holl designed, on a mesa in New Mexico, was a metal iceberg that eschewed right angles. His newest house, however, embraces them. The change was dictated not by Holls aesthetic whims but by his clients, who were moving from the Midwest to rizona, with a large contemporary art collection. What they wanted was a home that doubled as a private gallery. Indeed, although the scenery outside is gorgeous, the couple was less interested in framing views (something every house in the neighborhood tries to do) than in framing works by the likes of Jeff Koons, Bruce Nauman and Robert Ryman.

title: A Castles Colorful Story Gets a Heavy Rewrite
description: ANYONE who has toured Fleming Castle might consider returning for another round of tales that may not be so tall.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (Showtime) THE TUDORS Henry VIIIs contributions to history include the Church of England, sanctioned divorce and multiple beheadings. A new series further sexes up the story of this English king by taking a look at the young Henry (Jonathan Rhys Meyers, left) as he begins to form the legacy for which he would be known. In the first episode Henry prepares for war with France, and a lady-in-waiting becomes pregnant.

title: Trying to Preserve an Aging Relic
description: WESTPORT

title: The Little Church That Couldnt
description: THE Bay Ridge United Methodist Church has stood on a leafy Brooklyn corner since 1900, and somewhere along the way it picked up a nickname, the Green Church, a reference to the tint of the stone on its walls and its signature clock tower. These days, that stone can also be found, in large chunks and fine powder, scattered on the ground outside, near fences and scaffolding that have been erected to protect people walking in the front door.

title: A Nice Stiff Breeze, and a Nice Little Power Bill
description: GUS SANSONE has not had to pay an electricity bill in five years, thanks to the 35-mile-an-hour wind gusts that whip past his house on the high desert of San Bernardino County, Calif.

title: Bernanke Speaks, and the Market Retreats
description: The stock market dropped last week on Congressional testimony of Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, on Wednesday.

title: The Less Fuss, the Better
description: WITH the exception of dishes like lasagna, main courses for Sunday dinners tend to be extremely simple; the labor involved is more in the shopping (and expense) than it is in the actual cooking, as you can see from the recipes here.

title: Correction: A Better Society? Or a Better Rsum?
description: An article last Sunday about the motives behind community service misstated the sentence that the actor Russell Crowe received for throwing a telephone at a hotel desk clerk. He pleaded guilty to third-degree assault and was released on the condition that he avoid an arrest during the next year. He was not required to perform community service. The article also referred imprecisely to the recent discovery of rat infestation in a Greenwich Village restaurant. The restaurant was a KFC/Taco Bell, not a Taco Bell. (The reference was to a Taco Bell-loving rat.)

title: Too Many Men on the Fields (and Women and Children, Too)
description: At 11 p.m., with the temperature well below freezing, two teams of men in their 30s possessing varying degrees of athletic prowess played a spirited, if sloppy, game of soccer atop a Hudson River pier. A cold wind blew ball and bodies about in unpredictable ways.

title: Look, Its a Bird. Its a Plane. Its the Buick Super (in Reruns).
description: BUICK is bringing back the Super. After a 50-year hiatus, it will again produce cars with the Super name: a premium 2008 LaCrosse in a few months and, later, a premium 2008 Lucerne.

title: Jessica Liberman, Keith Wilcox
description: Jessica Brand Liberman and Keith Todd Wilcox were married yesterday evening at the Montauk Yacht Club in Montauk, N.Y. Judge Debra Freeman of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Plea to a Group Home: Another Backyard, Please
description: Mount Vernon

title: Leaps and Bounds in Stoudemires Knowledge
description: When Amare Stoudemire accompanied 12 students from his foundations learning center in Phoenix to the Arizona Science Museum last month for the popular touring anatomical exhibit on bodies, they all saw the sinews, bones and muscles that troubled him.

title: Doing the Math at Restaurants
description: To the Editor:

title: Can the Star Maker Make Himself a Star?
description: TIMBALAND is not an invisible man  not exactly. He has released four major-label albums, none a big hit but all respectfully received. He tried to become a music mogul by starting his own label, Beat Club, which didnt take off. For years he has popped up in music videos: hiding in the shadows of Aaliyahs Are You That Somebody, haunting Justin Timberlakes Cry Me a River. He has popped up on albums too, murmuring encouragement to Missy Elliott or seconding Jay-Zs boasts.

title: Condominiums With Classrooms
description: ONE of the hottest new amenities being offered in upscale urban condominium developments doesnt have anything to do with granite in the kitchen, marble in the baths, steam rooms or simulator golf. Its school.

title: Your Score
description: BORROWERS should know their credit scores before they try to get a loan.

title: Gone Is the Swaggering Prince of Prosecution
description: THE e-mail is pleading, imploring and often so very careful. In messages sent to their bosses at the Justice Department, federal prosecutors react to their firing.

title: A Brighter Padlock, at Twice the Price
description: WHEN overseeing consumer focus groups of high school students, Steve Hedlund pays closer attention when the deeper voices start talking. Teen girls, theyre too polite to say they dont like a product, said Mr. Hedlund, vice president for growth and innovation at Master Lock, based in Milwaukee. Its always the teen boys that are the litmus test.

title: Ex-Basketball Star Helps Rebuild His Hometown
description: Jersey City

title: Its Time to Test Drive the Sofas
description: IF youre in Milan and notice that the streets are ablaze with well-groomed people wearing fancy sunglasses and ergonomic shoes and lugging designer bags loaded with media kits, its because the citys most anticipated annual event  the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, a k a the Milan Furniture Fair  has once again descended.

title: Zoning Changes Proposed to Preserve West Harlems Character
description: Columbia Universitys proposal for a $7 billion expansion of its campus on 17 acres in West Harlem has touched off fears that another wave of gentrification will wash over this low-scale neighborhood of tenements, brownstones, housing projects, warehouses and small businesses.

title: A Housing Land Trust
description: Residents of Westchester can always mark the arrival of spring by the emergence of the annual crop of initiatives in County Executive Andrew Spanos State of the County address.

title: Borrowing Trouble
description: WHEN Gregory and Paula Sherman wanted to refinance the mortgage on their ranch-style home in Chattaroy, Wash., near Spokane, in June 2003, they went to a local mortgage broker.

title: Star Tech
description: Moritz Waldemeyer is doing his best to counter the stereotype of the socially inept techno-wizard nerd in Coke-bottle glasses. He zips around London in a bright-yellow 1979 MG; with his shaggy hair and gangly good looks, he could easily be mistaken for the lead singer in an English guitar band. Over the past few years, Waldemeyer has become the go-to guy for cutting-edge gadgetry: Zaha Hadid, Ron Arad and Hussein Chalayan have all availed themselves of his services. Needless to say, he does not wear a plastic pocket protector.

title: For Starkey of L.S.U., Interim Sounds Fine
description: CLEVELAND, March 31  As Louisiana State makes its fourth consecutive appearance in the womens Final Four, the interim coach Bob Starkey finds himself in the odd position of being undefeated and perhaps soon unemployed.

title: Shop | Someplace Like Home
description: Mixing commerce with domesticity, three Italian companies  Boffi (kitchens and baths), Porro (tables, chairs and case goods) and Living Divani (mostly upholstered furniture)  have joined forces in By, a newly opened retail space at 142 Greene Street that looks less like a showroom than a sophisticated loft. I didnt want to sell a catalog image, explains Piero Lissoni, the prolific Milan designer who is also the art director for all three companies. To that end, Lissoni mixed antiques and art with the companies products, and used glass partitions instead of walls to maximize light and space, which he calls the real qualities of luxury. Too bad the kitchen and bathroom dont actually function, or wed move right in.

title: Idol for the Operatically Inclined
description: BEYOND the elegant wood-paneled foyer, in the slightly dingy auditorium of the Academy of Vocal Arts in Philadelphia, opera singers took the small stage, one after another. A young soprano in gothlike attire earnestly bleated out Bellini. A radiant mezzo-soprano lighted the stage with a warm, vivid sound, but her top notes were consistently flat. A baritone spread his arms and bellowed as if his life depended on it. The Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions are open to all comers.

title: The Rebel Heiress
description: In his 1928 novel Nadja, Andr Breton cites an old French adage: Tell me whom you haunt  whom you befriend and Ill tell you who you are. Judged by this criterion, the English heiress Nancy Cunard, who haunted Bretons Surrealists and countless other artists besides, is one of the biggest stars youve never heard of. T. S. Eliot put her in an early version of The Waste Land; Pablo Neruda celebrated her lovely sky-blue eyes; and Samuel Beckett praised her spunk and verve. All three future Nobel laureates had fraught romances with her. Wyndham Lewis, Aldous Huxley, Tristan Tzara, Ezra Pound and Louis Aragon were among her lovers. She played tennis with Ernest Hemingway, received house calls from James Joyce and modeled for Constantin Brancusi. Langston Hughes called her one of my favorite folks in the world. William Carlos Williams, who kept a picture of her in his study, deemed her one of the major phenomena of history.

title: Its Not All About the Process
description: ONE of my wifes very close childhood friends is Bo Jones, publisher of The Washington Post. I recently found myself at dinner with him, Ben Bradlee, Sally Quinn and Jim Lehrer at a restaurant in Biarritz, France. Jim Lehrer asked us all a monumental question. He asked us what we missed most from our childhood. Everyone went through their story of how they missed something. I ended up being the last one to say something. The reality was I didnt have anything I missed from my childhood. We were pretty poor. We didnt even have inside plumbing until I was 17. That pretty much shut up everyone who was around the table.

title: An Autograph Is No Longer What Makes a Mitt Most Valuable
description: On a warm March afternoon at a Modells Sporting Goods store on Manhattans Upper East Side, 39-year-old Angel Valez was, appropriately enough, in a baseball frame of mind.

title: A Map for the Maze of Federal Contracts
description: CARL R. BONITZ is co-owner of a small business, and he wants a piece of the federal contracting pie.

title: The Dry Saloon, the Dissected Violin, the Dreamer of Sleepy Hollow
description: IN the spirit of James Barrons book Piano, which chronicled the birth of a Steinway concert grand in a Queens factory, John Marchese now offers up The Violin Maker: Finding a Centuries-Old Tradition in a Brooklyn Workshop (HarperCollins, $24.95).

title: Rangers Hold Their Ground in a Tight Playoff Race
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31  The Rangers stood or sat in clusters around televisions in the visiting locker room at Wachovia Center on Saturday night. The matter of their 6-4 victory against the Flyers had been settled, but they watched one of their playoff pursuers, Toronto, Sundays opponent, intently on the screens above them.

title: A Fairy Godmother for the High-End Fashion Set
description: Port Washington

title: Designers Do Affordable (No Fooling)
description: When shopping, it can be all too easy to feel as if you're being taken for a fool, handing over a deck of bills for a scrap of black fabric with two buttons. These days, though, designers are making it easier for shoppers to deceive rather than be deceived, colluding with stores to create lower-priced lines. Above, eight pieces that can help you say  silently  April Fool.

title: Funny Things Happened on the Way to the Condo
description: ONSTAGE at the Bonaventure Town Center Club in Weston, Fla., near Fort Lauderdale, the comedian Vic Arnell, 69, has the Saturday-night crowd right where he wants them: laughing so hard theyre dabbing away tears.

title: Once Upon a Mattress
description: I am Patty.

title: Book Smart | Home Edition
description: If youre confused by the plethora of new decorating books out there, try an old one. Pointed Leaf Press has reissued Decorating Is Fun!, the 1939 how-to volume by the legendary American designer and lifestyle guru Dorothy Draper. In it, she extols the virtues of black-and-white checkerboard floors, chintz slipcovers and painting your front door a bright, welcoming color, among other tips that ring as true today as they did when she wrote them. And once youve settled into your new home, you can learn how to be the hostess with the mostest in Drapers 1941 sequel, Entertaining Is Fun!, which was reissued by Rizzoli in 2004.

title: Laugh Lines: Jay Leno and David Letterman
description: JAY LENO

title: Composure and Whistles Keep U.C.L.A. at Bay
description: ATLANTA, March 31  It is called blitzing the ball screen, and U.C.L.A. does it as well as any team in college basketball. The tactic works this way: An opponent tries to set a screen at the top of the key, and the Bruins immediately jump the ball handler with two players.

title: Slide Show: Neo Geo
description: Get out your beanbag chair: The 1970s are back in original designs and new pieces that graphically evoke that era.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Nears Deal to Buy First Data
description: First Data, one of the nations largest credit-card processing companies, is near a deal to be sold for nearly $27 billion to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, according to people involved in the transaction. The deal for First Data, which controls the NYCE payment network, is expected to be announced tomorrow morning.

title: Surreality Check
description: When Salvador Dal created his Lobster and White Aphrodisiac telephones in 1938, they were certainly intended to invoke the bizarre dream mentality of the Surrealists. But unlike the melting clocks he painted, the phones were functional objects: designed for the poet and arts patron Edward Jamess house and produced by a decorating firm, the White Aphrodisiac was, above all, a telephone, though we rarely think of it that way. We tend to focus on these familiar objects as art, even though they originated in design, says Ghislaine Wood, a curator at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London. Theyve been divorced from their history.

title: O-m-m-m
description: To the Editor:

description: A.L: East | Central | West | N.L.: East | Central | West

title: Correction: Abracadabra: Lifting the Lid Off the Box
description: An article last Sunday about the Box, a Moulin Rouge-infused club that opened on the Lower East Side last December, misstated the role of Cordell Lochin in the business. He is a full partner, not a minor partner. The article also misspelled the surname of another partner. He is Richard Kimmel, not Kimmell.

title: Once the Butcher for the World, Now a Quarter-Acre Lot
description: CHICAGO

title: Comings and Goings
description: Stuck in London with some free time between visiting the Victoria and Albert Museum and Harrods? Go to visitlondon.com, click on its newest Web feature, London Explorer and type in either destination. The search engine (which also uses postal codes and tube stops for points of reference) will pull up the closest attractions in the vicinity  in this case, the Science Museum or the Natural History Museum  and flag them on a map, giving their exact coordinates, including Web sites. ... The Shelbourne, a Marriott Renaissance Hotel in Dublin, reopened last month after closing for two years of renovations. The 182-year-old property now features a lobby outfitted in Italian marble, stained glass and a new painting by Cian McLoughlin of the actors Barry McGovern and Johnny Murphy (left), who are known for their recent work in Samuel Becketts Waiting for Godot. Restaurants and bars include the Horseshoe Bar, the Saddle Room Restaurant and the No. 27 Bar & Lounge. Nightly rates start at about 365 euros, or about $496 at the rate of $1.36 to the euro, through June, and drop to 285 euros for July and August. (www.theshelbourne.ie). ... Food, wine and golf are the focus of a new program offered to American Express platinum card holders. Called Personal Pursuits, the program offers outings ranging from lunch at the French Laundry in the Napa Valley to a golf tournament in Bermuda. Transportation and lodging are not included unless otherwise specified (www.americanexpress.com/platinum). ... The Pink Beach Club in Bermuda is offering a Culinary Weekend Package through April 30. The three-night package, which starts at $2,600 per person (based on double occupancy) includes a fishing trip, breakfast, afternoon tea, dinner, airport transfers and taxes (www.pinkbeach.com).

title: Who Should Pay for a Broken Skylight?
description: Q After a recent storm, a huge chunk of ice fell off the roof of a commercial building that is next to mine and overlooks my deck and skylight. The ice broke the skylight. My co-op lease says that the windows are my responsibility. The owners of the building next door say they are not responsible. Is that true?

title: Torture Chamber
description: David Griffith opens his meditation on the Abu Ghraib photographs with an epigraph from Flannery OConnors story The Displaced Person: Mrs. Shortley, awaiting the arrival of the Polish refugee family coming to work on the farm where shes employed, recalls newsreel footage of death camp victims: Before you could realize that it was real and take it into your head, the picture changed and a hollow-sounding voice was saying, Time marches on!  Mrs. Shortleys view of the displaced Guizac family is, in fact, prejudiced by the fleeting images shes seen on the screen: she fears they will have imported such murderous ways from Europe, like rats with typhoid fleas.

title: Printed Matter
description: One of the most astonishing pieces shown at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair last May was a folding stool by the designer Patrick Jouin called OneShot. Its spiral shape and creamy white polyamide material were beautiful in themselves. But thats not what made it so amazing. The stool, including all of its 36 hinges and 12 moving legs, is all of a single piece. And even more amazing still, it was neither carved nor molded. It was printed.

title: Random Drug Tests for High Schoolers; Hospital Sets Its Sights on Pennsylvania (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Prague
description: The 36 Hours column last Sunday about Prague referred incorrectly to service on Czech Airlines from New York airports to Prague. The airline flies nonstop from Kennedy Airport only. It does not fly from Newark.

description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Greene, Nissim Oron
description: Nancy Ellen Greene and Nissim Oron are to be married today. Rabbi Meir Soloveichik is to officiate at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York.

title: Heather Boushey, Todd Tucker
description: Heather Marie Boushey and Todd Nathaniel Tucker were married yesterday. The bridegrooms father, the Rev. Dr. Robert Dale Tucker, a Southern Baptist minister, officiated in a nondenominational ceremony at Cafe Flora in Seattle.

title: Suicidal Secrets
description: I am a schoolteacher. A teenager told me about her thoughts of suicide. To offer her hope, I told her that I had contemplated suicide decades ago and survived with the support of friends and doctors. She told her therapist about this  fine with me  who told our school social worker, who criticized my conduct to our principal, perhaps endangering my job. Im not the therapists patient, but was it ethical of her to discuss me?  name withheld, Conn.

title: American Leage West
description: A.L: East | Central | West | N.L.: East | Central | West

title: New Bar Codes Can Talk With Your Cellphone
description: It sounds like something straight out of a futuristic film: House hunters, driving past a for-sale sign, stop and point their cellphone at the sign. With a click, their cellphone screen displays the asking price, the number of bedrooms and baths and lots of other details about the house.

title: Emily Fisher, Dennis Moore
description: Emily Lorraine Fisher and Dennis Stephen Moore are to be married today at Jackson Square Park in New Orleans. The Rev. Dr. Jerry K. Schwehm, a Presbyterian minister, is to perform the ceremony.

title: New York Noodletown
description: Historians may quibble, but spend any time with the jokers and memory thieves who while away their days eating and talking about Chinese food in New York City, and youll hear someone say it was Shorty Tang who cooked the best cold sesame noodles Manhattan ever tasted.

title: Interest-Rate Roulette: A Game of Many Dangers
description: WHEN it comes to interest rates, some investors seem to think that they can have their cake and eat it, too. They want rate cuts  and they want a vibrant economy this year.

title: 'The Appearance of Effortlessness'
description: Following are excerpts from Times interviews with other "amazing" seniors at Newton North High School.

title: Retirement Homes Go High-Rise and Urban
description: WHEN Dick Harris retired 16 years ago, he and his wife, Lynne, moved first to Sarasota, Fla., and then to a sprawling retirement community 45 minutes from Chicago. Now the couple expect to adopt a different kind of senior lifestyle: they plan to move next year to the Clare at Water Tower, a luxury high-rise under construction in the Gold Coast neighborhood of Chicago.

title: Lela Moore and Steven Ryan
description: Lela Miller Moore, a daughter of Jean G. Moore and Hugh J. Moore Jr. of Chattanooga, Tenn., and Steven Ryan, a son of Eileen M. Valinoti and Steven J. Valinoti, both of Levittown, N.Y., were married yesterday evening. Thomas Ryan, the bridegrooms uncle and a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Hudson Theater in Manhattan.

title: Op-Chart: A Tale of Two Suburbs
description: WHEN local taxes grow so burdensome that they drive away the young professionals that businesses need, a region loses competitiveness. Thats a threat now facing Long Island.

title: No Welcome Wagon for a Rehab Center
description: When St. Josephs Hospital of Hillcrest, Queens, prepared to close in 2004 after 42 years of existence, the neighborhood and the employees rallied hard to save it. But St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers nevertheless sold the hospital building for $10 million, citing poor financial performance, and the 4,000 petition signatures and the rallies could not keep the brick tower open.

title: Out of Francos Shadow
description: At the Corte Ingls bookstore in downtown Madrid, the divisions in Spanish society can be found spread out across the new-releases tables and propped up in the window displays. In the last few years, Spanish publishing houses have been putting out a stream of titles revisiting the Spanish Civil War and the four decades of dictatorship that followed. These books have revealed a spectrum of historical research and revisionism, from thinly veiled pro-Franco dissertations like The Myths of the Spanish Civil War to titles like The Enormous Mutilation: The Destruction of Spanish Universities Under Francoism.

title: While Finely Aged, Oporto Cultivates a Taste for the New
description: MENTION Oporto, and one tends to think of well-fed British gents puffing postprandial cigars as they sip garnet-colored wine and solve the world's problems before rejoining the ladies in the drawing room. But what that word  the name of Portugal's second-largest city  ought to conjure is an almost impossibly picturesque town of Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque buildings cascading down a steep gorge to the banks of the Douro River just before its waters reach the blue Atlantic.

title: For Auto or Horse Enthusiasts
description: A NEW plan for one of the prime development sites in Suffolk County proposes a $1 billion entertainment and hotel project, as well as hundreds of residences that would use an innovative form of vacation-home ownership.

title: Despite Spitzers Election Mandate, First Budget Proves a Humbling One
description: ALBANY, Sunday, April 1  During his campaign for governor, Eliot Spitzer spoke frequently about the need to rein in state spending and to change the way New Yorks government works. Day 1, Everything Changes was his oft-repeated slogan.

title: The New Owners Get the Once-Over
description: IF youre thinking of living in Stuyvesant Town or Peter Cooper Village, those immense, green-windowpaned collections of 1940s brick apartment towers near the East River, known for their neighborliness and affordability  well, just because they recently changed hands in a $5.4 billion transaction doesnt mean they are changing at heart. At least, not very rapidly.

title: Feeding the Cancer Machine
description: Annapolis, Md.

title: Of Rocks and Apples and the Disappearance of 20-Game Winners
description: The question was about 20-game winners, and Rich Donnelly wanted to talk about apple fights.

title: Feelings Are Mixed Regarding Bondss Chase
description: More than a third of Americans want Barry Bonds to break the career record for home runs and almost as many hope he fails, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Gators Top Bruins in Rematch and Earn Right to Another
description: ATLANTA, March 31  Three Florida underclassmen bypassed the N.B.A. draft and put millions of dollars on hold so they might get a chance to play one college basketball game.

title: Stacey Mariash and Rmy Bertin
description: Stacey Bernadette Mariash and Rmy Adrien Georges Bertin were married last evening at the Central Park Boathouse in New York. Jonathan Hefter, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: The Good Mother
description: We are living in  take your pick  a glorious renaissance era of writing about parenthood or a bathetic swamp of diaper blogs. On the nonfiction shelves, polemicists spar over whether mothers should stay at home; chick-lit heroines strap on pink Baby Bjrns; and online, mothers and fathers document milestones with a fervor formerly reserved for fanatical birders. Meanwhile, anthologies of personal essays cover every subject from miscarriage to only children.

title: The Little Lords of the Ring
description: TUCKED behind a neutral corner near the press barricade sits Al Roth, an older gentleman, attentive to each bout, but with no fierce allegiance to any one matchup. Not an ex-fighter himself, Mr. Roth is a boxing fan of more than 40 years. White-haired, he wears a red vest and saggy green corduroys, the nap worn off across the thighs where he rests his arms. Leaning forward, he clasps a newspaper rolled up in one fist, like a man on his way from the bookie to the track. He travels into the city for the Golden Gloves tournament each year from Mamaroneck, and sits way up front.

title: National League East
description: A.L: East | Central | West | N.L.: East | Central | West

title: Giuliani Says Ties to Kerik May Hurt Him With Voters
description: MANALAPAN, Fla., March 31  Buffeted once again by bad news about his disgraced former police commissioner, Rudolph W. Giuliani said Saturday that he should have looked more closely into the commissioners background and acknowledged that it may cause voters to question his judgment.

title: For Blue-Collar Musicians, a Factory All Their Own
description: BAYONNE

title: Deadline Nears for TV Negotiations
description: Major League Baseball continued to negotiate yesterday with cable operators and the Dish Network in an effort to persuade them to carry the Extra Innings package of out-of-market games and the fledgling MLB Channel.

title: Italian Scandal: The Sweet Life Turns Sour
description: ROME, March 31  On the list of Italys countless contributions to Western civilization is the phenomenon of the paparazzi. Immortalized in Fellinis La Dolce Vita, the Italian character Paparazzo was originally romanticized as a photographer of the stars who was more mischievous than hazardous, a necessary appendage to Roman glamour.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday in T: Travel, about hat making in Montappone, Italy, misspelled the name of a museum there. It is Museo del Cappello (Museum of the Hat), not Capello (Hair). Also, the headline rendered incorrectly the plural of hat. It is cappelli  not capelli, which is the plural of hair.

title: A Head for Figures
description: Barnaby Barford spends most of his working life in a shed in his East London garden, surrounded by cheap figurines  the banal ones you get for pennies from charity shops or on eBay, the ones with nothing to recommend them, the ones that nobody wants. Well, nobody except Barford. In the hands of this 29-year-old product designer, ceramicist, teacher and artist, these found objects are transformed into one-off collectors pieces  works of art, really, sold in London through the David Gill Galleries or at the major design fairs.

title: Can Poor People Be Taught to Save?
description: Why cant poor people save money? The answer might appear blindingly obvious: They dont earn enough. But that explanation didnt satisfy Stephen Brobeck  it was too easy, too defeatist. As the executive director of the Consumer Federation of America for nearly three decades, he has watched people increase debt and decrease savings. The trend disturbs him. While Brobeck thinks that everyone should save more, he is particularly concerned about the poorest Americans. About nine million households have effectively no financial assets  nothing to fall back on for emergencies or retirement. And it was with them in mind that Brobeck embarked on a social experiment to change peoples savings habits.

title: PBS Buys a Lot of Arguments for $20 Million
description: LAST August, Richard N. Perle, the former Bush administration adviser who advocated strongly for the Iraq invasion, found himself surrounded by antiwar demonstrators on the Mall in front of the Washington Monument.

title: Turkish Delights, With Appetizers the Best
description: NEW JERSEY has a few urban neighborhoods so transformed and enlivened by immigrant cultures that entering them is like going abroad. Drive down Bergenline Avenue in Union City or into the Ironbound in Newark, and you may be tempted to reach for your passport. A different language appears in the windows, the energy level kicks up a notch, and even the weather seems to change.

title: Emily Bahr, Jason Granet
description: Emily Jane Bahr, a daughter of Ilene Bahr and Dr. Gerald Bahr of New York, was married last evening to Jason Sloan Granet, the son of Andrea Granet and Stephen Granet of North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Robert Summers officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

title: Poor Nations to Bear Brunt as World Warms
description: The worlds richest countries, which have contributed by far the most to the atmospheric changes linked to global warming, are already spending billions of dollars to limit their own risks from its worst consequences, like drought and rising seas.

title: Alissa Smith, Derek Schaible
description: Alissa Gery Smith, a daughter of Mary-Jo Smith and Ford Smith of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Derek Justin Schaible, a son of Marcie Schaible of Waukesha, Wis., and Arlyn Schaible of Lakeville, Minn. The Rev. Harry J. Erdlen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in St. Pauls Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

title: If the Vehicle Is Round, Wheels Are Unnecessary
description: IT looks like a Volkswagen Microbus, the sort that starred in last years film Little Miss Sunshine, somehow squeezed into a sphere six feet in diameter.

title: The Week on Long Island
description: Few Voters Show Up to Elect Two Democrats

title: The Faces of Tariq Ramadan
description: For some years now, the Swiss philosopher and Muslim intellectual Tariq Ramadan has been saying he wants to reconcile Islamic tradition with Western democracy, conservative religious values with liberal political ones. But not everyone finds him credible. And being the grandson of Hassan al-Banna, the founder of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt, doesnt help. Skeptics say he is a radical in disguise  a Janus-faced rhetorician who presents a moderates face to Western audiences and a reactionarys to Muslim ones.

title: No Separate but Equal in Marriage
description: This past Monday, Connecticut debated the meaning of marriage before a packed Judiciary Committee hearing that lasted until nearly midnight. More than 50 people testified for and against a bill that, if passed, would make Connecticut the second state after Massachusetts to allow same-sex couples to marry. The bill takes a step beyond the states current law, passed in 2005, that extended civil unions to gay couples.

title: Acapulco Reinforces Spring Break Security
description: Until 2006, the biggest problem tourists normally faced in Acapulco were aggressive beggars and hawkers peddling their wares. During the last year, however, violent crime  much of it believed to be drug-related  has threatened to curb the booming tourism industry in one of Mexicos most visited resorts.

title: A Double Standard for the Triply Wed
description: WHEN Judith Giuliani recently revealed that she had been married not twice but three times, her disclosure caused a stir. In all the public accounts about her relationship with Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor, why had it never come out that she had an earlier, four-year marriage before she wed Bruce Nathan, long assumed to be her first husband?

title: Going Up, Getting Grumpy
description: The flier appeared on the elevator wall about a month ago. I cannot sleep with you listening to music and stomping back and forth all night, it read. Please be respectful or, at a minimum, buy a rug. The writer was not shy  the apartment number was typed at the top in bold letters.

title: Truth in College Lending
description: By rights, a student who calls a college financial aid office should reach one of the colleges aid officers. But that is often not the case, as a front-page article by Jonathan Glater of The Times pointed out last week. Many colleges route student calls to representatives of loan companies who pretend to work for the college but who actually have a vested interest in selling the costliest possible loans.

title: Mexico City:  NaCo Miscelnea
description: Unlike Mexican food or film, Mexican fashion is only beginning to attract the notice of American hipsters. But the nascent trend can already claim its first breakout brand: Mexico City-based NaCo.

title: Yes, Retirement Still Seems an  Impossible Dream
description: Its time for another retirement study to make you feel anxious and afraid. These studies always come to one conclusion: No matter how much you are saving for retirement, it isnt enough, and you should save much, much more. So youd better stop spending money on anything related to your present life.

title: Going Down Gambling
description: The art of losing, as Elizabeth Bishop put it in her poem One Art, isnt hard to master. It is something that is cumulatively learned  door keys here, a lover there  until one day you can be counted an expert. Of course, the joke is that we have no control over what we lose, or when, or how, because if we did, we would probably choose not to lose it in the first place.

title: For Girls, Its Be Yourself, and Be Perfect, Too
description: NEWTON, Mass., March 31  To anyone who knows 17-year-old Esther Mobley, one of the best students at one of the best public high schools in the country, it is absurd to think she doesnt measure up. But Esther herself is quick to set the record straight.

title: Correction: The Event and the Image, Fused by the Viewfinder
description: A picture last Sunday with an article about The Event, an exhibition of photographs at the Jeu de Paume in Paris, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of the French aviator Hubert Latham was by Lllustration, not Socit de Photographie.

title: Daughters of the Dinah, Unbound
description: Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Victoria Van Hyning, Alyn Still
description: Victoria Anne Van Hyning, the daughter of Marlene C. Piturro and Howard M. Van Hyning of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alyn Timothy Still, a son of Helen Still and Michael T. Still of Wrexham, Wales. Jon Berry, a member of the ministry and counsel committee of the Purchase Friends Meeting in Purchase, N.Y., oversaw the Quaker ceremony there.

title: In Matchup of Big Men, Ohio States Oden Comes Out the Ultimate Winner
description: ATLANTA, March 31  Some day, perhaps in the N.B.A., fans will be able to see and enjoy the much-anticipated one-on-one matchup between Greg Oden and Roy Hibbert, two 7-foot centers. Might it be like the legendary battles between Bill Russell and Wilt Chamberlain, or something different?

title: For Chatting Face to Face, Webcams With a Clearer View
description: SEEING people on screen while talking with them by phone has its advantages, but consumers have been slow to take to the video technology and its often grainy images. Now, better cameras and video services may change all that.

title: A New Frontier for Chinese Art
description: SEVEN years ago, the pre-eminent Chinese artist Ai Weiwei made a bold move to the outskirts of Beijing. In an area called Caochangdi Village, by the Fifth Ring Road in the citys northeast, he designed a compound for himself, some friends and a gallery called China Art Archives and Warehouse. For a while, they were left alone.

title: Listing Service Dream in Disarray
description: AT the dawn of the Internet age, the real estate brokers in Manhattan got together and said: Let us work together to provide a single place on the Web where buyers can see all the apartments we have to sell. We will help our sellers sell faster, and earn our commissions faster, they said.

title: The Bounty
description: I blame my parents. They never threw food away. I thought it was perfectly normal for a mother to say: Its starting to go bad. You have to eat it.

title: The End of the Line as Detroit Workers Know It
description: Detroit

title: More on Traveling With Pets, at 30,000 Feet
description: Thank you for your column on traveling with pets (March 4). But please expose the pet travel racket within Europe. We are seeking quotes for taking our Labrador from London to Nice in July or August. British Airways directs us to World Cargo (www.baworldcargo.com), which cites an oligopoly of four accredited shippers.

title: Whats the One Thing Big Business and the Left Have in Common?
description: The struggle to establish universal health insurance, dormant for more than a decade, is back. Should it actually succeed over the next few years, historians may trace that triumph, at least in part, to a news conference on Capitol Hill  and to a most unusual figure who participated in it. The event took place in early December, just after the Democrats won back control of Congress. title: Designs for Living
description: I confess that when I heard the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum had scheduled an exhibition titled Design for the Other 90%, I thought it was a survey of the welcome trend of retailers marketing stylish furnishings at prices that freelance journalists like me could afford. What a solipsist! The 90 % refers to the staggering 5.8 billion of the worlds population whose lives are defined not by rarefied yearnings but by the pangs of need. The kinds of products they require for survival have been ignored by most designers  until now. Whats so exciting about this show is that it marks a sea change, says Cynthia E. Smith, who curated the exhibition, which opens May 4. It surveys the trend toward more socially responsible design. A whole range of nonprofits and for-profits, community groups and international organizations are getting involved to create products that can lift the marginalized out of a subsistence existence. Smith cites a treadle pump from International Development Enterprises (IDE) that farmers can use to lift water from deep below ground. IDE re-engineered the traditional pump out of inexpensive metal cylinders and a bamboo frame so that those earning as little as a dollar a day could afford to buy it. Since it was introduced some 20 years ago, nearly 1.25 million have been sold in Asia and Africa, enabling farmers to extend their growing season and often double their incomes. And its not just groups that are making a difference  individuals are, too. Wanting to find a way for subsistence farmers to refrigerate their food, a Nigerian teacher, Mohammed Bah Abba, looked to African pottery for a solution. His earthenware pot-in-pot system draws on principles of physics used by the ancient Egyptians for food preservation. Now farmers can preserve enough produce to sell at market. The South African team of P. J. and J. P. S. Hendrikse created the Q-Drum wheel, to simplify transporting water. By demonstrating how ingenious, sustainable products can transform lives, the exhibit underscores the critical role design has to play in ending world poverty. Its admittedly a bigger notion than those of us with Cassina dreams and Target budgets typically entertain, but surely one we can all embrace.

As Astrid & Veronika opens, a New Zealand writer, Veronika, arrives in a remote Swedish village in flight from a mysterious tragedy. On the surface, she and her new neighbor could hardly be more different: Astrid has spent her whole life in this village, while Veronika has traveled the world; Astrid is a friendless recluse while Veronika wants only to be alone with her work, which has been brought to an unexplained halt. title: Sympathy for the Other
description: How does one regard a good man in a dark time? With joy, obviously, but also with sorrow. Seneca said in one of his letters that you must either hate the world or imitate it, but there are few things in this world so stirring as a man who neither hates it nor imitates it, but in the name of what is best in it resists what is worst in it. Such a man secures hope against illusion, and by example refutes any argument against the plausibility of historical action. It would be too hard to act if decency itself had still to be invented. And yet the uncommonness of such a man casts a long shadow over the faith in eventual justice or eventual peace, because the figure is so lonely against the ground. The good man in a dark time is the unrepresentative man. He has the honor of an anomaly. He marks the distance that still has to be traveled. And how much, after all, can a single individual accomplish, all the uplift notwithstanding? Heroes are not policies.

title: Off the Wall
description: Like the overscaled wallpapers for which she is known, the Australian designer Florence Broadhurst was larger than life. Florence Broadhurst: Her Secret and Extraordinary Lives (Chronicle, $25) charts the career of a woman born to outback obscurity in 1899. In her 20s, she was a nightclub star. By 1927, Broadhurst had moved to London, where, as Madame Pellier, she ran a Bond Street dress shop. After World War II, she returned to Australia with a 10-year-old son and a man who may or may not have been her legal husband, cultivating the persona of a genteel British lady. In 1960, when a tenant  a struggling wallpaper manufacturer  fell behind in rent, she stepped in and began issuing the prints that made her famous, whether or not she actually designed them herself. The final mystery of Broadhursts life is her brutal, still-unsolved murder, perhaps by one of Australias most notorious serial killers, in 1977. In 2002 her patterns were resurrected by Signature Prints to great acclaim. Clearly, Broadhurst deserves another moment in the spotlight. Despite somewhat jejune writing, this beautiful book  covered with one of her patterns and bursting with reproductions of many others  makes an excellent curtain call.

title: Hand-Eye Coordination
description: Since 2002, when Jenna Didier first draped the facade of Materials and Applications  her exhibition space in Silver Lake, Los Angeles  she has hosted a series of increasingly ambitious outdoor installations so eye-catching that neighbors have started complaining about the regular traffic jams out front. This spring, following Bubbles, an inflatable environment of glowing white orbs, M&A is moving in a subtler direction with ukendt/igloo (above), a collaboration with the Danish conceptual artist Anja Franke. Past M&A projects have included the Mylar canopy called Maximilians Schell and Here There Be Monsters!, a bamboo bridge over an interactive water installation. But Frankes vision of a hand-woven textile igloo presented a new challenge: how to continue to push the boundaries of the built environment and peoples imaginations while working within the low-tech, glitz-free realm of crafts. The answer, Didier and her partner, Oliver Hess, have discovered, lies less in ancient basket-weaving techniques or in Buckminster Fullers tensegrity principle (both of which theyve studied in depth) than in the values of community and working with ones hands. I think people wake up and realize they can affect positive change when they start using their hands, says Didier, who notes that their network of volunteers keeps expanding. Whether the goal is changing the world or learning to weave, volunteering is a fun way to spend a Saturday. As Hess points out with a smile, There arent many woven houses in L.A., but theres no reason that we cant at least try.

title: Growing Pains
description: Do you live in a concrete jungle and dream of an Eden of your own making, which you will tend in your spare time on sunny weekends? Do you keep a potted basil plant on the kitchen windowsill and wish that you could grow the lettuce thats on your plate? Do you picture yourself at some time in the distant future lovingly pruning antique rose bushes in riotous bloom or picking peaches from a tree in the backyard of a house that exists only in your dreams? If you answered yes to any of these questions, you may be at risk for Obsessive Gardening Syndrome, a disorder that claims the lives of innumerable Americans each year. Though there is no known cure, prevention is highly effective. Ask your bookseller for a copy of The $64 Tomato: How One Man Nearly Lost His Sanity, Spent a Fortune and Endured an Existential Crisis in the Quest for the Perfect Garden (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill), in which William Alexander documents his own worsening symptoms in hilarious detail.

People admired her before she was ill for the same reasons they admire her now. She comes across as honest, smart and unpretentious  as well as both devoted to and independent of her husband. But we have learned a great deal about the political arena from the hubbub that greeted her decision. For all the lip service Washington pays to valuing political players who are authentic and truthful, it turns out that real, honest-to-God straight talk about matters of life, death and, yes, political ambition, drives some people (to use Katie Courics locution) nuts.

title: Baby Lust
description: Here is a smattering of things I did during the six-year quest to conceive my daughter: interrupt love-making to squirt raw egg whites into myself with a turkey baster (its reputed to abet the feminine fluid that speeds sperm to egg); substitute two teaspoons of Robitussin for my morning coffee (its main ingredient thins and loosens mucous in the lungs, and although there is no actual proof, its thought to work similar juju farther south); down ovulation-stimulating pills that triggered fits of rage; inject myself with the urine of postmenopausal Italian nuns (the original source of some fertility drugs, though its hard to imagine how the goods are gathered); chug unidentifiable herbal potions that tasted like garden mulch; squander what would have been the college fund on long-shot in-vitro-fertilization treatments; imperil my marriage.

(Step into one of their bike lanes, and a Dane might sniff at you; but in three days of walking the expanse of Copenhagen, I never once heard a car horn.) title: Bringing Back the Sunday Dinner
description: IT is no surprise that Sunday has become the new Saturday, a day of errands and chores, of tidying up odds and ends of work or sitting at the desk for hours at a time, with maybe a little exercise and television thrown in. I am surprised, though, that this bothers me. Like many baby boomers, I have spent a great deal of energy cultivating an unsentimental and even antitraditional attitude. But I just cant seem to shake my fond memories of a quiet day in Queens, with few cars on the streets, everything except maybe a drugstore and a restaurant or two closed, and three generations of my family laughing over the remains of a Sunday dinner cooked by my grandmother.

It should gently prepare you for the startling pastel rays of dawn  since the sunrise, when youve been out all night, always seems to come as a surprise, like a pursuer you thought you had eluded. A drink at that hour should usher in thoughts of, say, pancakes.

title: The Meadowlands
description: Domein hemelrijk is a private garden of more than 250 acres a half hours drive from Antwerp on the border with the Netherlands. Its name is the merger of the Dutch words for sky and kingdom, and certainly in Belgiums lowlands, where everything is flat and there is no break from the drab neatness of centuries-old tree lines and drainage ditches, you have a different feeling when you see sweeping vistas and irregular lines. Hemelrijk is also the romantic result of the union between the late horticulturists Robert De Belder and his wife, Jelena, who, along with Roberts brother, Georges, created this magical place as well as the better-known public arboretum at nearby Kalmthout.

title: Popular Mechanics
description: When your local nail salon declares its hipness with a festoon of lanterns from an obscure Dutch designer, you know that designer wont remain obscure much longer. Bertjan Pot, 31, is part of the new generation of Dutch innovators  Hella Jongerius and Marcel Wanders are among them  who regard design almost like competitive sport. Pots Random Light (seen here in his Schiedam, Netherlands, studio among variations on the lights open-weave theme) has rapidly taken its place in the canon of perfect signifiers of Dutch design genius. But unlike Wanderss seminal Knotted Chair or Jongeriuss embroidered vase, the Random Light, which Pot originally crafted by wrapping fiberglass strands soaked in resin around a huge party balloon, has sold about 15,000 copies since its debut in 2002, making Pot a commercial success as well. It started as a handmade experiment, says Pot, who spent three years perfecting the production technique. (The Random is now machine-wrought.) It has come into the public consciousness much more than I could have ever expected.

title: Playing Havoc With the Hellebores
description: APRIL FOOLS DAY dawned early  months early  for Connecticut gardeners. Some of us in the southwestern part of the state can date it to late December, when a few foolhardy forsythia blossoms, seduced by the unusual warmth, blazed a wanton yellow amid the jolly evergreen swags and wreaths  and promptly shriveled. Just after New Years, others noticed befuddled bulbs  daffodils, hyacinths, narcissuses  sending up tenuous shoots that now protrude, cracked and yellowed, like rows of neglected teeth. Lenten roses  hellebores, named for their normal pre-Easter bloom time  blasphemed against nature with unseemly display at Christmas.

And the Albion, which is showing the Cartoon Chairs, will have an exhibition in June of the Campanas new Trans-Plastic series, an optical extravaganza that promises to make Mickey et al. look like, well, kids stuff.
