title: 36 Hours in Orlando, Fla.
description: ORLANDO may be America's most misunderstood city. Although it's best known as the home of Walt Disney World, Universal Orlando and other theme parks, those attractions have little to do with the brick-lined streets, mossy parks or natural lakefronts that make up the city's historic downtown. (Disney, in fact, isn't even inside the city limits.) This other Orlando is often overlooked by tourists, but it offers worthy thrills of a different sort, from Asian dining in lively Little Vietnam to an evening of improvisational comedy. It's also an Orlando with a sense of history, pride (as a hub for Florida's citrus industry) and urban sophistication, as evidenced by everything from an organic teahouse to a vibrant gay scene.

title: Paperback Row
description: AMERICA AT THE CROSSROADS: Democracy, Power, and the Neoconservative Legacy, by Francis Fukuyama. (Yale University, $15. ) This scathing polemic indicts the Bush administrations war in Iraq and the role that neoconservative ideas  concerning unilateralism and preventive war  played in shaping its outcome. Fukuyama, whose 1992 book The End of History and the Last Man was hailed as a classic neoconservative text on the end of the cold war, traces the origins and key principles of neoconservatism. He also proposes a post-Bush foreign policy, realistic Wilsonianism, which discredits forceful regime change and favors economic development and the creation of social capital, or soft power. Among the neoconservative intellectuals, Fukuyama has surely been the most imaginative, the most playful in his thinking and the most ambitious, Paul Berman wrote here.

description: Anne Dodge had lost count of all the doctors she had seen over the past fifteen years. She guessed it was close to thirty. Now, two days after Christmas 2004, on a surprisingly mild morning, she was driving again into Boston to see yet another physician. Her primary care doctor had opposed the trip, arguing that Anne's problems were so long-standing and so well defined that this consultation would be useless. But her boyfriend had stubbornly insisted. Anne told herself the visit would mollify her boyfriend and she would be back home by midday.

title: Chance and Circumstance: Twenty Years With Cage and Cunningham
description: One day, a year or two after I'd stopped performing with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, I received a phone call from Maxine Groffsky, who had left her position as the Paris editor of the Paris Review and had returned to New York. "I want to be your agent," she said. Astonished, I asked, "For what?" "Your book." "What book" "The one John Cage says you're going to write." "Well, maybe, someday." "No, now." I resisted; she persisted. So I wrote a sample chapter and Maxine presented it to Bob Gottlieb, the editor in chief at Knopf, and suddenly I found myself committed to the daunting project of writing a book. That was over thirty years ago. The writing and the not writing took that long.

title: A Good War Is Hard to Find
description: THE DAY THE BOMBS STARTED FALLING ON BAGHDAD my Notre Dame jacket, a dark blue satin jacket with NOTRE DAME stitched across the front and a pugilistic leprachaun on the sleeve-my most prized possession-had been stolen out of my locker. They also stole a package of Hostess Sno-Balls and a peanut butter and honey sandwich-snacks that I would eat after school to give me energy for wrestling practice. I weighed 110 pounds and wrestled in the 112 pound weight class.

title: Once Upon a Country: A Palestinian Life
description: When I was a child it seemed that everywhere I went I came across traces of my family's history in Jerusalem. My father once told me that we Nusseibehs came from a long line of thieves. All family dynasties, he explained with an expression between earnestness and jest, can trace their histories back to some act of brigandage. I think he said this because of the pride Arabs often take in their ancient roots. You have to live in the present, Father lectured to me over and over when I was a child. Whereas I never pinned down precisely who the thieves were, I had no trouble finding old gravestones with names chiseled into the eroded limestone that in my imagination magically connected me up with 1,300 years of forbears, all the way back to the hot sands of Arabia.

title: Why the French Don't Like Headscarves
description: IN EARLY 2004, the French government passed a law prohibiting from public schools any clothing that clearly indicated a pupil's religious affiliation. Although worded in a religion-neutral way, everyone understood the law to be aimed at keeping Muslim girls from wearing headscarves in school. The law was based on recommendations issued in late 2003 by two prestigious commissions, one formed by the Parliament, the other appointed by President Jacques Chirac (the Stasi Commission). Their hearings and the media coverage of the issue depicted grave dangers to French society and its tradition of secularism (lacit) presented by Islamic radicalism, a trend toward "communalism," and the oppression of women in the poor suburbs. Although some Muslims objected that the proposed law would violate their right to express religious beliefs and many observers doubted that a law banning scarves would seriously address the severe problems of integration in French society, the two commissions voted with near-unanimity for the law, and the measure passed with large majorities in the National Assembly and in the Senate. It went into effect in September 2004.

title: Ghosts of Spain
description: Sitting in the late autumn sun, in what had once been the Generalsimo's plaza, it was not difficult to imagine what had happened here, sixty-six years earlier. The same crooked, clay-tiled roofs ran down to the wood-balustraded balconies of the buildings around the square. One or two houses were new, and the town hall had been renovated, but the church was, of course, still there. The square remained open on one side, looking out over roof-tops and fields.

title: Stacked: A 32DDD Reports from the Front
description: One spring day in Central Park I crossed paths with a generously endowed woman wearing a T-shirt with an arrow and the words "My face is up here, pal." I longed to give her a sisterly hug. I restrained myself not only because we were strangers to each other, but also because I feared the mayhem that might result from such a collision of boobs. Still I looked her right in her lovely, underappreciated eyes and offered a nod of solidarity. All too often my own face plays a supporting role to the main attraction, my 32DDD breasts.

title: The Cheaters Guide to Baseball
description: Is cheating wrong? Should you even read this book? Isn't this topic so controversial and heated that you should purchase several copies of this book in case one or more suddenly combust? Or, if you're of a moralistic bent, so that you'll always have a copy to throw on the next bonfire?

title: Music and Dance
description: Carolyn Browns rich account of 20 years of dancing with Merce Cunningham and John Cage, Chance and Circumstance, provides an insiders portrait of two pioneering modernists who ventured into uncharted territory in the realm of dance and music. Brown vividly evokes the thrills and struggles inherent to true liberation, and describes the courage requisite to artistic inventiveness. She is a rare memoirist who focuses on her mentors physical and spiritual leaps rather than on herself; her guileless revelations illuminate what went right and wrong in Cunningham and Cages personal dealings, as well as in their fight for survival.

title: Traveling With Pets, at 30,000 Feet
description: Thank you for your column on traveling with pets (March 4). But please expose the pet travel racket within Europe. We are seeking quotes for taking our Labrador from London to Nice in July or August. British Airways directs us to World Cargo (www.baworldcargo.com), which cites an oligopoly of four accredited shippers.

title: Why We Travel
description: "You got a real sense that it was once a cultural epicenter for that part of India. On another level, youre just blown away by the scenery and the integration of the archaeology with the geology."

title: Neo Geo
description: Get out your beanbag chair: The 1970s are back in original designs and new pieces that graphically evoke the era.

title: One Thompsons In
description: Former Wisconsin Gov. Tommy Thompson announced today that he, too, will join the G.O.P. field of contenders for the partys nomination.

title: The Ledes Hiatus
description: Loyal readers of the Lede may have noticed that the blog hasnt been its normally robust self in recent days. Since the departure of Tom Zeller Jr., the editors have been plotting a new path; but the process has taken a bit longer than we had hoped.

title: Campaign Cash: Clinton at $26 Million
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential primary campaign said today that it had raised $26 million during the first quarter, more than three times as much as the previous record for this stage of a Democratic primary.

title: Jump Shots, Rebounds and . . . Slip Jig?
description: Turns out I didnt have to bribe my wife and daughter to let me watch Saturdays games. My daughter had a dance out late Saturday afternoon, and by the time she and her mother came home, there were fewer than seven minutes left in the Ohio State-Georgetown game. Greg Odens free throw gave Ohio State a 7-point lead, my daughter did her homework and I pleaded for Jeff Green to please take a shot.

title: Campaign Cash: An Update
description: One more update on the presidential campaign fundraising front: John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat, raised about $14 million in the first quarter, his campaign reported this afternoon. That is about twice what Mr. Edwards raised when he ran for president in 2004, though it puts him well behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who raised $26 million, and almost certainly behind Senator Barack Obama, who is not announcing his number today. Mr. Edwards deputy campaign manager, Jonathan Prince, said the campaign was satisfied with the showing and that it exceeded the campaigns own budget expectations. (By the way: You can expect EVERY candidate to say first-quarter receipts beat their own internal budget predictions; thats why they keep them internal).

title: When Will We Panic Over Climate Change?
description: Women collect water from a communal pump on the plains at the foot of Mount Kilimanjaro  the mountains ice cap is shrinking. Finbarr OReilly, Reuters

title: I Is for Immortality
description: This is Alice Mathias somehow magically reporting for a not-student-run news organization from the trenches of my senior spring at Dartmouth College. For the past four years, I have been studying in a safe, town-sized bubble in the New Hampshire wilderness, and on June 10th this bubble is scheduled to burst, at which point, along with (most of) the class of 2007, I will be catapulted into adulthood.

title: Opening Day Observations
description: My football allegiances are to the Philadelphia Eagles, though, considering my recent travel itinerary, I suspect you could call me a Saints fan: St. Lucie to St. Petersburg to St. Louis, and let me say, its great being here at Busch Stadium for opening day. All the seats here are red, although with seemingly everyone wearing the same color, its tough to tell whos standing or sitting.

title: Another Sort of Diplomacy
description: This article was written by the author last week while on tour with the Michael Gordon Band.

title: Another Sort of Diplomacy
description: [This article was written by the author last week while on tour with the Michael Gordon Band.]I'm writing from Sicily, where I just arrived with my ensemble, the Michael Gordon Band. We're playing a concert at the Etna Festival in Catania. As I'm sitting here in this beautiful Italian hotel, I'm thinking about how lucky I am to be able to travel around the world playing music. There's no way that this could be possible without the weighty investment that most Western and Asian countries make in the arts. Those of us who perform and compose semi-popular music - that is, experimental, art, classical and jazz - cannot survive in the free market like rock, urban and country musicians do. Although there is a fan base for these more esoteric types of music that numbers in the millions, it just doesn't add up to the large CD sales and stadium tours that the popular music stars enjoy.

title: A Night for Breathing Fire Into Gestures of Flamenco
description: Its easy, when confronted with one souped-up, watered-down spectacle after another, to despair of ever seeing good-quality flamenco on a concert stage. All the steam machines, lurid lighting and thematic programming in the world cant make up for the absence of honesty and heat.

title: Karma and Scoreboard Favor Mets in Their Opener
description: ST. LOUIS, April 1  The Mets opened their season here of all places, the site of a few miserable memories last October, and let the record show that when the Cardinals world championship banner was raised at 6:44 p.m. Sunday night, they did not avert their eyes or start sobbing. The Cardinals march to the title, which passed through Shea Stadium, happened more than five months ago. As far as the Mets are concerned, there are no cliffhangers, no ellipses, nothing to be continued.

title: Phelps Matches Spitz With Seventh Gold Medal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, April 1  There were other powerful images on the last day of these world championships: the bedraggled, besieged Ian Thorpe walking into an overstuffed news conference with the digital cameras hissing; and Katie Hoff crying in the pool after breaking the final world record of the meet.

title: From Odens Shadow, Conley Takes Charge
description: ATLANTA, April 1  For most of their time together as teammates in middle school, high school and college, Mike Conley Jr. has been the coaster under the tall glass of drink named Greg Oden. That has been O.K. with Conley, but not O.K. with Oden.

title: Tennessee Erases a 12-Point Deficit in Defeating U.N.C.
description: CLEVELAND, April 1  What was expected to be an elegant, high-scoring national semifinal game between Tennessee and North Carolina quickly became an artless grind Sunday night at the womens Final Four.

title: Warners Digital Watchdog Widens War on Pirates
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1  Hollywood studios spend millions every year trying to get people to watch their movies. At Warner Brothers Entertainment, Darcy Antonellis is trying to get them to stop watching  illegally, that is.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wedged Amid African Crises, a Neglected Nation Suffers
description: OTAH, Central African Republic, March 30  Every year, Robert Dourmadji would set aside some of his grain for seed, resisting the temptation to feed his wife and seven children with it even when times got lean as the planting season approached.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Near Deal to Buy First Data
description: First Data, one of the nations largest credit-card processing companies, is near a deal to be sold for nearly $27 billion to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, according to people involved in the transaction. The deal for First Data, which controls the STAR payment network, is expected to be announced this morning.

title: Abe Coleman, Wrestler Known as Hebrew Hercules, Dies at 101
description: Abe Coleman, a squat powerhouse of a professional wrestler, billed by promoters as the Hebrew Hercules and known to opponents by the two-footed kick he copied from kangaroos, died Wednesday in New York. He was 101, probably making him the oldest professional wrestler, according to wrestling publications.

title: Milledges Bat Turns Up Heat on Ice-Cold Green
description: ST. LOUIS, April 1  Almost as a rule, the Mets resist comparing their young, homegrown players with the games elite. But this time, General Manager Omar Minaya said, they were justified.

title: A Budget With a Breakthrough in Child Health Care
description: For two months, the high-volume battle over Gov. Eliot Spitzers cuts to hospitals and nursing homes has obscured a significant piece of his health care plan, a major expansion of state-subsidized health insurance, especially for middle-class children, which sailed with little debate into the state budget approved yesterday.

title: Ohio State vs. Florida, a New Rivalry
description: ATLANTA, April 1  The Florida Gators and the Ohio State Buckeyes have built a rivalry in 100 days.

title: New Cassel: Off-Duty Police Officer Shot
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was shot in the hand during a possible attempted robbery early yesterday, the Nassau County police said. The 25-year-old officer, whom the Nassau police did not identify, was treated at Nassau University Medical Center and then released. At 4 a.m., the off-duty officer was sitting in his car, which was parked on Kinkel Street between Prospect Avenue and Broadway, when a man with a handgun approached. A fight ensued, and the officer drove off after he was wounded in the left hand, the police said. The assailant was still at large last night.

title: For Floridas Athletic Director, a Bumpy Ride to the Top
description: ATLANTA, April 1  During the N.C.A.A. championship game between Ohio State and Florida on Monday night at the Georgia Dome, Gators Athletic Director Jeremy Foley said that he would touch his good-luck charm frequently.

title: 28 Arrested in Florida Online Sex Sting
description: Law enforcement officials in Polk County Fla., arrested 28 men for soliciting sex with minors after setting up a weeklong sting operation in a suburban home where undercover officers communicated with the suspected predators over the Internet.

title: Brooklyn: Attempted-Larceny Charges
description: Officers arrested two people yesterday morning while investigating two previous thefts at a church in Kensington, the police said. Carmen Sierra, 42, and her brother Juan Sierra, 43, were charged with attempted grand larceny and disruption of a religious service. The police said the two tried to steal money collected during services at the Holy Innocents Church, at East 17th Street near Beverley Road, shortly before 11 a.m. Ms. Sierra tried to break into a room while her brother served as a lookout, the police said. An undisclosed amount was stolen from the church on March 25, and an attempted burglary occurred on March 18, the police said. Mr. and Ms. Sierra have not been charged in connection with the previous crimes, the police said.

title: Tsunami Swamps South Pacific Islands
description: SINGAPORE, April 2  A powerful undersea earthquake in the South Pacific early today sent huge tides rolling across low-lying areas of the Solomon Islands, inundating entire villages and causing an unknown number of deaths, local officials reported.

title: Gaza Protest Demands Action on Kindapped Journalist
description: GAZA CITY, April 2  More than a hundred Palestinian journalists and other civilians conducted a sit-in outside the Palestinian prime ministers office here today, demanding greater efforts to find and free Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent in Gaza, who was abducted three weeks ago. Local and international journalists mounted a similar rally in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

title: Steinbrenner Consortium Backs Out of Horse Racing Bid
description: A group that includes the family of the Yankees principal owner, George Steinbrenner, has withdrawn from Excelsior Racing, which is among four bidders to run racing at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga, it was announced yesterday by the family spokesman, Howard Rubenstein.

title: Ford Motor Drops Euro RSCG Worldwide
description: The only incumbent agency taking part in a review for the creative account of the Volvo division of the Ford Motor Company has been eliminated. Spending for the assignment, now handled by various agencies in regional markets, was estimated at $150 million to $200 million a year.

title: A Misfired Memo Shows Close Tabs on Reporter
description: Journalists have an uneasy awareness that public relations professionals keep tabs on them, the better to hone the way they pitch and spin ideas for articles. And while the extent of this practice normally is not aired in public, it was last week when Wired magazine posted a long memo about one of its reporters that had been sent by e-mail to him by Microsoft, accidentally.

title: Americas Cup Fleet Is Unveiled in Valencia
description: VALENCIA, Spain, April 1  With a coy curtsy, known as dropping the skirts, the Americas Cup fleet unveiled its boats Sunday in a quaint ritual leading up to a quadrennial sailing clash of high-tech vessels and billionaires, gritty sailors and global corporate giants.

title: Pushing a New Writer Upstream
description: CHICAGO  At a table with a half-dozen enraptured Borders executives in a private room at the French bistro Mon Am Gabi, between sips of Ctes du Rhne, the fledgling British novelist Steven Hall began telling the Nicole Kidman story.

title: Post-Punk Makes Home in the Palace
description: Its a perfect match. Kele Okereke has questions. For instance: Is it wrong to want rewarding? To want more than is given to you? And the Rev. Frederick Eikerenkoetter, better known as Rev. Ike, has answers. For instance: Life takes from the taker and gives to the giver.

title: A Guaranteed Four Spades, or Maybe Not
description: After reading about the diagramed deal, you might feel it is still April 1. The layout arose during the final of the Blue Ribbon Pairs at the Fall North American Championships in Hawaii last November. It is described by Larry Cohen in the April issue of The Bridge World magazine (bridgeworld.com).

description: For tens of thousands of immigrants, making it to the Ferry Building on Ellis Island was the next-to-last step on a long, arduous journey to America.

title: City to Lose $308 Million in State Aid for Just a Year
description: The states record $120.9 billion budget will leave the city scrambling to replace $308 million in lost aid, the Bloomberg administration said yesterday.

title: Tribune Plans to Sell Chicago Cubs
description: The Chicago Cubs 2007 marketing slogan exclaims, Play Like Theres No Tomorrow! That will be literally true for the Tribune Company, which announced Monday that it would sell the Cubs, its storied subsidiary, later this year as part of the companys overall sale to the Chicago billionaire Sam Zell.

title: Former Met, and Closer, Looper Tries a New Role
description: ST. LOUIS, April 1  Some of the routines of a starting pitcher, the former Met Braden Looper already has down. He knows when to take a pregame shower, when to stop in the trainers room for a rubdown and when to head out to warm up. But the really important stuff  such as what to eat for lunch and where to eat it  he has yet to settle on.

title: New CDs
description: MARTINA MCBRIDE Waking Up Laughing  (RCA/Sony BMG Nashville)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in the special Museums section on Wednesday with an article about the relocation of the Grand Rapids Art Museum in Michigan misstated information about its site. The museum will be in a new building, not in a former federal office building.

title: Iran-Britain Standoff Shows Hints of Easing
description: LONDON, April 2  Iran said Monday that all 15 captured British naval personnel had confessed to intruding illegally into Iranian waters on March 23, when they were seized at gunpoint.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Iraq Town Struggles to Recover After Most Residents Fled
description: SABA AL BOR, Iraq, March 29  It was midafternoon in this dusty, sandstone-colored town, most stores and houses were padlocked and no cars were on the road. In the town center, a group of young men sat in the shade of a plastic tarpaulin, next to a stand with sodas and snacks, and stared phlegmatically at nothing much. The place was eerily quiet.

title: For Stringer, Only One Thing Left to Do
description: Cleveland

title: For Starters, Sturdy Effort and Victory for Glavine
description: ST. LOUIS, April 1  One start, one-tenth of the way closer to his 300th victory. At this rate, Tom Glavine will reach his targeted milestone by the end of May and be back home in Georgia comfortably retired by the Fourth of July. Right?

title: Rutgers Advances to Womens N.C.A.A. Final
description: CLEVELAND, April 1  This would have seemed impossible three months ago, Rutgers having a chance to win the womens N.C.A.A. basketball championship. After a sputtering start, the Scarlet Knights lost access to their locker room, to their university-issued practice gear and, apparently, to any chance of winning a national title.

title: 4 Years Later, Smart Growth Is Still Elusive at Hospital Site
description: WINGDALE, N.Y., March 26  The remains of the state mental hospital languish in this bucolic stretch of the Harlem Valley like a ghost town, an eerie compound of empty dormitories and overgrown fields that was once a community of 10,000 with its own bowling alley, baseball diamond, ice cream shop, fire company, farm and train station two hours north of New York City.

title: Illusory Characters With Startling Stage Presence
description: To the average moviegoer the sight of Eddie Murphy portraying several characters in the same scene is no longer a shock. Such special-effects trickery has become commonplace: a good makeup artist, a few carefully placed cameras, some digital tweaking and presto.

title: Supreme Court Denies Guantnamo Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Supreme Court declined today to hear urgent appeals from two groups of detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. The 45 men sought to challenge the constitutionality of a new law stripping federal judges of the authority to hear challenges to the open-ended confinement of foreign citizens held at the United States naval base in Cuba and designated as enemy combatants.

title: Sports Organizations Try to Limit Online Reporting
description: PARIS, April 1  When the Pan American Games start in Brazil in July, thousands of top athletes will run, wrestle and leap, but they will not be able to indulge in one popular daily exercise: blogging.

title: Jimmie Johnson Edges Jeff Gordon in Martinsville
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 1  Jimmie Johnson rounded the final corner of the final turn of the Goodys Cool Orange 500, took a bump from behind and would not give in as his racecar wiggled and the finish line approached.

title: Shiite Cleric Opposes Return of Baathists in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April 2  The most powerful Shiite cleric in Iraq has rejected an American-backed proposal to allow thousands of former members of Saddam Husseins Baath Party to return to government service, an aide to the cleric said Monday.

title: Stalking Strangers DNA to Fill in the Family Tree
description: They swab the cheeks of strangers and pluck hairs from corpses. They travel hundreds of miles to entice their suspects with an old photograph, or sometimes a free drink. Cooperation is preferred, but not necessarily required to achieve their ends.

title: Olmert Invites Arab Leaders to Hold Talks
description: JERUSALEM, April 1  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel on Sunday invited Arab leaders to join him for talks in a regional peace meeting in Jerusalem.

title: Rangers Avery Saves His Best for Biggest Game of Season
description: When his first shot flew into the Toronto net, Rangers forward Sean Avery pumped his fists with an intensity that stood out, even for him. He skated to the boards and pounded on the glass as the Madison Square Garden crowd roared. His goal came early, tying the score at 1-1 last night, but it set off a spark that pushed the Rangers to their biggest victory of the season.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Thursday about Jim Harrick, the former college basketball coach who is now the head coach in California of the Bakersfield Jam in the N.B.A.s Development League, misstated the name of a competing team in the state. It is the Anaheim Arsenal, not the Admirals.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on March 9 about Reading First, the Bush administrations program for low-income children, referred imprecisely to the involvement of G. Reid Lyon in the National Reading Panel, which recommended effective ways to teach reading. Dr. Lyon, a former head of a branch of the National Institutes of Health, advised his former boss, Dr. Duane Alexander, about candidates nominated for the panel. The final selection of members did not rest with Dr. Lyon; the law creating the panel called for Dr. Alexander to make that decision.

title: The Onion Speaks, and Sounds Familiar
description: With the anti-hype that is now mandatory for a perfect 2007 Web debut, the Onion News Network appeared online last week discreetly, almost meekly. The site initially featured only three new videos: one about immigration, one about Condoleezza Rice and one about drafting Civil War re-enactors to fight in Iraq. (They have character histories. They have nicknames for each other.)

title: Partnership Offsets Costs of Video by Fall Out Boy
description: Fans of Fall Out Boy who downloaded Thnks Fr Th Mmrs, the rock bands new video last weekend most likely enjoyed the spectacle of chimpanzees playing filmmakers and mocking the members of the band. But they may have noticed something else: Tag All Nighter, a deodorant body spray aimed at young men, is featured prominently in the video.

title: New Season Brings a Fresh Start for Yankees
description: The 57,478 seats at Yankee Stadium were empty yesterday on a chilly and gray afternoon. But shortly after 1 p.m., the ballpark began to hum with anticipation.

title: Thousands Are Laid Off at Circuit City. Whats New?
description: When executives at Circuit City decided last Wednesday to cut costs by laying off 3,400 of their most experienced salesclerks, they undoubtedly went through a number of calculations: that they could save $250 million over two years; that consumers are inured to bad service; and that the layoffs would be a one-day blip in the news.

title: Some Hospitals Call 911 to Save Their Patients
description: Should a hospital be able to handle a medical emergency?

title: A Law Not to Be Trifled With
description: Dirk Kempthorne must have wondered last week why he ever accepted President Bushs offer to become secretary of the interior. Seven former directors of the National Park Service lambasted a proposal that would allow more than 700 snowmobiles a day in Yellowstone National Park. A former senior auditor provided further evidence that the Minerals Management Service, another part of Mr. Kempthornes empire, had for years failed to collect royalties from big oil companies. And Democrats in the House jumped all over one of his assistant secretaries in the wake of a report that the department was secretly rewriting important regulations governing the Endangered Species Act with an eye to weakening it.

title: Seeking a Car That Gets 100 Miles a Gallon
description: The race is on to develop a commercially viable car that can travel 100 miles on a gallon of gasoline.

title: New Century Files for Bankruptcy
description: Once a highflier in the booming market for making risky mortgage loans, the New Century Financial Corporation filed for bankruptcy court protection today.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A map in the special Museums section on Wednesday that highlighted museum construction projects around the country referred incorrectly to the scope and timing of several of them. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/museums.

description: A PROMOTION scheduled to begin today may prompt hotel guests to exclaim, with apologies to Apocalypse Now, that they love the smell of advertising in the morning.

description: Just as you cant judge a stewed eel by its looks (otherwise who would eat one?), you cant judge a series by its name. Bizarre Foods With Andrew Zimmern, tonight on the Travel Channel, is smarter than its lame title implies, thanks to the charm and intelligence of its host.
