description: Austin, Tex.

title: China Says New U.S. Duty Disrupts Relations
description: HONG KONG, April 1  China has called on the Bush administration to reverse a decision to impose steep duties on Chinese exports of coated paper, state-controlled news media reported during the weekend.

title: Snakelike Charms From the Indian Desert
description: Colors of Rajasthan was what the World Music Institute called the program of Indian folk music and dance that it presented on Friday night at Symphony Space. But its star performer, a Gypsy dancer known in India as Gulabo, had the right idea. For her it was simply Gulabi Sapera & Party. The evening was indeed an ebullient, even raucous party of the sort that might occur at village weddings in the Great Thar Desert area of Rajasthan, in northwest India, where the company originated. Without the relatively restrained and subtler contributions of the troupes musicians, the enterprise could well have gotten out of hand.

title: Our National Debt
description: Washington

title: AirTran Raises Midwest Bid Again
description: AirTran Holdings, the discount airline company, is planning to raise its hostile bid for the Midwest Air Group a third time, to $15 a share, people briefed on the offer said last night. The company plans to announce the new bid today, these people said.

title: Celebrity Preacher in Need of Spin Control
description: Forgive the generalization, but there is simply no time period more accommodating to the historical documentary form than the first four decades of the last century. Photography, sound recording and film were all becoming established, but the technology was still ragged enough that the history looks like history, rather than like last weeks news. Documentaries made of such stuff, with their fluttery video and tentative audio, let you feel the emergence of the modern era.

title: They Call Me Mister Correspondent
description: Larry Wilmore, one of the newer fake reporters on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart, stakes out his comic targets with the glee and democracy of a kid in a candy store.

title: Old Church Becomes Mosque in Uneasy Britain
description: CLITHEROE, England  On a chilly night this winter, this pristine town in some of Britains most untouched countryside voted to allow a former Christian church to become a mosque.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Robert E. Petersen, the chairman of Petersen Publishing, omitted two of the four investors who paid $450 million for the company in 1996. The buyers included James Dunning Jr., who headed the team of investors, and Willis Stein & Partners L.P., a private equity fund based in Chicago. D. Claeys Bahrenburg, former president of Hearst Magazines, and Neal Vitale, former general manager of the Hollywood trade paper Variety, were not the only investors.

title: Former Governor of Wisconsin Sets Sights on the White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Tommy G. Thompson, the former governor of Wisconsin who served as President Bushs secretary of health and human services, said Sunday that he would seek the Republican nomination for president.

title: Angling for a Fight on and Off the Ice
description: In Canada, and in some border cities like Buffalo and Detroit, the most powerful and influential commentator in hockey requires no introduction. He is besieged at airports, restaurants and hotels by autograph seekers. Some people, upon recognizing him, have even pulled their cars to the side of the road to get out and shake his hand.

title: Common Defense
description: The American plan to install the forward edge of its antimissile shield in Poland and the Czech Republic has raised memories of the great cold war struggle over Americas decision to station medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe. Of course, back then the resistance was largely in the streets. This time most of the questioning is coming from within the governments of Germany and France.

title: With Big Names in Tennis Long Gone, a Teenager Fills the Void
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., April 1  The final day of the Sony Ericsson Open had the feel of a V.I.P. room after the last bold-face name slips away from the party. Serena Williams, the four-time womens champion, had left the Crandon Park Tennis Center a day earlier and taken two of her bigger fans, the Miami Heat basketball star Dwyane Wade and the actress Kristin Davis, with her.

title: Pre-Opening Day Jitters for Establishments That Live in Yankee Stadiums Shadow
description: Louie Dituri stood in front of his restaurant, the Yankee Eatery, across River Avenue from Yankee Stadium, on Sunday and ran through a mental checklist of last-minute preparations. His guys were precooking several batches of their famous shish kebabs, and the fresh rolls he ordered were to be delivered this morning. The bar in the back of the place was loaded, and after five days of spring cleaning, each crack and crevice was spotless.

title: Peer-to-Peer Downloaders Gorge on Songs
description: In 2006, the number of households with PCs that downloaded at least one song using free peer-to-peer software, like Limewire or BitTorrent, grew a modest 7.2 percent, reaching 14.9 million, according to figures released by the NPD Group, a market-research firm.

title: California Seeks to Ban Investment in Iran
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 1  It is the kind of political movement that fits handily on a bumper sticker: Divest Iran.

title: Distract and Disenfranchise
description: I have a theory about the Bush administration abuses of power that are now, finally, coming to light. Ultimately, I believe, they were driven by rising income inequality.

title: After Two Years of Work, an Updated Tabernacle
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 1  The Salt Lake Tabernacle, completed in 1867 by the faithful of the fledgling Mormon religion and home of the world-famous choir, reopened over the weekend after a two-year top-to-bottom renovation.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 1, 2007

title: The Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS The main news of the week will be the unemployment report for March (Friday). Other reports will include the Institute for Supply Managements manufacturing index for March (Monday), the institutes service index for March and factory orders for February (Wednesday), and wholesale trade for February and consumer credit for February (Friday).

title: Competition Begins for Public Radio Idol
description: Aspiring pop stars can turn to American Idol; budding screenwriters had Project Greenlight. So where do fledgling public radio hosts turn?

title: A Musical Coalition That Raises the Roof
description: In the 13th century a Malian king, Sundiata, consolidated the Mandinka empire across a swath of West Africa, from what is now Mauritania to the Ivory Coast, and from Senegal to Nigeria. Toumani Diabates Symmetric Orchestra, which played a deep-rooted, tradition-stretching and utterly kinetic concert on Friday night at Zankel Hall, recreates that empire as a modern musical coalition. Age-old patterns and modal melodies rocketed through the songs as Soumaila Kanoute or Mamadou Kouyate sang about topics ranging from love to the desertification of West Africa and the exploitation of African resources. Social commentary met dazzling virtuosity.

title: Quake Hits South Pacific, Setting Off Tsunami
description: SINGAPORE, Monday, April 2  A powerful undersea earthquake struck early Monday morning off the Solomon Islands, sending a tsunami crashing hundreds of yards onshore and setting off tsunami warnings around the South Pacific.

title: Mamma Roma on Love, Life and Acting
description: Fans of the Italian actress Anna Magnani might enjoy her reincarnation onstage at the Arclight Theater, where Theresa Gambacorta is doing a reasonably good imitation in La Magnani!, a one-woman show Ms. Gambacorta wrote. Those not already familiar with and enamored of Magnani, however, may find themselves wondering why anyone would want to resurrect someone so irritating.

title: Inquiry Into Student Loans Is Resolved
description: Citibank, one of the largest providers of student loans, and five universities have agreed to pay a total of $5.2 million to resolve an investigation into their student loan practices, the New York State attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, announced today.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about criticism of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales by federal prosecutors who questioned the firings of eight United States attorneys omitted a reporting credit. Rachel Mosteller contributed from Houston, where Mr. Gonzales was speaking; the article was written from Washington.

title: Real Estate Tycoon Increases Bid for Tribune
description: Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate tycoon, took another step toward winning the auction for the Tribune Company late last night when he agreed to raise his bid at the urging of the company's board, according to people close to the talks.

title: Cellphones for Little Kids? Can We Talk? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Your Normal Court (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats on Monday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK  Time is running short in the season finale as Michael (Wentworth Miller, above with Sarah Wayne Callies) tries to save Lincoln (Dominic Purcell) by using the strategies of Mahone (William Fichtner) against him. Testimony at the trial of Sara (Ms. Callies) proves to be unexpected and possibly deadly. T-Bag (Robert Knepper) and Bellick (Wade Williams) are up to their old tricks, but this time they refuse to give up.

title: 4 G.I.s Among Dead in Iraq; McCain Cites U.S. Progress
description: BAGHDAD, April 1  Mortar attacks, suicide car bombs, roadside bombs, ambushes and gun battles killed at least two dozen people on Sunday, including four American soldiers, the authorities said.

title: Brooklyn: Man Arrested After Stabbing
description: A 29-year-old man was charged with assault in the stabbing of another man outside a Williamsburg restaurant yesterday morning, the police said. The man then fled the scene, right, and tried to blend in with several homeless people to avoid detection, witnesses said. The stabbing occurred shortly before 9 a.m. outside Las Palmera de Mi Pueblo, a restaurant and bar at 347 Broadway near Keap Street. Witnesses said the suspect, Pedro Torres, had been hanging out under the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway before the stabbing, then left and returned about an hour later, followed by the police. They caught the dude over there, where we were standing, said James Cone, 53, who is homeless. We have a crate where we sit. He tried to sit there and hide. The victim, whose name was not released, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center and was in critical condition, the police said.

title: Justices Rule Against Bush Administration on Emissions
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  In one of its most important environmental decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases in automobile emissions.

title: Scottish Cop Isnt Fazed by Protests or Bagpipes
description: Its been 20 years since Ian Rankin started writing about Inspector John Rebus, the lone-wolf Scottish police detective who lives by his own set of rules. Rebus has a preferred way of conducting himself: any way he wants, and too bad if his superiors dont like it. Over time this attitude has brought Rebus exactly nothing, unless you count the satisfaction he takes in settling scores, one criminal miscreant at a time. He is now a year from retirement and not exactly resting on his laurels.

title: Clinton Campaign Shows Fund-Raising Edge
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination said Sunday that it had raised $26 million during the first quarter of this year, about three times as much as the previous record at this stage of a presidential race.

title: What Really Ruined Baseball
description: Atlanta

title: A Deal With the Devil
description: Washington

title: Speculation Is in the Air Over EMI and Apple
description: PARIS, April 1  Relations between Apple Inc. and the EMI Group, once at odds over the trademark rights to the Apple name, the record label of the Beatles, seem to be getting better all the time.

title: For Vancouvers 2010 Olympics, Proprietary Words
description: OTTAWA, April 1  The Winter Olympics are coming to Vancouver in 2010, and Canadas team is boasting that it will own the podium. If a bill before Parliament is passed, the organizers of those games will own something even more rarefied: the trademark on the word winter.

title: In Jamaican Politics, Just About Everything Is Cricket
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 26  Prime Minister Portia Simpson-Miller of Jamaica is not a member of the West Indies cricket team now competing in the World Cup. She neither bats nor bowls for the Windies.

title: Power-Sharing Deal in Ukraine Collapses
description: MOSCOW, April 2  A fragile power-sharing deal in Ukraine collapsed Monday when President Viktor A. Yushchenko ordered the dissolution of Parliament, the base of support for his rival, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, whom the president accused of usurping power. Mr. Yushchenko ordered new elections for May 27, less than eight weeks away.

title: Phelps Ties Record With Seventh Swimming Gold
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, April 1  There were plenty of powerful images on the last day of these world championships: bedraggled, besieged Ian Thorpe walking into an overstuffed news conference with the digital cameras hissing; Katie Hoff crying in the pool after breaking the final world record of the meet; Polands surprise gold medalist Mateusz Sawrymowicz sitting on a lane line and flexing his muscles for his friends and for his country.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Philip Roth Wins Saul Bellow Prize

title: Lacking Big-City Luster, Junior Miss Carves a Niche
description: COLTON, Wash.  The night after millions of people watched a rehabbed, alcoholic Miss USA crown her comely replacement on national television, six teenage girls competed in an alternate universe for the title of Colton-Uniontown Junior Miss.

title: Qaeda Is Seen as Restoring Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  As Al Qaeda rebuilds in Pakistans tribal areas, a new generation of leaders has emerged under Osama bin Laden to cement control over the networks operations, according to American intelligence and counterterrorism officials.

title: U.S. and South Korea in Landmark Trade Deal
description: SEOUL, April 2  The United States and South Korea today struck a landmark bilateral free trade agreement, the United States biggest since the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994 with Canada and Mexico, and its first with a major Asian economy.

title: Crime Drops in Newark, but Murders Are Flat
description: NEWARK, April 1  Mayor Cory A. Booker looked at the police statistics in front of him and let out a relieved sigh. Three months into 2007, overall crime here in New Jerseys largest city had dropped some 40 percent from the previous year. Shootings were down 42 percent, rapes 27 percent.

title: After Darfur, Starting Anew in the Midwest
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind.  Looking at old pictures taken in the desert sand in the Darfur region of Sudan, Fawzia Suliman pointed to one after the other: mother-in-law, sister, sister-in-law, cousin, and so on.

title: School Aid Fight Erupts in Albany as Budget Passes
description: ALBANY, April 1  Lawmakers finished passing an estimated $120.9 billion budget Sunday morning that they had not had time to read and had barely debated. But almost immediately after the final vote, the governors staff and the Legislature began to dispute what was written in the most contentious portion of the budget  education  underscoring the secretive nature of the negotiations that led to thousands of pages of legislation.

title: Taxing Private Equity
description: In the world of private equity, 2 and 20 is a formula for making money. The mavens of the industry  venture capitalists and buyout specialists  generally collect a management fee of 2 percent of the assets they manage and a performance fee equal to 20 percent of any profits. With hundreds of billions of dollars flowing through the 2-and-20 structure, the megabucks pile up quickly.

title: Sign in Idol Audience May Have Skirted Rules
description: People who watch American Idol are accustomed to seeing a muddle of handwritten posters in the studio audience with mawkish messages aimed at the contestants (Marry me Blake) or the judges (Simon U Tiger.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in the special Museums section on Wednesday about hand-held technologies for audio tours in museums misstated the name of a company that develops electronic tours. It is Antenna Audio  not Antenna Audio/Arts Communications Technologies. The article also misstated the executive position that Chris Tellis holds at Antenna Audio. He is vice chairman, not chief executive.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in the special Museums section on Wednesday with an article about campus galleries referred incorrectly to the status of the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive building at the University of California, Berkeley. The university is constructing a new building for the museum; there are no plans to raze the current building, which may be used for other purposes.

title: Crime Intensifies Debate Over Taping of Suspects
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The account, buried in a mountain of documents assembled for a Congressional investigation, describes a decidedly local yet brutal crime: a Navajo man charged with beating his girlfriend nearly to death and then hanging her by a rope outside their Arizona trailer home to make the attack look like a suicide attempt.

title: Hoping to Move Guitar Notations Into the Legal Sunshine
description: IF budding guitarists fail to master Stairway to Heaven in the coming months, they can no longer blame the music publishers.

title: A Winning Audition for Maytag Repairman
description: Maytag is going in another direction to find someone to portray its familiar advertising character.

title: A Salute for His Wounded, a Last Touch for His Dead
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, March 31  In the last moments of his life, Sgt. First Class Benjamin L. Sebban saw the flatbed truck speed into the concertina wire guarding his small Army patrol base near Baquba.

title: Adding Method to Judging Mayhem
description: There are, Dr. Michael H. Stone says, 22 varieties of killers, and he has ranked them in order of evil.

title: U.S. Keeping Pressure on Iran Over Seizure of 15 Britons at Sea
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  The White House on Sunday sought to increase pressure on Iran to return the 15 British sailors and marines it is holding, but took care to defer to Prime Minister Tony Blair, who has emphasized that he is seeking a diplomatic solution.

title: Paul J. Cohen, Mathematics Trailblazer, Dies at 72
description: Paul J. Cohen, a versatile mathematician whose path-breaking work in the field of logic helped resolve a fundamental question of mathematics and won for him the prestigious Fields Medal, died of a lung disease on March 23 in Stanford, Calif. He was 72.

title: M.I.T. Education in Taiwan, Minus the Degree
description: LUCIFER CHU, a 31-year-old from Taipei, Taiwan, is as good an example as any of the shrinking distances between East and West.

title: Young Voices, Freshly Plucked From a French Garden
description: If William Christies fans had their way, his visits to New York would always be to lead a fully staged production of one of the French Baroque operas that he performs with incomparable persuasiveness. But in recent years Mr. Christie has added another arrow to his quiver that is no less important. To ensure a steady supply of singers versed in Baroque style, he started Le Jardin des Voix in 2002. An academy for young singers at the Thtre de Caen in northern France, the program also offers a valedictory tour, which brought this years crop of 10 singers to Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening.

title: Treasury Auctions Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Seductive Machines for City Living
description: In todays Manhattan, there are few better ways to assume the mantle of sophistication than shelling out millions to live in a building designed by a famous architect. The result is a surfeit of architects pumping out emblems of conspicuous consumption.

title: Tick, Tock, or Maybe Tock, Tick
description: I cant think of a conductor who brings more interesting music on his visits to New York City than David Robertson. For years in Europe in the middle of every new-music enterprise imaginable, and now deepening his acquaintance with the standard repertory as music director of the St. Louis Symphony, Mr. Robertson has found ways to keep our minds from wandering.

title: Home Cooking for Pets Is Suddenly Not So Odd
description: A month ago, the thought of preparing home-cooked meals for a dog or cat might have seemed obsessive even for the most devoted pet lovers.

title: A Budget Is Born
description: Details about the passage of the first budget of the Spitzer era:

title: For sale: The home where the queen met her king
description: Rochford

title: Pretty Words, Jane; Would That You Were Too
description: Jane Austen lived in an age when a womans physical attractiveness was, next to her fortune, her greatest asset. Was she attractive or not? What if, to put it bluntly, she became a writer in part because she didnt have the looks to land a husband along the lines of a Mr. Darcy or a Mr. Knightley?

title: Amazing Graceand Talent, and Smarts, and Skills, and
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: In Good Hands
description: Inside Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston, where Dr. Atul Gawande, a surgeon and writer, performs a thyroidectomy.

title: Comedy Makes a Splash
description: "Room Service" was a bit slow on Saturday night at the SoHo Playhouse. That's because the Fire Department, not normally part of the cast of this 1930s comedy, had a role to play.

title: Is there no end in sight?
description: Real estate prices in London continue to be crazy. Is there no end in sight?

title: Google, YouTube and Nerd Logic
description: Googles acquisition of video-sharing site YouTube was driven by a culture of nerd logic, which has slammed the company headfirst into the culture of New Yorks Big Media, Clive Thompson wrote in New York magazine. And, in a development that many had predicted, the deal has made Google the target of a major lawsuit from Viacom, which contends its copyrighted materials are being used without its permission.

title: Data Domain Aims for $100 Million I.P.O.
description: Data Domain, which makes data-storage appliances, filed to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering. The companys backers include venture firms Greylock Partners, New Enterprise Associates and Sutter Hill Ventures.

title: AirTran Raises Midwest Bid Again
description: AirTran Holdings, the discount airline company, is planning to raise its hostile bid for the Midwest Air Group a third time, to $15 a share, people briefed on the offer said Sunday night. The company plans to announce the new bid Monday, these people said.

title: AT&T Weighs Bid for Italian Telecom Company Stake
description: AT&T said on Sunday that it was in negotiations to buy a major stake in Italys largest telecommunications company, Telecom Italia. The proposal, which expires at the end of April, would give AT&T a one-third stake in Telecom Italias holding company, Olimpia, but only if a Mexican wireless company America Movil buys an equal stake. AT&T, based in San Antonio, is an 8 percent owner of America Movil.

title: Chipmaker Xponent Gets $23 Million
description: California-based Xponent Photonics raised $23 million in a series 3 round with American River Ventures leading the charge. American River Ventures put up a $5 million stake while Xponents previous investors, including El Dorado Ventures, Arcturus Capital and the Samsung Group put up the rest. Xponent makes fast, small semiconductor chips using new optical technology.

title: Sequoia Capital Backs Financier for Indian Entrepreneurs
description: SKS Microfinance, a fast-growing Indian company that provides financing for entrepeneurs, has received an $11.5 million injection with Sequoia Capital putting up most of the funds. Sequoia, which has made such savvy previous investments as those in Google, Yahoo and YouTube, was joined in the round by Unitus Equity Fund, Vinod Khosla, Ravi Reddy, Odyssey Capital and prior investor Sidbi.

title: Landmark Theatres Raise Curtain on Philadelphia Market
description: Landmark Theatres has accquired the Ritz movie house chain in Philadelphia, marking an important step for the independent exhibitor. Landmark said Philadelphia was the only one of the top 10 American markets in which it was previously not present.

title: Winners and Losers in a Changing Climate
Jefferies Names Lead Healthcare Banker in Europe
description: The investment bank Jefferies said Monday that it had hired Ronald Openshaw to direct its European healthcare investment unit. Mr. Openshaw, who will be based in London, was previously chief financial officer at Asterand, a biotechnology company.

title: The Rise of the Super V.C. Angels
description: A new breed of wealthy investor is changing the way startups raise capital. Business Week took a look at a startup, Jaxtr, which makes software for routing calls from blogs to cell phones, and the unusual arrangement it made for its first round of financing.

title: Carlyle Takes 49 Percent of Chinese Steel Company
description: The Carlyle Group announced on Friday that it would invest $80 million for a 49 percent stake in Chinas Yangzhou Chengde Steel Tube Company. Yangzhou Chengde makes large-diameter seamless steel pipes and Carlyles investment will help the company to expand its business both domestically and abroad. The investment comes from Carlyle Asia Partners II, a $1.8 billion fund that makes control and strategic minority investments in Asia outside Japan.

title: Tata Takes Stake in Bumi Mines
description: Indias Tata Power announced this weekend that it is planning to take a 30 percent stake in coal mines owned by the Indonesian energy giant PT Bumi Resources for about $1.3 billion. Although Bumi failed to raise $3.2 billion through a share sale last year, there were at least six bidders vying for the coal companies this time around.

title: NBC and Citadel Increase Ion Bid
description: NBC Universal and the hedge fund Citadel Investment Group have increased their takeover bid for Ion Media Networks in an attempt to appease a disgruntled investor group. That group, which includes AIG and Gradient Partners, were upset over the original bid, which they saw as short-changing preferred shareholders.

title: A $12 Billion Start for I.P.O.s in 2007
description: In the first quarter of the year, initial public offerings have raised about $12 billion, 18 percent more than in the comparable period last year. The hedge fund manager Fortress Investment Group was the biggest first day earner with a pop of 67 percent at its opening and is the second-richest offering to open this year with a purse of $634 million.

title: Whitney Withdraws Herbalife Offer
description: J.H. Whitney will withdraw its $2.7 billion offer for the nutritional and weight-loss supplement makerHerbalife, the group said Friday. Its offer was rejected and the group may sell the roughly 25 percent of Herbalife it currently owns or could even buy more shares.

title: L.S.E. Opens Talks with Dubai Exchange
description: The London Stock Exchange has held talks with the Dubai International Financial Exchange about forging a strategic alliance and the possible acquisition of cross-shareholdings. According to the Guardian, sources who were not named confirmed that the London exchange is one of six parties who, according to Dubai officials, have expressed an interest in acquiring a stake in the exchange.

title: French Trucker Mulls Buying Britains Eddie Stobart
description: Norbert Dentressangle of France is considering the acquisition of a British trucking company, Eddie Stobart, the Guardian reported. The French outfit intends to expand its British operations and has identified Eddie Stobart as a potential takeover target.

title: Australian Credit Rating Agency Accepts Buyout Bid
description: An Australian credit checking company, Veda Advantage, has approved a buyout bid of 814 million ($656 million) Australian dollars from a private equity consortium of Pacific Equity Partners and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity, lifting its shares more than 7 percent. Allco Equity Partners, which has a 17.3 percent stake in Veda, has agreed to support the deal subject to a significant change in market conditions and in the absence of a superior offer, said Reuters.

title: Blackstone I.P.O. May Test Unusual Tax Treatment
description: As the Blackstone Group considers holding a $4 billion public offering, the private equity firms unusual structure as a master limited partnership could leave room for the Internal Revenue Service to challenge its tax-law assumptions, some analysts and academics told Reuters.

title: To Win Alliance Boots, K.K.R. May Need More Honey
description: Celesio, owner of Lloyds Pharmacy, has emerged as a third potential bidder for Britains Alliance Boots. Celesio would be in competition with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina, the deputy executive chairman of Alliance, who have already announced a $19.7 billion bid for Alliance, a chain of health and beauty stores.

title: Barclays Would Slash Jobs at ABN Amro, Report Says
description: Barclays is planning to make cost cuts of more than 3 billion pounds in its proposed merger with ABN Amro, the Dutch bank. The move will likely lead to the loss of hundreds of jobs at ABN Amros investment banking operations in London, the Telegraph reported.

title: Altadis Is Said to Reject Imperial Tobaccos Revised Bid
description: The board of Altadis is preparing to reject a revised bid from Imperial Tobacco, its British rival, that could come as early as this week, the Telegraph reported. Altadis, a Franco-Spanish tobacco group, is being courted by a number of private equity groups, a development that is thought to be behind the boards decision to reject Imperials bid.

title: Big Banks Said to Seek New York Real Estate
description: J.P. Morgan Chase, Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch are each in early talks with New York real-estate developers about building new trading floors in Manhattan, Bloomberg News reported, citing undisclosed sources. J.P. Morgans talks, with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, related to plans for a building in downtown Manhattan that mighgt be as tall as 57 stories, Bloomberg said.

title: Picking the Next Public Hedge Fund
description: Since the wild success of the Fortress Investment Groups initial public offering, which has minted five new billionaires, Wall Street has been buzzing about who will be the next hedge fund to go public. According to Fortune, the latest crop of potential offerings could come from Avenue Capital, Perry Capital and the Citadel Investment Group, which has already staged a bond offering.

title: Frances Sarkozy Attacks Hedge Funds as Speculative Capital
description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the rightwing candidate in the French presidential race, joined the growing chorus of European voices criticizing hedge funds, the Financial Times reported Monday. Speaking at a television debate on Sunday, Mr. Sarkozy attacked what he called speculative capitalism, citing hedge funds in particular: these aggressive funds  that buy up a company, sell it off in pieces, sack 25 per cent of the staff in the meantime, collect 25 per cent profit and create zero wealth. He added: I dont want a speculative capitalism. I want a capitalism that creates riches.

title: Did Community Pay Too a High Price for Triad?
description: Though Community Health Systems could soon boast of becoming the nations largest publicly traded hospital chain when it closes its $5.1 billion offer for Triad Hospitals, TheStreet.com says that the company may soon regret it. To achieve that lofty post, the sites Melissa Davis writes, the efficiency-minded Community is buying a hospital chain known for making generous investments to lure patients in competitive markets.

title: Carlyle to Hire Coca-Colas Top Asia Executive
description: The Carlyle Group is expected to announce on Monday the hiring of Coca-Colas most senior executive in Asia to spearhead regional investments across consumer-related businesses. The recruitment of the executive, Patrick Siewert, Coca-Colas chief operating officer for Asia-Pacific, is the second such hiring in recent weeks by the buyout firm and highlights the maturing of private equity in Asia.

title: S.E.C. Loosens Up With April Foolishness
description: Showing a rare flash of humor, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued a press release on executive pay disclosure quoting spokeswoman April Fuhrst and economist Anita Moore-Profit. In the release, the top market regulator in the United States sets out new rules on corproate pay and perks that Ms. Fuhrst said would reveal a treasure trove of titillating information, The Financial Times reported.

title: Xerox to Buy Global Imaging for $1.5 Billion
description: Xerox said on Monday it would acquire the office technology products provider Global Imaging Systems for $1.5 billion to expand its reach in the small and mid-sized business markets. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., said the deal values Global Imaging at $29 a share, a premium of almost a 50 percent to its closing price Friday of $19.50. Global Imaging shares rose more than 46 percent in pre-market trade.

title: Tribune Accepts Zell Bid, Plans to Sell Chicago Cubs
description: Sam Zell, the flamboyant Chicago real estate tycoon, who has never run a newspaper, has won the battle of the billionaires for Tribune, which said it accepted his $8.2 billion takeover offer after he matched a bid from Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad.

title: TXU Does Not Expect Other Suitors
description: TXU said on Monday that it has not received a competing bid to the $32 billion takeover offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group, and its financial advisers do not expect it to receive one. The power company, which agreed in February to the buyout, said it had signed confidentiality agreements with nine groups as part of the 50 day go-shop agreement with its buyers allowing it to pursue alternative transactions.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the coming auction of a 1729 Stradivarius at Christie's in Manhattan, which is allowing some patrons to try out the violin, referred imprecisely to the musical piece that one patron, Albert Cheng, played. It was the Bach Sonata No. 1 in G minor, not a Bach concerto.

title: Hedge Funds Now Dominate Junk-Grade Lenders, Study Finds
description: Three-quarters of loans to junk-rated companies in the United States are now provided by hedge funds and other non-banks, according to a new report on the leveraged loan market. The Financial Times said that the study highlights the speed with which non-traditional investors are taking over from banks as lenders and changing the way loans are made and traded  a trend that has taken hold in Europe.

title: Kohlberg Kravis to Buy First Data in $29 Billion Deal
description: First Data, one of the nations largest credit-card processing companies, said early Monday it had agreed to be acquired for $29 billion by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. The transaction is among the 10 largest buyouts ever. Kohlberg Kravis will pay $34 a share in cash for First Data, which controls the STAR payment network. The sale price represents a 26 percent premium to First Datas closing share price Friday.

title: Dubai Aerospace Announces Deal for 2 Carlyle Companies
description: Dubai Aerospace will buy Standard Aero Holdings and Piedmont/Hawthorne Holdings from the Carlyle Group for $1.8 billion, Standard Aero said on Monday in a regulatory filing. It said $1.034 billion of the total purchase price will be allocated to the purchase of Standard Aero.

title: Cash for Your Land!
description: While Alison was searching for a new architect who wouldnt break her heart, I had a thought. What if we just sold our small piece of dirt, banked the money and reconsidered this whole building-the-dream-house thing, which was turning out to be harder than I expected.

title: Free-Trade Fumble
description: [F]ree-traders have as much to fear from the Republicans who have been running the show in Washington as they do from congressional Democrats, writes business journalist Daniel Gross on his personal blog. Whether it was the Karl Rove-inspired steel tariffs of the first term, the persistence of absurd agricultural subsidies, or the general lack of interest in the ways in which the heightened insecurity surrounding jobs, incomes, and saps the support for free trade, or the general ability to convince foreign governments to see things our way, this administration hasnt done the cause of free trade a whole lot of good.

title: At Last, a 50-50 Shot
description: In researching a story I wrote for Play, the New York Times quarterly sports magazine, I talked to a gaggle of statisticians whose primary goal  other than putting together expensive algorithms designed specifically to make us all feel stupid  was to figure out the proper way to fill out an NCAA Tournament pool sheet. Most of these men are not only not experts in the field of college basketball, they mostly dont know anything about the game at all. Their expertise is numbers, not hoops.

title: Tribune Accepts Real Estate Magnates Bid
description: Sam Zell, a flamboyant Chicago real estate tycoon who has never run a newspaper, has won the battle of the billionaires for the Tribune Company, edging out a rival bid from Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad late last night.

title: Currys 2007 Predictions
description: The first time I walked into the dugout at Yankee Stadium in 2007 was a little past noon on Sunday. Before I could even sit down, a Yankees employee asked me how I thought the Yankees would do this season.

title: Then and Now: Walton and Noah
description: Sometimes things just swirl into clarity as if a camera lens is suddenly twisted into sharp focus. It was like that here at the Final Four yesterday when someone asked Joakim Noah of Florida about Bill Walton, who played for U.C.L.A. more than three decades ago.

title: Web Measurement Firm ComScore to Go Public
description: ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering. Backed by the venture firm Accel Partners, which owns a 27 percent stake, comScore said it plans to use the proceeds for working capital, capital expenditures and possibly for acquisitions. ComScore, which competes with measurement firms such as NetRatings and Hitwise, reported $66.3 million in revenue in 2006. It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.

title: Dollars for Democrats
description: The Hotlines Marc Ambinder thinks Hillary Clintons record-breaking $26 million haul for the first quarter of 2007 isnt as impressive as it seems at first glance. So  a good number? Yes, but really, not so much, Ambinder writes at Hotlines On Call blog. He explains:

title: 2008: On the Road This Week
description: With Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton setting the bar high  raising a reported $26 million in the first quarter of the 2008 race, her campaign and those of other senators hit the road this week while they are untethered to Congressional duties. (Theyre in recess.)

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Metropolitan Editor Joe Sexton
description: Joe Sexton, the metropolitan editor, answered reader questions about coverage of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut from April 2 through April 6, 2007.

title: Tancredos Platform: Immigration
description: DES MOINES  The field of Republican presidential hopefuls has just grown by one.

title: Gators Repeat as National Champions
description: With an emphatic and definitive victory over Ohio State, the Florida Gators left one final mark for their legacy as one of the great teams in college basketball.

title: Bernie Checks In
description: About three hours before the scheduled first pitch today, Joe Torre took a phone call in his office: Bernie Williams was on the line.

title: Subprime Mortgage Giant New Century Files for Bankruptcy
description: Once a highflier in the booming market for making risky mortgage loans, New Century Financial tumbled to earth Monday as it filed for bankruptcy. In the largest bankruptcy to date in the subprime arena, New Century listed liabilities of more than $100 million in its Chapter 11 filing with the federal bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del.

title: More Law Firms Crowd into Private Equity Deals
description: Another day, another 11-digit buyout deal.

title: When Tech Support is Outsourced  and Common Sense is Dead
description: And now, another exciting installment from the world of tech supportin this case, Dells (surprise!). It was sent to me by reader Jack E., and its subtitle could well be, When Tech Support is Outsourcedand Common Sense is Dead.

title: Campaign Cash: Romney, Giuliani
description: Former Governor Mitt Romney of Massachusetts and former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York announced this morning that they had raised eye-popping sums in the first quarter of the Republican presidential primary race  more than $20 million for Mr. Romney and $15 million for Mr. Giuliani.

title: Talking About the Citys Middle Class
description: At least three potential candidates for mayor in 2009  the Bronx Borough President, Adolfo Carrin Jr., City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Representative Anthony D. Weiner  are participating in a conference today on The American Dream in the Big Apple: Is New York City Still a Middle-Class Town?

title: Finding the Next Data Processing Buyout
description: Does Kohlberg Kravis Roberts planned $29 billion acquisition of First Data, one of the biggest credit-card payment processors, signal a field ripe for dealmaking? Adam Frisch, an analyst with UBS, on Monday suggested some other payment-processors that might also be good candidates for a leveraged buyout. Among them were Global Payments and Ceridian.

title: Midwest Air Urges Shareholders to Delay Decision on AirTran Bid
description: The Midwest Air Groups board asked shareholders on Monday to hold off on responding to AirTran Holdings revised bid for the airline. In a statement, the board said it would review the new offer of $15 ashare in cash and stock, and would make a recommendation to shareholders by April 13.

title: Murcer Is Back as Baseball Begins in the Bronx
description: When the doors of the elevator lobby open on the Loge level of Yankee Stadium, the first thing you see is a giant photo of Bernie Williams holding the 2000 World Series trophy at Shea Stadium. In the corner of the photo, holding a microphone and beaming as widely as Williams, is Bobby Murcer.

title: Starwood C.E.O.s Ouster Sparks Buyout Rumors
description: The ouster of Steven Heyer as chief executive of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide came as a surprise to analysts, who said that the companys strategy was sound. Of course, the news also prompted many to consider whether Starwood was a viable buyout candidate.

title: Id Rather Have Lots of Breast Milk Than a Million Melons, or, the Two Americas
description: Is America really divided along cultural lines?

title: Honoring Cory Lidle
description: Moments after Cory Lidles widow and son threw out the games first pitches, the image of late Yankee pitcher came walking out from the dugout and into the tunnel by the teams locker room.

title: Ask the Metro Editor
description: We know Empire Zone readers have a lot of questions about metro news coverage in The Times. Now theres an opportunity to pose them directly to the metropolitan editor, Joe Sexton.

title: The First Hour, If Not the Finest
description: A timeline of the first hour of the Yankees season, beginning with Carl Pavanos first pitch (a ball) at 1:10 p.m. YDT (thats Yankee Daylight Time, according to the big clock on the scoreboard.)

title: Russian Banks I.P.O. Could Reach $6 Billion
description: Vneshtorgbank, Russias second-biggest bank, could raise up to $6 billion when it makes its debut share offering with listings in Moscow and London next month. The state-owned bank plans to come to the market with an offering of 22 to 23 percent of its shares in May. Russias Economic Development and Trade Minister, German Gref, has said the bank could raise between $3.5 billion and $4.6 billion, while the bank has indicated it wants to raise between $4 billion and $6 billion.

title: Campaign Cash: McCains Numbers
description: It was an announcement that could make ones head spin. The campaign of Senator John McCain, once considered the clear front runner for the 2008 Republican presidential nomination, said this afternoon that he had raised a disappointing $12.5 million in the first quarter.

title: Bloomberg to Veto Metal-Bat Ban
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today that he intends to veto a City Council bill that would prohibit the use of metal bats in high school baseball games. The decision to veto the bill is the latest salvo in a long-running dispute that has divided youth baseball leagues, coaches, players and fans.Industry groups had hired lobbying and public relations firms to oppose the bill, while parents of players severely injured by balls hit off metal bats gave tearful testimony in support of it.

title: Campaign Cash Comparisons: McCain Falters
description: For all the parsing of fund-raising numbers that has been going on over the past 24 hours  should Hillary Rodham Clinton have raised more than $26 million? How did Mitt Romney come from nowhere to raise more than $20 million?  a first-quarter fund-raising report came out today that defied the effort of even the best political operative to spin it as anything but very bad news.

title: Why Live Near the Office?
description: In the age of the imperial chief executive, where a history of failure does not keep someone from getting another top job, some bosses think they should not be forced to actually live in the area where the company is located. They see no reason why their families should be uprooted.

title: Helping Shakira  Or Volunteering in Pakistan
description: For readers who want to help Shakira Parveen, the Pakistani woman in Tuesdays column who was pimped by her husband, the best route would be to send money through Mukhtar Mai and her aid organization. Mukhtar can pass on assistance and in any case is looking after people like Shakira.

title: Its a Profit Deal
description: Needing relief from medieval churches and cutesy cafes on a trip to Prague a few years back (O.K., and a tax break), I paid a call on the Prague Stock Exchange, tucked in a blocky, Soviet-style building off the main drag. I climbed a few flights of poorly lit stairs and entered a dour, dusty-musty office. I didnt expect John Thain clapping with happy C.E.O.s at the opening bell, but heck, this place might as well have been a D.M.V. I started pining for stained-glass windows again. Nonetheless, I learned more in the next 20 minutes about how the world works than I had in the last 20 years sweating on Wall Street as an analyst and running a hedge fund.

title: Wall Street Rakes It In
description: A Wall Street trade group put out combined profit statistics for the industry today, and they are impressive. The Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association says securities firms had combined pretax profits last year of $33.1 billion, up 88 percent from the prior year, and finally breaking the record they set in 2000 of $31.6 billion.

title: Tick Tock
description: Times running out to get in your applications for Win A Trip. Our team is hard at work going through the applications that have already been submitted. Needless to say, weve received some very interesting appeals.

title: The Expanding Empire of Funkmaster Flex
description: Flex, as in Funkmaster Flex, could describe the brand created by the man who began as a hip hop D.J. at Hot 97 in New York, before becoming a TV star, before applying his FMF logo to Lugz shoes and other products.

title: The Week Ahead
description: International Herald Tribune managing editor Alison Smale looks ahead at the events occurring worldwide this week.

title: Ohio State Depends on Lewiss Shooting
description: There seems to be general agreement that Florida is favored to beat Ohio State for the N.C.A.A. championship tonight in the Georgia Dome and the Buckeyes will have less of a chance for an upset if guard Ron Lewis has another performance like he did on Saturday.

title: Hoops Withdrawal
description: Tipoff here at the Georgia Dome is about two hours away. Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel has already taken his seat in the front row of section 107. The CBS crews are making their final adjustments, and the on-air talent is scrambling around in front of The Brackets court-side perch doing some final preparation.

title: Noah and Horford Vs. Oden
description: Some rosters for the Florida Gators list the 6-foot-10 Al Horford as the center and the 6-11 Joakim Noah as a forward. Other rosters reverse the positions. Still others list both of these juniors as center-forwards.

title: Championship or Coronation?
description: Theres a strong feeling in the media and amongst coaches consulted by The Bracket that things could get ugly here at the Georgia Dome tonight. The ESPN analyst and former St. Johns coach Fran Fraschilla, who is doing the international feed at the Final Four, (They love me in Iceland, Fraschilla joked) said he thinks that this Florida team will be remembered as one of the all-time greats in the history of college basketball.

title: A Klong at Grant Thornton
description: Grant Thornton, the auditing firm, might have had the belated realization last week that auditing a subprime lender could almost be as risky as financing one. In any case, letters dated Tuesday, March 27 and disclosed today announced that the firm was resigning as auditor of Fremont General and Accredited Home Lenders, two troubled lenders.

title: Good, Bad and Ugly
description: The Times's Claudia Dreifus talks with Dr. Philip Zimbardo, author of the new book "The Lucifer Effect: Understanding How Good People Turn Evil."

title: Floridas Three Bills
description: There is Billy Donovan, the Florida coach.

title: States of Uncertainty
description: Statewide surveys conducted by Quinnipiac University in three states  Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania  reveal that a significant number of voters do not yet have opinions of Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, and Mitt Romney, the former Republican governor of Massachusetts.

title: Does Oden Have a Big Game in Him?
description: Greg Odens numbers in five N.C.A.A. tournament games are pretty good: 14 points and 8 rebounds per game.

title: Richardson Signs Marijuana Bill
description: Bill Richardson, the New Mexico governor and Democratic presidential candidate, won the admiration  and at least one vote  of a smoky constituency today.

title: The Politics of Baseball
description: Rudolph W. Giulianis most intense week of campaigning to date, traveling in five states over four days, will begin and end in baseball stadiums.

title: Clinton Corners Iowa
description: FORT MADISON, Iowa  We know that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is a longtime Chicago Cubs fan. She has been since she was a little girl, growing up in Park Ridge, Ill.

title: A Wind Among the Reeds
description: Liang Wang of the New York Philharmonic provides a clarion example of the strides musicians from China have made in the realm of Western classical music.

title: Gators May Be Running Away
description: The defending champion Florida Gators hold a 40-29 halftime lead over the Ohio State Buckeyes tonight in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball championship game.

title: A Dreamers Guide to Life
description: Many people can look to a moment in their past and say, That was critical. That moment, or that choice, helped define me. For Caleb Peter Hobart, that moment came after his first year here at Texas A&M when he lost a scholarship.

title: Buckeyes Hanging in There
description: Oden began the second half with six points to raise his total to 17 and Ohio State managed to stay reasonably close to Florida.

title: Florida Too Much for Oden
description: With about five minutes remaining in the N.C.A.A. championship game in the Georgia Dome tonight, Greg Oden of Ohio State made two free throws to cut the Florida Gators lead to six points.

title: Gators Repeat as National Champions
description: ATLANTA, April 2  The Florida Gators left one final, indelible memory as one of the great teams in modern college basketball. Their emphatic 84-75 victory over Ohio State in the national title game Monday night gave them back-to-back championships  the first repeat titlist since Duke in 1991 and 1992  and a claim as arguably the best team since John Woodens dynasty days at U.C.L.A.

title: Holes in His Socks and Shoe Polish on His Suit
description: Clothes dont make the man. At least in my case.

title: For Tribune Buyer, a Storm to the West
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2  The Los Angeles Times was nothing but trouble for the Tribune Company, and it may prove even more of a challenge for its new owner, Samuel Zell.

title: To Help Rikers, City Wants More Prisoners in Brooklyn
description: The citys Department of Correction wants to double the number of prisoners it plans to house at a reopened Brooklyn House of Detention as part of its effort to ease pressure on the aging jail complex on Rikers Island, officials said yesterday.

title: Pelosi Arrives in Damascus for Syria Talks
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 3  Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic Speaker of the House, arrived today in Damascus, the capital of Syria, for a controversial visit that is seen as part of an attempt to sway the Bush administrations policy on Iraq and the larger Middle East.

title: Exercise: Increased Physical Activity Aids Menopausal Women
description: Women who engage in physical activities like walking and yoga may be able to reduce some of the physical and emotional problems that can come with menopause, researchers say.

title: German Suitor Makes Deal With Rivals and Ends Its Bid for Endesa, a Spanish Utility
description: MADRID, April 2  The German energy giant E.On on Monday withdrew its offer of 42.4 billion euros ($56.6 billion) for the Spanish utility Endesa in exchange for a promise from rival bidders to sell it part of Endesas assets, ending one of Europes most arcane takeover battles.

title: Rebel Ambush in Darfur Kills 5 African Union Peacekeepers in Deadliest Attack on the Force
description: DAKAR, Senegal, April 2  Five African Union peacekeepers were killed in a brazen rebel ambush in Darfur less than a mile from their base along Sudans border with Chad on Sunday evening, the African Union said Monday.

title: Blair Sees Iran Standoff at Fairly Critical Stage
description: Prime minister Tony Blair of Britain said today that the release of the 15 captured British sailors could still be secured by diplomatic efforts and that the next two days would be fairly critical in resolving the dispute.

title: Many Lawmakers Go to Iraq, but Few Change Their Minds
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  Visits to Iraq have become a required part of the political wardrobe for lawmakers hoping to be taken seriously in the debate over the future of the war.

title: Safety Foam Has Nascar Drivers Worried
description: Nascar has always listed safety as the primary goal in its efforts to design and develop the Car of Tomorrow for use in the premier Nextel Cup series. But safety has become a concern for some teams since the cars debut at Bristol Motor Speedway on March 25.

title: At Policy Conference, Practice for Mayors Race
description: An academic conference on the state of the middle class became a mini-rehearsal for the 2009 mayors race yesterday, with three probable candidates outlining their priorities  and occasionally jousting  on how to attract and retain moderate-income New Yorkers.

title: Market Strong for Apartments in Manhattan
description: While the national housing market is struggling with rising inventory and weakening home values, the prices and number of apartments selling in Manhattan rose in the first three months of this year, according to data released yesterday by several of New York Citys largest real estate brokerages.

title: Bank Said to Weigh Spinoff of a Unit
description: The Metavante Corporation, a financial processing firm, would become its own company under a deal being completed by its parent company, the Milwaukee bank Marshall & Ilsley, and the private equity firm Warburg Pincus, according to people with knowledge of the plans.

title: Many Diagnoses of Depression May Be Misguided, Study Says
description: About one in four people who appear to be depressed are in fact struggling with the normal mental fallout from a recent emotional blow, like a ruptured marriage, the loss of a job or the collapse of an investment, a new study suggests. To avoid unnecessary diagnoses and stigma, the standard definition of depression should be redrawn to specifically exclude such cases, the authors argue.

title: DNA Boosts Herodotus Account of Etruscans as Migrants to Italy
description: Geneticists have added an edge to a 2,500-year-old debate over the origin of the Etruscans, a people whose brilliant and mysterious civilization dominated northwestern Italy for centuries until the rise of the Roman republic in 510 B.C. Several new findings support a view held by the ancient Greek historian Herodotus  but unpopular among archaeologists  that the Etruscans originally migrated to Italy from the Near East.

title: U.S. Cites Indian Government Agencies in Weapons Conspiracy
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Justice Department, in an indictment disclosed Monday, charged that agencies of the Indian government participated in a conspiracy to sidestep United States export regulations and obtain secret weapons technology from American companies over several years.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about United Black Girls, a group show that closed at the Rush Arts Gallery in Chelsea on Saturday, omitted a co-curator and erroneously included another person as one. Derrick Adams was co-curator with Vanessa C. B. Riding; Courtney J. Martin contributed the introductory essay to the show but did not help put the show together.

title: Pianistic Postcards Spanning Centuries
description: The astounding French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard spent the first part of his adventurous career in the front lines of the musical avant-garde as a mainstay of Pierre Boulezs contemporary-music ensemble in Paris. In the last decade, though, he has branched out, revealing himself to be an elegant and exciting performer of Mozart, Beethoven, Schumann and Ravel.

title: Millions to Be Repaid After College Loan Inquiry
description: Citibank, one of the largest providers of student loans, as well as five universities have agreed to pay $5.2 million to students and the New York State attorney general to resolve an investigation into student loan practices, Andrew M. Cuomo, the attorney general, announced yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Denies Guantnamo Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear urgent appeals from two groups of detainees at Guantnamo Bay. The 45 men sought to challenge the constitutionality of a new law stripping federal judges of the authority to hear challenges to the open-ended confinement of foreign citizens held at the American naval base in Cuba and designated as enemy combatants.

title: Master of Search Seeks Mastery of the TV Dial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2  Following its conquest of YouTube last year, Google is now aiming for a piece of the old-fashioned tube.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,239 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Finding Hope in Knowing the Universal Capacity for Evil
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At Philip G. Zimbardos town house here, the walls are covered with masks from Indonesia, Africa and the Pacific Northwest.

title: Verdict Backing Oil-Royalty Whistle-Blower Is Overturned
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  A federal judge in Denver has overturned a jurys verdict in favor of a whistle-blower at the Interior Department who charged that the Kerr-McGee Corporation cheated the government out of millions of dollars for oil and gas it pumped in publicly owned coastal waters.

title: Plastic Bags, Everywhere (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Rep. Tom Tancredo of Colorado Enters G.O.P. Presidential Race
description: DES MOINES, April 2  Representative Tom Tancredo, a Colorado Republican who has challenged his party to take a stronger stance against illegal immigration, formally declared his presidential candidacy here on Monday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 2, 2007

title: Making Glass From Sugar (but Hold the Sand)
description: Here's one way to make glass: Mix silica sand, soda ash and limestone, heat to about 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit and let cool.

title: Blair Sees Iran Standoff at Fairly Critical Stage
description: LONDON, April 3  Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he was still hoping to secure the release of the 15 British sailors and marines captured by Iran through diplomatic means, and that the next 48 hours would be fairly critical in resolving the dispute.

title: Straddling Puccinis China, From Smaller Roles to Large Spectacle
description: First-time operagoers and long-term fans are drawn to different aspects of opera. First-timers may be pulled in by the excitement of the event: the big music, the spectacle. And in these respects, the Metropolitan Operas Turandot, which returned on Friday night, certainly passes muster. Franco Zeffirellis production delivers a lot of bang (scenery, costumes, number of bodies on stage) for the buck, and in the hands of the ever-impressive conductor Fabio Luisi, the orchestra and the chorus sounded great. And Puccinis music is pretty hot.

title: Newark: New Transit Director
description: New Jersey Transit yesterday named Richard R. Sarles Sr. as its new executive director. Since 2002, Mr. Sarles has managed the agencys $1.3 billion annual capital program and its three light rail lines. Before that, he worked at Amtrak directing the Northeast Corridor High-Speed Rail program. One of Mr. Sarless top priorities will be to oversee New Jersey Transits drive to build a second passenger rail tunnel under the Hudson River. He will also inherit a planned 9.6 percent fare increase, which is expected to go into effect on June 1. Mr. Sarles succeeds George Warrington, who said he was leaving to pursue other opportunities.

title: Did the Red Sea Part? No Evidence, Archaeologists Say
description: NORTH SINAI, Egypt, April 2  On the eve of Passover, the Jewish holiday that celebrates the story of Moses leading the Israelites through this wilderness out of slavery, Egypts chief archaeologist took a bus full of journalists into the North Sinai to showcase his agencys latest discovery.

title: U.S. and South Korea in Landmark Trade Deal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 2  United States and South Korean negotiators struck the worlds largest bilateral free trade agreement on Monday, giving the United States a badly needed lift to its trade policy at home and South Korea a chance to reinvigorate its export economy.

title: Termite Inspector Becomes New Braves Announcer
description: ATLANTA, April 2  Casey Motter, a termite inspector from Peachtree City, Ga., with a touch of a Southern accent, has been named the Atlanta Braves public-address announcer. He will be behind the microphone when the Mets play the Braves at Turner Field on Friday in Atlantas home opener.

title: High School Foes Form a Family at Rutgers
description: Cleveland

title: Different Paths for Womens College Stars
description: CLEVELAND, April 2  If Epiphanny Princes recruiting pitch had been more persuasive, she and Shannon Bobbitt might both be playing in the Rutgers backcourt Tuesday night in the womens national championship game.

title: Training: Ear-Tuning Helps Doctors Distinguish Heart Murmurs
description: Listening to a patients heart is a time-honored way for doctors to detect a variety of health problems. But it is not enough just to put a stethoscope to someones chest, and studies have found that many doctors dont really know how to interpret what they are hearing.

title: On Mideast Trip, U.N. Chief Sought to Expand New Role
description: LONDON, April 2  When Secretary General Ban Ki-moon addressed United Nations peacekeepers standing at attention in their powder-blue berets and military decorations in southern Lebanon on Saturday, he confessed that he had risen only to the lowly rank of corporal in the South Korean Army.

title: U.S. Revokes Stem Cell Patent
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has made a preliminary decision to revoke fundamental patents on human embryonic stem cells that some scientists and consumer groups say have impeded research into a promising new field.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about First Data, the credit-card processing company that is near a deal to be acquired by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, misidentified in some copies the payment network controlled by First Data. It is the STAR network, not the NYCE.

title: Reader Responses
description: The following are excerpts of reader responses to Alina Tugends March 31 Shortcuts column on how busy some people insist on being:

title: Florida Governor Is Hoping to Restore Felon Voting Rights
description: MIAMI, April 2  Hinting that a remarkable turnaround in state policy was near, Gov. Charlie Crist said Monday that he hoped to persuade members of the Florida cabinet this week to end the practice of stripping convicted felons of their right to vote.

title: Suspect in Terror Plot Admits Training in Pakistan and Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy
description: A man accused in an elaborate federal sting operation of plotting to provide training and money to terrorists pleaded guilty yesterday to attending a training camp run by the Pakistani terror group Lashkar-e-Taiba in 2002.

title: Anonymous Is Prominent in Audience of This Play
description: When Lisa Reynolds saw Bill W. and Dr. Bob, the play about the inception of Alcoholics Anonymous in the 1930s that opened Off Broadway recently at New World Stages, something strange happened. After Robert Krakovski, the actor who plays the A.A. co-founder Bill Wilson, delivered the first line of the play  My names Bill W., and Im an alcoholic  most of the audience spontaneously responded, Hi, Bill.

title: Drugs Are in the Water. Does It Matter?
description: Residues of birth control pills, antidepressants, painkillers, shampoos and a host of other compounds are finding their way into the nations waterways, and they have public health and environmental officials in a regulatory quandary.

title: From the Sidelines, a View of the Middle as the Loser
description: Bill Bradley, the former United States senator from New Jersey and former presidential candidate, got out of politics in 2000 after losing the Democratic nomination to Al Gore, and so wrote this book, he says, from outside the political pressure cooker, with no ax to grind and no political ambition to accomplish. And once the reader gets past the logy, platitude-filled opening pages of The New American Story, it becomes clear that Mr. Bradley is not going to pull his punches.

title: Atul Gawande Rocks in the O.R.
description: BOSTON  Just as precious to Dr. Atul Gawande as his loupes  magnifying glasses he wears during surgery  is his iPod, which he carries with him into the operating room and plugs into a little speaker there. On a recent day, when he took out a gallbladder, two thyroids and what was supposed to be a parathyroid gland but maybe wasnt, the playlist included David Bowie, Arcade Fire, Regina Spektor, Aimee Mann, Bruce Springsteen, Elvis Costello, the Decemberists and the Killers.

title: Plans for Revamped G.R.E. Are Abandoned
description: After spending four years and $12 million on research, the Educational Testing Service has abandoned plans to introduce a revamped Graduate Record Exam this fall.

title: Chicagoan Puts Up $315 Million to Win $8.2 Billion Tribune Co.
description: How did a Chicago real estate tycoon win one of the countrys premier media companies  a chain of big-city papers, two dozen television stations and the Chicago Cubs  in a deal valued at $8.2 billion with an investment of only $315 million of his own money?

title: Texas: Young Offenders to Be Freed
description: The new conservator of the troubled Texas Youth Commission, Jay Kimbrough, has identified 552 juveniles due or overdue for release from custody and will begin freeing them tomorrow, said Jim Hurley, a spokesman for the revamped commission. Most will be supervised on parole. The group does not include additional hundreds of the more than 4,000 other confined youths whose cases will be reviewed by a special panel to see why their minimum sentences have been extended. Investigators are reviewing at least 1,200 complaints of sexual abuse and other mistreatment of juveniles in state custody.

title: A Better New York Budget
description: After Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a self-declared steamroller, negotiated his first state budget last weekend, legislators were gleeful. A few even boasted publicly that for all of Mr. Spitzers brash talk, he had been easily flattened by the old hands in Albany.
