description: To the Editor:

title: Another Biomet Executive Resigns After Stock Options Backdating Inquiry
description: Biomet, an orthopedics maker based in Warsaw, Ind., has announced preliminary findings from an internal investigation of options backdating at the company from 1996 through last year. It also said that Daniel P. Hann, its vice president for administration and former general counsel, had resigned.

title: Looking Fit, Murcer Makes a Return to the Yankees Booth
description: Bobby Murcer saw the cream-colored Rolls-Royce that would take him to Yankee Stadium yesterday and uttered a mild protest about vehicular excess to his usual driver.

title: Board Accuses Starbucks of Trying to Block Union
description: The National Labor Relations Board has accused Starbucks of breaking the law 30 times in fighting union activity at four of its coffee shops in Manhattan.

title: Two Star Players, Two Glimpses of the College Experience
description: Atlanta

title: EMI to Drop Digital Locks in Web Sales
description: EMI Group, the British music giant, broke ranks with the music industrys biggest corporations yesterday by announcing a deal to sell songs online through Apples music service without copy protection.

title: 5 Deaths at a V.A. Complex Draw Lawmakers Concern
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2  Five deaths in recent months at the nations largest Veterans Affairs medical complex are troubling and could be a further sign of a system badly in need of closer oversight, two members of Congress said here Monday.

title: Ukrainian Leader Disbands Parliament
description: MOSCOW, April 2  A fragile power-sharing deal in Ukraine collapsed Monday when President Viktor A. Yushchenko ordered the dissolution of Parliament, the base of support for his rival, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, whom the president accused of usurping power. Mr. Yushchenko ordered new elections for May 27, less than eight weeks away.

title: Florida: Arrests in Child Sex Sting
description: Three employees of Disney World were among 28 men arrested and charged with soliciting sex from a child in a four-day sting operation outside Orlando. Sheriff Grady Judd of Polk County said most of the men were arrested after arriving at a house where officers were waiting. The men had communicated online, and in some cases by phone, with undercover officers posing as girls as young as 13. The Disney employees were identified as Thierry Ferron, 44, an electronics technician; Julio Segundo, 21, an intern in research and development; and Richard Gaugh, 55, a regional coordinator for Disneys Animal Kingdom. A Disney spokeswoman said the three had been placed on unpaid leave.

title: Relatives of Interned Japanese-Americans Side With Muslims
description: Holly Yasui was far away when a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled last June that the government had wide latitude to detain noncitizens indefinitely on the basis of race, religion or national origin. The ruling came in a class-action lawsuit by Muslim immigrants held after 9/11. But Ms. Yasui, an American citizen of Japanese ancestry, had reason to take it personally.

title: British Captives Admit Illegal Entry, Iran Says
description: LONDON, April 2  Iran said Monday that all 15 captured British sailors and marines had confessed to intruding illegally into Iranian waters on March 23, when they were seized at gunpoint.

title: Teaching Religion: Truth Isnt the Goal (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: With Professors Designs, Circus Is Dressed to Thrill
description: Beneath the high wires being hung from the ceiling at Madison Square Garden, David Murin was on a winding, frenetic walk to womens wardrobe.

title: Australia: Credit Checker Sold
description: Merrill Lynch & Companys buyout fund and Pacific Equity Partners agreed to buy Veda Advantage, the biggest credit-checking company in Australia and New Zealand, for 814 million Australian dollars ($659 million). Veda, which is based in Sydney, said its directors endorsed the bid, which was for 3.61 Australian dollars a share. The deal comes as record household debt has spurred demand for Vedas data.

title: U.S. to Seek the Death Penalty for a Reputed Acting Crime Boss
description: The government will seek to execute a reputed crime family boss accused of killing an associate, federal prosecutors said yesterday in pretrial court documents.

title: Foundation Set Up to Seek Justice for Ex-K.G.B. Spy
description: LONDON, April 3  The widow and associates of Alexander Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. agent poisoned in London last November, opened a foundation today to demand justice for him and expressed concern that Britain and Russia might allow his killers to avoid trial.

title: For Payne, Leading Augusta National Is Another Solemn Mission
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2  Billy Payne spends Sunday mornings in a third-row pew at St. Lukes Presbyterian Church in Dunwoody, Ga., sitting close enough to the pulpit that his minister, Christopher A. Price, can view him at his most confident and most vulnerable.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: The Phantom Strikes Again

title: Time in the Animal Mind
description: Humans are born time travelers. We may not be able to send our bodies into the past or the future, at least not yet, but we can send our minds. We can relive events that happened long ago or envision ourselves in the future.

title: Reports From Four Fronts in the War on Warming
description: Over the last few decades, as scientists have intensified their study of the human effects on climate and of the effects of climate change on humans, a common theme has emerged: in both respects, the world is a very unequal place.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Morehouse College and its search for a new president misstated the former position of the colleges current president, Walter E. Massey. Dr. Massey was a director of the National Science Foundation, not of the National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts.

title: Charges Dismissed for Ex-Enron Trader
description: A federal judge in Houston dismissed charges yesterday against a former energy trader at Enron who admitted to participating in the fraud that destroyed the company.

title: Goodby, Silverstein Wins Sprint Account
description: Sprint Nextel has ended a three-month review for its creative advertising account by selecting Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the assignment. Sprint Nextel spends $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion a year in advertising.

title: The Court Rules on Warming
description: It would be hard to overstate the importance of yesterdays ruling by the Supreme Court that the federal government has the authority to regulate the carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases produced by motor vehicles.

title: The Interactive Imaginings of a Spaniard in the Spotlight
description: It was fitting that Cesc Gelabert should close the dance component of Made in Catalunya, a festival celebrating the rich, idiosyncratic Catalan cultural history. Mr. Gelabert is one of the earliest modern-dance artists of a generation based in Barcelona that came of age in the 1980s. He is also sui generis, as his solo, Glimpse, suggested in a performance on Saturday night at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.

title: Showing Mugabe the Door
description: EVER since Zimbabwe began imploding in 2000, the conventional punditry about its president, Robert Mugabe, has largely been of the good-leader-turns-bad variety. Now, as the countrys economy enters its death throes  hyperinflation at 1,700 percent and expected to exceed 5,000 percent by years end; unemployment at 80 percent; the average persons purchasing power at 1953 levels; life expectancy the lowest in the world; an exodus of Africas most educated population  it would seem a good time to re-examine that orthodoxy and decide what the West can do to ease the dictators departure.

title: Sanctuary for Sex Slaves
description: Meerwala, Pakistan

title: Corzine Makes His Choice Among Ex-Colleagues in Senate
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., April 2  For a governor with a penchant for numbers, the calculus seemed apt: two backbenchers, one presidential candidate, and an endorsement.

title: Goodby, Silverstein Wins Sprint Account
description: Sprint Nextel ended a three-month review for its creative account by selecting Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, for the assignment.

title: Comcast, Cash in Mind, Ends Partnership
description: The cable television company Comcast and Insight Communications have agreed to end a cable partnership in four states because Comcast wants to add a source of cash flow.

title: Provenance Still Unclear, Possible Pollocks Have Been Sold
description: An announcement two years ago of the discovery of a trove of small drip paintings thought to be the work of Jackson Pollock set off an uproar in the world of art scholarship that has yet to die down. The paintings have been scrutinized by connoisseurs, been subjected to computerized pattern tests, undergone chemical analysis at Harvard and elsewhere, and deeply divided a group of once-united Pollock experts.

title: After Threats, Anti-Zionist Groups Synagogue Burns, but Arson Is Doubted
description: MONSEY, N.Y., April 2  The bitterness felt toward the Neturei Karta congregation had been evident since December, when members of the congregation, an anti-Zionist Jewish group, traveled to Tehran and shook hands with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad at a conference on the Holocaust.

title: The Claim: CPR Requires Mouth-to-Mouth Resuscitation
description: THE FACTS

title: A Dentist? Of Course. Its the Great White Way.
description: In the blinking, blinding thicket that is Broadway just above Times Square, Dr. Louisa Correa is right up there with the Dolce & Gabbana models in the fancy sunglasses and the Hilary Swank movie that opens Thursday.

title: On Hand for Opener, Swindal Is on Outside Looking In
description: The man who had been the chosen successor to lead the Yankees spent opening day at Yankee Stadium avoiding his wife, ducking the suite of the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, and cautiously pronouncing that everything was fine.

title: A Mutinous Group of Cells on a Greedy, Destructive Path
description: However much their politics and personal styles may otherwise divide them, Elizabeth Edwards and Tony Snow have now been linked in the public eye by a brutal disease that itself flouts the bodys partitions and ruptures the compartmentalized calm of which we all are built.

title: In New Cancer Guideline, a Host of Uncertainties
description: By using radio waves and magnetic fields to produce richly detailed images of soft tissue, magnetic resonance imaging can uncover breast abnormalities that cannot be seen with an ordinary mammogram.

title: Romney Reaps $20 Million to Top G.O.P. Rivals
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Mitt Romneys presidential campaign said Monday that it had raised $20 million in the first quarter, tapping two distant but rich networks  Wall Street and the Mormon Church  to easily outpace his better-known Republican primary rivals.

title: Washington: A Murder-Suicide on Campus
description: A gunman killed a woman and shot himself to death at the University of Washington in Seattle, the authorities said. The shooting happened in an office where the woman, 25, worked in a division of the College of Architecture and Urban Planning. Ray Wittmier, assistant chief of police for the university, said the gunman, who was 41 and not affiliated with the university, was under a restraining order forbidding him from having contact with the woman.

title: Day Laborers (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Stuck in an Airplane and in an Overloaded System
description: THE last two flights I have been on were delayed on takeoff for a total of three hours. Not so bad, considering that thousands of passengers were stranded on planes for up to nine hours in airports near Dallas on Dec. 29 as severe thunderstorms crossed the region. And on Feb. 14, thousands more were stranded by an ice storm for up to 10  hours on JetBlue planes, mostly at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Sports Briefing
description: Swimming

title: Improved Draft Status but No Championship for Oden
description: ATLANTA, April 2  Ohio State center Greg Oden showed the N.B.A. scouts Monday night that he could play smart, play hard and play angry.

title: A Wise Mugger Always Insists on Proof of Age
description: Any New Yorker with a sliver of decency was disgusted by the recent mugging of a 101-year-old woman, Rose Morat, in the lobby of her Queens apartment building.

title: Last Diva Standing: Young Voices Vie on a Grand Stage
description: A snapshot of a segment of operas next generation, with elements of randomness in the composition: thats the most the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions Grand Finals concert can actually hope to offer. The 11 finalists who sang onstage at the Metropolitan Opera on Sunday afternoon had been culled from some 1,500 singers in four rounds of national competition. The six winners took home $15,000 each; the five others, runner-up prizes of $5,000. All got the same boost of singing with the Met orchestra, on the Met stage, for an enthusiastic audience; for most of them, this will lead to new professional opportunities, though there are no instant tickets to a big career.

title: Grant Thornton Resigns as Fremonts Auditor
description: The auditor of Fremont General, a troubled financial company that is trying to sell its subprime mortgage business, has resigned with a complaint that the company had failed to provide information when promised.

title: At Risk: One Head Injury Sets the Stage for a Second One in Children
description: Children who suffer a head injury are much more likely to have another one within six months, researchers reported Monday. The big question is why.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A caption on Saturday with a picture showing a Pakistani man on his bicycle carrying a painting of his son, who he says was abducted by Pakistani intelligence agents in 2001, misspelled the name of the Pakistani capital. It is Islamabad, not Islambad.

title: Another Marathon Season Begins With a Quick First Step
description: There was a happy beginning in the Bronx yesterday.

title: Japan: Vehicle Sales Keep Falling
description: Vehicle sales fell for a 21st straight month, led by Nissan and Toyota, capping their worst business year in three decades. Sales of cars, trucks and buses, excluding minicars, fell 12.6 percent, to 487,738 vehicles in March from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. Nissans sales fell 16 percent, while Toyotas dropped 12 percent. Sales of vehicles excluding minicars dropped 8.3 percent, to 3.59 million units, the lowest level in 29 years, in the 12 months ended March 31.

title: Letters
description: Opiates, Pain and Drug Laws

title: Somerville: Police Officer Arrested
description: A Clinton Township police officer was arrested yesterday on a gun charge after he took a shotgun from a relatives house and headed for Somerset County in his truck, the county prosecutors office said. Around 10:30 a.m., a countywide alert was issued for the officer, Jason Peltack, after a friend called the police and told them that the officer had taken a 12-gauge shotgun from a home in Bridgewater. As a precaution, the prosecutors office ordered Immaculata High School in Somerville to be locked down for about an hour, said Wayne J. Forrest, the Somerset County prosecutor. Mr. Forrest would not say why the school was thought to be in danger or how the officer had planned to use the gun. Officer Peltack, 27, was arrested around 11:20 a.m. in Raritan and charged with a fourth-degree firearms offense. He was placed on paid medical leave and ordered to undergo a psychological evaluation, the authorities said.

title: Brooklyn: Witness Describes Bribery
description: After four days on the stand, the primary witness in a judicial bribery case finished his direct testimony yesterday, describing a series of gifts and cash payments made in exchange for legal assignments and favorable rulings. The defendant, Gerald Garson, a former State Supreme Court justice who oversaw matrimonial cases, has been charged with accepting bribes. The witness, a disbarred divorce lawyer named Paul Siminovsky, left, testified that he paid for meals for the judge and gave him a bottle of Scotch and other gifts as well as an envelope holding $1,000. On a surveillance recording played in State Supreme Court yesterday, the judge was seen accepting the money, then counting it and muttering profanities. On the recording, the judge returned the money and asked that it be given to his wifes political campaign. Mr. Siminovsky gave the money back to the judge, clapping his arm and saying, Dont worry about it. Mr. Siminovsky has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor.

title: Finding Doomsday Asteroids
description: How much effort should we expend to ward off the possibility that an asteroid might some day collide with Earth? Space experts attending a recent conference in Washington lamented the failure of the federal government  indeed, of the entire world  to take the threat seriously enough. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, at virtually the same moment, advised Congress on steps that could be taken to find and divert threatening asteroids only to conclude that it couldnt afford them.

title: Ukraine Leader Opposes Dissolution of Parliament
description: MOSCOW, April 3  Ukraines Prime Minister, Viktor F. Yanukovich, today defied an order by President Viktor A. Yushchenko to disband Parliament and called the decision a fatal mistake, as Ukraine lumbered into one of its worst political crises since the 2004 Orange Revolution.

title: Good to the Last Drop...of Milk
description: An offbeat new campaign reframes a familiar question by asking how far you might go if you dont get milk.

title: Employee Owners Dont Necessarily Have a Say in Management
description: More than 10 million workers have stakes in their companies through employee stock ownership plans, and many have benefited.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A graphic on Friday with an article about fund-raising for the 2008 presidential campaign referred incompletely to candidates this year who also sought their partys nomination in 2004. Dennis Kucinich, who is seeking the Democratic nomination, also ran last time; John Edwards, another Democrat, is not the only such candidate.

title: The Band Strikes Up to Play a Few of Its Favorite Things
description: Some concerts by the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra adhere to thematic prescriptions: the legacy of a single composer, for instance, or the sound of a specific place and time. The Songs We Love, which the band performed in more than a dozen cities leading up to a three-night stand at the Rose Theater, advanced a somewhat less focused agenda.

title: Gaza Strip: Protests Over Kidnapped Reporter
description: More than a hundred Palestinian journalists and others held a sit-in outside the prime ministers office in Gaza City to demand increased efforts to find Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent abducted there three weeks ago. In the West Bank city of Ramallah, local and international journalists also called on the government to do more. The Palestinian journalists union declared a three-day news boycott of the government and the office of President Mahmoud Abbas. BBC executives say there has been no information about Mr. Johnstons whereabouts nor any message from his captors saying what they want.

title: For Shtetl by the Sea, Only a Few Fading Signs Remain
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 2  The synagogue at 1415 Euclid Avenue had only a few members left when Daniel Davidson, a New Yorker seeking a standout South Beach retreat, bought it in 2003.

title: Foundations Giving Is Said to Have Set Record in 06
description: Giving by foundations climbed past $40 billion last year, according to estimates by the Foundation Center, breaking a record of $36.4 billion set in 2005.

title: Classical Music Looks Toward China With Hope
description: BEIJING, April 1  Yu Zhenyang, a self-assured 15-year-old violinist with a picture of Jascha Heifetz in his bedroom, glided through the Mendelssohn Concerto from memory. His teacher bounded across the room, flailing his arms, swooning to demonstrate pathos and urging Zhenyang to play with more passion.

title: 3 Dancers Making a Show of Their Age
description: In the relatively short history of modern dance, an awkward chain of events has unfolded that goes something like this: a choreographer gets older, his dancers get younger and suddenly, plopped into the middle of a work, is a solo in which the aging choreographer tries to get his groove back.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary last Tuesday about Walter J. Turnbull, the founder of the Boys Choir of Harlem, referred incorrectly to the status of the Choir Academy of Harlem, a public school that was created in partnership with the choir. Although the school is no longer affiliated with the choir, it does remain open; it did not close last year when the choir was evicted from the building.

title: Tenet Healthcare to Pay $10 Million Civil Fine
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (Dow Jones/AP)  Tenet Healthcare, one of the largest United States health care companies, agreed Monday to pay a $10 million civil penalty to settle charges that it failed to disclose that its earnings growth from 1999 to 2002 was driven by its exploitation of a loophole in the Medicare reimbursement system.

title: 3 Patents on Stem Cells Are Revoked in Initial Review
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has made a preliminary decision to revoke three fundamental patents on human embryonic stem cells. If the decision stands, some scientists and consumer groups say it could loosen restrictions on research in a promising new field.

title: Long-Awaited Cosmic-Ray Detector May Be Shelved
description: When Samuel Ting, the Nobel Prize-winning particle physicist, proposed back in 1995 to use the International Space Station to plumb the depths of the universe for antimatter, it was hailed by NASA as good news for the station, which suffered from the perception that it had no scientific use.

title: Buffalo: Man Jailed for 21 Years Is Freed
description: The rape convictions of a Buffalo man incarcerated for more than 21 years were vacated yesterday, five days after prosecutors announced that newly discovered evidence had linked another man to the attacks. The man, Anthony Capozzi, 50, was not in court for the hearing, during which Judge Shirley Troutman of Erie County Court ordered his release. Mr. Capozzi, who is schizophrenic and is being treated at a state prison hospital in Marcy, was convicted of two rapes in the early 1980s. He was released after prosecutors said that another mans DNA matched the DNA samples from the rapes. That man, Altemio Sanchez, cannot be charged with the rapes because of the statute of limitations, which was five years at the time, prosecutors said. Mr. Sanchez has been charged with three murders in the Buffalo area since 1990. He has pleaded not guilty.

title: McCain Wrong on Iraq Security, Merchants Say
description: BAGHDAD, April 2  A day after members of an American Congressional delegation led by Senator John McCain pointed to their brief visit to Baghdads central market as evidence that the new security plan for the city was working, the merchants there were incredulous about the Americans conclusions.

title: A Third Season at Sea, Preoccupied With Danger
description: The title Deadliest Catch can be confusing. The catch in question isnt great whites or stingrays or even that deadliest of prey, man; its the Alaska king crab, which can take off a finger if youre not careful, and can get pretty messy in a restaurant, but is otherwise harmless.

title: You Wont Find It Here (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: An Opulent Home, a Rich Past
description: The white marble mansion on Riverside Drive and 107th Street, its entrance guarded by two lions, has always attracted onlookers who have approached the home as if it were a sphinx. Since last year, when it was put on the market for $31 million, a mosaic of New Yorkers, including great-granddaughters of both the original owner and the architect, have shed new light on its rich history.

title: Links to Airlines Lost and Found Web sites
description: American Airlines:

title: Study Finds Parents Pass Whooping Cough to Babies
description: Rates of pertussis, or whooping cough, have been steadily increasing since the 1980s, and a new study reports that infants most often catch the disease from older household members, especially infected parents. Adults can transmit the illness without having any symptoms themselves.

title: Thomas Stands by His Man, Further Criticizing N.B.A. Referees
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 2  Two days after Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas criticized N.B.A. referees for their treatment of guard Stephon Marbury, he stood by his comments, even building on his case for why he believes Marbury should be sent to the foul line more often.

title: Lawmakers Call for Ouster of Top Inspector at Space Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Leaders of Senate and House subcommittees overseeing NASA called for removal of its inspector general on Monday, saying he had abused his authority and created a hostile workplace that interfered with his offices doing its job.

title: A New Owner Who Is Hedging His Bets
description: In a self-published little red booklet entitled Quotations from the Chairman, Samuel Zell, the real estate magnate who often sounds like a thoughtful version of Yosemite Sam, offered this guidance: Be a risk taker; however, define risk by your own terms.

title: Yanks First Remember Lidle in First Victory
description: A construction crane peeks over the left-field grandstand at Yankee Stadium now, a reminder of new beginnings. There will be only one more opening day at the old ballpark, with a new one rising in two years.

title: The Cycle Turns, and Airline Shares Have Fans Again
description: If everything goes perfectly  and that is a big if  the airline industry could report record profits this year.

title: Cheney Presses Attack on Democrats Timeline
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Vice President Dick Cheney said Monday that it was pointless for Democrats to pursue Iraq spending measures that set a timeline for leaving Iraq that President Bush would veto. Meanwhile, the top Senate Democrat signed on to a measure that would cut off money for the war next March if the president exercised his veto.

title: Manhattan: Mayor to Veto Ban on Metal Bats
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he intended to veto a bill that would prohibit the use of metal bats in high school baseball games. I dont know whether aluminum bats are more dangerous or less dangerous than wooden bats, the mayor said. I have had friends who are professional baseball players call me and argue both ways, but I dont think its the citys business to regulate that. The Council passed the bill on March 14 by a vote of 40 to 6; 34 votes would be required to override a veto. The bills main sponsor, Councilman James S. Oddo, said, Well have a second vote, and there will be a second opportunity for the City Council to stand up on behalf of the kids.

title: Brooklyn Academy and Old Vic Teaming Up
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music, in its first foray into producing plays in two decades, has announced a three-year joint venture with the director Sam Mendes and the Old Vic theater company in London to produce two plays a year, which will run in repertory for limited engagements on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Giving Voice to Vivaldi on Modern Instruments
description: So thoroughly has Antonio Vivaldis music become the near-exclusive province of period-instrument ensembles over the last two decades that it almost comes as a shock to see it turn up in a concert by an ensemble performing on modern implements. Thats perhaps less true of his Four Seasons, music too picturesque and exuberant for most violinists to resist its charms. The latest to succumb is Joshua Bell, who came to Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon as leader of the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields.

title: Mets Randolph Takes Early Measure of Rookies Nerve
description: ST. LOUIS, April 2  The first day of anyones major league career is usually filled with special moments. By the time he put on his uniform Sunday, the Mets rookie reliever Joe Smith said he already had a great one.

title: Ex-Qwest Official Testifies on Stock Buyback
description: DENVER, April 2 (Bloomberg News)  Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications who is on trial on charges of insider trading, called for a repurchase of $1 billion in company stock in 2001, a former Qwest president testified on Monday.

title: The Gators Guards Eclipse the Buckeyes Big Man
description: ATLANTA, April 2  The ball rolled loose in the open floor, and a Florida guard was there to snatch it. Each time there was a quick pass to an open Gators shooter, a 3-point shot seemed to fall through the net.

title: A Patients Demands Versus a Doctors Convictions
description: Doctors talk all the time about a patients right to refuse treatment. But what about the right to demand it?

title: After 2000 Loss, Obama Built Donor Network From Roots Up
description: CHICAGO  When Barack Obama announced to friends over brunch in 2002 that he planned to run for the United States Senate, one of their first questions was how he could possibly raise the necessary millions.

title: New DVDs: Early Bergman
description: EARLY BERGMAN

title: Kohlberg Kravis to Buy First Data for $29 Billion
description: First Data, one of the nations largest credit-card processing companies, said today it had agreed to be acquired by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company for $29 billion.

title: Coles Stake Acquired
description: Wesfarmers, Australias biggest home-improvement retailer, said it had bought an 11.3 percent stake in the Coles Group, the countrys second-biggest retailer, and is seeking talks with the company. Wesfarmers paid 16.47 Australian dollars ($13.40) a share for its stake, information from the Australian Stock Exchange shows, valuing Coles at 19.7 billion Australian dollars, or $16 billion. Coles, Australias second-biggest retailer, put itself up for sale in February, after saying it would not meet profit forecasts that had been cited to reject a bid of 18.2 billion Australian dollars by the private equity firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: One Troupes Exploration of Big Ideas
description: NEWARK, April 1  Liz Lerman has been choreographing pieces about social issues for nearly three decades. Her company, Liz Lerman Dance Exchange, includes members as old as 72 as well as disabled performers. In recent years the themes have grown very large, incorporating fewer and fewer of the small, vivid details that give such themes a life onstage.

title: Devils, Perched in First, Dismiss Another Coach
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 2  With the Devils in first place in their division and only three games to go in the regular season, General Manager Lou Lamoriello fired Coach Claude Julien on Monday and took the job. The move would be more bizarre if it were unprecedented.

title: Shiite Cleric Opposes U.S. Plan to Permit Former Baath Party Members to Join Government
description: BAGHDAD, April 2  The most powerful Shiite cleric in Iraq has rejected an American-backed proposal to allow thousands of former members of Saddam Husseins Baath Party to return to government service, an aide to the cleric said Monday.

title: Justices Say E.P.A. Has Power to Act on Harmful Gases
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  In one of its most important environmental decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday that the Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases in automobile emissions. The court further ruled that the agency could not sidestep its authority to regulate the greenhouse gases that contribute to global climate change unless it could provide a scientific basis for its refusal.

title: Top Chicago Police Official Resigns Amid Furor
description: CHICAGO, April 2  Police Superintendent Philip J. Cline resigned Monday amid a public outcry over the lack of swift disciplinary action against several police officers accused of involvement in two videotaped beatings of residents here in the last several months.

title: Dont Forget the Astrolabe
description: Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Bush Criticizes Democrats on War Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  The political brinksmanship over Iraq war spending intensified today as President Bush said Congressional Democrats had undercut the troops by passing legislation that ties continued war spending to Congressionally mandated timelines for the withdrawal of American combat units from Iraq.

title: Thomas Rogers, 79, Writer and Teacher, Is Dead
description: Thomas Rogers, a novelist whose wryly comic books chart the rocky landscape where youthful alienation  and youthful ardor  meet straight-backed WASP propriety, died on Sunday in State College, Pa. He was 79 and had lived in State College for many years.

title: Curtain Call for Rodriguez in Final Act of Melodrama
description: Not counting the player introductions, it took six minutes of the 2007 season for Yankees fans to boo Alex Rodriguez. It took 10 more minutes to jeer him again.

title: AirTran Raises Bid
description: AirTran Holdings, a low-fare carrier, increased its hostile takeover offer for the Midwest Air Group a second time yesterday, sweetening the bid by 13 percent, to $389 million.

title: Home Lender Is Seeking Bankruptcy
description: From an 11-story steel-and-glass tower that housed its headquarters in Irvine, Calif., the New Century Financial Corporation ruled as one of the nations largest mortgage lenders to individuals with weak, or subprime, credit during the recent housing boom.

title: A Stradivarius, Not Top of the Line, Goes for $2.4 Million
description: The bidding yesterday lasted less than four minutes. The rare Stradivarius violin went for a high  but not a record  price of $2.4 million.

title: EMI Dropping Copy Limits on Online Music
description: LONDON, April 2  Breaking with established practice, the EMI Group announced today that the record labels digital catalog would go on sale over the Internet without built-in copy restrictions.

title: A Classroom of Monkey Bars and Slides
description: I remember fondly a joy-filled childhood in which we came home from school, gobbled down a snack and ran out to play until dark. We made up games, taught each other to roller skate and ride bicycles, ran and jumped, climbed and fell, fought and negotiated, and generally had lots of fun without adults telling us what to do.

title: Techniques: Cooler Dialysis Fluids May Help With Insomnia and Fatigue
description: For all the lives it has saved, kidney dialysis has drawbacks, among them insomnia. As many as 8 of 10 patients tell their doctors they have trouble sleeping and suffer from fatigue during the day.

title: Dancing in the Dark
Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a high-definition video projection system that can put an actors image on stage next to him omitted the opening date for the play Losing Something, which will mark the first use of the system by an American theater company. Previews begin tonight at the 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, and the official opening is Friday.

title: Police Say Son Responded to Eviction With Fatal Gunshots
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 2  When the mother of an unemployed 20-year-old man tried to evict him from her Long Island home on Sunday, he killed her and his father, shooting them in the head, the Nassau County police said on Monday.

title: AT&T and Mexican Affiliate Seek Stake in Italian Company
description: MILAN, April 2  AT&T and its Mexican affiliate, Amrica Mvil, have bid more than $6 billion for control of Italys largest cellphone company, Telecom Italia.

title: Rebuilt Cubs Start Season by Putting Up For-Sale Sign
description: The Chicago Cubs 2007 marketing slogan exclaims, Play Like Theres No Tomorrow! That will be literally true this season for the Tribune Company, which announced yesterday that it would sell the Cubs, its storied subsidiary, later this year as part of the companys overall sale to the Chicago billionaire Sam Zell.

title: Aeroflot Surprises With Bid for Alitalia
description: MOSCOW, April 2  Russias national airline, Aeroflot, made a surprise bid on Monday for all or part of Italys national airline, Alitalia, as one of three potential buyers to meet a deadline set by the Italian ministry of finance.

title: Police Surveillance Before Convention Was Larger Than Previously Disclosed
description: The police surveillance program leading up to the 2004 Republican National Convention was larger than previously disclosed to people who are suing the city over their arrests at the convention, according to papers filed in federal court yesterday.

title: Massachusetts Will Register 04 Marriages
description: BOSTON, April 2  Gov. Deval L. Patrick of Massachusetts has ordered the state Department of Public Health to register the marriages of 26 out-of-state same-sex couples whose licenses were kept from state records by the former governor.

title: One Year Into Term, Chiles Leader Tries to Reverse Slide
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 30  What Michelle Bachelet promised when she was sworn in as Chiles first female president a little over a year ago was social justice and continued economic stability. What Chile faces at the moment, though, is a nagging corruption scandal and chaos in the transportation system here in the capital, which have combined to sap her popularity.

title: Lost and Very Rarely Found
description: The minute Scott Karambis passed through security on his way out of Logan Airport in Boston he realized his new video iPod was still onboard the Midwest Airlines plane.

title: My Life in the Army
description: In one sense, I was well positioned to enjoy the summer of love. In 1969, I was living in San Francisco, epicenter of hippiedom, antiwar fervor and utopian hope for perpetual peace.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (22, 26) KINGS OF CAMOUFLAGE They may sound more Star Trek than sea life, but cuttlefish, above, can impersonate the opposite sex; change their shape and color to blend in with their environment; and kill faster than you can say beam me up. This Nova special goes in depth to see how intelligent these versatile beings are.

title: K. I. Greisen, 89, Dies; Cosmic Ray Expert
description: Kenneth I. Greisen, a physicist who helped broaden methods of studying cosmic rays, including sending unmanned balloons into the upper atmosphere and planting detection devices in salt mines, died on March 17 in Ithaca, N.Y., where he was a former dean at Cornell University. He was 89.

title: Racing to Make Surf City Beach Safe by May 25, Opening Day
description: SURF CITY, N.J., April 2  Much of the sand along this popular 18-mile barrier island had washed away, leaving sections of beach with barely enough room to spread a towel.

title: Memo Pad
description: AIR TAXIS ADVANCE  DayJet, a Florida-based company, took delivery of three Eclipse 500 very light jets on Saturday as it geared up to start air taxi service by the summer. With 239 orders for the $1.5 million jets, DayJet is Eclipses largest customer. DayJet plans to begin its on-demand service on routes of 300 to 600 miles in Florida, and expand later throughout the Southeast, using regional and community airports rather than major commercial airports. Eclipse, with more than 2,500 orders for its 500 model, is one of more than half a dozen manufacturers making very light jets. About 5,000 of the new planes will be operating within 10 years, the Federal Aviation Administration has said.

title: On Opening Day, Williams Can Only Watch and Wish
description: Hiram Williams spoke yesterday to his brother, Bernie, who played so gracefully with the Yankees for the past 16 seasons. Hiram could hear the disappointment in Bernies voice and could understand why it was a draining day for a baseball player who no longer has a team.

title: Factory Growth Slows
description: Manufacturing growth slowed more than forecast last month and the cost of raw materials jumped, reinforcing concerns that inflation is not being reduced as the economy cools.

title: Ruling Undermines Lawsuits Opposing Emissions Controls
description: Yesterdays Supreme Court ruling on carbon dioxide emissions largely shredded the underpinning of other lawsuits trying to block regulation of the emissions and gave new momentum to Congressional efforts to control heat-trapping gases linked to climate change.

title: Manhattan: New Police Chaplain
description: Khalid Latif, 24, an imam who has served as a chaplain and adviser at Princeton University and New York University, was appointed yesterday as chaplain for Muslim members of the Police Department. Mr. Latif, who holds a masters degree from Hartford Seminary, is the second Muslim to join the Christian and Jewish clergy members in the departments chaplains unit. He succeeds Izak-El M. Pasha, a spiritual leader to thousands of black Muslims, who retired a year ago. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that the number of Muslims in the department was in the thousands.

title: In a Sopranos Recital Debut, a Focus on the Music Stand
description: One way for an Italian opera singer to smooth the path to the recital stage is to stay close to home turf. For the first half of her New York recital debut at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday, Barbara Frittoli, the Milanese soprano, focused on works by opera composers and Schuberts Italian canzone.

title: Disciplinary Hearings Leave N.F.L. Union in Awkward Spot
description: With disciplinary hearings scheduled today for Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones and Cincinnati Bengals receiver Chris Henry, the N.F.L. players union could find itself caught between some angry players and a much larger group that applauds the crackdown.

title: Floridas Place in History (and Odens)
description: For the entirety of the N.C.A.A. Tournament so far, niggling observers have been pointing out that the Ohio State Buckeyes tend to improve when mammoth monolith Greg Oden is out of the game. The team plays looser, it feels less tethered to the paint and it seems to, you know, smile and have fun occasionally. Some even wondered if Oden was somehow holding back the Buckeyes.

title: Where Does Florida Rank?
description: Florida won its second consecutive N.C.A.A. title and equaled the successful run of Duke in 1991 and 1992, the last school to win back-to-back championships.

title: Questions in Science
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Night at the Fights
description: Inside the Golden Gloves semifinals on March 23 in the Bronx.

title: A gift to the senses
description: Beach

title: The Phantom Strikes Again
description: The dictionary defines "phantom" as something that seems to appear to the sight but has no physical existence. Tell that to the actors, musicians and stagehands at the Majestic Theater, where "The Phantom of the Opera," the longest-running show in Broadway history, will hit the 8,000-performance milestone at its matinee tomorrow.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the experiences of high-achieving high school girls in Newton, Mass., misstated a verb property of Latin, which one of the girls in the article studies. It is the subjunctive mood; there is no subjunctive "tense."

title: New Directions
description: Photographs of shows at the 2007 Humana Festival of New American Plays.

title: Sana Security Closes $12 Million Funding Round
description: Sana Security, a maker of antivirus software, said it had received $12 million in venture funding in its latest round of financing, led by El Dorado Ventures, bringing its total venture funding to $40 million. Sana also named Don Listwin, who previously led Openwave Systems, as its chief executive officer.

title: F.T.C. Could Block $1.13 Billion Refinery Acquisition
description: Members of the Federal Trade Commission look likely to try and block the $1.13 billion acquisition of Giant Industries by Western Refining. Although Giants shareholders approved the purchase more than a month ago, a government lawyer has said that the April 10 vote is expected to spark a second legal fight to stop a deal under its review. In March, the commission voted to halt a merger between two nonresidential natural gas suppliers in Pittsburgh, Equitable Resources and the Peoples Natural Gas Company. The deal is pending.

title: Who Will Go to Bat for the Cubs?
description: Speculation as to possible suitors for the Tribune Companys Chicago Cubs baseball team ramped up Monday after Tribune said it would put the franchise on the block. The big names include Jerry Colangelo, chairman of the NBAs Phoenix Suns and a former owner of that team and baseballs Arizona Diamondbacks, and Mark Cuban, owner of the NBAs Dallas Mavericks.

title: Lenders Up in Arms over $1 Billion Tower Sale
description: Second-lien lenders, claiming theyve been shut out of their proposal to recapitalize Tower Automotive, are making noise about the companys plan to sell itself to Cerberus Capital Management for close to $1 billion.

title: Aeroflot Surprises With Bid for Alitalia
description: Russias national airline, Aeroflot, made a surprise bid on Monday for all or part of Italys national airline, Alitalia, as one of three potential buyers to meet a deadline set by the Italian ministry of finance. If successful, Aeroflots bid for the Italian flag carrier would be its first large investment outside the former Soviet Union, and it would be in keeping with a trend of Russian state-owned businesses making strategic investments in Europe.

title: E.On, Striking a Deal with a Rival, Withdraws Endesa Bid
description: The German energy giant E.On on Monday withdrew its offer of 42.4 billion euros ($56.6 billion) for the Spanish utility Endesa in exchange for a promise from rival bidders to sell it part of Endesas assets, ending one of Europes most arcane takeover battles.

title: Ex-Qwest Official Testifies on Stock Buyback
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communicationswho is on trial on charges of insider trading, called for a repurchase of $1 billion in company stock in 2001, a former Qwest president testified on Monday. Mr. Nacchio, 57, is accused of selling $101 million in Qwest shares from January 2001 to May 2001, before the stock price plunged, based on inside information that the company would miss its revenue targets.

title: Stifel Acquires First Service for $38 Million
description: Stifel Financial of St. Louis has acquired First Service Financial and its subsidiary First Service Bank for about $38 million, the company said Monday. Stifel said it had completed a private placement March 30 of $35 million of 6.79 percent cumulative trust preferred securities and planned to use the proceeds for the acquisition of First Service Financial. The deal is subject to escrow settlement.

title: Vyatta Nabs $11 Million in Second Round
description: San Mateo, Calif.-based Vyatta picked up $11 million in a second round of funding, the software company said Monday. The round was led by Comcast Interactive Capital, which may use Vyattas technology in new potential managed service bundles for small and medium-sized business and enterprise markets. Also in the round were J.P. Morgan Partners, ComVentures and ArrowPath Venture Partners.

title: Battery Ventures Buys Quovadx for $136.7 Million
description: A software company, Quovadx, has reached an agreement to be sold to Battery Ventures for $136.7 million, the company said. Battery Ventures is a venture capital and private equity firm with offices in Boston and the Silicon Valley.

title: Precious Primary Permutations
description: Alabamas primary schedule may have us all tied in knots.

title: Netezza Prepares for $100 Million I.P.O.
description: As NCR moves to spin off its Teradata  data-warehouse division, data-warehouse appliance startup Netezza has declared its own intentions to go public. An analyst firm, The 451 Group, takes a look at Netezzas prospects and suggests that the company is likely to get a rich valuation.

title: Citic Could Raise $4 Billion in Dual Listing
description: China Citic Bank, which jumped the final hurdle for its dual listing in both Hong Kong and Shanghai on Monday, could raise more than $4 billion in its planned initial public offering on April 27. Finance Asia suggests the listings could provide a genuine test of investor appetite for Chinese financial stocks.

title: Robert Van Securities Buys N.Y.s Blaylock
description: Robert Van Securities of Oakland, Calif., said Monday it bought a New York investment bank, Blaylock & Company. No financial details for the deal were released. The newly combined company will be known as Blaylock Robert Van.

title: Cytycs Augusta Medical to Acquire Adeza Biomedical
description: Augusta Medical, a subsidiary of Cytyc, has completed a tender offer for outstanding shares of Adeza Biomedical totaling about $403.6 million. Cytyc, based in Marlborough, Mass., said the company plans to complete the acquisition of Adeza as soon as possible. Adeza markets a test to determine whether pregnant women are at risk of giving premature birth while Cytyc makes diagnostic and surgical products.

title: Barclays Acquires EquiFirst for a Song
description: Fears that the subprime mortgage market is on the verge of collapse have driven valuations of the companies down and one Wall Street firm, apparently seeing an opportunity there, has taken advantage. In a deal that was originally valued at $225 million, Barclays Bank has completed its purchase of one subprime mortgage lender, EquiFirst, from Regions Financial for just $76 million.

title: Fannie Mae to Cut Several Hundred Jobs
description: The mortgage funding company Fannie Mae will lay off several hundred full-time employees by the end of 2007, according to a company spokesman. The job cuts are part of an effort to shave $200 million from operating expenses this year, the spokesman said.

title: Severstals Mordashov Settles for Reduced Dividend
description: Russian billionaire Alexey Mordashov is set to receive a $324 million dividend from his steel company Severstal. With his worth estimated at $8.5 billion, Mr. Mordashov was recently ranked Russias seventh richest man by Forbes magazine. Although pre-tax profits at Severstal fell to $1.75 billion for 2006, Mr. Mordashov said the companys outlook for 2007 was positive. He added: We will continue to drive value through strong organic growth and a disciplined approach to M&A.

title: Commission Suggests Repeal of 1930s Antitrust Law
description: A government-appointed panel of antitrust experts has recommended the repeal of a 1930s-era antitrust law designed to protect small retailers, Reuters said. The commission has been meeting to deliberate various antitrust laws, including the Sherman Act and the Robinson-Patman Act, to see whether they were in line with the modern economy. The suggested repeal of the latter was the biggest change recommended by the commission. The Robinson-Patman Act bars suppliers from engaging in anticompetitive price discrimination.

title: Caxton-Iseman to Buy KCP Income Fund
description: The KCP Income Fund of Canada will sell itself to a private equity firm, Caxton-Iseman Capital of New York, for about 493 million Canadian dollars ($426 million). The deal was announced Monday. Caxton-Iseman will also assume about 311 million Canadian dollars of debt. The Globe and Mail pointed out that KCP, a bleach and consumer products manufacturer based in Toronto, has become the latest income trust to respond to Ottawas new tax regime by selling out to an American private equity firm.

title: Australias Coles Gets $16 Billion Takeover Bid
description: Wesfarmers, the biggest home-improvement retailer in Australia, and buyout firms led by Pacific Equity Partners bid 19.7 billion Australian dollars ($16 billion) for the Coles Group in what would be a record takeover of an Australian company.

title: For Tribune Buyer, a Storm to the West
description: As Samuel Zell, the jeans-clad motorcycle rider, prepares to take over the conservative Tribune Company, he may have to deal with a bigger culture clash. The Los Angeles Times, the chains marquee California newspaper, was nothing but trouble for Tribune, and it may prove even more of a challenge for Mr. Zell.

title: Accredited Shares Rise After Lender Closes Hedge Fund Loan
description: Shares of Accredited Home Lenders Holding, a subprime mortgage lender, rose before the opening bell Tuesday after it said late on Monday that it had closed a loan from Farallon Capital Management, a hedge fund, to increase liquidity. In exchange for a five-year, $230 million term loan facility from Farallon, Accredited will give the hedge fund warrants to acquire about 3.23 million shares at an exercise price of $10 a share.

title: Is Tribunes Leveraged ESOP Worth the Risk?
description: Tribunes decision to use an employee stock ownership plan to help fund its sale to the real estate tycoon Samuel Zell has obvious benefits  most notably tax breaks  but also comes with some big risks, analysts said Monday. The clearest downsides are the large amount of debt in the Tribune deal and the potential hit to workers savings if the publishing and broadcasting company runs into trouble.

title: Broadcasters Research Firm Slams XM-Sirius Deal
description: The Carmel Group, the influential research firm whose analysis helped kill the 2003 merger of EchoStar and DirecTV, will release a new report Tuesday that outlines the strongest arguments yet against merging satellite radio companies Sirius and XM, The New York Post reported. Sponsored by the National Association of Broadcasters, which has already come out against the deal, the 11-page independent white paper includes a point-by-point rebuttal to the six main arguments put forth by Sirius and XM in favor of a merger.

title: Icahn Firms C.F.O. to Leave
description: The chief financial officer of an investment vehicle for Carl C. Icahn is leaving to take another job, the firm said in a regulatory filing Tuesday. The executive, Hillel Moerman, gave notice of his resignation to the Icahn company, American Real Estate Partners, last week, and the company said it did not make a counteroffer.

title: Reminder: Its Not Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Baseball
Music to Our Ears From EMI
description: OK, my jaw just hit the floor. This just in: Apple has persuaded EMI, one of the Big Four record companies, to offer its digital catalog of music without copy protection, starting in May.

title: Recipe: Neapolitan Ricotta and Wheatberry Pie
description: Neapolitan Ricotta and Wheatberry Pie

title: Tennessee Reclaims Women's Throne
description: Candace Parker led the Lady Vols to their first national title since 1998.

title: Nikko Shareholder Prods Citi to Raise Offer
description: Orbis Investment Management, a major shareholder of Nikko Cordial, stepped up pressure on Citigroup to raise its $14 billion bid for the Japanese broker by offering to sell its stake on the open market at a higher price. Analysts dismissed the move, which offers the shares at a price well above their current market value.

title: 'Mania' Mania
description: Additional images from the scene at this years WrestleMania.

title: With Subsidies, Its Better to Give Than to Receive
description: Hey China, will you please dump some more cheap glossy paper over here? Harvard economist Greg Mankiw, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Bush, explains why the Bush administration should celebrate the subsidies China gives to its paper industry. Mankiw writes on his personal blog:

title: 2008: More on the Q-1 Funds
description: As aides to Senator Barack Obama boast of a $20 million Q-1 fundraising total, Christopher Drew and Mike McIntire draw insights from his technique during the 2004 Senate primary in Illinois. During that race, Mr. Obama recovered from a $20,000 debt generated during a failed congressional bid and accumulated more than $5 million:

title: The Shrinking Middle Class
description: A conference on the future of New York Citys shrinking middle class on Monday featured clashes among several politicians who are considering running for mayor in 2009.

title: Renting Apartments in Barcelona
description: Do you know of any (reputable) Websites or services that list apartments for rent short-term (a week or 10 days) in Barcelona? Ive tried searching but have been unable to find any for a solo traveler. Id rather not stay in a hostel or a hotel, but would prefer a studio or one-bedroom in Barri Gotic or Raval.

title: U.N. Envoy Meets With Security Council Over Kosovo Independence
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 3  Martti Ahtisaari , the United Nations special envoy for the future status of Kosovo, met with the Security Council behind closed doors on Tuesday to discuss a proposal that would grant Kosovo independence from Serbia under international supervision.

title: An Assessment of Kohlberg Kraviss First Data Bet
description: As observers continue to scrutinize Kohlberg Kravis Robertss $29 billion deal for First Data, one thing has become clear: This deal is ambitious, even for a buyout heavyweight.

title: War at Home: Bush and the Veto
description: President Bush ratcheted up the pressure on Congress today, tugging on the emotional strings of military families with relatives in Iraq as he outlined the consequences of war spending bills approved by the House and Senate that he has vowed to veto.

title: Andy Pettitte and the Yankees, the Sequel
description: Andy Pettitte realizes this could be his last season in the major leagues so he is doing things a bit differently. As Pettitte prepares to make his first start of the season in his second incarnation as a Yankee on Wednesday night, he explained how his wife and four children will be at the game.

title: Clinton: Not Ready to Surrender on War Bill
description: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Iowa  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Democrats should not automatically accept defeat on the Iraq spending bill by assuming that President Bush will carry through with his veto threat.

title: A Flip to Make a Venture Investor Proud
description: Fred Wilson has made some lucrative exits in his career. The venture capitalist, of Union Square Ventures and Flatiron Partners, was an early investor in the Web site hosting service GeoCities.com, for example. That site was acquired by Yahoo for $3.6 billion in 1999, while the Internet boom was still in full swing.

title: Homes Under $200,000
description: Tour a condo on the Jersey shore, a Craftsman-style home in Galveston, Tex., and a house in the desert near Southern Californias Joshua Tree National Park.

title: Hofstra Applies to Host Debate
description: Hofstra University is one of 19 institutions that have applied to host presidential debates, the Commission on Presidental Debates has announced. Of the 19, only two three are in the Northeast: Hofstra, Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., and VisitPittsburgh, the Greater Pittsburgh Convention and Visitors Bureau.The commission  a nonprofit, nonpartisan corporation  was established in 1987 to sponsor and produce debates for the United States presidential and vice-presidential candidates. The commission organized two presidential debates each in 1988 and 1996, and three each in 1992, 2000 and 2004.

title: So You Think YOU Love The Sopranos?
description: This video summary of the first six seasons of The Sopranos, by Paul Guylas and Joe Sabia, is an exquisite act of devotion to a television show.

title: Should You Trade Like Blackstone?
description: Though Blackstone Group is most often described as a private equity firm, TheStreet.coms James Altucher argues that it is really a money-management outfit that also runs hedge funds. As the group prepares to go public, Mr. Altucher declares that Blackstone has the potential to eclipse every other financial institution.

title: So Small, New Yorkers Probably Thought They Missed It
description: If youve been dying to see the Smart ForTwo that is bound for the United States and figure it must be hiding beneath some Hummers skirt, brace for disappointment: The smallest car is the biggest no-show in New York. While the New York region could prove the prime American market for the 8.8-foot long urban runabout, officials of the Mercedes-owned Smart decided to focus marketing efforts on the higher-profile Detroit show last January and pass on New York until next Aprils show.

title: How Samuel Zell Scaled Tribune Tower
description: Chicago Tribune columnist Phil Rosenthal offers a quick and handy guide to the months of machinations leading up to the agreement to sell Tribune Company  which also happens to be Mr. Rosenthals employer  to real-estate magnate Sam Zell.

title: A Triple Piercing With That Frappuccino?
description: Starbucks stands accused by the National Labor Relations Board of breaking the law by retaliating against workers supportive of unionization at four of its coffee shops in Manhattan. Among the more unusual aspects of the complaint [Word document] is an accusation that Starbucks unfairly discriminated by selectively enforcing these two dress-code rules against pro-union employees:

title: Eleven Months to Rest Up
description: For all the sturm und drang college basketballs participants put themselves through to try to win a national championship, it is ultimately disappointing to see what they win for all their troubles: this trophy.

title: Spring Training
description: Just back from Florida and are my ears burning. No kidding. I didnt realize it was possible to sunburn your earlobes. But there you are, and Ive got the peeling skin to prove it.

title: Final Impressions of the Opener
description: It was a memorable Monday in the Bronx, for a lot of reasons. Here are some random observations a day later:

title: Historic Dining, At Least Architecturally
description: In tomorrows Dining section I re-review the restaurant the Four Seasons, which has been around since 1959. And as I perused past newspaper and magazine stories about the restaurant, giving myself a refresher course on its history, I was reminded that its interior is actually an official city landmark, designated as such by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Video: Panel on the Citys Middle Class
description: The Drum Major Institute has posted a video of a panel discussion, How Do We Make New York City a Place Where it is Possible to Become, and Remain, Middle Class? The panel was part of a half-day conference at Baruch College on Monday. On the panel were Adolfo Carrin Jr., the Bronx borough president; Councilman John C. Liu of Queens; Maria Thomson of the Woodhaven Business Improvement District; and Representative Anthony D. Weiner of Queens and Brooklyn. The video is here:

title: Earnings Growth Slows
description: Standard & Poors is out with what it says are final figures for growth in S.&.P. 500 operating earnings per share in the fourth quarter of last year, finding them to be up 8.9 percent from the same quarter a year earlier. That ended a string of 18 quarters of gains of 10 percent or more.

title: Web 2.008
description: A sampling of some of the latest campaign goings-on in cyberspace:

title: Blogtalk: Make It a Double (Latte)
description: Do celebrities (pierced or not) really go to Starbucks? [Starbucks Gossip]

title: Live From Gloomy Busch Stadium
description: The rain has stopped and the tarp is off the Busch Stadium infield, but the inclement weather still prevented the Mets from hitting outside. Some players hit in the indoor cage while others lounged on the clubhouse couches watching the Giants-Padres game and some lefthander named Barry Zito. Perhaps youve heard of him.

title: Faster Trains to a Cleaner World?
description: A French high-speed train speeds over a viaduct near Aix-en-Provence.Claude Paris/AP

title: Old Neighbors, One Floor and Decades Apart
description: I was happy to learn the other day that Nicky Anosike, Tennessees starting center in the N.C.A.A.s womens national title game tonight, is back in my neck of the woods. Were old neighbors, one floor and a couple of decades apart.

title: Blogtalk: McCain Draws the Heat
description: The last several days have been busy ones for Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and the blogosphere has trapped that buzz.

title: Baseball Around the Globe
description: The first pitch of 2007 was thrown to the Mets Jose Reyes, who is from the Dominican Republic. Reyes is one of the most dynamic players in Major League Baseball, a sport that continues to expand internationally.

title: Finale
The 25 Questions
description: I got the idea for this piece from mathematician David Hilberts well-known list of 23 Paris Problems (1900) that he hoped to see solved in the new century. Of course there is not the slightest connection between Hilberts list of problems and this list of questions. Not to mention the fact that many of these questions contain the answers simply in the asking.

title: The 25 Questions
description: I got the idea for this piece from mathematician David Hilbert's well-known list of 23 "Paris Problems" (1900) that he hoped to see solved in the new century. Of course there is not the slightest connection between Hilbert's list of problems and this list of questions. Not to mention the fact that many of these questions contain the answers simply in the asking.

title: The E.P.A. Fantasy: Science Conquers All
description: Now that the Supreme Court has ordered the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate emissions of carbon dioxide from cars, which of these scenarios is most likely?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about the deepening crisis in Ukraine misidentified the political leader affiliated with the Our Ukraine Party. He is President Viktor A. Yushchenko, not Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich.

title: Central Bank Leaves Interest Rate Unchanged
description: Australias central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a six-year high, giving policy makers time to study an inflation report later this month that may prompt an increase. The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia left the overnight cash rate target at 6.25 percent for a fourth consecutive meeting after raising it a quarter percentage point in November.

title: Its Howells Hometown, but Woods Is the Favorite
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3  A few zigzag turns from Augusta National Golf Club, at the end of a cul-de-sac on a leafy street, sits the house where Charles Howell III grew up.

title: Yankees Pettitte Can Still Hear Cheers From 2003
description: There have been no World Series games in the Bronx since Oct. 25, 2003, and no more games there for the losing pitcher that night, Andy Pettitte.

title: A Mentor Teaches How to Become Wise in the Ways of Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Sports Briefing
description: pro football

title: Palmer Content to Be Honorary Starter at Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3  Three years after Arnold Palmer retired from playing the Masters, he will stand on the first tee Thursday and hit a drive as the tournaments honorary starter. Palmer, a four-time champion, played in 50 consecutive tournaments after making his first appearance in 1955.

title: Clowns, Daredevils and Plenty of Volume
description: Fine circus is a subtle brew of miracle and spectacle. As well balanced as a high-wire act without a net, it blends physical feats from clowning to trapeze daredevilry with captivating costumes, artful lighting and thoughtful music. But somewhere along the way to the 137th edition of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, the balance has tipped. Heavily amplified music, pounding with seeming relentlessness throughout the 2-hour 10-minute show (including intermission), has become a distraction.

title: Captors Release Kidnapped Iranian Diplomat in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, April 3  An Iranian diplomat kidnapped by armed men wearing uniforms of the Iraqi security forces was freed here on Tuesday, Iraqs foreign minister said, adding that he continued to work to free five Iranians held separately by American military forces and was optimistic that they would be released soon.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Wendi Sanders Berger was named publisher at Fitness magazine, New York, part of the Meredith Corporation. She succeeds Lauren Buerger, who recently resigned, the company said. Ms. Berger had been publisher of another Meredith magazine, Child, which the company plans to close.

title: News Corp. Shareholders Accept Liberty Deal
description: Shareholders of the News Corporation have approved an $11 billion asset swap that increases Rupert Murdochs control over the company and transfers the DirecTV Group to Liberty Media, controlled by John C. Malone.

title: A $16 Billion Bid for Australian Retailer
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 3  A consortium of companies offered on Tuesday to buy the troubled retailer Coles on terms that value it at $16 billion, which would be the largest takeover attempt in Australia.

title: Competition Defines a Friendship
description: Cleveland

title: Toyota Is Up in Sales; G.M., Ford and Chrysler Fall
description: Detroits automakers stumbled in March while their Asian competitors took a sizable leap forward.

title: A New Decree From Chvez: Less Elbow-Bending
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 3  Many Venezuelans shrug off President Hugo Chvezs increasingly frequent calls to create a New Man through a Socialist revolution. But a decree severely limiting alcohol sales for much of Holy Week has certainly gotten their attention.

title: Recipe: Falafel
description: Time: 1 hour, plus 24 hours soaking

title: Wyandanch: Man Accused of 8 Burglaries
description: A man has been arrested in connection with eight burglaries in Suffolk County over the past three months, the police said yesterday. The man, Wayne Toney, 23, of Wyandanch, was arrested on Monday shortly after a robbery in which someone kicked in a house door and stole jewelry, the Suffolk County police said. After a further investigation, the police said, Mr. Toney was also arrested in connection with robberies in which copper pipes were stolen from houses heating systems. He was charged yesterday with eight counts of second-degree burglary in Suffolk County District Court, the police said.

title: On Easter, Symbolism and the Exuberance of Spring

One Easter, on a farm outside the old Samnite town of Venafro in Molise, I shared a 40-egg frittata made by the farmers wife. It wasnt the best frittata I ever had, but it surely was the holiest.

title: The Red-Meat Miracle, and Other Tales From the Butcher Case

My brother and sisters and I especially loved what we called red meat, which was beef cooked rare. The color was a big part of it, a vivid promise of juicy, mouth-filling flavor, nothing like the dull look of pork or chicken or pot roast. It may not have been up there with the loaves and fishes, but it seemed miraculous to me that red meat could come from the stolid creatures we saw  and smelled  on our after-dinner drives through the countryside.

title: Recalling a Time When a Street Divided Two Worlds

In the Lancashire mill town of his childhood, during the teens and twenties of the last century, the poor Jews clustered along a single dead-end street, and even that was only half theirs. Christians lived on one side, Jews on the other, separated by a few feet that might as well have been hundreds of miles. The Invisible Wall, Mr. Bernsteins heart-wrenching memoir, describes two cultures cohabiting uneasily, prey to misunderstandings that distort lives on both sides. It is a world of pain and prejudice, evoked in spare, restrained prose that brilliantly illuminates a time, a place and a family struggling valiantly to beat impossible odds.

Today, the United States is the only major country in the world where the private sector plays such a big role in caring for the old and the sick.

The response has been mixed, said Lovemore Madhuku, chairman of the National Constitutional Alliance, a coalition of rights groups, churches and labor unions that is demanding a new constitution. Most shops and banks seem to be open, but theres very little traffic and very little sign of business taking place.

title: Pakistan: Protest at Court Hearing on Suspended Judge
description: About two thousand lawyers and opposition supporters chanting Go, Musharraf! and other slogans against President Pervez Musharraf protested outside the Supreme Court in Islamabad as the countrys suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, left, appeared before a panel of judges to defend himself on charges of misuse of power. Similar protests were held in other cities. The panel adjourned the private proceedings until April 13. Mr. Chaudhrys lawyers urged an open hearing. Demonstrations and lawyers strikes have erupted around the country since General Musharrafs decision on March 9 to suspend the independent-minded Mr. Chaudhry. Opponents say General Musharraf suspended him to weaken the judiciary. At the protest in Islamabad, flags of an alliance of religious parties and flags of the political parties of the exiled prime ministers Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif fluttered in abundance.

The unit, based in Warwick, England, owns more than 2,500 sites and has contracts with its parent for access to electricity transmission towers, National Grid said. Arqiva, based in Hampshire, England, offers networking services to broadcasters and mobile phone companies including the Vodafone Group, Telefnica, O2 and Orange of France Tlcom. Macquarie is based in Sydney, Australia.

Neighbors became concerned when they had not seen Mr. McKeon for several days, the police said. They notified the police after entering the house and found him dead in the kitchen with bruises on his body. The police said they were on the lookout for someone Mr. McKeon knew. Lt. James H.
