description: Images from Lynn Davis's show at the Rubin Museum.

title: Dress Codes: Grays
description: Gray, the new navy blue. Not as traditional or boring as light blue or khaki, but not as racy or impractical as white.

title: Failed Bidders for Tribune Plan Their Next Move
description: The news that Samuel Zell is becoming the new chairman of Tribune and has no plans to sell any of its individual newspapers has not discouraged potential buyers  and even his rival bidders  from planning their next move.

title: News Corp. Shareholders Accept Liberty Deal
description: Shareholders of the News Corporation have approved an $11 billion asset swap that increases Rupert Murdochs control over the company and transfers the DirecTV Group to Liberty Media, controlled by John C. Malone.

title: Australian Group Buys Canadian Casinos
description: Australias biggest gaming company, Publishing & Broadcasting, which is owned by James D. Packer, agreed Wednesday to buy casinos in Canada for 1.37 billion Canadian dollars ($1.2 billion). Mr. Packer joined with the Macquarie Bank to buy Gateway Casinos Income Fund, a casino operator in western Canada, for 886 million Canadian dollars, Publishing & Broadcasting said. The venture also offered to buy two closely held casino management companies.

title: Nikko Shareholders Pressure Citigroup to Raise Its Bid
description: Shareholders of the brokerage firm Nikko Cordial have started a campaign to force Citigroup to raise its takeover offer of $13.4 billion for the firm, placing sell orders in the market at a higher price. Investors had placed sell orders for 122 million Nikko shares at 1,900 yen (about $15) on the Tokyo exchange Wednesday morning, up from 71 million at the close of trading on Tuesday, according to Instinet Japan.

title: Comcast to Acquire Cable Operator
description: Comcast, the nations largest cable operator, said Tuesday that it was buying a small New Jersey cable operator for $483 million. Analysts said the price was high in light of the number of subscribers but understandable given the customers affluence. The operator being acquired, Patriot Media and Communications, serves 81,000 video subscribers in central New Jersey, many of them in upscale neighborhoods that fit in with Comcasts service area.

title: For Wrigley, a Candy-Merger Conundrum
description: The prospect that Cadbury might merge with Hershey, though still merely speculation, would put Wm. Wrigley in an awkward spot, Breakingviews writes. Wrigley might like to bid for Hershey itself, but Wrigleys shares have have lost much of their flavor in recent years as the company failed to prove its prowess at deal-making.

title: Macquarie Acquires British Wireless Unit
description: The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group agreed to buy the British wireless network division of National Grid for 2.5 billion pounds ($4.93 billion) and combine the unit with its Arqiva broadcast business.

title: Inland Americans Pushiness Pays Off with Winston Acquisition
description: After forcing its way into the bidding, the Inland American Real Estate Trust has won the fight for Winston Hotels for about $458 million. In February, Winston Hotels of Raleigh, N.C., agreed to be acquired by private-equity interests in New York, but last month Inland American pushed its way into the picture by making an unsolicited $15-a-share proposal.

title: Novartis Leads $13.4 Million Round for MicroChips
description: MicroChips has secured $13.4 million in a round of funding led by the Novartis Venture Fund, the venture capital arm of Swiss drug giant Novartis. Other investors include CSK Venture Capital of Japan, Polaris Venture Partners, IDG Ventures, Medtronic, Boston Scientific, and the Boston University Community Technology Fund.

title: The Long Goodbye of Fred the Cat
description: For more than a year, Michael Brick, the Brooklyn courts reporter for The Times, has been chronicling the brief law enforcement career of Fred the Undercover Cat. Fred is gone, but his biggest case  well, his only case  endures. The latest installment is in The Times today.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Dials Up a Deal for Tropic
description: Alcatel-Lucent said it would buy Tropic Networks, a Canadian network equipment company created by Nortel Networks and other Canadian tech giants. Terms for the transaction were not disclosed. The deal is the result of a three-year relationship between Tropic and Alcatel, which led a $33-million round of financing for Tropic in 2004.

title: Surface Logix Gets $20 Million in Series D Round
description: Closing a $52 million Series D round of financing, Bostons Surface Logix has raised $20 million to help fund clinical development of its small molecule drug candidates. The round was fed by existing investors such as Venrock Associates, Arch Venture Partners, CW Group, HBM BioVentures, and Unilever Technology Partners.

title: Citigroup Hires New Chief of Asia Mining and Metals
description: Citigroup hired an executive from UBS to head its metals and mining operations in Asia, Finance Asia reported Wednesday. The executive, Alexander Molyneux, will become managing director of the division in mid-April after leaving UBS in Australia where he was most recently an executive director in the investment banking team.

title: Lone Star Confirms Asset Sale
description: The investment fund Lone Star confirmed widespread rumors on Wednesday that it would sell two of its South Korean holdings. Following a legal battle that forced it to abort a planned $7.3 billion sale of the Korea Exchange Bank last November, the fund is selling Kukdong Engineering and Construction and STARLease. ABN Amro is serving as Lone Stars adviser.

title: Currents
description: Take a peek at the homes of the rich, mercury glass and sarrine-inspired tweed and more.

title: Debt May Not Deter Wall Street from Veraz I.P.O.
description: In an initial public offering expected to raise about $99 million, Veraz Networks of San Jose, Calif., becomes the latest in a series of tech firms to catch Wall Streets eye this week despite the red ink at their bottom lines. MarketWatch reported that Veraz, a maker of voice over Internet protocol equipment, will offer 9 million shares at $10 to $12 each with underwriters Credit Suisse and Lehman Brothers.

title: Sirius, XM Peeved Over Broadcasters Sponsored Report
More Payment Processors Seen as Buyout Targets
description: With the financial sector already among the busiest for mergers, private equity firms and other buyers are looking deeper at behind-the-scenes payment processors and business-services providers as takeover targets, analysts said on Tuesday.

title: S.E.C. to Debate Sarbanes-Oxley
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is set to meet Wednesday to consider whether it should ease a part of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which imposed new duties on corporate executives and accountants after a series of fraud-ridden business collapses in 2002.

title: Trans-Atlantic Exchange to Be Listed Today
description: The chiefs of the merged New York Stock Exchange and Euronext said Tuesday, on the eve of the opening day of trading of its shares, that they were determined to create a truly global market that would include operations in China.

title: Eni Wins Gazprom Auction
description: In an auction Wednesday in Moscow, Eni, Italys state-run oil company, won the bid for a stake in Gazproms oil unit, a step that will help the Russian government reclaim the assets of the jailed billionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky.

title: Personal Shopper
description: A nap in a colorful wildflower meadow, without the pollen and bees.

title: Report Says China to Reject Carlyles Bank Stake Bid
description: The Carlyle Groups bid to buy part of Chongqing City Commercial Bank is expected to be rejected, according to Bloomberg News. The nay comes as China is cracking down on buyout firms based on concerns that they are not adding enough value and are only seeking short-term profits that do not improve the companies they buy.

title: Blackstone May Strike Deal with Chinese Plastics Maker
description: The Blackstone Group is in talks to buy into Chinas Guofeng Group, the countrys biggest plastics products manufacturer, Reuters reported on Wednesday citing sources it did not identify. Blackstone has been in talks with Guofeng Group, based in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui for several months, though no deal has been signed yet, the sources said.

title: Global Crossing Chief Sees Potential for Buyout Interest
description: Global Crossing may be attractive to private equity firms as it wins more customers for the fiber-optic network that forced the company into bankruptcy five years ago, the chief executive, John Legere, said in an interview with Bloomberg News. But he added that Temasek Holdings, which is Global Crossings majority owner, has no immediate reason to sell its stake, and an analysts said Temasek is likely to wait a year and a half or so before considering it.

title: Goldmans Top Hedge Fund Dropped 5.7 Percent in February
description: Goldman Sachss flagship hedge fund, Global Alpha, lost 5.7 percent in February, hurt by positions in stocks, global bonds and currencies including the Japanese yen. The decline left the $10 billion fund down 2 percent for the year through Feb. 28, according to a monthly update sent to investors. That compared with an average gain of 1.9 percent for hedge funds worldwide, according to data compiled by Hedge Fund Research in Chicago.

title: DaimlerChrysler Confirms Talks to Sell Chrysler
description: DaimlerChryslers chairman, Dieter Zetsche, said Wednesday that the German-American automaker has been in talks with potential buyers of its struggling Chrysler unit, confirming weeks of conjecture and rumor. Mr. Zetsche did not identify any of the interested parties, however, and said the company was still considering all options for the Chrysler business.

title: Bank of America to Lose Executive in U.S. Trust Deal
description: The Bank of America said Tuesday that Peter Scaturro, the chief executive of U.S. Trust, will not join the bank as originally planned when the two companies combine later this year. Mr. Scaturro, 47, will step down from U.S. Trust before the transaction is completed, a Bank of America spokeswoman said, declining to comment on the reason for his departure. Mr. Scaturro had been expected to become head of Bank of Americas private-banking business after it purchased U.S. Trust from Charles Schwab.

title: Living With Art
In the groove
description: So the white spots on the side of the soft tires of the F1 cars  that failed to be visible to spectators at the first race  will be replaced by a white-painted groove on the surface of the tire that touches the track. While this news is now a few days old, what is more interesting at the moment is that the weather forecast at the moment is for rain on Friday, Saturday AND Sunday. and so wet tires will be the story of the day, not the soft tires.

title: Early Birds Get the Interview
description: New York is known as a city that never sleeps, and some Toyota executives apparently do not, either.

title: Fading Away
description: Bert Teunissen casts an eye on ways of life that are fading away.

title: CKE to Buy Back Shares from Pirate Capital
description: CKE Restaurants, which owns, runs and franchises restaurant brands including Carls Jr. and Hardees, said Tuesday it had agreed to buy back 4.1 million shares of its stock for $77.3 million, or $18.97 a share. The company is purchasing the shares from Pirate Capital, an activist hedge fund, through an already-announced stock repurchasing plan. The shares amount to 6.1 percent of its total outstanding shares as of April 3.

title: Keen on Corfu?
description: Stunning

title: Is McCain Melting Down?
description: During this early stage of the invisible primary, John McCains presidential campaign is foundering. So decrees the punditocracy, in its accumulated wisdom. Joe Klein pronounces himself boggled by McCains recent Baghdad stroll. I mean, you might disagree with him on an issue, but hes usually been honorable and intellectually honest about his position. No longer, Klein writes at Swampland, the Time political blog. This is the sort of flagrant, Bushian baloney-slicing that he ran against in 2000. Is it his faltering campaign? Is it age? Its sad to see a good man embarrass himself in this way.

title: What About Bill?
description: What role the spouses of John Edwards and Rudy Giuliani would play during their theoretical presidencies has been discussed recently by the nations political prognosticators. The New Republics Michael Crowley wants to know: What about Bill? Crowley writes at The Plank:

title: Reader Responses
description: The following are excerpts to David Leonhardt's April 4 column on the layoffs at Circuit City and the corporate safety net:

title: 2008: Campaign Shuffles and New Ads
description: Senator John McCains sluggish first-quarter fundraising prompted a shakeup of his campaign team and a revamping of its strategy for garnering big donors. The Timess Adam Nagourney writes that Mr. McCains aides will adopt the big-donor bundler approach introduced by President Bushs first campaign in 2000 and that they have delayed an official announcement until after a major Iraq speech by the Arizona senator.

title: Trading Before First Data Bid May Spark S.E.C. Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is set to investigate suspicious trading activity in the days before Kohlberg Kravis Roberts offered to buy First Data, the credit card processor, for $29 billion, the Times of London reported Wednesday. At issue is a surge in the trading of call options in First Data shares days before Mondays announcement: About 80,000 of those options were sold last week, more than double the volume for all of February.

title: Zell Blasts Would-Be Partner Broad for Tribune Bid
description: Let the sniping begin. Samuel Zell, the billionaire real estate mogul who emerged as the likely new owner of Tribune on Monday, said that one of his rivals sought him out as a partner last month  only to go behind his back with another offer for the media empire. So Mr. Zell told the Chicago Tribune, according to a transcript obtained by The Los Angeles Times.

title: DoubleClick May Entice Buyers With Ad Exchange
description: If Google and Microsoft are circling DoubleClick  a bidding feud that has been reported but never acknowledged by any of the parties  it may be based partly on a new initiative that the online advertising firm announced Wednesday.

title: Campaign Cash: Obamas Total Rivals Clintons
description: Senator Barack Obamas presidential campaign announced today that it had raised at least $25 million in the first quarter of the year, a tally that is tantalizingly close to Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons fundraising in the same period.

title: Small (Car) Talk
description: Last night at dinner, I had the privilege of sitting with the new director of Fords SVT division, Hermann Salenbauch.

title: Ford Flexes Its Crossover Muscles
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Ford Flex full-size crossover

title: Rained Out in the Bronx
description: Andy Pettittes return to the mound at Yankee Stadium will have to wait at least one more day.

title: K.K.R. May Still Pursue Australias Coles
description: It may have been spurned once, but Kohlberg Kravis Roberts hasnt given up on Australias Coles yet. Though the supermarket giant said it has received an A$19.7 billion ($16 billion) buyout offer from Wesfarmers and others, K.K.R. said its consortium was still in pursuit. The consortium continues to look at the Coles business, a spokesman for the private equity firm told Reuters on Wednesday.

title:
With So Much to Choose From,
Why Such a Limited Menu?
description: So theres this sparrow on the front page of the Dining section today. Cute little bird, caught in a backyard in Brooklyn.

title: Starbucks Mystery  Solved!
description: We were a bit surprised by the overwhelming response (more than 170 comments) to our Starbucks post yesterday, so the metro desk has assigned some stringers to make the rounds at a few Starbucks shops talking to customers and employees about unions, piercings, coffee and what have you. Meanwhile, weve solved a mystery from that post  the location of the Starbucks store in the picture. It wasnt in the original caption information that we had, so we asked blog readers to guess.

title: Disclosure, Yes. Clarity? Keep Looking
description: Companies may be technically complying with new federal rules for disclosure of executive compensation, but Christopher Cox, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is suggesting that regulatory filings are often so long and incomprehensible that they arent really disclosure at all.

title: Clinton Holds Strategy  Not Fund-Raising  Session
description: Hows this for a coincidence? On the same morning that Barack Obamas presidential campaign released some of its fund-raising numbers for the first quarter of 2007, one of his chief rivals, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, is huddling at her Chappaqua home with her senior staff to talk about campaign strategy and the weeks ahead.

title: McCain Sets Speech, Announcement Dates
description: The campaign for Senator John McCain just released a schedule of events for later this month  as forecast by The Timess Adam Nagourney today  that includes forums for major policy speeches and, at the end of April, an official announcement tour of his presidential candidacy through the early primary/caucus states.

title: The Condom Giveaways 5 Million Mark
description: City health officials said today they gave away five million of the new subway-themed condoms in the first month following the product launch on Valentines Day.

title: Dont Hire Us    Save Your Money
description: One thing I love about New England (where I live part time) is that people are proud of how frugal they can be.

title: Interview: Volker Mornhinweg, Chairman of AMG
description: Talk about dedication. Nearly an hour after the AMG Black Series introduction, Volker Mornhinweg, who has been the chairman of AMG for a year-and-a-half, was still around the Mercedes-Benz booth and gracious enough to chat and even spill a few beans.

title: Ask the Metro Editor More
description: The metro editor, Joe Sexton, is still answering reader questions for the Talk to the Newsroom feature. Please send your questions to asktheeditors@nytimes.com.

title: Some Contrarian Advice on Chrysler: Keep It
description: Amid the rampant speculation about who might buy Chrysler  private equity firms? Canadians?  and what they might do with the beleaguered automaker, one analyst is putting forward an unusual argument. Mark B. Warnsman of Prudential Equity Group is asserting that DaimlerChrysler should stick with its Chrysler unit rather than dump it (though he said he suspects it will end up getting sold anyway).

title: The Orbach Campaign Presses On
description: Another round of the campaign for Jerry Orbach Way is scheduled for tonight at Roosevelt Hospital in Midtown.

title: The Mayors Wealth
description: For all the money Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has amassed, he sometimes seems a bit embarrassed to talk about it. Asked at a news conference if he had any quarrel with the accuracy of a new Fortune magazine article putting his fortune at more than $13 billion, the mayor was rendered speechless for a minute.

title: Skadden Names 29 New Partners
description: Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom, a New York law firm that often advises in big mergers and corporate restructurings, said Wednesday it promoted 29 attorneys to partner. The new partners include two members of its mergers and acquisitions group in New York  Jeffrey A. Brill and Kenneth M. Wolff  and two from its restructuring group in Chicago  Chris L. Dickerson and Ron E. Meisler. Below is the full list:

title: The King of the Road at Forty
description: The performance guru Carroll Shelby introduced, or rather reintroduced, the King of the Road Mustang at the 2007 New York auto show. Shelby introduced the original King of the Road model in 1967  at New York show.

title: Online Job Network Dice Files for I.P.O.
description: Dice Holdings, which runs career Web sites for technology and finance professionals, filed Wednesday to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering. Dice was acquired in 2005 by private equity firms General Atlantic and Quadrangle Group, which plan to sell an unspecified number of shares in the offering, according to the preliminary prospectus.

title: When It Rains, It Pours at Javits
description: The cars on display at the auto show look perfect and the exhibitors hire an army of people to keep them that way. This is a showcase, after all.

title: Environmental Ruling Fallout
description: Nearly every executive at the auto show has been asked how their company could be affected by this weeks Supreme Court ruling directing the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate carbon dioxide as a pollutant.

title: Protesting From the Rafters
description: First Toyota had to offer incentives to help move its new Tundra. Then on Wednesday, with the worlds press gathered, about five protesters from FreedomFromOil put up a banner over the front entrance of the Javits center criticizing the truck and the company for how they affect the environment. The police arrested most of the protesters quickly, but needed a cherry picker to get the last two. The banner came down with them.

title: Sloshing
description: Left to their own devices, and couches, humans instinctively resist change. Kings and C.E.O.s like it at the top. Workers dont volunteer to give up their jobs in the name of progress. Profits and productivity may create wealth, but how it gets into the right hands is another matter. Money doesnt flow  that sounds so planned. It sloshes. Theres a difference. As scary as it sounds, its the chaos of markets that keeps us well fed and out of trouble.

title: The Trax, the Beat and the Groove
description: Lawrence Ulrich, a contributing reporter to The New York Times, reviews three concept cars from General Motors.

title: The View From the Couches
description: On a snowy night in Ithaca, my four housemates and I sprawled on the mismatched couches of our quirky college abode. Since the start of our senior year, weve perfected couching (our word) to a T.

title: The Ultimate Relief Specialist
description: Creighton University pitcher Pat Venditte, believed to be the only ambidextrous pitcher in N.C.A.A. Division I baseball, performs in a game.

title: Fords Fields: Fashion Forward
description: Mark Fields has taken plenty of razzing the past year over his collar-length hair style, which has been universally described as a mullet.

title: A Modest Proposal for Job Flexibility
description: Circuit Citys move to fire its better-paid workers, the subject of David Leonhardts column  in Wednesdays Times, is a logical extension of the flexibile employment market that is more often praised than practiced in this country. Americans regularly criticize Western Europe for job protection policies that, by making it hard to fire people, also discourage hiring them in the first place.

title: Report From the Line at Starbucks
description: We asked Cassi Feldman, a freelance contributor to The Times, to visit a couple of Starbucks shops in Manhattan and talk to workers and customers, in light of our recent posts (here and here) arising from a federal labor complaint against the company. The Industrial Workers of the World, an ardently leftist union, began to organize Starbucks workers in 2004.

title: Blogtalk: Of Money, Scarves and Abortion
description: Money, head scarves, fundraising and abortion today gave political bloggers a large feast on which to feed.

title: Blogtalk: Extra Shots
description: Its getting warmer, time to argue in court about mass bike rides. [Runnin Scared]

title: Giuliani Stands His Ground on Abortion
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Maybe it was Yankee stadium that brought out the combative New Yorker in former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, but when he was asked about the treatment of his wife, Judith, by the press on Monday, he bluntly told reporters that they should back off and show some decency.

title: Ford Flex
description: New York Times contributing reporter Jerry Garrett reviews the Ford Flex.

title: Spitzer: I Won on Every Issue
description: As our friends at The Daily Politics are  reporting, Gov. Eliot Spitzer spent a half million dollars of his own money on television commercials rebutting the omnipresent ones that 1199 and the Greater New York Hospital Association aired to scale back the proposed Medicaid reductions.

title: The Countdown to Matsuzakas Debut
description: Call it Matsuzaka Mania or the Dissection of Daisuke. Whatever the moniker, it is percolating here in Kansas City, Missouri.

title: The Great White North
description: On Monday afternoon, I walked to lunch wearing flip-flops, a T-shirt and jeans. This morning, as I played tourist during an excursion to the Gateway Arch with some colleagues (and where I ran into Tom Glavine in the gift shop) I needed a sweater, my North Face fleece and gloves  and was still cold. The weather in St. Louis has been odd, to say the least, and during Willie Randolphs pregame session with reporters, he said the cold here reminds him of his Double-A season in 1974, when he played for the Pirates affiliate in Thetford Mines, Quebec, a small town in the south-central part of the province.

title: Mercedes-Benz C-Class
description: The Times's Jeremy Peters takes a look at the new Mercedes-Benz C-Class.

title: Romney in Iowa: A Call to Faith
description: URBANDALE  Mitt Romney, conducting a telephone conference call with potential Iowa caucus-goers tonight, told them he considered Jesus Christ to be his personal savior.

title: Scratching the Surface of General Motors Paint Jobs
description: Chris Webb, trends and exterior color designer for General Motors, has the daunting task of developing colors for all G.M. vehicles. Hopping from car to car throughout G.M.s auto show displays, the energetic Mr. Webb gave a fascinating and rapid-fire explanation of paint trends and technology. For example, did you know that many show cars  including a bright orange Camaro concept car here in New York  use special dyes to create a deeper tone? Problem is, he said, those dyes are U.V. unstable and fade in as little as six months.

title: Money Talks
description: The predominant topic this week has been fund-raising: candidates have reported their totals for the first quarter of 2007, from Senator John McCains $12 million to Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons $26 million. Posts below explore who raised what where, and who didnt. Now, which issue do you think the candidates need to address?

title: Maybe Shes Reappeared; Definitely Shes a Mystery
description: Laura Lippmans What the Dead Know is an uncommonly clever impostor story, so cagily constructed that it easily fulfills the genres two basic demands. First, Ms. Lippman is able to keep her reader guessing about the main characters disputed identity until the very end of this book. Second, when the revelation comes, it makes perfect sense, and it has been hiding in plain sight. This is not one of those mysteries with a denouement that feels tacked on, half baked or pulled out of thin air.

title: Editor of Playboy Indonesia Is Acquitted
description: JAKARTA, April 5  An Indonesian court acquitted the editor of Playboy Indonesia on indecency charges today, angering conservative Muslims who have been fighting to shut down the magazine since it first appeared last year.

title: Beltrn Has a Hot Start
description: ST. LOUIS, April 4  It took five and a third innings for the Mets to finally break through against their former closer, Braden Looper. And as has been the case this whole opening series, Carlos Beltrn was right in the middle of it.

title: Rain Delays Pettittes Return to Yankee Stadium
description: Andy Pettitte was hoping for cold weather for his return to the mound at Yankee Stadium, believing it would help his stamina. He was not quite sure he wanted what he got.

title: Bush Uses Recess to Fill Envoy Post and 2 Others
description: FORT IRWIN, Calif., April 4  President Bush used the Congressional recess on Wednesday to push through his choice to be ambassador to Belgium and to fill two domestic policy positions, provoking Democratic ire with all three appointments.

title: College Officers Profited by Sale of Lender Stock
description: The directors of financial aid at Columbia University, the University of Texas at Austin and the University of Southern California held shares in a student loan company that each of the universities recommends to student borrowers, and in at least two cases profited handsomely.

title: After Sudden Dismissal, Julien Speaks
description: Apparently, the Devils players were not the only ones stunned Monday when General Manager Lou Lamoriello fired Coach Claude Julien and then took over with the team in first place in the Atlantic Division and three games left in the regular season.

title: United Airlines Drops Fallon and Hires Start-Up Agency
description: United Airlines Drops Fallon

title: These Books, Possessed and Dangerous, Are for the Birds and Their Friends
description: Books are dangerous. At least that could be the moral of Final Fantasy Fables: Chocobo Tales, a quirky little game developed by h.a.n.d. for the Nintendo DS in which a possessed book tries to destroy the world.

title: New Mexico Bars Drug Charge When Overdose Is Reported
description: Struggling with an epidemic of drug fatalities, New Mexico has enacted a groundbreaking law providing immunity from prosecution for people who come forward to help drug users suffering overdoses.

title: Change in Qualifications for the Masters Tournament
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4  Billy Payne has made few alterations to Augusta National Golf Club, but he did decide to change the qualifications for invitations to the Masters tournament.

title: A Compact Digital Camera That Can Shoot in Low Light
description: Owners of digital single-lens reflex cameras can shoot in low light without flash by turning up their sensitivity controls. At settings of ISO 800 to 3200, the better cameras make pictures that are increasingly grainy, but still usable. At high settings, greater depth of field and faster shutter speeds make pictures sharper.

title: Irish Inquiry Faults Handling of Day of Attacks in 1974
description: DUBLIN, April 4  Although the decades of violent conflict over Northern Ireland have ended, an official report issued here on Wednesday demonstrated how the past still haunts the landscape.

title: Our Crumbling Foundation
description: Fifty-nine years ago this week  on April 3, 1948  President Truman signed the legislation establishing the Marshall Plan, which contributed so much to the rebuilding of postwar Europe. Now, more than half a century later, the U.S. cant even rebuild New Orleans.

title: Remember the Veterans (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Wealthy Connecticut School District Starts to Grapple With Racial Imbalance
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 4  More than half a century after the landmark desegregation ruling in Brown v. Board of Education, this overwhelmingly white and wealthy town is beginning to confront the yawning racial imbalance in its cozy, well-groomed neighborhood schools.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Ideas for the Pondscape

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Tuesday about the Juno awards, Canadas equivalent of the Grammys, misidentified the site of the awards ceremony. It was Saskatoon, Saskatchewan  not Toronto.

title: Tom Thumb Would Love to Wear the Latest in Bluetooth Headphones
description: Bluetooth stereo headphones dont come much smaller than the Plantronics Pulsar 260. These $110 wireless headphones, which can pick up streaming audio from phones and compatible MP3 players, weigh less than an ounce.

title: Iran Sets Free 15 Britons Seized at Sea
description: LONDON, Thursday, April 5  Iran on Thursday morning released the 15 British sailors and marines it seized at sea nearly two weeks ago, resolving a diplomatic impasse with what Irans president called a gift to the British people.

title: Qaedas New Leaders (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: From Tag Sale Experts, Words to Shop By
description: TAG sales can be found through local papers, community bulletin boards and signs along the road, but there are more comprehensive resources, including estatesales.net, a national online listing service, and Antiques and the Arts Weekly (antiquesandthearts.com), a newspaper serving antiques dealers and collectors. Tag sale regulars those who buy and those who sell  tend to develop their own philosophies about the best ways to shop. These are a few pointers.

title: Bronx Man Pleads Guilty in Terror Case
description: A jazz bassist and martial arts expert charged two years ago in an elaborate undercover terrorism investigation pleaded guilty yesterday to plotting to teach would-be Qaeda operatives how to wage jihad with hand-to-hand combat.

title: Photographing the Light in Places That May Soon Be Lost
description: But for the occasional modern accouterment  a microwave in Belgium, a row of 2005 calendars in Spain  Bert Teunissens photographs of Europeans at home could have been captured in the remote corners of the continent a century or two ago. Weathered faces gaze out from surroundings patinaed through generations of use. Fireplaces the size of caves radiate heat across stone-slab floors. Hams and sausages age on hooks dangling from massive wooden beams. A dog wiles away a lazy lifetime at its owners feet.

title: IPhone Killer (or Perhaps a Worthy Rival)
description: While smart-phone makers cower in the looming shadow of the June release of the iPhone from Apple, a small cellphone service provider called Helio is introducing a device that is getting plenty of buzz.

title: Daimlers Chief Confirms Talks to Sell Chrysler
description: BERLIN, April 4  DaimlerChrysler insists it is keeping all options open for the future of the Chrysler Group. But judging by its tense annual meeting here on Wednesday, Daimlers marriage to Chrysler is already finished  except for the ink on the divorce papers.

title: The Met Shows Off Its Hits and Misses
description: The Metropolitan Operas 40th-anniversary gala on Tuesday gave a reasonably accurate account of what life in the Mets Lincoln Center home has been and what it hasnt been. There were scenes from Puccinis Bohme, Massenets Manon and Donizettis Elisir dAmore. The tenor Rolando Villazn and the soprano Anna Netrebko showed up in all three.

title: For a Reds Prospect, Dreaming the Big League Dream, Again
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Two batters were due up ahead of him, but Carson Kainer had a batting helmet on and a bat in his hands. That is how eagerly Kainer awaited his first intrasquad game at-bat as a Cincinnati Reds minor leaguer, his first walk to the plate in more than nine months.

title: Discovery to Start Channel Focusing on Green Movement
description: Discovery Communications, the cable channel operator, plans to start a 24-hour channel focused on eco-friendly living, as part of a push into the rising environmental movement.

title: The Consequences of Corn
description: By now most farmers know what theyll be planting this spring. And all across the country the answer is the same: corn, corn, corn. The numbers are surprising. Farmers will plant some 90.5 million acres of corn this year  12 million more than last year and the most since 1944. Soybean acres are down by more than 10 percent, and there are similar decreases in wheat and cotton. The reason for this enormous shift is, of course, the ethanol boom and the corn rush it has created.

title: TiVo Plays a Trump Card: Web Smarts
description: What is it with the rash of new set-top boxes lately? One recent box brings the best of the Internet to your TV screen, like podcasts, Web videos and Internet radio. Another one is a video recorder that you can operate from anywhere in the world (for example, tell it to record a show), using only your cellphone.

title: Israels Protests Are Said to Stall Gulf Arms Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 4  A major arms-sale package that the Bush administration is planning to offer Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf allies to deter Iran has been delayed because of objections from Israel, which says that the advanced weaponry would erode its military advantage over its regional rivals, according to senior United States officials.

title: Bronx: Death From 1977 Wound a Homicide
description: The death of a man who survived nearly 30 years after being paralyzed by a sniper was ruled a homicide yesterday after the city medical examiner found that he had died as a result of his wound. The man, Gilberto Medina, 70, died at home of an infection on March 21. On Oct. 25, 1977, he was shot on a Bronx street in what the police called a random act. He was hit in the spine, a wound that left him paralyzed from the waist down. No one was arrested in the case. The reclassification of Mr. Medinas death comes after several similar cases in which people died years after they were shot, stabbed or otherwise assaulted. There were 35 such reclassifications last year, the police said, roughly three times the historical average.

title: Randolph Grabs a Chance to Proudly Wear No. 42
description: ST. LOUIS, April 4  Willie Randolph was 2 years old when Jackie Robinson played his final game for the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1956, so he was too young to have watched him play in person. Robinsons legacy lives on in the photographs scattered around his office and, for one day this season, on the back of Randolphs jersey.

title: U.N. Draft Cites Humans in Current Effects of Climate Shift
description: The latest United Nations assessment of the role of humans in global warming has found with high confidence that greenhouse gas emissions are at least partly responsible for a host of changes already under way, including longer growing seasons and shrinking glaciers.

title: Eddie Robinson, 88, Pioneer Grambling Coach, Is Dead
description: Eddie Robinson, who in 55 seasons as the football coach at Grambling State University won a record number of games, mentored scores of future professional players and helped bring racial awareness to a segregated Southern society, died late Tuesday night in Ruston, La. He was 88 and lived in Grambling, La.

title: Flying Toward Competitive Skies
description: International air travel is an example of an industry where arcane, out-of-date rules have held back growth and investment for too long. The deal between the European Union and the United States to modernize and rationalize the governance of the $18 billion trans-Atlantic aviation market is a welcome one for consumers.

title: Correction: Got Crows-Feet? Call the Downward Dog
description: An article last week comparing stretching classes misspelled the given name of an instructor who teaches active isolated stretching. She is Susana Picheny, not Susan.

title: Mainstay Soprano Feels Snubbed by the Met
description: Ruth Ann Swenson, a mainstay soprano at the Metropolitan Opera, will take the stage tomorrow to begin a run of Handels Giulio Cesare just six weeks after finishing chemotherapy for breast cancer.

title: Equity Firm Is Seen Ready to Sell a Stake to Investors
description: Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black, is seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, according to people close to the firm.

title: Germany: Siemens Unit Files Patent Case
description: A unit of Siemens, the biggest engineering company in Europe, sued Saint-Gobain Ceramics and Plastics, contending infringement of a patent for a radiation detector that is used in medical diagnostic scanners. Siemens Medical Solutions USA said the United States unit of Saint-Gobain, a European building materials supplier, was wrongly using the technology in marketing PreLude 420 crystals for scanners that produce images from radioactive materials injected into the body to detect diseases like cancer. The suit was filed in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del. Siemens is based in Germany and Saint-Gobain is based in France.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about problems facing the Smithsonian Institution misidentified the museum criticized by experts as having as its chief weakness its later-20th-century and contemporary collection. It is the Smithsonian American Art Museum  not the National Gallery of Art, which is not part of the Smithsonian.

title: Early 08 Fund-Raising Has Clear Blue Tint
description: DES MOINES, April 4  For anyone looking for a sign of the health of the Democratic Party going into the 2008 presidential campaign, it came Wednesday with the last of the fund-raising figures reported by the major presidential candidates.

title: No Such Thing as Junk
description: EARLY on a Sunday morning in March, a crowd of people hovered anxiously outside a modest Long Island home in Floral Park. A few of them had been there since before daylight  one since 3 a.m.  alternately dozing, pacing and peering through the windows of the house. By 9, those closest to the front door were starting to pound on it. Finally, the door opened a crack, and Mona Scavo, a tall woman with blond highlights, looked out at the crowd. O.K., were going to stay calm, right? she said in the friendly but firm tone of a kindergarten teacher. Ms. Scavo was there to run a tag sale, and it was clear she didnt want any trouble. Her customers have been known to shove their way through the front door as soon as it opens; on one occasion, a dispute between a few of them brought half a dozen police cars to the scene.

title: For Neutral Grays, the Mood Is Positive
description: SPRING, which in recent years has welcomed an Easter parade of colors in the mens wear department, is now humming a more sober song.

title: Judge Seeks Lower Profile for Astronaut Case
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 5  A judge said today that he would seal any psychological evaluations of Lisa Nowak, the former astronaut accused of trying to kidnap a romantic rival.

title: Trust Sued Over Backing Retiree Plan
description: A lawsuit filed in federal court in Manhattan last week contends that a retirement plan offered by the New York State United Teachers breached its fiduciary duty when it accepted millions of dollars in payments from an investment firm in exchange for endorsing the firms products to plan members.

title: Budget Gains for Fish and Farms, Not Judges
description: ALBANY, April 4  New York State is getting another fish pathologist. A million dollars is going to jump-start the effort to provide cellphone service along a major highway in the Adirondacks where a Brooklyn man died, unable to get a signal. And the states dairy farmers will get $30 million to help them recover from a bad year.

title: New York City Plans to Promote Circumcision to Reduce Spread of AIDS
description: New York Citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene is planning a campaign to encourage men at high risk of AIDS to get circumcised in light of the World Health Organizations endorsement of the procedure as an effective way to prevent the disease.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Nikolaj Hbbe to Lead Danish Ballet

title: Calendar
description: Green Architecture

title: Almost Like Having a Personal Secretary in the Kitchen
description: You rarely realize your kitchens running short of something until you are busy cooking  and then, inevitably, the pencil for the shopping list is missing. Luckily, theres a gadget that will let you dictate it.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,251 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: More Money for Agency That Oversees States Judges
description: New York States new budget will nearly double financing for the Commission on Judicial Conduct, the agency that investigates and disciplines judges throughout the state court system  including the town and village courts that have recently come under strong criticism.

title: One Side Declines to Gamble, and the Other Finishes Strong
description: Robert Heitzman Jr. of Suffern, N.Y., and Jonathan Weinstein of Evanston, Ill., finished second in the Lebhar Imp Pairs at the Spring North American Championships in St. Louis last month, 17 imps behind Boye Brogeland from Norway and Ishmael DelMonte from Australia. Heitzman and Weinstein scored well on the diagramed deal.

title: Online Experiment for Print Magazine
description: READERS of a weekly newsmagazine will soon be getting a bonus issue, but they will miss it if they look in mailboxes or on newsstands.

title: Director Wants More Authority in Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (Bloomberg News)  The top United States intelligence official said Wednesday that his position lacked the authority needed to run the countrys 16 intelligence agencies.

title: Chihuahua or Great Dane? One Gene Sets Dog Size
description: If it werent for IGF-1, Paris Hiltons life would be a lot less elegant.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline on Friday about a planned vote in Congress over the widespread killing of Armenians by the Ottoman Turkish government early in the 20th century incorrectly described the killings, in which 1.5 million Armenians died. It was genocide, not a massacre.

title: A Coach Who Symbolized a Golden Age of Football
description: Everybody knew the end was near for Eddie Robinson: James Harris and Doug Williams, Robinsons cornerstone quarterbacks at Grambling State University; the sprawling Grambling family; the news media that covered Robinsons historic moments. We all knew. His health had been in steady decline for months.

title: Discovery of Serbia Training Camp Draws Attention to Radical Islamists
description: NOVI PAZAR, Serbia, March 30  Security officials in this region of southern Serbia say they have found a base about 20 miles north of town that they believe was a training ground for radical Islamists who were planning an attack on members of the local Muslim community.

title: Nina Wang, 69, Outr Star of Hong Kong Estate Tussle, Dies
description: Nina Wang, reported to be the richest woman in Asia, who won control of her husbands Hong Kong real-estate empire after a tumultuous legal melodrama that featured a vanishing tycoon, a presumed death, charges of forgery and adultery, opium and impossibly short skirts, died on Tuesday in Hong Kong. She was 69 and had lived in Hong Kong for many years.

title: U.S. Is Reviewing Request by Iran to Let Its Envoy Visit 5 Iranians Seized in a Raid in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April 4  American officials are reviewing an informal request from the Iranian government for an envoy to visit five Iranians who were imprisoned after an American raid in northern Iraq in January, an American military spokesman said Wednesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the origins of the Etruscans referred incorrectly to the location of Lydia, an ancient region from which the Etruscans might have migrated to Italy. Lydia was in what is now western Turkey; there is no east coast of Turkey.

title: A Daughter Stolen in Wartime Returns to El Salvador
description: CACAOPERA, El Salvador, April 3  Suzanne Marie Berghaus finally came home.

title: Bronx: Welfare Supervisor Arrested
description: The City Department of Investigation has arrested a supervisor at the Human Resources Administration on charges of diverting nearly $10,000 in public assistance to pay rent on her Bronx apartment, Investigation Department officials said yesterday. The employee, Cherie Heyward, 44, whose job included supervising a unit that processed authorizations for payments at the Rider Job Center, was involved in issuing 12 checks for $720 to $920 between October 2003 and March 2004, for a total of $9,786.91, the officials said. Those checks, they said, were ostensibly for Ms. Heywards companion, a client of the job center, but went instead to Ms. Heywards landlord. Ms. Heyward, who has been charged with third-degree grand larceny, faces up to seven years in prison.

title: Googles Chief Gets $1 in Pay; His Security Costs $532,755
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., April 4  It is not common for the salary of an American chief executive to be dwarfed by the cost of keeping that executive safe. But then, Google is an unconventional company.

title: Thinking Outside the Gap
description: FASHION is like sudoku. For designers, its a constant challenge of solving the same old problem. And for stores, its always a numbers game.

title: Obama Shows His Strength in a Fund-Raising Feat on Par With Clinton
description: DES MOINES, April 4  If there was any doubt that Senator Barack Obama could stand toe to toe with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, at least in raising money, the matter was settled on Wednesday as Mr. Obamas presidential campaign announced raising $25 million in the first three months of the year.

title: Newark: E.P.A. Clears Itself on Cleanup
description: A report released yesterday by the Environmental Protection Agency found no evidence of discrimination against the people who live near a site where several proposed cleanups under the Superfund program had failed. Senators Robert Menendez and Frank R. Lautenberg and Representative Frank Pallone Jr. had asked the agencys inspector general to investigate allegations that the agency had neglected the residential area near the Ringwood Mines  where the Ford Motor Company dumped paint sludge from its plant in Mahwah for many years  because the area was populated by Ramapough Indians. The report said that problems with communications hurt cooperation between the agency and residents and recommended improving relations. The lawmakers criticized the report and asked the agency to study the treatment of residents more fully. Compiled by John Harney

title: Cemex Bid for Rinker Advances
description: Cemex, the third-largest cement producer in the world, received clearance from United States antitrust regulators for its $11.7 billion hostile offer for the Rinker Group of Australia. The Justice Department said Cemex, based in Monterrey, Mexico, had agreed to sell 39 operations in Florida and Arizona to preserve price competition for large transportation projects in the two states. Rinker, based in Sydney, a building materials maker, gets about 80 percent of its sales in the United States.

title: Nets Lose Their Crowd on Way to a Rare Rout
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 4  With 12 minutes remaining Wednesday night, Continental Arena was already nearly empty, quiet and hollow. The life had been sucked out of the building, but for good reason.

title: An Army of Housewives Battles TB in Bangladesh
description: BETGARI, Bangladesh  In the golden haze of dawn, Mohammed Salim Sheikh walked slowly through the paddies, so frail and thin that the lungi wrapped around his waist looked like a clowns oversize trousers.

title: Marbury Lights It Up for the Fading Knicks
description: The latest devastating blow to the Knicks season  and the blows are coming in rapid progression now  came in the form of a remarkable lean-in jumper and a powerful block at the final buzzer.

title: The British Are Coming to Play American Roles
description: At the party HBO held last week for the closing season of The Sopranos, Ray Stevenson, who made the guest list as star of another HBO series, admitted he would have liked to be in the tunic of Titus Pullo for one more season of Rome.

title: Sweeping the Cardinals Looks as Easy as 1-2-3
description: ST. LOUIS, April 4  The fans at Busch Stadium sat huddled far too long on this blustery 41-degree night, and when Carlos Beltrns second home run in as many at-bats disappeared into the right-field stands in the seventh inning Wednesday night, they finally had an excuse to flee. They were fed up with how thoroughly the Mets had dismantled the Cardinals throughout this series, and the 10-0 demolition that completed their three-game sweep stuck with the theme.

title: Not an Orange Revolution
description: Once again, the streets of Kiev are filling with two bitterly opposed Ukrainian political camps. The cast is the same as in 2004  the westward-leaning Viktor Yushchenko versus the Russia-leaning Viktor Yanukovich. But this time its not clear that Mr. Yushchenko has the moral high ground, as he did in 2004, when he won an election and Mr. Yanukovich tried to steal it. This time, Mr. Yushchenko lost his parliamentary majority and is trying to get it back in a way that may not be legal. This is a dispute that needs to be settled in the courts, not the streets.

title: Cruises Studio Hires a Disney Executive
description: United Artists, the boutique film studio being revived under Tom Cruise and his producing partner, Paula Wagner, said yesterday that it had recruited a top executive from the film operation of the Walt Disney Company, Dennis Rice, as its president for worldwide marketing and publicity.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 11:30 P.M. (My Network TV) HAPPY BIRTHDAY, ELTON! Never mind the cake and candles: a celebration like this calls for a fireworks extravaganza. In honor of his 60th birthday and his record-breaking 60th concert at Madison Square Garden, Elton John, above, hams it up amid an explosion of confetti. Celebrities like Sharon Stone, Simon Cowell, Sharon Osbourne, Robin Williams, Whoopi Goldberg, Paul McCartney, the Beckhams and Mr. Johns longtime collaborator, Bernie Taupin, salute the rocket man.

title: Under the Spanish Moss, a River Runs Blood Red
description: The tagline for the inane horror flick The Reaping asks, What hath God wrought?

title: Woods Versus the Field, and Nicklauss 18 Majors
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4  It was midnight on the eve of the final round of the 1997 Masters, and Tiger Woods could not sleep.

title: Israeli Soldiers Kill Palestinian Trying to Plant a Bomb in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, April 4  Israeli soldiers shot dead a Palestinian who was trying to plant explosives in the northern Gaza Strip on Wednesday, Palestinian and Israeli officials said. It was the second clash in a week in the area near Beit Hanoun, a site from which rockets have frequently been fired toward Israel, despite a tenuous cease-fire since November.

title: Mommy and Daddys Little Life Coach
description: WHEN Helen Barahal was deciding whether to sell an East Harlem apartment she was renting to tenants, she asked her son, Marcus, for advice.

title: We, Myself and I
description: FOR Aysha Hussain, getting dressed each day is a fraught negotiation. Ms. Hussain, a 24-year-old magazine writer in New York, is devoted to her pipe-stem Levis and determined to incorporate their brash modernity into her wardrobe while adhering to the tenets of her Muslim faith. Its still a struggle, Ms. Hussain, a Pakistani-American, confided. But I dont think its impossible.

title: Manhattan: Man Held in Fathers Killing
description: A 35-year-old man fatally stabbed his 67-year-old father last night in a parked S.U.V. as his mother watched from the back seat, the police and witnesses said. The victim, Ying Du of Flushing, Queens, was taken to St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan, where he was declared dead on arrival, the police said. The son was taken into custody for questioning and a knife was recovered at the scene. The S.U.V., a Nissan Pathfinder, was parked in front of 64 West 37th Street, where the family business, Phoenix Jewelry, is situated, according to neighbors. Mr. Du was sitting in the passenger seat and his son was in the drivers seat when they began arguing shortly after 6 p.m., witnesses said. The son took out a pocket knife and stabbed his father in the torso, the police said. A store owner who witnessed the arrest said the suspect was pretty catatonic, comatose and was obviously in shock.

title: Exercisers Slow It Down With Qigong
description: CHUNYI LIN remembers the first qigong class he ever taught in the United States. In 1993, he traveled from China as part of a cultural exchange between schools, and was asked to teach at a community center in Inver Grove Heights, Minn.

title: Thailand Bans YouTube
description: BANGKOK, April 4  Thailands military-appointed government blocked access to YouTube and several other Internet sites on Wednesday in a crackdown on material that denigrates the countrys monarch.

title: Cupids Arrows and Southern Hip-Hop Beats
description: Ballet Memphis is something of a little engine that could, to perhaps sum up the imaginative grit of Dorothy Gunther Pugh, who has presided over the group with equal dashes of elegance and temerity for 20 years. On Tuesday night both ingredients were on display in a program of New York premieres at her companys Joyce Theater debut.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about an accusation by the National Labor Relations Board of unfair labor practices at four Starbucks coffee shops in Manhattan misstated part of the name of the union seeking to organize Starbucks employees in New York, and misidentified the organization that reached a settlement with Starbucks last year. The union is the Industrial  not International  Workers of the World, and the settlement was with the labor relations board, not with the union.

title: 3 Charged in 2005 London Transit Attacks
description: LONDON, April 5  British authorities charged three Muslim men today with conspiring to help with reconnaissance and planning for the July 2005 suicide-bombing attack on the London transit system, which killed 52 people.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 4, 2007

title: Push to Ease Testing of Disabled Pupils
description: The Department of Education wants to relax testing rules so children with disabilities like dyslexia can take easier exams than required under the No Child Left Behind Act. The change, if approved by Congress, could triple the number of students taking simplified tests, the department said. About 1 percent of all pupils now take them.

title: Claim Raises Questions About Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The owner of an Ohio nuclear plant has asked its insurance company to pay for two years of lost production after a corrosion problem that it called unexpected and unforeseeable, even though it had resisted government pressure to inspect for acid leaks just before the problem was uncovered in 2002.

title: The President and Global Warming (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about auto sales in March gave incorrect rankings in the How Automakers Fared section. A corrected chart is on Page C2 today. The chart also misidentified the make and model of a car shown as the Biggest Gainer. It was a Toyota Prius, not a Chevrolet Impala.

title: Residential Sales
description: Hawaii

title: Connecting Theater to Sexuality and Faith
description: Convince me. Thats what many would think going to a musical linking Christs passion with that of the hate-crime victim Matthew Shepard, the gay college student who was beaten and left for dead in Laramie, Wyo., in 1998.

title: New York Rivals Share Tangled Playoff Fates
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 4  The Rangers will play their final regular-season home game Thursday night, against Montreal, without much thought about the intricate mathematics of the playoff race. What they know is that a victory is the solution. For the past six weeks, as they climbed into contention, the Rangers have known that only their results matter.

title: Lady Vols Planning the Return Trip
description: CLEVELAND, April 4  As expected, Candace Parker did not enter the Womens National Basketball Association draft Wednesday, which was great news for Tennessee and potentially bad news for every other college team.

title: Officer Faces Charges Tied to a Shooting
description: A police officer has been indicted on charges of evidence tampering and official misconduct in connection with the shooting of a fellow officer, according to court documents unsealed yesterday.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How high over my dining table should I hang the light fixture?

title: Afghanistan: 2 French Aid Workers Missing
description: Two French aid workers are missing in southwestern Afghanistan, along with three Afghan workers, officials said. The aid workers set off on a journey with a driver, a guard and a cook on Tuesday morning and have not been heard from since, said Muhammad Daoud Askaryar, the police chief of Nimruz Province, which borders Iran. The French Foreign Ministry said the two worked for the nongovernment organization Terre dEnfance, which focuses on programs for children.

title: Italians Win Yukos Units, but Gazprom Is to Benefit
description: MOSCOW, April 4  Two Italian energy companies won an auction Wednesday for assets of the bankrupt Yukos oil company, then promptly announced they would sell most of the assets to the state-owned Russian gas giant Gazprom.

title: Lesson for Newarks Streets: Look Left, Right, Left Again
description: NEWARK, April 2  In this city where traffic signals are sometimes mockingly called suggestions, scores of children, walking or playing, have been hit by cars over the past few years, many of them within sight of their homes.

title: A Show of Force for Arnies Army at Augustas First Tee
description: Augusta, Ga.

title: Why That Hoodie Your Son Wears Isnt Trademarked
description: The growth of the Internet has created significant challenges for intellectual property law. Virtually every day there is another story about online copyright infringement of some form or another. Music, photos, film, video, books  all the content-producing industries are being shaken up.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page picture caption on Monday about casualties suffered by an American combat brigade in Diyala Province in Iraq misidentified an officer standing at right while a hospitalized soldier received a Purple Heart. He is Command Sgt. Maj. Ray Edgar  not Maj. Charlie Fenton, the brigades chaplain, who was not pictured.

title: Outside Audit Is Promised for New Jersey Pension Fund
description: TRENTON, April 4  Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Wednesday that he would ask independent auditors to examine state financial records to determine how severely the pension fund for state and local workers has been jeopardized by underfunding.

title: More PC Protection, Less Time Looking at an Hourglass
description: Aiming for people who do not like to buy multiple security and utility programs, Symantec recently released an all-in-one suite called Norton 360 for Windows. The package combines antivirus and antispyware tools, a firewall and other applications to help protect a PC from the Internets ills, along with a backup feature to keep data safe in case of hard-disk woes.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, schedule information yesterday with a music review of a concert in the Wordless Music Series misstated the date of the next concert in the series. It is April 30, not April 20, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on West 64th Street in Manhattan.

title: Women Entrepreneurs Take on Rugged Alaska
description: JUNEAU, Alaska  Its 9 a.m., the air temperature is 15, the Taku winds are blowing and the gun-smoke gray sky spews snow over Juneau. The February snow stacks up on the boat docks of Harris Harbor, but cannot match the knee-length brown rubber boots Laurie Lindsey wears.

title: Spring Harvest
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Tech-Driven Metro Areas Renew Their Population Gains
description: Several metropolitan areas that either lost population or experienced a decline in its growth when the high-tech bubble burst appear to have recovered in the year ended last July 1, new census figures for the nations metro areas show. But Rust Belt and many coastal areas continue to hemorrhage people.

title: The Clothes Closet at the Mad Scientists
description: FITTINGLY for a store in a neighborhood that desperately needs a style lift, Hollander & Lexer is named for two pioneering plastic surgeons from the early 1900s.

title: Whos Talking About Retirement?
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The procedure that Larry King underwent in mid-March to flush a blocked major artery  which put him at heightened risk of a stroke  also caused a few flutters among his bosses at CNN.

title: British Envoy Meets With Palestinian Leader
description: JERUSALEM, April 5  A senior British diplomat met with the Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya of Hamas, in Gaza today to discuss the fate of a kidnapped BBC correspondent, Alan Johnston. This was the first meeting between an official of a European Union-member country and a minister of the Islamic movement Hamas since a new Palestinian unity government was formed in mid March.

title: Shell Expects Full Output From Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 4  A year after being forced to shut more than half of its oil operations in Nigeria because of militant violence, Royal Dutch Shell says that it has reached an agreement with local communities allowing it to return safely to the Niger Delta and that it expects to resume full production within five to six months.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with the Advertising Column, about a digital exchange set up by DoubleClick, reversed the placement of two of its executives. Scott Spencer was at left, and Michael Rubenstein was at right. (David Rosenblatt was in the middle.)

title: From Europe, a No-Chlorine Backyard Pool
description: MICK HILLEARY, an industrial designer who builds zoo exhibits and trade show displays, and who expanded into residential pools five years ago, has found that Americans have a clearly defined idea of what constitutes a proper swimming pool.

title: A Novices-Eye View of Life and Sense in Theater
description: Athol Fugard casts a misty-eyed glance back at the man who ignited his affection for the rough magic of theater in Exits and Entrances, his latest play, which opened last night at the 59E59 Theaters in a Primary Stages production.

title: Maker of Tainted Pet Food Is Sued
description: Lawyers who filed a class-action lawsuit against Menu Foods, which recalled more than 90 brands of pet food last month, are alleging that the company knew the food was tainted but waited to recall it. The lawsuit, filed in Chicago on March 20 by a woman whose cat died after eating the food, is also seeking an injunction to keep Menu Foods from destroying contaminated food because it is evidence. Numerous other lawsuits have been filed against the company. The Food and Drug Administration said that it had received more than 10,000 complaints, and that tests of the food had found a chemical used to make plastic cutlery. A Menu Foods spokesman would not comment.

title: Rights Groups Hail Arrests of 3 by U.S. in War Crimes
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 4  Latin American human rights groups have reacted with satisfaction and muted surprise to the arrest in the United States of three Argentine and Peruvian former military officers accused of human rights abuses who had fled their home countries to avoid prosecution there.

title: Manhattan: Lifeline for the Homebound
description: The city is reviving a long dormant program to help postal workers alert the authorities when they suspect that a homebound or elderly person needs assistance, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Under the program, the city would provide the elderly and those with disabilities with special stickers, or magnets, to place in their mailboxes. If mail piled up in those boxes, mail deliverers could alert supervisors, who would report through 311 that a resident might be in distress. Workers at the Department for the Aging would then try to get in touch with the persons emergency contact or visit the home. Residents can register for the program through 311.

title: 7 U.S. and 4 British Soldiers Are Killed in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April 5  Seven American and four British soldiers were killed in separate attacks around Iraq, military officials said today, and an American helicopter crashed south of Baghdad, wounding four soldiers.

title: Facing Reality About the War (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Actors Widow Gains Traction in 2nd Try at Naming Corner
description: If at the first community board you dont succeed, try another one.

title: Fascination With Mantle Now Blends Fiction With Fact
description: Fifty-four years ago, the sports book genre that should be named MickLit was begun with the publication of The Mickey Mantle Story, an autobiography of the very young Mantle as told to Ben Epstein.

title: Queens: Man Killed After Cashing Check
description: A man was fatally shot yesterday morning in South Ozone Park after transferring money to Caribbean relatives at a check-cashing store, the police and his companion said. The man, Courtney Atkinson, 51, who worked as a skycap at the Delta Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport, left his home on 126th Street around 11 a.m. to cash his paycheck and forward the money to relatives in Jamaica, according to his companion, Novette Facey. He was returning to the store, on Rockaway Boulevard, after realizing that he had made an error in the transfer, Ms. Facey said. The police said he was shot once in the chest on his way to or from the store. Ms. Facey, 38, who is the mother of three of his children, said she became concerned when he did not return home, and went outside to look for him. She discovered his body, covered by a sheet, lying on their street. The police said that they did not know if robbery had been the motive, and that there were no arrests as of last night. Ms. Facey described Mr. Atkinson as a hardworking man and kind father who liked nothing better than to set a pot of chicken-foot soup on the stove and kick back to reggae and calypso music. She cried as she said: I loved him. I dont know how Im going to live without him.

title: Shaped by a Sculptors Hand, and Foot
description: WHEN a four-by-five-foot pine storage bin appeared in front of Markos Lambros Drakotoss five-story town house on East 81st Street last August, his neighbors were not pleased. It was this huge brown box and it was a garbage bin, said Christina Desbiez, who lives a few houses away. People were afraid it would attract rats, and it wasnt very attractive, either.

title: Circumcision and AIDS (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pelosis Delegation Presses Syrian Leader on Militants
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 4  House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her delegation said they had frank words with President Bashar al-Assad and other senior Syrian officials here on Wednesday, pressing the president over Syrias support for militant groups and insisting that his government block militants seeking to cross into Iraq and join insurgents there.

title: Brazil: Google Steps Up Oversight
description: Google agreed to make it easier to remove offensive content posted on its Orkut social-networking site, heeding requests from prosecutors in Brazil. Google will set up a page on Orkut where prosecutors will send requests to remove content, the Rio de Janeiro state prosecutors office said. In Brazil, where Orkut is the most-used social networking site, prosecutors complained last year that the company was taking too long to comply with their demands to eliminate some material on the site. Google, based in Mountain View, Calif., said it had added workers to review reports of offensive or illegal content, along with special tools for law enforcement to expedite reviews.

title: How Dry Im Not (Sip, Sip)
description: FOR marathoners on hour-plus training runs, carrying water is a dilemma. A belt of small flasks gives a runner variety  water in an eight-ouncer, Powerade in another  but it lacks pockets. A single 20- or 32-ounce bottle holster bounces.

title: Spinning Into Oblivion
description: DESPITE the major record labels best efforts to kill it, the single, according to recent reports, is back. Sort of.

title: Study Questions Exam to Detect Breast Cancer
description: A highly promoted and widely used computerized system for examining mammograms is leading to less accuracy, not more, a new study finds.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in the Dining section yesterday with an article about a dinner of wild animals prepared by Steven Rinella, a writer, referred incorrectly to a bird Mr. Rinella was holding. It was a song sparrow, a protected species, which was later released; it was not one of the English sparrows that were cooked, and are not protected.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about a former editor and publisher of The Detroit Free Press misspelled his given name. He was Neal Shine, not Neil.

title: Injured in Iraq, a Soldier Is Shattered at Home
description: DUNBAR, Pa.  Blinded and disabled on the 54th day of the war in Iraq, Sam Ross returned home to a rousing parade that outdid anything this small, depressed Appalachian town had ever seen. Sams parade put Dunbar on the map, his grandfather said.

title: What We Can Learn From Britain About Iran
description: THROUGH the capture of and subsequent announcement that it would release 15 British sailors and marines, the Islamic Republic of Iran sent its adversaries a pointed message: just as Iran will meet confrontation with confrontation, it will respond to what it perceives as flexibility with pragmatism. This message is worth heeding as the United States and Iran seem to be moving inexorably toward conflict.

title: Vatican City: Pope Appeals for Help for Africa
description: The Vatican announced the release of Benedict XVIs first book as pope, Jesus of Nazareth, to be issued in Italian, German and Polish on his 80th birthday, April 16. The book is the first of two volumes on the life of Jesus Christ, which he has said he began working on in 2003, while still a cardinal. In an excerpt printed in the Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera, Benedict drew modern-day lessons from the Parable of the Good Samaritan, saying that rich nations that had plundered and sacked Africa had an obligation to help the worlds poor.

title: Clearing of Atlantic Yards Site Proceeds as Legal Thicket Grows Denser
description: Out on the cold damp streets of Brooklyn, work on the Atlantic Yards project is under way, and you dont even need to peek through a knothole to see it.
