description: To the Editor:

title: At Wal-Mart, Lessons in Self-Help
description: Employees at a Wal-Mart near Saratoga, Fla., have started an aerobics class twice a week in their break room. Wal-Mart workers in Denver are reimbursed for taking public transportation to and from work. And the staff at a Sams Club in Indianapolis now takes a daily walk around the perimeter of the store.

title: These Salons Forgo Beauty Sleep
description: AT 6:30 p.m., when many hair salons around the country are beginning to close their doors for the night, the cocktail hour at the new Frdric Fekkai salon in SoHo is just beginning.

title: Umbrian Umbrage: Send Back That Etruscan Chariot
description: MONTELEONE DI SPOLETO, Italy, March 31  A mountain village in Umbria is caught up in a tug of war with the Metropolitan Museum of Art over the 2,600-year-old Etruscan chariot that is a highlight of the museums new Greek and Roman galleries.

title: CNN Replaces Its Morning News Anchor Team
description: Disappointed with its ratings for its news program American Morning, CNN is replacing the anchor team of Soledad OBrien and Miles OBrien and installing the newly hired Kiran Chetry and the former CBS News correspondent John Roberts, the network announced yesterday.

title: Subdued by a Loss and a Cold Rain, Rutgers Fans Return to Earth
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4  As Dorothy might say, Toto, were still in New Jersey.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a shortage of playing fields for organized sports leagues in New York City referred incorrectly to an agreement between the city and some elite private schools regarding 63 playing fields on Randalls Island. The schools  not the city  would also get a virtual monopoly on two-thirds of the fields during after-school hours for 20 years.

title: Grandma Would Be Tickled Purple
description: THE pickled egg is not for everyone. Yet, in the interest of full disclosure, I would like to reveal the simple recipe for my familys favorite (and unusual) Easter delicacy.

title: Running for Dollars
description: At least one of the presidential candidates making the first feverish dash of the 2008 fund-raising derby felt obliged to describe the tastelessness of the race. Im raising obscene amounts of money, said Senator Barack Obama, hardly pausing on his way to piling up a first-round total of $25 million.

title: What Happens in Las Vegas Stays in Swingin Memories
description: Showbiz longevity has its perks. Whoever has the good luck to remain the last one standing gets to tell the uncensored version of what life was really like in the imperial playground. As the golden age of Las Vegas recedes into the gin-scented mists of Rat Pack lore, that eternal tomboy Keely Smith, now 79, is the one left standing. She is the kind of garrulous star witness dear to the hearts of showbiz historians and gossip mongers.

title: Ford Chief Sticking to His Road Map for Turnaround
description: The Ford Motor Companys sales continue to fall and no one is predicting a North American profit before 2009. But the chief executive insisted yesterday that he saw no need for deeper cuts beyond those scheduled in its recovery plan.

title: Florida Lets Most Felons Regain Voting Rights
description: MIAMI, April 5  Gov. Charlie Crist persuaded Floridas clemency board today to let most felons easily regain their voting rights after prison, saying it was time to leave the offensive ranks of states that uniformly deny ex-offenders such rights.

title: Immigration Raid Yields 62 Arrests in Illinois
description: CHICAGO, April 4  Immigration agents arrested two managers and 60 other employees of an industrial cleaning company Wednesday on immigration violations and charges of identity theft in an early morning raid at a meatpacking plant in central Illinois.

title: Rethinking the Pots on an Old, Cracked Terrace
description: THERE was a little brown wren singing on the stone wall as I puttered around my motley collection of pots last weekend. It felt good to be dumping the old soil into the wheelbarrow and rinsing the pots with my garden hose.

title: Questions Arise About Britons Actions in Iran
description: LONDON, April 5  The 15 British marines and sailors held captive in Iran for nearly two weeks arrived back home today. But Britains relief at their safe return was tarnished by questions about how they behaved during their detention and why they had been captured in the first place.

title: Equity Firm to Sell South Korean Units
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 4 (NYT)  Lone Star Funds, the private equity firm based in Dallas, said on Wednesday that it would divest itself of two of its South Korean holdings  a construction company and a leasing company  fueling speculation it was planning to exit the country.

title: Wrapped in Subway Logos, Free City Condom Is a Hit
description: Seductive forces abound in New York City: music, bars, food, money, power. And the No. 1 train, of course, though some people think the D train is really hot.

title: Telephone Deregulation Announced for Canada
description: OTTAWA, April 4  Overruling a Parliamentary committee and the national regulator, Canadas Conservative government announced Wednesday that it was largely deregulating the countrys telephone market.

title: Beaming Up 3-D Objects on a Budget
description: OVER the last few decades, the electronics industry has worked magic with documents by building gadgets that copy, e-mail, print or fax flat images. Now it is building boxes that do something similar with three-dimensional objects.

title: Europe Looks Into Possible War Crimes in Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 5  European diplomats said Thursday that they were investigating whether Ethiopian and Somali government forces committed war crimes last week during heavy fighting in Somalias capital that killed more than 300 civilians.

title: No Charges for Missing Mobsters Kin, Paper Says
description: BOSTON, April 4  Federal prosecutors have ended their investigation of whether William M. Bulger, the former president of the University of Massachusetts, thwarted efforts to find his fugitive brother, James, a mob figure charged with 21 murders, The Boston Globe reported Wednesday.

title: Unusual Allies in a Legal Battle Over Texas Drivers Gun Rights
description: HOUSTON, April 4  Keith Patton was driving home one night in February when police officers pulled over his red Ford Explorer for a traffic stop.

title: Moviemaking With VCD
description: Moviemaking

title: 2nd Ave. Subway Platforms May Get Glass Walls and Sliding Doors
description: The Second Avenue subway, as it is envisioned by planners at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, will have many modern features that set it apart, including roomier, brightly lighted stations with wider platforms that are cooled in the summertime and are fully accessible to the handicapped.

title: Prank or Statement? Flag-Burning Near Yale Has Campus Abuzz, and Puzzled
description: NEW HAVEN, April 4  The three Yale students were on their way back to campus about 3 a.m. Tuesday after visiting a friend. Along the way, they spotted an American flag hanging from a front porch and, according to the police, went up to it with a lighter. Within minutes, the flag was in flames, and the students were under arrest.

title: Liberty Trades Hammon for No. 2 Pick in the Draft
description: The W.N.B.A. president, Donna Orender, wearing a broad smile, walked to the lectern yesterday and announced that Liberty point guard Becky Hammon had been traded to the San Antonio Silver Stars for the draft rights to center Jessica Davenport.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Monday about casualties suffered by an American combat brigade in Diyala Province in Iraq misidentified an officer standing at right while a hospitalized soldier received a Purple Heart. He is Command Sgt. Maj. Ray Edgar  not Maj. Charlie Fenton, the brigades chaplain, who was not pictured. (Go to Article)

title: Math-Rock That Adds Up to a Big Sound
description: The poster for the current tour by Battles, an inventively strenuous math-rock band, depicts four stacks of amplifiers and a drum kit against a yellow background. It would be a modest and minimalist image, almost generic, were it not that the amps, and a telescoped cymbal stand, appear to stretch more than 20 feet into the air.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Pictures with an article in Science Times on Tuesday about how animals experience time were published in error. The photographs were of the Florida scrub jay  not the western scrub jay, which was used in the research described in the article.

title: Canada: Acquisition by Mining Company
description: The Lundin Mining Corporation, a Canadian mining company operating in Europe, said it had agreed to acquire Rio Narcea Gold Mines for 993 million Canadian dollars ($858 million) to take advantage of record nickel prices. Lundin offered 5 Canadian dollars for each share of Rio Narcea, 3.7 percent higher than its closing price on Tuesday, and 1.03 Canadian dollars per warrant, Colin Benner, the vice chairman of Lundin, said in a conference call. The company plans to increase Rio Narceas nickel and copper operation in southern Spain and might sell its gold mine in Mauritania, it said. Rio Narcea is based in Toronto, and Lundin is based in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: United Airlines Awards Creative Account to Start-Up Agency
description: United Airlines today dismissed Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, which created campaigns for the airline since 1996, and awarded its creative account to a start-up agency in Minneapolis, Barrie DRozario Murphy. Two of the three principals of the start-up worked on the United account at Fallon before leaving in November.

title: Extra Innings Is No Longer Exclusive
description: Cable subscribers will once again be able to watch out-of-market Major League Baseball games, ending their fears that the Extra Innings package would become the exclusive domain of DirecTV for the next seven years.

title: A Bespoke Bentley for Those With Bucks
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Bentley Brooklands

title: An Infiniti Concept Thats Soon to Be Reality
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Infiniti EX Concept design study

title: Star moves
description: British actress Helen Mirren, who has won a heap of awards for playing Queen Elizabeth, has bought herself a rundown castle in Puglia, Italy for 680,000  or about $1.3 million. From the looks of it, shell have to spend a lot more to make it habitable.

title: Sugar Shock
description: Spring's candy-colored accessories are more tart than sweet.

title: Impac Dublin Literary Award Finalists Announced
description: Salman Rushdie of Britain, Cormac McCarthy and Jonathan Safran Foer of the United States and J. M. Coetzee of South Africa made it to the shortlist of eight contenders yesterday for the $135,500 International Impac Dublin Literary Award, billed as the worlds richest prize for a single work of fiction, Reuters reported. Other finalists are Per Petterson of Norway, Peter Hobbs and Julian Barnes of Britain and Sebastian Barry of Ireland. The winner will be announced in Dublin on June 14.

title: Dutch Soldiers Stress Restraint in Afghanistan
description: The tactics of the task force emphasize efforts to improve living conditions and self-governance.

title: Susquehanna Said to Explore Deal With Amex
description: At least one suitor is exploring an investment in the American Stock Exchange, the New York Post said Thursday. It reported that Morgan Stanley, which was hired recently by the exchange to explore strategic options, has enticed Susquehanna Investment Group to begin highly preliminary talks.

title: Trust Sued Over Backing Retiree Plan
description: A lawsuit filed in federal court in Manhattan last week contends that a retirement plan offered by the New York State United Teachers breached its fiduciary duty when it accepted millions of dollars in payments from an investment firm in exchange for endorsing the firms products to plan members.

title: Prosecutors Rest Case Against Ex-Chief of Qwest
description: Prosecutors rested their case Wednesday against Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, after more than a dozen company managers, industry analysts and others testified that they had been worried about looming financial challenges at the time Mr. Nacchio was selling $101 million in stock.

title: Lundin Mining Acquires Rio Narcea Gold Mines
description: Lundin Mining, a Canadian mining company operating in Europe, said it had agreed to acquire Rio Narcea Gold Mines for 993 million Canadian dollars ($858 million) to take advantage of record nickel prices. Lundin offered 5 Canadian dollars for each share of Rio Narcea, 3.7 percent higher than its closing price on Tuesday, and 1.03 Canadian dollars per warrant, Colin Benner, the vice chairman of Lundin, said in a conference call. The company plans to increase Rio Narceas nickel and copper operation in southern Spain and might sell its gold mine in Mauritania, it said. Rio Narcea is based in Toronto, and Lundin is based in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Cemex Bid for Rinker Advances
description: Cemex, the third-largest cement producer in the world, received clearance from United States antitrust regulators for its $11.7 billion hostile offer for the Rinker Group of Australia. The Justice Department said Cemex, based in Monterrey, Mexico, had agreed to sell 39 operations in Florida and Arizona to preserve price competition for large transportation projects in the two states. Rinker, based in Sydney, a building materials maker, gets about 80 percent of its sales in the United States.

title: Roche Strikes $600 Million Deal for BioVeris
description: The health care company Roche Holding agreed to buy BioVeris for $600 million to expand its medical testing business. The move strengthens Roches position in diagnostics, where it is already a global leader. BioVeris said it had agreed to be acquired for $21.50 a share, a 58 percent premium to Tuesdays closing price of $13.60. The purchase will allow Roche to expand its immunochemistry business from human diagnostics into segments like life science research, patient self-testing, veterinary testing, drug discovery, drug development and clinical trials.

title: German Software Maker to Buy WebMethods
description: Software AG of Germany said Thursday it would acquire webMethods, a Nasdaq-traded maker of application integration software, for $546 million. At $9.15 per share, the offer is nearly 26 percent more than webMethods closing share price on Wednesday. WebMethods, based in Fairfax, Va., held its initial public offering in February 2000, with its shares jumping more than 500 percent in their first day of trading to close at $212.63, after adjusting for stock splits.

title: Unarco Expands Via Purchase
description: Unarco Material Handling has purchased Kingway-Inca-Clymer Material Handling from American Capital Strategies. Though deal terms were undisclosed, Unarco becomes the second-largest pallet rack maker in the United States with the acquisition.

title: CompuCredit Plays First International Card with Barclays
description: Atlanta-based CompuCredit has made its first international portfolio buy in a deal with Barclaycard, a division of Barclays Bank. The maker of credit cards for high-risk individuals bought $970 million in Monument sub-prime credit card receivables from Barclaycard for $770 million.

title: Xoft Pockets $33.2 Million in Fourth Round
description: In a fourth round of funding, Xoft said Wednesday it had raised $33.2 million to continue making its miniature X-ray device used to treat breast cancer. New investors in the round included Easton Capital, New Science Ventures and Hambrecht & Quist Capital Management.

title: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
description: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

title: Of Legal F1 Cars and White Striped Tires
description: In addition to the controversy involving the legality of the Super Aguri and Toro Rosso cars, theres that other story about the moving floors, particularly on the Ferrari and the the BMW Sauber. That little device that is supposed to hold the floor in place legally during inspection of the car, yet allow it to move  which is illegal and helps the aerodynamics  when the car is on the track, has, not surprisingly turned out to be considered no problem at all by the drivers of the Ferrari and the BMW.

title: Quebecor Sees Potential for Media Unit I.P.O.
description: Canadas Quebecor might consider an initial public offering for its media division if conditions become right, a move that would help facilitate stock-based acquisitions, Quebecors chief executive, Pierre Karl Pladeau told The Globe and Mail.

title: Ameristar Bets on Chicago in Casino Purchase
description: Looking to expand the Chicago areas gambling market, Ameristar Casinos of Las Vegas has agreed to pay $675 million to acquire the Resorts East Chicago casino in East Chicago, Ind. Resorts International Holdings is an affiliate of an investment group, Colony Capital. Ameristar said it expects to close the deal sometime in the fourth quarter.

title: Will RBS Crash the ABN Amro Party?
description: As Barclays and ABN Amro continue to thrash out a deal, speculation mounted Wednesday that the Royal Bank of Scotland could foil the British banks proposed takeover of the Dutch giant.

title: Britain to Review Listing Rules
description: Under pressure from stock market investors, Britains Financial Services Authority will review the rules that apply to foreign companies listing in London, according to a report in The Guardian. Investors are concerned that a two-tier system of corporate governance is developing as companies domiciled in Britain have to comply with one set of rules while those outside face less stringent regulations.

title: CanWests Alliance Deal Under Fire
description: The unitholders of the Movie Distribution Income Fund are going to court in a bid to halt CanWests purchase of Alliance Atlantis Communications until they are given a say in who their Canadian partner will be, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: Charterhouse Plans for Saga I.P.O.
description: A British private equity firm, Charterhouse, is considering an initial public offering of Saga, a company that sells holiday travel packages and insurance to elderly consumers. Charterhouse provided financial alssistance for a management buyout of the company three years ago. Saga has appointed Close Brothers to work with the board in exploring future ownership options for the business, according to reports. An initial public offering would take place in the latter half of 2007 while analysts believe a float would value Saga at more than 2.5 billion.

title: Lehman Gets Greenlight in Qatar
description: Lehman Brothers has been granted a license to operate in Qatar, the bank said Thursday. After having moved into Dubai last year, Lehman will continue to expand its Middle East business via a strategic relationship with the Qatar Investment Authority to seek ways to invest globally.

title: Carlyle Said to Prepare $1 Billion Hedge Fund
description: The Carlyle Group, the Washington-based private equity giant, plans to start a $1 billion hedge fund called Blue Wave, according to two reports Thursday that cited undisclosed sources. The Wall Street Journal said the fund would open next month, but a source told Reuters that was inaccurate.

title: S.E.C. to Ease Sarbanes-Oxley Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously Wednesday to ease rules under the Sarbanes-Oxley anti-fraud law that would give more leeway in requirements for companies and their auditors. Sarbanes-Oxley was enacted in 2002 following several corporate and accounting scandals and requires companies to assess the strength of their internal checks and balances to guard against fraud.

title: Pay Dispute May Blindside Aston Martin Deal
description: A threat to the proposed 479 million pound ($944 million) sale of Ford Motors Aston Martin to a consortium led by the British entrepreneur David Richards loomed Wednesday as a pay dispute intensified. The Transport and General Workers Union said its members at some of the companys factories planned to stage a one-hour walkout on April 13 followed by a ban on overtime.

title: Indian Law Bars Essar Takeover by Vodafone
description: In a letter to the Indian finance ministry obtained by the Financial Times, Vodafone has acknowledged that it would be in breach of limitations on foreign direct investment if it attempts to take direct ownership of Indias Hutchison Essar. The proposed deal for the mobile operator is valued at $11.1 billion.

title: AT&T Is Open to Partners in Telecom Italia Deal
description: AT&Ts Rick Moore said the company is open to Italian partners in its bid for Telecom Italia Mr. Moore, AT&Ts development head, told an Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera, We are absolutely ready to take into consideration the interests of Italian industrial and financial partners.

title: K.K.R. Could Borrow $11 Billion for Coles Bid
description: A group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may borrow $11 billion to pay for their third attempt to buy the Coles Group, Australias second-biggest retailer. Citing unnamed sources, Bloomberg News reported that the group is in talks with Barclays, Citigroup, Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs, the Royal Bank of Scotland and UBS regarding the loan.

title: Concept Taxicabs
description: An exhibit at the 2007 New York International Auto Show featured concept taxicab designs.

title: Video Recorder Death Match
description: David Pogue referees a face-off between TiVo and the generic cable company box.

title: CardioVasc Secures a Merger and Venture Funding
description: Along with its purchase of ActaVascular Systems this week, CardioVasc, a medical device company, said it had raised $20.3 million in venture funding. The companies will combine to be called Nfocus Neuromedical.

title: Rexel Raises $1.3 Billion in I.P.O.
description: Rexel, the worlds biggest distributor of electrical equipment, raised 1.02 billion euros ($1.36 billion) in an initial public offering intended to cut debt Wednesday. Selling 61.5 million shares at 16.5 euros per landed the offer was at the low end of the spectrum for Rexel, with the business now valued at 4.18 billion euros.

title: Black Defense Says Payments Were Backed by Board
description: Defense lawyers at the criminal fraud trial of the media baron Conrad M. Black sought to show on Wednesday that millions of dollars of payments received by Mr. Black and his co-defendants were approved by the board of his former company. Prosecutors contend that Mr. Black and three former executives diverted some $60 million from the media conglomerate, Hollinger International, by sending the payments to entities closely controlled by Mr. Black.

title: Las Vegas: Leading the Way for New York?
description: William Neuman, who covers transportation for The Times, reports today that officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority are looking at using glass doors  which open and shut at the edge of the platform and prevent passengers from falling or jumping onto the tracks  when they build the much-anticipated Second Avenue subway.

title: K.K.R. Withdraws from Sainsbury Bidding Group
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has dropped out of the group considering a bid for J Sainsbury, the British supermarket chain, because of its involvement in a takeover approach of Alliance Boots, Bloomberg News reported. The Times of London said the remaining members of the CVC Capital-led consortium could submit a Sainsbury bid by Thursday.

title: Colony Capital Head Demands Sale of Carrefour Property
description: The founder of Colony Capital, Thomas Barrack, says he wants Carrefour, the European retailer, to raise as much as 30 billion euros ($40 billion) from property sales, more than what Carrefour says its real-estate assets are worth, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Barrack, who bought 9.1 percent of Carrefour with the French billionaire Bernard Arnault, said the company should consider selling and leasing back stores to finance expansion.

title: Sleuthing at Saturn
description: Usually its impossible to escape the hordes of hovering public relations people during the press days of an auto show. That was definitely not the case on Wednesday at the Saturn display here in New York. Three visits to Saturns information booth revealed nothing: no press kits, no cigar-chomping executives, not a single marketing wunderkind.

title: C-Class, One for Comfort, One for Sport
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2008 Mercedes-Benz C-Class, sport and luxury models.

title: Darfurs Death Toll
description: Eric Reeves, the Smith professor who has been a long-time expert on Darfur (and who has a new book on it), has a new analysis out on his website, www.sudanreeves.org. Heres an excerpt:

title: The Worst Way to Burn a Flag
A Joke
description: Someone sent me this email making the rounds on the internet (particularly among academics), explaining: Why God Never Received Tenure:

title: Genesis: Hyundais Blue Light Special?
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Hyundai Genesis concept

title: BMW Puts On a Happy Face
description: Introduced on Wednesday: BMW 5 Series

title: Obamas Fundraising Advantage
description: We wouldnt want to engage in the practice of spinning the money before it is spent, ordaining mega-fund-raising as the sine qua non of a credible candidacy, condemned by editorial page of The New York Times today. But lets link to Philadelphia Inquirer columnist Dick Polmans assessment of the state of the 2008 Democratic presidential race anyway. The plain truth is that the Clinton campaign has failed its first big test, Polman writes on his personal blog. He adds, We dont yet know officially that Obama has outraised Clinton in primary season money, but ABC News, citing inside sources, reported last night that he collected $23 million, and Clinton $20 million. Her campaign has declined to confirm or deny.

title: Deutsche Hires Bankers from Three Rivals
description: Deutsche Bank has lured an 18-year veteran investment banker from Goldman Sachs to join its mergers and acquisitions group. The banker, Bruce Evans, who was a managing director in Goldmans consumer retail investment group, will report to Jean Manas, Deutsches head of mergers and acquisitions in the Americas  and a former Goldman banker, the New York Post reported.

title: At War With Absurdity
description: This feature by Carl Colpaert, who wrote and directed, may be a mixed bag, but it is so impressive in so many ways that it demands to be taken seriously. It's a black comedy about a returning Iraq war veteran named Jess (Joe Arquette) that aims for an absurd, satirical tone (think "Dr. Strangelove" by way of "Coming Home") but rarely hits the mark.

title: Ion Board Urges NBC and Citadel to Raise Their Bid
description: The board of Ion Media Networks is pushing the media giant NBC Universal and the hedge fund Citadel Investment Group to raise their already-sweetened takeover offer before a deadline next month that could plunge the troubled TV network into bankruptcy, the New York Post reported, citing sources it did not identify.

title: 2008: Reversal of Fortunes
description: With the Democratic presidential field outraising the G.O.P.s, $78 million to $51 million, The Timess Adam Nagourney, writing from Des Moines, writes that the figures quantified a trend apparent here and in New Hampshire.

title: Table Tennis as Extreme Sport
description: Those with fond memories of desultory games of table tennis at the local Y.M.C.A. will be totally unprepared for "Ping Pong," probably the most extravagant celebration of a childhood game ever committed to film. Based on Taiyo Matsumoto's popular comic and fetishizing teenage angst as only the Japanese can, the movie examines male friendship through the prism of extreme sport. And if you don't think Ping-Pong is extreme, prepare to be persuaded otherwise.

title: Obtaining a Tibet Travel Permit
description: I am interested in traveling to Tibet independently. I have read different requirements needed to obtain the Tibet Travel Permit. Do I have to apply for the permit with an already purchased package or would I be able to arrange travel once I arrive in Lhasa. What exactly are the rules?

title: Who Needs I.P.O.s Anyway?
description: So much for peer pressure.

title: Released From Prison, but Not From His Past
description: The mesmerizing two-minute opening shot of "Los Muertos" is filmed from the viewpoint of a man lost in the jungle, weaving among the tree trunks and underbrush, looking up at the sunlight streaming down, fleetingly glancing at two dead, butchered boys lying on the ground, then glimpsing the figure (but not the face) of a passing man holding a bloody knife.

title: Solving the Car-Propulsion Problem
description: Predictably, my account last week of a presentation and test drive of BMWs liquid hydrogen-powered cars generated all kinds of angry nay-saying.

title: Blogs Blog About Blog Trackers Sale Prospects
description: Technorati is known for its software that searches and indexes thousands of blogs. So the company is presumably quite aware of the buzz making the rounds on the Net, in which bloggers are speculating that Technorati is positioning itself for a sale. Technorati has denied those rumors, but the denials may only be fanning the flames. After Michael Arrington of TechCrunch (the blog that broke the news that Google might buy YouTube) wrote about the situation, he appended his post with this update quoting Technoratis chief executive:

title: Just In: New Police Academy Will Be in Queens
description: At 1 p.m. today, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is scheduled to announce that the Police Departments training academy, shooting range and driver training facility will be consolidated and moved to a campus to be built in College Point, Queens.

title: A Two-Stage Booster for Volvos Wagons
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Volvo XC70

title: And Saturns Hexagon Shall Be Called . . .
description: The judging committee, after reviewing your more than 200 nominations, has finally settled on a name and a myth for the mysterious hexagon on Saturn. But first, lets take a look at a hexagon in Denmark pointed out to me by several readers.

title: The Next Tread-Mightily S.U.V. From Lexus
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Lexus LX570

title: The Blackstone I.P.O.: A Skeptics View
description: The desire to get behind the velvet rope can be a powerful thing. But when regular investors are finally given the chance to own a piece of Blackstone Group, the hugely profitable private equity giant, they should resist, Jim Jubak, markets editor for MSN Money, declared on TheStreet.com. He actually suggests they should run screaming from the I.P.O.  even as he predicts that they probably wont.

title: A Slim Victory for Four Seasons Buyers
description: The management-led consortium seeking to take Four Seasons Hotels private eked out a victory Thursday as shareholders voted in favor of the groups $3.4 billion offer. About 70 percent of limited voting shareholders who cast votes and 51.9 percent of non-insider shareholders approved the deal, the luxury hotelier said.

title: Chasing Woods at Augusta
description: Tiger Woods is going for his fifth green jacket and 13th major victory over all at this year's Masters.

title: American Express
description: An ad for American Express.

title: Treetops and Towers
description: The mix of commerce and culture  plus sublime modern architecture, great food, nonstop nightlife and amazing views  makes Hong Kong a great weekend destination.

title: A New Trade Route for China
description: The new trade link between Brazil and China marks a profound shift in world agricultural trade.

title: Inverness Injects Itself into Biosite Fight
description: An expensive bidding war for a blood test maker, Biosite, may grow even pricier. On Thursday, Inverness Medical Innovations made a $1.6 billion tender offer, topping an earlier $1.55 billion offer from Beckman Coulter. The bid by Inverness, which already owns 4.9 percent of Biosite, values Biosite at about $90 a share. Beckman Coulters offer was valued at about $85 a share.

title: Kerkorian Offers $4.5 Billion for Chrysler
description: Tracinda, the investment arm of the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, offered today to pay $4.5 billion in cash to buy the Chrysler Group, 12 years to the month after an earlier attempt by Mr. Kerkorian to buy the company, which was instead acquired later by Daimler-Benz of Germany.

title: I Hope He Pitches His Butt Off
description: There were about 40 members of the news media parked to the right of the third base dugout at Kauffman Stadium, about 20 stationed in the stands behind the dugout and about 30 more poised to the left of the dugout. This scene was a tribute to Daisuke Matsuzaka, who, eventually, would walk out of the dugout onto the field.

title: Hard to Spoil New Yorkers Appetites
description: My colleague Kim Severson wrote in yesterdays Dining section about the Bloomberg administrations fascination with food, including a stepped-up schedule of restaurant inspections by the New York City Department of Health.

title: A Narrow Window for Recess Appts.
description: Senate Democrats were caught off guard by the Bush administrations recess appointments this week. And part of the reason was that lawmakers are just not accustomed to being on recess this year.

title: Podcast: Bloombergs Final Days
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: D.N.C. Shuns Fox in Debate Schedule
description: The Democratic National Committee announced today that it would sanction six presidential debates, beginning later this year. It said dates, logistics and such have not been decided yet. They would start in July, and be held once a month.

title: What Is Chrysler Worth?
description: Kirk Kerkorian is not so much offering to buy Chrysler as he is volunteering to be paid to take it on.

title: Close to Home
description: Washingtonians, in the years that I lived in their city, always professed to care little about fashion, and I saw no reason not to take them at their word. However, Washington loves inside dope  of every kind  and so I learned a valuable lesson in that early part of my career: Tell the readers whats going on in the fashion world, fill up their heads with information to drop at their next dinner party, but, for gods sake, dont show them. Its the showing bits that kill copy, that bore down on the reader like an ancient aunt. and Mr. Ungaros collection of ruffled dresses

title: The Question of Circumcision and H.I.V.
description: The New York City health commissioners decision to encourage men at high risk of contracting HIV to get circumcised has drawn an array of reactions today, including a note of caution from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Cheney: Pelosis Diplo Effort Bad Behavior
description: On Rush Limbaughs show today, Vice President Dick Cheney talked about the trip taken by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to visit with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, and the message she delivered from her meetings in Israel about peace talks. (Which the office of Ehud Olmert, the prime minister of Israel, moved quickly to clarify.)

title: Proxy Firm Adds to Pressure on Times Company
description: Critics of The New York Times Companys corporate governance have gained a powerful ally. Institutional Shareholder Services, a proxy advisory firm, on Thursday advised the media companys shareholders to withhold their votes for directors seeking re-election in order to send a strong message that changes are needed. The firms recommendation came less than three weeks before the Timess annual shareholder meeting, which is likely to be a contentious affair. A fund managed by Morgan Stanley has been pressuring the Times Company to dissolve the two-tiered stock structure that gives voting control to the Sulzberger family, something the Times has said it will not do.

title: A Surprise from Umbria
description: Sometimes you dont know what you are missing.

title: Puma Shares Jump Amid Talk of PPR Bid
description: Shares in Puma Rudolf Dassler Sport surged nearly 10 percent on Thursday as speculation mounted that PPR, the French luxury goods conglomerate, would launch a bid for the German sportswear maker. There are rumors in the market that Pinault Printemps could make an offer for Puma next week, an unnamed trader told Reuters. Puma shares rose 9.5 percent by mid-afternoon trading in Germany Tuesday, far outpacing that countrys mid-cap stock index, up 0.2 percent. The trading volume of Puma shares exceeded the three-month average by more than six times.

title: Heart Disease, the No. 1 Killer
description: Heart disease kills more Americans than any other disease, partially because treatments known to make a difference are often ignored.

title: Damon Undergoes M.R.I.
description: While snow flurries sprinkle the field, Johnny Damon is warm and toasty in the Yankees clubhouse right now. Theres no need for him to take batting practice, because hes not playable tonight.

title: What Was He Thinking?
description: Is it just me, or has the time come to get out the fools cap, dust it off and place it smartly on the head of John McCain?

title: Movie Minutes: 'The Hoax'
description: A. O. Scott, chief movie critic of The Times, reviews "The Hoax," starring Richard Gere and Hope Davis.

title: Movie Minutes: 'The TV Set'
description: A. O. Scott, chief movie critic of The Times, reviews "The TV Set," about the filming of a fictional sitcom.

title: My Alter Ego
description: My literary hero and role model is a fictional serial killer.

title: Making a Case For New York City
description: There are no automaker design studios in New York City. I find this extremely puzzling. New York is the center for fashion, all sorts of design, music and art  all of which must feed into each other somehow and breed a sort of design energy that would be beneficial to automakers. Right?

title: Maserati GranTurismo
description: Maserati's new GranTurismo, one of many exotic cars on display at the New York International Auto Show, features a 405-horsepower V-8 engine.

title: Subaru WRX
description: Contributing writer Richard Chang reports on the unveiling of the redesigned Subaru WRX at the New York International Auto Show.

title: Do You Care if Your Computer is Green?
description: Greenpeaces latest ranking of mobile phone and computer manufacturers came out this week and the results were quite surprising. Companies were scored based on their take back and recycling policies for their products, and on whether they have moved to manufacturing with less toxic materials. Greenpeace says that as much as 4,000 tons of e-waste are discarded an hour, things like keyboards and computer circuitry.

title: Looking Beyond the Brass Ring
description: I still remember the day when I was in my mid-20s that Cate, my best friend from college, told me her cousin had gotten into Harvard.

title: Infiniti EX Concept
description: Infiniti's new EX concept car offers drivers features that make parallel parking easier.

title: Jackson Defers to the Black Caucus on Fox Debate
description: In an interview with the Rev. Jesse Jackson this afternoon, he told us that while he had concerns about Fox News, he had decided to give deference to the Congressional Black Caucus institute which cut a deal with Fox to do two presidential debates.

title: Giuliani Says Hell Quit His Day Job
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  On the last day of his four-day campaign outing through several of the early states, Rudolph Giuliani said that he would be leaving the consulting firm he founded so he could focus on winning the Republican nomination.

title: Bites in Valencia, Spain
description: Food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a the Minimalist, watches Pep Crespo make paella at a restaurant called L'Alter outside the city.

title: Steinbrenner Returns to Tampa
description: The good news for a handful of New York sports writers (including me) is that Yankee principal owner George M. Steinbrenner has returned to his home in Tampa, Fla. Steinbrenner was on hand for the Yankees opener against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays on Monday.

title: Jeter Ties Mattingly
description: Trailing by two runs with one out in the bottom of the seventh inning, Derek Jeter hit a hard ground ball in the hole between the shortstop and the third baseman. Ben Zobrist, the Devil Rays shortstop, got to the ball but did not have enough time to turn and throw and Jeter was given an infield hit.

title: Update: A Dialogue on Circumcision
description: Our earlier post on the role circumcision might play in reducing the risk of contracting H.I.V. drew strong opinions from scores of readers. Tonight, Geoffrey Cowley, a spokesman for the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, sent us a statement saying that the city had not developed a campaign to promote circumcision, but had begun a discussion on the possible benefits of the procedure.

title: Down to the Wire
description: Tomorrow is the deadline for Win A Trip. The applications are rolling in and were looking forward to picking a winner later on this month.

title: This Deal Is Encouraging and Absurd
description: THIS is a tale of two markets. One has unbridled optimism and believes that risk is a thing of the past. The other has experienced severe losses and can think of no reason those losses will not become worse.

title: Art in Review
description: CLOSED CIRCUIT Video and New Media at the Metropolitan Metropolitan Museum of Art 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street Through April 29

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Met Opera Gets $10 Million Gift

title: Parent of Airbus Appoints a Board Member to Be Its German Co-Chairman
description: PARIS, April 5  The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company named a new German co-chairman Thursday, tapping a longtime aerospace engineer who also played a central role in conceiving the groups delicate management structure.

title: An S O S for 911 Systems in Age of High-Tech
description: TAHLEQUAH, Okla.  As in many areas of the country, more 911 calls here come from cellphones than land lines. But 40 percent of the nations counties, most of them rural or small-town communities like this one, cannot yet pinpoint the location of cellphone callers, though the technology to do so has been available for at least five years.

title: Kerkorian Offers $4.5 Billion for Chrysler
description: The Tracinda Corporation, the investment arm of Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor, offered today to pay $4.5 billion in cash to buy the Chrysler Group, 12 years to the month after an earlier attempt by Mr. Kerkorian to buy the company, which was instead acquired later by Daimler-Benz of Germany.

title: Portraits in Zen, From Celestial to Comic
description: Japan Society, which is celebrating its centennial, has a history of producing exquisite shows of Buddhist art. They appear, on average, every 5 to 10 years, and they can be life-changers. After I saw a show of early Buddhist sculpture there in 1983, I went home, packed a bag and flew to Tokyo. I needed to go to where that art came from, and I spent a month visiting temples and monasteries across the country.

title: Creatures More Slothful Than You and Me
description: By the time The Wind in the Willows was published in 1908, its author, Kenneth Grahame, had committed himself to a life of consummate lollygagging, a vocation for which he presumably had affectionate disdain. The book came about as a series of stories he had written for his son; in them the slothfully well-to-do take a fair amount of ribbing. Though Grahame, who had written for much of his life, left his banking career in 1907, he lived 25 more years without producing another book.

title: Cellphones, Maxi-Pads and Other Life-Changing Tools
description: NAIROBI, Kenya
AROUND TOWN

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about an analysis of studies on the effects of hormone therapy for menopause misstated the results of a study on the risks of taking estrogen alone as hormone therapy. Estrogen alone increased the risk of stroke; it did not also increase the risk of breast cancer. The article also omitted the name of the journal that published the analysis. It was The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: For Cable TV, No Interest in Selling Ads the eBay Way
description: Auctions on eBay may be adored by millions of consumers around the world, but the large cable television networks have decided they want nothing to do with them.

title: Panel Seeks Written Account From Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee asked Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales on Thursday to provide the panel with a written account of his role in last years dismissals of eight United States attorneys at least two days before his scheduled April 17 testimony.

title: Valuing Older Teachers (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: No Recess From Bad Appointments
description: President Bush resorted to an old political trick this week, using recess appointments to evade Senate confirmation votes that he was sure to lose. All three are extraordinarily bad appointments  and three more reminders of how Mr. Bushs claims of wanting to work with Congresss Democratic leadership are just empty words.

title: Zell Gets Veto Power at Tribune
description: The Tribune Company last night disclosed new details of its plan to go private in a complex deal engineered by the real estate tycoon Samuel Zell, including provisions that will give Mr. Zell broad authority over corporate activities.

title: German Industry Would Alter Law Requiring Labor Seats on Boards
description: FRANKFURT, April 5  An unusual law that shapes the oversight of German companies is again being re-examined after corruption scandals at Siemens and Volkswagen, even as more companies are finding ways to skirt it.

title: Kids as Life Coaches (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Seaports May Provide Blueprint for Leasing Toll Roads
description: Resistance to the possibility that New Jersey will lease its largest toll roads to big financial firms is based largely on the fear that those investors would sharply raise prices to maximize their profits.

title: American Express Gets Specific and Asks, Are You a Cardmember?
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS has decided there is no more life left in My life. My card.

title: 3 Are Charged With Aiding London Transit Attack
description: LONDON, April 5  The British authorities charged three Muslim men on Thursday with conspiring to help with reconnaissance and planning for the London transit attack that killed 52 people in July 2005.

title: Gonzales Aide Who Refused to Testify Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Monica Goodling, the Justice Department official who helped coordinate the firings of eight United States attorneys, an episode that has jeopardized the position of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, resigned today.

title: Piers of California: At Sea Without a Sail
description: A PIER is a folly, a highway to nowhere. Whether lined with fishermen or filled with the cries and clattering of a roller coaster, whether thick with the aromas of hot dogs and fries or freshly gutted fish, they are there for nothing but the pleasure of humanity.

title: Wildlife Smugglers Test Their Skills, Even at the Airport
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1  Somewhere amid the rolling suitcases, plastic baggies filled with lip gloss, laptops, skis and other sundry items streaming through Los Angeles International Airport, there are, occasionally, rare butterflies, elephant tusks, sea turtle eggs and, in one case, a pair of pygmy monkeys, stuffed down the pants of an incoming passenger.

title: Giuliani Reaffirms That He Would Not Seek Abortion Changes
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., April 5  Rudolph W. Giuliani, campaigning in South Carolina, firmly stated that as president he would not seek to make abortion illegal.

title: British Envoy Seeks to Free Reporter Seized in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, April 5  A senior British diplomat met with the Palestinian prime minister in Gaza on Thursday to discuss the fate of a kidnapped BBC correspondent, Alan Johnston.

title: Passion for Golf Bound Three Who Died in Plane Crash
description: It was a 10-year-old tradition among golfing buddies: Every spring, Joe Massaro and three of his close friends would fly to North Carolina for some good times and  weather and skills permitting  some good golf.

title: Female Lawyers Set Sights on Yet One More Goal: A Seat on a Board
description: Barbara Paul Robinson has been the first at many things.

title: On the Big Island, a Place for Price-Sensitive Home Shoppers
description: PUNA is not the most obvious second-home paradise. It has a lot of rain, harbors a host (at least) of mosquitoes and is hard to reach from the mainland. Then theres the hard-to-ignore fact that much of its lava-encrusted land sits right in the flow zone of an active volcano, Kilauea.

title: On Cold Day, Matsuzaka Justifies Hot-Stove Hype
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 5  The hype about Daisuke Matsuzakas pitching has been percolating for months. The questions have been looming, too. Who is this immensely talented pitcher? How successful will he be with the Boston Red Sox? Did the Red Sox invest $103 million wisely?

title: Emissions Already Affecting Climate, Report Says
description: BRUSSELS, April 6

title: Fire Forces Shutdown of Nuclear Reactor
description: A fire forced the shutdown of the Indian Point 3 reactor, in Buchanan, N.Y., this morning. There was no release of radiation, but it was the second plant shut-down this week.

title: Greece: Tourists Evacuated From Cruise Ship
description: Four warships and two military helicopters joined a fleet of commercial vessels that rushed to evacuate 1,200 passengers, mostly Americans, and 300 crew members from a cruise ship that ran aground off the Aegean island of Santorini while trying to dock. The authorities said the cruise ship, the Sea Diamond, operated by Louis Hellenic Cruise Lines, began listing after striking a bed of rocks about a mile from the coast. The ship was later towed from the rocks. It had left Greeces main port of Pireaus on Monday for a weeklong island-hopping cruise in the Aegean.

title: An Outsiders Delicate Approach to a Well-Worn Repertory
description: Admirers of Alfred Brendel can mark the arrival of spring by his annual visit to Carnegie Hall. There were no mysteries or surprises on Wednesday night: Haydn, Beethoven, Schubert and Mozart have always been the heart of Mr. Brendels repertory, and here were all four. Like some gentleman farmer of the Classical piano repertory, he has been plowing and planting the same plot of land for more than 50 years. On the other hand there is a stubborn diligence and almost moral spiritual energy that sustains our attention.

title: On Gilded Sharks and Loverboys
description: On Sunday the new season of HBOs Entourage comes in like a lamb: a cuddly, fluffy, annoying little lamb. Its disturbing. Obnoxious Entourage looks all sweet, buttoning its jokes up tight and cutting away to broad reaction shots. This makes a fan extremely wary.

title: French Presidential Candidate Skips Visit as Protesters Gather
description: PARIS, April 5  The conservative presidential candidate Nicolas Sarkozy abruptly canceled a campaign visit to a neighborhood of the eastern city of Lyon on Thursday as protesters gathered there, warning that he would not be welcome.

title: Birds of a Feather
description: WHEN Gayla Groom scoots the cats from her bed and walks outside to check on the yard, the neighbors dont care if she is minus her clothing. Nor do they mind living next to her 20-by-20-foot slab-wood cabin that cost $14,000 to build. It is also perfectly normal for one elderly neighbor to call her each morning, as a courtesy, to say she has not died.

title: Little Italy Says Ciao to The Sopranos
description: Not for nothing, but Tony Soprano and his crew have been pretty good for business in Little Italy. Thats what Cha Cha says, anyway, and hes been on Mulberry Street almost since the days when La Guardia was the name of a sitting mayor, not an airport.

title: A Familys Growing Pains, Both Adolescent and Adult
description: Whole New Thing, a minutely observed family drama about a hothouse flower transplanted into the wild outdoors, is the rare film in which the actors playing parents and child feel biologically connected. That flower, the 13-year-old Emerson Thorsen (Aaron Webber), is the haughty, home-schooled only child of a bohemian couple living in a house they built in the Nova Scotia woods.

title: With Hustle, Boston College Earns Trip to Title Game
description: ST. LOUIS, April 5  The puck, cleared the length of the ice by Boston Colleges Brian Boyle, caromed off the back boards and came to rest to the right of the empty North Dakota net. The Fighting Sioux, already on a power play, had pulled their goalie for a six-on-four advantage to try and tie this Frozen Four semifinal. Certainly, one of them would reach the puck first.

title: Slumping Blake Tries to Regain Confidence
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., April 5  James Blake finally broke through in 2006, when he won five tournaments, defeated top players like Rafael Nadal and Andy Roddick and rose as high as No. 4 in the ATP rankings. Blake became the first African-American player to crack the top 10 in tennis since Arthur Ashe in 1980.

title: Modern Furniture for the Middle Class, Designed by a Swedish Star
description: Three floors of the Bard Graduate Center, at 18 West 86th Street in Manhattan, are filled with curvy, modern, bent and laminated beech easy chairs and chaise longues with woven, webbed seating  perfect for any beach house. There are daybeds with adjustable reading stands and companion floor-level book cribs, armchairs with rotating bases and elliptical blond dining tables with spindly legs that seem to float above the floor. A film on one wall depicts a glass house in a forest by the sea.

title: Returning Oliver Twist to His Grim Dickensian Home
description: Neil Bartletts adaptation of Oliver Twist, presented by the Theater for a New Audience, must easily be among the most competently acted productions on or Off Broadway at the moment. Carson Elrod moves fluidly between his dual roles as the storys wry narrator and the Artful Dodger. Ned Eisenberg gives us a Fagin smarmy, tortured and mesmerizing. As Rose Brownlow, Elizabeth Jasicki exquisitely captures the fragility born of supreme goodness.

title: Back to the (Double) Feature
description: The essence of Grindhouse, Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantinos exuberant, uneven tribute to the spirit of trash cinema, is distilled in a scene from Death Proof, Mr. Tarantinos feature-length contribution to the project. Two vintage American muscle cars, already scuffed and dented from chasing each other along back roads and two-lane blacktops, descend, engines whining and tires squealing, onto a highway full of late-model minivans, S.U.V.s and family sedans, all of them driving safely within the lines and the speed limit.

title: 22 Brands of Dog Biscuits Are Added to Pet Food Recall
description: A recall of pet food tainted with melamine, a chemical used to make plastic products, has been widened to include 22 types of dog biscuits, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday.

title: Gotta Minute? So, Theres This Guy Tony ...
description: Like mob bosses of legend, The Sopranos is pensive, brooding and austere. Heavy silences, broken by spells of rage, pervade David Chases masterpiece, which enters its final season on Sunday. The Sopranos is not glib. It does not have truck with glibness.

title: Deadly Confrontations Are Relatively Rare for F.B.I. Agents
description: F.B.I. agent shot in showdown with bank robbers.

title: Wind and Fast Greens Get the Better of the Best
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5  On a postcard-pretty morning at an old converted nursery, a retired professional golfer walked to the first tee at Augusta National Golf Club and announced that it was a beautiful day. Arnold Palmer reared back, smacked a drive on the screws, and faded into the background of the Masters, leaving 96 players to give their own assessment of a tournament that teases and tempts them so.

title: Ford Pays Chief $28 Million for 4 Months Work
description: The Ford Motor Company paid its new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, $28.18 million in his first four months on the job, the automaker said in a regulatory filing yesterday.

title: Freed Sailors and Marines: We All Wanted to Get Home
description: Following is the statement read alternately by Capt. Chris Air, 25, of the Royal Marines, and Lt. Felix Carman, 26, of the Royal Navy, on behalf of the 15 British sailors and marines freed by Iran on Thursday, as recorded by the Press Association. Captain Air and Lieutenant Carman were the highest ranking of the 15 detainees; in the British military, a captain of marines and a naval lieutenant are equivalent ranks.

title: Group Urges Investors Not to Back Times Co. Board
description: An independent corporate advisory group is urging shareholders of The New York Times Company to withhold their support for board members to pressure the company over dissatisfaction with its performance and ownership structure.

title: Far-Right French Candidate Visits Ethnic Enclave
description: PARIS, April 6  Jean-Marie Le Pen, the far-right candidate for president of France, ventured into what might be expected to be hostile terrain today, making a surprise visit to a troubled multiethnic suburb of Paris.

title: With Arenas Out for Season, Playoffs Lose Some Flair
description: Gilbert Arenas limped off the court Wednesday night, his quiet concern in ominous contrast to his usual flamboyance. Yesterday, the Washington Wizards title hopes flickered all but out when they learned that Arenas, their leading scorer, would be lost for the rest of the season. His injury also means the N.B.A. will be without the player who would have been its most colorful character in the playoffs.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (TLC) SHUT UP! ITS STACY LONDON The Queen of Style finally gets her own throne in a new talk show. This sneak peek gives a taste of whats to come this fall, when the show moves into the regular TLC lineup alongside What Not to Wear (see below), Ms. Londons flagship. In Shut Up!, Ms. London, left, will do what she does best, offering advice on how to just say no to bad fashion and relationship choices with the help of experts and a bevy of beauty wizards. Segments include My Life in Five Outfits, which traverses a celebritys career through clothes. Tonights test run includes the actresses Jane Krakowski and Lisa Rinna, the shoe designer Kristen Lee and the author Ron Geraci. Clinton Kelly fans, never fear: Mr. Kelly, Ms. Londons endearing W.N.T.W. co-host, will be helping Americans adjust their ps and qs in Mind Your Manners, also going on the air this fall.

title: Yale Students Lawyer Says Flag Burning Was Just a Prank
description: The three Yale students arrested early Tuesday for burning an American flag were not trying to making a political statement, but were just pulling a prank, according to their lawyer.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Oceandance, With Swordplay
description: Many and exhausting are the physical activities that occupy the long hours of The Pirate Queen, the loud and restless musical that opened last night at the Hilton Theater.

title: Romney Used His Wealth to Enlist Richest Donors
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  Mitt Romney, the multimillionaire founder of a giant private equity firm, knew he did not need other peoples money to mount a presidential campaign. But as they began planning a campaign more than two years ago, Mr. Romney and his advisers wanted to avoid the fate of two other millionaires, Steve Forbes and Ross Perot, whose self-financed campaigns went down as quixotic indulgences.

title: Islanders Win and Keep Postseason Hopes Alive
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., April 5  As distasteful as it seemed to be to their fans, the Islanders needed help from the Rangers on Thursday to even keep thinking about the playoffs. But the Islanders also needed to win, and that would turn out to be the hard part.

title: Cable TV Networks Boycott eBay Ad Exchange
description: Auctions on eBay may be adored by millions of consumers around the world, but the large cable television networks have decided they want nothing to do with them.

title: A Cowboy Tycoon, Back in the Saddle
description: The first man I fell in love with was Gene Autry. I was only 4, but I wasnt alone in my ardor. Autry, the singing cowboy, was a true showbiz phenomenon, the only American performer to have five different stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame  one each for films, recordings, television, radio and live performance. In 1941 alone, he did eight recording sessions, seven movies and a weekly radio show.

title: Going With the Flow
description: WHO Colleen Parker, 39, an information technology recruiter, shown with her husband, Alon Friedman, 40, a doctoral student and instructor

title: Makers of Artificial Sweeteners Go to Court
description: Sweetness is about to be the subject of a bitter courtroom fight.

title: Germany: Acquisition for Software Maker
description: Software, a software maker, agreed to buy webMethods of the United States for $546 million in cash to add networking software to its product line and more than double its customer numbers in North America. Software, based in Darmstadt, will pay $9.15 for each webMethods share, the companies said. The price is 26 percent higher than the closing price of webMethods on Wednesday. WebMethods, based in Fairfax, Va., sells software systems that allow companies to link ordering and customer service systems and monitor the data, said David Mitchell, the chief executive.

title: Newark on Time on Budget, but a Fiscal Crisis Looms
description: NEWARK, April 5  When the Municipal Council approves the 2007 budget later this month, there is sure to be a burst of mutual acclaim among council members and the mayor for putting together a $720 million spending plan that was passed on time and without a tax increase.

title: The Residences at Atlantis and the Ritz-Carlton, Rancho Mirage
description: The Residences at Atlantis

title: China Says It Had Nothing to Do With Tainted Pet Foods
description: SHANGHAI, April 5  China said today that it had no record of exporting any agricultural products that could have tainted the pet food that has been linked to the deaths of cats and dogs in the United States.

description: To the Editor:

title: How Supply-Side Economics Trickled Down
description: Great Falls, Va.

title: Third Suspect Tied to F.B.I. Shooting Is Caught
description: After an overnight manhunt by police and federal agents in Central New Jerseys wooded horse country, the authorities today arrested a third suspect wanted in connection with a shooting outside a bank on Thursday in which an F.B.I. agent may have accidentally been killed by one of his own.

title: Federal Official in Student Loans Held Loan Stock
description: A senior official at the federal Education Department sold more than $100,000 in shares in a student loan company even as he was helping oversee lenders in the federal student loan program.

title: None Hurt, and Another Tale Added, in Collapse at Storied Village Bar
description: Part of a wall collapsed yesterday in a popular Greenwich Village restaurant and onetime speakeasy where literary giants like John Steinbeck and F. Scott Fitzgerald once gathered.

title: 6 Americans and 4 Britons Are Killed in Attacks in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April 5  Six American and four British soldiers were killed in separate attacks around Iraq, coalition officials said Thursday, while an American helicopter crashed south of Baghdad, wounding four soldiers.

title: Britain: K.K.R. Drops Out of Sainsbury Bid
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company dropped out of the group that is considering a bid for J Sainsbury, the supermarket chain, leaving its three partners to pursue the takeover plan. CVC Capital Partners, the Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group make up the rest of the group, which must decide on a bid by next Friday.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Citigroup Shake-Up Puts Private Bank Under 2 Executives
description: Citigroup reorganized senior management at its private bank yesterday, replacing the chief executive, Damian M. Kozlowski, with two executives.

title: Is Romney a Hunter? Depends on What Hunt Is
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  In seeking their support for his presidential campaign, Mitt Romney has struggled over the last few months to reassure Republican conservatives that he is one of them.

title: Freed Britons Are Back Home but Face Questions About Their Capture and Behavior
description: LONDON, April 5  The 15 British marines and sailors held captive in Iran for nearly two weeks arrived back home on Thursday. But Britains relief at their safe return was tarnished by questions about how they behaved during their detention and why they had been captured in the first place.

title: Pettittes Return Lost Amid Sloppy Play
description: It was as if a glass bubble covered Yankee Stadium in the eighth inning last night, the way the snow flurries swirled against the black sky. A disjointed game was reaching its peak and the ballpark was all shook up.

title: A Prisoner Dies After an Attack in a Bronx Cell
description: A prisoner died on Wednesday shortly after he was attacked by three men who were in a holding cell with him at the Bronx County Courthouse, the police said.

title: Why Bicyclists Head to Georgia
description: THERES a rhythm to watching, eating and pedaling your way through the 667-mile Tour de Georgia, a roving, carnivalesque professional road cycling race (held this year April 16 to 22) that brings about 500,000 visitors to some of Georgias highest mountains and most colorful hamlets. About 120 are competitors in the race. For most of the rest, the tour is part sports spectacle, part Appalachian sightseeing trip and part movable party.

title: No Diplomatic Change After Britons Release
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The Bush administration said Thursday that the release of 15 British sailors and marines held by Iran for two weeks created no new openings in dealing with Tehran, and it urged American allies to return their attention to enforcing new sanctions against Iran.

title: As Musharrafs Woes Grow, Enter an Old Rival, Again
description: NEW DELHI, April 5  As the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, wrestles with swelling public disaffection over his rule, one of his key political rivals, Benazir Bhutto, has embarked on an international campaign to revive her political standing.

title: Central Park Calls in the Dogs, Hoping Theyll Drive Out the Geese
description: For anyone who believes geese are unobjectionable, think again. Here are some things the citys parks department would like you to know: Geese are voracious eaters and can ruin acres of manicured lawns. They chase away ducks. Adult geese produce nearly one pound of droppings each day.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Latin Lovers
description: Paris

title: At Their Best, Knicks Werent Good Enough
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 5  Throughout the Knicks early trials and their many, many stumbles, Isiah Thomas maintained an air of patience and calm. There was, he reasoned, another game, another week, another month to make things right.

title: In New Haven, Art Almost Everywhere You Look
description: NEW HAVEN'S identity has been entwined with Yale University's for centuries. The college's neo-Gothic buildings gild the city's oldest avenues, but it's not all heady Ivy League intellectualism in New Haven. The city has also actively cultivated the artistic left side of its brain.

title: Material Muse for Some Strange Bedfellows
description: In the 1950s art and poetry were the hottest couple in downtown Manhattan. Painters referenced poetry. Poets wrote art criticism. John Ashbery claimed to approach words abstractly, as an artist uses paint. In the 1960s, however, poetrys influence faded and advertising became arts favored muse.

title: Fort Worth, With a Cowboy Past, Has an Artistic Present
description: SEEING Fort Worth and skipping Dallas is sort of like visiting Buda but not Pest. The two cities are so codependent by now, intertwined by their joint airport and a network of interstates, that outsiders can be forgiven for lumping them together.

title: Where Rumors Fly, Traffic Stalls, and Sharpshooters Roam the Golf Course
description: BRANCHBURG TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 5  John Hawkins, who lives by the third fairway of the Fox Hollow golf course here, is used to the occasional errant golf ball rolling onto his property.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Correction
description: An article on Saturday about a delay in a deposition for lawsuits against New York City over arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention misstated the context of a response by Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman. Mr. Browne was responding to a general question about a pre-convention surveillance program when he said, No comment on anything that may have a bearing on pending litigation. He says he was not in fact addressing a question about an apparent discrepancy between statements by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and himself about whether that surveillance had uncovered a plot to bomb a subway station.

title: So How Should We Treat Iran? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Three-Way Connection of Minds and Bodies
description: If ever there were a show to quash the ridiculous notion that art and entertainment are necessarily separate realms, its Becky, Jodi and John, choreographed by John Jasperse in collaboration with the other two performers.

title: To Mark a Cab Centennial, These Designers Look Ahead
description: Rocco Filippone trained his knowing eyes on his sons college project and said he would give it a B.

title: Goldberg Variations Galore by New Musics Torchbearer
description: The pianist Blair McMillen can play composers like Liszt, Debussy and Scriabin with flair, intelligence and Juilliard-honed virtuosity, as his self-produced 2004 recording Soundings makes abundantly clear. But what most excites this 36-year-old North Carolina native is contemporary music. He is best known as a mainstay of several contemporary music ensembles in New York.

title: A Cub Is Abandoned, and a Star Is Born
description: BERLIN, April 5  What is it about Germans and bears?

title: When It Counts, Augusta Grinds Down Laboring Els
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5  Ernie Els has spent his career being told that he has a game built for the Masters. He has come so close to winning that he could nearly feel a green jacket on his shoulders.

title: Two French Cruise Passengers Missing Off Greece
description: ATHENS, April 6  Greek Navy divers searched the wreck of a cruise ship today for two missing French passengers after authorities rescued nearly 1,600 tourists and crew members from the ship.

title: Nuclear Plant Owner Seeks Payment for Lost Production
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  The owner of an Ohio nuclear plant has asked its insurer to pay for two years of lost production because of corrosion that it called unexpected and unforeseeable, even though it had resisted government pressure to inspect for acid leaks just before the problem was uncovered in 2002.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a delay in a deposition for lawsuits against New York City over arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention misstated the context of a response by Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman. Mr. Browne was responding to a general question about a pre-convention surveillance program when he said, No comment on anything that may have a bearing on pending litigation. He says he was not in fact addressing a question about an apparent discrepancy between statements by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and himself about whether that surveillance had uncovered a plot to bomb a subway station. (Go to Article)

title: True Story of a Fake Story About Hughes (Really)
description: The literary and journalistic frauds of the present era  the fudgings, thefts and fabulations of James Frey, Jayson Blair, Stephen Glass, Kaavya Viswanathan and their sorry ilk  are small potatoes compared to the work of Clifford Irving. Mr. Blair led readers of The New York Times to believe hed been to Texas; Mr. Frey convinced Oprah Winfrey and many others that hed been to jail. But Mr. Irving, back in the early 1970s, conned a major publishing house and a popular magazine into buying a much bigger and more brazen lie.

title: A Bumpy Ride on a Brazilian Highway, and Long Waits at Either End
description: RONDONPOLIS, Brazil  For thousands of truck drivers working Brazils biggest soybean export routes, the road is full of potholes the size of large pizzas.

title: Quinn Urges More Money for Libraries in Budget
description: Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn called yesterday for increased library hours and money for new education initiatives and health clinics for underserved areas. Those changes are included in a proposal that would add $61 million to Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs $57.1 billion preliminary budget for next year.

title: In a Handel Romp, Whimsy Collides With Tragedy
description: The shiny pinks and greens of Chas Rader-Shiebers production of Handels Flavio are a nice complement to a score that presents arias nestled side by side, bright and sweet and varied as the offerings in a box of candy, linked by premises as ordered and flimsy as cardboard dividers. This Flavio, which returned to City Opera on Wednesday night, is a confection: much of a good thing, not all of it sophisticated or uniformly pleasing, but leaving a reasonably pleasant aftertaste.

title: Somali Battles Bring Charges of War Crimes
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 5  European diplomats said Thursday that they were investigating whether Ethiopian and Somali government forces committed war crimes last week during heavy fighting in Somalias capital that killed more than 300 civilians.

title: Michael Dibdin, 60, Detective Novelist, Is Dead
description: Michael Dibdin, an internationally acclaimed British crime novelist whose best-known books feature the brooding Italian police detective Aurelio Zen, died on March 30 in Seattle. He was 60 and had lived in Seattle in recent years.

title: Again, Kerkorian Makes a Move for Chrysler
description: Kirk Kerkorian is back. After making billions on brazen investments in Hollywood, Las Vegas and Detroit, he is now pursuing Chrysler once more, a dozen years after his last attempt.

title: Darryl Stingley, 55, Paralyzed Player, Dies
description: Darryl Stingley, a receiver for the New England Patriots who became a quadriplegic after an intentionally violent hit in a 1978 preseason game, died yesterday in Chicago. He was 55.

title: Shedding Light on Americas Dark Recesses
description: Theres something quintessentially American about the way Taryn Simons photography exhibition An American Index of the Hidden and Unfamiliar examines the cultures irreconcilable differences. Ms. Simon couches the show in the intellectual, power-to-the-people oratory of leftist politics. Yet she clearly delights in exposing, in a quasi-tabloid fashion, Americas underbelly.

title: Official Who Held Loan Stock Put on Leave
description: The federal Education Department said this afternoon that it had placed a senior official on leave, following disclosures on Thursday that he held stock in a student loan company, even as he had helped oversee lenders in the federal student loan program.

title: Manhattan: New Atlantic Yards Suit
description: A coalition of advocacy and neighborhood groups filed a lawsuit yesterday in State Supreme Court seeking to overturn the states approval of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, charging that the review process was flawed. The suit, filed by 26 groups, stated that the Empire State Development Corporation intentionally understated or played down the potential costs and traffic and pollution effects of the project in its zeal to approve it in December. The $4 billion project, proposed by the developer Forest City Ratner, calls for eight million square feet of housing and office space and a basketball arena near Downtown Brooklyn.

title: New Urgency in Debating Health Care
description: Since Hillary Rodham Clintons effort to overhaul the nations medical system was rejected in 1994, most big employers have stayed out of the debate on health care reform.

title: Remington Arms Is Sold
description: Remington Arms, the gun maker that has equipped American soldiers for 150 years, has agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm, Cerberus Capital Management, for $118 million, a statement by Remington said yesterday. title: Bloomfield: Flood Stops Rail Service
description: New Jersey Transit service on the Montclair-Boonton Line was suspended for more than seven hours during the morning rush yesterday after a hydrant broke, flooding the tracks, the agency said. Service was suspended on the line around 5:45 a.m., said Penny Bassett-Hackett, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit, after more than a foot of water rose over the tracks near the Watsessing station, near Montclair State University. A delivery truck crashed into the hydrant in the parking lot of a nearby Home Depot store. Pumps were brought in to remove the water and commuters were diverted to bus and Newark PATH lines. Service was restored about 1 p.m., Ms. Bassett-Hackett said.
