title: Democrats Rise Has Pluses, Say G.O.P. Centrists
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  If the Democratic ascendance on Capitol Hill was supposed to usher in dark days for Republicans, it is hard to tell from talking to moderate ones like Mike Ferguson, who represents a suburban district in central New Jersey.

title: Judge Orders a Florida School to Allow a Gay Tolerance Club
description: MIAMI, April 6  A south-central Florida high school accused of discrimination must officially recognize a student club that works to promote tolerance of gay men and lesbians, and grant it the same privileges as other school clubs, while a lawsuit takes its course in federal court, a judge ordered Friday.

title: Lesser Charge for 13-Year-Old in Fatal Fight
description: Lawyers for the city yesterday withdrew a manslaughter charge against a 13-year-old boy accused of fatally injuring his classmate in a schoolyard fight in East Elmhurst, Queens, on March 23. Instead, they proceeded with a misdemeanor assault charge.

title: A Top Aide to Gonzales Resigns, Becoming Latest Fallout Casualty
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  A top aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales resigned on Friday, becoming another casualty of the political storm that has rocked the Justice Department in the aftermath of last years dismissals of eight United States attorneys.

title: Boat Race Has Become More Than Tradition
description: In Britain, it is called the Boat Race, and for the past 152 years, it has been how Oxford and Cambridge have settled bragging rights.

title: Regulatory Commission Downgrades Indian Point Reactor After Fire and Another Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission downgraded its safety assessment of the Indian Point No. 3 nuclear reactor on Friday, hours after a transformer fire forced the plants second shutdown in a week and the fourth in the last 12 months. The commission said it would conduct extra inspections.

title: Unresolved Chords Echo for the Disappeared
description: There may have been a more moving show of contemporary political art in the city this season than The Disappeared at El Museo del Barrio, but if so, I missed it. The title refers to a peculiarly chilling form of violence associated with political upheavals in Latin America over the last 40 years, one that is now becoming more common in Iraq.

title: Late Changes Made Report More Dire, and Less
description: Since it was created in 1988, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has been criticized from all sides at one time or another.

title: Fugitive Tells of Life on the Run and of a Killing
description: DANNEMORA, N.Y., April 3  Seeing him sitting in a plastic chair behind prison plexiglass, it is hard for a visitor to imagine that Ralph J. Phillips, better known as Bucky, led hundreds of state police officers on a manhunt through the towns and backwoods of western New York for the better part of five months last year.

title: Battle Grows Over Renewing Landmark Education Law
description: When President Bush and Democratic leaders put together the bipartisan coalition behind the federal No Child Left Behind Act, they managed to sidestep, override or flat out ignore decades of sentiment that education is fundamentally a prerogative of state and local government.

title: Scientists Detail Climate Changes, Poles to Tropics
description: BRUSSELS, April 6  From the poles to the tropics, the earths climate and ecosystems are already being shaped by the atmospheric buildup of greenhouse gases and face inevitable, possibly profound, alteration, the worlds leading scientific panel on climate change said Friday.

title: Judge Reverses Stand in Case of Ex-Astronaut
description: MIAMI, April 6  Just hours after scheduling a hearing on his plan to seal court documents in the case of a former astronaut accused of attacking a romantic rival, a judge canceled the hearing and said he would allow the release of the records, with the exception of psychological evaluations.

title: Guggenheim Passed Over for New Venice Museum
description: PARIS, April 6  After a battle involving money, art and politics, the French billionaire Franois Pinault has been chosen over the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation to turn a much-coveted unused customs house at the entrance to Venices Grand Canal into a new museum of contemporary art.

title: Mussina Falls Behind Early and Yankees Cant Catch Up
description: Every team in the majors has had a starter pitch five innings at least once this season. Every team, that is, except the Yankees.

title: For Michigan State Goalie, What Happens Off Ice Stays Off Ice
description: ST. LOUIS, April 6  Being an asthmatic and short can make Michigan State goaltender Jeff Lergs job even tougher. Sometimes, just finishing a team meal becomes a challenge.

title: The Real Fumble in Damascus
description: There is at least one point on which we and the critics of Nancy Pelosis visit to Damascus can agree: It is the White House, not the speaker of the House, that should be taking the diplomatic lead. But the Bush administration has far more appetite for scoring political points than figuring out whether talking to Syria might help contain the bloodletting in Iraq or revive efforts to negotiate peace.

title: Deputies to a U.S. Attorney Step Down
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Rachel K. Pauloses swearing in on March 9 as the United States attorney in Minneapolis stirred debate in local legal circles because of the ceremonial trappings, including a performance by a municipal choir and a Marine Corps color guard, at the event attended by more than 300 people at the citys University of St. Thomas law school.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a dispute between the makers of Equal and Splenda referred incorrectly to an earlier legal battle between makers of pasta sauce. Conopco, which unsuccessfully sued Campbell Soup in 1996, was the maker of Ragu  not Prego, which Campbell produces. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the gender of the judge overseeing the Equal-Splenda case. Gene E. K. Pratter is a woman.

title: Warriors Home in Washington
description: The House has acted swiftly to deal with some of the shameful conditions at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, where soldiers wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan were discovered foundering in slum-like billets and bureaucratic neglect as outpatients. A measure creating a stronger system of case managers, counselors and advocates for the Armys war-wounded received unanimous approval from angry lawmakers. But so far there has been no comparable action in the Senate.

description: On April 15, when the Yankees play in Oakland, Mariano Rivera may not be the only Yankee wearing No. 42.

description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday ordered drug companies to stop making and selling anti-nausea suppositories containing a drug that the agency said did not work when used in that form.

title: Britons Say They Feared for Lives in Iran Captivity
description: LONDON, April 6  Their greatest scare, they recalled, came on the second day, when they were flown to Tehran, blindfolded and backed up against a prison wall while their Iranian captors fiddled with weapons, cocking rifles and making them fear for their lives.

title: Woods Salvages a Bad Round on Day Two
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6  Tiger Woods drowned two golf balls in Raes Creek, hit another one over the back of the 15th green, and flirted with playing himself out of the 71st Masters before rallying late.

title: Karzai Says He Has Met With Some Taliban Members in an Effort at Reconciliation
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 6  President Hamid Karzai said Friday, for the first time, that he had held meetings with members of the Taliban as part of a reconciliation effort, but he ruled out talks with the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, or foreign militants fighting with the Taliban.

title: A United Front Against the Taliban
description: AS the spring fighting season opens, Afghanistan faces many challenges: terrorism, the Taliban, Islamic extremism, drugs and criminals, warlords and factional friction, weak government and an inadequate national and international security presence.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The S.& P. 100 Stocks chart in Business Day yesterday was published in error. A corrected chart appears on Page C7.

title: Wrestling With Songs Tougher Than the Rest
description: Bruce Springsteen, finally taking the stage at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, started out by assuring the crowd that he was still alive. Or maybe he was reassuring himself. The evening had felt, he said, a little bit like that dream everybody has, where youre invisible and youre floating above a room, and all these people are talking about you. The kicker, of course, is that it turns out to be your funeral.

title: Griffin Spins Wheel and Gets Horse With Derby Potential
description: In his primary pursuits, success has always come easily for Merv Griffin, who, with his hit records, hit game shows, popular talk shows and savvy real estate investments, is good at just about whatever he does. Horse racing, though, is different. Last year Griffin, who operates a modest-sized racing stable, could not conquer the Kentucky Derby, where winning is as much about luck as it is about talent or smarts.

title: Networks Condemn Remarks by Imus
description: On Wednesday morning, Don Imus called the students who play for the Rutgers University womens basketball team a bunch of nappy-headed hos.

title: A Huge Helping of Wolf in One Marathon Evening
description: Ingesting 44 songs by Hugo Wolf in a single gulp at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday night was an experience somewhere between generosity embraced and a marathon negotiated. The Austrian Cultural Forum, branching out from its tiny performance space in Midtown, divided the considerable burden of Wolfs Spanisches Liederbuch among three singers. And the performers onstage indeed seemed fresher after two and a half hours than the good-size audience, which had made it through two intermissions before beginning to dwindle.

title: Detroit Decides to Help Shape, Not Resist, Regulation of Emissions
description: The New York International Auto Show, which opened to the public yesterday, is a picture of an industry with a cloud over its head.

title: Second Fiddle to an Old Master
description: LAST Monday night, Christies auctioned off a 268-year-old carved wooden box with funny-looking holes in it for more than $2.7 million.

title: California: It Was the Maid, Not the Butler, Police Say
description: Detectives in Atherton arrested two people in a $100,000 wine theft from the cellar of a private residence. The 450 bottles that were stolen between Dec. 28 and Jan. 4 included a rare 1959 magnum from Chteau Ptrus in Bordeaux. The suspects, Zhi Mua Deng, 50, a domestic worker who had access to the house, and Xiao Yan Xiang, 52, were taken into custody after cameras installed by the police caught them returning to the cellar. It was just greed on the part of the crooks, said Detective Sgt. Joseph C. Wade, who was in charge of the investigation. The cellar was locked, but she had a key. The two are charged with burglary, conspiracy and possession of stolen property. At the suspects residences, the police found wine boxes, but only three bottles of wine. We are still looking at what happened to the wine, Sergeant Wade said.

title: As One Syria Trip Draws Fire, Others Draw Silence
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  Ever since 1952, when a Republican senator, Arthur H. Vandenberg, coined the phrase, it has been said that in American foreign affairs, politics should stop at the waters edge. Now, with President Bush confronting an opposition party in control of Congress, that fiction is becoming harder to maintain.

title: HUD Institutes Changes to Speed Storm Repairs
description: Louisiana homeowners may get faster access to rebuilding grants after a federal decision late last month that is forcing the state to change its slow-moving $7.5-billion Road Home program to repair houses damaged or destroyed by hurricanes in 2005.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about a new push to confront racial imbalance in the Greenwich, Conn., public schools misstated the content of full-page advertisements placed recently in local newspapers by a group calling itself Concerned Citizens of Greenwich. The ads raised concerns about a proposal to spend $23 million rebuilding Glenville School, and offered a broader critique of a new task force considering topics including racial balance and redistricting. The ads did not ask that neighborhood schools not be made to suffer in the rush to bolster other schools.

description: A reporter for MarketWatch, an online business news site owned by Dow Jones, resigned yesterday after published reports suggested that a Web site she started on her own might have created a conflict of interest.

title: Prez Continues the Mets Streak of Sparkling Starts
description: ATLANTA, April 6  After the giant American flag was presented, the military jets flew overhead and the Braves were introduced, something unprecedented happened for an opening game at Turner Field: The rafters in left field, where the pennants commemorating the Braves division championships hang, remained quiet.

title: Jazz Meets Ballet and a Tango Breaks Out
description: Odyssey Dance Theater called its New York debut program Shut Up and Dance! but failed to heed that advice. A jazz-ballet company based in Salt Lake City, Odyssey performs in a fusion style that is now familiar, blending traditional jazz with classical ballet and modern dance and in the process losing much of the distinctively sharp, thrusting edge of traditional jazz dance.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 9 P.M. (Hallmark) LOVES UNENDING LEGACY (2007). This fifth installment in the Love Comes Softly series, based on the novels by Janette Oke, finds Missie LaHaye (Erin Cottrell, above), now a frontier widow, and her son returning home to her parents two years after the murder of her sheriff husband. Altruistic to the end, she adopts an orphaned teenager, who then implores Missie to rescue her 7-year-old brother. Two men, a pastor and a sheriff, are willing to help, and to woo. But Missies grief may prevent her from finding true happiness.

title: A Difficult Journey of Devotion to One Faith and to a Spouse of Another Faith
description: Toward the end of the worship service on Good Friday in 2001, Carrie Pass looked down the pew at the man she was thinking she just might marry. His name was Chris Boova, and in their nearly two years as a couple she had never seen his face so stricken.

title: Suns Complaint on Chip Maker Is Dismissed
description: Hynix Semiconductor, the worlds second-largest computer memory chip maker, has won a dismissal of claims by Sun Microsystems that it conspired to drive up memory chip prices, overcharging chip buyers.

title: A Chance to Be Heard
description: Jack Cline, an Alabama industrial chemist, was exposed to benzene on the job and developed leukemia. When Mr. Cline tried to sue, he ran into a surreal glitch in Alabama law: any time he filed his lawsuit would have been either too early or too late. Mr. Clines widow, Martha Jane Cline, is asking the United States Supreme Court to review the case. The court should grant review, and rule that Alabamas laws violate the Constitution.

description: An article on Tuesday about the history of a mansion for sale on Riverside Drive in Manhattan referred incorrectly to Victoria Sanders, a great-granddaughter of the original owner, Morris Schinasi. She was not in fact raised in the mansion.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 6  A prominent child psychiatrist who treated generations of troubled youth and preached sex education on public television was arrested Thursday night, accused of sexually abusing three patients.

description: Say you are looking for a deal on an airline flight. The Internet abounds with offers for low fares. You can find them on the major Internet travel agent sites like Orbitz, Travelocity or on more specialized sites like Cheaptickets.com or Sidestep.com.

title: Telecom Chief Quits in Italy After Clash Over Bid
description: MILAN, April 6  The chairman of Telecom Italia, Guido Rossi, resigned Friday after clashing with the companys largest shareholder, capping a week that began with AT&T and Amrica Mvil offering to buy control of Telecom, the biggest Italian telecommunications company.

title: Fourth Man Is Caught After F.B.I. Agents Death at Bank
description: By about 9:15 a.m. Thursday, it seemed the surveillance operation was going smoothly and according to plan. A team of more than two dozen agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation was one step ahead of its quarry, shadowing several men whom they believed to be violent, heavily armed bank robbers about to undertake their fifth holdup in New Jersey in two months, this one at a PNC Bank in Readington Township.

title: Four Amigos in Search of Agave-Based Adult Beverages
description: I RECKONED that inviting three fellow Texans to a tequila tasting might prove to be a risky proposition when I heard the jackhammers. It was a late winter evening, and I was shivering on the curb in front of Dos Caminos restaurant in Midtown Manhattan. The jackhammers were ripping up the sidewalk to make way for new rows of outdoor tables. My brain was already throbbing from the racket, and I hadnt even taken my first shot.

description: A brigade of young percussionists flicked their mallets up and down amid a thick underbrush of drums, chimes, vibes and the metal equipment that held them. An encyclopedia of plinks and plunks, thwoks and whacks flew out from the stage.

description: Fishermen and scientists may never fully understand the striped bass, but they will never stop trying. Few fish have been studied as much as the striped bass has between spring and fall. Its wintering biology, however, is less understood.

title: Breast Cancer Screening
description: The often confusing issue of screening for breast cancer just got more confusing. First, a major medical group disputed the need for regular mammograms for all women ages 40 to 49, as is currently recommended. Then a widely used computer system that was supposed to make mammograms more accurate was judged to make them less accurate. And guidelines just issued by the American Cancer Society recommend annual M.R.I. scans  in addition to mammograms  for all women at especially high risk of developing breast cancer, starting at age 30.

title: Olcott Deming, 98, Ambassador to Newly Independent Uganda, Dies
description: Olcott Hawthorne Deming, a career Foreign Service officer and the first American ambassador to Uganda after it gained independence from Britain in 1962, died on March 20 near his home in Washington. He was 98.

description: WASHINGTON, April 6  After months of prodding China to crack down on pirated copies of American movies, music and software, the Bush administration appears ready to escalate the dispute into a legal confrontation.

description: IF someone said that you could reduce your bills by a significant amount by taking one simple step  and this step would be neither time-consuming nor embarrassing  wouldnt you want to know what it was?

title: Courts Lack Authority in Prisoners Case, Judges Say
description: A federal appeals court ruled that United States courts did not have the authority to prohibit allied military forces in Iraq from transferring to Iraqi government custody an American who has been sentenced to death. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled that the prisoner, Mohammed Munaf, 53, did not have recourse to American courts because he had been convicted by a court of a sovereign nation. Mr. Munaf, an Iraqi who became an American citizen in 2000, was convicted for his role in the kidnapping of three Romanian journalists in Baghdad. Mr. Munaf, who was sentenced to death by hanging by an Iraqi judge, has said his trial was flawed and his confession coerced. Jonathan Hafetz, a New York lawyer representing Mr. Munaf, said an appeal would be sought.

title: News Agency and Google End Dispute Over Use of Material
description: Agence France-Presse, a global news agency based in Paris, said yesterday that it had settled its lawsuit against Google Inc., the online search engine, and would allow the Internet company to post news and photos from AFP journalists.

It is $6.2 million  not $30 million, which is the amount for restoration of all animals harmed by DDT.

title: Radical Pakistani Cleric Threatens Suicide Attacks in Capital

The program, CNN: Special Investigations Unit, will be shown weekly, not occasionally.

On stage Wednesday at Studio B in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, he stood with his electric guitar, eaves of long hair falling on either side of his face, nodding at his work. His piece  it was only one piece  started with one repeated loud staccato note, played with a pick ad infinitum as a seemingly endless dexterity drill.

title: Mourning on the Inside
description: KEITH RICHARDS, the hard-living guitarist for the Rolling Stones, recently claimed  in jest, he now says  that, after the death of his father in 2002, he mixed some of the old mans ashes with cocaine and snorted them. While the tabloid press was quick to milk this revelation for every last bit of shock value, ingesting a dead family member isnt quite as depraved as it seems. After all, funerary cannibalism, as anthropologists call it, has existed in different parts of the world since prehistoric times.

title: Elizabeth Kals Reilley, Scholar of Horticulture, Dies at 99
description: Elizabeth Kals Reilley, a horticultural librarian, scholar and book collector who amassed a major private collection of rare books on landscape design, died on March 29 at her home in Muttontown, N.Y. She was 99.

title: Early Offensive Burst Among Best Ever
description: The Mets are off to a scorching start. Not only are they 4-0 but they have outscored their opponents 31-3. The Mets +28 run differential through their first four games is the second best mark for a team with four straight wins to start a season in the past 100 years, according to ESPN. The Milwaukee Brewers had a +32 run differential through the first four games of the 1978 season. The Brewers went on to 93-69 record but finished third in the American League East (this was before there were three divisions and the Wild Card, and the Brewers were in the American League) and did not make the playoffs.

title: A Royal Moment at the Malaysian Grand Prix
description: Formula One is definitely an us and them sport. There is what Jackie Stewart likes to call the inner sanctum of the paddock, and then there are the cramped grandstands or grass and dirt areas surrounding the circuits where the spectators assemble. There are several levels of spectator areas, from concrete seats to Paddock Club lodges. Some people attend races on buses, others in their cars left in dusty or muddy parking lots, and others fly in by helicopter. The eating habits of race goers ranges from gourmet in the Paddock Club to hot dogs or their equivalent in the outer reaches of the circuit area. The F1 parties vary from the camp fire get togethers to galas with the cream of the Paddock club and a regions social elite.

description: An article last Sunday about a new map depicting the citys Jewish heritage erroneously included an actress- director among Jewish figures from the Bronx. Penny Marshall is not Jewish.

title: Correction: F.Y.I.
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about a publicist for the Barnum & Bailey Circus from 1881 to 1907 misstated his given name. He was Richard Hamilton, not William. (He went by Tody.)

title: Collecting the Old West
Collecting the Old West
description: The mayor of Harrisburg, Pa., spent $7.8 million of public funds on items for an Old West museum he hoped to open.

title: Win a Trip Update
description: The entry period for Win a Trip closed last night. I hope everybody was able to get their applications in on time. Whats next? A team of folks at The Times will read through the thousands of applications weve received and select roughly a dozen students and a dozen teachers as finalists. Well be in contact with the finalists in the coming weeks.

title: 2008: War Tops Most G.O.P. Agendas
description: Marc Santora of The Times analyzes the foreign policy message in Rudolph W. Giulianis new stump speech and finds that 9/11 is a constant backdrop, even if he rarely mentions the terrorist attacks.

title: Pena, Pena Jr. and Matsuzaka
description: Tony Pena did not see videotape of his sons at-bats against Bostons Daisuke Matsuzaka last Thursday, so he was curious when I recounted how he had one. The younger Pena, the rookie shortstop for the Royals, grounded out to Matsuzaka twice, but he saw a total of 11 pitches and did not seem unnerved.I talked to him, but we didnt get into the game, Pena, a Yankees coach, said. When I talk to him, I try to make it father and son. When he has time away from the ballpark, I want him to be relaxed and not make it about baseball.Pena smiled as I told him how professionally his son had handled himself in postgame interviews. Pena Jr. praised Matsuzaka, but did not sound as if he had just faced the reincarnation of Tom Seaver.He was normal, he said of Matsuzaka. Hes got good stuff.Real good stuff. Matsuzaka pitched seven innings and whiffed 10 to power the Red Sox past the Royals, 4-1. Pena will get to see Matsuzaka on April 21, when he is scheduled to start against the Yankees at Fenway Park.

title: Warhol on Display
description: If you want your product to be famous, like Campbells Soup, Coca-Cola or Brillo, get an artist like Andy Warhol to immortalize it.

title: Helping Mukhtar Mai
description: In Sundays column, I wrote about Hasina Bibi and her struggle to get justice after the murder of her daughter  and, more broadly, about Mukhtar Mais own crusade to help people like Hasina Bibi. I know some readers will want to know how they can help.

title: Look, Ma, No Handles
description: As a group from the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum toured the auto show earlier this week, one woman stopped in front of the Lincoln MKR design study and asked suddenly: Why do none of the concept cars have door handles? She was right.

title: Mukhtar's Refuge
description: Nicholas D. Kristof revisits the rape victim who has created a sanctuary for women in Pakistan.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu
description: The timing of Mike Huckabees full-show interview on CBSs Face the Nation is, lets put it this way, a mixed blessing. On the one hand, its Easter Sunday, so many of the evangelical voters that the former Arkansas governor and Baptist pastor is courting in his bid for the G.O.P. presidential nod might be focusing more on tomorrow mornings Easter egg hunt than on national politics. On the other hand, presumably because its Easter, NBCs Meet the Press, which competes with Face the Nation in many markets, has only a pundit panel scheduled. So maybe viewers will flip channels in search of harder news.

title: A Q&A With Dr. Elizabeth Nabel
description: Dr. Elizabeth Nabel, a practicing cardiologist and researcher studying the genesis of plaque in coronary arteries, became director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute on Feb. 1, 2005. A firm believer in prevention, she exercises vigorously nearly every day and can recite her blood pressure, blood cholesterol and body mass index. Here are the five things she thinks everyone should know about heart disease.

title: Corrections: Daughters of the Dinah, Unbound
description: An article last Sunday about the Kraft Nabisco Championship, a golf tournament in Palm Springs, Calif., that is the centerpiece of a spring social gathering for lesbians, referred incorrectly to the tournament. It is the first of the four annual major tournaments for the Ladies Professional Golf Association; it is not the first L.P.G.A. event of the year.

title: Isles Beat Flyers, Then Wait for Help to Arrive
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 7  Islanders left wing Ryan Smyth, his hair still wet from a shower, strode out of Wachovia Center shortly after 4 p.m. Saturday and stepped onto a white bus with a leprechaun painted on the side.

title: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe Critics Face Beatings
description: HARARE, April 5  Keith Charumbira had just stepped off a minivan taxi in southwest Harare three weeks ago, fresh from a Friday evening gathering of civic advocates in Zimbabwes capital city, when he saw the knot of policemen walking toward him. It was too late to flee.

title: Rites of Spring
description: IT is a season of renewal for Christians and Jews as they commemorate momentous events in their histories: for Christians, the resurrection of Jesus; for Jews, the liberation of the ancient Hebrews from slavery in Egypt. As Jews began celebrating the eight days of Passover at sundown last Monday, Christians observed the final, most solemn days of Lent in preparation for Easter services this weekend. Here are a handful of stories about different faith communities around the region.

title: A Touch of Artistic License
description: DO you remember that smart, funny guy in high school who was so nice he danced with the girl nobody else would dance with? Kevin Kennon, now a high-powered architect with an office in Lower Manhattan, is that guy.

title: Captain of the Low Seas
description: BETWEEN the recent migration of the Fulton Fish Market and the impending arrival of Santiago Calatravas stack of ultra-luxurious condos, the South Street Seaport is somewhat short on true grit these days. It is shorter still with the recent and possibly permanent departure of Lars Hansen.

title: The Widening College Loan Scandal
description: Congress needs to address the college loan scandal that has unfolded since New Yorks attorney general, Andrew Cuomo, began to investigate the troubling  and possibly illegal  payments to universities that steer students to so-called preferred lending companies. These kickbacks are part of a wider pattern of shady dealing that, we now find out, reaches into the federal government as well.

title: San Francisco, N.Y.
description: MOST social networking Web sites emerged from San Franciscos first dot-com boom. Now the people behind some of those sites, their pockets lined with venture capital, are taking the socializing offline, hoping to give the San Francisco singles scene some flesh-and-blood sex appeal.

title: How It Happens: It's Not a 'Plumbing Problem'
description: When Dr. Peter Libby, chief of cardiovascular medicine at Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston, talks to his patients about heart disease, he often has to start by disabusing them of a popular misconception.

title: Show Goes On, Just Dont Drink to It
description: Pitman

title: Whats on Sunday Night
description: 9 P.M. (PBS) THE WIND IN THE WILLOWS He may be the worlds most exasperating amphibian. But Mr. Toad, the exuberant spendthrift (played by the British comedian Matt Lucas, above) with a fondness for boats, cars and snazzy attire who is at the center of this new Masterpiece Theater adaptation of the Kenneth Grahame childrens classic, has friends to spare. They include the stern Badger (Bob Hoskins), the easygoing Ratty (Mark Gattis) and the ever-loyal Mole (Lee Ingleby). Anna Maxwell Martin brings up the rear as the Jailors Daughter, who befriends Toad after his shenanigans land him in prison, and Imelda Staunton is the Barge Lady, who almost outwits the clever green schemer after his prison break. But who can blame the group for their misadventures? As Ratty says to Mole as they row dreamily down the stream, Believe me, my young friend, there is nothing  absolutely nothing  half so much worth doing as simply messing about in boats.

title: Home Where Family Died Is Now Safe Haven
description: BALTIMORE, April 7  For most of the last five years, the charred corner house in a blighted East Baltimore neighborhood stood vacant, a symbol of all that could go wrong in an urban war on drugs.

title: 2 Years After Big Speech, a Lower Key for Obama
description: COLO, Iowa, April 6  Senator Barack Obama is not big on what he calls red-meat applause lines when he campaigns in small communities like this one, 45 miles northeast of Des Moines. He does not tell many jokes. He talks in even, measured tones, and at times is so low-key that he lulls his audiences into long, if respectful, silences.

title: How to Confine the Plants of the Future?
description: A NEW generation of genetically engineered crops that produce drugs and chemicals is fast approaching the market  bringing with it a new wave of concerns about the safety of the global food and feed supply.

title: Powerfully Mixed Messages at the Show
description: JUST as automakers prepared to parade their signature V-8 models with 300, 400 and even 500-plus horsepower last week at the opening of the New York International Auto Show, a landmark Supreme Court ruling on greenhouse gas emissions wafted a message to the petrol-fueled party in Manhattan: enjoy the fun while it lasts.

title: Miracles and the Fast Track to Sainthood
description: To become a saint during the Roman Catholic Churchs first thousand years, it was enough for a local church in Christendoms far reaches simply to declare someone holy. But inevitably, sticky issues of process and standards crept in: in the 12th century, Pope Alexander III scolded Swedes for venerating a monk killed in a drunken brawl.

title: Get Out. No, Wait, Come Back!
description: WALKING ON EGGSHELLS

title: Kosovo War-Crimes Trial Splits West and Prosecutors
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Ramush Haradinaj, a stocky ethnic Albanian former guerrilla commander and, briefly, Kosovos prime minister, is either one of the most impressive leaders to emerge in the Balkans in recent years or a vicious war criminal. Or perhaps both.

title: A Passover Sermon, a Play, and a Century of the Melting Pot
description: The melting pot metaphor, touchstone of Americas debate over immigration, was claimed by the rabbi of a New York City synagogue, who said he coined it in a Passover sermon he gave exactly 100 years ago.

title: This Thing of Ours, Its Over
description: IM old, Carm, Tony Soprano says at the beginning of the end on Sunday. This New Jersey mob boss has recovered from last seasons shooting but tells Carmela he feels changed: My body has suffered a trauma it will probably never recover from.

description: To the Editor:

title: Slain F.B.I. Agent Is Recalled as Watchful, Loyal Neighbor
description: Though Barry Lee Bush knew well the dangers that went with being an F.B.I. agent, he liked to joke that the most perilous part of his day was the hourlong commute to his office in Newark from his home in Easton, Pa., a friend and neighbor of Mr. Bush said yesterday.

title: Form, Function and Controversy
description: CLEANLINESS, as the saying goes, is next to godliness. But combine these two virtues into a single product and some consumers may take offense.

title: For the Chief Justice, a Dissent and a Line in the Sand
description: WASHINGTON

title: Formula One Turns From Grand Prix Courses to Semantics
description: SEPANG, Malaysia, April 7  As the BMW Sauber team shows off its Formula One cars not only at the Malaysian Grand Prix this weekend, but also at daily demonstrations in a park in Kuala Lumpur, it is clear why the team stands where it does in the sports latest controversy.

title: Existential
description: The threat thats represented by the extreme elements of Islam on a global basis now, Vice President Dick Cheney told Newsweek, is a problem that I think will occupy our successors maybe for two or three or four administrations to come. It is an existential conflict.

title: U.S. Warplanes Attack Shiite Gunmen as Fighting Persists in City South of Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, April 7  American fighter jets carried out an airstrike against Shiite militiamen in the southern city of Diwaniya on Saturday as battles continued there for the second day, American and Iraqi officials said.

title: The Stuff That Creativity Is Made Of
description: The Alpan Gallery has often pursued interesting, noncommercial visual art projects in the shadow of the Heckscher Museum and other Long Island public art institutions. In October, the gallery, which was founded in Roslyn by Nese Karakaplan in 1987 and moved to Huntington about five years ago, officially became a nonprofit art space.

title: The Big Picture, and Your Picture
description: YES, when it comes to investing, you want to keep your eye on the proverbial ball, watching your portfolio carefully to ensure maximum returns with minimum risk.

description: Three of the N.B.A.s leading scorers got an assist from Steve Candeloro last month.

title: For Selig and Baseball, It Was a Very Good Year
description: The story goes that when Babe Ruth demanded an $80,000 salary for the 1931 season, he was reminded that the sum was more than President Herbert Hoover made ($75,000). Yeah, Ruth supposedly responded, but I had a better year than he did.

title: Three Ways to Shine in a Foggy Market
description: IT was a lackluster quarter for the overall market, but some mutual funds made money from eclectic stock portfolios. Here, managers of three of the top-performing funds talk about their stocks, their strategies and what they see ahead in the market.

title: Pressing for Independent Advice From Consultants
description: FOR more than three decades, Jeffrey S. Hyman advised companies on executive pay packages for Hewitt Associates, one of the countrys largest providers of compensation consulting and other corporate services.

description: Troubled Theater Welcomes Support

description: DAVID DIAOS earliest works are now rarely seen, but today one hangs prominently in the exhibition High Times, Hard Times: New York Painting 1967-1975, at the National Academy Museum in Manhattan through April 22.

title: Teaching the Police to Stay a Step Ahead of Car Theft
description: AT a little past midnight on a recent Sunday night in a Los Angeles suburb, Bell, the police moved to stop a weekly illegal street race that had been carving up the side streets along the Long Beach Freeway for six months.

title: Correction: Look Whos Coming to the Democrats Place
description: The On Politics column last Sunday, about a scheduled appearance before a State Assembly committee by Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey, erroneously included a legislator among those whose offices had received subpoenas from Mr. Christies office for records. Assemblyman Joseph Cryans office was not subpoenaed.

title: On the Red Sea, as Hotels Go Up, Divers Head Down
description: IN the wilds of Marsa Alam, Egypt, nothing is familiar. Pastel mountains, a pink, green and yellow pointillist fantasy, soar overhead, scraping the shimmering curtain of the sky. Sand dunes fan out in orderly waves, orange-striped goats feeding between them, and flocks of blue parrots coast by above. Hamada el-Kawy, my guide to this strange land, taps his eyes and points to a purple unicorn grazing on a nearby mountain. Unicorns are famously wary of strangers, but this one hasnt noticed us yet, its horned head facing the other direction. We make our way toward it, silently, slowly, hoping for a closer look, but its no good. It sees us and bolts.

title: Heartbreak in Suburbia, Exuberance in Colombia
description: Panda Bear

title: The Poet of Exile
description: Poets behave like conquistadors wherever they roam, picking up a new verse form, a lover, some inventive cursing, a disease. Would Byron have been Byron without Italy and Greece? What would Eliot and Pound have become without the hostility of London? Can we imagine Hart Crane without the Caribbean or Elizabeth Bishop without Rio? Derek Walcott has crossed so many borders, his poems read like a much-thumbed Baedeker. To a boy born on St. Lucia, the rhythms and intonations of English verse were a passport to the elsewhere; but they came with a burden  the language of the colonial masters was not the one caught in his ear at home. How choose, he wrote, Between this Africa and the English tongue I love? / Betray them both, or give back what they give?

title: Hot Dogs With No Disrespect
description: When the Papaya King chain was considering towns for its first New Jersey outpost, Clifton was a natural pick.

title: A Garden Cures Rootlessness
description: GUILFORD

title: The Chicken and the Egg Both Come First Here
description: THERE are lovely pale green eggs available at John Boys Farm Market these days, but they have nothing to do with Easter. Instead, these eggs come naturally from the farms Araucana chickens, one of four types that provide this Pound Ridge farm with its daily quota of fresh bounty.

title: Is the U.S. Protecting Foreign Artifacts? Dont Ask
description: WASHINGTON

title: Rangers Lose Intensity, but Hold on to 6th Place
description: PITTSBURGH, April 7  For the first time in more than a month, the Rangers exhaled.

title: When a Brand Name Considers a Move
description: THE Arizona Beverage Company is nearing a decision on whether to move its headquarters from Lake Success to Woodbury or to New Jersey. If Arizona Beverage goes, it will be the second company in recent months to announce intentions to move its headquarters from the village, which is in northwestern Nassau County; Canon USA said in November that it was going to Melville.

title: One Dances the Cancan, the Other the Minuet
description: THE town houses at 10 and 12 West 56th Street could not be more different. One is a sumptuously French essay built entirely in limestone, the other a subdued Georgian-style brick residence. But they are inextricably linked, constructed almost at the same time by two business partners, Frederick Edey and Henry B. Hollins, who was sometimes known as Harry. Now, a circle of sorts is closing as the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which designated 12 West 56th Street in 1984, is aiming to do the same for its neighbor.

title: The Year the Pie and Coffee Ran Out
description: LIKE the homecoming queen who was its resident ghost, Twin Peaks died young and left a ravaged but still beautiful corpse. Both demises are now inextricably linked: When David Lynchs hit series revealed who killed Laura Palmer in the fall of 1990, it also committed a kind of symbolic suicide.

title: Back From Iraq at the Great American Diner
description: BENSALEM, Pa.

title: On TV, Attitude Is More Important Than the Way the Vowels Sound
description: ENGLISH enunciation isnt what makes Americans weak at the knees: its the cruelty behind the words. The British are breathtakingly callous when it comes to comedy, as is all too obvious in this era of Ricky Gervais and Sacha Baron Cohen. Try as we might, we can never quite match their flinty talent for trafficking in boorishness and scalding embarrassment.

title: Theyre Playing Our Song?
description: THERE was no stopping Helena Thorne Marrin when the music started. Do you do the Charleston? she asked a just-arrived guest at the black-tie fund-raiser she had helped to organize.

title: Real Crimes, Unreal Weapons
description: IN January, a 13-year-old wielding what looked like a .38-caliber revolver tried to rob a Chinese restaurant in Mount Vernon, N.Y., until workers wrested the gun from him.

title: Housing Slump Pinches States in Pocketbook
description: MIAMI, April 7  State tax revenues around the country are growing far more slowly this year and in some cases falling below projections, a result of the housing market slowdown that has curbed voracious spending on real estate, building materials, furniture and other items.

title: Gingrich Assails Gonzales on Prosecutor Firings
description: WASHINGTON, April 8  Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, today became the latest Republican to criticize Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales for the controversial dismissals of eight United States attorneys and said Mr. Gonzales should consider stepping down.

title: The Three Souths
description: Everyone who lived through the Civil War, Abraham Lincoln observed in his second Inaugural Address, knew that slavery was somehow its cause. Ever since, historians have been struggling to explain that somehow. Their interpretations fall into two broad schools. One sees the war as the result of an irrepressible conflict between two societies with incompatible interests and values. The second blames irresponsible agitators and a blundering generation of political leaders for bringing about a war that could and should have been avoided.

title: Home Loans: A Nightmare Grows Darker
description: SNAZZY and newfangled mortgage loans, like those with low initial rates of interest or extended terms of 40 or 50 years, helped to drive homeownership rates in the United States from around 64 percent two decades ago to a peak of almost 70 percent in recent years. Called affordability loans, these new kinds of mortgages have gone mostly to first-time home buyers and borrowers with tarnished credit or spotty employment histories.

title: A Mutual Inspiration Society in Action
description: FOR the last few weeks the guitarist Pat Metheny and the pianist Brad Mehldau have been conducting an almost nightly experiment. On a cross-country string of concerts in support of their fine recent Nonesuch albums  Metheny Mehldau, which has sold more than 30,000 copies since September, and Quartet, released on March 13  they have been combining two of modern jazzs most distinctive personalities, in a mercurial sort of chemistry. And the results are exceeding some high expectations.

title: Has the Exit Sign Ever Looked So Good?
description: WHAT was the price of failure in corporate America in 2006?

description: Senators Offer New Plan to Pay for Rail Cars

description: Keith Orr thought he would surprise his doctor when he came for a checkup.

description: Couldnt they have said no?

title: Was He the Eggman?
description: THE story of eggs Benedict is a hard one to tell. The beginning is shady at best, the main character has a hangover, and there are decades when nothing much happens. But the genre is certain, and the setting clear: Eggs Benedict is a mystery rooted in a long-vanished version of New York. Despite the dishs twisted history, it provides a link to one of the citys more glamorous eras.

title: Hearing Voices
description: FROM age 13, Daniel Smiths father heard voices  inner instructions to move a glass across the table or to use this subway turnstile rather than that one. The strain of fighting the voices in secret, Smith believes, led to the psychotic depression his father suffered in his late 30s. The father responded with rage when he later learned that his own father had also heard voices, ones that advised on discards at gin or (less correctly) on bets at the track. What pain could have been avoided if only it had been clear that such voices are not necessarily signals of mental illness.

title: Tara Smith, Thomas Struth
description: Tara Bray Smith, a writer, and Thomas Struth, the photographer, were married yesterday by the Rev. Vernon Nichols, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: No Longer an Outsider Looking In
description: UNLIKE those people who move to the South when nearing retirement, Bob Trenta headed to the warmth of Florida early in his career. Now, decades later, he wanted to return North  back to his not-quite-home turf.

title: Knowing the Score
description: The other day I was sitting across from my accountant. He was calculating what I earned, spent and deducted. My head was racing. Did I earn more than last year? Did I deduct too little? Then there was a new chunk of money to consider, recently left by my father. Did that bequest really equal more than all my savings? Im doing well compared with most, but I still wondered why I make less than many I know.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: PRAGUE UNDER THE INFLUENCE

description: DID D-Wave Systems achieve the incredible  a startling advance in computing that would radically expand human capacities for industrial activity and scientific discovery, long before experts believed it possible?

description: SMITHTOWN

title: What Kind of Car Is a Ford Madox Ford?
description: A decade ago in Berlin, sunk in a plush seat in the Konzerthaus on the Gendarmenmarkt, I sneaked Clive Jamess Unreliable Memoirs from my handbag to distract myself from a concert that was being conducted at Looney Tunes velocity. Sinking into the pages, I forgot about the music lovers around me, the chandeliers above and the strenuously laboring musicians below, and slipped into the world of Jamess hardscrabble Australian boyhood. Absorbed in his account of a disastrous youth-group performance  he was supposed to crouch on the floor and wait for a large girl named Maureen to somersault over him  I read: She came hurtling out of the back annex, along the corridor, through the connecting door, into the hall, up to the springboard and into space. She drove me into the floor like a tack. I burst out laughing ... and was jolted back into awareness of my august setting by 80 enraged spinning heads and sputtered shushes from three rows of German aesthetes. I had failed to spot the warning printed on the cover of the book, plucked from the ticker tape parade of critical praise it had earned in Britain: Do not read this book in public. You will risk severe internal injuries from trying to suppress your laughter.

title: On Frances Far Right, Tweaking an Image
description: PARIS, April 6  Jean-Marie Le Pen, the far-right presidential candidate, ventured into potentially hostile terrain on Friday, making a surprise visit to a troubled, multiethnic suburb of Paris.

title: A Utah Dynasty Is Divided Over a Presidential Preference
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 4  Jon M. Huntsman Sr., a self-made billionaire, philanthropist, and patriarch of one of Utahs most powerful families, waxes philosophic in the letters he has written urging people to support former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts as the Republican nominee for president. A defining moment for the future of our great country, Mr. Huntsman calls the 2008 election.

title: Inside the List
description: KEEP YOUR NOUN ALIVE: Jeremy Scahills muckraking book Blackwater: The Rise of the Worlds Most Powerful Mercenary Army, enters the nonfiction list at No. 9. Its a crackling expos of the secretive military contractor Blackwater USA, which Scahill refers to as both the new Halliburton and the elite Praetorian Guard for the global war on terror.

title: Making Sense of All the Math
description: THERE is a cruel logic in the fact that the most important purchase of a persons life is also the most daunting. Mortgage products, especially in recent years, have grown complex enough to strain the mathematical capacities of many borrowers, and shifting market conditions only add to the complexity.

title: What G.E.s Profit Says About the Planet
description: AS General Electric goes, so goes the world, more or less.

title: The War of the Russes, Ballets Fabled Troupe
description: NOW, just weeks from the start of the spring seasons of New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater, is as good a time as any to consider the Americanization of classical dance. Again and again, the story has been told through George Balanchine, who came, saw and conquered. But there was ballet in the United States before Balanchine got here. And there were other forces kindling the flame far beyond New York. Their influence persists even now, as Dayna Goldfine and Dan Geller show in their documentary Ballets Russes.

title: A Caution Signal on Profits. A Red Light for Stocks?
description: FOR weeks, Wall Street has been debating whether the economy is headed for a fall. Thats because investors look to economic growth to see where corporate earnings might be headed, says Sam Stovall, chief investment strategist at Standard & Poors.

title: Reds Heightened by a Warm Spell
description: In 2002, after one of the warmest growing seasons then on record, Adam Suprenant, the winemaker at Ospreys Dominion in Peconic, capitalized artfully on his red grapes. It couldnt have been hard; properly tended red grapes matured so perfectly that year that the regions best wines virtually made themselves.

title: He Changed His Spots, but Cals Still the Car-Sales King
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.

title: Game-Time Decision
description: I organized a trip to a pro basketball game for 20 friends, purchasing tickets up front, then collecting the cash from each person. On game night, several did not show up, only some of whom alerted me in advance. I sold those tickets at face value at the arena. Who should get that money? Should it be refunded to the no-shows? Spread evenly among all?  P. J., Texas

title: A Father on Poster Board Just Wont Do
description: MY three-dimensional husband, Scott, became a Flat Daddy this spring, when his frequent absences (he is an active-duty Navy pilot preparing for deployment) made me worry that our two young children were forgetting him.

title: Thinking Big at a Time Others Are Thinking Small
description: AT community meetings in veterans halls, senior centers and junior high cafeterias throughout Queens, its the rare debate that doesnt center on the thorny issue of zoning. From Maspeth to Douglaston, simmering anger over McMansions and overbuilding in general is bubbling over. The result is a boroughwide push to use zoning  specifically downzoning  to keep out the tall, bulky multifamily dwellings that seem to be popping up in more and more neighborhoods.

description: Nassaus Bid for Cigarette Tax Draws Opposition

description: The Public Editor column on March 11 incorrectly identified John F. Burns. He is The Timess Baghdad bureau chief, not a former bureau chief there.

title: Poor Defense Brings the Mets Fast Start to a Halt
description: ATLANTA, April 7  The overlooked story line in the Mets sizzling start, Manager Willie Randolph said before Saturdays game, was their crisp defense. As the Cardinals bumbled all over the outfield and the Braves booted grounders, the Mets, in going 4-0, seemed immune from such mishaps.

title: Laurie Baker, Designer of Homes for Indias Poor, Is Dead at 90
description: Laurie Baker, a British architect whose chance meeting with Mahatma Gandhi in the 1940s started him on a lifelong career of designing low-cost and environmentally respectful houses in India, died on April 1 at the Hamlet, a home he designed himself, in Thiruvananthapuram, the capital of the state of Kerala. He was 90.

title: Sing Out, Sky Dobbs!
description: As a light rain coated the dugouts of Shea Stadium on Wednesday evening, an 18-year-old from Manalapan, N.J., named Sky Dobbs stood at a microphone facing the field. She was wearing a black New York Mets ski jacket, and her curly brown hair was whipped by the wind.

title: In Custody Fights, a Hurdle for the Poor
description: Custody battles are rarely gentle affairs, but if you are poor, such fights can carry an added frustration: waiting months to get a court-approved visit with your own child.

title: Letters
description: The Washington Back Channel

title: Bonnets at the Table
description: Easter finery will be on display today during the Easter Parade and Easter Bonnet Festival, along Fifth Avenue from 49th to 57th Streets. And culinary skill is on display at these fine restaurants, many of them recent additions to the area.

title: Congress Seeks Compromise on Generic Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  Senior members of Congress from both parties are working feverishly on legislation that could give consumers access to lower-cost copies of biotechnology drugs that now cost tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.

title: Most Valuable? McGrady Surely Ranks for Impact
description: Tracy McGrady wanted in on the debate. But first he wanted a definition.

description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Borrowing Trouble
description: An article last Sunday about a class-action lawsuit over mortgage lending practices referred incorrectly to the loan-to-value ratio that is considered prudent for mortgages. It is a maximum of 80 percent, not a minimum of 80 percent. (The loan-to-value ratio is a measure of risk that compares the size of the total loan on a property to the underlying collateral.)

title: Google Offers Flight Information by Text Message
description: So youre on the way to the airport, doing your pretravel mental inventory. Passport? Check. Ticket? Check. Quart-size zip-top clear plastic bags? Check. Confirmation of flight departure? Hmm. Forgot about that one. If you have a cell phone (check!), theres no need to panic. Google has recently joined with the Web site flightstats.com to offer a free text-messaging service that distributes flight status reports and other airline information.

title: More Pieces. Still a Puzzle.
description: SUNLIGHT, remarked the Supreme Court justice Louis D. Brandeis, is said to be the best of disinfectants. One problem with too much sunlight, however, can be the blinding glare.

title: The Art of the Stump
description: IT was a few winters ago, when Nancy Bruning was walking along Cabrini Boulevard in Washington Heights to meet the exercise class she leads in Fort Tryon Park, that she spotted an unusual object atop a tree stump.

title: Calendar of Events
description: FILM

title: Fans Sour on Sweeter Version of Asias Smelliest Fruit
description: TUNG PHAEN, Thailand  You can take the sugar out of soft drinks and the fat from junk food. But eliminate the pungent odor from what may be the worlds smelliest fruit and brace for a major international controversy.

title: The Look of Love
description: I would say that I did a U-turn in my art in 1955 when I saw my first child being born, the sculptor Manuel Neri has said. That is when he began creating the astonishing life-size painted figurative sculptures in plaster, bronze and marble that he has made for the last half-century. Before then he had been an Abstract Expressionist oil painter and a disciple of Richard Diebenkorn. It was a fantastic moment. I realized then that the female body has the magic. The male may have the power, but the female has the magic.

title: Keeping the Faith
description: Walk into a shop to buy a newspaper or a wurst or a Game Boy in the German city of Regensburg and your server will probably welcome you with a brisk grss Gott, shorthand for God greet you. Its the local form of hello: street-corner dudes and grandmas, everyone says it. This is Bavaria, Germanys Catholic heartland, a region that gives the lie to the popular notion that Western Europe has tossed its Christian heritage in historys dustbin. Bavaria is as modern as you please  a center of the European telecommunications industry, the home of BMW (as in Bavarian Motor Works)  but on any special occasion you see couples wandering around looking like Hansel and Gretel, in lederhosen and dirndls. Elsewhere in Germany, Bavarian jokes serve the same function that Polish jokes used to in the United States. Bavarians will tell you they hold to tradition, religion and antique styles of speech not out of stupidity or addiction to kitsch but because they believe these things encompass what is real and true.

title: Seeing the Beauty in Imperfect Floors
description: EVERY morning, as I climb the stairs and trudge down the hall to my office, I pass over a section of floor that gives a noticeable groan. In former years, I made a mental note to one day pry up the offending plank and pad it with another layer of butcher paper. I also conceded this probably would come after about 200 other pressing chores.

title: Meetings Are Part Revival, Part Rally, but All Sharpton
description: On a rather small, anonymous stage in Harlem, in an old building a few doors down from a Laundromat and a Dunkin Donuts, something unexpected happens to the Rev. Al Sharptons sizable and nationally known persona. It shrinks accordingly.

title: Long Player
description: Writing a history of Columbia Records must have seemed a piquant idea, and The Label, by Gary Marmorstein, indeed tells an epic tale, full of the requisite clashing egos in the executive suite and (figurative) blood on the boardroom floor, with some of the great music of our time as underscoring.

title: With a Cafes Evolution, a City With a Little Less Grit
description: During a recent afternoon at a place called Alt Coffee, on Avenue A, a young woman on a couch read a book called Sister of the Road: The Autobiography of Boxcar Bertha. Sitting nearby, another young woman, with dreadlocks and a nose ring, gazed at a laptop computer. A gray-haired man dozed in a chair as Beatles music played through speakers.

title: Converting a Co-op to a Condominium
description: ONE question often asked is whether it makes sense for a co-op to convert to a condominium. And most lawyers say that completing such a conversion is almost always more trouble  and more costly  than its worth.

title: After Rockslide, Merchants Are Still Struggling
description: ALMOST 16 months after a landslide damaged several shops on Fifth Avenue in Pelham, the owners of those businesses are painfully aware of the difference between an earth movement and a rock topple.

title: As Scores Climb Ever Higher at Augusta, So Does Woods
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7  The last red number at Augusta National Golf Club fell at 6:34 p.m., sending the Masters to a place it has never been.

title: A West Side Story With a Promising Ending
description: TWO decades after deciding to resuscitate its economically troubled west side, Annapolis, Md., is now placing its hopes for a continued neighborhood revival on a new mixed-use development called Park Place.

title: Two Mommies
description: As a novelist, A. M. Homes has made a minor speciality of luridness. In all of her writing there is a latent sense that a crime has been or is about to be committed. Her memoir, The Mistresss Daughter, is no exception: it has the same foreboding, the same ambience of barely controlled menace. It opens with the sentence: I remember their insistence that I come into the living room and sit down and how the dark room seemed suddenly threatening, how I stood in the kitchen doorway holding a jelly doughnut and how I never eat jelly doughnuts. And as Homes moves through her account of her origins, the prevailing mood is that of film noir.

title: Energy Has a Tough Act to Follow: Itself
description: ENERGY investors are going to have a hard time duplicating their success of the last five years.

title: Pilgrim With an Oboe, Citizen of the World
description: DRESSED in black, his oval face adorned with sideburns and an upturned lock of hair, the slender oboist looked like a New Wave Tintin as he took his seat on stage for an orchestra rehearsal.

title: Tween on the Screen
description: Six or eight hip, pretty, very nervous-looking girls  somewhere around 14 years of age, though its possible they only look that old  were perched on couches in the splashy lobby of Nickelodeons New York production offices, high above Times Square. The girls were there to audition, but they werent holding scripts, because they were not auditioning for anything in particular. Were seeing kids all the time, Paula Kaplan, senior vice president of talent at Nickelodeon, told me. Even when we dont have a show to cast. Were meeting kids on a regular basis, just bringing them in, just to see who they are.

title: Jennifer Lindbom, Majid Yavary
description: Jennifer Kristin Lindbom and Majid Yavary were married yesterday at Westbury Manor in Westbury, N.Y. Ahmad Pakzad, a Muslim minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Mobile Ring Tones Starting to Lose Their Revenue Zing
description: As CD sales nose-dive, the music industry has been relying on cellphone ring tones as one way to lift sagging revenues. Ring tones have been such a big hit that Billboard even has charts for them now. (The No. 1 ring tone from a CD last week was This Is Why Im Hot by the rapper Mims.)

title: Big Auto Shows Scramble for Bragging Rights
description: DETERMINING which auto show can most accurately claim to be Americas biggest is like measuring tall buildings. There are many ways to count and little agreement on which figures are best.

title: Discrimination in Your Backyard (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: In One Swing, Rodriguez Is an Instant Hit
description: Alex Rodriguez slapped his hands as he rounded first base yesterday afternoon and then nearly plowed into the third-base coach Larry Bowa as he rounded third. Before touching home plate, he heaved his batting helmet toward the sky, a smile on his face every step of the way.

title: Kimberly Hamm, Jim Rendon
description: Kimberly Ann Hamm, a lawyer, and Alexander Elias Rendon, a writer, were married Friday morning at the New York City Municipal Building.

title: If the Building Is New ...
description: BUYERS should ask some additional questions if they are considering a new building. They should find out, for instance, about the warranties on their appliances and heating system, and who will control the board.

title: Gentlemen of the Road
description: Chapter 11: On the Unforeseen and Annoying Resemblance of a Bek's Life to an Ill-Played Game of Shatranj

title: Correction: Arsenic and Old Photos
description: An article and a picture caption last Sunday about the Getty Conservation Institutes effort to document all the ways photographs have been developed over the years misidentified an instrument used to analyze the chemical makeup of old prints. It is an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, not an infrared spectrometer. (The infrared instrument is also used in such work.)

title: Flexing Big Muscles for a Little Library
description: The Ulmer Park Branch Library, a squat, one-story brick building on Bath Avenue in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, would seem to have little in common with the skyscrapers and the wavy metal arena proposed for the 22-acre site to the north where the developer Bruce Ratner seeks to build the Atlantic Yards.

title: Attorney Inquiry Touches a Pillar of New Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  The seat of federal justice in Albuquerque is named for Senator Pete V. Domenici, a former mayor and native son who has showered New Mexico with federal money during his decades in Washington and was rewarded by having his name adorn the United States courthouse.

title: A Dozen Dont-Miss Models at the New York Auto Show
description: LOOKING for Americas next top model? If youre interested in something more substantial than underfed young women preening on television for a modeling contract, youll find plenty of candidates at the New York International Auto Show.

title: The Salsa Makes the Difference
description: Heading east on the Post Road in Fairfield, it is hard to miss the glowing red sign for La Salsa Fresh Mexican Grill, high up on an ecru-colored building. What is easier to overlook is that this diminutive place offers one of the better bargains around. And while the food comes off the grill with great rapidity, the quality of its ingredients sets it leagues above Taco Bell.

title: Options for Sending Excess Baggage Home From Abroad
description: I am returning to the United States after a lengthy stay in Germany and wonder how best to transport the things I have acquired. Books, for example, are heavy, and last time Lufthansa made me take stuff out of my bags to meet the weight limit. But its expensive to mail packages. Would it be cheaper to take these things as excess baggage?  Louis Marvick, Lneburg, Germany

title: Colt, With Big Victory, Shows Growth
description: Barclay Tagg took Nobiz Like Shobiz into the Wood Memorial looking for a growth spurt, a mental one that would match the colts imposing physique. Tagg, the colts trainer, believed he had a horse with more ability than Funny Cide, the gelding he trained to victories in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes in 2003.

title: Natural, Equal, Universal
description: According to many people in the West today, human rights trump all other claims and values, including those of custom, community and culture; everyone in the world, including every individual in strange faraway places like Darfur, has certain inalienable rights simply because he or she is a human being. As conventional as this claim has become for us, in the entire sweep of history it is quite extraordinary and of fairly recent origin. How did it come about and what has been its history? These are the questions Lynn Hunt has sought to answer in this remarkable little book. Indeed, because she covers so much ground in so few pages and with such clarity, Inventing Human Rights is a tour de force of compression.

title: Suspect in a Shooting Near Kennedy Is Arrested at a Virginia Bus Station
description: The principal suspect in a fatal shooting near Kennedy International Airport was taken into custody without incident yesterday in Richmond, Va., and confessed to the shooting, the Richmond police said.

title: Chained to His Desk
description: AS Jonathan Lethem made clear so cleverly in his purposely plagiarized article, The Ecstasy of Influence, in the February Harpers, no canvas is ever really blank. And artists are cut from the same cloth, the tapestry of art history.

title: Calculating the Pay Figures
description: TO measure executive compensation, Sunday Business studied 200 large public companies that filed proxies by March 31, 2007, for last year. Equilar Inc., an executive compensation research firm, compiled and analyzed the data from corporate filings.

title: Fears, Threats and the Occasional Bark
description: On March 16, the memo was slipped under each of the roughly 1,700 apartment doors in East River Housing, the complex of four red-brick co-op towers at the eastern end of Grand Street. Harboring of Dogs in Violation of Proprietary Lease, read the subject line. Residents were strictly enjoined not to harbor, possess or keep a dog, and were threatened with legal action if they persisted.

title: Maestro of the Internet
description: IF Mendelssohn were alive today, would he have a MySpace page? Probably, if the new board of directors of Orchestra New England had anything to do with it.

title: Heidi Brooks and Javit Drake
description: Heidi Michele Brooks and Javit Ahmed Drake were married in Charleston, S.C., last evening. The Rev. Dr. Preston N. Williams, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Mills House Hotel.

title: The Fabulist
description: Q: Youre about to publish your first novel, The Ministry of Special Cases, about a poor Jewish couple in Buenos Aires whose only son is disappeared in 1976. Did you spend a lot of time in Argentina researching the book? No. I was first there in 1991, for a friends wedding and honeymoon. It was a great honeymoon. Ive never been married, but I have been on a honeymoon.

title: Religious Principles Take Root in Funds
description: RELIGION has always been a central theme of American life, but until recently, there werent too many options for those interested in investing based on religious principles. That has begun to change.

title: Travels Abroad Lead to Journeys Within
description: ON a recent Thursday afternoon the photographer Lynn Davis sat nursing a cappuccino in the airy, ground-floor cafe of the Rubin Museum of Art in Chelsea. The Rubin, which opened in 2004, is primarily devoted to the Buddhist art of Himalayan Asia, and that afternoon Ms. Davis, a slender woman with translucent skin and a gleaming mane of white hair, seemed to radiate an air of inner tranquillity and relaxed contemplation.

title: National Parks Put Elk and Bison on the Menu
description: Lu Harlow, the food and beverage director at Yellowstone National Park, encountered an unexpected problem when she first put bison on one of the parks menus about three years ago. There is a buffalo on the emblem of employees uniforms, she said. A bunch of people told me they felt too guilty to try it.
