description: To the Editor:

title: Turning Roar of the Road Into a Whisper
description: During tough budget times in 1990, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. terminated the states highway sound barrier program. Since then  despite a significant increase in congestion  no barriers have been built along Connecticuts busiest byways, except for a handful in areas that qualified for federal aid by expanding capacity.

title: Near the Fast Lane, Rumblings About Noise
description: ON a sunny afternoon last week, Richard Rosen, who has explored the winding roads of Little Neck for virtually all of his 43 years, piloted his navy minivan around the service roads of Lake Success, the Nassau County community just over the city line from his house in Little Neck. His goal was to check out stone barriers along the Long Island Expressway that are designed to keep highway noise from spilling into adjacent residential areas.

title: In Her Fashion
description: With the publication of A Model Summer, Paulina Porizkova makes her own contribution to a literary sub-sub-genre, books by supermodels. Most of these get bad reviews, either because theyre truly awful, like Naomi Campbells Swan, which won Seventeen magazines Super-Cheesy Award, or  call me a conspiracy theorist  because jealous book critics arent tall and gorgeous, so they try to wield their puny amount of power to establish some sort of moral order.

title: Can Man Improve on Natures Fishbowl?
description: ATLANTA

title: The Soul of Morocco
description: A STRANGE device, ornate and arcane, looms over the passing mule carts and djellaba-robed masses that daily throng Talaa Kebira, the Broadway of Fez, the 1,200-year-old Moroccan city. Built into the high wall of the 14th-century Bou Inania mosque, just across from a halal butcher and his hanging rows of skinned lambs, 12 finely sculptured windows hover over 13 carved wooden blocks, on which long ago rested 13 brass bowls.

title: Greek Youth Remake Seattle of the Balkans
description: NEAR the seventh-century Church of Aghia Sophia in the northern Greek city of Salonika, prides of revelers are filling art-grunge bars like Urban and Pastaflora Darling! on lively Zefxidos Street. It's a weeknight  a Monday going on Tuesday, in fact  but it feels like a Saturday. The tsipouro is flowing, the New Pornographers are blaring, and the people, a blend of wispy artists bobbing to the music, balding academics recalling their anarchist years and caffeinated students now living theirs, are energized.

title: Making the Cut: A Matter of Interpretation
description: During Semana Santa, the Holy Week before Easter, it is customary among Latin American Catholics to refrain from eating red meat in favor of fish. Even so, the carniceras, or butcher shops, of Jackson Heights, Queens, were bustling last week with Hispanic customers tempted by glossy lobes of liver and super-thin slices of top round steak.

title: More Than an Easter in Common
description: TODAY, Eastern Orthodox, Roman Catholic and Protestant Christians have the wonderful opportunity to celebrate Easter together on the same date. To many, that idea might sound natural, since the celebration of Easter speaks to the most central aspect of the Christian faith: the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead.

title: Theres a History to All This History
description: AS suburbs stretch farther and farther out, the beachy Long Island Sound city of Milford, an hour and a half from New York City and an easy trip to places like New Haven and Stamford, finds itself changing in character  shifting, for many, from second-home destination to home sweet home.

title: Chain Reaction
description: If, like me, you are of a scientific bent  or even if youre not  New Mexico in the 1940s is one of those legendary places where the destinies of colorful and disparate strangers intertwined to cast long shadows on history. Atomic scientists, artists, soldiers and spies, cowboys and Indians all wandered through the winding canyons.

title: Correction: The Week in New Jersey
description: A headline on a report in The Week column last Sunday about the book written by Dina Matos McGreevey misstated her marital status. She is the estranged wife of former Gov. James E. McGreevey, not his ex-wife.

title: Rise of the Takedown
description: TO Alicia Estrada, a professor of Central American studies who was ejected from a screening of Mel Gibsons Apocalypto last month after grilling him about the historical accuracy of that Maya epic, which he directed, she was not a heckler, as Mr. Gibsons representatives called her, but a dutiful academic asking of him what she asks of students in her classroom.

title: Hunger Strike Breaks Out at Guantnamo
description: A new, long-term hunger strike has broken out at the American detention center at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, with more than a dozen detainees subjecting themselves to daily force-feeding to protest their treatment, military officials and lawyers for the detainees said.

title: In Thailand, Keeping the Festive in Festival
description: THE Thai festival calendar begins this week with the New Year soaking of Songkran, a nationwide water fight with roots in traditional Buddhist cleansing ceremonies. In recent years, the celebration has become more like St. Patrick's Day with water guns as Thai and farang (foreign) tourists guzzle alcohol and hose one another down in pursuit of what locals proudly call sanuk, or fun.

title: Correction: Glenn Horowitz Profile
description: A profile on March 25 about the rare-book and archives dealer Glenn Horowitz referred incompletely to M.G. Lord, his first wife. Her last work in the field of political cartooning was some 15 years ago; she is known today as a writer.

title: The Loft Where Time Stood Still
description: I RECENTLY sat in Los Angeles, staring at an article describing plans to build a residential tower on 10th Avenue on the Far West Side of Manhattan. Nothing new there. Except that the developer doesnt realize that his tower is destined to obliterate a strange and unexpected thing: my time capsule. Or, as some people used to call it, my mausoleum.

title: Laptops on Broadway; Zoo; Comics and Drama; Paul Taylor Dancers
description: LAPTOPS ON BROADWAY

title: Light at the End of the Trail
description: A 20-MILE trail through the largest remaining tract of contiguous forest in Central New Jersey could finally be reality in the next five years.

title: Behind the Wheels
description: THE New York International Auto Show is under way at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. A week ago there was nothing but concrete floor and pillars, but between last Sunday and when the doors opened to the public on Friday, 667 trailers were unloaded, an elaborate ceiling lighting system was lowered and 800,000 square feet of carpeting was laid out.

title: An Author Discovers, and Then Writes, The Best Place to Be
description: IN 1970, not long after Lesley Dormen moved to New York City, she was asked out on a date. Ms. Dormen, a new college graduate from Ohio, was working in Midtown at a magazine published by the Girl Scouts of America. When the designated Friday evening arrived, I came out of my office, and it was raining and there werent any cabs available, she said. I didnt know how to take the subway. I couldnt ask; I didnt dare. It was too shameful not to know. So I walked. Her destination was Park Avenue and 90th Street.

title: Those Plummy Tones Dont Work, Except When They Do
description: I WAS surprised to discover that quantum mechanics sounds sexier without an Oxbridge accent. This revelation came to me, somewhat to my mortification, when Michael Frayns Copenhagen, a play about the atomic physicists Niels Bohr and Werner Heisenberg, opened on Broadway in 2000.

title: Finding Their Niche in Cellphone Games
description: KARINA SIMONS became a cellphone game designer almost by default.

title: A Tribute, and One Conspicuous Absence
description: TRENTON

title: Womens Health, in Focus
description: I GREW up in Brooklyn during the height of the civil rights movement. It was a time of change and hope. My parents reinforced that feeling and made me think I was the most privileged person alive. Ive made the most of opportunities.

title: Proceed to Checkout
description: In the aftermath of Sept. 11, when publishers scrambled to provide explanations for the attacks, Benjamin R. Barbers 1995 book, Jihad vs. McWorld, an examination of the tensions between consumer capitalism and religious fundamentalism, was dusted off, rushed back to press and propelled to best-sellerdom. Around that time, Barber also released a memoir of his stint as a freelance intellectual in the Clinton White House, a melancholy rumination on the failures of that administration as well as his own failure to be named chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. With his latest book, Barber, a political theorist at the University of Maryland, returns to familiar territory. But if Jihad provided an answer to the ubiquitous post-9/11 question Why do they hate us?, the question behind Consumed seems to be Who wouldnt?

title: Return to Mogadishu
description: Nuruddin Farah, the graying, balding sage of Somali letters, has a literary vision both broad and deep, the vision of an exile and a patriot. Civil conflict has hollowed out the humanity of many of his compatriots, making them unfit to become responsible citizens even if Somalia can be made to function again, but the same calamities have acted on Farah differently, even benignly. Assuming a patriotic duty, he seeks goodness and bravery amid the evil, going willingly into the chamber of horrors that has become Somalia since the fall of Siad Barres dictatorship in 1991. In a challenge to the clan loyalties tearing Somalia apart, he has vowed to keep my country alive by writing about it.

title: With Bud Palmer
description: Bud Palmer moved from one outstanding career to another. A basketball star at Princeton, he played for the Knicks from 1946 to 1949 and was the teams first captain. After his playing career ended, he was a longtime television sportscaster and New York Citys public events commissioner. Now 85, Palmer lives in West Palm Beach, Fla. FRANK LITSKY

title: Special Education Enrollment Up Again in 06
description: THE number of New Jersey schoolchildren in special education grew faster than regular enrollment in most districts last year, continuing a trend that has persisted for many years and adding millions of dollars to school costs.

title: Switching Tracks With a South Korean Pact
description: THE free trade agreement the United States signed with South Korea last week could be the most important step in the nations trade policy since the North American Free Trade Agreement went into effect 13 years ago. If Congress approves it, the slashed tariffs could lead to billions of dollars of new trade. Yet it could also symbolize a shift away from global trade negotiations, which were supposed to help poor countries to grow.

title: About That Political Traffic Jam in Iowa
description: FORT MADISON, Iowa

title: North Koreans Arm Ethiopians as U.S. Assents
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  Three months after the United States successfully pressed the United Nations to impose strict sanctions on North Korea because of the countrys nuclear test, Bush administration officials allowed Ethiopia to complete a secret arms purchase from the North, in what appears to be a violation of the restrictions, according to senior American officials.

title: Country Living and Quiet Neighbors
description: AT the Greenwood Hill Condos, a pair of new buildings in the Greenwood Heights section of Brooklyn, the north-facing apartments have views of the Statue of Liberty and the Manhattan skyline. But the south-facing apartments face the headstone-studded hills of Green-Wood Cemetery across the street.

title: Iraq Confronts Hussein Legacy Cast in Bronze
description: BAGHDAD, April 7  He was ousted, captured, tried and executed. But while the dictator may be gone, his legacy visibly lives on.

Correction: The Complicated Power of the Vote to Nowhere
description: An article last Sunday about Congressional actions intended to end the Vietnam War misidentified the Democratic senator who co-sponsored an unsuccessful amendment with Senator Mark Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, that would have forced a withdrawal of all American troops by the end of 1971. He was George McGovern of South Dakota  not Frank Church of Idaho, who was involved in other antiwar legislation.

title: U.S. Clinches Victory; Will Meet Sweden in Semis
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., April 7  Andy Roddick, James Blake, and Bob and Mike Bryan took turns circling the tennis court inside Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum on Saturday, waving the American flag in front of a roaring capacity crowd. It was a victory parade for the United States Davis Cup team, which clinched its quarterfinal against Spain with a doubles victory by the Bryan twins.

title: Selling Himself and Prints, Too
description: THE e-mail message arrived in the middle of the night.

title: Have Fun
description: Theres a particular tone of voice that mothers use when they watch their kids at the pool  a queasy combination of have fun and dont die. Its how my mother sounded when I was leaving the country last year.

title: Up Front
description: William Logan, who wrote this weeks cover review, is known in the poetry world as a critic who doesnt mince words. His recent and largely negative assessment in these pages of a volume of Hart Cranes poetry and letters, for example, brought in dozens of angry letters. Logans response to those who dont like his plain-spoken reviews?

title: What I Wish I'd Known
description: Naomi Atrubin's life might have been different. She would know what was happening that Christmas Eve when she had her first heart attack.

title: Lisa Ristow and Mark Polansky
description: FOR most of his life, Mark L. Polanskys heart was in outer space. Then one day, he agreed to give Lisa N. Ristow, a striking blonde and former high-school cheerleader, a ride to a work-related brunch. She appeared at his doorstep in Houston, and his heart came screeching back to planet Earth.

title: Quietly, Retail Executives Move Into Top Paydays
description: THE richest paydays are supposed to be reserved for Wall Street titans, oil barons and banking moguls. So what is a handbag maker doing atop the list?

title: A Rough Ride Ends Where It Started
description: INVESTORS smooth and profitable stock market ride hit a nasty speed bump in February and finished the first quarter just about where it started.

title: Tana Ryan and Gregory Newton
description: Tana Rae Ryan, a daughter of Jamey Jo Greco of Southampton, N.Y., and Tony Keil Ryan of Highland Village, Tex., was married yesterday to Gregory Alan Newton, a son of Elaine Cantrell of Sierra Vista, Ariz., and George Newton, also of Sierra Vista. Pastor Jeff Love, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at Oro Valley United Church in Oro Valley, Ariz.

title: Ready for the Worst: Here Come the Bears
description: THE bears burst out of hibernation on Feb. 27, erasing the stock markets year-to-date gains and raising investors fears that the road ahead would be rough.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lets Go, Spring
description: Shop windows and even houses are showing signs of spring, a tradition that began with the great 19th-century department stores. Fading from the scene after World War II, the Eastertime urge to decorate has revived with the 21st century.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 7, 2007

title: Rapture
description: Janet is a young woman with a seizure disorder  which partly explains the title of Erica Wagners first novel. In the beginning, her seizures sound like anxiety attacks: A breath of cold metal, high in the back of her throat. The wrong end of a telescope. Was he watching her? She dug her nails into her wrist to hold herself in place, felt her chest rise and fall. She would not go over the edge of it. She would resist. But in fact her condition seems more dire, though never precisely diagnosed. A doctor in her childhood advised her: Dont tell anyone unless you have to. Janets seizure syndrome becomes one of this novels set of intricately guarded secrets  not because she tells no one but because the experience can in no way be shared.

title: Sociable Darwinism
description: Just as in the classic clashes of nature, where every mutational upgrade in a carnivores strength or cunning is soon countered by a speedier or more paranoid model of antelope, so the pitched struggle between evolutionary theory and its deniers has yielded a bristling diversity of ploys and counterploys. The heavyhanded biblical literalism of creationist science evolves into the feints and curlicues of intelligent design, and the casual dismissiveness with which scientists long regarded the anti-evolutionists gives way to a belated awareness that, gee, the public doesnt seem to realize how fatuous the other side is, and maybe its time to combat the creationist phylum head on. And so, over the last few years, scientists have unleashed a blitzkrieg of books in defense of Darwinism, summarizing the Everest of supportive evidence for evolutionary theory, filleting the arguments of the naysayers or reciting, yet again, the story of Charles Darwin, depressive naturalist extraordinaire, whose increasingly pervasive avuncular profile has lofted him to logo status on par with Einstein and the Nike swoosh.

title: Stocks Climb in a Short Trading Week
description: The stock market had a short but splendid week, with gains that brought the three major indexes close to the peaks they had reached before the sharp global sell-off that started on Feb. 27.

title: A War of Narratives
description: On the Dead Sea, Jordan

title: A Womans Work Earns Her Enemies
description: MEERWALA, Pakistan

title: Still Guilty After All These Years
description: Chicago

title: A Village Is Thinking Beyond Cabanas
description: ATLANTIC BEACH

title: Comings and Goings
description: For the 50th anniversary of the San Francisco International Film Festival (fest07.sffs.org), taking place from April 26 to May 10, the city itself will play a more prominent role than usual. In between screenings of bay area documentaries like Fog City Mavericks (2007), which explores the history of filmmaking in San Francisco, and Audience of One (2007), which follows a local Pentecostal minister as he directs a sci-fi biblical epic, participants can visit the shooting locations of classic San Francisco movies, like Fort Point. Located under the Golden Gate Bridge, the fort provided the jumping off point (literally) for Kim Novak in Alfred Hitchcocks 1958 thriller Vertigo, before Jimmy Stewart fished her out (below). For a list of San Francisco sites made famous by Vertigo, Dirty Harry, The Maltese Falcon and other classic movies, visit www.sffs.org/filmtours/selfguided.html. ... Nine Marriott resorts in the Caribbean and Mexico, including Grand Cayman Marriott Beach Resort and CasaMagna Marriott Cancun Resort, are offering the 1040 Family Travel package, which encourages parents to use their tax refunds for a sunny family vacation. The package, for which there is a five-night minimum, includes nightly rates starting at $154 (based on double occupancy, with children 12 and under staying for free), breakfast, an in-room family pizza party, and turndown service with milk and cookies. Reservations must be made prior to May 31 for travel between June 1 and Aug. 31/ (www.paradisebymarriott.com/taxrefund). ... Starting May 1, Air France will offer a new morning flight from New Yorks John F. Kennedy airport to the Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris. Flights leave at 7:50 a.m., arriving in Paris at 9 p.m. the same day, while the return flight leaves Paris at 8:45 p.m. and arrives at 11:00 p.m. (www.airfrance.com/us). ... Royal Caribbean International is starting a new wellness-oriented program this month on its newest ship, Liberty of the Seas. Fitness classes and spa treatments will focus on finding ones balance and will include Tai Chi, meditation, massage and acupuncture. The program also includes lectures on health issues, a virtual personal trainer kiosk that assists guests in creating fitness routines, healthy menu options and shore excursions that include biking, kayaking, snorkeling and zip-lining (www.royalcaribbean.com). ... The Association of Southeast Asian Nations has a new Web Site, www.cruiseasean.com, which introduces its ten members, including Cambodia and Thailand, to the cruise industry and to travelers new to the region. Port and tourism information for each member country is available.

title: Shilpa Patel and Christopher Larson
description: Shilpa Patel, the daughter of Dr. Shaila Patel and Dr. Sumant Patel of Houston, was married there yesterday to Christopher Lynn Larson, a son of Linda Larson and Robert Larson of Fort Collins, Colo. The Rev. Dr. Helen Appelberg, an Episcopal priest, officiated at a ceremony that incorporated Christian and Hindu traditions at the Hotel Derek.

title: Fattening Goodies in All Their Sugary Glory
description: Sugar Buzz is a high-calorie, free-wheeling, almost all-female group exhibition inviting us to savor the diversity of contemporary art made of sweets, or inspired by them. Though the 40 assembled works by almost 30 artists are not terribly complicated, or edifying, they are pretty enough to look at, even vaguely nourishing  the ultimate eye candy.

title: Bibliophiles Not Baby Sitters
description: Torrance, Calif.

title: Womans Body Found Under Bronx Bridge
description: The body of a woman was found yesterday inside a black bag underneath a bridge in the Bronx, not far from Van Cortlandt Park, the police said.

title: Amid Booming Enrollment, the Odd District Out
description: AT a time when enrollment is so far above capacity that some of the states public schools hold classes in closets, one six-town region in northwestern Connecticut has the opposite problem: Enrollment has declined so sharply that officials are considering combining grades, laying off teachers and canceling sports programs.

title: Barcelona: Hesperia Tower
description: THE BASICS

title: Jolly Good Show ... Or Was It?
description: COULD it be that the mere presence of an English accent is enough to bewitch American audiences into overrating performances by British actors? Thats the cheeky suggestion made recently by the British actor, novelist, critic and all-around cultural Renaissance guy Stephen Fry. I shouldnt be saying this  high treason really  but I sometimes wonder if Americans arent fooled by our accent into detecting a brilliance that may not really be there, he told the British magazine Radio Times. I mean, would they notice if Jeremy Irons or Judi Dench gave a bad performance? Not that those two paragons ever would, but its worth considering.

title: Hamas Seeks Prisoner Releases for Israeli Soldier
description: JERUSALEM, April 8  Hamas militants involved in seizing an Israeli soldier whom they have held captive for 10 months said over the weekend that they had sent Israeli officials, through Egyptian mediators, a list of Palestinian prisoners they would demand released in exchange for freeing him.

title: How the West Was Accumulated, Back East
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.

title: Its Time to Pack Up Those Beanie Babies
description: TWO of the dresser drawers in my 12-year-old daughters room were broken. It was not the drawers fault, nor Annies. It was time. The top of the waist-high dresser had served as a changing table for our four children, and our oldest is now a college freshman. If that baby boy lay on that dresser today, his size 12 feet would scrape the floor.

title: Stingiest Devil of Them All
description: From his spot at the bar, Dr. Coyle Connolly, a dermatologist and rabid Flyers fan, had an open look at Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur. It was late summer 1995 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Connollys heart was on the mend after Brodeur and the Devils broke it with their defeat of Philadelphia in that years Eastern Conference finals.

title: 2 Are Critically Injured in Hit and Runs
description: Two people were in critical condition last night following two hit and runs, one in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn, according to the police.

title: The Anarchist Casebook
description: Anyone who turns to genre fiction for escapist reading is well advised to stay clear of Ian Rankins hard-boiled procedurals featuring Inspector John Rebus of the Edinburgh police force. Like George Pelecanos, the American crime novelist he most resembles, Rankin is a flinty realist with little use for the romantic heroics that allow series detectives to operate above the fray of real life lived in real time. Events that shape the course of history in Scotland are just as likely to determine the plots of his novels. But while that factual fidelity lends authenticity to his books, it also accounts for their unwieldy structure and overburdened narratives.

title: About the Series
description: ABOUT THE SERIES They are the leading causes of illness and death in the United States today  heart disease, cancer, stroke, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes and Alzheimers disease, in that order. And they have a lot in common.

title: Restless Innovations From Alain Resnais
description: AT 84, with his silver helmet of hair, elegant bearing and crisply pressed blue blazer, Alain Resnais can look more like a retired yachtsman than one of Europes most senior and respected filmmakers. Yet, after 16 features and countless shorts, the director of Hiroshima Mon Amour and Night and Fog isnt ready to settle back on a leather banquette and sip Champagne from a flute. Mr. Resnais continues to work and work brilliantly, drawing on a reserve of youthful energy and imagination to produce a new film every two or three years, full of surprises.

title: Another Fine Mess, Born of Excess
description: HELLO, everybody, and welcome back to the humor column of the Mutual Funds Report, where we wrestle chuckles out of the world of investing and finance. This time, were taking on the impending financial apocalypse prompted by the collapsing subprime mortgage market.

title: A New Proposal to Rescue Yonkers Waterfront
description: YONKERS

title: First You Cry, of Course, but Illness Also Has an Upside
description: BETTY ROLLIN, a best-selling author and a former NBC News correspondent, woke up one morning and realized that she was happy. Not an unusual realization for a woman with a good marriage, a good job and good health.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: The Timess Picture of TV Viewing Is Fuzzier Than It Appears
description: THE opening paragraph of a Times front page story on March 1 asserted that ABCs World News had scored its second ratings victory in the last three weeks over NBCs evening newscast. Splashed across a graphic next to the article were average viewer totals for the two programs for each of the previous four weeks.

title: Trail of Tears
description: Throughout human history, seemingly simple turns of events have changed the fates of individuals and nations. In 1906, Thomas Watt Coslett invented a way to keep iron corset stays from rusting, and the bottom fell out of the whale-bone market. The whalers who remained on the eastern shore of Hudson Bay switched to trading for the creamy pelts of the Arctic fox, which local Inuit, on the Ungava Peninsula, began to trap in ever greater numbers. But when prices for skins fell in 1950, at a time when fox populations had also crashed, trappers  formerly subsistence hunters  moved to trading posts and begged rations from the Canadian police.

title: Little Changes, Big Results
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: New Tricks
description: Let me know when youre ready, Diane Mollaghan called out as I rummaged one recent winter afternoon through the costumes and props she had stored in the back room of a run-down house trailer on the grounds of the Town Lake Animal Center in Austin. Mollaghan, a 34-year-old animal-behavior researcher and graduate student in the University of Texass psychology department, was waiting in the trailers main room beside a tan-and-brown mutt that had recently been left in the shelters night drop-off box with no ID tags or background-information form. Estimated by the shelters staff members to be a Manchester terrier mix, it looked like a pointy-faced Chihuahua on stilts, a creature of indeterminate origin and yet-to-be-determined disposition. That, literally, was where I was to come in.

title: Mismanaged Care
description: The timing of this book is perfect. An epidemic of anxiety over the cost of health care has catapulted reform back onto the national agenda, and states from California to Massachusetts are now experimenting with universal coverage. It also promises to be a key issue in the 2008 election.

title: Fixing the School Aid Formula
description: The New York State Legislature passed a practically on-time budget last week with a lot in it to be happy about. That good news was obscured almost immediately by rounds of loudly self-serving analysis by lawmakers over the way the budget distributes education aid to the New York suburbs. Neither the complaining (in Westchester) nor the crowing (on Long Island) was entirely appropriate.

title: How to Find Profit Away From the Herd
description: MUTUAL funds are a destabilizing force in the stock market. Thats the finding of a recent study, which suggests that fund-induced volatility creates profit opportunities for investors who are willing to buy a stock after most funds have sold it, and to sell after most funds have bought.

title: The Week in Westchester
description: Arrests and Cars Seized in Prostitution Crackdown

title: Freed Britons May Sell Their Stories, Drawing Criticism
description: LONDON, April 8  Two days after they were paraded as heroes with a story to tell, some of the 15 British sailors and marines captured and released by Iran seemed today to have decided they have a story to sell.

title: $187 Million Public School, Under a Cloud in New Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 5  The new high school here will not be endowed with luxuries like a food court, a swimming pool or a greenhouse, even though at $187 million it is one of the most expensive to be built in the states history.

title: Sports Briefing
description: fantasy sports

title: Three Ross for Many a Meal
description: James Christopher Tracy, winemaker at Channing Daughters, on the South Fork of Long Island, was a chef. His three 2006 ross  a merlot, a cabernet franc and a cabernet sauvignon  complement many warm-weather dishes.

title: Shea Parking Will Be Scarce During Project
description: The Mets have tentative plans to place replica bases in the parking lot of their new ballpark, Citi Field, to commemorate the site of the infield at Shea Stadium. The more immediate concern to the teams fans may be finding a parking spot to watch Jos Reyes and his teammates run around the real bases this season.

title: Trenton Is Tense After 9 Killings in 3 Months
description: TRENTON, April 4  The homicide rate in this city is soaring, and the police know retaliation can only make things worse.

title: The Sales Pitch, Minus Salesmen
description: THE Internet makes it possible to do a lot of things at 3 oclock on a Sunday morning, including sauntering through an auto showroom  a virtual one, that is. But one thing has been missing: a sales pitch.

title: Late Scoring Spree Hands Spartans Championship
description: ST. LOUIS, April 7  Justin Abdelkaders dance after his game-deciding goal for Michigan State might have been niftier than the score itself. After burying a Tim Kennedy feed with 18.9 seconds to play, Abdelkader jumped, spun and skipped away in celebration while his teammates on the bench mobbed one another and Coach Rick Comley.

title: With Dual Triple-Doubles, Carter and Kidd Join Elite
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 7  With just over a minute and a half remaining in the Nets game Saturday night, point guard Jason Kidd missed a 3-pointer from the wing, caught his own rebound as it sailed over the baseline and threw the ball off the back of Wizards forward Jarvis Hayes to keep possession for the Nets.

title: Currys Unexpected Shot Gives Knicks Some Hope
description: MILWAUKEE, April 7  Eddy Curry was left alone Saturday night, his high-scoring teammates having all abandoned him for the training room. As the hour grew late, he was alone again, standing 23 feet from the basket with the game  and the Knicks season  on the line.

title: Correction: Oops, There Goes That Ferrari Enzo
description: A brief report in the Suits column on March 25, about the inaugural flight of the superjumbo A380 to Kennedy International Airport, misstated the planes maximum weight on takeoff. It is more than 1.2 million pounds, not 1.3 million tons.

title: The Road to Success Is Paved by Cheating
description: The gambler accused of playing three-card monte with the truth  find it if you can  played the odds on athlete integrity by luring players from the University of Toledo into a point-shaving scheme.

title: Unsettling History of That Joyous Hallelujah
description: IN New York and elsewhere a Messiah Sing-In  a performance of Handels oratorio Messiah with the audience joining in the choruses  is a musical highlight of the Christmas season. Christians, Jews and others come together to delight in one of the consummate masterpieces of Western music.

title: Israel Fires on Militants Planting Bomb, Killing One
description: JERUSALEM, April 7  Israeli Army helicopters fired at Palestinian militants in the northern Gaza Strip early Saturday, killing one, the military said. It was the third Israeli military strike in Gaza in 10 days, indicating a further erosion of the tenuous cease-fire that was declared in November.

title: Fume-Free (for Now) and Looking to the Future
description: TEN years ago, the idea of worrying about the future of the land around the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn would have seemed a little strange, especially in hot weather. An underground tunnel designed to circulate the canals water had been out of service for decades, and as a result, sewage from nearby houses and storm drains overflowed regularly into the canal, emitting a formidable stench.

title: No Wheels? No Problem
description: IN a city that drives everywhere, Los Feliz Village in Los Angeles stands out. Just east of Hollywood, below the sylvan hills where the Griffith Park Observatory recently reopened, the neighborhood is home to a growing cluster of shops and restaurants  all eminently walkable from each other.

title: Where Mozart Tops the Charts
description: AN oboist from the New York Philharmonic telephoned looking for some Astor Piazzolla tango etudes. Then an amateur cellist called to ask what was in stock by Scott Joplin.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: RADIANT DAYS. By Michael A. FitzGerald. (Shoemaker & Hoard, paper, $15.) Take a young man, successful but lacking in experience. Add a woman, opaque and mysterious, her past a dark negative the narrator holds up to the light, finding only his own reflection. Throw in a war, a disillusioned journalist as the antagonist whose world-weary asides counter the young mans tedious ignorance. Its an old story, made fresh by the first-time novelist Michael FitzGerald, who places his novel at the cusp of the Web boom and the end of the war in the Balkans, when Anthony Sinclair, a CNET producer disgusted by the soulless ease of his life, meets Gisela, a Hungarian bartender. He soon finds himself traveling from San Francisco to Budapest with her, supposedly to retrieve her son from an orphanage. There, they meet Marsh, a young British journalist covering the conflict, whose affection for Anthony takes the form of brutal proddings. (As they walk the streets of a trashed Serbian city in Croatia, Marsh tells Anthony to put his hands up and remain silent: Maybe just save your opinions for something you know about, like snowboarding, or whatever it is you did in college?) As Giselas story unravels, so does Anthony. But Radiant Days is more than a case study of Western apathy, circa 1995. With painful precision, FitzGerald shows us how little of Anthony  and the fractured countries he visits  there remains to redeem.

title: After 50 Years in Acting, Fully Relaxed in His Craft
description: Fairfield

title: The Web Gives Hotel Guests the Last Word
description: NEARLY every morning, over his second cup of coffee, Tom Brady, general manager at the Affinia Chicago, logs onto his computer and surfs over to TripAdvisor.com to see if there are any new postings about his hotel.

title: An F for W.
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was national security adviser to Jimmy Carter, has steadily warned that American arrogance might well lead to catastrophe abroad. And unlike his ingratiating Republican counterpart, Henry Kissinger, he was an early and vociferous opponent of the Iraq war.

title: Canned Heat
description: Nancy Silverton is rebelling a little later in life than most. At 52, the Los Angeles chef, who translated her training at Lentre into a widely respected career as a pastry chef, cook and business owner, has really gotten into prepared foods. Id forgotten how good V8 juice tastes! said Silverton, who spent a year combing the aisles of supermarkets and specialty stores in search of kitchen catalysts for her seventh cookbook, A Twist of the Wrist: Quick Flavorful Meals With Ingredients From Jars, Cans, Bags and Boxes (Knopf). Im waiting to get the phone call from Alice ... , she said of her mentor, the world-renowned food purist Alice Waters.

title: Guides to Negotiation (With the Boss or a Child)
description: WE spend a huge part of life in situations that require negotiation, whether with members of our family (Can we have a dog?), clients (We need to move up the delivery date), employees (Id like a raise) or our bosses (We need you to relocate).

title: The Vehicles Thieves Covet
description: TWO reports on auto theft offer different views on which models are most popular with car thieves.

title: White House Delivers a Spring Break Punch to Get Back in the Fight
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., April 7  On its face, President Bushs decision to use the Congressional recess to fill three administration posts with appointees Senate Democrats had vowed to block  including a man who helped finance attacks against John Kerrys war record in the 2004 presidential race  was a puzzler.

title: A West Side Story With a Promising Ending
description: TWO decades after deciding to resuscitate its economically troubled west side, Annapolis, Md., is now placing its hopes for a continued neighborhood revival on a new mixed-use development called Park Place.

title: Leni Riefenstahl
description: To the Editor:

title: What You Should Know
description: Dr. Elizabeth Nabel, a practicing cardiologist and researcher studying the genesis of plaque in coronary arteries, became director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute on Feb. 1, 2005. A firm believer in prevention, she exercises vigorously nearly every day and can recite her blood pressure, blood cholesterol and body mass index. She thinks everyone should know five things about heart disease:

title: Nuova Cucina Newcomer on Restaurant Row
description: DO you only review Italian restaurants? a reader once asked. Of course not. But sometimes it seems that the only restaurants to open with regularity are Italian.

title: Added Attraction: A Charming Bistro
description: BLUE SKY BISTRO does Malverne proud. In contrast to its neighbors in a tiny strip mall  a Chinese takeout and a nondescript pizza parlor  Blue Sky Bistro has a polished stone front and a brave little topiary tree in a pot by the door.

title: 36 Hours in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG's newest tourist attraction, a 25-minute cable-car ride over the rugged green hills of Lantau Island, says a lot about this former British colony. Ngong Ping 360 (www.np360.com.hk) demonstrates Hong Kong's fascination with travel and technology; the skyrail's hilltop terminus, an ersatz Chinese village, plays to local passions for eating, shopping and taking pictures. From there, it is a short walk to the Po Lin monastery's 112-foot-tall bronze statue of Buddha seated on a lotus throne, an expression of Hong Kong's fundamental Chineseness. This crazy mix of commerce and culture  plus sublime modern architecture, great food, nonstop nightlife and amazing views  makes Hong Kong, 10 years after its transition from British to Chinese rule, still one of the world's biggest tourist draws.

title: In the Grip of Octopus at a Greek Taverna
description: IF one dish can represent a restaurant, at Pithari Taverna it would be the octopus. It was one fat tentacle on a blue plate, in a clear pool of oil and vinegar specked with oregano. Fresh from the grill, it was fragrant, almost fork tender and luscious.

title: A Run-Up Reduces Bargains in Utilities
description: UTILITIES stocks have been on quite a run. For the fourth consecutive year, their share prices have been beating the Standard & Poors 500-stock index by a wide margin, after years of trailing the overall market.

title: A Long-Delayed Security Deposit
description: Q When my 24-unit building changed owners a number of years ago, the former landlord returned the security deposit on my rent-stabilized apartment. The new landlord made no request for a deposit until recently. On my last lease renewal I was asked to send in a partial deposit, and this year the landlord is demanding the remainder for the full deposit. Since I have lived here now for over a decade without a deposit, can the new landlord demand one now?

title: On Coogans Bluff, a Stairway to Trouble
description: The zigzagging concrete-and-steel stairway between Edgecombe Avenue and the Harlem River Drive has a name; the half-obliterated bronze letters on the landing read The John T. Brush Stairway.

title: For First Time Since 1993, Asbury Park Gets a Police Chief
description: Asbury Park

title: Yes, Its a 7-Year Streak, but No, Theyre Not Bragging
description: LANCE ARMSTRONGS winning streak  seven consecutive Tour de France victories from 1999 through 2005  helped to make him the pitchman for American Century Investments target-date retirement funds.

title: Not Necessarily Toast
description: Back to Basics Egg & Muffin Toaster

title: Preservationists Scramble to Buy Vital Link to Rowayton Nature Sanctuary
description: NORWALK

title: 2 Die and 3 Are Wounded in 3 Unrelated Bronx Shootings
description: Unrelated shootings early yesterday in the Bronx left two men dead and three people injured, the police said. No arrests had been made by late yesterday.

title: Gordon Ramsay Spreads His Culinary Tentacles
description: Gordon Ramsay, the celebrity chef known for such food programs as Hells Kitchen in the United States and The F-Word in Britain, has opened yet another eating establishment in a city already overpopulated with dining rooms bearing his brand. Adding to his roster of nine other London restaurants  including one at Claridges and another in the Savoy  not to mention his outposts in New York, Dubai and Tokyo, Mr. Ramsay last month opened an upscale pub on the banks of the Thames in the East End.

title: Tolstoy Was Right: Flop Musicals Are All Unique
description: LIKE most hard-core theater aficionados, Ethan Mordden has deeply held and often blistering opinions. Unlike most, he has earned a place for those opinions in works of widely praised scholarship, including a seven-book history of the Broadway musical from 1920 to 2005. Though he would like to add one more book to that series, covering the period from 1900 to 1920, he says no one would read it. Instead his latest book, All That Glittered, just published by St. Martins Press, is a chronicle of the golden age of drama on Broadway: 1919 to 1959 by his reckoning.

title: Disruption on ESPN.com
description: A system error in ESPN.coms Fantasy Baseball League has disrupted live scoring and roster moves since Tuesday. Were fantasy players ourselves, and we recognize that it is not acceptable for our players to have anything short of a great experience, an ESPN.com spokesman, Paul Melvin, said in a written statement. We also recognize that getting every problem resolved is what will ultimately satisfy our players. In 2005, ESPN.com was forced to apologize to fans for traffic problems with its Fantasy Football League. ESPN.com would not disclose how many users play fantasy games through its Web site, and would not say how many users have been affected by the most recent problem.

title: Walk, Dont Run, Is Rule for Two Champion Racers
description: Hauppauge

title: Wandering in Weimar Purgatory
description: THE first episode of Berlin Alexanderplatz, Rainer Werner Fassbinders 13-part (plus epilogue), 15 1/2-hour adaptation of Alfred Dblins 1929 novel, is called The Punishment Begins. There is a heavy, obvious irony, since the hero of this modern urban anti-epic, a former pimp named Franz Biberkopf, has just been released from Tegel Prison, where he has served a four-year sentence for beating his girlfriend to death.

title: Sleepless in Cairo
description: During the last few years, my neighborhood in Cairo has experienced such an influx of refugees from the Iraq war that longtime residents have begun, with a mixture of affection and unease, to call it New Baghdad. Two dialects of Arabic are spoken in the streets, and there is Iraqi flatbread for sale in the local market. The family living in the apartment upstairs came to Egypt from Iraq nine months ago. Their history was revealed to me by degrees: I exchange greetings with Hassan  an artist with a salt-and-pepper mustache, and the head of the household  whenever I pass him in the stairwell, but because we are a man and a woman and unrelated, local standards of propriety make further conversation difficult. The story of their flight from Iraq came through the neighborhood gossip that passes from the men to the women to me, the buildings sole but affectionately treated Westerner.

title: A (Relatively) Good Quarter for Foreign Stocks
description: OWNERS of American blue chips found the first quarter eventful if unprofitable. Investors in overseas stock markets had more to show for their wandering spirit as those markets continued a long run of outperformance.

title: Picassent, Spain: LAlter
description: Valencia, of course, is the home of paella (and, this year, of the America's Cup), but the best paella I could find in the area was outside the city, in a town called Picassent. To get there, I drove though the Albufera, the rice-growing region around a vast lake where  arguably, at least  Europe's best and first rice is grown.

title: Mother Faces Murder Charge After Newborn Is Found Dead
description: A 25-year-old woman who went to a Brooklyn hospital on Friday night suffering from abdominal pain and excessive bleeding was arrested yesterday in the death of her newborn daughter, who was later found in a garbage bag on the back porch of the womans family home, the police said.

title: Blast Kills 6 NATO Soldiers in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 8  Six NATO soldiers were killed in a roadside blast in southern Afghanistan today, NATO said in a statement issued from Kandahar airbase. One other NATO soldier was wounded.

title: Transparency, Lost in the Fog
description: POP quiz: What highly paid chief executive thought nothing of plunking down a thousand bucks for an ivory back scratcher?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Treating Teammates Differently

title: Instant Messages
description: Among the best-kept secrets of American visual culture are those plastic-lettered, brightly illuminated religious message boards that beseech all to Repent Now, Be Saved or Make Us Instruments of Your Peace and Love. Though in plain sight, they are virtually invisible, and like those ubiquitous convenience store displays announcing gas or egg prices, the average religious signboard offers the essentials  usually times and dates for worship or a spiritual bromide. But in CHURCH SIGNS ACROSS AMERICA (Overlook, $19.95), the photographers Steve Paulson and Pam Paulson have found and documented the uncommon poetry and sly wit used to rouse the flock, and the book is curiously inspirational.

title: Correction: Gone Is the Swaggering Prince of Prosecution
description: An article last Sunday comparing the independence of todays United States attorneys with that of past federal prosecutors misstated the middle initial of a law professor at the New York University School of Law who commented on the danger of mixing politics and enforcement. He is Stephen M. Gillers, not Stephen J.

title: Correction: The Review of The First Man-Made Man
description: A review on March 18 about The First Man-Made Man: The Story of Two Sex Changes, One Love Affair, and a Twentieth-Century Medical Revolution, by Pagan Kennedy, refers incorrectly to Michael Dillon, the main subject of the book, who was born a woman. Dillons sex change is considered the first of the modern era because of its surgical sophistication and its early use of testosterone, starting in 1938. But he was not the first person on record to undergo surgery to change his gender. (Records of surgery to alter sexual characteristics go back to ancient times.)

title: Just Ask
description: New Yorkers consider themselves among the savviest and nerviest consumers in the world. But when it comes to buying real estate, what they forget to ask is startling.

title: Morristowns Incendiary Mayor
description: The one thing you can say for certain about the controversy over day laborers is that it incites people to the boiling point. That is certainly true in Morristown, where the mayor, instead of trying to calm tempers, seems to be doing everything he can to turn up the heat.

title: The Undeparted
description: On the surface, recent votes in Congress appear to signal a new Democratic determination to withdraw from Iraq. But the reality is otherwise. It is not only that the resolutions were drafted and adopted with the certain knowledge that they would be vetoed. More important, even if a future Democratic president did try to implement the new plans, the results would likely end up looking oddly similar to the Bush administrations current strategy. In politics as in war, things are seldom what they seem.

title: Clearing Air in Spring Training Puts A-Rod in a Good Place
description: Alex Rodriguez said he figured the ninth inning would come down to his at-bat yesterday because, with the Yankees, almost everything seems to revolve around him. Rodriguez cannot avoid being a story, even when he is not a story and even when he is desperately trying to avoid being a story.

title: Sunday in the Market With McCain
description: JOHN McCAINS April Fools Day stroll through Baghdads Shorja market last weekend was instantly acclaimed as a classic political pratfall. Protected by more than a hundred American soldiers, three Black Hawk helicopters, two Apache gunships and a bulletproof vest, the senator extolled the progress and good news in Iraq. Befitting this loopy brand of comedy  reminiscent of Wedding Crashers, in which Mr. McCain gamely made a cameo appearance  the star had a crackerjack cast of supporting buffoons: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who told reporters I bought five rugs for five bucks!, and Representative Mike Pence of Indiana, who likened the scene to a normal outdoor market in Indiana in the summertime.

title: Latte Laborers Take on a Latte-Liberal Business

The labor board charged that Starbucks, the ubiquitous coffee chain, committed 30 violations of law in the process of trying to ward off union activity at four Manhattan outlets.

title: Dried Cherries May Help Travelers Fight Jet Lag
description: Instead of pretzels, long-haul flight attendants might want to consider handing out bags of dried cherries to passengers. According to Dr. Russel Reiter, a nutrition researcher and one of the worlds authorities on melatonin, cherries might help fight jet lag. Tart cherries contain melatonin, which is then absorbed into the blood stream influencing your biological clock, he said.

title: Fancy Meeting You Here
description: A short while ago, a ripping yarn called Grim Legion: Edgar Allan Poe at West Point came across my desk. Published by Bewildering Press, a relatively new firm that specializes in speculative writing, Grim Legion recounts the rousing adventures of the future author of The Fall of the House of Usher shortly before he was expelled from the United States Military Academy in 1831. A bit of a screw-up, though not yet the morbid, self-destructive alcoholic he would later become, Poe has stumbled upon a monstrous plot by a shadowy organization called the Helvetian Society whose ultimate objective is nothing short of ... well ... monstrous.

title: Hot and Cold
description: Last week began with a Supreme Court decision declaring that the federal government had the authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions and all but ordering the Bush administration to do so. It ended with a report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change  the worlds authoritative voice on global warming  warning that failure to contain these emissions will have disastrous environmental effects, especially in poorer countries, which are least able to defend themselves and their people against the consequences of climate change.

title: Magic Words
description: Back in 1990, Newt Gingrich sent his Republican colleagues a list of words to use to describe their Democratic opponents: sick, pathetic, bizarre, traitors and corrupt were some of the choicest. Getting the party on message helped the Republicans win in 1994, but Gingrichs memo was a disaster for our political culture: it enshrined as demonstrated truth the idea that winning elections in America is all a game of spin and wordplay  a game Republicans happened to be better at than Democrats. Weirdly, even after last Novembers Democratic rout, were still living in Newts world. Those Republican magic words  that blind voters, according to the blogger Jeffrey Feldman, are still the big threat to Democrats electoral success  and, to help the left, he offers a rhetoric handbook, Framing the Debate, based on the Democratic strategist George Lakoffs ideas about politics and language. In it he parses the language of great speeches to give progressives some words of their own  keywords and metaphors, as he describes them  that will help create persuasive frames for their policies, like us against them or happiness is achievement.

title: Paperback Row
description: BROOKLAND, by Emily Barton. (Picador, $15.) Set in late-18th-century Brooklyn, Bartons second novel is a beautiful tale of women, gin-making and bridge-building. As a small child, Bartons heroine, Prudence Winship, looks across the East River from the village of Brooklyn (or Brook land) at Manhattan. Years later Prudence and her sisters  high-spirited Temperance and silent, eerie Pearl  operate a gin distillery inherited from their father and dream of building a single-span bridge to connect Brooklyn with Manhattan (well before the actual Brooklyn Bridge was completed in 1883). Our reviewer, Christopher Corbett, called Brookland a story not just of risk, daring and ambition but of the courage to fail  and the courage to live on after failing.

title: Stiffed

Thats what a number of newspapers and blogs saw in photos of the 15 released British seamen in their grimly fitting, Tehran-issued suits. Essentially, people connected the ugliness of the three-button suits to an ugly purpose: humiliating the British government. A serviceman without uniform or insignia is powerless. And the suits are the opposite of the smartly tapering Savile Row kind, perhaps a statement in itself. Inevitably, some people just saw the horrible sartorial gaffs; one reader of the Guardian, in London, pointed out that men should never button their jackets over a vest and never, ever button the top button of the jacket.

title: Parties Matter
description: The political polling season is already upon us (a bit prematurely, but everything is ahead of itself these days), and polls taken in the past couple of weeks reveal a pattern that commentators are busy explaining. When the question asked is, which party do you trust to do a better job with the economy, the war, global warming, the environment, education, the deficit, immigration, reputation abroad, the administration of justice, the rebuilding of New Orleans?, the Democratic party wins  and in some categories by impressive margins. The same polls show that 60 to 70 percent of the American people believe that the country is heading in the wrong direction, and there is no doubt that President Bushs rating numbers are also headed in the wrong direction. Why then do Hillary Clinton, John Edwards and Barack Obama consistently lose to Rudy Giuliani and John McCain in head-to-head matchups? (The three Democrats do outpoll Mitt Romney, but who wouldnt?)The answer usually given is that its early. Two years out voters are reacting to personalities, or rather, to their perception of personalities. When things get more serious, and the candidates are put under the lens of relentless scrutiny and have to answer hard questions about hard issues, the ratings, we are told, will turn less on personality and more on policy, and the numbers will change.
