title: A Down-to-Earth Chef Who Wanders the Globe
description: The problem with cooking shows is that you have to watch people cook. Theres slicing. Theres sauting. Theres the occasional Busby Berkeley-style overhead shot of stock evaporating in a $350 pot. Sometimes a host says Bam! or drops a roast or peeks out from inside an oven. Thats when things perk up.

title: A Plastic Wrapper Today Could Be Fuel Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, April 8  Scientists worldwide are struggling to make motor fuel from waste, but Richard Gross has taken an unusual approach: making a fuel-latent plastic, designed for conversion. It can be used like ordinary plastic, for packaging or other purposes, but when it is waste, can easily be turned into a substitute diesel fuel.

title: Woman Led Police to Dead Infant Her Sister Is Accused of Killing
description: When police officers searching for a newborn baby arrived early Saturday at the home of a Brooklyn woman who was thought to be the mother, one of her sisters told them, What youre looking for is in the back.

title: Accounts
description: Accounts

title: A Madison Avenue Deal Maker Continues His Spending Spree
description: Miles S. Nadal, the Monty Hall of Madison Avenue, is at it again, doing what he loves to do best: making deals. But when is enough enough?

title: Tribune Under Zell: New Boss, Old Feud
description: When Sam Zell agreed to take over the Tribune Company, he also took on a longstanding feud between the companys Chicago headquarters and its biggest holding, The Los Angeles Times.

title: Johnson Goes From Chicken Wings to Masters Champion
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8  Before Zach Johnson became a Masters champion, he was a golfer chasing titles sponsored by Hooters.

title: In Success of Smart Growth, New Jersey Town Feels Strain
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J.  The neighborhoods here seem plucked from an urban planners catalog: trimmed lawns, picket fences and freshly minted homes. Shopping is an easy stroll away on the wide sidewalks. A greenbelt wraps the town like a bow.

title: Another Layer of Scandal
description: As Congress investigates the politicization of the United States attorney offices by the Bush administration, it should review the extraordinary events the other day in a federal courtroom in Wisconsin. The case involved Georgia Thompson, a state employee sent to prison on the flimsiest of corruption charges just as her boss, a Democrat, was fighting off a Republican challenger. It just might shed some light on a question that lurks behind the firing of eight top federal prosecutors: what did the surviving attorneys do to escape the axe?

title: This Time Around, Clutch Shot Eludes a Proven Winner
description: Augusta, Ga.

title: Bedard Gives Orioles an Outing Yanks Could Use
description: Orioles starter Erik Bedard made it all look so easy. He retired 20 of the last 22 batters he faced yesterday, baffling the Yankees with a diet of breaking balls and fastballs.

title: Looking to Monkeys to Explain How Top Dogs and Underdogs Act
description: David Zellniks new play Serendib, at the Ensemble Studio Theater, is a celebration of the beta male: the soulful sort, human or primate, who triumphs even as he lacks Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopfs DNA. How typically do beta males succeed in the laboratory of real life? Do alphas always overcome them? Are betas happier, less addled? And about those alphas: Are they genetically predisposed to their alpha-ness, or are environment and circumstance responsible for their aggressive, victory-or-nothing dispositions?

title: To Close Gaps, Schools Focus on Black Boys
description: OSSINING, N.Y.  In an effort to ensure racial diversity, the school system here in northern Westchester County is set up in an unusual way, its six school buildings divided not by neighborhood but by grade level. So all of the second and third graders in the Ossining Union Free School District attend the Brookside School.

title: Blast Kills 6 NATO Soldiers in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 8  Six NATO soldiers were killed in a roadside blast in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, NATO said in a statement issued from Kandahar airbase. One other NATO soldier was wounded.

title: Todays News, Tomorrows History
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: After Four Games, Matsui Finds Himself on the D.L.
description: It took a broken wrist to sideline Hideki Matsui last season and end his streak of 1,768 consecutive games played, which spanned two continents and 13 years. This season it took only four games, a cold day and a ground ball to put him on the disabled list.

title: Ranchers and Army Are at Odds in Old West
description: DENVER, April 6  Mack Louden worries that his 30,000-acre ranch sits in the cross hairs of the Armys plans to expand its Pion Canyon Maneuver Site at Fort Carson, and he, along with other Colorado ranchers, are increasingly upset about the idea.

title: Sex and Politics,  la Caesar and Cleopatra
description: The Metropolitan Opera has a big impediment to producing Handel operas: its enormous auditorium. Both Rodelinda, which the Met first mounted in 2004 starring Rene Fleming, and Giulio Cesare, which opened on Friday in a revival of a staging by John Copley introduced in 1988, were originally presented by Handel in the Kings Theater in London, which seated just 850. In principle the Mets 3,700-seat house is way too big for early-18th-century opera. Some of the most ravishing moments in Giulio Cesare are pensively lyrical arias accompanied by only a small complement of continuo instruments.

title: Belgians Hail the Middle Ages (Well, Not the Plague Part)
description: AARSCHOT, Belgium  During the week, Ivonne Janssens, 57, is a hospital cleaner. But come the weekend, she climbs the narrow steps of a three-story medieval tower and turns into a 14th-century duchess with a faux-emerald necklace, a linen headdress, a leather satchel full of fake gold coins and a retinue of mercenaries to fend off invading French knights.

title: New CDs
description: BRIGHT EYES Cassadaga (Saddle Creek)

title: Maestro of Los Angeles Philharmonic to Pass the Baton to a Wunderkind
description: Esa-Pekka Salonen, the onetime wunderkind from Finland who has led the Los Angeles Philharmonic as music director for 15 seasons, has decided to leave the orchestra when his term ends in 2009. His successor? A wunderkind from Venezuela named Gustavo Dudamel, one of the hottest  and youngest  conducting properties around.

title: Locking Up the Crucial Evidence and Crippling the Defense
description: David L. Knellinger will go to trial this month in Virginia because the government says his computers hard drive contains pornographic pictures of children. There are two basic defenses to that incendiary charge. One is to raise questions about how the pictures got there. The other is to argue that what appear to be real children are actually just images generated by computers.

title: Gingrich Faults Gonzales for Attorneys Mess
description: WASHINGTON, April 8  Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich on Sunday became the latest Republican to criticize Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales for the dismissals of eight United States attorneys, and he said Mr. Gonzales should consider stepping down.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the drought in the West referred incorrectly to the level of Lake Powell on the Utah-Arizona border. While the lake is at the same level it was in 1973, it is not the lowest it has been since then. It was briefly lower in early 2005. (Go to Article)

title: McDonalds to Allow More Unions in Chinese Stores
description: SHANGHAI, April 9  A year after Wal-Mart unionized all its stores in China under pressure from the government, McDonalds is cooperating with Chinas large state-controlled union to allow more unions in its 670 outlets here.

title: In a Television Carnival, Buy, Sell or Cringe
description: The cult status of James J. Cramer, the host of the CNBC television show Mad Money, may derive more from the manic atmosphere he creates on the show than the sagacity of his stock tips.

title: A Custom Ride, Legal for the Street or the 18th Tee
description: Jim McIntyre drives to the grocery store in a golf cart resembling a 1957 Chevy Bel Air.

title: Costly Contraceptives
description: For almost 20 years, college health centers have been able to purchase contraceptives at nominal prices. This was not a tax-funded subsidy. It was a financial incentive that gave drug manufacturers an exemption from Medicaid pricing rules so they could sell contraceptives and other products to certain charitable groups, like the college clinics, at an extreme discount. In response to concerns that drug companies were abusing this privilege, language was sewn into legislation in 2005 to close a loophole. It also inadvertently slashed this important benefit for clinics and their patients.

title: The Unpleasant Reality for Women in Sports
description: I stood in front of the associate professor Barbara Osbornes Sports Law class at the University of North Carolina last Wednesday. The subject was the seldom talked-about disparity of power and privilege between black and white women in the sports industry.

title: Looking Ahead
description: QUARTERLY REPORTS Earnings season gets under way with the first Dow component, Alcoa, reporting first-quarter results (Tuesday), followed by the BlackBerry maker Research in Motion (Wednesday), Rite Aid (Thursday) and another Dow component, General Electric (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow because of the seventh and eighth days of Passover. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Guantnamo Detainees Stage Hunger Strike
description: A long-term hunger strike has broken out at the American detention center at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, with more than a dozen prisoners subjecting themselves to daily force-feeding to protest their treatment, military officials and lawyers for the detainees say.

title: Radical Shiite Cleric Calls on Iraqi Forces to Unite Against the U.S. Military
description: BAGHDAD, April 8  Moktada al-Sadr, the rebellious Shiite cleric and power broker, exhorted Iraqi security forces on Sunday to unite with his militiamen against the American military in Diwaniya, an embattled southern city in Iraq where fighting has raged for three days.

title: Restoration on the Half Shell
description: Calais, Vt.

title: Microsoft Brings Instant Chat to TV Screen, Through Games
description: Microsoft planned to announce today that it will make its Windows Live Messenger service available on its Xbox 360 game consoles, bringing instant messaging from the computer to the television.

title: More Nuggets on Pay From Proxy Filings
description: Many of the most interesting nuggets on executive pay are buried so deep in the new corporate filings that it helps to bring along a calculator and a shovel.

title: Iran Looks for Missing Ex-F.B.I. Agent
description: TEHRAN, April 8  Iran said Sunday that it was searching for a former F.B.I. agent who has been missing in Iran for almost a month.

title: Soldiers Captors Say They Gave List of Demands to Israel
description: JERUSALEM, April 8  Hamas militants involved in seizing an Israeli soldier whom they have held captive for 10 months said over the weekend that they had sent Israeli officials, through Egyptian mediators, a list of Palestinian prisoners they would demand released in exchange for freeing him.

title: Sweet Little Lies
description: Four years into a war fought to eliminate a nonexistent threat, we all have renewed appreciation for the power of the Big Lie: people tend to believe false official claims about big issues, because they cant picture their leaders being dishonest about such things.

title: Is That Finally the Sound of a 2nd Ave. Subway?
description: The neckties are wide and the sideburns long, the pickaxes gleam in the sunlight. The governor thanks the president for providing money. The mayor jokes that whatever is said about this project in the years to come, certainly no one can say that the city acted rashly or without due deliberation.

title: Iraqi Cleric Challenges U.S. With Big Rally
description: BAGHDAD, April 9  Tens of thousands of protesters loyal to the militant Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr took to the streets of the holy city of Najaf on Monday in an extraordinarily disciplined rally to demand an end to the American military presence in Iraq, burning American flags and chanting Death to America.

title: One Killed in Shooting in Michigan Office
description: One person was killed and two were wounded today by a former employee of an accounting firm in Troy, Mich., a suburb of Detroit. Police reported that they had stopped a suspect by mid-afternoon in Genesee County, about 45 miles north of Troy.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 8, 2007

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,258 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the weekend:

title: 6-Year-Olds Under Arrest
description: Avon Park, Fla.

title: Colder Than Christmas, but Still Easter Delights
description: The sun was missing. Wintry winds scythed over the city and snow flurries hovered in the air. But on the coldest Easter since 1940  colder even than last Christmas  bells pealed, hymns resounded in the churches and a subtle spring beauty cut the gloom on Fifth Avenue and in quiet corners of New York.

title: Same Fistful of Diamonds, Two Very Different Openings
description: The White House Teams took place in Amsterdam last February. The 16 invited teams were divided into two groups of 8, with the top two in each section moving into the semifinals. Last month this column featured deals from one semifinal and the final. But the latest edition of the International Bridge Press Associations bulletin contains several other excellent deals from this event.

title: Imus Suspended for 2 Weeks Over Racial Remark
description: NBC News suspended the radio host Don Imus tonight for two weeks after the outcry over his racially disparaging remarks about the Rutgers University womens basketball team, calling his comments racist and abhorrent.

title: An Odd One Cometh (Can You Say Drama?)
description: Patrick Wolf is only 23, but already he is one of Britains most appealing young singer-songwriters. Hes a disco-obsessed virtuoso who can (it appears) play just about every instrument in the orchestra; a canny and uncanny performer who has long seemed destined for pop stardom or some weird variant of it.

title: Circuit Breaker
description: The announcement that Circuit City was laying off some 3,400 of its better-paid workers to fill the same positions with cheaper labor has become the latest chapter in the new rulebook for corporate America. There are significant social questions for policy makers in these new norms, but businesses need to consider whether this is really the answer.

title: Dear Diary
description: Correction Appended

title: Online Booksellers Face Higher Costs for Shipping Abroad
description: THE Postal Service is taking the ship out of shipping, and thousands of small online booksellers are bracing for trouble.

title: In a Flash, Curry Proves He Can Lead the Knicks
description: Until Saturday night, the idea of asking Eddy Curry to hit a buzzer-beating, game-saving 3-pointer was ludicrous, if not outright nutty. It may still be considered so, even after Curry made a 3-pointer to force overtime and help the Knicks defeat Milwaukee.

title: The Presidencys Mormon Moment
description: IN May, Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor and 2008 Republican presidential hopeful, will give the commencement address at Pat Robertsons Regent University. What better opportunity for Mr. Romney to discuss the issue of his Mormon faith before an audience of evangelicals?

title: The Latest Real Estate Drama in the Hamptons Is About Newspaper Turf
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  On a recent Saturday morning in the offices of The East Hampton Star, the low moan of a fire siren came through an open window and David E. Rattray, the newspapers editor, sprang into action. Swiveling in his chair to his police scanner, he learned about a fire at a local retirement community and quickly called a photographer.

title: Roddick Is Putting It All on Line for the Davis Cup
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., April 8  After Andy Roddick strained a hamstring in Miami in late March, the safe move might have been to lay low for a few weeks, rest his leg for the coming clay-court season and skip the Davis Cup match between the United States and Spain this past weekend.

title: Iran Claims Progress in Enriching Uranium
description: NATANZ, Iran, April 9  Iran claimed Monday that it is now capable of industrial-scale uranium enrichment, a development that would defy two United Nations resolutions passed to press the country to suspend its enrichment program.

title: In Familiar Music, a Pianist Shows What He Can Do
description: If you dont know me by now, runs the opening line of a famous song by Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes, you will never, never, never know me. This could be about the core classical-music repertory, certainly from the point of view of anyone who has gone through a competition, in which pieces are reduced to one-word tags (as in the judges would like to hear the Beethoven).

title: Moon over Miami
description: Mondrian

title: Polling Early and Often
description: Mitt Romneys campaign fired off an announcement last week, trumpeting a new poll that found Mr. Romney had taken the lead among Republican presidential candidates in New Hampshire. Zogby: Romney Rockets! it said.

title: Photographs
description: Images of Petr Ginz's family and of his diary.

title: Don Imus on Al Sharptons Radio Show
description: The following is text of a discussion between the Reverend Al Sharpton and Don Imus on Reverend Sharpton's radio show regarding racial comments made on the Don Imus radio show, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the drought in the West referred incorrectly to the level of Lake Powell on the Utah-Arizona border. While the lake is at the same level it was in 1973, it is not the lowest it has been since then. It was briefly lower in early 2005.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Monday about the reopening of the Ferry Building on Ellis Island incorrectly described some of the exterior restoration and architectural features. Don Fiorino, the project manager for the National Park Service, said workers peeled lead-coated copper (not lead) off the building's cupola (not off the eagles perched atop it). The copper was replaced with zinc-coated copper, not zinc. And the eagles are stamped, not carved.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on March 27 about graduate students who have killed their professors referred incorrectly to the case of Theodore Streleski, a Stanford University student who bludgeoned Karel deLeeuw, a Stanford math professor, to death. At the time of the killing, Mr. Streleski's academic adviser was Halsey Royden, not Dr. deLeeuw. Mr. Streleski was told by Dr. Royden that his research was sufficient to earn him a doctorate if he wrote a dissertation; Mr. Streleski was not told that after 19 years of graduate school he was not going to get a doctorate.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the free-trade agreement between South Korea and the United States misstated a middle initial for the director of the Global Business Center at the University of New Haven, who discussed the benefits of the deal to the American economy. She is Usha C. V. Haley, not Usha C. H.

title: Kurt Vonnegut
Correction: For the Record
description: A headline in Business Day last Monday with an article about the translation of course materials at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology into Chinese misstated the location of the project. It is based in Taiwan, not mainland China.

title: Shoring Up an Archive
description: Corbis is responding to the rise of low-cost online rivals that threaten to undermine its photo sales.

title: Under Fire in Afghanistan
description: A battle with the Taliban underscored the difficulties of the war in a region where the insurgents enjoy tribal support.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The headline on the Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday, about the effect of the Internet on intellectual property law, misidentified one of the areas facing the most significant challenges. It was copyrights, not trademarks.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Takes Stake in Railroad Company
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, says it has acquired a 10.9 percent stake in Burlington Northern Santa Fe, becoming the railroad companys largest shareholder. Berkshire owned 39,027,430 shares of Burlington Northern with a market value of $3.23 billion as of April 5, according to a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Before Friday, Berkshire had not disclosed a stake in the railroad, Americas second-largest behind Union Pacific.

title: Outrage! A Nations Phones May End in Foreign Hands
description: It has all the makings of a standard Italian financial melodrama, with the usual cast of characters. There is a struggling company that is a takeover target, and the controlling shareholder trying to squeeze what he can from a bad investment. Add to that a just-resigned chairman, a group of minority shareholders excluded from the deal, and foreign buyers facing a reluctant government and skeptical financial establishment.

title: More Nuggets on Pay From Proxy Filings
description: Many of the most interesting nuggets on executive pay are buried so deep in the new corporate filings that it helps to bring along a calculator and a shovel. The Securities and Exchange Commissions new disclosure rules were supposed to make it easier for investors to understand how top managers were being paid. But piles of new data and proxy statements that are about as easy to parse as the federal tax code have even experts scratching their heads.

title: Harrahs Shareholders Approve $17 Billion Buyout
description: Harrahs Entertainment shareholders approved a $17.1 billion buyout by two private equity groups Thursday in the largest deal ever to take a publicly held casino company private, officials said. Shareholders controlling 66 percent of outstanding stock approved selling Harrahs, the worlds largest casino company, to the Apollo Management Group and the Texas Pacific Group, Harrahs officials announced. Harrahs board had unanimously recommended approval.

title: Citigroup Snaps Up Taiwan Bank
description: Citigroup has agreed to buy Taiwans Bank of Overseas Chinese for 14.1 billion Taiwan dollars ($426 million) amid growing foreign interest in Taiwans undervalued banking sector. Citigroup will acquire 100 percent of the company in the all-cash deal, a board member, Weng Chien, told Reuters. Under terms of the deal, Citigroup will pay 11.80 Taiwan dollars per share, the companies said in a statement. The acquisition will increase Citigroups Taiwan-based assets to $22.8 billion.

title: Tyco Unit Signs Red Sox Deal Ahead of Spin-Off
description: The $10 billion medical devices giant about to be spun off from Tyco International plans to introduce itself to the world next week in Fenway Park. The company, Covidien, has signed a multiyear deal estimated to be worth seven figures to become a sponsor of the Boston Red Sox, a pact that will give Covidiens new logo prime real estate in the middle of the left-field wall at the ballpark.

title: In Tribune Deal, Possible Conflicts Ran Deep
description: In many multibillion-dollar deals, conflicts of interest are an unavoidable way of life. The multiple roles that Merrill Lynch and Citigroup played in the $8.2 billion sale of Tribune  advising the company in the sale process as well as providing financing to the winning bidder, Samuel Zell  show these conflicts on a grand scale, DealBook wrote in a column in Sundays New York Times. Tribune, a publishing and broadcasting giant, did take steps to preserve objectivity, forming a special committee and hiring an outside adviser. But the situation still raises questions about whether Mr. Zell was given a privileged seat at the negotiating table.

title: Cisco May Be Stalking Big Game
description: Cisco Systems may be gearing up for some big plays, according to BusinessWeek. In an effort to increase growth at the networking company, Ned Hooper, who heads up business development, which includes mergers and acquisitions as well as venture capital investments, is looking to make bigger-and potentially riskier-acquisitions than the company has ever done before, according to the magazine.

title: Is Kraft Sweet on Cadbury?
description: Kraft Foods, which exited the candy business two years ago, may be looking to get back into it in a big way. The Chicago Tribune reports that Kraft may have its eye on London-based Cadbury Schweppes, which under pressure from investor Nelson Peltz announced plans to sell its soft drinks business, which includes Dr. Pepper, Snapple and 7 Up.

title: A Few More Suitors for Tribunes Cubs Emerge
description: A few more names have been added to the line-up of potential bidders for the Chicago Cubs. A wealthy Chicago businessman, Don Levin, who has turned the citys minor-league Wolves into a winner in hockey, has been contacted by the baseball teams owner, Tribune, and is putting together a bid, he told The Chicago Tribune.

title: To Win Key Player, Citigroup May Buy His Hedge Fund
description: In an effort to bring Wall Street veteran Vikram Pandit into the fold, Citigroup is considering shelling out as much as $600 million for the former Morgan Stanley bankers hedge fund, Old Lane.

title: Primedias $1 Billion Price Tag Deters Bidders, Report Says
description: The Primedia Enthusiast group still has the attention of several potential bidders, but the $1 billion price tag for the media group has given some pause, according to The New York Post. Those still eyeing the group, whose titles include Motor Trend, Powder, Surfing and the Practical Horseman, are Veronis Suhler Stevenson, with backing from Leonard Green Partners; Curtco Media, in conjunction with the Blackstone Group; Elevation Partners; and Quadrangle Group, the report said.

title: MetroPCS Gears Up for $1 Billion I.P.O.
description: In what could be the years largest initial public offering to date, MetroPCS Communications is looking to raise as much as $1 billion when it goes public April 18. The wireless phone service provider last week filed to price 50 million shares for its upcoming I.P.O. at between $19 an $21 each.

title: The Week Ahead: the Senate Returns
description: Half of Congress makes its way back to Washington this week as the Senate returns to challenge the Bush administration on stem cell research in addition to the war in Iraq and the firing of eight federal prosecutors.

title: Dow Chemical: The First $50 Billion L.B.O.?
description: A consortium of Middle Eastern investors and American buyout firms is reportedly preparing a $50 billion bid for the Dow Chemical Company in what could be the biggest leveraged buyout ever. According to The Sunday Express, a financing package has been put in place for a break-up bid of between $52 and $58 a share and a formal offer valuing the company at at least $50 billion could come by the end of this week.

title: The Daily Reel Nabs Seed Funding from Prism
description: The Daily Reel, which filters and reviews user-generated video in search of the next rising star, has landed seed financing on the way to a first round. Prism VentureWorks, based in Westwood, Mass., provided the six-figure seed round. According to the Red Herring, The Daily Reel employs editors to separate creative Web gems from Aunt Mathildas vacation video and hopes to gain the support of advertisers and sponsors eager to hook up with the creative community.

title: Sainsbury Suitors Offer Stake as Sweetener
description: The private equity consortium stalking J Sainsbury offered the British supermarket chains shareholders a quarter of the company in stub equity as part of its 9.7 billion pound ($19 billion) takeover bid, according to The Times of London.

title: C.E.O. Pay: More Pieces, Still a Puzzle
description: While new disclosure rules have resulted in far more information, analysts say they still do not necessarily offer greater insight into executive compensation, The New York Times reported in Sundays special section on executive pay. Its like reading through Tolstoys War and Peace,  Lynn E. Turner, a former S.E.C. chief accountant and now a managing director of research at a proxy adviser, Glass, Lewis & Company, told the Timess Eric Dash. What is missing is a clear, succinct story about how the compensation committee came to the amount they were going to pay.

title: Silicon Valley Moneymen Make a Play for Airwaves
description: Some of Silicon Valleys most powerful venture capitalists and technology investors have joined an investment group that is preparing to challenge cellphone carriers, cable and satellite companies for valuable radio spectrum that will be freed when television broadcasters convert to digital signals.

title: In a Television Carnival, Buy, Sell or Cringe
description: The cult status of James J. Cramer, the host of the CNBC television show Mad Money, may derive more from the manic atmosphere he creates on the show than the sagacity of his stock tips.

title: Mirant to Consider Sale of Company
description: Mirant, a power company with a market capitalization of more than $10 billion, said early Monday it had hired J.P. Morgan Chase to help it explore strategic options including a possible sale of the entire company. The strategic review, which Mirant said was intended to enhance stockholder value, comes less than a year after Mirant withdrew its hostile bid for a rival, NRG Energy, after the $8 billion offer sparked a shareholder revolt. A few months ago, the Texas utility TXU agreed to be acquired by a pair of private equity firms, leading some analysts to suggest that Mirant could be a possible takeover candidate as well.

title: Where Will Zell Lead The Los Angeles Times?
description: Now that Samuel Zell has won Tribune, is he planning to sell off The Los Angeles Times? That question was on industry observers minds after Mr. Zell and his wife, Helen, dined Friday with Hollywood mogul David Geffen, who has for some time now been angling to gain control of the newspaper.

title: Goldman Wins Advisory Role for Dubai Bank Merger
description: Goldman Sachs won a contract to advise Emirates Bank International and National Bank of Dubai on merging, the lenders said on Monday. The two banks, in which the government of Dubai has stakes, said last month they would merge to create the Gulfs biggest lender.

title: Morgan Stanley and Time Warner Settle Suit
description: Morgan Stanley and Time Warner settled claims against them in a 2003 lawsuit that alleged AOL Time Warner fraudulently inflated its online advertising revenue and subscriber counts, the investment bank said in a regulatory filing Friday. Morgan Stanley was named as a defendant for its role as Time Warners adviser in the merger with America Online in 2001 and as underwriter of bond offerings completed in 2001 and 2002.

title: Taking a Peek Through the Hedges
description: Not so long ago, the talk about hedge funds was about their money  the art their managers bought or the salaries they paid themselves. But now as the discussion has moved to whether hedge funds bid up the price of oil, or even if they are the virus that could kill the market, New York Magazine has devoted its latest issue to those lightly regulated investment pools.

title: Behind the Curtain at Blackstones Hedge Fund
description: While Wall Street eyes the Blackstone Groups looming initial public offering with jealousy, investors looking for an edge into learning how one of the worlds most-connected money managers trades can study the holdings of its equity hedge fund. The New York Post takes a look at filings made by Blackstones Kailix Advisors fund and finds that the $1.3 billion fund has made a massive wager on the energy sector.

title: Warners Third EMI Bid May Go Right to Investors
description: The Warner Music Group is considering a merger with EMI by making a direct appeal to shareholders to undermine the opposition of EMIs management, The Times of London reported on Sunday. The EMI board last month rejected what it described as a preconditional offer at 260 pence per share. Any deal between the two companies, which rank No. 3 and No. 4 in recorded music sales, would require clearance by competition regulators.

title: Moon River and Me
description: The fact that we were going to take a long weekend in Savannah, before we sat down with another architect, shows just how much my attitude about building our dream home had changed in just a matter of months.

title: The Professors Lost Luggage
description: Can you be placed on the governments terrorist watch list for delivering an anti-Bush lecture? Walter F. Murphy, emeritus professor of law at Princeton, thinks thats what happened to him. On 1 March 07, I was scheduled to fly on American Airlines to Newark, N.J., to attend an academic conference at Princeton University, designed to focus on my latest scholarly book, Constitutional Democracy, published by Johns Hopkins University Press this past Thanksgiving, Murphy writes at the group legal blog Balkinization. When I tried to use the curb-side check in at the Sunport, I was denied a boarding pass because I was on the Terrorist Watch list. Murphy adds:

title: The Resilient Pork Barrel
description: From The Empire Zone notebook published today:

title: Farallon to Acquire Affordable Residential Unit for $1.8 Billion
description: Farallon Capital Management, the $26 billion hedge fund, has agreed to buy the manufactured home community business of Affordable Residential Communities for about $1.8 billion. In a statement, Affordable said it would keep its insurance business and use the sales proceeds to finance additional acquisitions. The company owns and operates about 57,264 home sites in 275 communities in 23 states.

title: School Aid in the 2007-8 New York State Budget
Former UBS Executive Joins Probitas Partners
description: Adam Frieman, until recently the deputy head of United States equity capital markets at UBS, has joined Probitas Partners, a placement agency. title: Key Man: Steven Robinson
description: Fashion designers take the bows, yet the fashion world knew of Steven Robinson, the assistant to John Galliano, who died suddenly last week in Paris at 38. Steven worked with John at both Dior and Galliano, on mens and womens, on haute couture and ready-to-wear, and they worked together from the late 1980s, when chronically short of money, everything rode on hopefulness and Johns genius. When John went to Dior, so did Steven and Bill Gaytten, his other longtime assistant. I always thought of them as the luckiest boys in fashion  hard-working, yes, but lucky, lucky to be in Paris at that time in their lives. Steven helped make real Johns fantastic ideas, though somehow this doesnt really touch all that he did. Steven was usually the first person Id see backstage after a show. A burly figure, he always looked flushed and happy and in a hurry. Did you like the show? hed say, and, of course, I knew that he knew that I did. Yes, Steven. It took nothing away from Steven Robinson that he was the assistant in the house. It is a great pity that he is gone.

Investors may simply have been nervous ahead of Palms analyst and investor day on Tuesday. Or they may have been reacting to statements by Palm chief executive Ed Colligan in an interview with Bloomberg News, in which he said that he is not concerned about calls for his company to be sold. Just a few weeks ago, reports on Unstrung.com, CNBC and elsewhere fueled takeover speculation about Palm, which makes the Treo smartphone, lifting its shares as high as $19.50 in intraday trading. No bid materialized, and the stock has fallen more than 11 percent.

The alliance is a nonprofit group that advocates for public access to the citys shores and waterways. It had been a project of the Municipal Art Society of New York from 1999 until it was spun off as an independent entity last week, said Kent L. Barwick, president of the art society. Mr. Lewis, 46, who lives in Flatbush, Brooklyn, said yesterday that he hoped to build the alliance into a large not-for-profit agency that will be dedicated to finding common ground among waterfront developers, government officials and the public.

The fire, which officials said was caused by a candle in the living room, began shortly after 10 a.m. in the building at 2504 Bronx Park East. Of the four people who escaped, three refused medical treatment. The fourth was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, the department said. Twelve firefighters were treated for injuries, the most serious described as burns to the ear. The officers who caught the children were identified as Paul McLaughlin and Maximo Rosado, both assigned to the Bronx.

title: Washington: Fish Protection Lags, Court Agrees
description: A federal appeals court upheld a ruling that found that federal agencies under the Bush administration had neglected to plan sufficiently for the protection of endangered salmon and steelhead in the Columbia and Snake Rivers. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, affirmed a 2005 decision by Judge James A. Redden of Federal District Court in Portland, Ore., that forced the National Marine Fisheries Service to revise its plan for the fish. Judge Redden said the agency had not met requirements of the Endangered Species Act. The government has been working on the new plan, its third try, and a draft is due later this year. Environmentalists and other groups have long argued that the best way to protect the fish is to remove four hydroelectric dams on the lower Snake River. The Bush administration has said that the dams are a permanent part of the landscape but that other measures, like habitat restoration, can improve fish populations.

The $15.3 billion offer is the biggest ever by a Mexican company and one of the largest in Australian corporate history.

title: Former N.Y.S.E. Chairman Needham Dies
description: James J. Needham, the first full-time paid chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, died on Friday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 80. The cause was complications related to myelodysplastic syndrome, a bone marrow disorder, his son-in-law, Tim Donahue, told The New York Times.

title: Funds Said to Consider $45 Billion Bell Canada Bid
description: One of Canadas largest pension funds is in early talks with other pension funds and a private equity firm to form a consortium to mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, The New York Times reported Tuesday, citing people briefed on the discussions. Such a takeover bid would be the largest buyout in history and represent a rare effort by a pension fund, rather than a private equity firm, to lead a buyout of this size.

title: Bankruptcy Trustee Opposes New Centurys Sale of Mortgages
description: New Century Financial, the subprime lending giant that filed for bankruptcy protection last week, should not be allowed to sell $50 million worth of mortgages to a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland, a United States trustee said Monday in court papers.

title: Ruling Backs Unions Protest on Sale of Tribune Paper
description: After finally agreeing to sell itself to Samuel Zell following a complicated auction, Tribune is now facing a roadblock on a smaller deal. An arbitrator has ruled that Tribunes sale of The Advocate of Stamford to Gannett violated a union contract by failing to require Gannett to honor the newsroom employees collective bargaining agreement, according to court papers filed Monday by the union.

title: State-by-State Property-Tax Rates
Pressure Mounts on Times Co. as 2d Proxy Firm Enters Debate
description: A second corporate advisory firm is urging shareholders of The New York Times Company to withhold their votes for directors at the companys annual meeting this month, underscoring the mounting investor discontent over the dual-class share structure of the Times Company and some of the strategic decisions taken by management.

title: Hollinger Money Was Disclosed, Witness Says
description: Defense lawyers at the fraud trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black produced documents on Monday that a prosecution witness agreed showed that payments at the heart of the case had been publicly disclosed.

title: Citigroup May Trim Its Compliance Corps
description: Charles O. Prince III spent his first two years as chief executive of Citigroup adding more compliance officers and improving the banks controls after a series of messy scandals. Now, Mr. Prince is looking to slim its bulging compliance ranks in an effort to keep the bank from getting bogged down.

title: Defense Rests in Trial of Ex-Qwest Chief
description: The defense rested its case Monday in the insider trading case of Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, ending widespread anticipation that Mr. Nacchio might take the stand on his own behalf.

title: Take-Twos Chief Financial Officer Resigns
description: Take-Two Interactive Softwares chief financial officer became the latest casualty at the beleaguered video game publisher following a shareholder revolt spearheaded by several activist investors. The financial officer, Karl H. Winters, announced his resignation Monday, less than two weeks after the chief executive and several board members were ousted by shareholders.

title: Private Equity Fund-Raising Up 67% in 1st Quarter
description: For those wondering if private equity could sustain its run of record fund-raising, the answer is: yes, it apparently can. Fund-raising by private equity firms in the United States rose 67 percent in the first quarter, according to Dow Jones Private Equity Analyst. Sixty-eight funds have raised $44.3 billion in the first quarter of 2007, compared with the 46 funds that raised $26.6 billion in the first quarter of last year, the newsletter said. In 2006, private equity firms raised a total $246.3 billion in 359 funds.

title: Salesforce.com Boosts Web Offerings with Koral Purchase
description: Salesforce.com, best known for its hosted sales applications, is pushing into Web content management. The company on Tuesday expects to detail new products and the acquisition of start-up Koral, which created a Web content management service tied to Salesforce.com. Terms of the purchase of Koral, a nine-person firm based in San Mateo, Calif., which first launched its product last fall, were not disclosed.

title: Putting a Price Tag on Facebook: Round 2
description: Much ink has been spilled on the question of whether social networking site Facebook will sell out and, if so, for how much. Following Googles $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube last year, rumors percolated that Yahoo and Viacom were interested, and that Facebooks founder and chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, was holding out for a $2 billion offer.

title: China Citic Bank Looks to Raise $3.86 Billion in I.P.O.
description: China Citic Bank plans to raise up to 30.14 billion Hong Kong dollars ($3.86 billion) in an initial public offering ahead of its Hong Kong listing on April 27, a news report said Tuesday. The indicative price range of the H shares  Hong Kong dollar-denominated shares of companies based in mainland China  is 4.72 Hong Kong dollars to 6.17 Hong Kong dollars each, according to a term sheet seen by Dow Jones Newswires.

title: For Citi, Old Lane Could Mark New Strategy
description: Amid reports that Citigroup may buy the hedge fund Old Lane, The Financial Times writes that Citis chief executive, Charles Prince, once dismissed the notion of acquiring a hedge fund manager as the flavor of the moment. Breakingviews suggests Old Lane could bring both financial and personnel headaches for Citi.

title: Algoma Becomes Subject of Takeover Chatter
description: The takeover drums are once again pounding out the name Algoma Steel. Algoma shares jumped 2.36 Canadian dollars to close at 53.89 Canadian dollars ($46.96) Monday on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The activity was fueled by several factors, including a report in the industry newsletter Steel Business Briefing, word that Algomas management will brief potential bidders for the company this week, and the steady rise in steel prices.

title: A Fight for Democracy
description: Nicholas D. Kristof reports from Pakistan on what happens when villagers vote the 'wrong' way in elections.

title: Private Equity Firm Seeks to Block Imax Filing Delay
description: Shares of Imax fell nearly 10 percent Monday after a private equity fund manager said it was seeking support from other bondholders to oppose the giant screen makers bid for more time to file its 2006 financial results. The Catalyst Capital Group of Toronto said in a statement that it is organizing opposition to Imaxs move to seek consent from bondholders for a waiver from certain financial reporting defaults.

title: Former Edocare Executives Charged With Fraud
description: Two former executives at Endocare, a medical products company based in Irvine, Calif., were indicted Monday for allegedly helping to inflate company revenue in a fraud that cost investors more than $200 million. A former chief executive, Paul W. Mikus, and a former chief financial officer, John V. Cracchiolo, were charged with wire fraud, securities fraud, filing false statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission and lying to Endocares accountants.

title: Nasdaq Posts Best 1st Quarter for I.P.O.s Since 2000
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market posted its strongest first quarter performance for initial public offerings listings since the beginning of 2000. The total number of public offerings for the first quarter of 2007 came to 42, Nasdaq said. Six of the 10 largest offerings in the United States by proceeds raised listed on the exchange in the first quarter, led by National CineMedia  the largest so far this year, according to Nasdaq.

title: U.S. Markets Attract More Foreign Listings
description: Despite fears that burdensome federal regulations are scaring companies away, markets in the United States are getting more foreign listings, TheStreet.com reported. During the first quarter, 19 percent of the 67 initial public offerings on the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq Stock Market and the American Stock Exchange were foreign-based, according to Dealogic. Thats up from 16 percent for all of last year.

title: La Jolla Playhouse Gets New Artistic Director
description: Christopher Ashley, the director of "Regrets Only," the 2000 revival of "The Rocky Horror Show" and the coming Broadway production of "Xanadu," has been named the new artistic director of the La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego.

title: K.K.R. Consortium May Top Coles Bid
description: The third time may be a charm for the Kohlberg Kravis Roberts-led consortium looking to gain control of the Australian retailer Coles Group. Coles said Tuesday that the Kohlberg consortium may top a bid of 19.7 billion Australian dollars ($16.1 billion) for the retailer by Wesfarmers.

title: Obama on the Letterman Show
description: April 10 - Presidential candidate Barack Obama appeared on 'The Late Show with David Letterman' Monday night, the possibility of a double ticket with Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Bertelsmann Buys Out Time Warner Stake in Book Club
description: Bertelsmann, the owner of the publisher Random House, agreed to buy Time Warners stake in the Bookspan book club for a reported $150 million to become the biggest operator of book, music and DVD clubs in the United States. Bookspan, a 50-50 joint venture between the biggest media companies in the United States and Europe, will be fully owned by Bertelsmann after the purchase.

title: Theater Briefs
description: The Tony Award-winning actor James Naughton ("City of Angels," "Chicago") will direct the world premiere of David Epstein's "Surface to Air" at Symphony Space.

title: Morgan Stanley Shareholders to Vote on Pay Resolution
description: Morgan Stanley shareholders will vote Tuesday on a resolution that would give them a greater say in how the investment bank pays its top executives. The securities firm is just one of many companies facing such resolutions at their annual stockholder meetings; others include Bank of New York and Citigroup.

title: Former Head of Hedge-Fund Backed Studio Returns
description: The former head of the independent movie production house First Look Studios, who left the company in March after reportedly falling afoul of the companys hedge fund backers, is back at the helm. Henry Winterstern, who resigned last month as chief of First Look, will be running the company again alongside Avi Lerner, whose Nu Image/Millennium Films bought the struggling First Look last month.

title: J.P. Morgan Expands Boston Operations
description: J.P. Morgan Chase said it plans to add up to 100 people to its mutual fund services division in Boston and move the unit to new space downtown. The financial services giant said it has hired more than 150 for the Boston group since last year, which now numbers 450 and provides custody, accounting, and investment operations for mutual fund companies.

title: Internet Start-Up Gets Debt Financing from Hercules
description: Hercules Technology Growth Capital said on Monday it had provided $22.5 million of debt financing to Ikano Communications, a provider of Internet services. Hercules is a specialty finance company providing growth capital to venture capital and private equity backed technology and life science companies.

title: Sirion Gets $45 Million Injection from New Investors
description: Sirion Therapeutics has picked up five new institutional investors in a Series B private equity financing that raised $45 million for the company. A new investor, Aisling Capital, led the latest round of funding. Other new investors include Advent International and Bear Stearns.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about Samuel Zell using an Employee Stock Ownership Plan, or ESOP, in a transaction for the Tribune Company omitted a condition for an owner to avoid capital gains taxes on the proceeds of a sale of company shares to such a plan. In addition to the ESOP holding the stock for at least three years, the company has to be private for at least one year before the sale.

title: United Rentals to Explore Sale of Company
description: United Rentals, an equipment rental chain with a market capitalization of about $2.2 billion, said Tuesday it had hired UBS and Credit Suisse to help it explore strategic options including a possible sale of the company. It also said its chief executive would retire in June.

title: Blackstone, Texas Pacific Reportedly Drop Sainsbury Bid
description: One week after Kohlberg Kravis Roberts dropped out of the running for J Sainsbury, two other buyout firms have followed suit. The Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group have left the consortium bidding for J Sainsbury, a chain of grocery stores, after the founding family opposed an offer of less than 600 pence ($11.85) a share, Bloomberg News reported citing unnamed sources.

title: Malek and McCain
description: Last week, Senator John McCain turned to Frederic V. Malek to help his fundraising efforts. Right away, some liberal groups brought up Mr. Maleks carrying out a request from President Richard M. Nixon in 1971 that he count the Jews at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Stem Cell Vote in the Balance
description: The Senate is expected to pass legislation this week that would ease the Bush administrations limits on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research. The measure, passed by the House, is identical to the bill that passed the Senate 63 to 37 last year before being vetoed by President Bush.

title: PPR to Offer $7.1 Billion to Capture Puma
description: PPR, the French conglomerate whose brands include Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent, will offer 5.3 billion euros ($7.1 billion) for the German sportswear company Puma after reaching a deal to buy out a leading shareholder, PPR said Tuesday. Puma welcomed the offer and said it would recommend the bid to its shareholders.

title: A Billion-Dollar Year for Top Hedge Fund Managers
description: A harsh truth of the hedge-fund world is that someones painful loss is usually someone elses big gain.

title: Tony Soprano, Ordinary Suburbanite
2008: Romneys Aides on His Religion
description: During a March conversation at Harvard, strategists for Mitt Romney accused his Republican rivals of playing up, albeit subtly, the former Massachusetts governors Mormon faith. Dan Balz has the story in The Washington Post:

title: A Premiere, 70 Years Later
description: Princeton University is staging the premiere of a version of Pushkins 1825 play Boris Godunov, which ran afoul of the Russian government in the 1930s.

title: $800,000 Homes
description: Tour a cottage on the Georgia coast, a condo in downtown Denver and a contemporary house on the Hawaiian island of Oahu.

title: A Capitol Idea
description: Michel Richard is one of the few Washington chefs who could be a star in New York, and his restaurant Citronelle would be a huge hit here.

title: Update: BCE Stock Rises 7 Percent
description: Shares of BCE, which owns Bell Canada, were up as much as 7 percent Tuesday after it was reported that the companys largest shareholder was contacting other investors about a possible takeover bid. The New York Times reported that the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan has reached out in recent weeks to Caisse de Dpt et Placement du Qubec and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about pursuing a takeover, which could be valued at $45 billion, including assumed debt. DealBook has also learned that Ontario Teachers held talks with Providence Equity Partners, a United States-based private equity firm that specializes in media and telecommunications investments.

title: MasterCard Sells Low, Buys High
description: Heres a peculiar investment strategy: Sell something for $39, and then buy it back less than a year later for more than $100. Thats essentially what MasterCard International is proposing to do with its own stock.

title: Googles Next Great Enterprise
description: Too bad I didnt spot this the day it went upApril Fools day.

title: Tribecas Second Try
description: Subaru stylists baffle me. Without getting into the nuances of each model, I wonder how a company that can design a car as outright handsome as the Legacy can also step on its own toes so often.

title: Is Michael Bloomberg Worth $13 Billion?
description: For a company whose raison detre is publishing financial data, Bloomberg LP is remarkably stingy with details about its own financial picture. But that has not stopped Fortune magazine from trying to guess how much the company, founded by New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, is worth. Using lots of back-of-the-envelope estimates, bolstered by some hitherto unreleased financial information from the company itself, Fortune calculates that Bloomberg LP may be worth about $20 billion. That would give Mr. Bloomberg, who owns more than two-thirds of the company, a stake worth a cool $13 billion.

title: The SX4 Family Tree Gains a Trunk
description: Introduced on Thursday: 2008 Suzuki SX4 Sedan

title: From B9 to Benign
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2008 Subaru Tribeca

title: V-22 Osprey's Troubled Launch
description: The V-22 Osprey, a hybrid aircraft, will be deployed to Iraq this September. Critics say its limitations may make it vulnerable to attack.

title: J.P. Morgan Hires Banker From HSBC
description: J.P. Morgan Chase has added another investment banker to its financial institutions group, according to an internal memo. Tod Perkins, who will be a managing director, comes to J.P. Morgan from HSBC Securities, where he was head of the depository institutions group for the Americas. Prior to that, Mr. Perkins was a managing director at Credit Suisse, where he focused on banks.

title: Almost Seeing It All at Fenway Park
description: And in the 96th season at Fenway Park, I can see the entire field. Well, almost.

title: Big Apple and Big Shoulders Vie for CBOT
description: The struggle for the Chicago Board of Trade is more than just another bidding war. To hear the Chicago Tribune tell it, it represents a larger power grab by big New York investment banks, who favor a late bid from the IntercontinentalExchange over the previous offer from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. It is, the Chicago newspaper suggested Tuesday, the Big Apple versus the City of Big Shoulders, with New York interests working hard to make sure their city tops Chicago in the market for exchange-traded derivatives.

title: Lehman Chief Talks About LAffaire Woody
description: When top-producing Lehman Brothers investment banker George H. Young III abruptly resigned in February, neither Lehman nor Mr. Young  known as Woody  offered much in the way of a public explanation for the rift.

title: Financial Adviser Sentenced to 5 Years for Fraud
description: Martin A. Armstrong, the financial adviser who has spent seven years in jail for contempt of court, was sentenced Tuesday to five additional years in prison for running what prosecutors say was a $3 billion Ponzi scheme. Judge John F. Keenan of the Southern District of New York also ordered Mr. Armstrong to pay restitution to the fraud victims, who are to receive $80 million  plus one dollar more  from Mr. Armstrong and others involved in the alleged scheme.

title: Bush on the Democrat-ic Congress
description: As he was assailing Congressional Democrats for delays in passing an Iraq war spending bill, President Bush stopped to make sure he got his Democratic terminology straight.

title: 2008: Rutgers and Imus
description: At their news conference today, the Rutgers womens basketball team took a few questions from the media about Don Imus, the racially charged remarks he made about them and the controversy that has engulfed them.

title: Newt Explains It All
description: Senator John Kerry and Newt Gingrich debated climate change today.

title: Blogtalk
description: Report card: Republicans give Ds to Spitzer. [Capitol Confidential]

title: The Dining Table Wine School
description: So now I have two cases of wine in my parlor beckoning me to start drinking.

title: Giuliani on Imus and the Confederate Flag
description: MONTGOMERY  The remarks by Don Imus  are reverberating in the presidential campaign, with Rudolph W. Giuliani telling reporters today that the remarks were wrong, very wrong, but adding he would continue to appear on the show in the future.

title: On the Threshold of a Global Job Market
description: The stunningly bad proofs of my senior portraits arrived in the mail when I was home over spring break, wallowing in anxiety about my lack of post-graduation employment. The proofs themselves are of a fine quality; it is my panicked expression that ruins them.

title: Growing Case for a Nuclear Solution?
description: A worker checks the radioactivity of drums containing nuclear waste at a power plant near Seoul, South Korea.Lee Jin-man/AP

title: Hold the Bread Crumbs
description: Pt de campagne, or country pt, is a variation of meatloaf that's elegant enough to serve at dinners where you want to impress your guests.

title: The Power of Green
description: Tom Friedman on how America can regain its international stature by taking the lead in alternative energy and environmentalism.

title: Hey, Thats My Helmet!
description: Doug Mientkiewicz was in the on-deck circle at the Metrodome last night when a fan heckled him. This is not unusual in Minnesota, where some fans find it cool to boo Mientkiewicz even though he did not leave via free agency  the Twins traded him in 2004.

title: Boof Is No Match for A-Rod
description: The Twins starter tonight is Boof Bonser, who is 1/3 of the greatest trade in modern baseball times (in my opinion): A.J. Pierzynski to the Giants for Joe Nathan, Bonser and Francisco Liriano in 2003. Still hard to see why the Giants gave up three young pitchers for a catcher they would cut after one year.

title: The C.B.C. Stands By Fox
description: Despite the fact that the three top contenders (at this point) for the Democratic nomination say they wont take part in a September debate in Detroit sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus Institute and Fox News, the C.B.C. released a statement tonight announcing that it stands by its plan.

title: 2008: MoveOn, Democrats and the War
description: The Democratic presidential candidates gathered tonight  or, actually, their voices did  for what was billed as the first Virtual Town Meeting of the 2008 campaign. Topic: Iraq.

title: Ever considered Antigua?
description: NonSuch

title: Rare Company for A-Rod
description: Think about this: in the history of baseball, only one player has ever hit more home runs in the first seven games of a season than Alex Rodriguez. That was the Hall of Famer Mike Schmidt for the Phillies in 1976. A-Rod is one of eight others who have hit six homers in the first seven games.

title: A Word of Advice During a Housing Slump: Rent
description: In a stark reversal of the housing market, its now clear that people who chose renting over buying in the last two years made the right move. In much of the country, including large parts of the Northeast, California, Florida and the Southwest, recent home buyers have faced higher monthly costs than renters and have lost money on their investment in the meantime.

title: To Study Wine, Buy and Drink
description: PEOPLE ask me, more often than any other question by far, where to go to learn about wine.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the photography licensing company Corbis misidentified the photographer who took a well-known photo of John F. Kennedy Jr. playing under his fathers desk in the Oval Office. It was Stanley Tretick  not Cecil Stoughton, who also shot pictures in the Kennedy White House.

title: Upsetting the Balance
description: Masai Mara, Kenya

title: Indians, Cheered by Sausage, Feel at Home in Milwaukee
description: MILWAUKEE, April 10  Slider, the Cleveland Indians furry mascot, hung K signs from Bernie Brewers perch above the left-field bleachers and slid down his slide after a Kelly Shoppach home run. John Adams, the Indians famed drummer for more than 30 years, pounded out his familiar cadence in the right-field bleachers.

title: Seven Games, Six Homers: Rodriguez Stays Locked In
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 10  The Minnesota Twins could have reached into their past and cloned Walter Johnson, and it probably would have made no difference. Alex Rodriguez is especially hot right now, seeming to bludgeon any pitcher in his path.

title: California: Judge Backs Schools in Race Case
description: A judge has ruled that the Berkeley Unified School District does not violate state law when considering race in assigning students to programs. The ruling stems from a lawsuit filed last year by the Pacific Legal Foundation, a supporter of a 1996 ballot measure designed to abolish the use of sexual and racial preferences in government hiring and contracts. The judge, Winifred Y. Smith of Alameda County Superior Court, ruled Friday that the district appropriately used racial demographics, rather than the race of individual students, in deciding student placement. But the judge let stand the lawsuits challenge to a mentoring and tutoring program.

title: Rapids Spirits Are Higher Than the Mercury
description: It was a blue-ribbon day as the Colorado Rapids opened their Major League Soccer season and their new sold-out stadium, Dicks Sporting Goods Park.

title: Food Calendar
description: Steak Class

title: A First-Class Response to a Second-Class Put-Down
description: Of grace and dignity, without a single boob joke for ratings or a raunchy sidekick for on-air laughs, the women wearing Rutgers scarlet managed to capsize societys power differential yesterday.

title: Recipe: Supernatural Brownies
description: Adapted from Chocolate: From Simple Cookies to Extravagant Showstoppers, by Nick Malgieri (Morrow Cookbooks, 1998)

title: No Stella, No Stanley, but a Streetcar Named Desire Visits New York City
description: Yesterday, on a street in Times Square, there were no azaleas or Spanish moss, no hot and fetid air, no maligned wives in slips or coarse husbands in torn T-shirts, no New Orleans of the imagination at all.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the partial collapse of a wall at Chumleys, a popular Greenwich Village bar and restaurant, misspelled the given name of the original owner. He was Leland Chumley, not Leleand, and was known as Lee.

title: Battle Lines Drawn at Preliminary Hearing in Bell Case
description: The three detectives charged in the shooting that killed Sean Bell returned to court for a brief hearing today, surrounded by supporters and detractors who will likely become fixtures as the case winds its way toward trial.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies on Sunday about the Mets first loss of the season, to the Braves in Atlanta on Saturday, referred incorrectly to pitcher Tom Glavines pursuit of 300 career victories. He had been seeking his 292nd victory, not his 293rd.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about a brush fire on Staten Island that routed residents from their homes gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of a man whose property was damaged. He is Dan Archer, not Archerdiff.

title: Rare Protests at Brigham Young Over a Planned Cheney Appearance
description: PROVO, Utah, April 10  The invitation extended to Vice President Dick Cheney to be the commencement speaker at Brigham Young University has set off a rare, continuing protest at the Mormon university, one of the nations most conservative.

title: Con Ed Told to Cover Its Own Costs After Blackout
description: ALBANY, April 10  A Queens assemblyman is warning that New York Citys ratepayers could wind up paying for tens of millions of dollars that Consolidated Edison spent to repair its network in western Queens after a nine-day blackout last July.

title: Kurt Vonnegut, Writer of Classics of the American Counterculture, Dies at 84
description: Kurt Vonnegut, whose dark comic talent and urgent moral vision in novels like Slaughterhouse-Five, Cats Cradle and God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater caught the temper of his times and the imagination of a generation, died Wednesday night in Manhattan. He was 84 and had homes in Manhattan and in Sagaponack on Long Island.

title: NBC Drops Imus Show From Its Cable Network
description: NBC News dropped Don Imus yesterday, canceling his talk show on its MSNBC cable news channel a week after Mr. Imus made racially disparaging remarks about the Rutgers University womens basketball team.

title: DNA Results Announced in Smith Case
description: Larry Birkhead, the former boyfriend of the late Anna Nicole Smith who had been insisting that he was the father of her child, emerged from a courtroom in the Bahamas on Tuesday with his hands held high over his head and declared, I told you so.

title: When the Cure Is Not Worth the Cost
description: ON its face, providing equal coverage for mental and physical illnesses sounds like a good idea, something only a managed-care bean counter could oppose. To that end, Representatives Jim Ramstad, Republican of Minnesota, and Patrick Kennedy, Democrat of Rhode Island, have introduced the Paul Wellstone Mental Health and Addiction Equity Act.

title: The Enticing Oyster, in Months With R or Not
description: SURELY if I put my mind to it I could learn how to shuck oysters without serious damage to myself. But I havent done so, even though I love them when they are icy cold, filled with the briny flavor of the sea and ready to be slurped out of the shell.

title: Rutgers Women Send Imus an Angry Message
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J. April 10  It had all the appearances of a pep rally: Louis Brown Athletic Center was jammed with spectators and reporters Tuesday morning as the Rutgers womens basketball team strode onto the noisy court behind the universitys president, the athletic director, their coach and her assistants.

title: Citigroup to Lay Off 17,000 in Overhaul
description: Citigroup announced today that it would eliminate or reassign more than 26,500 jobs as part of a sweeping overhaul to cut costs and streamline the global banks sprawling operations.

title: When the Iraqis Show Us the Door (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: Leash-Free Dogs at Night in City Parks
description: The Parks and Recreation Department announced yesterday that a policy of allowing dogs off leashes during overnight hours will become effective next month. Beginning May 10, owners with a license and proof of a current rabies vaccination will be permitted to let their dogs roam in designated areas of city parks from 9 p.m. to 9 a.m. Under an unofficial policy, the department has for years not given tickets to dog owners who let their pets run free at night in parks.

title: With Usual Flourish, Sharpe James Pulls Curtain on a Career and an Era in Newark
description: NEWARK, April 10  You notice that no one ever calls me Mr. Mayor, Sharpe James said with a sly smile on Tuesday, the day after he announced that he would not seek re-election to the State Senate and signaled an end to his 37 years in the contact sport known as politics. Everybody calls me Sharpe. If I was a political boss and ran a political machine like so many say I do, then they would all call me Mr. Mayor.

title: Trial Starts in Case of Couple Who Robbed Mob, and Paid for It
description: It stands to reason that the Mafia took responsibility for killing Thomas and Rose Marie Uva, a young couple shot to death near their home in Ozone Park, Queens, on Christmas Eve 1992.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Monday with a front-page article about a proposal for a blogger code of conduct misstated a Web site that has developed a set of standards. It is BlogHer.org, not BlogHer.com.

title: Inside Story of a Hip-Hop Return to Glory
description: Rock the Bells is the story of one mans labor of love to reunite the original members of the Wu-Tang Clan for a 2004 hip-hop concert in San Bernardino, Calif., and it demands neither familiarity with the music nor a hankering for rhyme. Instead Casey Suchan and Denis Henry Hennellys lively documentary grabs hold of the backstage drama and doesnt let go until the last weary fan has shuffled off home.

title: Some Stilted Conversations, but Signs of a Cultural Shift
description: PARIS, April 7  New business students may yearn to chat with one another in Wall Street English, but the bottom line is that the conversations are a little stilted.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts last Wednesday about the success that Chinese classical musicians have found in the West referred incorrectly to Sa Chen, a finalist in the 2005 Van Cliburn piano competition, and misstated her age. While she is among a new crop of stars, she is not among those in their teens or barely out of them; she is 27, not 17.

title: What You Get for ... $800,000
description: Richmond Hill, Ga.

title: Ex-Duke Players Await an Announcement
description: RALEIGH, N.C., April 10  The three defendants in the Duke lacrosse sexual assault case and their families arrived in the area late Tuesday in expectation of an announcement from the state attorney general clearing them of all charges, one of the defense lawyers said.

title: Can Trump Casinos Keep Up With the Neighbors?
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Two of the three casinos here that bear his name rank dead last in terms of gambling revenues among the 11 casinos in town. And in an industry that sometimes seems like a legal means of printing money, his casino holding company lost $19 million last year  in no small part because it is freighted with a staggering $1.4 billion in debt.

title: Auditors Plea Deal in Larceny Will Cost Him His Corvettes
description: ALBANY, April 10  A veteran state auditor pleaded guilty on Tuesday to stealing $1.2 million that was supposed to be used to help the mentally ill. Under the plea deal, he will face up to 10 years in prison and must sell his collection of Corvettes.

title: NASA Delays Shuttle Launching Until June to Fix Hail Damage
description: The much-delayed launching of the space shuttle Atlantis is being pushed back again into June as NASA struggles to repair thousands of gouges on the crafts hail-pocked fuel tank, officials said yesterday.

title: Ivy League or Bust? For Some, Anyway (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: After Recall, Dog and Cat Owners Seek Out Organic Food
description: BOSTON, April 10  The health-conscious customers at the store in the trendy South End neighborhood want wholesome food: vegetable and fruit chews; high-protein, low-carb nuggets; and organic meals containing cottage cheese.

title: For Democrats, Health Care Is a Rite of Passage
description: Senator Barack Obamas campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination faces many tests over the coming months, but few are as fraught with risk and opportunity as this: His promise to produce a plan that will achieve universal health coverage by January 2013.

title: Bronx: Dead Woman Is Identified
description: The police said yesterday that they had identified a woman whose body was found in a black bag beneath a bridge in Frank S. Hackett Park on Saturday. The woman, whom the police identified as Christie Nelly, 36, of West 29th Street in Bayonne, N.J., died of compression to the neck, a spokeswoman from the medical examiners office said. Callers identified Ms. Nelly after the police released a sketch of her, the police said. The time of her death was unclear, but a passer-by saw the bag under the Fieldston Road entrance to the Henry Hudson Parkway and called 911 at 9:25 a.m., according to the police. No arrests have been made, and the investigation was continuing.

title: Correction: The Curious Cook
description: The Curious Cook column last Wednesday, about the chemistry of meat color, referred incorrectly to the chemical that binds with the pigment myoglobin to make nitrite-cured meat pink. It is nitric oxide (NO)  not nitrous oxide (N2O), a sedative used in dentistry.

title: Closing Arguments Begin in Trial of Ex-Qwest Chief
description: DENVER, April 10  A federal prosecutor, Colleen Conry, portrayed Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest International, on Tuesday as a man who knowingly and unlawfully concealed Qwests growing money troubles, while simultaneously cashing in on his stock options.

title: Packing for the Ineffable
description: Westport, Conn.

title: Strange Racetrack Critters and the Horses They Watch
description: In a few short weeks the best 3-year-old horses in the United States will line up at the starting gate for the Kentucky Derby. Elsewhere, on that same day, thousands of horses at tracks across the country will also race, a lot more slowly and for a lot less money. Their drama is the subject of Not by a Long Shot, T. D. Thorntons chronicle of a sad season at Suffolk Downs, better known to its patrons as Sufferin Downs.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on April 3 about problems faced by Michelle Bachelet, Chiles first female president, referred incorrectly to the political affiliation of her predecessor, Ricardo Lagos Escobar. While both belong to the same coalition, they are not now of the same party. (Ms. Bachelet is a Socialist; Mr. Lagos is a former Socialist who founded the Party for Democracy, or PPD.) (Go to Article)

title: Orange: Woman Killed Man After Fight, Police Say
description: A 33-year-old man was killed on Monday night after a woman he had been dating ran him over with a car after an argument, the Essex County prosecutor said yesterday. The woman, Natasha White, 31, was charged with murder, said the prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. Ms. Dow said that about 11 p.m. Ms. White drove her silver Lexus into a pickup belonging to her companion, Zachary Sanders, after an argument outside a bar at Main Street and Lincoln Avenue. She then pointed her car at Mr. Sanders and ran him over, Ms. Dow said. Mr. Sanders was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where he was pronounced dead just before midnight. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: A Studio Head Who Resigned Is Back
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10  In a surprise move, Henry Winterstern, who abruptly resigned as chairman of the independent studio First Look in March, has been named co-chairman of the studio, the company announced on Tuesday.

title: Senate Inquiry in Loan Case Is Studying Stock Transfer
description: An Education Department official and financial aid directors at three universities received stock in a student loan company from the companys current president in what may have been a violation of securities law, Senate aides looking into the transactions say.

title: U.S. Says It Found Iranian Arms in Sunni Area
description: BAGHDAD, April 11  Arms that American military officials say appear to have been manufactured in Iran as recently as last year have turned up in the past week in a Sunni-majority area, the chief spokesman for the American military command in Iraq said Wednesday in a news conference.

title: North Korea Offers to Admit Nuclear Inspectors
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 11  North Korea has offered to allow United Nations nuclear inspectors to enter the country for the first time in more than four years, Governor Bill Richardson of New Mexico said here today after making an official visit to North Korea and meeting with senior officials there.

title: Defending Iraq War, McCain Assails Democrats
description: LEXINGTON, Va., April 11  Senator John McCain of Arizona today accused his potential Democratic presidential rivals of playing small politics in opposing the war in Iraq, saying withdrawal would lead to chaos across the Middle East, embolden Al Qaeda and expose the United States to another 9/11  or worse.

title: Bidders Are Lining Up for a Chance to Own the Cubs
