description: CHICAGO, April 10  Thomas Begel badly wants to buy the Cubs, and in his seat behind home plate at Wrigley Field on Monday, he offered a wealthy fans sentiment sure to be repeated by other bidders.

title: Romney Says Hell Expand Armed Forces by 100,000
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  Mitt Romney made his most extensive remarks on military and foreign policy on Tuesday, saying that if elected president he would push to add at least 100,000 troops to the armed forces and significantly increase military spending.

title: Columbia to Receive $400 Million for Student Aid
description: Correction Appended

title: Rodriguez Hikes Socks and the Homers Follow
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 10  When Alex Rodriguez took batting practice Tuesday, he had these five hits in a row: fly ball off the right-field wall, two flies off the center-field wall, ground ball up the middle, fly ball into the left-field seats.

title: Former Duke Players Cleared of All Charges
description: RALEIGH, N.C. April 11  All remaining charges were dropped today against three former Duke University lacrosse players who had been accused of rape more than a year ago, North Carolinas attorney general announced, concluding a three-month investigation of a racially charged case that polarized and outraged many in the state and nation.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 10, 2007

title: Group Questions Cellphone Fund-Raising
description: A new program that lets cellphone users send text messages to donate to the American Red Cross in major natural disasters has come under fire by a consumer group that contends the program is a business development strategy masquerading as charity.

title: Bush Criticizes Democrats for Delay in Iraq Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  President Bush, at loggerheads with Congress over an emergency Iraq spending bill, accused Democrats on Tuesday of behaving irresponsibly, as the two sides moved closer to confrontation over whether  or how far  lawmakers could push Mr. Bush toward withdrawing troops.

title: Queens: Man Accused of Seeking Mothers Murder
description: A Rikers Island inmate was charged yesterday with trying to hire someone he believed was a hit man to kill his mother, prosecutors said. The inmate, Joseph Salvio, 30, of Astoria, is accused of asking an undercover police officer to kill his mother in exchange for three of her fur coats, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Salvio was serving a four-month sentence for drug possession when he tried to arrange the killing, Mr. Brown said. He added that Mr. Salvio told the undercover officer to make the killing look like a robbery at his mothers home in Astoria and said he could keep three coats  a mink, a fox, and a raccoon  worth $10,000.

title: Special Assessments: When Your Board Wants More of Your Money
description: In February, when the Apache Wells development in Mesa, Ariz., approved plans for a new $8.5 million community center, many homeowners were not happy with their share of the bill: $6,020 each.

title: A Japanese All-Star Game and a Reunion at Fenway
description: BOSTON, April 10  When Ichiro Suzuki took his position in center field for the Seattle Mariners on Tuesday at Fenway Park, he noticed an advertisement behind him. The sign featured a Dunkin Donuts coffee cup with Welcome to Fenway written in Japanese. Just by looking at that, Suzuki said, I can tell its something big.

title: Chaos at the Line Where Performer and Audience Blur
description: A show by the reunited Stooges deals with the boundaries of the self; its about private-made-public and public-made-private. It airs ideas (and parts of the body) that usually arent laid open, and turns the hey-ho communal experience of rock into an inner monologue.

title: Jagjit Singh Chauhan, Sikh Militant Leader in India, Dies at 80
description: Jagjit Singh Chauhan, the Sikh who led a violent separatist movement in Indias northern Punjab State, died at his home in Tanda, India, on April 4. He was 80.

title: French Luxury Retailer Makes a Friendly Bid for Puma
description: FRANKFURT, April 10  The French luxury goods retailer PPR bid about $7 billion on Tuesday for Puma, the German sporting goods company, promising to keep its chief executive, Jochen Zeitz, at the helm of the company he turned around.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Sorting Through the Wreckage of a Love Most Foul
description: By the end of David Harrowers Blackbird, a drama that promises to be the most powerful of the season, Jeff Daniels and Alison Pill are about as naked as its possible for two people to be.

title: Two Bodies Are Found in a Town Where These Things Dont Happen
description: COLDEN, N.Y., April 10  Geraldine Jackson was getting ready to have her family, including two great-grandchildren she doted on, over for Christmas dinner at her house in the hills outside Buffalo when it burned down on the morning of Dec. 22.

title: Housing Authority Is Facing $225 Million Deficit in 07
description: One year after announcing plans to raise rents, cut costs and appeal to federal and state officials for help in closing a $168 million budget gap, the New York City Housing Authority is facing an even bigger budget shortfall.

title: Tied to a City, a Farmers Market Proves Hardy
description: PORTLAND, Me.  Until last summer, the 136-year-old building at 28 Monument Square had been one of the most visible eyesores at the center of this energetic Atlantic Coast city. You would never know it now.

title: Brooklyn: Lawyer for City Contractors Charged
description: A lawyer representing some city construction contractors was arrested yesterday and charged with defrauding city agencies by allowing the contractors to avoid paying benefits to workers, federal prosecutors said. The lawyer, Steven Coren, 56, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court to mail fraud, money laundering and obstruction of justice, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. Prosecutors charged that Mr. Coren helped set up a fund in which contractors for agencies including the City Housing Authority, the School Construction Authority and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority deposited fringe benefits payments for workers, but the contractors then used the money for other purposes. Mr. Corens lawyer, Marc L. Mukasey, said his client was at all times practicing law honorably and legally and expects to be fully exonerated.

title: The Rutgers Winning Team
description: It is hard to imagine a better commentary on Don Imuss disgraceful behavior than the appearance yesterday by the very women he verbally assaulted, the Rutgers basketball team. Mr. Imuss comments were racist and sexist, aimed at young athletes who deserved high praise, not such low treatment. The students were dignified, suitably angry and hurt, and the class act of the moment.

title: How a Queen Lost Her Heart Before She Lost Her Head
description: Only three characters inhabit Marie Antoinette: The Color of Flesh, but this impeccably acted play at the 45th Street Theater has the sweep of a historical novel. The history in this case is the French Revolution: its real events swirl outside, while inside at Versailles, emotions swirl just as vigorously around a triangle of love and friendship imagined by the playwright, Joel Gross.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Wednesday about the risky state of New Jerseys pension fund for state and local government workers misidentified the office held by John O. Bennett, then a New Jersey senator, in 2001, when he abstained from a vote to increase teachers pensions by 9 percent. Mr. Bennett was the Republican majority leader of the State Senate at the time, not its co-president.

title: The Money Trail That Linked North Korea to Macao
description: HONG KONG, April 11  To American law enforcement agencies, it was one of the most elaborate smuggling investigations in memory. When it concluded almost two years ago, it produced dozens of arrests, as well as hard evidence that Chinese criminal gangs had smuggled counterfeit American currency, cigarettes and drugs made in North Korea into the United States.

title: NBC Drops Imus Show From Its Cable Network
description: NBC announced this evening that it was dropping Don Imuss program from its MSNBC cable network as the backlash continued to grow over racially disparaging remarks Mr. Imus made about the Rutgers University womens basketball team and advertisers said they were pulling their commercials from the morning television program.

title: First Suburb Gets a Taste of Disorder
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

title: In Alabama, Giuliani Calls Confederate Flag a Local Issue
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 10  Answering a question that has become a litmus test of sorts for Republicans campaigning in the South, Rudolph W. Giuliani said Tuesday that he would leave the decision about whether to fly the Confederate battle flag over the State Capitol here to the people of Alabama.

title: Recipe: French Chocolate Brownies
description: Adapted from Baking: From My Home to Yours, by Dorie Greenspan (Houghton Mifflin, 2006)

title: Ethiopia Holding 41 Suspects Who Fought With Somali Islamists, Officials Confirm
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 10  Ethiopian officials acknowledged Tuesday for the first time that they had detained 41 terrorism suspects from 17 countries who had been fighting for Somalias Islamist movement.

title: Taking Back a Childhood Favorite
description: OF all the reasons to visit my friends with small children, grilled cheese sandwiches may be the best.

title: Recipe: Queso Fresco Quesadillas With Papaya-Avocado Salsa
description: FOR THE SALSA:

title: Recipe: Country Pt
description: 2 pounds pork shoulder, with some fat, cut into chunks

title: Top Players Help Nets Bottom Line
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  The Nets are far from cleansing themselves of the bad habits that have caused them to be such an unstable team this season.

title: Turkey: Hijacking Ends Peacefully
description: A man hijacked a domestic airliner en route to Istanbul but surrendered to the authorities shortly after the plane made an emergency landing in Ankara, its 178 passengers unhurt, the authorities said. The man, identified by the Anatolian news agency as Mehmet Goksin, a Turk, boarded the plane with the rest of the passengers in southeastern Diyarbakir. Government forces are fighting Kurdish separatists in the area, and the hijacker was initially suspected of political motives. But he made no clear political demands, after falsely claiming that he was wearing explosives, the authorities said. The arrested man has a criminal record and a troubled family background, they said.

title: Imus Struggling to Retain Sway as a Franchise
description: That Don Imus can be abrasive and offensive is undeniable, but he is also one of the most successful and influential pitchmen in the history of radio, if not broadcasting.

title: China Attacks U.S. Action on Trade
description: HONG KONG, April 10  The Chinese government expressed deep regret and strong dissatisfaction today with the Bush administrations decision to file two complaints against China with the World Trade Organization, while separately releasing statistics showing that Chinese exports grew last month at the slowest pace in five years.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on April 3 about problems faced by Michelle Bachelet, Chiles first female president, referred incorrectly to the political affiliation of her predecessor, Ricardo Lagos Escobar. While both belong to the same coalition, they are not now of the same party. (Ms. Bachelet is a Socialist; Mr. Lagos is a former Socialist who founded the Party for Democracy, or PPD.)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about the housing slumps effect on state tax revenues misstated the status of a tax credit and local tax cap in New Jersey in some copies. The legislation has been signed into law, it is not awaiting approval.

title: New York City Water Rates Expected to Rise 11.5 Percent
description: New York City officials plan to raise rates 11.5 percent on the water that every New Yorker uses, the largest annual increase in 15 years.

title: Recipe: New Classic Brownies
description: Adapted from Alice Medrichs Cookies and Brownies (Warner Books, 1999)

title: The Teacher Ate My Homework
description: BROOKE ARCE has never eaten at Le Bernardin. She has not even heard of it, even though she could walk there from her high school in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Anaheim Has Gone From Warm and Fuzzy to Fiery and Nasty
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 9  The Anaheim Ducks used to have an animated Tinkerbell that fluttered across the scoreboard and sprinkled pixie dust onto pictures of players heads.

title: Minding the Store in a Condo
description: Patrick Cooney stops in frequently at the Museum of Modern Art store on the corner of Spring and Crosby Streets in Manhattan. Before Christmas, he loaded up on T-shirts and toys for the family. MoMA is a part of New York, he said.

title: A Lost Boris Godunov Is Found and Staged
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 8  In 1936, two of the Soviet Unions greatest artists decided to work on a new theatrical production of Pushkins Boris Godunov for its authors coming jubilee. Sergei Prokofiev wrote 24 musical pieces while the visionary stage director Vsevolod Meyerhold mapped out scenes and started rehearsals. The following year, Stalins terror fixed its gaze on Meyerhold and he abandoned the project. Three years later, he was dead, shot by a firing squad.

title: A Word of Advice During a Housing Slump: Rent
description: A promotional spot for the National Association of Realtors came on the radio the other day. The spot, introduced as something called Newsmakers, was supposed to sound like a news report, with the associations president offering real estate advice.

title: Euro Rises on Signs of Faster European Growth
description: The euro advanced to a record against the yen and a two-year high against the dollar yesterday as signs of faster economic growth in Europe prompted traders to increase their bets on higher interest rates.

title: Where on the Web Is Matt Lauer?
description: SINCE 1998, NBC has been sending a Today host to far-flung locales like Angkor Wat, Easter Island and Machu Picchu, all for a feature on the show called Where in the World Is Matt Lauer? This week, to help promote the next installment, Mr. Lauer is taking his most ambitious foray so far into cyberspace.

title: U.S. Sends (Another) Warning on Darfur
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  While the Bush administration is dispatching another top envoy  this time Deputy Secretary of State John D. Negroponte  to deliver another strong message to the Sudanese government about the killing in the Darfur region, critics say the diplomacy is allowing Sudan to play for time as the death toll mounts.

title: Sallie Mae Agrees to Student Loan Settlement
description: Sallie Mae, the nations largest lender to college students, has agreed to pay $2 million into a fund to educate high school students and their parents about student loan options, in order to resolve an investigation into its relationships with colleges and universities.

title: Mets Milledge May Go to Minors to Get More At-Bats
description: Manager Willie Randolph had a decision to make in the eighth inning of the Mets 11-5 victory against Philadelphia on Monday afternoon: With Moises Alou on second and Shawn Green at first representing the go-ahead run, Randolph wanted to replace one of them with Endy Chvez, a faster runner and a superior defender. But which one?

title: Islamists Bring Fight to Capital of Algeria
description: PARIS, April 11  Two bombings in Algeria, one targeting the prime ministers office in the countrys capital, killed at least 23 people today, marking a sharp escalation in the Qaeda-linked violence that has been spreading across North Africa in recent months.

title: English as Language of Global Education
description: PARIS, April 7  When economics students returned this winter to the elite cole Normale Suprieure here, copies of a simple one-page petition were posted in the corridors demanding an unlikely privilege: French as a teaching language.

title: China Conveys Regret Over Trade Complaints
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, April 11  The Chinese government expressed deep regret and strong dissatisfaction on Tuesday with the Bush administrations decision to file two complaints against China with the World Trade Organization.

title: Letter From California: A Late-Night Seminar on Lewis Thomas
description: Last week I read with my students an essay by Lewis Thomas called On Medicine and the Bomb, which was first published in 1981. It has been a long time since I taught it  probably 20 years  and a lot has changed since Thomas wrote it, including the structure of global politics and most of the numbers he uses.

title: Good Miso: Its All About the Journey
description: Conway, Mass.

title: Frances Unfocused Candidates Vie for Undecided Voters
description: PARIS, April 10  Nicolas Sarkozy, the conservative candidate for president, suggests that pedophilia is most likely a genetic flaw; Sgolne Royal, the Socialist, does not seem to know that Taliban extremists are no longer running the government of Afghanistan; and Jean-Marie Le Pen, the ultrarightist, recommends masturbation instead of free condoms to meet young peoples sexual needs.

title: Don Imus, Suspended, Still Talking
description: Don Imus was suspended. But it looked as though NBC had suspended the suspension. This scandal-harried radio host and MSNBC star was free to appear on Today yesterday and explain himself again and again: His interview with Matt Lauer and his debate with the Rev. Al Sharpton, their second, were shown simultaneously on the MSNBC show Imus in the Morning.

title: A New Fractional: Owning a Piece of a Yacht
description: An eighth of a yacht is better than none. Or so reasons Han Verstraete, chief executive of YachtPlus.

title: The Perfect Bacon Sandwich Decoded: Crisp and Crunchy
description: LONDON, April 10  Should it be slithery or scrunchy, glutinous or grilled? The answer, British scientists say, may be divined by a formula: N = C + {fb(cm)  fb(tc)} + fb(Ts) + fc  ta.

title: Profits Soar at Alcoa on Strong Demand and Higher Prices
description: The aluminum company Alcoa reported its most profitable first quarter ever yesterday as rising metal demand from China and the aerospace industry bolstered prices.

title: Shock Wave: Don Imus, Unplugged (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Some in G.O.P. Express Worry Over 08 Hopes
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  Republican leaders across the country say they are growing increasingly anxious about their partys chances of holding the White House, citing public dissatisfaction with President Bush, the political fallout from the war in Iraq and the problems their leading presidential candidates are having generating enthusiasm among conservative voters.

title: Democrats Invite Bush to Capitol to Discuss War Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Having been lectured by President Bush over the war spending legislation and invited to the White House for one-way discussions, Senate Democrats countered today by inviting the president to come to the Capitol instead.

title: Panel Said to Alter Finding on Voter Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  A federal panel responsible for conducting election research played down the findings of experts who concluded last year that there was little voter fraud around the nation, according to a review of the original report obtained by The New York Times.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Saturday about Ralph J. Phillips, who is serving a life sentence for having shot three New York State troopers, one fatally, after breaking out of jail, misstated the name of the prison where he is incarcerated. It is the Clinton Correctional Facility, a state prison in Dannemora  not the Clinton County Correctional Facility.

title: Pentagon Orders Longer Tours for Soldiers in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  All active-duty Army troops now in Iraq or Afghanistan or headed to either country will serve 15-month tours of duty, up from the usual 12-month tours, effective immediately, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Israel Says Hamas Was Plotting Terrorist Attacks
description: JERUSALEM, April 10  Recent interrogations of arrested members of Hamas in the West Bank town of Qalqilya produced information that the Islamic organization there was planning imminent terrorist attacks against Israel, including one using a large truck bomb, the Israeli Shin Bet internal security service said Tuesday.

title: Jailed Adviser Is Sentenced and Fined in Fraud Case
description: Martin A. Armstrong, the financial adviser who has spent seven years in jail on a contempt-of-court charge, was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison for running what prosecutors said was a $3 billion Ponzi scheme.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article last Wednesday about the prospect of adding a statue of Mark McGwire to those honoring great St. Louis Cardinals players gave an incorrect given name in some copies for a catcher for the old St. Louis Browns whom the creator of the statues, Harry Weber, considered a baseball hero. He was Clint Courtney, not Cliff.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The headline with an article yesterday about the possible deployment of 13,000 troops from four states misidentified the soldiers. They are National Guard members, not reservists.

title: Dryers Hot, Pass the Pomade and Pray for a Good Hair Day
description: We seem far enough along now in the subgenre of reality television devoted to competitive style and re-imaging that a show about hairdressers facing off to produce up-dos that look like bowls of pad Thai seems vaguely quaint and well intentioned, as if it were 1995 all over again.

title: Panel Backs Controllers
description: Air-traffic controllers need schedule changes to ensure they get enough rest, a safety board said, noting that one worker may have had only two hours of sleep in the day before a 2006 crash in Lexington, Ky., that killed 49 people. The recommendation from the National Transportation Safety Board to the Federal Aviation Administration is a victory for controllers, who have said for months that they are short staffed and forced to work too-long hours, harming safety.

title: Full Federal Appellate Court Will Revisit Abortion Issue in South Dakota
description: A South Dakota law that would require doctors to tell women seeking abortions that the procedure would terminate the life of a whole, separate, unique, living human being will be revisited today by the 11 judges of the federal appeals court in St. Louis.

title: Look Out, Below! Intrepid Plots a Course High and Dry
description: The aircraft carrier Intrepid came close yesterday to displaying more of its normally submerged bottom than had been glimpsed in a generation. But for the full picture, observers will have to wait a little longer.

title: Western Water Shortage (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: An Artists Underground Flowering
description: Its gratifying when an influential underground artist is profiled in an accessible, entertaining documentary. For that reason alone, Mary Jordans film Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis, whose subject is an antiestablishment director, is worth seeing  even though Ms. Jordan dices Mr. Smiths films into snippets that dont convey their languorous rhythms, and seems content to mythologize rather than dissect.

title: Recipe: Salami and Horseradish Cheddar Bagel Sandwich
description: 2 bagels, halved

title: Purveyor to the Queen Faces Test From Wal-Mart
description: OTTAWA, April 9  When Queen Elizabeth needs groceries, her staff usually sends out to Fortnum & Mason. Household goods at Buckingham Palace often come from the Selfridges department store. And the tea poured at royal tea parties is likely to have been blended by R. Twining & Company.

title: 4 Serbs Guilty in Execution of 6 Bosnians
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, April 10  A Serbian war-crimes court on Tuesday convicted four former paramilitary officers in the July 1995 killings of six Bosnian Muslims from Srebrenica, where thousands of Muslims were killed the same week.

title: Inhale, Then Listen Up: Heres a Pungent Cheese With a Complicated Past
description: Le Sousbois is a rare artisanal cheese from Switzerland with a story to tell. Robert and Anne Henchoz from Rossinire, in the Vaud region of southwestern Switzerland, make about 2,000 of these cows milk cheeses each month. The cheeses have a grassy aroma and come in thick disks about 3  inches in diameter. Beneath the cross-hatched ivory rind is a satiny, mildly pungent, spoonable interior. A band of spruce bark is wrapped around it.

title: Recipe: Baked Oysters With Apples
description: Adapted from Fish, by Sophie Grigson and William Black (Headline, 1998)

title: Recipe: Comt Grilled Cheese With Cornichon Spread
description: 2 tablespoons whole grain mustard

title: N.H.L. Playoff Wish: Beautiful Goals and Creative Play
description: If the Stanley Cup playoffs are anything like the just concluded regular season, hockey fans are in for a treat. Despite some persistent problems  an epidemic of head injuries from legal but malicious checks, a pro-fighting backlash against new rules designed to reduce violence and lagging attendance in several cities  the hallmark of the 2006-7 season has been an abundance of beautiful, creative goal-scoring.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Stars Align for Live Earth at Giants Stadium

title: White House Mulling War Czar, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The White House is exploring ways to restructure the National Security Council, including the possible appointment of an official who would oversee the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, The Washington Post reported in its Wednesday issue.

title: Ever-Changing Fame, as Fluid as It Is Fleeting
description: When Larry Birkhead came out of a courthouse in the Bahamas yesterday, raised his arms and jubilantly said to the television cameras, I told you so!, he completed a strange transformation. Less than a year ago, before he became a chew toy for celebrity journalists, he was an unknown freelance photographer and former boyfriend of Anna Nicole Smith, not an image with wholesome written all over it. But during the months of legal wrangling to prove that he is the father of Ms. Smiths baby daughter, Dannielynn, Mr. Birkhead exuded clean-cut sincerity, emerging as a sentimental favorite over rival Howard K. Stern, Ms. Smiths companion and business adviser.

title: Buildings Called Key Source of Citys Greenhouse Gases
description: Laying the groundwork for a plan to reduce the production of greenhouse gases in the city, the Bloomberg administration released a study yesterday showing that New Yorks roughly 950,000 buildings are responsible for a vast majority of the citys carbon dioxide emissions.

title: The Bar Makes a Difference
description: UNSWEETENED chocolate for baking and cooking no longer needs to be dull-looking, gritty and inedibly bitter. Like bittersweet and semisweet chocolate, high-quality unsweetened chocolate is now widely available. It has a glossy sheen, a silky texture, a rich fragrance and a complex flavor. All this makes a big difference in the result.

title: Newark Boys School Teacher Is Accused of Sexual Relationship With Student
description: NEWARK, April 10  An English teacher at the prestigious Newark Boys Chorus School has been arrested on charges that she had a sexual relationship with one of her 13-year-old students.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 11 P.M. (Bravo) SHEAR GENIUS Twelve hairstylists snip and clip their way to a $100,000 prize from the hair products company Nexxus and a chance to show off their technique in Allure magazine in the latest of Bravos design-based competition series. The berstylist Sally Hershberger, above, who created the Meg Ryan cut and spawned its multitude of imitators, is lead judge with Michael Carl, fashion director of Allure, and Jaclyn Smith, pulling double duty as the shows host. The stylist Ren Fris, channeling Tim Gunn  la Project Runway, acts as the salon manager for the contestants  some of whom will either be cut, in the words of the panel, or told they blow away the competition.

title: Three Plays Portray a Couple Bound by Love and Conflict
description: The first of the exquisitely quiet, gently reaching plays in Arlene Huttons Nibroc Trilogy, in repertory at the 78th Street Theater Lab, begins with a young woman reading on a train bound from the West Coast at the end of 1940. It is a crowded train, spatially and psychically. The freight cars are carrying the bodies of F. Scott Fitzgerald and Nathanael West, who died within a day of each other, West in a car accident said to have been brought on by the wrecked condition in which his friend Fitzgeralds death had left him.

title: Daddies in a Panic, and Mommy, Too
description: Washington

title: Take-Twos Mr. Fix-It Inherits a Handful
description: The closest Strauss Zelnick usually gets to playing video games is watching over the shoulders of his two young sons. Mr. Zelnick concedes that his gaming skills are better suited for Pong and Pac-Man than Grand Theft Auto, the smash hit from the company that he is now in charge of turning around.

title: Letters
description: Squirrels for Supper

title: Wine Calendar
description: Cocktail Classics to Taste

title: Retaining Wall at Ground Zero Will Get Its Own Wall
description: A section of the legendary slurry wall at ground zero  the sturdy concrete bathtub that kept the waters of the Hudson River from inundating the World Trade Center site before and after the twin towers collapsed on Sept. 11, 2001  will be getting its own $10 million bathtub.

title: Knicks Become Infuriated as Bulls Pour On the Points
description: CHICAGO, April 10  Just about every negative emotion washed over the Knicks on Tuesday night. It started with frustration, which quickly gave way to humiliation and finally rage.

title: Imperial Nights in Tunisia, With Mythology Underfoot
description: LOS ANGELES  Athena, the Greek goddess of wisdom, sits gazing languorously at herself in the river after a musical solo on an aulos, an ancient double-reed pipe. The river itself is symbolized by an elderly yet muscular man sitting across from her.

title: Elizabeth Jolley, Australian Gothic Writer, Dies at 83
description: Elizabeth Jolley, an Australian writer who came to wide public attention only late in life, but whose distinctive literary voice and eccentric literary preoccupations eventually made her one of her countrys most acclaimed novelists, died in Perth on Feb. 13. She was 83.

title: Romania, a Poor Land, Imports Poorer Workers
description: BACAU, Romania  To get around the chronic labor shortages hampering this traditional textile center and in other industries across Romania, Sorin Nicolescu, who runs a clothing factory, came up with an original solution: import 800 workers from China.

title: Writers Guild President Starts the Countdown Toward Contracts End
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10  As his wedding neared, some 19 years ago, Patric Verrone, now president of the Writers Guild of America West, joined his bride-to-be in a ritual common to show business types. The couple formed a company, one with a clever name: Calloo Callay.

title: Taliban Release Body of Journalist Seized in Afghanistan Last Month
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, April 10  The body of an Afghan journalist abducted and slain by Taliban insurgents after they freed his Italian colleague in a prisoner trade was delivered Tuesday to Kandahars hospital. The physician on duty confirmed the identification and said the cause of death was a slit throat.

title: Macao Set to Resolve North Korea Snag, U.S. Says
description: BEIJING, April 10  The government in Macao is prepared to release funds linked to North Korea that have been frozen in a local bank, the Treasury Department said Tuesday, as negotiations continued in order to meet the Norths demand that the money be returned before it begins nuclear disarmament.

title: A Mosque Raid Sets Off Sunnis in Iraqs Capital
description: BAGHDAD, April 10  Sunni militants and residents of the Baghdad neighborhood of Fadhil fought a fierce daylong battle with the Iraqi Army and American soldiers on Tuesday in what appeared to be the most sustained confrontation since the start of the security plan to calm violence in the capital.

title: Nigerias Imperiled Elections
description: President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria likes to present himself as the man who led his country toward democracy. But his reputation  and that of his country  will be deeply marred unless he moves quickly to rein in the chaos and corruption threatening this months elections.

title: Curry Trade Continues to Pay Dividends for Bulls
description: CHICAGO, April 10  Homecoming has become an emotionally complicated affair for Eddy Curry. The United Center has turned hostile. Fans root nearly as hard for Currys Knicks to fail as they do for the Chicago Bulls to succeed.

title: Homework
description: Homework

title: Chinese Prime Minister Visits Japan
description: TOKYO, April 11  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China began a three-day visit to Japan today, in what China and Japan described as an important step forward in repairing diplomatic ties between the two East Asian rivals.

title: DiPietro Starts Workouts, but Dubielewicz Will Start
description: SYOSSET, N.Y., April 10  Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro practiced Tuesday, but not with the team. He was signing autographs when his teammates took the ice to prepare for their first-round playoff series against the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Meatloaf Made Meatier
description: IF you can make meatloaf you can make what the French call pt de campagne, or country pt. It is simply a variation of meatloaf, a splendid one. It is denser, with more meat, and has no filler like bread crumbs. The addition of cream and spices makes it delicious and elegant enough to serve at dinners where you want to impress your guests. Meatloaf cant do that.

title: House Subpoenas More U.S. Attorney Files
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  House Democrats on Tuesday subpoenaed more documents from the Justice Department, ratcheting up efforts to obtain unedited copies of hundreds of documents pertaining to personnel matters surrounding last years dismissals of eight United States attorneys.

title: ImClones Drug Fails in Pancreatic Cancer Study
description: ImClone Systems said yesterday that its cancer drug Erbitux failed to help pancreatic cancer patients live longer in a study, a setback for the companys plan to expand the market for its only product.

title: School Records on Special English Classes Are Called Works of Fiction by Critics
description: Under ordinary circumstances, few documents in a New York City high school serve as prosaic a purpose as the so-called bubble sheet. In homeroom and then in each class a teacher uses that sheet, a roster of names, to mark attendance, indicating whether students are present or absent by filling in the appropriate little circular bubble.

title: Where the Motto Is: Try, Try Again
description: AT some point I began to brace for a hailstorm, and to wonder if the locusts would sweep in after that. The E.U. was plagued, on a scale that was almost biblical.

title: 2 Charged in Texas State School Abuse Case
description: HOUSTON, April 10  A former assistant superintendent and a former principal at a Texas state school for juvenile offenders were arrested Tuesday on charges of deviate sexual intercourse and other sexual contact with six boys ages 16 to 19.

title: Bush on the Border
description: President Bush went to the Mexico border in Arizona on Monday and showed once again that immigration is an issue he understands. He said America suffers from a system that exploits people who come to do jobs that citizens wont do. He said the country needed a practical answer that promotes an orderly flow of legal immigrants, eases pressure at the border and opens a path to citizenship for the hidden 12 million who keep our economy humming. And he urged Congress to find that answer through a serious and civil and conclusive debate.

title: Seas Rise in India Buries Islands and a Way of Life
description: GHORAMARA ISLAND, India  Shyamal Mandal lives at the edge of ruin.

title: Algerian Temptations, Speaking a Little French
description: I LIKE cookies. You probably like cookies. Cookies are likable.

title: Recipe: Pea Soup With Oysters and Pernod
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: No Cutting in Line for Puget Sound Ferries, Under Penalty of Law
description: MUKILTEO, Wash., April 6  Riding a ferry across Puget Sound amid evergreen islands and majestic mountain peaks might seem a pretty smooth way to commute. But first you have to get on the ferry.

title: The Flute Is Awfully Nice, Tamino, but Check Out That Astral Sketchbook
description: William Kentridge, who conceived and directed the visiting production of The Magic Flute at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Monday night, is a black-and-white man. His flat scenery is not so much painted as rubbed and scratched by charcoal on white paper. Not surprisingly Mr. Kentridge is interested, if not obsessed, by early motion pictures and their first attempts at animation.

title: Tougher N.F.L. Suspends Two Players for Conduct
description: Saying the integrity of the National Football League had to be protected, Commissioner Roger Goodell yesterday suspended Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones without pay for the 2007 season and Cincinnati Bengals receiver Chris Henry for the first eight games for repeated off-the-field conduct problems.

title: Simple Pleasure, American Style
description: CHOCOLATE has developed a peculiar aftertaste.

title: Personal Shopper
description: A place apart, for children, guests or novelists.

title: Currents
description: In Pasadena, Calif., a look at forward-looking houses, two powerful vacuums that go easy on closet space and more.

title: The Clubhouse in the Sky
description: Adult clubhouses have grown in popularity.

title: Other Metro Areas
description: To find data on metropolitan areas across the country, you can go to our online buy-vs.-rent calculator. Along the left side of the page, near the top, you should see the words "Monthly rent." Next to these words is a button with a question mark on it. Click that button, and you will be able to choose from a menu of metro areas.

title: When You Get in a Scrape With Nature
description: Jon Tierney, critical care paramedic, tests first-aid kits.

title: Bagel Chain to Seek Nasdaq Listing
description: The Einstein Noah Restaurant Group, a chain of bagel stores controlled by a hedge fund, Greenlight Capital, filed Tuesday to sell as much as $125 million in stock in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq. The company, whose stock now trades on the Pink Sheets, said it owns or franchises about 600 locations in the United States under the names Einstein Bros. Bagels, Noahs New York Bagels and Manhattan Bagel. Morgan Stanley and Cowen are joint bookrunning managers for the offering.

title: Morgan Stanley Shareholders Vote Against Executive-Pay Resolution
description: A resolution that aimed to give Morgan Stanley shareholders a greater say in how top executives are paid failed to win a majority of votes cast at the firms annual meeting Tuesday. The defeat  only 37 percent voted in favor of the motion  represents a setback for activist investors who are seeking to gain a greater say in how executives are paid at dozens of companies.

title: Defense Asserts Blacks Use of Hollinger Jet Was Encouraged by Board
description: The media magnate Conrad M. Black was urged by his company to use a corporate jet to travel to the Pacific island of Bora Bora on vacation because of safety concerns and did not represent an illegal siphoning off of claims, his lawyers suggested on Tuesday. A defense lawyer, Edward L. Greenspan, brushed aside the prosecutions claim, saying the audit committee of the board of Mr. Blacks Hollinger International media empire urged executives to take the companys Gulfstream 4 jet as a security measure because of the nature of the business this company was in.

title: Tech Deals Start Strong in 2007
description: Lifted by 20 transactions worth more than $1 billion in the first quarter, technology deal-making started strong in 2007, with buyout shops and infrastructure-software transactions both major drivers. The analyst firm The 451 Group looks at whether deal-makers can keep up the pace.

title: Fine Points: It's '80s in the Shades
description: Sunglasses in any color, so long as it's white.

title: Will Activist Investors Flex Their Muscles in Puma Deal?
description: Activist investors in Europe have been increasingly flexing their muscles to block unwanted deals and encourage break-ups of under-performing companies. And now that French luxury group PPR has tabled a friendly $7 billion bid for the German sportswear outfit Puma, industry watchers are wondering if another battle royale is in the offing.

title: Closing Arguments Begin in Trial of Ex-Qwest Chief
description: A federal prosecutor, Colleen Conry, portrayed Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest International, on Tuesday as a man who knowingly and unlawfully concealed Qwests growing money troubles, while simultaneously cashing in on his stock options.

title: Take-Twos Mr. Fix-It Inherits a Handful
description: Strauss Zelnick, Take-Two Interactive Softwares new chairman, has taken on risky corporate overhauls in the past, but none have been as complex as the turnaround of Take-Two, which he called the biggest thing weve done.

title: Friedman Billings to Hive Off Capital Markets Unit in I.P.O.
description: Investment banking firm Friedman Billings Ramsey Group plans to raise as much as $243.3 million through an initial public offering of its capital markets subsidiary. The bank will sell up to 13.5 million shares of its FBR Capital Markets unit at a price of $16 to $18 each, the bank said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Citi to Cut 17,000 Jobs in Broad Overhaul
description: Citigroup announced Wednesday that it would eliminate or reassign more than 26,500 jobs as part of a sweeping overhaul to cut costs and streamline the global banks sprawling operations.

title: The TXU Deal That Didnt Happen
description: Sharyland Utilities says it considered bidding for a piece of TXU, which recently agreed to a record buyout offer from a consortium of private equity firms, but ultimately decided against making a bid after TXU threatened litigation.

title: ABN-Barclays Deal May Bring $100 Million in Fees
description: Advisers to Barclays and ABN Amro could share about $100 million in fees for their work on what would be the biggest financial-services merger in history, based on comparable fees from previous deals, Bloomberg News reported. While hardly a small sum, the amount would be one-third less than what advisers charged last year for AT&Ts purchase of BellSouth, underscoring how financial-services deals tend to bring relatively lower fees than transactions in other industries.

title: Magna and Onex Team Up for Chrysler Bid, Report Says
description: Magna International, the Canadian auto parts supplier has teamed up with a Canadian private equity firm, Onex, to make a run at DaimlerChryslers Chrysler Group, according to The Globe and Mail. The idea behind the bid for Chrysler is that Magna would bring its expertise to operating auto factories, while Onex would use its financial finesse to run Chryslers credit arm, the report said.

title: The Newest Investment Bank: K.K.R.
description: With each passing day, big private equity firms are looking more and more like Wall Street investment banks, says BusinessWeek, noting that the Blackstone Group is advising on corporate deals and bankruptcy restructurings and that Bain Capital is a major middle-market lender.

title: Bronfmann Sues Vivendi Over Pension Payments
description: Vivendis former vice chairman Edgar Bronfman Jr. sued the company Tuesday, alleging it improperly cut his pension payments by 65 percent. In a lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Bronfman, now chief executive of the Warner Music Group, contends that Vivendi, the French entertainment group, reduced his pension last year after claiming it had erroneously been crediting him for 15 years of service beyond the 20 years of actual service Bronfman had already accrued.

title: Nasdaq May Buy Philly Exchange, Report Says
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market is in talks to buy the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to gain a stake in the fast-growing options business, according to The Wall Street Journal. The report said Nasdaq has been discussing a link with the regional exchange for months, but a deal is not expected to be reached any time soon.

title: Unibail Offers $15 Billion for Dutch Rival
description: A real estate company, Unibail Holding, said it had offered $15 billion in stock for a Dutch rival, Rodamco Europe, and that the board and a key shareholder of Rodamco had endorsed the deal. The companies estimated their combined real estate portfolios, focused primarily on European shopping malls, would have been worth 21.7 billion euros ($29 billion) in 2006 with rental income of 974 million euros.

title: Biosite Board to Sit Down With Second Suitor
description: Biosite, the target of a billion-dollar biotech bidding war, said Tuesday it would sit down with a second suitor to discuss a hostile takeover bid priced at $90 a share, which is about $3 below its current share price.

title: WiMax Start-Up Picks Up $50 Million from V.C.s
description: A WiMax equipment startup, Telsima, announced a new $50 million Series D round of venture funding that will bankroll the companys expansion plans in India and Eastern Europe. Telsima, which makes WiMax-based broadband wireless access technology, received the money from its initial investor syndicate, which includes NewPath Ventures, New Enterprise Associates, CMEA Ventures, and Intel Capital.

title: K.K.R. Faces Rivals in Bid for Alliance Boots
description: A private equity firm in London, Terra Firma Capital Partners and a biomedical research foundation, Wellcome Trust have confirmed that they are interested in bidding for Alliance Boots, the drugstore chain and pharmaceuticals wholesaler, a development that could lead to a bidding war with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: New Century Loans May Pose Double Whammy for Wall Street
description: The bankruptcy filing of New Century Financial left several investment banks with hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars in claims. But what is the real risk for the Wall Street firms that extended credit to the subprime lender?

title: Should Goldman Crack Open the Black Box?
description: Goldman Sachs manages $147 billion in alternative assets, making the securities firm a behemoth in the hedge-fund business. So why, asks Thorold Barker of The Financial Times, doesnt Goldman enjoy the same heady market valuation as Fortress Investment Group, which recently went public? Part of the problem, he suggests, is the black box factor: Goldman simply doesnt tell investors and analysts much about its hedge fund operations. If the firm wants more credit for its hedge fund prowess, it might want to consider pulling back the veil a bit.

title: CVC Is Said to Bring Goldman onto Sainsbury Bid
description: CVC, the private equity firm attempting to mount a bid for J Sainsbury, has enlisted the backing of the private equity division of Goldman Sachs in a last-ditch attempt to rescue its fast-collapsing proposed deal for the British supermarket chain, according to The Telegraph.

title: Hedge Funds Take Stock in Big Bankruptcies
description: Cerberus Capital Management, the Fortress Investment Group and D.E. Shaw are among the hedge funds who have been buying shares in bankrupt companies in an attempt to influence the restructuring or force acquisitions, according to Financial News. Shareholders typically have little say in bankruptcy proceedings, but funds with equity stakes have been taking active roles in cases involving Calpine, Northwest Airlines and Delphi, among others.

title: ABN Amro Clears More Legal Hurdles to Barclays Deal
description: Barclays Banks 80 billion pound ($158 billion) merger with ABN Amro took another step forward as ABN rushed to settle legal action over money transfers and the government regulator in The Netherlands said that, in principle, it did not object to takeovers by foreign banks. The Telegraph reported that ABN is attempting to reach an agreement with the United States Department of Justice over certain deficiencies in its anti-money-laundering systems.

title: Who Needs Retro When Youve Got Classics?
description: Last weekend, visitors to the New York auto show had a great opportunity to check out some old cars along with the new models.

title: Vision Raises $55 Million for Hedge-Fund Incubator
description: Vision Investment Management, a manager of an Aisan fund that invests in various hedge funds, has raised about $55 million for a new vehicle that will seed and incubate hedge fund start-ups, Reuters reported. The firms Vision Angel Fund is likely to invest with its first two managers within 30 to 45 days, Julius Wang, a managing director with the Hong Kong-based firm, told the wire service. He said that the investment target size will be between $100 million to $150 million.

title: Obama Makes His Pitch to Wall Streets Money Men
description: Democratic presidential hopeful Barack Obama apparently spent Monday rubbing shoulders with some of New Yorks financiers at a round of fund-raising events in Manhattan. Less than a week after the Obama team announced that he had all but matched Hillary Clintons first-quarter fund-raising totals of $26 million, Mr. Obama was back at it, answering questions at the home of a retired investment banker, Steven Gluckstern, an event that The New York Observer says was co-hosted by a money manager, Whitney Tilson, and an investment banker, Bob Ennis.

title: Financial Firms Help Office Rents Hit New High
description: Financial services firms helped office rents in Manhattan reach record highs in the first three months of 2007, the real estate brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield said Tuesday. Financial services accounted for 35.7 percent of leasing during the quarter, as rents in Midtown reached a record average $70.77 a square foot, with some surpassing $150 a square foot, Cushman & Wakefield said.

title: Can Trump Casinos Keep Up With the Neighbors?
description: Speculation over the fate of the three Trump Entertainment casinos in Atlantic City has heightened since mid-March, when the company disclosed that it had hired Merrill Lynch to explore all our options, as Donald Trump, who owns 30 percent of the holding company, put it. That includes the possibility that the company might sell all three properties  or perhaps dispose of a single hotel to raise the capital to improve the other two.

title: Retail M&A Boom Has Run Its Course, Paper Says
description: The boom in mergers and acquisitions that made retailers and apparel makers prized targets and resulted in ownership changes for marquee names such as Neiman Marcus, May Department Stores and Toys R Us, is finally cooling, The New York Post said Wednesday. In year-to-date figures, retail and apparel companies accounted for just 2.9 percent of overall mergers and acquisitions activity compared with a recent high of 8 percent for the same period in 2005, the paper said, citing data from Thomson Financial.

title: Clear Channel Bidders Huddle Ahead of Vote
description: The private-equity firms fighting to save their $27 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications are weighing their options ahead of a crucial vote on the deal next week, the New York Post reported citing unnamed sources. Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital  which struck a deal last year to buy Clear Channel for $37.60 a share  held serious discussions over the past week on whether to increase their offer for the radio giant in order to appease a group of cantankerous shareholders demanding a sweeter deal.

title: U.S. Investor Is Said to Plan Bid for Gold Fields
description: Update: It appears someone pulled a fast one on Bloomberg News  and us. Click here for details.

title: Blowout in Beverly Hills
description: Candy & Candy, the high-end London developers who are expected to produce record sales when One Hyde Park is completed in Knightsbridge, are taking their bespoke style to Beverly Hills.

title: In Defense of Imus
description: The New York Times editorial page has condemned Don Imus for his disgraceful behavior, and Gwen Ifill wrote on the op-ed page that the sincerity of Imuss apology seems forced and suspect because hes done some version of this several times before. But there are some Imus defenders out there.

title: Manor Care Hires Financial Adviser
description: Manor Care, a nursing-home operator, said Wednesday it had hired J.P. Morgan Chase to help it explore a full range of opportunities to add shareholder value. The company did not give any specifics about the alternatives under review but said in a news release that it was well-positioned to consider taking advantage of currently attractive conditions in the financial markets. Manor Cares stock surged after the announcement, rising 11 percent in early trading Wednesday to $61.65, a 52-week high. At that price, the company has a market capitalization of about $4.5 billion.

title: 2008: G.O.P. on Defense
description: With Senator John McCain trying to revive his flagging campaign with a major policy speech on the war in Iraq today, The Timess Adam Nagourney and John Broder examine concerns among top G.O.P. officials that the war and other matters are hurting their chances to retain the White House.

title: On the Record: The Dems and Health Care
description: On Monday, Adam Nagourney kicked off The Timess new online political columns that examine the candidates, the campaigns and the issues, with a look at  early polling in the 2008 presidential campaign and the risks the candidates court when they rely on those numbers.

title: Bombings in Algeria
description: Two bombings in Algeria, one targeting the prime ministers office in the countrys capital, killed at least 17 people.

title: Meeting Greg
description: We took the scenic route from Savannah on our way north to Beaufort, bypassing Route 95 for the undivided Okatie Highway (on most of the route, highway was merely aspirational).

title: TV for a Me First Society
description: The soon-to-conclude not-TV-its-HBO series The Sopranos is the most cynical television drama in history, suggests Matt Zoller Seitz in The Star-Ledger. The show is a worst-case scenario look at human nature in which the inhabitants of an insular, paranoid, highly materialistic subculture are confronted with the choice between doing the right thing and the convenient thing, and nearly always go with option B. He adds:

title: The Politics Before the Layoffs
description: Item 1 The Bloomberg administration, fighting Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposal to close some business tax loopholes  or to raise business taxes, depending on your perspective  warns that the proposals would harm companies like Citigroup. Mark Page, the mayors budget director, tells the City Council  in March that Citigroup told the city that the governors proposal would cost it $60 million more in taxes each year.If its more expensive to be located here, thats obviously a major incentive to be less located here, Mr. Page said.

title: The War at Home: McCains Speech
description: The campaign of Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona and presidential contender, released the advance text of his remarks given at the Virginia Military Institute.

title: Update: Citi Shares Fall After Revamp Is Announced
description: Shares of Citigroup declined more than 1 percent Wednesday after the company gave details about its long-awaited plan to cut costs. Citis stock  which has made only modest gains in the past three years, frustrating many investors  had been rising in recent days in anticipation of the announcement, which followed a companywide review led by Citis chief operating officer, Robert Druskin. Analysts said the plan, which includes 17,000 job cuts and 9,500 job reassignments or relocations, was generally in line with what Wall Street had expected.

title: Reader Responses
description: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardt's April 11 column on the relative merits of buying and renting a home:

title: Going Medieval
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: CVC Calls Off Sainsbury Offer
description: The bidding for J Sainsbury came to an end on Wednesday, as CVC Capital Partners called off the 10 billion pound ($19.7 billion) bid for the British grocer after failing to meet the founding familys desired price. Though CVC offered the board 582 pence a share, the family, which holds about 18 percent of the retailer, wanted at least 600 pence a share.

title: Vonages Dubious Honor: Worst I.P.O. of 2006
description: We hate to pile on a company when its down, but we couldnt resist running some numbers on Vonage Holdings, the upstart Internet-based phone company whose initial public offering last year has gone from bad to worse to apocalyptically awful. With the latest downtick in Vonages stock, coming after a federal judge ordered it to stop using technology licensed by Verizon, the I.P.O. is by far the worst of 2006, according to Thomson Financial. At $3, the stock has lost more than 82 percent of its value since last May, when it was sold to the public at $17 apiece. The shares are now below the average price paid by Vonages pre-I.P.O. investors, a prestigious group of venture and private equity investors including New Enterprise Associates, Meritech Capital Partners, 3i, and Bain Capital.

title: Fred Thompson Discloses Cancer
description: Fred Thompson told Fox News today that he was diagnosed with a type of lymphoma in 2004, but that the cancer is fortunately a good kind if you can ever call something like that a good kind, and has been in remission.

title: About That Gold Fields Bid
description: It appears someone may have pulled a fast one on Bloomberg News  and, by extension, DealBook. Bloomberg reported early Wednesday morning that Edward Pastorini, an American investor, was planning a bid for Gold Fields, the worlds fourth-largest mining company. DealBook included a link to the Bloomberg item in Wednesdays e-mail newsletter. One problem: More and more, the story looks like a hoax.

title: Are Web 2.0 Startups Missing the I.P.O. Party?
description: Initial public offerings are back  and tech I.P.O.s are really back, writes Brian Caulfield of Forbes.com. But the most heavily hyped segment of the tech boom  the glitzy Web 2.0 companies  has produced a grand total of zero stock offerings. What gives? There are various meanings of Web 2.0, and this article doesnt quite offer up a definition, but it makes reference to the kind of buzzy, Web-based companies backed by venture investors such as Benchmark Capital, Draper Fisher Jurvetson and Sequoia Capital and contrasts them with the networking- and telecom-related tech firms that have held I.P.O.s this year.

title: Dodd Pushes Tougher Bill on Ending War
description: In Iowa tonight, Senator Christopher Dodd is expected to provide his vision for ending the war in Iraq and beyond, urging the other contenders in the 2008 Democratic field to support the Reid-Feingold measure that calls for withdrawal of all troops and a funding cutoff by March 31, 2008.

title: When Its A-Rod, Its Personal
description: Ive got a question for our Bats readers: Why do so many fans take the issue of Alex Rodriguez so personally?

title: SWF, SBM, SBF, SWM: Whos seeking whom?
description: Now that youve debated the importance of height and looks and income in the dating market, lets consider something else that people note in their personal ads: race.

title: CBS Poll on McCain and Iraq (Pre-Speech)
description: A plurality of Americans say Senator John McCain is making the situation in Iraq sound better than it actually is, and a strong majority still do not think the United States will ultimately succeed in the war despite Mr. McCains assertions to the contrary, according to the latest CBS News Poll.

title: Hire Slow, Fire Fast
description: Angell & Phelps, Daytona Beach - Angell & Phelps makes chocolates. Owner Al Smith tells host Hattie Bryant that he may sell chocolate but he's in the people business.

title: Teach, Preach, Coach, Counsel
description: On Target Supplies & Logistics, Dallas - On Target distributes supplies and provides warehouse logistics. Owner Albert Black tells host Hattie Bryant how he cultivates people.

title: Find Money to Match Your Dream
description: Boston Duck Tours, Boston - Boston Duck is the cities' most popular tourist attraction. Founder Andy Wilson tells host Hattie Bryant how he ran out of his own cash.

title: Create Good Work for Women
description: National Assn. Independent Truckers - Cheryl Womack's company in Kansas City provides insurance for big rig owners. She tells host Hattie Bryant about her mostly-female team.

title: Hold On to Quality People
description: Ebby Halliday Real Estate, Dallas - Ebby's team will do six billion in sales this year. She tells host Hattie Bryant that her success strategy is no secret.

title: Attract Money With a Great Idea
description: Fess Parker Winery, Los Olivos, CA - Fess Parker tells host Hattie Bryant that he learned about financing ideas from his first boss, Walt Disney.

title: Find an Angel Investor
description: The Band Of Angels, Silicon Valley - Hans Severins and Fred Hoar tell host Hattie Bryant why angel investors look for new ideas.

title: Be Where Your Customers Are
description: Weatherend Estate Furniture - Gil Harper's company builds heirloom quality furniture in Rockland, Maine. He tells host Hattie Bryant how he spends advertising dollars.

title: Use a Famous Face Carefully
description: Sundance Catalog, Salt Lake City - Harry Rosenthal explains to host Hattie Bryant that making a famous person the face of your business can backfire.

title: Respect Technology
description: Ironbound Valve Actuation Company - Ironbound's owner Howard Kent tells host Hattie Bryant that for decades he has found ways to use technology to increase profits.

title: Set Your Ego Aside
description: Gadabout SalonSpas, Tucson - One employee explains to host Hattie Bryant why Gadabout SalonSpas is such a special place to work.

title: Study Your Trends
description: Understanding Financial Statements - Veteran entrepreneur and author, Jim Schell, helps owners face the facts. He tells host Hattie Bryant that monitoring trends is vital.

title: Build Brand
description: Cloud 9 Shuttle, San Diego - John Hawkins bought a shared-ride company out of bankruptcy. He tells host Hattie Bryant how he brought it back to life.

title: Thomson Moves On; Bartiromo Moves In
description: Wednesday brought two developments related to CNBC correspondent Maria Bartiromo: One brought some closure, the other was a closing. The Financial Times reported that Todd S. Thomson, the Citigroup executive whose dismissal raised questions about his ties to Ms. Bartiromo, has reached a deal with Citi over his severance package. Whats next for Mr. Thomson, who was once considered a contender to lead Citi? Bloomberg News said he has set up a real estate development firm called Headwaters Capital as he considers his options. In other real-estate news  yes, we are reaching for a segue here  The New York Observer reports that Ms. Bartiromo and her husband, Jonathan Steinberg, have closed their purchase of a five-level, $6.5 million townhouse on Manhattans Upper East Side.

title: Create a Franchise With Systems
description: Auntie Anne's Pretzel, Gap, PA - Founder Anne Beiler tells host Hattie Bryant that she can teach anybody how to make a pretzel and run a store.

title: Promise a Job For Life
description: Joseph's Lite Cookies, Deming, NM - Founder Joseph Semprevivo tells host Hattie Bryant that as long as he is working at Joseph's the people on his payroll will be too.

title: Promote From Within
description: Nicole Miller, New York City - Judy Scarpola tells host Hattie Bryant that when she started at Nicole Miller she never dreamed that she would become a vice president.

title: Make Marketing Fun and Funny
description: Katz's Deli, Bar and Gallery, Austin - Marc Katz brought New York deli food to Austin nearly 3 decades ago. Marc tells host Hattie Bryant how he keeps customers coming back.

title: Let Customers See What You Do
description: Oregon Log Homes, Maupin, Oregon - Host Hattie Bryant talks with founder Mike Neary and marketing expert John Wargo. Mike says moving to a busy highway increased his sales.

title: Put Job Descriptions in Writing
description: Oregon Log Homes, Maupin, Oregon - Founder Mike Neary tells host Hattie Bryant that he should have given employees more detailed guidance when he first started hiring.

title: Spitzers Former Deputy Joins Paul Weiss
description: While he was New Yorks attorney general, Eliot Spitzer was known as the sheriff of Wall Street for his efforts to root out wrongdoing in the financial-services sector. Mr. Spitzer went on to become New Yorks governor, and now his top lieutenant from his A.G. days, Michele Hirshman, has found new work as well: Ms. Hirshman will join Paul Weiss as a partner in the law firms litigation department.

title: Inspire Employees to Learn
description: Gadabout SalonSpas, Tucson - Founder Pam McNair tells host Hattie Bryant that the more training she provides the more profit she realizes.

title: Be Nice
description: Rodgers Chevrolet, Woodhaven, MI - Owner Pamela Rodgers has an MBA in finance.  With confidence she tells host Hattie Bryant that being nice translates to the bottom line.

title: Act Bigger Than You Are
description: Zubi Advertising, Miami - Tere Zubizaretta helps customers reach the Hispanic market.  Tere told host Hattie Bryant that being small is not a good reason to be shy.

title: Choose Your Words Carefully
description: Tires Plus, Minneapolis - Tom Gegax started and grew Tires Plus to 2,000 employees.  He told host Hattie Bryant that nobody wants a boss and everybody wants a coach.

title: Use Four Steps To Coach Employees
description: Tires Plus, Minneapolis - Tom Gegax told host Hattie Bryant that there are four steps to coaching employees.  He started and grew Tires Plus to 2,000 employees.

title: Think of Data as Cold, Hard Cash
description: Madison Park, Seattle - Brian Jacobsen and other business owners told host Hattie Bryant that they have processes in place to treat data like cash.

title: The Least Responsible Are the Most Affected
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans April 11 column, Upsetting the Balance.

title: A Kinder, Gentler Third Point? Dont Count on It
description: The latest issue of Trader Monthly, which features a list of the 100 top-earning hedge fund managers, writes that Daniel Loebs venomous tongue has fallen silent of late and his legendarily incendiary memos have disappeared. We beg to differ. Proof to the contrary came Wednesday in a blistering letter to the board of PDL Biopharma, a drug development company in which Mr. Loebs hedge fund firm, Third Point, owns a 9.7 percent stake. In the letter, which was distributed in a press release, Mr. Loeb urges PDL to remove its chief executive, Mark McDade, whom he describes as being fixated on when his boat slip in the marina adjacent to the new corporate headquarters will be ready rather than on his companys underperforming stock.

title: Document: Oink
description: That is the name that the conservative Manhattan Institute for Policy Research has given to the list [two formats: pdf or Excel spreadsheet] it has compiled of pork-barrel member item projects found in the 2007-08 state budget. There are some 5,800 obvious ones, but the institute adds that it may have missed some fine print.

title: Public Hearings on Water Rates
description: The New York City Water Board is expected to approve an 11.5 percent increase in city water rates, the largest annual increase in 15 years. The first public hearing on the rate change was this afternoon in Queens, but more are planned around the city: Heres the full schedule.

title: Beware, Owners of Rundown Buildings
description: New York City wants to strengthen its hand against recalcitrant landlords by giving itself broad new powers not simply to make patchwork emergency repairs in long-troubled buildings but to overhaul entire systems, like heating or plumbing, and then force the landlords to foot the bill.A bill to be introduced in the City Council, with the support of the Bloomberg administration, would give the citys housing agency the right to go into buildings with dozens of serious housing-code violations and a history of unpaid emergency repairs, do a cellar to roof inspection and fix not only immediate problems but whole underlying systems.

title: Getting Fish Back on the Menu
description: New York and six other Northeastern states have joined in a regional pact to reduce mercury emissions low enough for advisories against eating freshwater fish to be lifted some years in the future.Satisfied that they have reduced the amount of mercury pollution generated within their own borders as much as possible, the states are trying to focus attention on mercury pollution that drifts into the region from the Midwest, particularly from states where coal-fired power plants are the prime source of electricity.

title: McCains War Campaign
description: LEXINGTON, Va.  -Senator John McCain followed his speech on Iraq at the Virginia Military Institute with a fairly contentious press conference.

title: Blogtalk: Excelsior!
description: Eliot Spitzer has formed a national PAC, the Excelsior Committee. [The Politicker]

title: What the Whole World Was Doing 1 Second Ago
description: The concept of the Web as a decentralized network  a sprawling, makeshift Busytown built of bamboo, copper wire and coal chutes  may have run its course.

title: Imus in the Hornets Nest
description: Don Imus must feel as if he has been run over by a cement truck, which then reversed and backed over him.

title: In Medicine, Its Man vs. Machine
description: Last week, a new study showed that radiologists dont need no stinking machines. Radiologists read mammograms, at $120 a pop, to look for breast cancer. One out of every 200 films shows a suspicious pattern the radiologist recognizes from years of experience. Its tedious work in a dark room with a magnifying glass. And mammograms are often read twice  another $120. A new system called computer-aided detection, or CAD, can identify the same patterns a doctor can, by referring to a database of known cancer films. And now a third of all second mammogram readings are done by CAD, for $20 each. But the study from the University of California, Davis, showed that a radiologist with CAD was statistically no better than a radiologist alone in finding cancer. Round 1: Doctors.

title: Not Following the Money
description: I love my friends and family, but Ive seriously considered sending this memo to every one of them:

title: Francona and Japanese 101
description: Terry Francona, the manager of the Boston Red Sox, spoke honestly about his level of communication with Daisuke Matsuzaka, the Japanese pitcher. There is not much. A few words, some nods. But Francona is trying.

title: Blogtalk: McCains Conference Call
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona participated in a conference call with conservative bloggers soon after delivering a speech on Iraq. The bloggers who posted after the call seemed impressed with the Senators blunt talk. (Many in the conservative camp have lost or never had exuberant confidence in Mr. McCains candidacy.)

title: Talking Baseball With Jay Schreiber
description: Assistant sports editor Jay Schreiber is the driving force behind much of The New York Timess baseball coverage. Working with reporters and other editors, Schreiber develops the themes, personalities and story lines The Times writes about during the baseball season.

title: War at Home: The Volleys Dont Stop
description: Its been a long, newsy day with the spotlight on the political impasse over how to deal with the war in Iraq. The Senates back on Capitol Hill this week; President Bush and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid have been trading off on invitations and near-insults that dont seem to meet each others criteria for talking in the same room; the Pentagon announced today that soldiers would be required to serve 15-month stints, not 12-month stints.

title: Tricking Out TiVo
description: In The Times last week, I wrote about the wild new Internet features of the TiVofeatures that take it light-years beyond its original functions as a video recorder.

title: Obama Gathers Donor Huddle
description: Fresh off their $25 million success in the first-quarter, Senator Barack Obama invited his leading fundraisers to Washington today for a series of meetings about the progress of the campaign.

title: Like Kids in a Candy Store
description: Were interviewing Ron Guidry before the game today, and hes standing in the middle of the clubhouse here at the Metrodome. Im off to Guidrys left, and behind him is this wall of candy, three shelves full. I cant stop staring at it.

title: NBC News Drops Imus Show Over Racial Remark
description: NBC News dropped Don Imus yesterday, canceling his talk show on its MSNBC cable news channel a week after Mr. Imus made a racially disparaging remark about the Rutgers University womens basketball team.

title: Patriots Face Early Tests by Playoff Teams
description: The New England Patriots, who established themselves as the early Super Bowl favorites with a free-agency spending spree this off-season, will have plenty of early tests for their revamped roster.

title: City to Seek Broader Power Over Buildings
description: New York City wants to strengthen its hand against recalcitrant landlords by giving itself broad new powers to overhaul entire building systems  like heating, electrical or plumbing  in long-troubled properties, and to force landlords to pay for the work.

title: The Drive-In Without the Drive
description: FOR video razzle-dazzle, its hard to beat the $5 million mansion of the Florida concrete multimillionaire Bill Williams, in Naples. The slickest piece of engineering in the home is most likely the 32-inch Samsung LCD screen in the master bath, which, in a Disneyesque bit of business that a wicked stepmother might appreciate, is embedded in a large mirror. If you feel like watching a movie from the tub, as Mr. Williams, a 51-year-old bachelor, often does, you turn it on; when its off, you see only the mirror.

title: Shell Settles With Europe on Overstated Oil Reserves
description: FRANKFURT, April 11  Royal Dutch Shell agreed Wednesday to pay European and other non-American shareholders about $450 million in a settlement to help resolve legal disputes stemming from its overstatement of oil reserves.

title: California: Audit Clears Payment to Paramour
description: A report by the San Francisco city attorney cleared Mayor Gavin Newsom of any legal wrongdoing in relation to a cash payment made to a woman with whom Mr. Newsom had had an affair. In February, Mr. Newsom confessed to having had a brief affair with the woman, Ruby Rippey-Tourk, his appointments secretary and the wife of his former campaign manager. In 2006, Ms. Rippey-Tourk sought treatment for substance abuse, leading to a payment of about $10,000, a cash-out of sick time accumulated as part of city program that allows the transfer of sick time to employees facing catastrophic illness. The report found that while the categorization of substance abuse as a catastrophic illness was unusual, there was no evidence that Mr. Newsom had pressured anyone.

title: Playoff Hockey to Suit Every Fan Around New York
description: West Orange, N.J.

title: Thompson Is in Remission From Lymphoma
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee, perhaps better known as the district attorney on the television drama Law & Order, disclosed Wednesday that he has been living with cancer for more than two years, but said it would not prevent him from considering a presidential bid.

title: Retailers Net Up 4%
description: Bed Bath & Beyond, the home furnishings retailer, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit climbed 4 percent as the company used discount coupons to lure customers.

title: World Bank Chief Apologizes for Arranging Job
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Paul D. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank, apologized today for his role in arranging a highly paid job at the State Department for a woman with whom he has a personal relationship.

title: How Did the Universe Survive the Big Bang? In This Experiment, Clues Remain Elusive
description: An experiment that some hoped would reveal a new class of subatomic particles, and perhaps even point to clues about why the universe exists at all, has instead produced a first round of results that are mysteriously inconclusive.

title: Stem Cell Bill Clears Senate, and Bush Promises a Veto
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The Senate on Wednesday passed a bipartisan measure that eases limits on the federal financing of embryonic stem cell research, setting up another confrontation over the issue with President Bush.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the New York Police Departments use of a surveillance watchtower in a parking lot at Shea Stadium during the Mets home opener misstated the number of parking spaces that have been lost at the stadium this year because of construction  a point raised by a fan who complained about the tower taking up parking spaces. About 2,100 have been lost, not 20,000.

title: Ivy League Admissions (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: No Proof That Board Approved Black Payments, Lawyer Says
description: CHICAGO, April 11 (Bloomberg News)  A Hollinger International internal investigation found no proof that the board approved most noncompete payments to Conrad M. Black, then its chairman, or to two others on trial for stealing the money, a company lawyer testified on Wednesday.

title: Officers Pay Tribute to Slain F.B.I. Agent
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 12  Under a steady rain and somber skies, hundreds of law enforcement officers streamed into a school today for the memorial service of a veteran F.B.I. agent who was killed last week in a confrontation with a group of armed robbery suspects.

title: Adam and Eve After Eden and Billie Holiday Too
