description: John Butlers heyday as a ballet choreographer was in the 1950s, but his presence and repertory lingered for two decades or so. By that time Mr. Butler, who died in 1993, was considered a little old-fashioned. Narrative, intensely dramatic ballets like his were out of style.

title: Tighter Limits Likely on Cellphone Fees
description: A panel of the European Parliament is set to recommend that fees Europeans pay for making and receiving mobile phone calls outside their home markets be lowered by more than originally expected, dealing a setback to the telecommunications industry. Members of the Industry, Research and Energy Committee are expected to approve a proposal today to reduce so-called roaming charges to a maximum 0.40 euro for outgoing calls, and 0.15 euro for incoming calls, plus the value-added tax. Leaders of all major political parties on the 52-member panel except the Greens have endorsed the plan, according to a copy of their agreement obtained by The International Herald Tribune. If it receives the committees support, the proposal will go before the full Parliament on May 9.

title: Its the National Guard (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: As Subprime Market Implodes, a Contrarian Prospers
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  In a clubby market where securities based on risky mortgages, credit card debt and other financial assets are traded, John Devaney is known for making brash pronouncements  and for often being proved right.

title: Because a Logo Is Not Enough
description: IT takes a lot for me to walk into an athletics store because I suffer from severe P.E. Class Syndrome, or PECS. No matter how much I may exercise now, I have dark and partly repressed memories of being beaned with dodge balls or standing in different fields praying the ball would never come, wondering what in Gods name everyone was screaming about.

title: Defense Closes Arguments in Trial of Ex-Qwest Chief
description: DENVER, April 11  Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, never exaggerated the companys growth rates to enhance the value of his personal stock, Herbert J. Stern, a defense lawyer, said Wednesday.

title: A Music Device That Can Play, Oh, 2 Million Songs or So
description: SanDisk has joined up with Yahoo to add a new wrinkle to its latest MP3 player, the Sansa Connect.

title: About Creation, Pope Melds Faith With Science
description: ROME, April 11  Science cannot fully explain the mystery of creation, Pope Benedict XVI said in comments about evolution that were published in a book on Wednesday. At the same time, he did not reject evolutionary theory or endorse any alternative for the origins of life.

title: The Dog Barks in Surround Sound
description: RANDY FISK is the creator and administrator of backyardtheater.com, a site where video buffs share information and advice about their backyard setups. Mr. Fisk, who lives in Coal Valley, Ill., and is a vice president for technology at the Small Newspaper Group, a Midwestern publisher, is a do-it-yourselfer who built his outdoor screen.

title: Newark: Mans Body Found on Highway Ramp
description: The body of a man who had been shot to death was found early yesterday morning by a state trooper along Route 280 in Newark, the authorities said. The trooper found the body along an on-ramp on the westbound side of the highway shortly after 1 a.m., said Sgt. Jeanne Hengemuhle, a state police spokeswoman. The mans identity was not released yesterday pending notification of his family, but officials with the Essex County prosecutors office said the man had died from several gunshot wounds. No arrests had been made by last night.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Extra Time soccer roundup yesterday, about the Sunderland clubs turnaround in an effort to return to the English Premier League, referred incorrectly to the competition through which teams rise to that league from the next level, the Championship. The Championships top two teams  not just the top team  receive automatic promotions; the next four compete for one more spot, not for two.

title: For the Record
description: A letter from Wingdale, N.Y., last Thursday about global warming referred incorrectly to the United States production of heat-trapping gases. It is the leader in emissions over all, but not per capita.

title: A Line Divides Art and Life. Erase It at Your Own Risk.
description: It is as if Gabriel Garca Mrquez and Mario Vargas Llosa, vivid portrayers in their different ways of Latin Americas violences and visions, had become their own extravagant protagonists. Instead each has written at a certain alleviating distance, and perhaps it is the distance that art requires to achieve itself, just as it takes a few inches of travel for a blow from a fist to hurt.

title: In Dash to Playoffs, Jagr Hitched Rangers to His Star
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 11  To look at the score sheet from the Rangers game against St. Louis in early March, a shootout victory that the Rangers believe saved their season, Jaromir Jagr appears inconsequential. He scored no goals, had no assists. He did not record a shot on goal.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A Media Talk report in Business Day on Monday, about the cult status of James J. Cramer, the host of the CNBC television show Mad Money, referred imprecisely to the aftermath of his sell recommendation on Dendreon shares. Because trading was halted the morning after the recommendation, few investors would have been able to sell  causing them to miss an earnings opportunity  before trading in Dendreon shares resumed. Mr. Cramers recommendation did not necessarily cause investors to lose money.

title: Chinese Leader Address Japans Parliament
description: TOKYO, April 12  In a rare address to Japans parliament by a Chinese leader, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China today pledged friendship with Japan, but also cautioned that Tokyo must match its past apologies for its wartime aggression with concrete actions.

title: Ground Broken Yet Again for 2nd Avenue Subway
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and a host of other dignitaries went underground today for a groundbreaking ceremony for the Second Avenue subway in a never-used tunnel built for the on-again-off-again project in the 1970s.

title: Gay by Design, or a Lifestyle Choice?
description: RON GEREN, an actor in Los Angeles, commutes to auditions and jobs throughout Southern California in a sleek black Mazda MX-5 Miata convertible. But for a recent date with a woman, he rented a Cadillac Escalade because he was so used to friends saying his Miata is gay.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article Tuesday about mounting criticism of the Italian governments policy in a hostage crisis in Afghanistan misstated the nation that Italy had urged to release prisoners belonging to the Taliban in order to win the release of a kidnapped Italian journalist. It was Afghanistan, not Pakistan.

title: The Mets Hot Pursuit of Theater Delivers a Drama of Its Own
description: Peter Gelb, the new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, is determined to enhance the dramatic component of opera at the house by hiring strong directors from the world of theater and film and by cultivating singers who are not just top-notch vocalists but compelling actors.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about Congressional investigations of the Justice Department decision to dismiss eight United States attorneys gave an incorrect job description in some copies for a Wisconsin official who was convicted of corruption charges brought by the United States attorney in Milwaukee. The official, Georgia Thompson, was a purchasing official in the states Department of Administration, not an aide to Gov. James E. Doyle. (After a federal appeals court heard oral arguments in the case last week, it ordered her immediate release from prison.)

title: Allies Meet to Discuss Afghan War, as Taliban Offensive Looms
description: QUEBEC, April 11  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and allied defense ministers gathered here on Wednesday to discuss the war in Afghanistan at a moment of reckoning for the nations carrying the brunt of combat there.

title: Money Does Buy Looks
description: A PAIR of socks at Tom Fords new store costs $75. If this is a problem, stop reading now.

title: Deal Expected From Nestl to Buy Gerber for $5 Billion
description: Nestl, the worlds largest food company, is expected to announce today that it is buying the baby food giant Gerber for an estimated $5 billion, people involved in the transaction said yesterday.

title: New York City Wins 10-Year Exemption on Water Filtration
description: After a long and exacting review, federal environmental officials have concluded that New York Citys upstate water supply is still so clean and pure that it does not have to be filtered for another decade or longer.

title: Rubin Caslow, 86, Leader of a Smoked-Fish Dynasty, Dies
description: Rubin Caslow, a titan of smoked fish who for half a century paved America with salmon, whitefish and herring, died on Sunday at his home in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 86.

title: In the Real World of Work and Wages, Trickle-Down Theories Dont Hold Up
description: When asked why he robbed banks, Willie Sutton famously replied, Because thats where the money is. The same logic explains the call by John Edwards, the Democratic presidential candidate, for higher taxes on top earners to underwrite his proposal for universal health coverage.

title: Mets Have No Defense for Prezs Seven Ball Fours
description: Oliver Prezs last outing at Shea Stadium in 2006 went a lot better than his first one in 2007.

title: Are Bugs the Pests, or Humans? Organic Lawns Take Hold
description: FOR most Americans the ideal yard is a weedless lawn. Garden writers may extol alternatives like ground covers and wildflower meadows, but a picture-perfect green velvet rug has remained the goal, even though attaining it seemed to require an arsenal of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides.

title: Bush Advisers Approach on E-Mail Draws Fire
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Political advisers to President Bush may have improperly used their Republican National Committee e-mail accounts to conduct official government business, and some communications that are required to be preserved under federal law may be lost as a result, White House officials said Wednesday.

title: Italy Calls for Standards in Dealing With Kidnappings
description: ROME, April 12  Italys fragile government, under fire for making a deal to free an Italian journalist in Afghanistan, on Thursday proposed international standards for confronting the rising number of high-profile kidnappings in war zones.

title: Philadelphia School Sells a Second Eakins
description: Less than four months after Philadelphians thwarted its bid to buy The Gross Clinic, an 1875 masterpiece by Thomas Eakins, an Arkansas museum founded by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice L. Walton has quietly purchased another much-loved Eakins painting from the Philadelphia medical school that sold the first.

title: China and Japan in Delicate Minuet to Ease Deep Diplomatic Tensions
description: TOKYO, April 11  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China began a three-day visit to Japan on Wednesday, in what both countries described as an important step forward in repairing diplomatic relations.

title: Philadelphia School Sells a Second Eakins
description: Less than four months after Philadelphians thwarted its bid to buy The Gross Clinic, an 1875 masterpiece by Thomas Eakins, an Arkansas museum founded by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice L. Walton has quietly purchased another much-loved Eakins painting from the Philadelphia medical school that sold the first.

title: North Korea Set to Carry Out Nuclear Deal
description: Correction Appended

title: Genentech Profit Increases 68%
description: Genentech said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 68 percent, driven by sales of its cancer drugs Avastin and Rituxan.

title: Canceled by Principal, Student Play Heads to Off Broadway
description: Students at a Connecticut high school whose principal canceled a play they were preparing on the Iraq war are now planning to perform the work in June in New York, at the Public Theater, a venerable Off Broadway institution, and at the Culture Project, which is known for staging politically provocative work. A third show at a Connecticut theater is also being discussed.

title: Court Theatrics as Lawyers Duel at Ex-Judges Trial in Brooklyn
description: Certain occupations require people  or permit them  to spend the day screaming at somebody. Two men seemingly inclined toward such work, Michael S. Washor and Michael F. Vecchione, have found a prominent forum at the judicial corruption trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Manhattan: Woman Found Dead After Fire
description: An elderly woman was found dead inside her Chelsea apartment after a fire yesterday morning , fire officials said. The fire, which was under investigation, began just before 11:45 a.m. at the back of the womans second-floor apartment at 246 West 18th Street, fire officials said. The woman, whose identity was not released yesterday, lived with her son William Pifer, 70, who was at a doctors appointment when the fire occurred. The police did not release her age, but neighbors said she was in her late 90s.

title: Magical Mystery Tour Ends for Apple Corps Executive
description: There has been a good deal of irrational exuberance in the virtual world of Beatles chat sites since Tuesday. That morning Apple  the Beatles company, not the computer maker  announced that Neil Aspinall, its chief operating officer nearly from the start, has decided to move on, and that his chair would be filled by Jeff Jones, a vice president at Sony/BMG whose focus over the past dozen years has been catalog reissues.

title: The Billion-Dollar Brushoff
description: If there is a single, logical justification for the wild executive compensation packages that have become standard at large American companies, it is performance. In too many cases, pay has little or nothing to do with results, and some of the most jaw-dropping packages are for executives who have been told to hand over the reins.

title: Rising Inflation May Mean More Fed Rate Increases
description: At their last meeting, Federal Reserve officials agreed that more interest rate increases might be needed to tame rising inflation, though they also expressed concern that the economy could slow more than forecast.

title: Westbury: 10 Charged in Drug Arrest
description: Federal agents charged 10 people yesterday with selling crack cocaine in the Westbury area of Nassau County, prosecutors said. Seven of the suspects are members of the Bloods street gang, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. Ms. Mauskopf said F.B.I. agents seized two handguns, material used to make and package crack, and an unknown amount of material believed to be crack and powdered cocaine. She said the arrests followed an eight-month investigation by the F.B.I. and local police officers.

title: Citigroup to Cut 17,000 Jobs and Move 9,500
description: Citigroup announced today that it would eliminate or reassign more than 26,500 jobs as part of a sweeping overhaul to cut costs and streamline the banks sprawling global operations.

title: Astronomer Sees Signs of Water in Atmosphere of a Dusty Planet
description: There might be water beyond our solar system after all.

title: As Postseason Draws Near, Nets Three Stars Turn It On
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The Nets decisive 6-0 spurt against the Washington Wizards on Tuesday night started with a short jumper by Vince Carter in the lane. That was followed by consecutive fast-break layups from Richard Jefferson and Jason Kidd.

title: Senate Panel Admonishes a Beleaguered Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Adopting the tone of a stern parent with a wayward child, senators warned the Smithsonian Institution on Wednesday that it must create a new, more accountable management structure or risk jeopardizing support from lawmakers and the public.

title: Four Years Later in Iraq
description: Four years ago this week, as American troops made their first, triumphant entrance into Baghdad, joyous Iraqis pulled down a giant statue of Saddam Hussein. It was powerful symbolism  a murderous dictator toppled, Baghdadis taking to the streets without fear, American soldiers hailed as liberators.

title: Manhattan: Council Hearing on Bus Safety
description: A city education official promised members of the City Council yesterday that the Education Department would take steps to address reports of problems on city school buses. The official, Kathleen Grimm, the deputy chancellor for finance and administration, said the department would hire more investigators, improve record-keeping and standardize reporting of problems on the buses. Ms. Grimm testified before the Council Committee on Education, which convened a hearing in response to a series of reports in The Daily News that detailed physical and sexual abuse by students, bus drivers and monitors on school buses.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about condemnation of the radio host Don Imus for his remarks about the Rutgers womens basketball team misidentified the book that Barack Obama, then a senator-elect, was promoting when he appeared on Mr. Imuss show in November 2004. It was Dreams From My Father  not The Audacity of Hope, which was published in 2006.

title: Developer That Bought Times Building Puts Up For-Sale Sign, Hoping to Triple Its Money
description: What a difference 885 days make.

title: Senators Push for Answers on Pensions in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 11  State senators from both political parties said at a hearing on Wednesday that they had been shocked to learn that they had voted again and again in recent years for measures that had left the state pension in great distress, and they faulted the state treasury for failing to explain to them the risks of what they were doing.

title: Those Who Can, Do. Those Who Retire, Teach.
description: TO fans hooked on professional wrestling  and to himself  Diamond Dallas Page isnt just a three-time world champion whose signature move is a ghastly maneuver called the diamond cutter. Hes a phenom.

title: Working on Overhaul, Russia Halts Adoption Applications
description: Americans wishing to adopt from Russia may face an indefinite wait. The country has temporarily stopped accepting new applications from American adoption agencies as part of an overhaul of its accreditation process.

title: Hes Not My Grandpa. Hes My Dad.
description: LATE in 1996, while rehearsing for a production of A Christmas Carol in New York, Tony Randall was giddily anticipating becoming a father  at the age of 77.

title: Realtors Expect Home Prices to Show First Annual Decline
description: The problems in the subprime loan market will make it more difficult for borrowers to get mortgages and will cause home prices to fall this year for the first time on record, the National Association of Realtors said yesterday.

title: John McCain in His Own Words
description: From remarks yesterday to the cadets of the Virginia Military Institute in Lexington, Va.:

title: Canada: Ex-Officer Returns to Parts Maker
description: Magna, the Canadian auto parts manufacturer, said that a former president, Belinda Stronach, left, the daughter of the companys founder and controlling shareholder, Frank Stronach, would be returning to the company to be the executive vice chairwoman. The company said that Ms. Stronach would not seek re-election to the Canadian Parliament, where she has served since 2004. Magna has been discussed by auto analysts as a possible bidder for the Chrysler division of the DaimlerChrysler Corporation. My father is looking to the future, the company is facing important strategic decisions, and the Canadian and global auto sector and economy are in a period of great challenge, Ms. Stronach said in a statement.

title: Scientists Retrieve Proteins From Dinosaur Bone
description: In a retrieval once thought unattainable, scientists have recovered and identified proteins in a bone of a well-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex, a dinosaur that lived and died and was fossilized 68 million years ago.

title: Manhattan: Singer to Pay $2.5 Million Tax Bill
description: Marc Anthony, the singer and husband of Jennifer Lopez, the singer and actress, has agreed to pay $2.5 million in back taxes, interest and penalties for 2000 to 2004, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday. Mr. Morgenthau said that three companies controlled by the singer, whose real name is Marco Antonio Muniz, either failed to file tax returns or did not report all taxable income in those years. But he said Mr. Muniz was not prosecuted because he had relied on his brother Bigram Zayes, acting as his general manager, and his accountant, Philip Sarna, to pay taxes, and prosecutors could not prove that he was aware of their failure to pay taxes. Mr. Zayes and Mr. Sarna have pleaded guilty to tax law felonies, and will be sentenced to a conditional discharge after paying back taxes and fines. Mr. Muniz and Ms. Lopez file tax returns separately, prosecutors said, so Ms. Lopez is not involved.

title: CBS Drops Imus Radio Show Over Racial Remark
description: CBS brought the tumultuous weeklong crisis over racially insensitive remarks by the radio host Don Imus to an end late this afternoon when it canceled the Imus in the Morning program, effective immediately.

title: Correction: The Look of Very Old Money

However much they may recall scenes of the 50s and 60s  Grace Kelly in To Catch a Thief, Brigitte Bardot on the French Riviera  they also summon trashy 80s lip-gloss moments from, say, an early Cars video.

title: To Fight Global Warming, Some Hang a Clothesline
description: AS a child, I helped my mother hang laundry in our backyard in Tamaqua, Pa., a small coal mining town. My job was handing up the clothespins. When everything was dry, I helped her fold the sheets in a series of moves that resembled ballroom dancing.

description: The fourth White House Teams took place in Amsterdam in February. Before the main event there was a 96-board exhibition match between a top Dutch team, comprising Sjoert Brink, Bas Drijver, Bauke Muller, Vincent Ramondt, Berry Westra and Simon de Wijs, and a team composed of four Americans, Rose Meltzer, Roger Bates, Kyle Larsen and Alan Sontag, and two Norwegians, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness.

title: Reyna Discovers You Can Go Home Again
description: Claudio Reyna is, if you will, the anti-Beckham. In his homecoming to America, the crowds will never squeal his name the way they probably will for David Beckhams calculated arrival in Los Angeles later this season. But Major League Soccer needs Reyna nearly as much as it needs the English import.

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) NOTES FROM THE UNDERBELLY Jennifer Westfeldt, left, best known as the sexually confused journalist looking for Mr.  or Ms.  Right in Kissing Jessica Stein, stars in this new comedy series as Lauren, one-half of a couple embarking on parenthood. Peter Cambor plays her husband, Andrew, who narrates each episode. Melanie Paxson and Sunkrish Bala are Julie and Eric, slightly obnoxious expectant parents. Rachael Harris is Cooper, a divorce lawyer intent on keeping Lauren out of the mommy cult. And Michael Weaver is Danny, Andrews childish buddy, who cant believe his friend no longer wants to trawl for hot women. Oh, but probably he does.

Her job is to help market cosmetics, even if that means tacky advertisements that prey on womens insecurities (With crepey skin like this, shes no longer the life of the party) or over-the-top promotion strategies. (A cross-country bus tour to promote acne cream is called the Blemish Brigade.)

description: GILLETTE and Schick make more money selling razor blades than razors, right?

title: Court Says Jury Can Hear of Basketball Stars Cover-Up Efforts in Shooting
description: TRENTON, April 11  The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that prosecutors could tell jurors of efforts by the former New Jersey Nets star Jayson Williams to erase evidence of his involvement in the 2002 shooting death of a limousine driver in Mr. Williamss home. Mr. Williams faces a retrial on a charge of reckless manslaughter.

title: Brooklyn: Mortar Shell Found in Apartment
description: Police officers evacuated four buildings in Gravesend early yesterday morning after they found an AK-47 rifle, four handguns, ammunition and a mortar shell while searching an apartment on Ocean Parkway, the police said. The mortar shell was determined to be inert, the police said. Officers assigned to the Brooklyn South narcotics squad found the weapons while executing a search warrant at 2281 Ocean Parkway about 1:30 a.m., the police said. Two men, Christopher Ocera, 42, of 2281 Ocean Parkway, and Danny DiSpigno, of East Seventh Street, were arrested, the police said. Mr. Ocera was charged with weapons possession, selling marijuana and resisting arrest, and Mr. DiSpigno with assault, possession of marijuana and resisting arrest, the police said.

title: Daughter of Sheiks Lawyer Accused of Faking Sick Days
description: When Lynne F. Stewart, the New York City defense lawyer convicted last year of aiding terrorism by smuggling messages out of prison for a client, was sentenced in October, her daughter Brenna took a day off to be there.

description: BAGHDAD, April 12  A suicide bomber wearing an explosive vest struck deep inside the heavily fortified International Zone on Thursday, killing eight people when he detonated inside the Parliament building just a few feet from the main chamber.

title: 11 Jail Guards Accused of Beatings in Brooklyn
description: Eleven federal jail guards, including a captain and three lieutenants, were charged today with beating two inmates at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, one so badly, officials said, that pools of his blood and bits of his hair lay on the floor of the cell when it was over.

description: Notes From the Underbelly is a revolting sitcom about pregnancy. Watch and youll lose your appetite for life. The characters are alternadads and shopaholics who consider Lost pornography and make sex jokes that belong in 40th-birthday cards by the Har-Dee-Har line.

title: Roscoe Lee Browne, 81, Actor of Stage and Screen, Dies

When tucked in a pocket or clipped to a belt loop, the HangTimer uses its tri-axis accelerometer to sense when the wearer has left terra firma and then measures each hundredth of a second aloft  otherwise known as hang time.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 11  The revival of the Yankees starting rotation lasted two games. Mike Mussina walked off the mound in the third inning at the Metrodome on Wednesday, the latest victim of a leg injury and the latest casualty on the staff.

description: Sallie Mae, the nations largest lender to college students, agreed yesterday to pay $2 million to settle an investigation by the New York attorney generals office and said it would close down student call centers it has run for college financial aid offices.

title: Hamas Criticizes U.S. Security Aid for Abbas
description: Hamas, the militant group now in a fragile unity government with the rival Fatah faction, criticized a $59 million American aid package authorized earlier this week to bolster Palestinian security measures as dirty and ill intentioned because most of the money is to be used to support the Fatah forces of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas. Hamas said all the money should be channeled through the Palestinian treasury. In Brussels, the Palestinian finance minister, Salam Fayyad, asked the European Union for $1.3 billion to avert an acute financial crisis this year. The European Union deals with Mr. Fayyad, an internationally respected independent member of the unity government, but boycotts Hamas, which it defines as a terrorist organization. The Union, which suspended direct aid to the Palestinian Authority when Hamas came to power a year ago, said it would not be resumed at this stage.

title: NBC News Drops Imus Show Over Racial Remark
description: NBC News dropped Don Imus yesterday, canceling his talk show on its MSNBC cable news channel a week after he made a racially disparaging remark about the Rutgers University womens basketball team.

title: Kurt Vonnegut, Novelist Who Caught the Imagination of His Age, Is Dead at 84
description: Kurt Vonnegut, whose dark comic talent and urgent moral vision in novels like Slaughterhouse-Five, Cats Cradle and God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater caught the temper of his times and the imagination of a generation, died last night in Manhattan. He was 84 and had homes in Manhattan and in Sagaponack on Long Island.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Executive Pursuits column in Business Day on Saturday, about tasting tequila, referred incompletely to the territories in Mexico that are allowed to call their agave-based drinks tequila. The Tequila Regulatory Council of the Mexican government recognizes five territories  not just Jalisco  as sources for the production of tequila. The others are Guanajuato, Michoacn, Nayarit and Tamaulipas. The column also misattributed a literary quotation about the process of going bankrupt, which was likened to overindulging in tequila. The reference to gradually and then suddenly was from The Sun Also Rises by Ernest Hemingway, not from F. Scott Fitzgerald.

title: F.D.A. Panel Rejects Merck Pain Pill in 20-1 Vote
description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., April 12  A panel of federal drug advisers voted 20-to-1 today to reject an application by Merck to sell its pain pill Arcoxia because of concerns that the drug could cause as many as 30,000 heart attacks a year if widely used.

title: U.S. Suspects That Iran Aids Both Sunni and Shiite Militias
description: BAGHDAD, April 11  Arms that American military officials say appear to have been manufactured in Iran as recently as last year have turned up in the past week in a Sunni-majority area, the chief spokesman for the American military command in Iraq said Wednesday in a news conference.

title: In 5-Year Effort, Scant Evidence of Voter Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Five years after the Bush administration began a crackdown on voter fraud, the Justice Department has turned up virtually no evidence of any organized effort to skew federal elections, according to court records and interviews.

title: Senate Bill Seeks Power for Medicare on Drug Costs
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Senate Democratic leaders pushed Wednesday for legislation that would allow Medicare to negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans. Their bill does not go as far as one passed by the House, which requires such negotiations.

title: I.M.F. Cuts U.S. Growth Forecast for Year to 2.2%
description: The International Monetary Fund yesterday cut its forecast for economic growth in the United States this year to 2.2 percent, the slowest expansion in five years, citing a weakening housing market.

description: Mets Manager Willie Randolph took stock of his team before its game last night against the Philadelphia Phillies at Shea Stadium. And he liked what he saw.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 11  Mariano Rivera was given No. 42 sometime during his rookie season in 1995, and it was two more years before he realized that Jackie Robinson had worn it for the Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: A Navigation System Shows a Good Listener Isnt So Hard to Find
description: Most navigation systems talk to you. The Magellan Maestro 4050 also listens  making it the first portable navigation device that does so, according to its maker. The spoken commands it understands include go home, reroute, and nearest restaurant. You can even tell it what kind of cuisine youre seeking.

description: Nestl, the worlds largest food company, is expected to announce today that it is buying the baby food giant Gerber, for an estimated $5 billion, people involved in the transaction said yesterday.

description: BOSTON, April 11  Massachusetts is poised to become the first state to make it possible for 99 percent of its adults to be covered by health insurance, with an ambitious plan that sets limits for the premiums people would be expected to pay.

title: Manhattan: Compliance With Tobacco Laws Rises
description: Nearly 9 out of 10 New York City businesses obey laws forbidding the sale of tobacco to people under the age of 18, city officials said yesterday. In the most recent round of inspections, investigators for the Department of Consumer Affairs found that 89 percent of businesses licensed to sell tobacco in New York check for identification and refuse to sell to minors, said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The department spot-checks businesses across the city using teams of inspectors and teenage workers. When the program started in 1998, 52 percent of businesses followed the rules, officials said.

description: WASHINGTON, April 11  An independent panel assessing dilapidated facilities and red tape for wounded Iraq war veterans at Walter Reed Army Medical Center on Wednesday issued a sweeping indictment of leadership failures, inadequate training and staffing shortages.

Daisuke Matsuzaka, the pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, was behind the mound and Ichiro Suzuki, the leadoff hitter for the Seattle Mariners, was beside the batters box. title: Ford Recalls Escape S.U.V.s
description: Ford Motor Company is recalling more than 500,000 Escape small sport-utility vehicles after 50 reports of engine fires caused by corroded brake parts. Ford notified dealers of the recall, covering the 2001 to 2004 model years, Tuesday and is preparing to send letters to owners, a Ford spokeswoman, Kristen Kinley, said. The decision follows a National Highway Traffic Safety Administration investigation last year, Ms. Kinley said. The recall affects only conventional gasoline-powered versions, Ms. Kinley said. Recalled vehicles will be checked at dealers. If the antilock braking system component is replaced, owners will not be charged, she said.

title: Britain: Suitor Ends Sainsbury Offer
description: The buyout firm CVC Capital Partners scrapped a 10 billion ($19.7 billion) bid for J Sainsbury, the British grocery chain, after CVC was abandoned by its bidding partners and Sainsburys founding family held out for more money. The family, which owns about 18 percent of the retailer, wanted more than the 582 pence ($11.46) that CVC bid for each share. It became clear that the consortium would be unable to make a proposal that would succeed, CVC said in a statement. The Blackstone Group, the Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company all left the bidding consortium in the last week. Selling to the private equity group would have risked damaging the companys strong balance sheet and a largely freehold property base, said John Sainsbury, former chief executive of the company. Eroding these attributes would make the company more vulnerable to competitive pressures.

description: BUFFALO, April 11  In his last playoff appearance, Buffalo Sabres center Tim Connolly rushed through the neutral zone with the puck and cut toward center ice, where he was crunched by the Ottawa Senators Peter Schaefer.

title: Feel the Vibe, Literally
description: From sound to fury, video-game enthusiasts can be truly immersed in an alternate reality, but they need more than just a PC or a game console for that experience.

title: Intelligence Chief Announces Renewed Plan for Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  The director of national intelligence outlined a plan on Wednesday to make progress on significant problems still bedeviling American spy agencies nearly two years after a much-heralded intelligence overhaul.

title: Cows, Oysters and Chesapeake Bay
description: How much manure ends up in the watershed is the question at the center of an unsual effort to reinvigorate the bay's declining grasses, crabs, fish and oysters.

title: Mussina: Its Not Bad
description: Another day, another leg injury for the Yankees. This time it was starter Mike Mussina, who left in the third inning with a strained left hamstring.

title: McCain Makes His Case on Iraq
description: In a speech at the Virginia Military Institute in Lexington, Va., Senator John McCain issued a forceful call for the United States to press on in Iraq.

title: The Crown of Europe
description: Europe's culture capital for 2007, Luxembourg has loyal - and royal - visitors.

title: Cheap and Cheerful in San Juan
description: A frugal weekend soaking up this colorful city's streets, plazas and historical sights.

title: Weekend in Portland
description: With less traffic, better public transportation and Mount Hood in its backyard, this self-styled City of Roses in Oregon doesnt stand in anybodys shadow.

title: Napas Spa Town
description: Take a tour of Calistoga, Calif., a Napa Valley spa town that attracts visitors with natural hot springs and unstuffy culture.

title: Theater Briefs
description: The Eugene O'Neill Theater Center will present its annual Monte Cristo Award posthumously to the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Wendy Wasserstein in a ceremony during a gala dinner at the Puck Building in Manhattan on April 30.

title: A Vonnegut Sampler
description: A guard would go to the head of the stairs every so often to see what it was like outside, then he would come down and whisper to the other guards. There was a fire-storm out there. Dresden was one big flame. The one flame ate everything organic, everything that would burn.

title: China, Old and New
description: Images from the reinstallation of the Chinese galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Works by Kurt Vonnegut
description: Novels

title: Imus Show Canceled
description: CBS yielded to pressure when it canceled Imus in the Morning, ending a program that had been broadcasting for more than 30 years.

title: Big-Box Art
description: A sampling of current shows in Chelseas big-box galleries offers a map to some of the ways artists use space in, and also around, art these days.

title: Nestl to Buy Gerber for $5.5 Billion
description: Nestl, the worlds largest food company, agreed to buy the baby food giant Gerber for $5.5 billion in cash to extend its push into the health and wellness category. Gerber, famous for its Gerber Baby ads, is currently owned by Novartis, the Swiss pharmaceuticals company, which has been selling noncore businesses in recent years to focus on health care. Separately, Novartis said Thursday it had named Joseph Jimenez, previously of the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, to be chief executive of its consumer health division.

title: Something new in London?
description: Driving around the suburbs of London, one sign has become ubiquitous  that belonging to OliverFinn.

title: Business Students Put Their Start-Up Ideas to the Test
description: These days, hundreds of business schools hold competitions involving students presenting start-up ideas to a panel of judges. Usually, winners receive money, from $5,000 to $100,000 or more. In some cases, they are also given free legal, public relations and accounting advice.

title: Defense Closes Arguments in Trial of Ex-Qwest Chief
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, never exaggerated the companys growth rates to enhance the value of his personal stock, Herbert J. Stern, a defense lawyer, said Wednesday.

title: No Proof That Board Approved Black Payments, Lawyer Says
description: A Hollinger International internal investigation found no proof that the board approved most noncompete payments to Conrad M. Black, then its chairman, or to two others on trial for stealing the money, a company lawyer testified on Wednesday.

title: New Chief at Comverse Sparks Deal Speculation
description: The news Wednesday that the software maker Comverse Technology had named a chief executive to succeed its founder and former chief, who fled the United States last year to escape arrest over an options scandal, sparked speculation among some analysts that the company was headed for a sale or break-up.

title: NovaStar May Put Itself Up for Sale
description: NovaStar Financial, the struggling subprime lender, said Wednesday that it was exploring strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the company. The company also said it had obtained a $100 million financing commitment arranged by Wachovia Capital Markets.

title: Comcast Does the Fandango
description: Comcast, the nations largest cable operator, announced Wednesday that it was buying the online movie ticketing service Fandango and starting a new Web site for watching TV and movies. The new site, Fancast.com, will be in place this summer and allow users to watch on-demand shows via television, the Internet and wireless devices.

title: Adviser on TXU Deal Warns on Texas Energy Bill
description: The chief adviser to the two private equity firms that have agreed to buy TXU suggested that the buyout shops might walk away if the Texas House of Representatives decides that the deal for the energy company will require state approval. Texas lawmakers on Thursday will debate whether the $45 billion buyout of TXU by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group should require state regulatory approval.

title: Magna Confirms Talks With Onex on Chrysler Bid
description: Magna Internationals chairman confirmed that the Canadian auto parts maker is in talks with a private equity firm, Onex, about making a bid for Chrysler, the United States carmaker that DaimlerChrysler has put on the block. Separately, Chryslers former chairman Lee Iacocca warned in his latest book that Chrysler could become a shattered remnant if sold, according to The Detroit Free Press.

title: When Private Equity Investors Go Solo
description: The Ontario Teachers Pension Plan is the latest private equity investor to consider direct involvement with a buyout target. The Financial Timess Lex column suggests that cutting out the middle man is cheaper but may not produce the same quality results as the best buyout funds. And Lex also warns that charities or pension funds could find themselves painfully exposed if they leap into oversized positions in single companies at this stage of the cycle.

title: Justices Inclined to Let Overtsock Suit Go to Trial, Report Says
description: It looks like Overstock.com, the online retailer whose chief has been waging war against naked short selling and what he sees as a vast conspiracy to drive his companys stock down, will get its day in court. The California Court of Appeal for the First District in San Francisco seemed ready to let the online retailer get a full airing on its claims that a financial analysis company and a hedge fund conspired to put it out of business, The Recorder reports.

title: Fund Said to Seek Changes at Sprint
description: Relational Investors, an activist fund led by Ralph Whitworth, has built a stake of nearly 1 percent in Sprint Nextel, the wireless carrier, and is calling for major changes, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing unidentified sources. Mr. Whitworth has met with Sprints management and urged them to reduce capital spending and consider selling Sprints fiber-optic networking and long-distance operation, the Journal said.

title: Private Equity Owner Says Warner Wont Overpay for EMI
description: If the EMI Group was hoping that the Warner Music Group would bring its bid for the British label more in line with the offer it made for EMI last year, one of its private equity owners dashed any such expectations.

title: Mexican Midas Edges Out Oracle of Omaha on Forbes List
description: Look out Bill Gates, here comes Carlos Slim Helu. The Mexican telecoms mogul has breezed past Warren Buffett and is gaining on the Microsoft co-founder on the list of the worlds richest men, according to Forbes.

title: Citigroups Cuts Take a Bite Out of Big Apple
description: Citigroups global cost-cutting effort will be felt especially keenly in New York, where Citi is the largest private employer. Of the 17,000 jobs the bank said would be cut, about 1,600 will be eliminated in the city, where Citigroup has 27,000 employees and its headquarters.

title: Nordic Exchange in Tie-Up Discussions
description: Shares in the Nordic stock exchange operator OMX soared as much as 18 percent Thursday after the company said it is discussing possible forms of cooperation with several exchanges and other market venues.

title: Qatar Fund Said to Be in Lead for Barneys
description: A private equity fund linked to the royal family of Qatar appears to be the favored bidder for the upscale department store Barneys New York, Womens Wear Daily reported. The trade paper said that an unnamed fund was edging out bids from other suitors with an offer of more than $1 billion for Barneys, which is owned by the Jones Apparel Corporation.

title: Virgin Radio Headed for I.P.O.
description: SMG, the struggling owner of Scotlands two ITV franchises, plans to spin-off Virgin Radio, a pop and rock station, in an initial public offering as it seeks to cut debt and focus on its core television business. The offering of the station, which has 2.5 million listeners, will provide a strong platform for Virgin Radios future growth, according to SMG.

title: The Router Diaries
description: David Pogue's horror story behind the installation of four 802.11n wireless routers.

title: Weinsteins Films May Falter, but Not Their Focus
description: As last weekends box-office take for the heavily promoted Grindhouse tumbled in at just $11.6 million, a chilly realization came with the numbers: Not all is well with the fledgling Weinstein Company.

title: Fed Chief Backs Current Hedge Fund Rules
description: Light regulation of hedge funds has worked well so far and seems appropriate given the benefits the funds provide to the financial system, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Wednesday. Speaking at New York University Law School, Mr. Bernanke stressed that the purpose of hedge funds  investment pools aimed primarily at wealthy investors and institutions  was to take risks.

title: Doubts Pile Up in Gold Fields Bid
description: More details emerged about a fishy report by Bloomberg News yesterday  picked up by news services including DealBook  that an American financier was planning a bid for Gold Fields, one of the worlds largest gold producers.

title: Apollo to Acquire Xstratas Aluminum Unit
description: The mining company Xstrata said it would sell its aluminum business to Apollo Management for $1.15 billion. The business being sold, known as Noranda Aluminum, includes a primary smelter and three rolling mills in Tennessee, North Carolina and Arkansas along with other operations, the company said.

title: Vonages Chief Executive Resigns
description: It was just yesterday that DealBook was observing how Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company, has the dubious honor of being the worst initial public offering, by far, of 2006. Then came word Thursday morning that Vonages chief executive, Michael Snyder, has abruptly stepped down and resigned from Vonages its board of directors. Thursdays news release gave no reason for Mr. Snyders departure, but the company is clearly in crisis mode. Its stock has lost more than 80 percent of its value since it went public in May, and Vonage is at risk of losing access to an important piece of technology that is the subject of a patent dispute with Verizon.

title: Help Wanted: War Manager
description: American Scene blogger Reihan Salam endorses the White Houses search for a war czar, even if no one seems to want the job. Salam writes:

title: Sean Bell Case: Change of Venue?
description: There continues to be talk of moving the trial in the Sean Bell case.

title: MedImmune Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: MedImmune, citing recent approaches from major pharmaceutical companies and dissatisfaction within its shareholder ranks, said Thursday it had hired Goldman Sachs to help it look for potential buyers. MedImmune, a biotechnology company whose products include the flu vaccine FluMist, had a market capitalization of about $9 billion based on Wednesdays closing share price; the shares surged more than 8 percent in premarket trading Thursday. The company said there was no guarantee it would be sold and added that it would not give any public updates on the process until it was complete.

title: Meaty Comedy
description: Nothing else in "Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters"  certainly not the labored title, which sounds like would-be "Borat"  is as funny as the first five minutes. Let me qualify that: not much that I have seen in movies recently made me laugh as hard as the opening bit, in which a parade of singing cartoon movie snacks is disrupted by a caterwauling death-metal rendition of familiar pre-film warnings: don't talk or use your cellphone or otherwise disrupt the motion picture experience.

title: Norsemen of the Apocalypse
description: All grunting, all goring, the witless action flick "Pathfinder" has little to recommend it, though Terrence Malick completists may be interested to know that it rips off a few setups from that master's magnum opus "The New World." The time is the 10th century A.D., "500 years before Columbus," or so it says in some introductory text, and the place is some pastoral if murkily shaded, almost monochromatic, stretch of coast, where native peoples hunt, fish and smile with what's meant to be the wisdom of the ages but registers as cultural clich.

title: A New Life, by Chance
description: In cloudy, gorgeous Vancouver, a disgruntled young man named Ryan (Paulo Costanzo) is fired from his tedious white-collar job on the same day that his girlfriend (Katharine Isabelle) breaks up with him. The hero then chances into a job with the local lottery, profiling winners for its public relations magazine while courting a set dresser (Steph Song) and getting pulled into a money-laundering scheme with her ex-boyfriend (J R Bourne) that affords Ryan fancy clothes, a shiny sports car and moral qualms.

title: Minimalism in Motion
description: This debut feature from Justin Swibel, which spends a little over an hour observing a young man silently cleaning a palatial suburban estate, is so minimalist that at times it feels as if a prank were being played on the audience. And yet Mr. Swibel's style is so assured, and the film's rhythms are so precise, that it would be a mistake to dismiss "Modern Man" as a pretentious goof.

title: 2008: Republicans Buffeted by War
description: The Republican candidates, particularly Senator John McCain, appear to be stuck between Iraq and G.O.P. primary voters. In their analysis, The Timess John M. Broder and Adam Nagourney write:

title: The Trouble With Home-Networking
description: As you may know if you watched my Times Web video this week, I've had a heck of a week.

title: Obama, Edwards Rank High in MoveOn Votes
description: The results are coming in from the MoveOn Virtual Town Meeting, the Tuesday forum for Democratic presidential candidates to talk about Iraq. Tens of thousands of members of the liberal group voted for which candidate they believe best represented their views on Iraq.

title: Milan Hotels Near La Scala
description: Could you recommend a good hotel within safe walking distance of La Scala Theatre?

title: Steel Company Ipsco in Sale Talks
description: The Russians may be planning another multibillion-dollar deal in North America. Ipsco, a Canadian steelmaker with executive offices in the United States, said Thursday that it is in discussions that could lead to a sale of the company. Ipsco did not identify the potential buyer, but the statement followed a report in a Russian newspaper that Russian steel company Evraz Group was in takeover talks with Ipsco. Ipscos shares jumped nearly 7 percent on Thursday, giving it a market capitalization of about $6.6 billion.

title: Texas Lawmakers Call for TXU Bid Inquiry
description: Beware the consequences of spurning a suitor. That might be the warning to take away from the latest twist in the proposed $45 billion buyout of TXU, the Texas energy giant. On Wednesday, two Texas legislators said they want the states attorney general to investigate claims that TXU threatened to sue a potential bidder.

title: Keep the Minimum Tax; Lose the Income Tax
A Dissection of an Abduction
description: With "Voice of a Murderer," the unpredictable Korean director Park Jin-pyo returns to the docudrama form he employed so provocatively in "Too Young to Die," his 2002 examination of septuagenarian sex. That film was judged unfit for public viewing by the Korea Media Rating Board, but this time the filmmaker is playing it safe: "Voice of a Murderer" arrives complete with its own public-service announcement.

title: Fidelity Makes a Big Bet on Fortress
description: Fortress Investment Group is not a stock for the faint of heart. Its shares surged 68 percent when they hit the market in February in what was the first public stock offering from a United States hedge fund and private equity firm. Since the offering, the shares have swung as high as $37 and as low as $23.34. The company generates eye-popping returns through its various funds, but many parts of its profit-making machine are proprietary secrets. So it was remarkable to learn, thanks to some filing-watchers at Financial News, that Fidelity Investments, the worlds largest mutual fund company, has bought more than a quarter of the shares that Fortress sold in the I.P.O., giving it a 10 percent stake in the company.

title: Qantas Bidders Lower the Bar for Takeover Bid
description: In a last-ditch effort to save its A$11 billion ($9 billion) bid for Qantas Airways, the consortium of private equity suitors has reduced its shareholder acceptance requirement to 70 percent from 90 percent. The group of bidders, including the Texas Pacific Group and Macquarie Bank, will also extend its offer for Australias largest airline to May 4.

title: Dow Fires 2 Executives for Buyout Talks
description: Three days after it insisted it was not up for sale, Dow Chemical has fired two executives it claims held unauthorized talks to sell the company. In a press release, Dow said Pedro Reinhard, a board member, and Romeo Kreinberg, an executive vice president, had engaged in business activity that was highly inappropriate and a violation of the companys ethics code. Mr. Reinhard was Dows chief financial officer until late 2005.

title: Massa tricked, Hamilton treated  the overtaking explained
description: Lewis Hamilton decided to clarify his statement about tricking Felipe Massa into going off the track at the Malaysian Grand Prix last Sunday in Sepang. It was Lap 6 and Hamilton was being chased by Massa until the Ferrari driver went off the track in a cloud of rubber smoke after making a bad judgment on the passing procedure. Hamilton, after the race, said he had tricked Massa into that, and then apologized. It was a nice moment in the press conference, in fact.

title: Bloomberg Unveils Gun Video
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was in Ohio this morning, where he unveiled a new ad for his Mayors Against Illegal Guns coalition. The ad  posted on YouTube  urges the repeal of an amendment to federal spending bills that Mr. Bloombergs group says has restricted police departments from getting access to federal tracing data on guns used in crimes. The campaign has a Web site, too: protectpolice.org.

title: The Trouble With Home Networking
description: As you may know if you watched my Times Web video this week, Ive had a heck of a week.

title: WestLB Takes Major Stake in DaimlerChrysler  Unintentionally
description: Whoops! The 14 percent stake that WestLB took in DaimlerChrysler wasnt the beginning of a takeover play  it was a mistake.

title: Podcast: The Melting Pot
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: Q & A:  Saul Bolton
description: Saul Bolton has been kicking around New York City kitchens for a while. He worked under David Bouley. He worked under Eric Ripert.

title: Welch Says Pursuit of Boston Globe Is Over
description: It seems that John F. Welch Jr.s dream of becoming a newspaper baron will have to wait. Speaking before an audience at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the former chairman of General Electric said Thursday that The New York Times Company has made it clear that the Boston Globe is not for sale. Last year, Mr. Welch expressed an interest in buying The Globe, and he joined with Jack Connors, co-founder of Boston advertising agency Hill Holliday, to explore making an offer. But the Times Company has repeatedly said that The Globe is not on the block, and Mr. Welch appears to have gotten the message.

title: Kerik Out of Guyana
description: The Politicker  points out this report from Guyana, which says that Bernard B. Kerik has decided to pull out of his contract to serve as a security advisor to President Bharrat Jagdeo, because of the federal investigation here at home:

title: Turkey and Genocide
description: People often ask why the U.N. doesnt do more to stop the genocide in Darfur. Well, the answer is complex and largely involves the perfidy of Sudans protectors on the U.N. Security Council, above all China. But this week has underscored that the U.N. cant even confront a genocide that happened in 1915.

title: Lagging on Pollution Reviews
description: The state of New York routinely fails to review the pollution permits of hundreds of factories, generating stations, sewage treatment plants and other operations that discharge billions of gallons of contaminated water into the states rivers and lakes, according to a study [pdf] released today by Environmental Advocates of New York, a citizens group.

title: In the News: The Duke Case
description: The system failed the Duke University lacrosse team, and most of the finger-pointing has been aimed at Mike Nifong, the prosecutor. As I wrote in my column at the time, he indeed behaved disgracefully and disbarment seems to me about the right penalty.

title: Greeting Us With Flowers?
description: Iraq public opinion is unfailingly fascinating, and reading opinion polls from Iraq are extraordinarily illuminating  and depressing. Heres the latest, from ABC News, noting that 51 percent of Iraqis favor killing our troops, and 80 percent of Shiites disapprove of our presence along with 97 percent of Arab Sunnis. Read and weep.

title: City Water Passes a Purity Test
description: After a long and exacting review, federal environmental officials have decided that New York Citys upstate water supply is still so clean and pure that it does not have to be filtered for another decade or longer.

title: Reyes Is Worth the Price of Admission
description: Something I discovered while wondering how many games this weekend will be rained out: Of the Mets starters, only two players have more walks than strikeouts this season. Ill give you three guesses, and the first two dont count. Still dont know? The first one is Moises Alou (4 BB, 3 K). The second is Jose Reyes  the same Jose Reyes who would swing at airplanes, ants and everything in between for the first few years of his career. In 2005, Reyes walked 27 times and struck out 78 times.

title: Googles Really Crazy Acquisition Strategy
description: The market for initial public offerings of Internet startups has been weak in the past few years. So for venture investors and Silicon Valley entrepreneurs seeking a way to cash out, a sale to Google, Yahoo and a handful of other Web giants has become the brass ring. So what does Google, which has about $11 billion in cash and lots of high-priced stock to use as currency, look for in an acquisition target? According to its chief dealmaker, Google likes ideas that are really crazy.

title: Recession Pessimism
description: Money cannot buy happiness, but it can help with optimism.A poll from The Los Angeles Times and Bloomberg reports that most Americans think a recession is at least somewhat likely over the next year. Those making less than $40,000 a year are far more likely to think that will happen. So are blacks, and women are much more pessimistic than men.

title: Lots of Experience on the Mound
description: An interesting fact about tonights Tom Glavine/Jamie Moyer pitching matchup from our good friends at the Elias Sports Bureau:

title: Mixed Report on Rent Affordability
description: The citys rent guidelines board has released a report  [pdf] today on rent affordability.

title: Fired Dow Executive Denies Holding Rogue Deal Talks
description: One of the two men fired by Dow Chemical on Thursday has rejected allegations that he held unauthorized talks with potential buyers of the company. The behavior of the company is very unusual, and the accusations have absolutely no substance and are highly damaging to my reputation after 30 years of employment, Romeo Kreinberg told The Associated Press. Mr. Kreinberg, who had been an executive vice president at Dow, was dismissed Thursday along with Pedro Reinhard, a member of Dows board, for holding what the company said were highly inappropriate talks with third parties about a possible sale of Dow Chemical.

title: The Shape of Things
description: During a news conference today, Barbara Bartoletti, legislative director of the League of Women Voters of New York State, said the 51st Senate district looked like Abraham Lincoln riding on a vacuum cleaner.

title: YouBe the Talking Head
description: YouTube, the online video-sharing site, is upping the ante for candidate-voter outreach. As part of its YouChoose 08 channel, a new Spotlight will feature a different candidate each week with a video asking for user responses.

title: If The Jock Offend Thee
description: Five syllables can get you fired.

title: Cashman: Yanks Will Wait on Mussina
description: Just spoke with General Manager Brian Cashman for an article to run in tomorrows Times. Cashman said he spoke today with Mike Mussina, who received treatment for his strained left hamstring at the Coliseum in Oakland. According to Cashman, theres still a chance Mussina can avoid the disabled list.

title: Indonesia's Fight Against Terrorism
description: After 32 years of dictatorship, Indonesia found freedom in 1998. This victory allowed fundamentalist Islam to return. Now, an infant Muslim democracy fights terrorism.

title: Pork Men of the Year
description: In an institution that has grown increasingly partisan in recent years, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a Hawaii Democrat, gave a warm tribute today to Alaskas Ted Stevens, in honor of his new status as the longest-serving Republican senator:

title: Some Muslims Face Backlash
description: Islam in Indonesia is often fused with local cultures. But some of its more unorthodox practices have incited backlash from extremists.

title: A Democratic Battle Over Islam
description: Some local and national politicians are promoting an increased Islamiziation. At the national level, an exemplary democratic counter movement is pushing back.

title: More Bad News for Juan Padilla
description: Juan Padilla cant catch a break. The Mets announced tonight that all the elbow discomfort Padilla has felt since making his lone spring appearance, on March 11, is because of a partial tear of the flexor tendon in his right elbow. It will be the second major elbow surgery in 13 months for Padilla, who underwent reconstructive elbow surgery last March.

title: Senator Byrd: The Sailor Man
description: Forget 2008. Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia is clearing the air about 2012.

title: Three Paths Toward the Future
description: I dont want to put too fine a point on it, but indecision is the new black.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Disturbia'
description: The Times's chief movie critic, A. O. Scott, reviews "Disturbia."

title: Movie Minutes: 'Red Road'
description: The Times's chief movie critic, A. O. Scott, reviews "Red Road," which won a Jury Prize at last year's Cannes Film Festival.

title: Kurt Vonnegut, Countercultures Novelist, Dies
description: Kurt Vonnegut, whose dark comic talent and urgent moral vision in novels caught the temper of his times and the imagination of a generation, died on Wednesday night. His novels became classics of the American counterculture, making him a literary idol, particularly to students in the 1960s and 70s.

title: One April Day
description: I got my tax bill this week.

title: State Workers in New Jersey Vote to Ratify New Contract
description: TRENTON, April 12  After weeks of internal squabbling, state workers approved a four-year contract on Thursday that would give them a 13 percent overall pay increase but would also require them to pay a portion of health insurance premiums for the first time.

title: Queens: City Workers Killer Is Sentenced
description: A Queens man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 25 years to life in prison for fatally shooting a city worker in 2002, prosecutors said. The man, Taiquan Williams, 25, of Jamaica, was convicted last month of second-degree murder for shooting Eugene McMahon, an employee of the Department of Environmental Protection, as he sat in his department car in Flushing, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. McMahon, 46, was supervising a repair when Mr. Williams shot him in the head and stole his wallet.

title: Our Prejudices, Ourselves
description: AMERICA is watching Don Imuss self-immolation in a state of shock and awe. And Im watching America with wry amusement.

title: Longer Duty Leaves Forces Disappointed but Stoic
description: JUWAYBA, Iraq, April 12  Sgt. Jonas Dailey was one of the last in his infantry company to learn Thursday morning that it would be staying an extra three months in Iraq.

title: Surveillance and Subterfuge in Corporate Shadows
description: In the sleek, paranoid world of Perfect Stranger, the Internet and the ugly side of human nature converge to evoke a treacherous corporate climate of multiple identities, high-tech spying, obsessive prurience, blackmail and murder. Communication is carried on under assumed names in e-mail messages, instant messages and coded cellphone texts. Every character is an unscrupulous go-getter with a cache of guilty secrets to protect.

title: Citys Catskill Water Gets 10-Year Approval
description: After an exacting review that lasted several years, federal environmental officials have concluded that New York Citys upstate water supply is still so clean that it does not need to be filtered for another decade or longer.

title: Turmoil Grows for Wolfowitz at World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Paul D. Wolfowitzs tenure as president of the World Bank was thrown into turmoil on Thursday by the disclosure that he had helped arrange a pay raise for his companion at the time of her transfer from the bank to the State Department, where she remained on the bank payroll.

title: For Gods Sake
description: In 1981, Gary North, a leader of the Christian Reconstructionist movement  the openly theocratic wing of the Christian right  suggested that the movement could achieve power by stealth. Christians must begin to organize politically within the present party structure, he wrote, and they must begin to infiltrate the existing institutional order.

title: Postcards by Irving Penn Find a Home at the Morgan
description: The Morgan Library & Museum has acquired 67 portraits of artists, writers and musicians, by Irving Penn, taken from 1944 to 2006.

title: Space Redefined in Chelsea
description: In art, space is a frontier, but there is nothing final about it. It is a complicated, layered place that artists continually explore, manipulate and expand, transforming our understanding of it and of arts potential too. And the best place to experience recent activity on this frontier is the space walk that is west Chelsea.

title: Bloomberg Bolsters Gun Drive in Ohio and Kentucky
description: CINCINNATI, April 12  Broadening his national effort to reduce the use of illegal guns, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York announced the addition of 14 mayors from Ohio and Kentucky to his coalition on Thursday and unveiled a campaign to pressure Congress to allow cities to share information about the source of guns used in crimes.

title: Orpheus Descending, Composer Remembering
description: Sentiment is not a quality often associated with concerts of new music. So a friend of mine was struck, after a performance of new work by the American Composers Orchestra some years ago, to find two industry insiders in the audience reduced to tears, simply because they found one of the pieces so beautiful. It was Kingdom Come, by Ingram Marshall.

title: Officer Convicted of Murder Is Once Again Denied Parole
description: William R. Phillips, a former New York police officer who was a star witness for a commission investigating police corruption in the 1970s, has spent the last 32 years in prison for murdering a prostitute and her pimp.

title: Sounds and Visions, Auguring Tomorrow
description: In recent years a few American orchestras and opera companies have tried introducing video elements to the experience: close-ups of the conductor, or the solo oboist, or the soprano singing Mimi.

title: Could It Be? A Miracle on 2nd Ave.
description: Here are some of the amazing things that are going to happen now:

title: Defense Chiefs of NATO and Other Allies to Press for More Trainers for Afghan Forces
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Defense ministers from NATO nations and other allies meeting Thursday in Quebec agreed to press for a new deployment of 3,400 trainers for the Afghan police and armed forces, increasing by almost one-tenth the international military commitment there.

title: The Duke Case: What Was Learned? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Parise Wastes Little Time in Firing Up the Devils
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 12  The Devils may not have much offensive firepower but they do have Zach Parise. With 31 goals during the regular season, tops on the Devils, he is the type of player a team can lean on. Thats exactly what the Devils did Thursday in an imperfect 5-3 victory over Tampa Bay in their Eastern Conference quarterfinals opener.

title: Queens: Mother Charged in Babys Death
description: A Bronx woman was indicted yesterday on a charge of second-degree murder in connection with the death of her 2-week-old son on Dec. 31, prosecutors said. The woman, Lucila Rojas, 25, is charged with placing a blanket over the face of her son, Anthony, preventing him from breathing, then leaving him in a trash bin in Jackson Heights, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. At first she told the police that someone had taken the boy from her at gunpoint, but later confessed to investigators, Mr. Brown said. Ms. Rojas has pleaded not guilty, a spokesman for Mr. Brown said.

title: World Bank Board Weighs Response to Chiefs Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The World Banks executive board was deliberating today what action to take regarding its president, Paul D. Wolfowitz, amid new evidence that he had not been entirely candid about his role in giving his girlfriend, a World Bank employee, a raise and transfer.

title: Port ID Program May Miss Deadline
description: A plan to bolster port security with identification cards for 750,000 workers may miss a July 1 deadline at the 10 highest-risk sites, a Senate panel was told. Workers may not start receiving cards until next month, instead of the original March 27 target, according to the Government Accountability Office. Kip Hawley, who leads the Transportation Security Administration, said workers at the Port of Wilmington, Del., would be first to have cards. The government began trying to start the port security program, which has cost $99.4 million so far, in December 2001.

title: Toll in Bombings in Algeria Rises to 33; Manhunt Begins
description: PARIS, April 12  The death toll from Wednesdays suicide bombings in Algeria rose by 10 on Thursday, to 33, and the police mounted a nationwide manhunt for those responsible for the attacks.

On PBSs broadcast of Operation Homecoming: Writing the Wartime Experience on Monday, a handful of stations, including WNET in New York, have chosen not to bleep out eight words and not to obscure a few crude images, none of which the stations would normally put on the air.

title: Whatever Size the Wave, Some Surfers Reach for the Paddle

Golden Garibaldi fish swam among swaying leaves of kelp; stingrays and a small shark kicked up grainy clouds of sand. A dark reef loomed amid imposing waves as we approached the headland.

description: These days, we reflexively think of Beethovens works for cello and piano as cello works with piano accompaniment. But as collaborative pianists never tire of pointing out, that isnt how Beethoven or his first audiences regarded them, and the scores titles support that view: the sonatas, formally, are for piano and cello. And that was how the pianist Andras Schiff and the cellist Miklos Perenyi played them on Wednesday evening, in the first of two concerts at the 92nd Street Y devoted to all the Beethoven piano and cello works. (The second was last night.)

title: Trenton: Workers Ratify Contract
description: After weeks of internal squabbling, state workers approved a four-year contract on Thursday that will give them a 13 percent overall pay increase but will also require that they pay part of their health insurance premiums for the first time. The new contract affects about 43,000 state workers affiliated with the Communications Workers of America and will take effect on July 1. Workers will contribute an extra half of 1 percent of their salary to the states troubled pension fund, and the retirement age for new employees will be raised to 60 from 55. The contract ratification is a political victory for Gov. Jon S. Corzine, who has been outspoken about his desire to control spiraling pension and health care costs.

title: Bangladesh: New Boss Delays Vote to 2008
description: Offering the first hint of a timetable for a return to democracy, Fakhruddin Ahmed, left, the head of the army-backed caretaker government, promised parliamentary elections before the end of 2008. I would like to state here categorically that we shall not stay in office a single day more than is necessary, he said in a televised broadcast. In January, after months of clashes between the countrys two main political parties, the government declared emergency rule and a Jan. 22 general election was canceled. Political activity has since been barred and members of both parties have been arrested on charges of graft.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9:30 P.M. (IFC) HENRY ROLLINS: UNCUT FROM ISRAEL  Mr. Rollins, left, unfurls his biting tongue in a new season of raw talk, starting with this 90-minute special that weaves a spoken-word show in Tel Aviv with film from a journey around the Holy Land. Returning to Israel for the first time in 10 years Mr. Rollins gets a personalized tour from Ziv Korren, a photojournalist, with stops at the Western Wall, the Church of the Holy Sepulcher and the West Bank security wall, punctuated of course by Mr. Rollinss commentary on pop culture, world events and the resilience of the Israeli people. (Working with the U.S.O. he has already let loose in Afghanistan, Djibouti, Egypt, Honduras, Iraq, Kuwait, Qatar, South Korea and Turkey.) At 11 p.m. The Henry Rollins Show moves into position with Marilyn Manson, discussing his new album, Eat Me, Drink Me, and Peaches as the musical guest. Janeane Garofalo joins the show full time with The Disquisition, a commentary segment filmed in her New York apartment.

title: Letters to the Editor

My generation spent much of its collective lifetime rallying against all forms of discrimination and embracing diversity. And now we want these distinct separations in our golden years so we can be with people just like us. Sounds like were turning into the not in my retirement generation. What am I missing here?

description: Paranoia strikes deep.

Years of bloody conflict and oppressive rule by the Taliban, driven out in 2001, had stripped Afghanistan of its beauty infrastructure. It was a land of bad haircuts, poorly applied makeup and no styling gel. To Ms. Rodriguez, a Michigan hairdresser with a can-do attitude, task No. 1 was obvious: get these poor people some beauty salons.

Ms. Baez served as president and then secretary to the board from 2000 to 2003, prosecutors said. She has pleaded not guilty.

These ranged from the Armys failure to anticipate the high flow of casualties from Iraq and Afghanistan to the Byzantine ratings system that puts soldiers through four separate hearings to determine  or discourage  their needed level of care.
