description: The Senate easily approved a bill this week that would free embryonic stem cell research from the worst shackles imposed by the Bush administration. The House passed its version earlier. A substantial majority of Americans tell pollsters they support embryonic stem cell research. Yet one man, President Bush, and a minority of his party, the religious and social conservatives, are once again trying to impose their moral code on the rest of the nation and stand in the way of scientific progress.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Bush administrations acknowledgment that it froze $25 million in a Macao bank as a bargaining chip in negotiations with North Korea over its nuclear program described the frozen money incorrectly. It was distributed over 52 accounts of individuals or firms, including 17 with ties to North Korea. It was not in a single account.

title: The Violetta, Germont and Alfredo of Yore
description: Some opera lovers now live in fear of the impending arrival of Grard Mortier as general director of New York City Opera because of his reputation for radical interpretations of repertory staples. The production of La Traviata revived on Wednesday night originally served as a corrective to an earlier venture of that sort: a controversial Nicholas Muni staging from 1991, in which Verdis beloved characters were surrounded by pimps, drugs and guns, with a finale set in an AIDS ward.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Bush, McCain and the War Critics (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: Councilman-Elect on Ballot
description: A State Supreme Court justice declined yesterday to take any action on a lawsuit to remove Dr. Mathieu Eugene from the ballot in a special election for the 40th Council District in Brooklyn. The ruling means that Dr. Eugene is one of two candidates who will remain on the ballot for the election, which is set for April 24. Dr. Eugene won a special election for the seat in February, but he declined to take the seat after the City Council asked for information verifying that he lived within the 40th District, which includes Crown Heights and Flatbush. A second special election was scheduled, and Dr. Eugene said he would be a candidate. John Ravitz, executive director of the New York City Board of Elections, said yesterday that only Dr. Eugene and Harry L. Schiffman, the director of government and community relations at Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, remained on the ballot.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Tuesday about professional football prospects from Hampton University referred imprecisely to the universitys location. It is on the peninsula of the Hampton Roads region in southeastern Virginia; it is not on the states Eastern Shore.

title: Was There a Ghost? No, Just a Tunnel at the Latest Subway Groundbreaking
description: The politicians and dignitaries sat on a stage about 40 feet under Second Avenue and 99th Street, at the dead end of a 35-foot-wide tunnel built in the 1970s for the on-again-off-again Second Avenue subway. The tunnel was sealed when New York Citys fiscal crisis hit, and ever since then it has been waiting for a day like yesterday  a day of cleansing spring rains and underground rites.

title: Manhattan: Whistle-Blower Bill Passed
description: The New York City Council passed a bill yesterday enhancing whistle-blower laws to protect city employees who report conduct that is harmful to the health, safety or educational welfare of a child. Councilman Robert Jackson said the bill was aimed at protecting teachers from coercion to inflate test scores and those who report the failure of a school to follow through on federally mandated individual education plans for students with special needs. But some critics, including the mayor, say the bill would provide teachers facing poor performance reviews a tool to use against superiors. City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn rejected that notion yesterday, saying it would not hamper efforts to bring more accountability to schools. The Departments of Education and Investigation oppose the bill, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has signaled that he would veto it.

title: Report Says the Young Buy Violent Games and Movies
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12  A surge in online promotion and the proliferation of unrated DVDs has eroded the entertainment industrys promise not to entice youth with violent fare, according to a Federal Trade Commission report on the marketing of violence to teenagers.

title: For New Jersey Governors, Plenty of Time on the Road Is a Job Requirement
description: The perks of being a New Jersey governor are considerable: the power to appoint the entire state cabinet, and the availability of an ornate mansion named Drumthwacket to call home.

title: The Good Life at the Top of the Napa Valley
description: CALL it the ultimate wine-country fantasy: Buy a weekend retreat in Napa Valley and swaddle the house in cabernet vines, then start bottling the yield into vintages good enough to attract the praise of the finicky wine news media. Well, Randy and Lisa Lynch did just that that five years ago. The Lynches, who own an advertising agency in San Ramon, Calif., bought a three-bedroom vacation home in Calistoga, in Napas far north, and planted 12 acres of cabernet, merlot and petit verdot grapes.

title: Afghanistan: 4 NATO Soldiers Killed
description: Four NATO soldiers died in roadside bomb attacks within 24 hours, the military said. The nationalities of the soldiers were not disclosed. Two were killed Wednesday in southern Afghanistan, where mainly Canadian troops are based, and two were killed yesterday in eastern Afghanistan, where mostly American soldiers are deployed.

title: Needing Quality Victory, Wrong Nets Show Up
description: CLEVELAND, April 12  As masters of deception, the Nets put forth a very predictable performance against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Thursday night.

title: EMI and Beatles Representatives Settle Royalty Dispute, Fueling Speculation on Deal
description: LONDON, April 12  The company that manages the Beatles commercial interests and the EMI Group, which holds the rights to the bands recordings, said on Thursday that they had settled a dispute over royalties, renewing speculation that a deal to release the Beatles music in digital form might be near.

title: In Oldtimers Game at Shea, Glavine Outpitches Moyer
description: The quirks of early-season scheduling yielded a pitching matchup last night that could have come from a Craigs List ad: One wily 40-year-old changeup artist with 20-victory seasons on rsum seeking another to share in historic feat. Must be left-handed. Being from the Northeast is a plus, too. No phone calls, please, just meet at Shea Stadium by 7:10 p.m.

title: Manhattan: Benefits for More Workers
description: The City Council passed a bill yesterday extending death benefits to family members of sanitation and correction workers killed in the line of duty. The bill is expected to be signed by the mayor and would go into effect immediately with a retroactive date of September 2005. Sanitation Department officials say that that date would cover claims by the survivors of two sanitation workers and a supervisor who have died since 2005, two from heart attacks and one in a work accident. Survivors of firefighters and police officers killed in the line of duty already receive health care coverage. But the city must now act on a case-by-case basis to provide those same benefits to survivors of sanitation and correction workers, a process that could take months.

title: A Bodegas Failure Spawns a Successful Movement
description: FOR most readers of the citys newspapers, the tales are bitter, if familiar: immigrant owner of bodega is robbed, or killed, often for petty cash. A family grieves.

title: From Call Girl to Kant Girl in a Flash of White Panties
description: The overripe morsel who gets batted around in the Japanese absurdithon The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai looks like she was conjured up by a teenage boy in dangerous hormonal overdrive. As gently plumped as a freshly cooked hot dog and about as intelligent, Sachiko Hanai (Emi Kuroda) works as a prostitute servicing men who tend to yell for their mothers at inappropriate moments. Its a living or something like it, though mostly its just a suitable setup for the ensuing clutter of soft-core political parody, hard-core narrative nonsense, breezy sexism, junky visuals and penny-ante surrealism.

title: Gonzales Aide Suggested  Replacements for Attorneys
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  A Justice Department e-mail released today shows that the former chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales proposed replacement candidates for seven United States attorneys nearly a year before those prosecutors were fired, in contrast to testimony last month in which the aide said that no successors were considered before the firings.

title: Turkish Military Leader Prepared to Lead Attacks in Iraq
description: ISTANBUL, April 12  The head of Turkeys armed forces said publicly on Thursday, in the militarys sharpest language to date, that he was prepared to conduct operations in northern Iraq to crush Kurdish rebels hiding there.

title: People
description: People

title: Tainted Pet Food Is Said to Be Still on Shelves
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Tainted pet food is still on the market almost a month after a recall began, Food and Drug Administration officials said Thursday at a Senate hearing.

title: Germanys Export-Led Economy Finds Global Niche
description: JENA, Germany  For those seeking the elixir that has given new life to Germanys economy, a visit to this ancient university town in the eastern part of the country would be a good place to start.

title: Giving All for Her Country but Also Feeling the Pain
description: We know that its easy to be seduced by a pretty face, but is it possible to be seduced by a sexy name? Painkiller Jane, a new series that starts tonight on SciFi, suggests that it is. Someone appears to have encountered the gritty comic book character, thought, Wouldnt that be a cool title for a TV series? and then decided to make one. The result is just what youd expect: The name ends up being the best thing about the show.

title: In a Lonely Place, Saved by Puppies
description: The wily and resourceful young screenwriter Mike White writes movies that seem as if they were cooked up by the skinny, self-consciously awkward guy who always ends up alone in a corner at the office holiday party. As it happens, Mr. White, who sometimes acts in the films he and others write, is a skinny, seemingly self-aware guy, though given his rsum  Chuck & Buck, The Good Girl, School of Rock and Nacho Libre  its a safe bet he doesnt often play the wallflower, at least in Hollywood.

title: Turkey and the U.N.s Cover-Up
description: More than 90 years ago, when Turkey was still part of the Ottoman Empire, Turkish nationalists launched an extermination campaign there that killed 1.5 million Armenians. It was the 20th centurys first genocide. The world noticed, but did nothing, setting an example that surely emboldened such later practitioners as Hitler, the Hutu leaders of Rwanda in 1994 and todays Sudanese president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir.

title: Give to Public Colleges (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheating at Chess (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sand in Your Shoes, Fine Linens on Your Bed
description: THESE new hotels on the Jersey Shore are open year-round, with rates varying by season and room; two- or three-night stays are sometimes required. All the marble, glass, silk and leather in the interior design makes them less than child-friendly  but theyre not intended to be.

title: Mountains of the Mind in Chinese Art
description: Outward bound and inward bound are the yin and yang of Chinese landscape painting. Movement is the modus operandi in an art that takes us hiking up mountains and cruising down streams, but always in a spirit of rumination. This is action painting as thinking.

title: Rutgers Players Accept Apology From Imus
description: The coach of the Rutgers University womens basketball team said today that the team members accepted the apology delivered by former radio personality Don Imus at the New Jersey governors mansion on Thursday night.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary in some copies yesterday about the writer Kurt Vonnegut misidentified the novel in which a recurring Vonnegut character, Kilgore Trout, was introduced. It is God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater, or Pearls Before Swine, not Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Childrens Crusade. The surname of another character, who appears in the novel Breakfast of Champions, or Goodbye Blue Monday, was misspelled. It is Philboyd Studge, not Sludge.

title: Next Up for the Yankee Dynasty
description: WITH his soon-to-be-former son-in-law Steve Swindal reportedly no longer his heir apparent, and no other members of the immediate family likely to step up, George Steinbrenner might have to think outside the box to find a replacement. According to insiders, the following little-known candidates have emerged as serious contenders for the Yankee throne:

title: Latest Casualty Is Symbol of Citys Heyday and Unity
description: BAGHDAD, April 12  There is not much left in Baghdad that all its residents, Sunnis and Shiites, laborers and professors, consider their own. But the Sarafiya bridge, flung across the Tigris, tied the city together, literally and metaphorically.

title: As Early-Season Losses Mount, the Nationals Look to the Future
description: ATLANTA, April 12  As the Washington Nationals played their first opening day game at home under their new ownership last week at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, their fans complained about the late delivery of season tickets, parking problems and cold hot dogs at the concession stands.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about the discovery of a womans body under a bridge in a Bronx park misstated the name of the park. It is Frank S. Hackett Park, not Frank Shackett.

title: Sallie Mae Said to Talk to Suitors
description: Sallie Mae, the nations largest lender to college students, is in talks to be bought out by private equity in what could be a deal for more than $20 billion, people briefed on the discussions said yesterday.

title: Apple Says It Will Delay OS X Release for 4 Months
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 12  Apple Inc., the computer and consumer electronics company, said Thursday that the introduction of the new version of its flagship Macintosh OS X operating system would be delayed as much as four months because of quality issues.

title: Festivals With a Mexican Flair
description: SAN ANTONIOS Fiesta Days started in 1891, as the story is told by Jorge Gonzalez, president of the citys Festival Commission, when San Antonians decided to greet President Benjamin Harrison with a peaceful spin on military history. Some of the ladies in town had read that in France, when someone important visited, they celebrated a famous battle, Mr. Gonzalez said. The women decided to commemorate the Battle of San Jacinto, the decisive 1836 engagement in Texass struggle for independence from Mexico.

title: 11 Jail Guards Are Indicted in 2 Beatings in Brooklyn
description: Eleven federal jail guards, including a captain and three lieutenants, were charged yesterday with beating two inmates at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, one so badly, officials said, that a pool of his blood and bits of his hair lay on the floor of his cell when it was over.

title: Study Identifies Dinosaur Protein
description: In a retrieval once thought unattainable, scientists have recovered and identified proteins in a bone of a well-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex that lived and died and was fossilized 68 million years ago.

title: Hooking a Big One
description: Ive been a fisherman for 25 years and everyone in my immediate family owns waders. I even proposed to my wife in the middle of a trout stream in north Georgia. I own a home site here in the Balsam Mountain Preserve community, where my long-term plan is to build a retirement home. Until then I have a fractional share of a cabin that entitles me to eight weeks of use a year, which is about all my family can manage time-wise.

title: So It Goes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Study Finds New York State Behind in Pollution Permit Reviews
description: New York State routinely fails to review the pollution permits of hundreds of factories, generating stations, sewage treatment plants and other operations that discharge contaminants into the states rivers and lakes, according to a study released yesterday by Environmental Advocates of New York, a citizens group.

title: Bibles Thumping, Suspenders Snapping
description: The handsome wooden courtroom that has been erected on the stage of the Lyceum Theater is Christopher Plummers personal playground. This may sound like a frivolous description of a forum for the lofty and abidingly important debate that occupies Inherit the Wind, the 1955 drama that opened last night, also starring Brian Dennehy, in a revival that is just about as wooden as its set.

title: My Life in Pictures
description: With her lustrous hair and cover-girl smile, Kelly Klein remains the all-American poster child.

title: Another Choice: Hip Resurfacing
description: Hip resurfacing, an alternative surgery to total hip replacement, can offer an interim solution to many younger patients.

title: Who Needs Car Keys?
description: Many cars today are being made with push-button starters, which have also become standard on hybrid-electric vehicles.

title: Finding a Vacant Lot to Buy
description: HOW do you even find a vacant lot for sale?

title: A Cultivated Eye
description: This spring the fashion forward take their hues from nature.

title: Citigroup Closes in on Deal for Hedge Fund
description: Citigroup is expected to announce a deal to buy Wall Street veteran Vikram Pandits hedge fund Old Lane at its annual meeting Tuesday, according to The New York Times. The deal, which has been the subject of numerous reports this week, would put a former top executive at Morgan Stanley at the head of its alternative investments group, but it is also being suggested that it would give Citigroup chief Charles O. Prince III a viable successor.

title: Jury Deliberating in Insider-Trading Trial of Former Qwest Chief
description: Jury deliberations began Thursday in the insider-trading trial of Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, after three weeks of testimony about what he might have known, and intended, when he sold $101 million worth of stock six years ago.

title: Events Leading to an Accident
Hollinger Executives Relied on Lawyers Advice, Jury Told
description: Jurors at the fraud trial of the toppled newspaper tycoon Conrad M. Black heard on Thursday that Hollinger executives relied on the advice of outside lawyers and accountants for how to account for the payments they made to themselves.

title: Ex-Executive Agrees to Pay $800 Million in Restitution
description: Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive of Computer Associates, has agreed to pay almost $800 million in restitution to investors who lost money because of the companys accounting fraud.

title: Dubai, Not Qatar, Is In Pole Position for Barneys, Report Says
description: A day after a report surfaced that the Jones Apparel Group was nearing a deal to sell Barneys New York to a private equity fund linked to the royal family of Qatar, a second report has emerged that says it is in fact Istithmar, a private equity firm owned by the Dubai government, that is in the lead to buy luxury department store.

title: Designed for Living
description: In Creating a dazzling persona, Louise Nevelson fused her art and her life. Leslie Camhi wonders if an artist can still look like one.

title: MTM Technologies Gets Fresh Financing
description: MTM Technologies, an information technology provider, announced Thursday that it has received an additional $3.8 million of equity financing from its existing investors, Pequot Ventures and Constellation Ventures. The company also announced that Francis J. Alfano, the companys chief executive, would be departing in the near term.

title: Zell Insists He Wont Sell Pieces of Tribune
description: Ever since real estate mogul Samuel Zell won the auction for Tribune, speculation has been rampant on what he plans to do with the various pieces of the struggling media company.

title: Ms. April
description: Favorite color: mauve. favorite author: Umberto Eco. Favorite food: meyer lemon sorbetto. Favorite magazine: T.

title: Red Sox Owner Bets Big on Small I.P.O.
description: Boston Red Sox principal owner John Henry is making big bet on a small life-extension research start-up that is preparing for an initial public offering.

title: Judge Approves Aramark Buyout Settlement
description: Aramark, a Philadelphia food concessionaire for colleges, hospitals and stadiums, won a judges approval yesterday for last years settlement with shareholders over the companys $8.3 billion management buyout in January.

title: Will Private Equity Dial Up Telecoms Deals?
description: Following The New York Times report this week that one of Canadas largest pension funds is in early talks with other pension funds and a private equity firm to form a consortium to mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, analysts and industry watchers are wondering if more such buyouts are in the offing.

title: Hefty Maker Buys Rival for $1 Billion
description: Pactiv, maker of the Hefty brand line of plastic bags, said Thursday it has agreed to pay $1 billion to acquire closely held Prairie Packaging, a maker of disposable tableware. Prairie, with five U.S. manufacturing facilities, employs 1,200 people and is expected to generate revenue this year of about $500 million, Pactiv said.

title: Ipsco Talks May Spark Bidding War
description: Reports that steel pipe maker Ipsco is in takeover talks with a Russian rival, Evraz Group, may spark a bidding war for the Canadian company, The Globe and Mail says. The newspaper reports that the company is planning to auction itself off and cites Indias Jindal, U.S. Steel, Nucor and Brazils Companhia Siderurgica Nacional as likely suitors.

title: Monster Replaces Chief Executive
description: Monster Worldwide replaced its chief executive, William Pastore, with former Symbol Technologies Chief Sal Iannuzzi, a week after the jobs-site operator cut its sales forecast. Mr. Pastore, formerly Monsters chief operating officer, took the helm after Andrew McKelvey left in October amid an investigation into the companys options practices.

title: Gannett Unloads 4 Papers
description: USA Today publisher Gannett said Thursday it will sell four daily newspapers to GateHouse Media for $410 million. Gannett, the largest U.S. newspaper publisher, is selling the Norwich Bulletin in Connecticut, the Rockford Register Star in Illinois, the Observer-Dispatch in Utica, N.Y., and The Herald-Dispatch in Huntington, W.Va.

title: Morgan Stanley Still Cant Resist Hedge Funds
description: As other investment banks jostle to grab stakes in hedge funds, Morgan Stanley, which has made five such investments in as many months, shows no signs of slowing down anytime soon. David Sidwell, chief financial officer of Morgan Stanley, said at the banks annual shareholder meeting: We will continue to grow asset management through acquisitions, minority stakes, team lift-outs and targeted external hiring and internal transfers.

title: Suit Over N.Y.S.E. Merger to Proceed, Judge Rules
description: A Manhattan judge has declined to dismiss fraud and breach of fiduciary duty allegations against John Thain, the chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange, by a former seatholder of the exchange. But the judge, Justice Charles E. Ramos, dismissed breach of fiduciary duty and negligent misrepresentation claims against the exchange itself in connection with its 2005 merger with Archipelago Holdings and its transformation from a not-for-profit to a public company.

title: Morgan Stanley Beefs Up Japanese Hotel Holdings
description: Morgan Stanley is buying 13 hotels from Japanese carrier All Nippon Airways for 281 billion yen ($2.4 billion), the airline said Friday, in a transaction that would roughly double the investment banks portfolio of hotels in Japan. The deal, to be completed June 1, includes high-end hotels in Tokyo, the resort island of Okinawa as well as northern and southern Japan, ANA said in a statement.

title: 2007 A Face Odyssey
description: Not since the human animal made the evolutionary leap have standards of beauty changed so dramatically. Daphne Merkin on cyborg chic.

title: Peoples United Seeks to Raise $3.4 Billion in Offering
description: Peoples United Financial, a commercial bank based in Bridgeport, Conn., said late Wednesday that it expects to raise $3.4 billion by selling stock in a second-step offering that fully converts the bank from a mutual holding company into a publicly traded company.

title: Merrill May Partner Up With Cruises United Artists
description: Merrill Lynch may end up becoming a full partner in Tom Cruises United Artists, according to The New York Post. The Post reports that negotiations between Merrill Lynch and UA over a $500 million film-financing package are being held up because the investment bank is having trouble finding a partner for the equity portion of the deal and the bank may end up putting up the cash itself.

title: HowStuffWorks Raises $75 Million
description: HowStuffWorks, an informational Web site for the mechanically minded, said it closed a new $75 million funding round that included investors Capital Research & Management and Chilton Investment Company. Billionaire financier Carl Icahn also participated in the round, The Deal said.

title: Will Buyout Brouhaha Put Dow Chemical In Play?
description: The irony of Thursdays spectacle at Dow Chemical, which fired two senior executives for allegedly engaging in rogue negotiations to sell the company, is that it may have whetted investors and suitors appetite for a Dow takeover. I find it interesting how private equity had penetrated the highest levels of the company, HSBC Securities analyst Hassan Ahmed told Bloomberg News. The announcement is telling us that there are parties interested in making that bid. Shares of Dow rose 2 percent Thursday as some suggested that, while these talks appear to have been bungled, Dow could still make an attractive takeover target for Middle East investors or private equity firms. Breakingviews said this may be an example of the wrong people doing the right thing.

title: Sallie Mae in Deal Talks With Private Equity
description: Sallie Mae, the nations largest lender to college students, is in talks to be bought out by private equity in what could be a deal for more than $20 billion. A buyout, if completed, would be an impressive show of muscle-flexing by private equity firms, which have grown emboldened over the last two years by acquiring ever larger targets. Shares of Sallie Mae, formally known as SLM Corporation, jumped more than 11 percent Friday in premarket trading.

title: From Full-Time Senators to Full-Time Candidates
description: In theory at least, the opening act of the 2008 presidential campaign could have played out on Capitol Hill, where the majority of the candidates hold their day jobs.

title: The Formula One circus goes on
description: Formula One may have added one full hour to Friday practice sessions this year, and Bahrain may be the first race for the two main support series, GP2 and the Porsche Supercup, but the Bahrainis still saw fit to come up with ways to fill in the down moments of a race weekend for the spectators.

title: Midwest Board Dismisses Third AirTran Bid
description: Midwest Airs board has again rebuff AirTrans hostile offer for the airline. In a statement on Friday, the board said it recommends that the companys shareholders reject the discount airlines revised $15 a share tender offer, saying the new bid remains too low. Nearly two weeks ago, after AirTran raised its offer a third time, Midwests board told shareholders that it would evaluate the new proposal.

title: On the Trail: From Full-Time Senators to Full-Time Candidates
How Bush Is Like Hank Aaron
Can a Stabilized Apartment Be Rented at Market Rates?
description: Q I live in a three-bedroom rent-stabilized apartment. I currently pay about $800 a month. Can I sublet my apartment for the market rate (currently about $2,500) and pay a fee to the landlord?

title: 2008: Clintons Clean Government Speech
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is set to unveil her plan to modernize the government today in New Hampshire. Heres what she told The Associated Press, which noticed parallels to former President Bill Clintons Reinventing Government initiative:

title: For Now, the Last of Lastings
description: As expected, Lastings Milledge was sent down to Class AAA New Orleans after Thursdays game to make room for todays starter, Mike Pelfrey. And as we have come to expect from Milledge, who has handled everything thrown at him during his brief stay (except major-league pitching) with grace and professionalism, he was particularly thoughtful in discussing his feelings.

title: As Sallie Maes Stock Jumps, Eyes Turn to Washington
description: Shares of Sallie Mae were up as much as 11 percent in early trading Friday as investors reacted to a report that the United States largest lender to college students was in talks about a possible buyout. The New York Times said the negotiations for Sallie Mae, formally known as SLM Corporation, were at a late stage and named Blackstone Group as one of the potential bidders. Sallie Maes stock surged $4.44 to $45.19 early Friday, giving the company a market capitalization of about $18.6 billion. Despite the rise, however, the shares are still well below their 52-week high of $55.21, which they reached in May 2006.

title: Las Cruces, N.M.
A Watergate Moment
description: Conservative blogger Captain Ed Morrissey acknowledges that the Bush administration has to turn over the mysterious missing e-mails that Karl Rove and others sent using addresses owned by the Republican National Committee: Now they have to open those files for Congress inspection in order to demonstrate that they have complied with the 1978 Presidential Records Act, a law that comes straight out of Watergate. But that doesnt mean he likes it. Morrissey writes:

title: K.K.R. May Seek a Public Partner in Coles Bid
description: To improve its bid for Australian retailer Coles Group, the consortium led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may partner with a public company, Reuters reported Friday citing an unnamed source. Analysts have said that a rival A$19.7 billion ($16.4 billion) bid by Wesfarmers, one of the countrys biggest conglomerates, is more attractive because it is in cash and stock.

title: Donald Shoup Super Fan No. 1
description: Who is Donald Shoup?

title: Worship
description: I don't know about you,but I practice a disorganized religion.I belong to an unholy disorder.We call ourselves,"Our Lady of Perpetual Astonishment."You may have seen us prayingfor loveon sidewalks outside the bettereating establishmentsin all kinds of weather.Blow us a kissupon arriving or departing,and we will climaxsimultaneously.It can be quite a scene,especially if it is rainingcats and dogs

title: Were Under Way
description: Having finally found (and hired) an architect, Alison and I headed off down a long country road in Beaufort for a celebratory (and working) lunch at the Shrimp Shack, a wonderful dive by the bridge to Hunting Island.

title: From the Archives: India
description: As Nick mentioned earlier were back in India. There were a trove of great stories from our last trip here in Jan. 2006. The best tales were about Indian women with exceptional courage.

title: Sound Design
description: Images of Jean Nouvel's Philharmonie de Paris.

title: Bloomberg Takes the Compliment
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wryly shrugged off the honor of being named Americas best mayor by Readers Digest in its May issue. In its Americas 100 Best tributes, the magazine said Mayor Bloomberg has championed a ban on smoking and trans fats in restaurants, pushed for bodegas to sell fresh produce and reduced-fat milk and luanched a diabetes registry, among the efforts.

title: Betting on Bling: Merrills Luxury Index
description: As some people fret about conspicuous consumption, high levels of consumer debt and the worlds growing income gap, Merrill Lynch has come up with a way for investors to profit from these trends. The investment bank has introduced a Luxury and Lifestyle Index, which it described in a press release as the first tradable certificate that tracks shares of luxury goods companies, such as BMW, Bulgari, and Bang & Olufsen. Merrills new index also includes some less-exclusive names such as Avon and The Gap.

title: Choosing Hip Resurfacing
description: Keith McDonald underwent hip resurfacing surgery, a newer alternative to total hip replacement.

title: No Promises on Second Avenue
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was non-committal this morning when asked if he could guarantee that the on-again, off-again Second Avenue subway line would finally be built.

title: Single Female Seeking Same-Race Male
description: Readers responded to my last post with lots of theories and personal reports on peoples preferences in interracial dating. Also some complaints that I seemed to be asking for comments about only whites and blacks  an impression I didnt mean to give. Researchers have been studying other races, too. Theyve found that theories and anecdotal evidence arent a very reliable guide to these questions: some of the common stereotypes dont match the data.

title: As Amaranth Moves Out, Goldman Moves In
description: If nothing else, this will be good news for cabbies of Greenwich, Conn. The newspaper in that town is reporting that Goldman Sachs has taken over the Greenwich offices formerly occupied by Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund firm that collapsed last year after losing about $6.5 billion on bad bets on natural-gas futures.

title: Citi Gets Its Hedge Fund, and Its Banker
description: Citigroup agreed to buy hedge fund Old Lane Partners as part of a deal that puts a former top executive at Morgan Stanley at the head of its alternative investments group. Citigroup, the global banking giant, has spent months courting the executive, Vikram Pandit, who left Morgan Stanley in 2005 after he was blocked for a chance at running the investment bank. Financial terms were not disclosed, but The New York Times reported Friday that the transaction was expected to cost $600 million to $800 million.

title: Cott Confirms Deal Talks After Stock Fizzes
description: Cott, the Canadian maker of private-label soft-drink brands for retailers such as Wal-Mart, said Friday that it is in talks with potential partners and is exploring the potential benefits of participating in possible industry consolidation. Cott didnt name any of the potential partners, but the press release included a reference to Cadbury Schweppes, which last month announced plans to split its candy division from its drinks division. The Wall Street Journal reported Friday that Cott is negotiating with private equity firms about combining its operations with Cadburys beverage arm. The report sent Cotts shares up nearly 30 percent.

title: Giulianis Campaign Numbers
description: While were still stressing out over tax day, the campaigns have an even more complicated set of numbers to turn in on April 15 (no, theres no grace period for them). First-quarter reports are due to the Federal Election Commission on Sunday, and the campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani just filed, a few days before the deadline. [Message from reporters: Thank you!]

title: The Little Extras
description: I wanted it to feel residential, Tom Ford said of his new store on Madison Avenue, with its suede-covered walls, sleek sofas, Italian cabinets and wet bar. This is penthouse residential, Bel-Air, where Ford has a Richard Neutra pavilion. Ford has sunk a lot of money, his own, into Tom Ford the store. And in the parlance of store designers, theres nothing run of the mill about the shopping experience. A butler named Jason greets you, a maid in white apron and gloves takes your coat. You will be invited to look at swatches, if you are interested in a custom-made suit, which start at $5,000. If you buy a shirt, it will be put into a handsome gray box and your name will be written on it. You might be told that a shoe last (with a slightly elevated heel) was identical to one that Gianni Agnelli liked.

title: Church Narrows the Gap on State
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Apr. 13 column, For Gods Sake.

title: Sallie Maes Option Trading Jumped Before Buyout Report
description: In a development that is growing steadily less surprising, Reuters reported Friday that trading of call options in Sallie Mae jumped Thursday ahead of a report by The New York Times that the student lender may go private. But some analysts said that the trading, while unusual, did not necessarily signal insider trading.

title: Where Have You Gone, Jeff Mangold?
description: A clubhouse turns its achy legs to you?

title: So What Should We Drink?
description: By now youre probably waiting to hear where I stand on the Don Imus issue.

title: In Darfur
description: My research assistant, Winter Miller, steadily developed an interest in Darfur, and a year ago she persuaded me to let her accompany me on . In retrospect, I probably shouldnt have agreed, because we traversed a rather dangerous no-mans-land that the Janjaweed was pillaging. At one point, our vehicle got stuck, and a bunch of Janjaweed kids helped push us out of the sand  but, fortunately, their dad wasnt around.

title: 3 New Suitors Step Up for ABN Amro
description: An all-out war for ABN Amro may be under way. Three bidders  the Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander Central Hispano and Fortis  have sent a letter to the Dutch bank asking to engage in exploratory talks, ABN Amro said in a statement Friday.

title: Clintons Fix for Government
description: When Al Gore wanted, in the early days of the Clinton administration, to illustrate the complexity and inefficiency of government procurement regulations, he went on David Lettermans show, picked up a hammer, and smashed a glass ashtray.

title: Frugal Traveler: A Cheap Room Puts Old San Juan Within Reach
description: Old San Juans greatest pleasure  simply strolling this beautiful place  costs nothing. Share your tips on how to visit San Juan frugally.

title: Looking Beyond Private Equitys Giants
description: Nearly all private equity deals are worth less than $1 billion, but you wouldnt know it from all the headlines about firms constantly leapfrogging each other to put together bigger buyouts.

title: Displacement and Destruction
description: Suaada Saadoun was the head of one of only four Sunni Arab households in a neighborhood in western Baghdad that has become a front line in the sectarian war.

title: McCain Is Nothing If Not Consistent
description: Readers respond to David Brookss April 12 column, The Fatalist.

title: Imus Took It a Step Too Far
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Apr. 12 column, Paying the Price.

title: Blogtalk
description: A message in the downfall of Don Imus. [TalkLeft]

title: Romneys Primary-Only Money
description: Mitt Romney has just reported his first quarter fund-raising numbers to the Federal Election Commission, and, as predicted, even though he raised significantly more than Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Romneys higher spending rate puts them on almost equal footing in terms of available cash.

title: Youre Not Going to Believe This
description: Or maybe you are. Carl Pavano has been scratched from his start tomorrow. All Ive heard so far is its a sore arm. I expect well have a lot more details when the clubhouse opens here in Oakland in about five minutes.

title: CBS Poll Finds Republican Envy
description: Most Democratic primary voters are satisfied with the current field of candidates for their partys Presidential nomination, while their Republican counterparts wish they had more choices, according to the latest CBS News Poll.

title: Google Buys DoubleClick for $3.1 Billion
description: Google reached an agreement Friday to acquire DoubleClick, the online advertising company, from two private equity firms for $3.1 billion in cash, the companies announced, an amount that was almost double the $1.65 billion in stock that Google paid for YouTube late last year.

title: A Portrait of a Painter
description: Alice Neel feeds pigeons from the window of her apartment, plus an excerpt from Michel Auder's video documentary "Portrait of Alice Neel 1976-1982."

title: In A Painter's Home
description: Richard and Hartley Neel talk about the painter, Alice Neel, in her apartment on West 107th Street.

title: A Question for the Class of 2007
description: What is the most useful thing you learned in college?

title: Only 21, Already a King
description: Felix Hernandez of the Seattle Mariners turned 21 years old last Sunday, but he has already won 20 games in the major leagues and has the kind of stuff that makes me think he might win about 180 more.

title: Vows: Kimberly and Stefano
description: The romance between Kimberly Young and Stefano Rivella began on the dance floor.

title: Sunni Nuclear Concerns
description: Iran's decision to continue uranium enrichment has led some  countries to consider pursuing civilian nuclear technology.

title: Blogtalk: The Case of the Missing E-Mails
description: Each development in the saga of the fired United States attorneys story digs deep battle lines within the political blogosphere. The revelations that Bush administration and Justice Department staffers discussed the issue on their Republican National Committee e-mail accounts and that those e-mails may have been deleted added fuel to an already burning fire. While conservative blogs have been quiet so far on the case of the missing emails, the left-leaning blogs dug right in.

title: Finding the Best Around-the-world Ticket Fare
description: We are stationed in Germany, and when we return to the States after our tour, we wish to travel via Australia and Okinawa, Japan, to visit friends. Would this merit an around-the-world ticket? If so, where would I research the options? Is one carrier known to have less expensive fares?

title: And You Get Cool Stuff, Too
description: If youve been watching any of the Mets games on television this season, perhaps youve seen camera shots of players sitting in the dugout wearing wool winter caps with the team logo on them. At the start of the season, players and team personnel are given every article of clothing imaginable with the Mets insignia: socks, pants, several different types of T-shirts, sweatshirts, hats, polo shirts, dress shirts, and the list goes on. For the most part, those cloths are useful year-round. But the winter caps?

title: Air Travel in India
description: Theres nothing quite like opening the paper and seeing this image as your plane is headed down the runway destined for India.

title: An Origami Flag
description: The Times Magazine asked 10 artists to design 'green' flags to illustrate Thomas L. Friedman's cover story. Here's how origami artist Robert J. Lang created his flag.

title: "Frankenstein" and "Slippery Jim"
description: Clips from the 1900s: "Frankenstein" by J. Searle Dewley is an American film, and "Jim le Glisseur (Slippery Jim)" by Ferdinand Zecca comes from France.

title: The Return of FuturePhone?
description: A few months back, I wrote about the miracle that was Futurephone: a service that offered free unlimited overseas calls.

title: Pavano to Start on Tuesday?
description: Thats what Joe Torre is saying. Thats what Carl Pavano is saying. But its really hard to believe that.

title: The World Since 9/11, in Detail and Sorrow
description: Apparently, a church dance in Greeley, Colo., led to 9/11.

title: Markets Suffer After Russia Bans Immigrant Vendors
description: MOSCOW, April 13  From a stall inside the Rizhskiy vegetable market, Rustam K. Umarov conducts an illegal trade in oregano, cinnamon sticks, peppercorns, saffron powder and shish kebab marinade.

title: Knicks Hopes Are Shaky in Middle
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: It Isnt Saltwater Under the Bridge
description: VALENCIA, Spain  Grant Dalton was on the shore and watching on television as Team New Zealand shattered equipment and a countrys illusions during the last Americas Cup.

title: Building a Paris Hall Around Its Audience
description: PARIS, April 13  Over the last two decades, as successive French governments have poured money into renovating the Louvre and building new museums, an opera house and a national library in Paris, lovers of orchestral music here grew resentful.

title: Isles to Wait Until Game Time to Decide if DiPietro Will Play
description: AMHERST, N.Y., April 13  By most appearances, Rick DiPietro is ready to return to the net Saturday night for Game 2 of the Islanders first-round playoff series against the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Rights Groups in Zimbabwe Tally Attacks on Opposition
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 13  Human rights groups in Zimbabwe have begun to document in numbers and names an extraordinary government campaign of abductions and beatings aimed at critics of President Robert G. Mugabe.

title: Correction: The End of the Dispensable Iranian
description: An Op-Ed article on Tuesday, about the 10th anniversary of a German courts verdict in the assassination of four Iranian Kurdish leaders, incorrectly described the role of Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, the incumbent, in the 1997 Iranian presidential race. He did not run for re-election.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) UNITED 93 (2006). The film opens with four Muslim men praying in a hotel room. It quickly cuts to the interior of a plane, where pilots have just picked up a dispatch warning them to guard against possible cockpit intrusion. Two minutes later, at 9:28 a.m., the men  Ziad Jarrah (Khalid Abdalla), Saeed al-Ghamdi (Lewis Alsamari), Ahmed al-Haznawi (Omar Berdouni) and Ahmed al-Nami (Jamie Harding)  have broken into the cockpit and taken control. What happens next is mostly unknown until 10:03 a.m. on Sept. 11, 2001, when, after passengers try to break down the cockpit door, the plane, United 93, plows into a field in Pennsylvania, killing everyone aboard. (Above, Becky London and Tom ORourke as the passengers Jean and Donald Peterson.) Using information from the 9/11 Commission Report, Paul Greengrass tells the story of the passengers who decided they would rather go down fighting.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about an exhibition of Roman mosaics from Tunisia at the Getty Villa in Pacific Palisades, Calif., misstated the date of the battle of Thapsus, in which Julius Caesar ensured Roman control of North Africa. It took place in 46 B.C., not 47 B.C. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the commander of Caesars opponents. They were led by Pompeys father-in-law, not by Pompey, who had been murdered.

title: Though Not in Aprils Rhythm, Pelfrey Doesnt Miss a Beat
description: Mike Pelfrey spent the last two weeks in Florida pitching, eating, waiting, working out, waiting, pitching, watching movies, working out and waiting some more until the day finally came for him to fly to New York and be a bona fide major leaguer again.

title: When Body and Mind Share the Suffering
description: Amanda Loulaki and her trio of dancers appear to be well into the aftershock stage when the lights rise on Delirium, or that taste in my mouth, which had its premiere on Thursday at Danspace Project. Torsos shudder and clench, legs splay; its as if some great upset has occurred, and their bodies are only now registering its effects.

title: World View Podcast
description: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

title: A Parable Cuts Across Cultures, Using the Sparest of Blades
description: Candle flames flicker. Water sloshes. Monks chant. An organ keens. A madwoman mourns her dead child. Benjamin Brittens Curlew River, a not-quite-opera dubbed a church parable by its composer, cuts across cultures, from Japanese to Western Christianity, to channel a sense of dark ritual borne on music.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about a dispute in which Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard law professor, is trying to block Norman Finkelstein, a political science professor, from gaining tenure at DePaul University in Chicago included an incorrect reference to DePaul that Mr. Finkelstein attributed to a dean there who opposes tenure for him. While DePaul is a Roman Catholic university, it is not Jesuit, and Mr. Finkelstein acknowledges that the dean, Charles Suchar, did not say that it is. The article also misstated Mr. Suchars middle initial. It is S, not E.

title: Car Keys Could Go the Way of Tail Fins
description: Are we about to lose our car keys for good?

title: Google Buys DoubleClick for $3.1 Billion
description: Google reached an agreement today to acquire DoubleClick, the online advertising company, from two private equity firms for $3.1 billion in cash, the companies announced, an amount that was almost double the $1.65 billion in stock that Google paid for YouTube late last year.

title: Lawyer Attacked for Book His Panel Deems Offensive
description: ALBANY, April 13  Raoul Felder, a celebrity divorce lawyer who is chairman of a state commission that oversees judges, has been given a unanimous vote of no confidence by the other nine members of the commission for helping to write a book they said is racially and ethnically inflammatory.

title: Direct Any Hate Mail to Imus, His Wife Says
description: A day after CBS Radio canceled Imus in the Morning, Don Imuss wife, Deirdre, was co-host of a radiothon to benefit childrens charities on WFAN, the New York radio station that had broadcast Mr. Imuss show.

title: A Turtle Goes Home, in Old-School Style
description: Tomorrow nights installment of Nature on PBS, plaintively titled Voyage of the Lonely Turtle, is an odd throwback. Its the animal documentary as sentimental epic, with a stentorian voice  in this case F. Murray Abrahams  narrating, a little too poetically, the dangerous journey of a creature driven by some genetic imperative to travel thousands of miles.

title: Courts and Greens
description: A little over four years ago, when the forces of deregulation were riding high, this page observed that the federal courts could turn out to be the last, best hope for slowing the Bush administrations assault on the body of bipartisan environmental law established over the last four decades and, by extension, on the environment itself.

title: In a Filmdom Premiere, a Foe for Gore
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 13  The screening here on Thursday night had many elements of a classic film-world shindig. There were gift bags and television cameras, cold cocktails and hot popcorn. Ushers showed V.I.P.s to their seats, and local politicos rubbed shoulders with the movies backers and flacks.

title: Prokofievs Take on Pushkins Czar, Revealed at Last
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 12  Sergei Prokofiev and Vsevolod Meyerhold, the Russian stage director, scorned Modest Mussorgskys music for his opera Boris Godunov. The opera was based on Aleksandr Pushkins play about Godunov, the 16th-century czar, and they hoped to present what they believed would be a more accurate representation of Pushkins vision with a 1936 staging featuring a new score by Prokofiev.

title: Pavano Is Latest Name on Growing Injured List
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 13  The Yankees most often injured player has added himself to their growing list of injured pitchers. Carl Pavano, who missed most of the last two seasons with a variety of ailments, will miss his start here Saturday with stiffness in his right arm.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A dance review on April 2 about Colors of Rajasthan at Symphony Space in Manhattan, citing information in the program, misidentified the musician who played the wooden blocks. He was Bhawroo Khan Langa, not Habib Khan Langa. (Habib Khan Langa played the bowed lute and double flute.)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Friday and in some copies on Thursday about the writer Kurt Vonnegut referred incorrectly to the military role of the character Billy Pilgrim in the Vonnegut novel Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Childrens Crusade, set in Europe during World War II. Pilgrim was a chaplains assistant, not an infantry scout, although he encounters scouts in his travels and joins up with them.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,285 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Earnings Up for Cuomo and Spitzer in Last Year
description: ALBANY, April 13  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos earnings doubled last year even though he left his previous job midway through 2006, according to financial information that he released on Friday.

title: Citigroup Adds Hedge Fund and Its Leader
description: For nearly a year, Charles O. Prince III had been courting a former top Morgan Stanley investment banker. Yesterday, he got his man  Vikram S. Pandit, who will head Citigroups alternative investments group. But Mr. Prince may be paying a steep price.

title: Immigration, Through Many Lenses (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Amaker Brings Baggage to Harvard
description: BOSTON, April 13  Harvards director of athletics, Robert L. Scalise, introduced Tommy Amaker as the mens basketball coach Friday with a nod to Amakers credentials, telling a room packed with reporters and alumni about Amakers 19 postseason appearances in 23 years as a college player, assistant coach and head coach.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on April 3 about a plan by the New York City Department of Correction to reopen and expand the Brooklyn House of Detention in Boerum Hill referred incorrectly to a community leader who opposes the reopening. Sandy Balboza, president of the Atlantic Avenue Betterment Association, is a woman.

title: Wintry Conditions Have Interfered With a Rite of Spring
description: It was chilly in Cleveland yesterday afternoon, but Bob DiBiasio, the vice president for public relations for the Indians, said the sun was shining. DiBiasio had not seen any kind of consistent sunshine in a while, especially on a day when the Indians were scheduled to play a home game.

title: Kiss Kiss, Vroom Vroom: They Were Born to Drive
description: Redline tells a simple story: high rollers bet on car races along the Los Angeles-Las Vegas corridor; an Iraq veteran (Nathan Phillips) returns home to find his brother in trouble with a counterfeiter; a singer (Nadia Bjorlin) raised near a racecourse takes a driving gig to secure a record deal; she is coerced into driving for the crook; the ex-soldier must liberate her.

title: G.E.s Earnings Increase 2%; High-Cost Products Sell Well
description: The General Electric Company benefited from robust sales of engines, turbines and other big-ticket items in the first quarter, even as it grappled with problems in its consumer finance, plastics and health care businesses.

title: Report Accuses CA Founder Wang of Overseeing Accounting Fraud
description: Charles B. Wang, the founder and former chairman of Computer Associates, oversaw a decade-long accounting fraud at the software company, according to a report released Friday by the companys directors.

title: Exile Is Rebuked for Urging Ouster of Putin
description: LONDON, April 13  Boris A. Berezovsky, a self-exiled Russian tycoon, earned sharp rebukes from London and Moscow on Friday when he urged the forceful ouster of Vladimir V. Putin as president of Russia and a new revolution there.

title: Combat, With Limits, Looms for Hybrid Aircraft
description: The Marine Corps said yesterday that the V-22 Osprey, a hybrid aircraft with a troubled past, will be sent to Iraq this September, where it will see combat for the first time.

title: A Rebel-Turned-Governor Takes the Wheel in Indonesia
description: BIREUN, Indonesia

title: Stan Daniels, 72, a Writer of Emmy-Winning Sitcoms, Dies
description: Stan Daniels, a television writer who won Emmy Awards for his work on the groundbreaking situation comedies Taxi and The Mary Tyler Moore Show, died April 6 at his home in Encino, Calif. He was 72.

title: Hip Surgery With a Future
description: Hip replacement, an operation that about 300,000 Americans undergo each year, is one of the great success stories of modern medicine.

title: Barry Nelson, Broadway and Film Actor, Dies at 86
description: Barry Nelson, an actor who had a long career in film and television, starred in some of the more durable Broadway comedies of the 1950s and 60s, and achieved a permanent place in the minds of trivia buffs as the first actor to portray James Bond, died last Saturday, his wife said yesterday. He was 86.

title: Mimi Lerner, 61, Opera Singer With an Unconventional Career, Dies
description: Mimi Lerner, an internationally renowned mezzo-soprano and educator who came to the operatic stage late in life, died on March 29 in Pittsburgh. She was 61.

title: An Amazing Race, With Cars as the Stars
description: Insincerity pervades Drive, the mysterious drama about a cross-country road race that starts tomorrow on Fox. Its apparent in the wooden performances, the on-the-nose score and the sterile stagecraft.

title: Talk of Possible $20 Billion Deal for Sallie Mae Pushes Shares Higher
description: Shares of Sallie Mae, the nations largest lender to college students, surged nearly 15 percent yesterday on the prospects that the company could be bought out in a deal worth more than $20 billion.

title: Reginald H. Fuller, 92, New Testament Scholar, Dies
description: Reginald H. Fuller, a prominent British-born New Testament scholar who used his knowledge of Hebrew and Greek to hunt for the historical Jesus and his fluency in German to debate the nuances with theologians, died on April 4 in Richmond, Va. He was 92.

title: E-Mail Identified G.O.P. Candidates for Justice Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  A Justice Department e-mail message released on Friday shows that the former chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales proposed replacement candidates for United States attorneys nearly a year before they were dismissed in December 2006. The department has repeatedly stated that no successors were selected before the dismissals.

title: A Building for Diller by Gehry
description: It was raining hard Thursday morning as I headed to the new headquarters of IAC/InterActiveCorp, Barry Dillers Internet conglomerate, as he likes to call it. Although some employees had been working there since February  the guinea pigs, joked Jason Stewart, IACs chief administrative officer  the building had been officially open for business less than two weeks.

title: A Catholic Debate Mounts on the Meaning of Just War
description: For over four years, George Weigel, staunch supporter of President Bush and biographer of Pope John Paul II, has never ceased to insist that the war in Iraq meets all the traditional moral criteria for a just war. And most leaders and thinkers among Mr. Weigels fellow Roman Catholics, along with many non-Catholic proponents of just-war thinking, have never ceased to disagree.

title: Say Good Night, Bandwidth Hog
description: AN article in PC Magazine last week revealed that customers across the country have received letters from Comcast warning them to limit their bandwidth consumption or face a one-year termination of service.

title: Wolfowitz Fight Has Subplot
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  When President Bush appointed Paul D. Wolfowitz as the president of the World Bank two years ago, the White House had to put down an insurrection among European nations that viewed the administrations best-known neoconservative as a symbol of American unilateralism and arrogance.

title: Vatican Envoy to Avoid Holocaust Ceremony
description: JERUSALEM, April 13  The Vaticans ambassador to Israel has said he will skip the official Holocaust Remembrance Day ceremony at a national museum here on Sunday to protest the museums depiction of Pope Pius XII as a largely passive bystander to the murder of Jews during World War II.

title: Theft Empties Pantry, but Hungry Keep Coming
description: Down at the end of a narrow, stuccoed hallway on the ground floor of a low-income high-rise, Kezlie Mulbah waited with an empty stomach.

title: Republican Candidates Set Fast Pace for Spending
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Mitt Romney, whose presidential campaign leads the Republican primary field in fund-raising, spent nearly 60 percent of the $20.7 million he raised in the first quarter, setting a breakneck pace for the start of the 2008 race.

title: In Charge Again, Codey Plans No Surprises
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 13  Stranded by a punctured tire, Richard J. Codey, the State Senate president, was waiting for a ride home from the parking lot of his district office here on Thursday night when a stranger marveled that he was even standing, let alone contemplating changing the flat.

title: Chinese Composer Talks Cello, All Dialects
description: As Huang Ruo originally conceived it, his new cello concerto, People Mountain People Sea, was to have started not with music but with a recorded voice  Mr. Huangs  speaking in a made-up language, accompanying projected photographs of China in the 1920s. The photographs, by Sidney Gamble, inspired the piece, but after spending an afternoon in a studio recording his speech and trying out this multimedia introduction at the Miller Theater, where the work is to have its premiere tonight, Mr. Huang decided to drop it.

title: Political Rsum, Not Court, Stood Out for a Contender
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Rachel L. Brand, by her own admission, has never prosecuted so much as a traffic case. But in January 2006, when Justice Department officials began to discuss removing some United States attorneys, Ms. Brand was proposed as the top federal prosecutor in the Western District of Michigan, an e-mail message released on Friday shows.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the scant evidence of voter fraud that has been found since the Bush administration began a crackdown five years ago misstated a court ruling on a 2003 Texas Congressional redistricting law. While the Supreme Court ruled that the Texas Legislature violated the Voting Rights Act in redrawing a southwestern Texas district, the court upheld the other parts of the plan. It did not strike down the law.

title: Hernndez Loses Control as Mets Fall
description: Orlando Hernndez responded as if he meant no harm when he hit Shawn Hill, the Washington Nationals starter, on the right hand with a pitch during the sixth inning at Shea Stadium yesterday. When Hill reached first base, Hernndez motioned to him, apologizing for the errant pitch.

title: Officer Is Cleared of Felony Counts
description: A New York City police detective was acquitted yesterday of some of the most serious charges relating to a 2004 off-duty car accident on Staten Island in which he was accused of driving drunk and injuring two women in another car.

title: Snap Judgments of Israel, More Than Words Can Say
description: The Jewish Museum is probably not the first place you would look for a tough but impartial critique of Arab-Israeli politics. And you dont find one in Dateline Israel: New Photography and Video Art, a survey of recent art that takes Israel as its subject.

title: Giants Add Backup for Manning
description: After two seasons of backing up Eli Manning with a pair of inexperienced quarterbacks, the Giants have added a passer with more comprehensive credentials.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A dance review on Thursday about John Butler: An American Master, performed by the Richmond Ballet and guest artists at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the presenter. It was the John Butler Foundation, not the Richmond Ballet.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an agreement by Sallie Mae, the nations largest student lender, to settle an investigation by New Yorks attorney general into relationships between universities and student loan companies misidentified in some copies the lender that runs call centers for financial aid offices at Texas Tech and Wayne State University. It is Nelnet, not Sallie Mae.

title: Banker Gathers His Defenders, but There Arent Many
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Paul D. Wolfowitz, the embattled president of the World Bank, worked behind the scenes on Friday to gain the support of finance and development ministers from around the world, but there were few endorsements of his leadership outside the Bush administration.

title: Wellesley Class Sees One of Us Bearing Standard
description: For her Wellesley classmates, Hillary Clintons quest to become the first female president is a generational mirror. Some like what they see; others are less certain.

title: Washington Dares to Challenge the Lender It Depends Upon
description: IS it risky for a big borrower to offend its largest lender?

title: Sales Abroad Propping Up the Economy
description: A weakening economy is getting some relief from abroad as American companies step up their sales to foreigners, the latest data, released yesterday, suggests.

title: Tools to Keep the Web Safe for Children
description: RECENTLY, a friends 9-year-old son stumbled onto some all-too-vivid pornography while playing games on a childrens Web site.

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: If Its a Merger, 2nd Thoughts Should Follow
description: THE term merger mania may be more than a snappy description of the recent pace of corporate deal-making. It could be an astute diagnosis of a malady spreading through boardrooms and financial markets.

title: An Uncertain Prognosis, and Many Risks
description: Like any victim of life-threatening injuries, Gov. Jon S. Corzines recovery will be a step-by-step process measured initially by the hour.

title: Ex-Senator Will Not Run for Governor of Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 13  A former United States Senator, John B. Breaux, ended his monthslong flirtation with the Louisiana governors race Friday evening, declaring that he would be not be a candidate in the election this fall.

title: A Lender Sought Favor at College, Papers Say
description: A top executive of a student loan company asked Capella University to re-order its list of recommended lenders, according to documents being reviewed by Senate officials who are examining the relationship between the loan company and the academic institution.

title: Wit and Panache in the British Fashion, Without All That Grand-Gesture Rubbish
description: Boys and girls of New York City, Ricky Wilson said. You are familiar with our work? Or maybe it was a triumphant answer, not a leading question: You are familiar with our work! It could even have been a chiding reminder: You are familiar with our work  so act like it.

title: Music in Review
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC

title: Woman in Gang Assault Trial Says Man Started the Fight
description: As the independent filmmaker told it, he made an innocuous remark, on the order of Hi, howre you doing? to a pretty woman walking by, and inexplicably found himself spat at, pummeled and stabbed by a pack of marauding lesbians. But one of the lesbians, who is charged with attempted murder, took the witness stand in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday and told a different version of the story, in which the man was a raunchy, cigarette-throwing aggressor.

title: When the Bidding and Discard Yield Key Clues
description: West led the spade three.

title: Hospital Sues Insurer, Charging Conspiracy
description: A Brooklyn hospital has sued one of the city's largest health insurers, asserting it conspired with doctors and others to wrongfully deny coverage for patients.

title: Whose Job Is It, Anyway?
description: We have long suspected that there is no one in charge of the Iraq war. How else can you explain four years of multifront failures, including President Bushs most recent plan to order even more American troops to risk their lives there without demanding any political sacrifice or even compromise from Iraqs leaders? So we were not surprised to hear that White House officials are looking for someone to oversee both Iraq and the faltering Afghanistan war and not surprised that they were having a tough time filling the job.

title: Corzine Facing Severe Hurdles in Intensive Care
description: TRENTON, April 13  Relying on a ventilator to help him breathe, Gov. Jon S. Corzine was in intensive care at a Camden hospital on Friday night as his children and colleagues wrestled with a litany of medical and political uncertainties after a devastating traffic accident in which he was by all accounts not wearing a seat belt.

While Elena Lappin translated the book from the Czech, David Curzon helped her translate that poem and another in the book called Remembering Prague.

title: Guardedly Kicking the Tires on Chrysler
description: DETROIT, April 13  Dieter Zetsche, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, found out last summer that selling cars as a TV pitchman is harder than it looks.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 13  Isiah Thomas wore a grim expression. Down to his left, Jamal Crawford and Quentin Richardson wore suits. David Lee and Stephon Marbury wore warmups that they never shed.

April 13  Facing a hailstorm of criticism for pressing sexual assault charges against three men he now agrees were wrongly accused, the Durham County district attorney was before a hearing on Friday where his lawyers argued for dismissal of the most serious ethics charge against him.

description: An article yesterday about an apology by the district attorney in Durham County, N.C., to three former Duke lacrosse players whom he had charged with sexual assault in a case that was later dismissed gave an erroneous identification in some copies for the player represented by James P. Cooney III. He is a lawyer for Reade W. Seligmann, not Collin Finnerty.

description: Although it circled Mars longer than any other spacecraft, the Mars Global Surveyor did not die a death of old age last November, a review board assembled by NASA announced yesterday.

description: Lily Wheelwright and Ry Russo-Young were friends while growing up in the West Village and pursuing their artistic dreams as classmates at Saint Anns School in Brooklyn. So when Ms. Russo-Young became a writer-director and began casting her first full-length movie, Orphans, it seemed somehow fitting that she would pick Ms. Wheelwright for one of the two lead characters.

title: Pope Describes His Book on Jesus as a Personal View, Not Doctrine
description: VATICAN CITY, April 13  A pope, by definition, stands for certainty, at times even infallibility. So a few words from Benedict XVI in the first book of his two-year papacy may come as a surprise.

title: Corzines Vital Signs Improving Slowly, Doctors Say
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Apr. 14  Gov. Jon S. Corzine underwent an hourlong surgery today to clean the leg wound he suffered during a car crash Thursday, and doctors said he is exhibiting signs of improvement that bolster their confidence that he had escaped any brain or spinal injury.

title: Schumer and State Legislators Seek to Block Starrett City Sale
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer joined Democratic members of the State Assembly yesterday in a campaign to keep Starrett City from being sold in a $1.3 billion deal that they say would doom the vast Brooklyn housing complex as an affordable home for poor and working-class tenants.

title: Attacking Bush, Clinton Urges Government Overhaul
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., April 13  Saying that the last six years had shaken the faith of many Americans in our government, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed a series of initiatives on Friday to make the federal government more competent, effective and thrifty.

title: In the Spotlight, the Politics of Buckling Up
description: As constituents and public officials wished Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey a full recovery from his injuries in a car accident, many were shaking their heads that someone who is so smart, and has so much to lose, would put himself at risk by apparently not wearing a seat belt.

title: A Boxer Tests How Far His Popularity Will Carry Him
description: Manny Pacquiao, a championship super featherweight boxer, is largely known as a uniting force in his native Philippines. When he fights, it has been said, the streets clear, crime drops and people gather around their televisions.

title: A Conversation With Michel Bonnefous
description: Michel Bonnefous was general manager of the winning team during the last Americas Cup, but he is trying to project neutrality this time.

title: Shock Talk Without Apologies
description: There has to be an Imus event every once in a while. Ethnicity being the volatile thing it is, gratuitously inflammatory remarks have to be discouraged, so bounds of acceptable speech have to be clarified. Clarity comes when, inevitably, someone oversteps and gets slapped down.
