description: To the Editor:

title: Taking His Theater Talent Well Over the Rainbow
description: Remember happenings? I dont, actually. The term dates from the 1960s, when it was used to describe aesthetic events of somewhat spontaneous origin and general fabulousness. It has a quaint ring now, but it sprang to mind recently when I found myself searching for a way to describe the eruption of something unusual  and, yes, fabulous  in the middle of Terrence McNallys Some Men, a sweet, sentimental and otherwise unexceptional comedy of gay life in 20th-century America at the Second Stage Theater.

title: Google Buys an Online Ad Firm for $3.1 Billion
description: Google agreed to its largest acquisition yesterday, reaching a deal to purchase DoubleClick, the online advertising company, from two private equity firms for $3.1 billion in cash, almost double what it paid for YouTube last year. And perhaps just as important, the deal kept DoubleClick from the hands of Microsoft.

title: A Portrait of the Big City, Painted in Little Moments
description: Speed-dial the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts right away: there is just tonight left to see Larry Keigwins Bolero NYC, a joyful and breathtakingly clever celebration of the city and its people that is probably the most inexpensive legal fun to be had for miles around.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An appraisal in The Arts on Tuesday about the cartoonist Johnny Hart, who died last Saturday, misspelled the given name of another comic strip artist who, like Mr. Hart, grew up listening to radio comedians and watching the movies of Charlie Chaplin and Laurel and Hardy. He is Mell Lazarus, not Mel. The appraisal also incorrectly rendered the name of a weekly publication Mr. Hart sold cartoons to early in his career. It was Colliers, not Colliers.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Illinois, Hunters Discover Ideal Setting for Trophy Bucks
description: PITTSFIELD, Ill.  The natural abilities of the United States most widely distributed big-game animal, the white-tailed deer, are amazing. It can leap tall fences, see small movement from a great distance, and even tell if a tiny, drifting scent belongs to the same farmer who is out in his fields regularly or to one of the human predators who infiltrate the woods every fall.

title: Car Bomb Kills Dozens in Iraqi City of Karbala
description: A car bomber struck this morning near a bus station in the holy city of Karbala, one of the main pilgrimage destinations for Shiites, killing at least 34 people, including several children, according to the governor and security officials.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A listing of credits in Weekend on April 6 with a film review of Grindhouse, based on information provided by a publicist, omitted an editor of one part of the film and erroneously credited another editor with both parts. The Planet Terror segment was edited by Robert Rodriguez and Ethan Maniquis, not by Mr. Rodriguez and Sally Menke. Ms. Menke edited only the Death Proof part of the film.

title: Museum Honors Hispanic Culture
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 12  With a hot pink carpet on the sidewalk and a 600-piece mariachi band in the wings, this city has swung into fiesta mode to welcome the nations largest Latino museum, a collaboration with the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Oversight Report Says U.S. Food Aid Practices Are Wasteful
description: The United States governments food aid programs are riddled with wasteful practices, including the inherently inefficient sale of American-grown food in poor countries to finance antipoverty programs run by aid groups, according to a report by the Government Accountability Office released yesterday.

title: Breaking the Truth Barrier
description: TUESDAY, April 15, 1947, dawned wet and cold. But the eager crowd at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn didnt care. Before the game, 15 photographers hovered around the Brooklyn Dodgers new first baseman. Ill be No. 42, he had joked to his wife that morning. Just in case you have trouble picking me out.

title: Street Sense Looks to Be the Favorite in the Derby
description: Among the two dozen or so horses in consideration for the Kentucky Derby, there is no head of the class. The prep races have largely been slowly run affairs and the winners have not done enough to generate much buzz. But a 3-year-old colt named Street Sense could change all that today in Lexington, Ky.

title: CA Says Its Founder Aided Fraud
description: Correction Appended

title: Beware of Lapsing Ethicists
description: With a healthy sense of political survival, House freshmen who campaigned against Congressional corruption are prodding the new Democratic majority to deliver on its promises of ethics reform. Commendable progress was made in January, when the House tightened its rules against accepting gifts from lobbyists. But there is still worrying foot-dragging on the key question of reform: whether to create an independent entity to oversee the integrity of lawmakers, rather than leaving that job solely to the less-than-vigilant House ethics committee.

title: The Tibet They Never Knew
description: Dreaming Lhasa, a dramatic feature film from the documentarians Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, is about a Tibetan-American documentary filmmaker named Karma (Tenzin Chokyi Gyatso) making a movie about the plight of Tibetans who fled persecution by the Chinese and settled in Dharamsala, the Dalai Lamas exile headquarters in northern India.

title: A Play About the War (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Science of Attacking Cholesterol
description: Science is making progress in understanding how cholesterol damages human health, and the pharmaceutical industry is tackling the challenge with a variety of drugs, says Fred Hassan, chairman and chief executive of Schering-Plough.

title: Qaeda Group in Iraq Says It Led Attack on Parliament
description: BAGHDAD, April 13  An umbrella insurgent group that includes Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia claimed responsibility on Friday for a brazen suicide bombing the previous day inside the Parliament building. The attack killed one legislator and wounded at least 22 other people.

title: Lottery Used to Narrow Work Visa Petitions
description: Swamped by petitions for work visas from highly educated or skilled foreigners, immigration authorities have conducted a lottery for the first time to determine which ones will be considered, federal officials announced yesterday.

title: Nose With an Imagination, and Hard-Boiled Crime
description: She walks in smelling like mashed potatoes, and every guy within 30 feet wants to be the gravy. Such mouthfuls of hard-boiled nonsense regularly erupt from Luther Pinks (James Todd Smith, a k a LL Cool J, as he is billed) in Slow Burn, a wooden police thriller that is as dull as it is impenetrable and ultimately beyond ludicrous. Luther has a thing about odors. People and places conjure the scents of grapefruit, mangoes and tangerines and even Big Macs in his amazingly sensitive nostrils.

title: New Appointments at the Times Company
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that Todd Haskell, the vice president for business development for the media group, will take on the added responsibility of advertising on The New York Times Web site.

title: More Con Than Neo
description: WASHINGTON

title: Afghanistan: British Soldier Killed
description: A British soldier was killed and two others wounded in a firefight in southern Helmand Province, a day after two NATO soldiers were reported killed in separate roadside bombings. The British death brings the number of NATO soldiers killed in the last week to 12. Of the other nationalities known, eight were Canadians who had been deployed in southern Kandahar and one was an American soldier, killed in the east. Fighting has also been reported in Helmand and Zabul Provinces.

title: Rangers Reap Benefits of Having Hossa in Lineup
description: ATLANTA, April 13  Rangers Coach Tom Renney wanted to keep left wing Marcel Hossas shifts short in Game 1 against the Thrashers. After all, the 25-year-old Hossa had missed the past month with an injured left knee.

title: New Jersey Man Appears Before Tribunal in Ethiopia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 13  Amir Mohamed Meshal, an American terrorism suspect jailed in Ethiopia, appeared in front of a military tribunal there on Friday, but Ethiopian officials did not disclose the outcome.

title: Japan: Chinese Premier Ends Visit With a Charm Offensive
description: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China wrapped up a three-day visit to Japan, saying that the two nations had reached broad consensus on how to move their relations forward but still needed time to resolve their many differences. Mr. Wen spent his last day trying to show the softer side of Chinas leadership to Japanese who have grown anxious in recent years of Chinas economic rise and growing military strength. Mr. Wen met farmers and played baseball with students at Ritsumeikan University in Kyoto.

title: Maryland Takes the Lead
description: As the nation braces for a long and numbing presidential election, the State of Maryland has done voters a favor by rejecting the Electoral College as a fossil in need of a democratic makeover. Gov. Martin OMalley and the Annapolis legislature made the state the first in the nation to decide that its Electoral College members should someday be required to vote for the presidential candidate chosen by a plurality of the nations voters, not according to the states parochial tally.

title: Companion of Wolfowitz Rejects Portrayal
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Before she became the subject of intensive news coverage as the companion of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the World Bank president, Shaha Ali Riza was known as a highly educated international bureaucrat who worked on issues related to women and girls in developing countries.

title: In a Highway Instant, a Driver Is Tested
description: Police officials were scouring New Jersey yesterday for a red Ford pickup truck that is believed to have fled the scene Thursday evening after setting off the chain-reaction accident in which Gov. Jon S. Corzine was seriously injured, officials said.

title: Lawyer Says Rove Assumed E-Mail Was Kept
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  Karl Rove, the chief political strategist for President Bush, did not intentionally delete e-mail messages to avoid creating a paper trail detailing his work, his lawyer said on Friday. Rather, he mistakenly thought that the messages were being preserved by the Republican National Committee.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Thursday about New York City Ballets offer of free tickets to the final dress rehearsal of its new production of Romeo and Juliet misstated the date when they will be distributed, beginning at 9 a.m., at the New York State Theater box office. It is April 22, not tomorrow.

title: Warren E. Preece, 85, Who Revamped Encyclopedia Britannica, Dies
description: Warren E. Preece, a former editor of The Encyclopaedia Britannica who in the early 1970s shepherded it through its first major redesign in decades, a task he likened publicly to fighting a war, died on Wednesday in Philadelphia. He was 85 and had lived in Philadelphia in recent years.

title: Talkers in Trouble, on the Radio and at a Chemical Giant
description: THE flameout of the radio host Don Imus dominated the discourse this week, but there was other intrigue, including what Dow Chemical said were unauthorized merger talks held by two of its officials and the continuing investigation into the practices of student loan companies.

title: Financially, Solar Power for the Home Is a Tough Sell
description: With a $2,000 federal tax credit and generous rebates from states like New Jersey and California, it has never cost less to install a solar power system.

title: Post-Imus, WFAN Opts for More Sports, for Now
description: Whenever Don Imus left for vacation, traveled west to his cattle ranch for children with cancer in New Mexico or was hospitalized for his various ailments, there was never a doubt that he would return to the WFAN radio studio in Astoria, Queens, or, in later years, to the MSNBC studio in Secaucus, N.J.

title: More Aches and Pains: Now Pavano Will Miss Start
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 13  The Yankees most fragile player has added himself to the teams growing list of wounded pitchers. Carl Pavano, who missed most of the last two seasons with a variety of injuries, will miss his start here Saturday with stiffness in his right arm.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the trial of one man accused of killing seven people at a fast-food restaurant in Palatine, Ill., in 1993 misstated the date the picture was taken and referred incorrectly to the date the bodies were found. The picture was taken on Jan. 9, 1993, not Jan. 8. The bodies were found on Jan. 9, not two days earlier.

description: Following is a transcript of an interview by Michael Gordon and Adam Nagourney with Senator John McCain. A few of the questions have been edited for brevity and clarity, and extraneous material omitted.

title: Yankees Bullpen Cant Secure Igawas First Victory
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 13  When Joe Torre summoned Kyle Farnsworth in the seventh inning on Friday, three outs earlier than usual, it was a subtle demotion. Farnsworth is usually the eighth inning pitcher for the Yankees, but he has been shaky lately and cannot work more than one inning at a time. He did nothing to restore his manager's faith.

title: Correction: How to Confine the Plants of the Future?
description: The Re:framing column last Sunday, about genetically engineered crops used in medicine, misstated the status of a proposal by Ventria Bioscience to plant its pharmaceutical rice in fields in Kansas. The Agriculture Department is evaluating comments before making a decision; it has not yet approved the permit.

title: Correction: A Bridge Over the Atlantic, in Labor Policy
description: The Economic View column on April 1, about labor policies in the United States and Europe, misstated the status of efforts in Congress to raise the minimum wage. Separate bills to raise the wage have been approved by the Senate and the House, but legislation has not been enacted.

title: Correction: The End of the Line as Detroit Workers Know It
description: An article on April 1 about the future of American auto workers referred incorrectly to an occupation for which Jeffrey Vitale, a DaimlerChrysler employee, is preparing. He is studying to be a physical therapist assistant, not a physical therapist.

title: Keeping The Shiny Side Up
description: A house for the road, the Airstream has long intrigued Americans as an ideal combination of their twin loves, vehicle and home.

title: Puzzles: Tax Break
description: Withhold everything! Before you race off to the post office, here's a challenge to tax your brain. To begin, solve the first six puzzles, each of which will give you a one-word answer, which you should enter in the numbered boxes below the puzzle. Then follow the instructions for the last puzzle, "Final Reckoning," to get the answer to this question:

title: Rallies Around the Country
Losing the Keys, on Purpose
description: Drivers with a penchant for losing their keys or locking them in their cars undoubtedly appreciate new technologies that let vehicles be unlocked and driven without even lifting a key.

title: Future F1 stars everywhere
description: Lewis Hamilton, Felipe Massa, Kimi Raikkonen and Fernando Alonso continue to stake out their territory. Massa takes his second pole in a row and Hamilton qualifies in second after qualifying fourth in the first two races, this time beating Alonso, who takes fourth  behind Raikkonen. But as I write these words there is another name attracting attention as the final lap of the first race of the GP2 series comes to an end, marking the first race in the career in the Formula One support series for Bruno Senna.

title: Your Comments on My Iraq Column
description: My Sunday column is about Iraq. I argue that the basic problem with the Bush approach is that we want to be there more than Iraqis want us there  and thats a recipe for disaster. In that context, I suggest, Congressional efforts to curtail funding for the war are helpful because they signal that our patience is wearing thin. I welcome your comments below, and as always Im particularly interested in substantive and thoughtful commentary.

title: Obama Returns Lobbyists Donations
description: Senator Barack Obamas campaign said late Friday that it had returned more than $50,000 in donations after learning that the contributors were federal lobbyists, which the campaign had pledged not to accept money from.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: April 15
description: The highest profile guest on this weekends news shows is none other than Vice President Cheney, who has had a lot to say lately on the state of the war in Iraq and about Speaker Nancy Pelosis overseas trip.

title: Flaherty Sees Danger Ahead for Farnsworth
description: Throughout a baseball game, analysts will make hundreds of comments, critiques and predictions. But it is not often that an announcer is as prophetic as John Flaherty was Friday night during the Yankees-As game on the YES Network.

title: Notes on Update 1.1.2.0
description: Wow! Its been a while since Ive been able to get to the blog. I also realized I never made a post when we launched version 1. In an attempt to earn your forgiveness the list of changes below will cover everything between version 1.0.0.0 and version 1.1.2.0. There were not very major changes as we were more interested in fixing any hidden stability issues before releasing version 1.0.0.0.

title: Mike Piazza, Father Figure
description: Went over to the As clubhouse to see Mike Piazza before the game. I hadnt been over there in a couple of years, but it hasnt changed at all. If anything, its even more like a frat house than ever.

title: Bundling
description: When New York City was still New Amsterdam a quarter-millennium ago, the teenage children of the Dutch settlers were allowed to enjoy a physical intimacy known as bundling, a word related to binding. The great Dictionary of American Regional English (DARE) defines the verb to bundle as to share a bed with a person of the opposite sex while fully clothed (or with some other impediment to sexual intercourse). That impediment was a bundling board, a long plank of wood set between the courting youths to guarantee at least the appearance of chastity.

title: Starting With an Empty Lot
description: WHY buy a house when you can build one?

title: The Pilotless Plane That Only Looks Like Childs Play
description: IF youre the type of shopper who spends billions of dollars on lethal military gadgets, and youre ever invited to visit General Atomics Aeronautical Systems  the small, privately held San Diego company that has quickly become one of the military industrys most celebrated businesses  take a bit of advice: accept a ride on the corporate jet.

title: Sandra Urie, Frank Herron
description: Sandra Ann Urie and Frank Farnum Herron were married last evening at the Massachusetts Horticultural Society in Wellesley. The Rev. J. Philip Zaeder, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Historys Painful Fallout
description: If anything good comes out of New Jerseys pension crisis, it will be a newfound awareness among politicians and voters alike of the dangers of overblown promises to cut taxes. Overpromising, together with the willingness of both Democrats and Republicans to use any gimmick conceivable to avoid a tax increase, is what put New Jersey in such deep trouble in the first place.

title: A BMW to Ride When a Trip Is Long and Time Is Short
description: Huntington Beach, Calif.

title: Police Find Pickup Driver Who Left Site
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 14  The New Jersey State Police said Saturday that they had located the driver of a pickup truck that set off the crash that severely injured Gov. Jon S. Corzine. But the police said they had no plans to charge the man with leaving the scene of the accident because he said he was unaware his vehicle had been involved.

title: As Growth Hits a Wall, Nascar Faces a Less Certain Future
description: On the cusp of the 2007 season, Brian France, chairman and chief executive of Nascar, stood before reporters at Daytona International Speedway and declared that the sport was continuing its remarkable rise.

title: Capturing the Teenage Immigrant Experience
description: WITH little more than a secondhand camera she bought 20 years ago, Barbara Beirne, a lifelong resident of New Jersey, has hiked through remote regions of the Appalachian Mountains and flown as far as Northern Ireland in search of compelling subjects for her photographs.

title: Dispatches From the Front Line of the Great Vodka War
description: Theres been a lot said lately about how the European Union has staved off war on its continent. Really? How about the great Banana War, in which the combined forces of the New World and third world were routed, and the European Commission boldly proclaimed that nothing with abnormal curvature could be called a banana? (Britons who persist in claiming that the European Union mandated straight bananas are just trying to malign it.) And even now the Vodka War is raging.

title: Have Spatula Will Travel
description: INSIGHTS that might never occur to you while eating hot yogurt soup in a restaurant in Istanbul suddenly take on a surprising clarity when making that soup yourself in a hotel kitchen there  the combination of the delicate egg yolks, tangy yogurt, lemon and mint evoking both a past where nomadic Turks first turned milk into yogurt and a present where their descendants eat the thick and creamy creation with almost every meal.

title: A Riot of Flavor From Spain
description: If aromas and flavors could somehow be replicated visually in neon, Sitios de Bodegas 2006 Conclass, a tangy white, would illuminate a dining room.

title: Marisa Simpson, Jason Fisher
description: Marisa Folger Simpson and Jason Fisher were married last evening at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Curt Collier, the leader of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: A Leading Cause of Death, but Less So
description: Last month, Elizabeth Edwardss breast cancer recurred. Then Tony Snow, the presidents press secretary, said his colon cancer was back. On Wednesday, Fred Thompson, the former Republican senator from Tennessee and a possible presidential candidate, said he has had lymphoma.

title: Clowns, Remember Your Balloon Deduction
description: LIBERACE, who once said, I didnt get dressed up like this to go unnoticed, faced an Internal Revenue Service audit in 1968 over thousands of dollars he claimed as tax deductions for lavish outfits he considered business expenses. His lawyers eventually convinced a United States Tax Court judge that his bejeweled, rhinestone-studded suits and feathered capes were not everyday attire their client could wear on the street, and a precedent was set. Preparing returns for actors, singers, dancers and other artists is a subspecialty for some tax professionals, like Scott Rodabaugh of Premier Tax and Financial Services in Manhattan. With the Tuesday deadline looming, Mr. Rodabaugh, a former stage manager and sometime marathon runner, has been busy seven days a week but found a few scarce minutes to speak about the finer points of his job with Steven McElroy. Here are some excerpts:

title: My Wife Is Mad
description: Laura Restrepo writes about Colombia, her native land, but she spends a good deal of her time in Mexico, and to read her latest novel, "Delirium," is to understand why. Most of the action takes place in the Colombian capital, Bogot  a city, one character says, "where everyone's at war with everyone else"  at a time when the whole country seems either insane or, perhaps worse, in love with insanity and helpless to change. Although Restrepo doesn't specify the year, it appears to be 1983: "E.T." and "Flashdance" are in the movie theaters, Ronald Reagan is president of the United States, and the most powerful man in Colombia is Pablo Escobar, darkly presiding over the vast cocaine empire of Medelln. Escobar "doesn't like being called the King of Coca," though; according to someone who knows him, "he prefers Father of the Nation." And "Delirium" is about his nation of frightened, maddened children, the Colombia he sired.

title: In Challenge to Survey Low-Wage Workers, Researchers Pursue Snowball Sample
description: Imagine a more challenging group to identify and quantify than jazz musicians. They tend to be itinerant. Also, poor. Go to the clubs, and those likely to be performing are the more successful ones. Ask the musicians union, and chances are those enrolled will be disproportionately older and account for only a fraction of the total.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Comedy

title: Another Angle on the V-Twins
description: IN the revival of Italian motorcycle brands in recent years  Ducati most notably, but Aprilia, Laverda and MV Agusta as well  the make with the greatest reserve of emotional equity in the United States may be Moto Guzzi. American enthusiasts often regard Moto Guzzi as Italys Harley-Davidson, with just as much character and attitude (though a much smaller product line).

title: Carey Alpert, Jared Spitalnick
description: Carey Beth Alpert, a daughter of Helaine and David J. Alpert of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Jared Brett Spitalnick, a son of Andrea and Dennis Spitalnick of Old Westbury, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. White officiated at the New York Palace Hotel in Manhattan.

title: The Visceral Realist
description: Over the last few years, Roberto Bolao's reputation, in English at least, has been spreading in a quiet contagion; the loud arrival of a long novel, "The Savage Detectives," will ensure that few are now untouched. Until recently there was even something a little Masonic about the way Bolao's name was passed along between readers in this country; I owe my awareness of him to a friend who excitedly lent me a now never-to-be-returned copy of Bolao's extraordinary novella "By Night in Chile." This wonderfully strange Chilean imaginer, at once a grounded realist and a lyricist of the speculative, who died in 2003 at the age of 50, has been acknowledged for a few years now in the Spanish-speaking world as one of the greatest and most influential modern writers. Those without Spanish have had to rely on the loyal intermittence of translation, beginning with "By Night in Chile" (2003), two more short novels  "Distant Star" (2004) and "Amulet" (2007)  and a book of stories, "Last Evenings on Earth" (2006), all translated by Chris Andrews and published by New Directions.

title: Philadelphia Struggles to Quell an Epidemic of Gun Violence
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14  In a hospital emergency room, a young man winces as doctors try to determine how badly he has been injured.

title: Ethiopia Denies Shipment From Korea Violated Ban
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The Ethiopian government has denied that it violated United Nations sanctions by carrying out a secret purchase earlier this year of military equipment from North Korea.

title: When Complaining Isnt Enough
description: Connecticut makes it easy to find out if a contractor or even a doctor has been the target of complaints. But just try to discover whether an auto body shop has a history of shoddy service. The problem is not registering a complaint; the Department of Motor Vehicles Web site provides forms and links. The problem is getting relevant information before you bring the family jalopy in for repairs.

The pictures, in muted tones, may work too hard to supply a story  images of a hospital and a graveyard tell us the stooped grandfather from the early pages has passed on  but on the whole they complement the haunting simplicity of Issas art.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE WIND FROM THE EAST. By Almudena Grandes. Translated by Sonia Soto. (Seven Stories, $27.95.) The east wind that whips Spain's southwest coast can be so trying, explains one of the characters in this long and pleasantly meandering novel, that the courts allow it to be cited "as an extenuating circumstance in cases of assault and battery, physical abuse, even murder." Juan, a doctor in his early 40s, and Sara, 53, a single woman of some means, become friends after settling in the same new beachfront development. For these emotional refugees from Madrid, the wind takes some getting used to. Why they each came to Andalusia are the mysteries that propel the narrative forward, and Grandes unravels them at a perfect pace, with just enough tension between the revealed and the hidden, the past and present. Sara's story, one of betrayal on many sides, reaches back to the Civil War, and the deal her impoverished parents struck with the devil, in the guise of a well-to-do woman who for a time was Sara's surrogate mother. Juan, who arrives with his 10-year-old niece and mentally disabled brother, has left behind a decade-long affair with his sister-in-law, now dead, and one terrible night he can't forget. The mix also includes an attractive single mother who cleans house for these two neighbors. It's all the ingredients for a sentimental daytime soap. But although she edges dangerously close, Grandes, whose book will appear next month, manages to keep this intricate story of flawed people engaging and fresh.

Carver is also like Hemingway, though, in the simplicity and clarity of his pared-down language, his precise descriptions, his use of dialogue to evoke complicated emotional situations. Not a lot happens in a typical Carver story  or not a lot that goes on outside peoples heads  and this may explain why, though he is admired by many filmmakers (and probably even more screenwriters), not many Carver works have been turned into movies. title: 2007: A Face Odyssey
description: We have always been slightly uneasy  notwithstanding our growing cultural obsession with youth and physical perfection  about the enormous value we assign to female physiognomy, based as it is on nothing more substantive than an undemocratic rolling of the genetic dice. Clearly, although we have all been bequeathed a more or less similar arrangement of facial features (eyes, nose, mouth, neck, skin), there are some women who emerge, either by way of felicitous lineage or a hazard of good fortune, with mugs to die for. Audrey Hepburn. Vivien Leigh. Grace Kelly. Julie Christie. Julia Roberts. Halle Berry. Penlope Cruz. The variations may range from the gamine to the sultry, the classic to the exotic  stopping along the way for the slightly more Nordic look that often goes with blond lovelies  but the theme is the same. They are undeniably beautiful; we, by and large, however attractive or striking, are not. This tragic and unearned differential (one that is becoming ever more tragic in a looksist society) has led us to devise ways of minimizing beautys importance with dispassionate abstractions or consoling, somewhat grandmotherly mantras. If you want to get high-minded about it, you can clutch for solace at the conjecture of the 18th-century philosopher David Hume that beauty exists merely in the mind . . . and each mind perceives a different beauty and hope that no one will notice that this observation, if it ever held up, preceded the invention of photography. Closer at hand is the adage Beauty is as beauty does, which is the kind of snippy comment Mary Poppins might have made if she came upon one of her charges preening before his or her reflection. Then there is the old platitude Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, which attempts a similar leveling of the playing field.

title: Off-the-Book Construction Jobs Soar in City, Study Shows
description: An economic study set to be released today found widespread illegal practices in New York Citys residential construction industry, estimating that one-fifth of the 82,000 workers who build housing in the city work off the books.

title: Brooke Rosen, Steven Lucks
description: Brooke Alyson Rosen, a daughter of Barna and Joel Rosen of Atlantic Beach, N.Y., was married last evening to Steven Miles Lucks, the son of Carole and Richard L. Lucks of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Dennis Math officiated at the Woodmere Club in Woodmere, N.Y.

title: By a Dead Lake
description: When Elfriede Jelinek was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2004, the response of the international press and literary world was wildly mixed. Many commentators were surprised and puzzled (who?); others expressed shock and outrage; a few gave their enthusiastic endorsement. One member of the Swedish Academy resigned in protest. The predominant tone was one of cautious approval.

title: Chance to Have Olympics Is a Balm for a Troubled City
description: CHICAGO, April 14  This citys image could use a little lift.

title: Correction: Has the Exit Sign Ever Looked So Good?
description: An article last Sunday with a report on executive pay about exit packages for ousted chief executives misstated a salary equivalent of the average severance in 2006. That average, $9 million, was equivalent to about 170 weeks of salary for each year, not each week, at the helm.

title: Resolve to Be Ambivalent
description: One of the essential flaws in President Bushs Iraq policy is that America comes across as wanting to be in Iraq more than the Iraqis want us there.

title: A Companion to Protect Addicts From Themselves
description: LOS ANGELES

title: San Francisco: The Orchard Garden Hotel
description: THE BASICS

title: Under the Sea
description: This is where a land starts and ends, Henning Mankell says in the portentous style he favors in Depths. He could have added, This is how a mystery writer writes. Mankell, known in Sweden and beyond for his genre fiction, has dared to try something more nebulous here. But hes encumbered with all those irritating little habits mystery writers can develop: staccato sentences, paragraphs and chapters; characterless characters; implausible dialogue; heavy symbolism, with metaphors and similes battling for supremacy; clunky injections of back story and other info; reminders in case you forgot everything; and that old audience-grabber, plot for plots sake, in the form of a murder every now and then (even the cat gets killed).

title: Americas Cup Draws the Haves and the Have-Yachts to Spain
description: The Americas Cup has returned to the continent if not quite the time zone from whence it came, as can be confirmed by a long panoramic look at the huge amphitheater formed by the refurbished port in Valencia, Spain.

title: Indian Point Says It Will Miss Deadline for Siren System
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Friday that it would not grant the operators of the Indian Point nuclear reactors an extension for the completion of an blackout-proof siren system, opening the way for what the agency called an enforcement action.

title: Childrens Books
description: The hardest part of writing fantasy may be getting the ending right. Often writers spin an intriguing premise into a whirling world of mystery, suspense and atmospheric adventure, only to let the whole thing collapse into a heap of disappointing nonsense. Not so Martine Leavitt in Keturah and Lord Death, which was a finalist last fall for a National Book Award. The conclusion is the best part of this novel-length fairy tale: at once unexpected and inevitable, sad and triumphant, satisfying yet abidingly mysterious.

title: Players Vying for Awards Get a Creative Assist
description: In the N.B.A., players do not directly campaign for postseason awards like most valuable player, rookie of the year or sixth man of the year. Rather, they rely on creative communications staffs to generate tools that will get voters thinking and talking.

title: Comings and Goings
description: For todays travelers, iPods are as common as e-tickets. Not only do MP3 players store books and podcasts, they can also translate words and phrases, given the right software. McGraw Hills iSpeak language-learning series, created for iPods, seems to fit the bill. Versions are available in Spanish, French, German and Italian, with Chinese, Japanese and Portuguese versions coming out this summer. Costing $12.95, each iSpeak is divided into categories like food, weather, entertainment and introductions (www.mhprofessional.com). ... Hyatt Hotels and Resorts is also courting the MP3 generation. Treating music like wallpaper, the chain is mixing special Hyatt playlists for two of its resorts and making them available for guests to download. The lobby of the Hyatt Regency Scottsdale Resort and Spa at Gainey Ranch features the smooth vibes of Ive Mendes and Jazzanova, while the Hyatt Regency Lost Pines Resort and Spa, outside Austin, Tex., is playing Texas swing numbers by bands like Asleep at the Wheel. Guests who like what they hear can buy the playlists for $22 at the hotels or through their Web sites, www.scottsdale.hyatt.com and www.lostpines.hyatt.com. ... Norwegian Cruise Line is rolling out Nintendos Wii video game consoles on its ships. Games will include Wii Sports (tennis, golf, baseball, boxing and bowling), Wii Play (table tennis, air hockey and other games) and WarioWare (Smooth Moves and Excite Truck). The game consoles are hooked up to large screens in the atrium and other common areas, so guests can play one another (www.ncl.com). ... Volunteers are needed to complete work on the Continental Divide Trail, extending 3,100 miles from Canada to Mexico. Participants of all skill levels and backgrounds are welcome, from cooks to prepare meals for other volunteers, to experienced trail builders (www.cdtrail.org). ... The Ritz-Carlton, New Orleans, which reopened last December following repairs and renovations after Hurricane Katrina, is reopening its spa on Monday. It has a new cafe, a fitness center and a retail center. The spa, which has 22 treatment rooms, is 25,000 square feet and features treatments like the Marie Laveau Voodoo Love Massage and the Multicolor Masquerade Facial, above. ... On March 30, the Ritz-Carlton, Tokyo opened in a 53-story tower. The hotel has 250 guest rooms, a sky lobby, several restaurants and bars, and a health club and spa. Nightly rates start at 65,000 yen, about $545 at 121 yen to the dollar (www.ritzcarlton.com). ... Tokyo is scheduled to get another new hotel in September, the Peninsula Tokyo, looking out on the Imperial Palace Gardens. Plans are for 314 rooms, a rooftop restaurant and a spa. Rates are expected to start at 60,000 yen, or $495 at 121 yen to the dollar (www.peninsula.com).

title: What Would Carrie Do?
description: WITH bouncy bass lines and bouncier hairstyles, the electro-pop trio the Klaxons have brought a rainbow-dappled splash of fun to the British music climate of bedroom brooders. Their futuristic good-time grooves suggest they are having a party and inviting everyone.

title: Passing the Baton: Be Bold, New York
description: AMERICAN orchestras have historically been hidebound institutions afraid of alienating mainstream subscribers. Boards tend to hire the most renowned maestros they can attract and afford: sure bets, in other words, safe investments. And many orchestras are weighted down with the burden of having to be the public face of a citys higher cultural aspirations.

title: Michelin Guides to Rate More American Cities
description: First there was New York, then San Francisco. Now Los Angeles and Las Vegas will get the Michelin treatment.

title: A Safe Haven in New Haven
description: AS Washington tussles over the fate of the nations estimated 12 million undocumented immigrants, municipal governments are taking sides. Places like Morristown, N.J., and Danbury, Conn., are cracking down. Others, like New Haven and New York City, are embracing their undocumented workers.

title: Maybe It Isnt Evident, but for Knicks, Its Progress
description: Failure smacked the Knicks across the face late Friday night, after a windup that lasted for four weeks. The whiplash was evident.

title: Fierce Storm Drenches East Coast
description: The calendar may say April, but the weather felt more like winter today, with a northeaster storm dumping several inches of rain in the New York region and forcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights at area airports. The Mets game was called off and there were fears of flooding in coastal and inland river areas.

title: Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Resume Meetings
description: JERUSALEM, April 15  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, met here on Sunday, resulting in some mixed messages regarding a resumption of the long-dormant peace efforts between the two sides.

title: Baby on Board, and a Photography Business, Too
description: AFTER Natasha Cuevass daughter, Dakotah, was born in 2003, she wanted to capture every moment of her babyhood on film. A year and many hundreds of prints later, Mrs. Cuevas decided that it was time to invest in the new high-end digital camera she had been coveting.

title: Correction: A Bridge Not Quite Far Enough for Some
description: An article last Sunday about Roosevelt Island residents wish for additional access to the Queensboro Bridge misstated the years during which the islands only auto access was via an elevator from the bridge. The elevator was in use from 1916 to 1956  not 1930 to 1955.

title: Radicals for Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Homers and a Hit Batsman Chase Hernndez
description: Mike Winters did not carry a gavel or demand order as he called balls and strikes at Shea Stadium yesterday. But during a dramatic moment in the Mets game against the Washington Nationals, he sentenced Orlando Hernndez with the authority of a judge. And for the record, he was wearing black.

title: Is Justin Timberlake a Product of Cumulative Advantage?
description: As anyone who follows the business of culture is aware, the profits of cultural industries depend disproportionately on the occasional outsize success  a blockbuster movie, a best-selling book or a superstar artist  to offset the many investments that fail dismally. What may be less clear to casual observers is why professional editors, studio executives and talent managers, many of whom have a lifetime of experience in their businesses, are so bad at predicting which of their many potential projects will make it big. How could it be that industry executives rejected, passed over or even disparaged smash hits like Star Wars, Harry Potter and the Beatles, even as many of their most confident bets turned out to be flops? It may be true, in other words, that nobody knows anything, as the screenwriter William Goldman once said about Hollywood. But why? Of course, the experts may simply not be as smart as they would like us to believe. Recent research, however, suggests that reliable hit prediction is impossible no matter how much you know  a result that has implications not only for our understanding of best-seller lists but for business and politics as well.

title: A Cube, Like Meccas, Becomes a Pilgrim
description: HAMBURG, Germany

title: Chic? Hmm
description: Is Sgolene Royal a gazelle, air hostess or Frances next Joan of Arc? Since this 53-year-old became the presidential candidate for Frances Socialist Party, opinions have remained divided. She just looks so bourgeois for someone left-wing, says Marisa Berenson. The designer Martine Sitbon, on the other hand, finds her pretty well dressed. She adds, By wearing a skirt, shes avoiding that frumpy trouser-suit look so prevalent amongst female politicians. The shoe designer Christian Louboutin describes Royal as physically, great and someone whose appearance has dramatically evolved since working for Mitterrand in the 1980s.

title: New Jersey Governor Has Another Operation
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 14  Gunshot wounds, stab wounds and other perils of urban life keep the trauma surgeons at Cooper University Hospital here busy. Of the roughly 2,500 patients that the trauma center treats every year, hospital officials say, 10 percent to 15 percent are crime victims.

title: At a Hospital With a Prominent Patient, Extra Guards and TV Trucks Add to the Hubbub
description: Gunshot wounds, stab wounds and other perils of urban life keep the trauma surgeons at Cooper University Hospital in Camden, N.J., busy. Of the roughly 2,500 patients the trauma center treats every year, 10 percent to 15 percent are crime victims, hospital officials say.

title: Sidewalk Sheds: How Long Is Too Long?
description: Q The building next to ours erected a sidewalk shed that partly extends in front of our building. It would not bother us were it not for the fact that it has been up since 2004 and no work has been done since it went up. The owner has dutifully renewed the permit for the shed with the New York City Buildings Department every year.

title: Where Town Met Country
description: THE block of West 72nd Street from Broadway to West End Avenue is, from the point of view of historic preservation, where the wild things are. Its buildings have been either left alone or mutilated, restored or destroyed, according to their owners desires. At the Broadway end of the block, just beyond the boundary of the Central Park West Historic District, the delicate Colonial Club of 1892 has been flattened; at West End, the most striking house on the street has received surprisingly careful attention.

description: ON a frigid Sunday night this February, just after I had put the baby to bed, the intercom buzzed.

description: PARIS

title: North Korea Misses Key Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The first deadline for North Korea to shut down and seal its main facility for manufacturing nuclear weapons fuel expired today with no apparent action by the North to fulfill its commitments, while China asked angry officials in the Bush administration to show patience.

title: Together in Toronto and Having a Few Laughs
description: Sam Mitchell tossed perfect spirals toward his starting point guard, T. J. Ford, who dropped one to the hoots of teammates and coaches lingering in the Toronto Raptors practice gym last week. Mitchell then punted the football to the ceiling.

title: Corzine Crash Comes at Crucial Time for N.J.
description: Members of the staff of Gov. Jon S. Corzine say it could take a week to 10 days before he is well enough to resume his duties as the governor of New Jersey. His doctor said it could be days or weeks. Six months may pass before he can get around by himself.

title: A Gumshoe Adrift, Lost in the 70s
description: RAYMOND CHANDLER, the creator of the tough-but-honorable Los Angeles private detective Philip Marlowe, once wrote in a letter to a friend: The private eye is admittedly an exaggeration  a fantasy. But at least hes an exaggeration of the possible.

title: A Cheap Room Puts Old San Juan Within Reach
description: CALLEJON DE LA CAPILLA, a narrow, brick-paved alleyway about 200 feet long, is the nexus of cool in Old San Juan. Behind a thick wooden door is the Nuyorican Cafe, the hottest spot for live jazz and salsa; across from it is a chinchorro, or hole-in-the-wall bar, whose grittiness borders on absolute chic; and at the far end lies Calle Fortaleza, whose ultra-fancy restaurants have earned the area the ultimate sign of approbation  an acronym: SoFo.

title: Yes, Wall St. Still Gets Some Things Right
description: A FEW days ago, I was at a gathering of retirees at a friends house. I fell into conversation with a group of prosperous-looking men from Texas. They were talking about new developments in oil exploration and recovery. In particular, they were talking about something called fracturing. This is done when oil is trapped in sedimentary rock and doesnt just gush out of the ground when you find it, the way it did for James Dean in Giant.

title: Hilary Johnston, Jeremy Desmon
description: Hilary Michelle Johnston, a daughter of Becky and John Johnston of Belleville, Ill., was married yesterday to Jeremy Carl Desmon, the son of Janet and David Desmon of Williamsville, N.Y. Joyann Ferguson-Pratt, a marriage officer and deputy register general with the Commonwealth of the Bahamas, officiated in Lucaya on Grand Bahama Island.

title: The Night Train to Bucharest
description: LITERATURE is fond of the wise child. But what of the not-so-wise child, the ordinary boy who doesnt project greatness from the schoolyard and isnt the hero of the nursery? What if hes asthmatic and antisocial and throws a kicking, screaming temper tantrum when his mother goes to work? Can such a child be ennobled by the passage of time, his struggles granted retroactive gravitas and his childish confusions rearticulated with adult clarity? If the child grows up to be a wise man with a novelistic bent, perhaps. But theres no guarantee: not every unhappy child is a David Copperfield.

title: Case History/Shu Uemura Lipstick
description: Sometimes it takes a sense of history to come up with a futuristic design. When the New York architects Tsao & McKown were asked to design a case for Shu Uemuras Rouge Unlimited lipstick  which has 17 vivid new shades for spring  they found inspiration in the companys original clear refills. Calvin Tsao explains, We always thought the transparency was important, but thought, Lets make that the packaging. Changing the case from one meant to be thrown away to one meant to be shown off wasnt easy: eliminating the lipsticks metal pan (which would have shown through the plastic) took a year, during which time, Tsao notes, We built a 15-story building.

title: Cindy Dodard and Vaishnav Krishnan
description: Cindy Dodard, a daughter of Marcia Dodard and Dr. Pierre Dodard of Glen Cove, N.Y., is to be married in Brooklyn today to Vaishnav Krishnan, the son of Vani Krishnan and Dr. Eshwaramani Krishnan of Manama, Bahrain. title: Regional Ambience, Global Cuisine
description: THE thing I like best about the Water Street Cafe in Stonington is the specificity of the atmosphere. Its a pleasantly funky New England seacoast tavern of indeterminate age, clothed with an assortment of objects and memorabilia. Despite a dominant maritime theme, the collection is diverse and intriguing enough that one imagines it to have simply accrued gradually over the life of the restaurant, through a variety of means, the way a life story develops over time.

title: Scatologically Correct
description: NEXT weekend, the Bronx Zoo is planning to unveil a state-of-the-art eco-friendly restroom outside its Bronx River Gate entrance. I say unveil because the gleaming structure, with its waterless urinals and composting toilets, was actually opened last fall; but zoo officials have been waiting until Earth Day to publicize it.

title: Suji Kim and Raymond Short
description: Suji Kwock Kim and Raymond Collier Short were married yesterday afternoon at the National Arts Club in New York. The Rev. Verity A. Jones, a minister of the Disciples of Christ, officiated.

title: Showing Off Cars With Real Curves
description: PHOENIX

title: Airstream: The Concept Travels Well
description: AS if abandoned by a misdirected camper who parked in the dark, a silver Airstream trailer sits these days in the lobby of the Museum of Modern Art. A model called the Bambi, designed in 1960 with Airstreams distinctive streamlined riveted skin, has been acquired for the museums design collection.

title: N.Y. Officials Warn of Floods From Storm
description: Officials warned New York-area residents to be prepared today for what meteorologists and emergency planners are saying could be the worst storm since 1992.

title: A Feast in a Store
description: Iavarone Brothers, a 12,000-square-foot specialty market in Wantagh, has all the makings of an Italian feast.

title: On Rethinking the Javits Center
description: The thousands of people who went to the New York International Auto Show in recent days saw first-hand the shabby state of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and its surroundings. For some time now politicians and developers have been trying to figure out how to improve both the center and the large, mostly untended patch of Manhattan around it. Now Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his new team are getting ready to put their own stamp on this painfully long-running story.

title: The Night of the Know-It-Alls
description: AT 6 p.m. last Saturday, some 150 people took their positions on the perimeter of the Panorama of the City of New York, an intricate scale model that was commissioned for the 1964 Worlds Fair. Among them were history buffs, mavens, plane-spotters, savants, parkies, tour guides and the offspring of cabdrivers: a cross-section, in other words, of those New Yorkers who might spend three hours on a Saturday night debating the names of bridges.

title: Expanding the Options
description: For years, Seventh Avenue South in the West Village had little to offer in the way of dining. But over the past six months, options have greatly improved with the openings of these restaurants.

title: A Quick and Tasty Trip to Tokyo
description: The stretch of Post Road inhabited by Fuji Mart bears as much resemblance to Tokyos Ginza district as a chopstick does to a living tree. Yet once you step into this tiny shop, within a mirrored-glass cube building, youll feel as if youve been transported to Japan.

title: Meredith Lissack, Matthew Goldstein
description: Meredith Lissack, the daughter of Carol and Rafael Lissack of Philadelphia, was married last evening to Dr. Matthew Alan Goldstein, a son of Amy and George Goldstein of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Ramie Arian officiated at the Park Hyatt Philadelphia at the Bellevue.

description: Carle Place

title: Brooke Richie, Mark Rogers
description: Brooke Alyson Richie, the daughter of Diane E. Richie and Dr. Jerome P. Richie of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Mark Douglas Rogers, the son of Jennifer and Douglas H. Rogers of Dallas. The Rev. James Knutsen, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Church of the Incarnation in Santa Rosa, Calif., with the Rev. Marshall Brown, a Presbyterian minister, taking part.

title: Still Catering to Food Fanciers
description: The gourmet in the name seems almost quaint, but in 1979, when Mona Spilo opened Bedford Gourmet across from the single-screen movie theater in Bedford Village, Cuisinart was not yet a household word. The shop is the size of some walk-in closets in town, and on busy days customers looking for a special cheese, or maybe just a bit of conversation, are apt to bump quite literally into somebody they know.

title: Japanese and Chinese Fare, in a Lakefront Setting
description: BASICALLY, Toro is just another neighborhood restaurant, but it comes with a twist. The view from the dining room is of pretty Lake Gleneida. Route 6 and a small parking space separate the restaurant from the lake, but the intrusion is minor. While the restaurant is hardly a destination in itself, if the recreation the lake offers happens to bring hungry diners to its glittery shores, Toro is worth keeping in mind.

title: Microsoft Urges Antitrust Officials to Scuttle DoubleClick Deal
description: Microsoft, a veteran defendant of epic antitrust battles in the United States and Europe, is urging antitrust officials to consider scuttling Googles plan to buy DoubleClick, an online advertising company.

title: Catching a Second Wind at Quarters End
description: THE best-performing stocks of the recent past tend to keep beating the market  just as past losers continue to lag behind. But why?

title: Promenade
description: This year men stole the scene at the Easter parade on Fifth Avenue. In a fashion world gone haywire, the show of classic navy blazers and crisply tailored suits with coordinated ties and pocket handkerchiefs looked very sharp, indeed. Maybe the hats come out only for this special occasion, but the men wore them with aplomb.

title: Russian Police Break Up Protest in St. Petersburg
description: MOSCOW, April 15  Riot police officers dispersed an opposition rally in St. Petersburg on Sunday, rounding up and arresting protesters and their leaders in a chaotic street scene.

title: Spicy Tastes of Thailand, With Vegetables as Stars
description: KENNY CHEN, the chef and proprietor of the new Thai Station Restaurant in Merrick, has come full circle. Years ago Mr. Chen owned and cooked at an equally modest place, Pad Thai in Oakdale, before trading up to two Thai restaurants, both called Lemon Leaf, in Hicksville and Carle Place. Then he sank everything into his pride and joy, Shangri-La of Asia, a fusion restaurant in Garden City Park. It was there, in 2003, that he first crossed my radar.

title: North Korea Misses Important Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The first deadline for North Korea to shut down and seal its main facility for manufacturing nuclear weapons fuel expired Saturday with no apparent action by the North to fulfill its commitments, while China asked angry officials in the Bush administration to show patience.

title: Weeding Out Conflicts
description: Until the speaker of the House, James Amann, decided to limit his fund-raising work last month, he was involved in a clear conflict of interest for which he was justifiably criticized. On the side, Mr. Amann has been raising money for the Multiple Sclerosis Societys Connecticut chapter, for which he is paid $67,500. In that job he solicited donations from the same lobbyists who would do just about anything to curry his favor as the most powerful man in the legislature.

title: Patient Privilege
description: When I went for an examination, my surgeon asked if two residents could be present. I felt uncomfortable being undressed in front of extra people, and so I declined. My surgeon scolded me, saying I was preventing the next generation of doctors from being trained. Why is it my responsibility to provide training for medical students?  name withheld, Beit Shemesh, Israel

title: In a Tussle Over Power, Trees Are in the Middle
description: In a cautionary tale that may resonate citywide, residents of 250 Mercer Street, a 277-unit apartment building near Fourth Street, say their efforts to prevent New York University from uprooting 18 mature trees on their block have been undermined by their own co-op board.

title: Fire, the Wheel and, of Course, Mop Slippers
description: BEHOLD the Annoy-o-tron. The easy-to-hide magnetized device promises to drive a co-worker insane.

title: Mirja Spooner, Edward Haffner
description: Mirja Catherine Laksmi Spooner and Edward Charles Haffner were married yesterday at the Church of the Transfiguration in New York. The Right Rev. Andrew St. John, the vicar of the church, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Retail Sales Could Set the Tone on Wall St.
description: ONE facet of economic activity after another will have its moment under the microscope this week. Reports are expected on home construction, inflation, manufacturing and leading indicators, but one measure of consumers willingness to keep spending may matter most on Wall Street, in one economists opinion.

title: Paul Watzlawick, Therapist Behind Rapid Diagnosis Strategy, Dies at 85
description: Paul Watzlawick, a therapist who advanced a novel strategy for rapid diagnosis and treatment of problems that occur in marriages and families, died on March 31 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 85.

title: A Soft Sell With Cold, Hard Cash in Mind
description: I JUST spent a languorous afternoon watching a new form of video entertainment, sponsored by advertisers like Budweiser and General Electric on Web sites they have created. Unlike other forms of branded entertainment in which products are embedded in the story line, this genre of programming makes no mention of the products at all.

title: A Dream Weaver Threads Together the Best of 3 Classic Chevys
description: FRED KANTER deserves a lifetime pass to the New York auto show.

title: Adopting City Mannerisms
description: ENGLEWOOD

title: For Sale May Mean You Lose
description: THERE are quiet fire sales occurring inside the corporate bankruptcy world that hurt bondholders and other creditors while, in many cases, enriching insiders at failed companies.

title: Jane Vaughn, Daniel Constantineau
description: Jane Blair Vaughn, the daughter of Margaret Weld Vaughn and Jack Hood Vaughn of Tucson, is to be married there this evening to Daniel Scott Constantineau, the son of Christine Constantineau and Roy Constantineau of Virginia Beach. Judge Sharon Douglas of the Pima County Superior Court in Tucson is to officiate at the Arizona Inn.

title: Giambis Homer in 13th Cures All for Yanks
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 14  The Yankees lead the majors in errors, with 13 in their first 10 games. Their starting rotation is depleted by injuries, and their bullpen is exhausted. But they are always a threat to change a close game with one swing.

title: Shannon Briggs Says Nyet
description: The Russian domination of the heavyweight title is finis, over and done, Shannon Briggs declared in an open letter last fall. Briggs, who referred to himself as the Black Hope, the American Hope, had recently won the World Boxing Organizations championship belt by knocking Sergei Liakhovich entirely out of the ring in the closing seconds of the bout. Now Briggs was calling out the champions recognized by the other three major sanctioning bodies: Wladimir Klitschko, a Ukrainian, and Oleg Maskaev and Nikolay Valuev, both Russians. I am made in Brooklyn, U.S.A., he announced, and I am definitely in the heavyweight-title house.

title: Spellbound by a Whisperer and Romanced by a Whistler
description: CALL it what you will: individuality, perhaps contrarianism? The narrow confines of established music categories seem to bring out the defiance in artists. The Brazilian singer Bebel Gilberto, daughter of the well-regarded musicians Joo Gilberto and Micha, suggests she is pioneering her own style: Bebelmusic. Ms. Gilbertos second album was nominated for a Grammy. Her third, Momento (Six Degrees), is being released April 24. Ms. Gilberto compared putting out an album to raising a child: The baby is now walking. Songs on her album freewheel between English and Portuguese. Her lyrics of love and longing flutter and repeat in a blend of Brazilian beats, with alternating pulsating and breathy electronica. This month Ms. Gilberto, 40, begins a world tour, starting in London and stopping in the United States in May. From her apartment in Manhattan, she spoke with Winter Miller about what shes listening to now and why.

title: The iPod and the Vacuum Tube Sing a Warm Duet
description: IPODS are fine for listening to music on the go, but sometimes people want to cast headsets aside and hear their playlists piped through the living room by a sound system.

title: California Adopts First Phase of Ocean Preserves
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 14  California wildlife regulators adopted a sweeping ocean protection plan on Friday, the first such statewide effort in the country, intended to establish a network of underwater refuges.

title: Lenders Sought Edge Against U.S. in Student Loans
description: In a fierce contest to control the student loan market, the nations banks and lenders have for years waged a successful campaign to limit a federal program that was intended to make borrowing less costly by having the government provide loans directly to students.

title: Correction: A West Side Story With a Promising Ending
description: The National Perspectives article last Sunday, about a new mixed-used development on the west side of Annapolis, Md., misidentified the river that touches this part of the city. It is the Severn River, not the Potomac.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 14, 2007

title: Pampering Pets on the Road
description: Picture a hotel room where you sleep on a sage, copper or nutmeg velvet bed fitted with orthopedic pads, a down-filled cushion and Rivolta Carmignani sheets from Italy. A knock tells you your beef sirloin patty has just arrived. Now picture the recipient of these amenities  not you, but your dog.

title: Bombs Kill 34 in Baghdad in Spite of Crackdown

title: Everybody Hates Don Imus

Even in that short span, theres been an astounding display of hypocrisy, sanctimony and self-congratulation from nearly every side of the debate, starting with Al Sharpton, who has yet to apologize for his leading role in the Tawana Brawley case, the 1980s racial melee prompted by unproven charges much like those that soiled the Duke lacrosse players.

description: ASPEN, Colo.  David A. Stockman is trying to unwind at his second home here after another long day spent scouring legal documents. Dinner at a restaurant with his wife, Jennifer, has been a balm, to say nothing of the big glass of scotch he has nursed throughout the evening.

title: A Tax to Clear the Air

A few years ago, Mr. Bloomberg raised the city tax on cigarettes to $1.50 a pack. Mr. Suozzi wants to make it $2 a pack in Nassau, and is urging the New York State Legislature to give him permission.

Now that Victoria and David Beckham have fled to Los Angeles, Englands reigning WAG is Coleen McLoughlin, whose memoir Welcome to My World recently held the No. 1 position on the Times of London nonfiction list.

title: Report Criticizes Marines Actions in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 14  American marines reacted to a bomb ambush with excessive force in eastern Afghanistan last month, hitting groups of bystanders and vehicles with machine-gun fire in a rampage that covered 10 miles of highway and left 12 civilians dead, including an infant and three elderly men, according to a report published today by an Afghan human rights commission.

title: Learning at the Stoves of the Masters
description: HOTELS large and small, luxurious and affordable, in big cities and distant corners are now offering cooking courses as an amenity for their food-savvy guests. While the details vary, there are some constants. Just as with their rooms, hotels require a reservation for a cooking class. The price most always includes the cooking instruction and recipe booklet as well as a meal based on the feast youve preparedvery often served in a magical setting. Classes are often open to the public as well as hotel guests and take approximately a half-day, usually a morning class followed by lunch.

title: 36 Hours in Portland, Ore.
description: "NICE is an adjective that Portland, Ore., can't seem to shake. But below the fleece-clad and Teva-wearing exterior lurks a cool and refreshingly unneurotic city that marches to its own cosmopolitan beat. Truth is, Portland doesn't want to be Seattle, its highly caffeinated neighbor to the north. With less traffic, better public transportation and Mount Hood in its backyard, this self-styled City of Roses doesn't stand in anybody's shadow. Its vibrant downtown overflows with urban pleasures like chic restaurants, funky nightclubs and spritely neighborhoods crackling with youthful energy, but nobody's boasting. That's another nice thing about Portland.

description: Joel Agee, who reviews Elfriede Jelineks new novel in this issue, is known as an accomplished writer and translator. His memoir Twelve Years: An American Boyhood in East Germany (1981) is a classic of the genre, and a second memoir, In the House of My Fear, was published in 2004. His translations of Heinrich von Kleists Penthesilea and Hans Erich Nossacks The End: Hamburg 1943 won, respectively, the 1999 Helen and Kurt Wolff Prize and the 2005 Lois Roth Prize of the Modern Language Association. title: A Director, and Mother, Confronts Infanticide

In her new movie, Stephanie Daley, Ms. Brougher flirts with genre again, this time the murder mystery. Opening Friday, Stephanie Daley is also a dual character study, a snapshot of the current social climate and a piercing look at the way circumstances push people into places they shouldnt have to go. But almost from the first moments  ski-booted feet trudging through snow, then faltering as blood seeps into the bootprints  what drives the narrative is a single question: What has she done?

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 14  The Devils got away with giving up three goals Thursday because Tampa Bay Lightning goaltender Johan Holmqvist gave up five. The Devils did not exploit a weakness as much as Holmqvist sprang a leak.

title: Accusations, Words in Defense: The Mounting Storm Over Wolfowitz
description: Paul D. Wolfowitz finds himself under heavy fire once again. As a deputy secretary of defense in the Bush administration, he was an architect of the war in Iraq.  Now, as president of the World Bank, he has become embroiled in a dispute over his role in giving his companion, a World Bank employee, a raise and transfer. Mr. Wolfowitz, who was nominated to the job by President Bush in 2005, issued an apology late last week, and the banks executive board promised quick action to decide his fate. One of his signature campaigns has been cracking down on corruption in poor countries that the bank assists. Now his critics are calling him a hypocrite.

title: Our Men in Uniform

title: La Vida Loca
description: I have to admit that, until a month ago, I had never heard of Carmen Laforet. The idea that there might be a lone woman in what seems the unrelievedly male pantheon of Spanish novelists of the post-Civil War era  an era which to outsiders, as Mario Vargas Llosa writes in his introduction to Nada, seems to reek of fustiness, sacristy and Francoism  was like discovering an extra story built in a house you thought you knew.

title: Getting Piggy With It
description: Bastien Gonzalez has always been hard to track down, flying from one capital to the next to tend to the toes of the rich and richer. In 2004 he inked an exclusive deal to bring his signature, polish-free, totally buffed medical Pedicure de Bastien to the One and Only resorts  in Dubai, the Maldives, Mauritius and Los Cabos, Mexico. He spends Sundays in Paris with his girlfriend; infrequent contact is why we have so much love, he said. This marathon plays out in 18,688 miles traveled per week; 3 passports owned; 10 clients per day; 3,000 pedicures in 2006; 18 pedicurists trained last year; 10 pedicurists fired last year; and 1 buffing chamois used per month. Price for Pedicure de Bastien: $140.

title: Hey, Thats (Not) Funny
description: SECOND maybe only to the Big Bang, the elusive essence of comedy has been subjected to a lot of theorizing. In Woody Allens Crimes and Misdemeanors, a character played by Alan Alda described it pompously and mathematically as tragedy plus time. Steve Martin says its what makes you laugh but not puke. Schopenhauer believed it was based on a false syllogism, and other philosophers said it revolved around a hidden misunderstanding. (Lone Ranger: Looks like were surrounded by Indians, Tonto. Tonto: Whats all this we stuff, kemo sabe?)

title: Haute Rocks | Youll Always Have Paris
description: Van Cleef & Arpels is adding new facets to the City of Light with its Une Journe  Paris collection  a day in Paris interpreted through jewels that take their inspiration from the citys best-loved landmarks, from Jardin des Tuileries to Tour Eiffel, from Avenue Montaigne to Place Vendme. The line of the Pont des Arts, for example, ripples through a bracelet; the Opras red velvet curtain inspired a cascading ruby-and-diamond necklace. Those craving Ladure macaroons will have to settle for baguettes.

Now perhaps I can quit my job. Three days a week, I do some consulting for a little branding firm in London.

title: White Bricks and Pale Imitations
description: MANHATTAN HOUSE, the 19-story slab of an apartment building on a full Upper East Side block bounded by 65th and 66th Streets and Second and Third Avenues, was built to stand out, from its size to its stark silhouette to its most striking feature: its bold white-brick skin.

title: They Had a Hammer
description: Controversy chases the Russian writer Vladimir Sorokin the way a dog chases a stick. His 1999 novel, Blue Lard, featuring some hot man-on-man love between Stalin and Khrushchev, provoked pornography charges and a public protest in Moscow, where copies of the book were dumped in a large mock toilet. His libretto for a Bolshoi Opera production earned the threat of an inquiry in the Duma in 2005. Despite the international publicity generated by all this, little of Sorokins work has reached American audiences.

title: Space Craft
description: In New York City, small apartments are a fact of life. So for those of us who cant afford an architects expertise to maximize our tiny living spaces, heres the next best thing: an architects own tiny living space. Ghiora Aharoni, a 37-year-old Israeli who started his own firm in Manhattan four years ago, found a 550-square-foot apartment in the West Village that was typical of tenement buildings of the early 20th century. That is to say, it was a warren of cramped rooms. Aharonis ingenious renovation made the apartment feel lighter and more open and added much-needed storage space  without losing the charm of its original architecture.

The bovinely pregnant are now demanding the full Demi Moore treatment, in what is quickly becoming a seventh-month rite of passage. Usually shot in black and white and occasionally joined by partners, pets and even surrogates, the pregnant nude is keeping studio photographers busy on both coasts.

Hundreds of youths, many from New York City, had clashed with the police on city streets after being ejected from New Roc, and more than 200 police officers, including some from other Westchester departments, were called in. At least seven youths were arrested.

title: Playing the Numbers When Putting Voice to Bach
description: NO one can be sure exactly what Bach was up to when he wrote the B minor Mass near the end of his life. A Roman Catholic Mass by a Lutheran, assembled from movements written over more than two decades, it amounts to a survey of musical possibilities in the liturgy, an encyclopedia as much as a text for actual performance.

description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Vice President Dick Cheney today called Congressional Democrats irresponsible for using a war spending bill to set a timetable for withdrawing troops from Iraq. He said he was willing to bet the Democrats would eventually give into President Bushs demands for legislation with no strings attached.

description: Egon Bondy, a poet and philosopher whose idiosyncratic cocktail of whimsically demented verse and profoundly subversive metaphysics lubricated the underground movement that helped topple Communism in Czechoslovakia, died on Monday in Bratislava, Slovakia. He was 77.

title: Cthulhu Meets Godzilla
description: My tinfoil hat is off in admiration for anyone who translates speculative fiction for fun or profit. Lord Xenu knows, the genre can be difficult enough to understand when reader and author speak the same language; the challenge becomes exponentially greater when an interpreter must take an idea that is by definition alien to native speakers, and somehow make it comprehensible to foreign audiences. (Is there a Japanese word for "flesh-tube monster"? Apparently, there is.) But when this act of alchemy is performed just right, the cumulative effect is like science fiction squared: it can introduce a reader  even one accustomed to being shown worlds he never realized were possible  to new ways of thinking about the unknown.

title: With a Berth Secure, the Nets Plot a Playoff Renaissance
description: About 30 minutes after his team knocked the Knicks out of playoff contention Friday night, and about 15 minutes before he would learn that his team had clinched a playoff spot, the Nets Vince Carter, wide-eyed and speaking in his matter-of-fact tone, said, Im just glad were just one step closer to our goal.

title: Nothing to Hide, Gonzales Insists in Early Account
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales offered a measured apology for his mistakes in the dismissal of eight United States attorneys, but said in testimony prepared for a Senate hearing on Tuesday that he had nothing to hide and that none of the prosecutors were removed to influence the outcome of a case.

title: Childrens Books
description: Irish mobsters, once a pulp fiction staple, have made a comeback this season with the new NBC drama The Black Donnellys. Now Jessie Haas, who has written several highly regarded novels involving horses, explores the historical roots with Chase. Its a page turner about the Molly Maguires, or Sleepers  the secret brotherhood of Irish miners who were legendary in the coal country of 19th-century America. When Phin Chase, an orphan growing up in a Pennsylvania coal town, witnesses the murder of a mine boss by the gang, he is forced to flee, pursued by both the real murderer and a mysterious stranger riding a horse that seems to have the uncanny ability to track Phin like a bloodhound.

description: JERUSALEM, April 15  A previously unknown group in Gaza sent a statement to news organizations on Sunday claiming that it had killed Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent who was kidnapped in Gaza City on March 12. The BBC said it was aware of the reports and deeply concerned, but emphasized that there was no independent verification of the claim, which it was treating as rumor.

As Charlotte Hughes, then a reporter for the paper, none-too-definitively declared, Everybody in India, apparently, eats curry. And although she noted that curries were complicated to prepare, nevertheless, American cooks with a pioneering spirit can master curry dishes.

The Story of the Cannibal Woman opens three months after the crime, and Roslie Thibaudin, a 50-year-old painter, still finds it hard to get out of bed. She cant sleep, or eat or paint, and is mired in a state of semi-wakeful numbness  that hour of lead, when the feet, mechanical, go round, that Emily Dickinson wrote follows great pain.

description: Among the hair salons, sushi academies, travel agencies and driving schools stuffed into a densely occupied block of Union Street in Flushing, the eye nearly misses the maroon awning over Rims Fine Jewelry, embossed with the image of a large diamond.

title: Local Culture as Part of the Green Experience

title: Kimberly Young, Stefano Rivella

title: Paperback Row

(Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.99. ) Gladwells best-selling first book, The Tipping Point, argued that small actions can ignite positive social change; Blink, a paean to the power of first impressions, makes the case for thin-slicing. There is, Gladwell suggests, a subconscious process through which we sift huge amounts of information, isolate telling details and come to rapid conclusions, even in the first two seconds of seeing something.  Blink is a book about those first two seconds, he writes. The book moves through dozens of stories about thin-slicing, from a Pentagon war game to New Coke, which tested well but flopped in the marketplace. Gladwell has us flying around the world and across disciplines at hectic speed, and hes always dazzling us with fascinating information and phenomena, David Brooks wrote in the Book Review.
