title: The Story of the Cannibal Woman
description: Cape Town always slept in the same position, curled up in the muzzle of a gun. After hours of grim silence as heavy as a great fur coat of a former Soviet leader, the sound of engines began to sputter and roar throughout the city. In the distance, like the cries of cormorants, the horns of the first ferries split the clouds of mist grazing the sea as they left for Robben Island, once a concentration camp, now transformed into an international tourist attraction. Then the brakes of the overcrowded buses, arriving from the wretchedness of the shantytowns and converging on the splendors of the city center, screeched to a halt at the same stops. The feet of thousands of blacks in cheap shoes tramped toward the subaltern jobs that had always been their lot. All these sounds were preceded by the throbbing rounds of the police helicopters as their eyes pierced the dawn, searching to oust the criminals from their rat holes. For Cape Town at night oozed with all sorts of foulness and rottenness, a nightmare from which the city awoke completely drained, its storm channels churning bile and pus, its head of medlar trees and maritime pines bristling with fright.

title: Religion Without Truth, Part Two
description: In a March 31st Op-Ed column I critiqued Professor Stephen Protheros claim (quoted in Time magazines April 2nd issue) that the academic study of religion  takes the biblical truth claims seriously and yet brackets them for purposes of classroom discussion. I questioned how anyone could take something seriously by leaving it at the door or putting it on the shelf. And I said that in the absence of its truth claims  claims like salvation is through belief in Jesus Christ who rose from the dead and redeemed us by taking upon himself all our sins  a religion was nothing more than a set of stories and ritual practices bereft of any transcendent meaning of which they would be the expression. You can teach those stories and practices  just as you might teach the stories and practices of baseball (which is, I know, the religion of some people)  but you wouldnt, I insisted, be teaching religion, only its empty shell.Of the hundred or so comments I received, only a few indicated agreement with my point. The others raised a number of objections, and among those objections three were prominent: 1) I fail to understand that one can teach the truth claims of religion as historical and cultural facts without either believing or disbelieving in them: To understand the works of Christians such as Chaucer, Dante, Milton or Shakespeare, one must understand something of Christianity. One must not, however, become a Christian. 2) Teaching the exclusive truth claims of a religion as matters of fact goes against the principles of liberal democracy and liberal education: Teaching religious thought as dogma is not education, but theocracy. 3) What I said in this column is contradicted by what I said in earlier columns: The argument you present seems to run counter to your prior claim that any potentially controversial topic can and should be studied within academicized grounds.First of all, I stipulate to the usefulness of teaching the bible as an aid to the study of literature and history. Im just saying that when you do that you are teaching religion as a pedagogical resource, not as a distinctive discourse the truth or falsehood of which is a matter of salvation for its adherents. One can of course teach that too; one can, that is, get students to understand that at least some believers hold to their faith in a way that is absolute and exclusionary; in their view nonbelievers have not merely made a mistake  as one might be mistaken about the causes of global warming  they have condemned themselves to eternal perdition. (I am the way.) What one cannot do  at least under the liberal democratic dispensation  is teach that assertion of an exclusive and absolute truth as anything but someones opinion; and in many classes that opinion will be rehearsed with at best a sympathetic condescension (lets hope they grow out of it) and at worst a condemning ridicule (even in this day and age, there are benighted people).

title: A High-Tone Riff on the Hi-dee-hi and Boop-a-doo of Broadway
description: A concert hall is not necessarily the ideal place to lend an ear to the lullaby of Broadway. The hip-hooray can sound a little staid, the ballyhoo less informally brassy than you might like. But at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, Rob Fisher, Kelli OHara and the New York Pops breezed through a half-century and more of American musical theater with warmth and personability that made the evening feel like a spontaneous family gathering around the living room piano.

title: Dear Diary
description: Overheard conversation between two men walking east on 50th Street between Eighth Avenue and Broadway.

title: Nothing to Hide, Gonzales Insists Before Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales offered a measured apology for his mistakes in the dismissal of eight United States attorneys, but said in testimony prepared for a Senate hearing on Tuesday that he had nothing to hide and that none of the prosecutors were removed to influence the outcome of a case.

title: A Trophy Mag Wears Camouflage
description: Sid Evans, the editor of Field & Stream, is hardly the only editor in the ferocious world of Manhattan publishing with a reputation for taking no prisoners. But he is the only one with the temerity to actually hang the heads on the wall.

title: Burton Passes Kenseth for Second Win at Texas Track
description: FORT WORTH, April 15  To say the Texas Motor Speedway has been fickle understates its capriciousness. No track on the Nascar circuit could match the speedways record of a different winner for each of its first 12 Nextel Cup series races.

title: Getting the C.E.O. Treatment at Conferences
description: FIRST there were boutique hotels  small, private, luxurious and impressive. They were expensive, but that was not an issue for the people frequenting them.

title: Gates Wants Mideast Allies to Back Iraq
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 16Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates will urge Middle East allies to provide greater political backing to the Iraqi government on a multi-day trip to the region, a senior Defense Department official said.

title: Bronx: Driver Killed in Parkway Fall
description: The driver of a 2004 Acura was killed early yesterday after he lost control of his car, which went over a guardrail on the Bronx River Parkway and fell onto a parked truck, the police said. The police and the drivers uncle identified the man as Rabindranath Ramjanack, 22, of Mount Vernon. A passenger, whose name was not released, crawled from the car and was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he was in serious condition last evening, the police said. The police said that the roads were wet, but that they were unclear as to what caused the driver to lose control. The accident occurred about 1 a.m. on the parkway near East 233rd Street. The Acura went over a guardrail on the right shoulder, landing on a Metro-North truck, then rolling off to the ground.

title: Big Medical Step, Starting With the Citys Poor
description: For years, policymakers have said that the next big step in American health care should be electronic records systems that remind doctors and patients about needed care, and make it easier for doctors to share information with one another.

title: Virginia Tech Shooting Leaves 33 Dead
description: Thirty-three people were killed Monday on the campus of Virginia Tech in what appears to be the deadliest shooting rampage in American history, according to federal law enforcement officials. Many of the victims were students shot in a dorm and a classroom building.

title: Ecuador Appears Likely to Rewrite Constitution
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 15  President Rafael Correas proposal to rewrite Ecuadors Constitution seemed on its way to a landslide victory in a referendum on Sunday, even as the nationwide vote was shadowed by a disclosure that Mr. Correas father had been imprisoned decades ago in the United States on drug smuggling charges.

title: A Woman Wrongly Convicted and a U.S. Attorney Who Kept His Job
description: Madison, Wis.

title: Late Run Gives Nets Hope for Better Playoff Seed
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 15  Even when the stakes were at their highest this season, and nothing was guaranteed, the Nets often had a difficult time kindling their inner fire. Now, with a postseason pass in hand, there was a question of how seriously the Nets would approach the one thing left to be had: the sixth seed in the Eastern Conference.

title: Watching the War and Acknowledging the Dead
description: ON Tuesday morning, Daniel K. Ropkin booted up his computer and confronted a list that was getting longer, he said by telephone from his home outside Sacramento. Mr. Ropkin operates Spread the Word: Iraq-Nam (iraqnam.blogspot.com), a Web site tracking military deaths in Iraq, and the Defense Department press releases that had accumulated over the last two days announced 18 new fatalities.

title: Cheney Predicts Bush Will Win Struggle Over War Spending
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Vice President Dick Cheney said in an interview broadcast Sunday that Congressional Democrats were irresponsible for using a war spending bill to set a timetable for withdrawing troops from Iraq. He said he was willing to bet that the Democrats would eventually cave in to President Bushs demands for legislation with no strings attached.

title: Cleaning Up the Alternative Tax
description: This page normally has little patience for people who gripe about paying taxes. But most of the four million taxpayers who owed the alternative minimum tax this filing season have cause to complain.

title: Spitzer Learns His Job Comes at a Cost
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has taken some lumps in the press during his first 105 days in office, while Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has been riding a wave of positive publicity about his investigation into student loan practices.

title: Ms. Mopey, Begone! Power Pop Is Back!
description: AVRIL LAVIGNE

title: At Lady Magazine, a Ruthless Chick-Eat-Chick World
description: Sally Koslow was editor in chief of McCalls until it was transformed into a celebrity vehicle with Rosie ODonnell at the helm. To the extent that Ms. Koslows Little Pink Slips features an embattled editor named Magnolia Gold and does not have a character named Sally Koslow, it qualifies as a work of fiction.

title: Requiem for a Club: Saxophone and Sighs
description: There was plenty of exuberant noise at Tonic on Friday night: shrieking horns, fuzzed-out guitars, the jackhammer thump of a bass drum. It could almost have passed for a typical night at the club: two sets of improvisation organized by the saxophonist John Zorn and an installment of the Bunker, a techno party hosted by Bryan Kasenic, a k a DJ Spinoza.

title: Student Lender to Pay $2.5 Million Settlement
description: Education Finance Partners, a student loan company that investigators found had paid at least 60 colleges and universities across the country for steering students to its loans, has agreed to pay $2.5 million to resolve an investigation of its practices by the New York attorney general, according to lawyers who have taken part in the negotiations.

title: Rest for the Weary, and Wi-Fi Too, All for Less Money
description: SADLY for many budget business travelers, low-cost hotels in Europe are often not nearly as cheap as their rooms feel. On a recent Monday night at the Ibis Madrid Centro  one of the French chain Accors budget hotels that are pitched to a white-collar crowd  a clutch of business travelers quickly found that out.

title: At the Movies (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of Playoffs, Knicks Run Out of Gas, Too
description: TORONTO, April 15  With their playoff hopes ended, the Knicks reverted to a familiar script Sunday night. They were in the game throughout but could not come up with plays at critical times in a 107-105 loss to the Toronto Raptors.

title: Salvatore Scarpitta, New York Artist, Dies at 88
description: Salvatore Scarpitta, an artist whose work ranged from three-dimensional wrapped canvases that evoked survival and death to sculptural renderings of cars and sleds that extolled his belief in travel as a metaphor for life, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Macao Bank Challenges U.S. Treasury Ruling
description: SHANGHAI, April 16  A Macao bank at the center of international efforts to dismantle North Koreas nuclear weapons program today challenged a United States Treasury Department ruling that bars the lender from access to the American financial system.

title: Kiss and Howl: This Man Is a Wolfs Best Friend
description: In A Man Among Wolves, a bizarre and riveting nature documentary that will be shown tonight on the National Geographic Channel, a British former gamekeeper named Shaun Ellis feeds wolf cubs prechewed food from his own mouth. He licks them on their chops. They lick him on the lips. He howls, eats and frolics with them.

title: Who Is the Player King Behind Prom Queen?
description: People aiming to sell Prom Queen, the latest strange bird in the online-video aviary, invariably refer to the Web series as Michael Eisners Prom Queen.

title: From Visitors, a Glimpse of Corzines Private Life
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 15  His three adult children are spending much of their time in a small conference room at Cooper University Hospital here, talking on their cellphones or reading get-well notes from all over the country. His companion of about two years has tried to maintain some sense of normalcy, she said Sunday afternoon, by reading every single paper in America.

title: From Brownstone to Baghdad, TV Crew Armed With Ingenuity
description: When the producer Marcela Gaviria and the correspondent Martin Smith traveled to Iraq in November for the PBS series Frontline, they found themselves without a translator after the man they had lined up canceled abruptly because his brother had been kidnapped, shot and left for dead. (The brother lived, they were told.)

title: Lobster Elusive, and Price Exclusive, as Harvest Suffers
description: NORTH PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 13  Mark Castelli has plenty of king crab, shrimp and tilapia for sale at his seafood store here, Captains Catch, but lobster is nowhere to be found.

title: The Winning Card
description: PRESIDENT BUSH has once again started speaking out for comprehensive immigration reform, and a draft plan to rally Republican senators on the issue is circulating just as Congressional hearings on the issue approach. Members of Congress recognize that voters are looking for real reform that rests on resolute, effective enforcement of our immigration laws.

title: Don Ho, 76, Entertainer Who Defined the Hawaiian Image, Is Dead
description: Don Ho, an entertainer who defined popular perceptions of Hawaiian music in the 1960s and held fast to that image as a peerless Waikiki nightclub attraction, died Saturday in Honolulu. He was 76.

title: Tools for Staying in Control While Traveling
description: JUST because you are on a business trip does not mean you cant keep up with your expense reports, check your voice mail without racking up roaming cellphone charges or even watch TiVo episodes in your hotel room. Here are some helpful services and products that can make a positive difference without weighing you or your luggage down.

title: U.S. Consulate Closes in Morocco Over Security Concerns
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco, April 15  The United States Consulate here said Sunday that it would close until further notice, a day after two brothers carried out puzzling suicide attacks near the consulate amid a spate of bombings in Morocco and Algeria.

title: Whats Cooking in First Class?
description: WHEN it comes to food, airlines seem to be going all out for the well-paid business traveler.

title: Exploring the Imprint of Black Americans
description: Imagine the boxing gloves Muhammad Ali wore when he knocked out Sonny Liston just steps away from a first edition of Phillis Wheatleys 1773 book of poetry, the first published by an African-American, around the corner from the cell door behind which the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. wrote Letter from a Birmingham Jail.

title: Suitors Raise Bid for Clear Channel
description: The two private equity firms seeking to buy Clear Channel Communications have sweetened their offer, fearing that their initial bid may be rejected by shareholders.

title: 34 People Are Killed in Six Bombings in Baghdad; 2 Britons Die in Helicopter Crash
description: BAGHDAD, April 15 -- At least 34 people were killed in Baghdad on Sunday in another day punctuated by car bombings and suicide vest attacks on civilian targets of the kind that the two-month-old American security crackdown has so far been unable to restrain.

title: Hoboken: Fire Forces Dozens From Homes
description: More than 150 firefighters battled a five-alarm blaze at a lumber yard for nearly four hours last night before bringing it under control, officials said. Several buildings near the General Lumber Company, at Clinton Avenue and Second Street, were evacuated as a precaution, Mayor David Roberts of Hoboken said. The fire started about 5 p.m., and three firefighters suffered minor injuries, Mr. Roberts said. More than three dozen people were evacuated from their homes and taken to a municipal center. The Red Cross was assisting. Residents would probably be able to return home by this afternoon, Mr. Roberts said. The Fire Department asked Public Service Electric and Gas to shut off power in a four-block area around the scene, affecting 1,400 customers, according to a utility spokeswoman. The cause of the fire is still under investigation. Its been a very bad day here, between the flooding and this fire, Mr. Roberts said. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: In Wars Daily Grind, Death Is Routine, Dinner Is Good
description: At the end of Warriors, the second of 11 documentaries to be shown this week as part of PBSs America at a Crossroads series, Ron Maloney, a National Guard lieutenant, returns from a 22-month tour in Iraq to his neat, welcoming house on Long Island and tends to his garden. There is a robust-looking lawn, and there are pretty flowers on a vine. The peace and comfort of such luxuries are unfamiliar to so many people outside the United States, he suggests.

title: AOL Founder Hopes to Build New Giant Among a Bevy of Health Care Web Sites
description: Stephen M. Case wants to be Americas doctor, courtesy of the Web.

title: New Stage for Pioneer Who Lost His Way
description: More than 40 years after Roky Erickson began his recording career, he played his first New York concert Friday night at Southpaw. It was a set of beefy, fuzz-toned, vociferous garage rock, propelled by Mr. Ericksons saber-toothed rhythm guitar and topped by his biting high voice. He was backed by a band, the Explosives, that made its younger opening acts sound timid. The music was stronger than anyone might expect.

title: Afghan Foreign Minister Bars Deals to Free Hostages
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 15  Afghanistans foreign minister, Rangeen Dadfar Spanta, on Sunday ruled out any further deals with kidnappers after a videotape was broadcast showing two French aid workers whom the Taliban claimed to be holding hostage.

title: Storm Leaves Flooding and Travel Disruptions
description: Rain from a rare spring Northeaster that pelted the New York metropolitan area all day Sunday and into today flooded streets and basements, disrupted air travel and commuter railroads and cut power to thousands of homes.

title: Horses Victories Garner Attention, but Also Raise Some Questions
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 15  Like them or not, 20 horses have shown that they are worthy of a place in the starting gate for the 133rd running of the Kentucky Derby. The latest two did so in jaw-dropping fashion Saturday: Dominican ran down the 2-year-old champion Street Sense to capture the Blue Grass Stakes here by a nose, and Curlin zoomed to a record 10 -length victory in the Arkansas Derby.

title: When a Judge Offers an Opinion Away From the Bench
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

title: Signs of Infection
description: People in positions of great power are the ones who define those who are relatively lacking in power. So when Don Imus, a very powerful radio personality, dropped his disgusting verbal bomb on the members of the Rutgers womens basketball team, he sent a powerful message across the airwaves: that the young women on the team (the black ones, at least) were crude, ugly and genetically inferior, and that all of the women were whores.

title: Militant Iraq Cleric Pulls 6 Officials Out of Cabinet
description: BAGHDAD, April 16  The rebellious Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr withdrew his six ministers from the Iraqi cabinet on Monday, in the first major shake-up of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis government since it was installed a year ago.

title: Private Jets on a Shoestring
description: NOT every business can squeeze a private jet into its budget. When basic models start around $12 million (the price of a new twin-engine, four-passenger Gulfstream), the term cost-prohibitive takes on a truer meaning.

title: To Rangers Relief, Shanahan Seems Back to Normal at the Right Time
description: ATLANTA, April 15  His signature fist-pump made its debut in the Rangers postseason as forward Brendan Shanahan flashed a gap-toothed smile after scoring the winning goal. It was a window into the skills that Shanahan has displayed for 19 N.H.L. seasons: he got open in a shooting lane, called for a pass from Sean Avery and snapped a shot for a clutch goal.

title: Violent Protests in Nigeria Over Election Results
description: ADO EKITI, Nigeria, April 15  Violent protests broke out in several of Nigerias 36 states as partial results from highly contested state elections appeared to hand most of the victories to the governing Peoples Democratic Party.

title: Paying Homage to a Workhorse Thats Half One
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn., April 14  In early April, the mules rule this city 40 miles south of Nashville. Long ears twitch in trailers that bump through the streets, braying rings out in Maury County Park, and residents greet strangers with Have a good Mule Day.

title: Book Fair Unites Anarchists. In Spirit, Anyway.
description: So what, exactly, is an anarchist?

title: A Few Good Lawyers
description: THOSE of us hurrying to finish our taxes by tomorrows deadline will probably, at some point, succumb to thoughts of the I.R.S. as an all-powerful bully. But the truth is, the government is not always a match for the tax advisors of wealthy people, so a lot of taxes will go unpaid at the top of the income scale.

title: In a Troubled Time, a New Business Magazine
description: Joanne Lipman, the editor of Portfolio, the new business magazine from Cond Nast, tapped gently last Monday on the door of David Carey, the publisher, and then burst into his bright Midtown corner office.

title: Gonzales Hearing Delayed After Virginia Tech Shooting
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  The Senate Judiciary Committee has postponed the hearing, originally set for Tuesday, in which Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales is to testify about the dismissals of eight United States attorneys.

title: Lawsuit Goes to Trial Against the Long Island Diocese Over Sexual Abuse of Teenagers
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 15  A rare civil trial involving sexual abuse and the Roman Catholic Church starts here on Monday, and jury selection last week gave a hint of what could come.

title: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Giving Away Information, but Increasing Revenue
description: THOSE who dont have $6,000 or enough prominent connections to get into a TED conference can take heart. The price of admission just went to zero, provided you can settle for a more remote experience.

title: Amid Turbulence at CBS Radio, an Old Hand Is Back
description: Five years after leaving a top post at CBS Radio, Dan Mason officially returns today to lead the unit again. He is likely to find that the headaches have worsened.

title: Bush Reiterates His Demands on War-Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  President Bush pressed Congress again today to pass a war-spending bill without restrictions, asserting that lawmakers would be undercutting American troops in Iraq if they failed to do so.

title: Microsoft Urges Review of Google-DoubleClick Deal
description: Microsoft, a veteran defendant of epic antitrust battles in the United States and Europe, is urging regulators to consider scuttling Googles plan to buy DoubleClick, an online advertising company.

title: Russia Tries to Save Polar Bears With Legal Hunt
description: VANKAREM, Russia  Here on the frozen edge of the countrys Arctic expanse, where a changing climate has brought polar bears into greater contact with people, Russia has embraced a counterintuitive method of trying to preserve the creatures: hunting them, legally.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Disturbia Bumps Blades From Top Box-Office Spot

title: Way Off Base
description: Normally, politicians face a difficult tradeoff between taking positions that satisfy their partys base and appealing to the broader public. You can see that happening right now to the Republicans: to have a chance of winning the partys nomination, Republican presidential hopefuls have to take far-right positions on Iraq and social issues that will cost them a lot of votes in the general election.

title: James Lyons, 46, Film Editor and Actor, Dies
description: James Lyons, a film editor whose most notable collaborations were with the director Todd Haynes on several feature films, including Safe, Velvet Goldmine and Far From Heaven, died Thursday in Manhattan. He was 46 and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: East Coast Storm Breaks Rainfall Records
description: A rare spring northeaster masquerading as a classic winter storm roared up the coast and across the New York region and the Northeast yesterday with bullying winds and torrential rains that flooded shorelines and rivers, disrupted travel, brought down power lines and washed out Sunday plans for millions of people.

title: Donors Linked to the Clintons Shift to Obama
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton seeks to reassemble the Democratic money machine her husband built, some of its major fund-raisers have already signed on with Senator Barack Obama.

title: A New Deal for the Mentally Ill (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks Stall on New York Port, but Sharp Words Are Traded
description: Negotiations between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and one of its largest tenants stalled on Friday, raising the likelihood that a deal to hand over control of a Staten Island terminal might fall through. And if the tug-of-war escalates, development in the area could be at risk, the tenants officials said.

title: Gaza Militant Group Says It Killed BBC Reporter
description: JERUSALEM, April 15  A previously unknown group in Gaza sent a statement to news organizations on Sunday claiming that it had killed Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent who was kidnapped in Gaza City on March 12. The BBC said it was aware of the reports and deeply concerned, but emphasized that there was no independent verification of the claim, which it was treating as rumor.

title: Best-Informed Also View Fake News, Study Says
description: Americans may have more news outlets today than two decades ago, but they still dont know much more about current events than they did then, according to a new survey by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press.

title: Looking Ahead
description: EARNINGS REPORTS The following companies are scheduled to release earnings reports this week: Citigroup, Eli Lilly, Mattel and Wachovia (Monday); TD Ameritrade Holding, Comerica, CSX, Dow Jones, EMC, Intel, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, Mellon Financial, Northern Trust, Wells Fargo and Yahoo (Tuesday); Abbott Laboratories, Commerce Bancorp, E*Trade Financial, eBay, JPMorgan Chase, Motorola, PNC Financial Services, Allstate, Bank of New York, Tribune and United Technologies (Wednesday); Advanced Micro Devices, Altria Group, Continental Airlines, D. R. Horton, First Data, Gannett, Google, Merck, Merrill Lynch, Nokia, Schering-Plough, Southwest Airlines, UnitedHealth Group and Wyeth (Thursday); Caterpillar, Honeywell, McDonalds, SAP, Schlumberger and Xerox (Friday).

title: E-Mail Innovator Plans to Enlist in the Wireless Campaign of the Patent Wars
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 15  Nicholas Fodor is about to dive into the patent wars that have tangled up the business of wireless e-mail. But his weapon of choice is not a lawsuit. It is a new e-mail service he is developing using the knowledge gained from years of experience with e-mail software.

title: Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Open Regular Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, April 15  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, met here on Sunday, resulting in some mixed messages regarding a resumption of their long-dormant peace efforts.

title: Chinas Signals on Warming
description: Two factors are crucial to the success of any global system to reduce greenhouse gases. One is American leadership; the other is Chinas full participation. Despite President Bushs diffidence, there has been mounting pressure for the United States to assume a more aggressive role from mayors, governors, some in Congress and, lately, even the Supreme Court. And now there are some modestly encouraging signs from China.

title: Manhattan: Woman Killed in Crash
description: A man was charged with vehicular manslaughter after a crash on the Henry Hudson Parkway that killed a woman early yesterday, the police said. The man, Joseph W. Harris, 29, of Harlem, was also charged with driving while intoxicated. He was treated for minor injuries at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center and then taken into custody. The woman, Gretchen Patterson, 48, of Brooklyn, was pronounced dead at St. Lukes, according to the police. The police said that Mr. Harris was speeding south on the parkway about 12:30 a.m. when he slammed into Ms. Pattersons car near 74th Street, sending her vehicle into two other cars and over a wall. Ms. Pattersons car landed 26 feet below, in Riverside Park. The drivers of the other two vehicles, men ages 19 and 24, were treated for minor injuries. Mr. Harriss vehicle came to a halt upside down on the parkway. Mr. Harris refused a Breathalyzer test before his arrest, the police said. Two passengers, men ages 22 and 23, in Mr. Harriss vehicle suffered minor injuries, the police said.

title: Wall Street Journal Wins 2 Pulitzer Prizes
description: The Wall Street Journal won the Pulitzer Prize for Public Service today for uncovering the unethical practices of business executives who had rewarded themselves millions of dollars by backdating stock options. The articles, by Charles Forelle, James Bandler and Mark Maremont, have led to the federal investigation of more than 130 companies, and at least 70 top executives have lost their jobs.

title: Resisting the Nazis Despite the Odds
description: The discipline and determination are half-brilliant, half-mad: in 1940, in Warsaw, the Polish-Jewish historian Emanuel Ringelblum decided that the entire experience of Jewry under Nazi rule should be thoroughly documented. The internment of Jews within the Warsaw ghetto, he wrote (with chilly irony), provided even greater opportunity for development of the archive.

title: Accounts
description: Accounts

title: Tax Returns Rise for Immigrants in U.S. Illegally
description: With the tax deadline approaching, illegal immigrants are sending in federal returns in what appear to be record numbers despite fears heightened by recent immigration raids around the country.

title: Now on YouTube: The Latest News From Al Jazeera, in English
description: YouTube may be best known for showing video clips from its users of hamsters pratfalls or attempts to don as many T-shirts as possible. Starting today, it will also become an easy way to view content from Al Jazeera English, the English-language version of the Qatar-based television news station.

title: By the Hour or the Day, an Office of Ones Own
description: AS a consultant to companies that want to expand their international reach, Albert Jones often finds himself far from his base in Chicago. But when he goes to meetings in places like Britain, Bahrain or Indonesia, he does not rely on a hotel conference center, a cramped hotel room or even a cafe to be his makeshift office. Instead, before each trip, he arranges to work in spaces run by the Regus Group, which has a network of 950 locations, consisting of meeting rooms and individual offices, which can be secured for an hour, a day or longer in cities as small as Frisco, Tex., and as far-flung as Abu Dhabi.

title: BBC Cant Confirm Killing of Reporter in Gaza
description: The British government said today that it was urgently seeking information about reports that a previously unknown group in Gaza had killed Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent who was kidnapped in Gaza City last month. The group, calling itself the Tawhid and Jihad Brigades, first sent an e-mail message with the claim to a journalist at the Palestinian Ramattan news agency in Gaza on Sunday. The message said that the group held the British government, the Palestinian government and the Palestinian presidency responsible for the death, and said that its demands for the release of Palestinian prisoners inside Israel had not been met.

title: Intel Seen Using China Forum to Detail Plans on Hand-Helds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15  Intel is planning to announce a number of technology advances this week at a conference in Beijing, including an initiative that could give rise to a new class of wireless hand-held computers, according to several people close to the efforts.

title: Goodness Gracious, Thats Why Hes a Mess
description: Here it is halfway through April, and the slippery grip of winter hasnt quite relaxed its hold on the city. But New York Theater Workshop clearly is ready for summertime. This Off Broadway company, normally among the citys most adventurous, concludes its season with a solo show that is the stage version of a beach read: John Fugelsangs stand-up memoir All the Wrong Reasons.

title: Imus Fracas Becomes a Draw in Plays Revival
description: As Don Imus was being removed last week over an on-air racial slur, the producers of Talk Radio, the Broadway play by Eric Bogosian in which Liev Schreiber stars as shock D.J. Barry Champlain, had a sense of life imitating art.

title: Yankees Add Pavano and Mussina to D.L.
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 15  In the Yankees most hopeful outcome, Mike Mussina and Carl Pavano would have taken the bullpen mound on Sunday morning, thrown with no pain and made their turns in the rotation this week.

title: A 30th-Anniversary Retrospective Offers Both a Primer and a Premiere
description: The Boris Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg swept into City Center on Friday night for a three-week season that is a 30th-anniversary retrospective and has an American premiere, The Seagull, tucked in for good measure. The opening program was, for the most part, an eye-filling canter through three decades of repertory, seen in excerpts. Mr. Eifmans Red Giselle was performed in full the following night.

title: The Kindness of Travel-minded Strangers
description: Considering that hes on the road at least one week a month, Eran Steinberg relies pretty heavily on local car service companies to take him from his New York City office to area airports. So when he caught one of the usual limo drivers padding the bill on a recent trip, Mr. Steinberg was desperate for another service he could trust.

title: Cold-War Days: School Drills of Duck and Cover (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dropped Duke Charges Renew Hope in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, April 15  When North Carolinas attorney general said last week that an overreaching prosecutor lacked the evidence to support charges of rape against three former Duke University lacrosse players, some in this neighboring state hoped that tremors from his pronouncement would help free a former star high school football player.

title: I.R.S. Audits Middle Class More Often, More Quickly
description: Middle-class Americans, listen up: the I.R.S. is much more likely to audit you this year. Those caught cheating can expect to pay about $4,100 more on average in income taxes.

title: Cheruiyot and Grigoryeva Win Boston Marathon
description: Into the bellows and in between the raindrops of a noreaster, the runners of the 111th Boston Marathon set out from Hopkinton this morning, the swirling wind and high 40 degree temperatures as much an opponent as an individual sport could have.

title: Sallie Mae, Mired in Controversy Over Loans, Is Under Siege
description: Standing before a group of student lending executives in late 2005, Representative John A. Boehner, then chairman of the House Education Committee, vowed he would keep their interests in mind as legislation made its way though Congress.

title: Iran Says It Wants Bidders for 2 More Nuclear Plants
description: TEHRAN, April 15  Iran said Sunday that it was seeking international bids for building two more nuclear power plants despite international pressure over its nuclear program.

title: The Lengths Frequent Fliers Go for Toiletries
description: FREQUENT fliers are an adaptable bunch because they need to be. The evolving restrictions on what can and cannot be carried on airplanes  particularly rules involving liquids, gels and aerosols  have forced them to find new ways to take what they need to look and feel their best on business trips.

title: Negotiators Say Sallie Mae to Be Sold for $25 Billion
description: Sallie Mae agreed late last night to be sold to JP Morgan Chase, Bank of America and two private equity firms for $25 billion, said people involved in the negotiations.

title: DiPietros Return Has Islanders Optimistic About Playoffs
description: SYOSSET, N.Y., April 15  The Islanders held an optional practice Sunday, and goaltender Rick DiPietro was the first player on the ice. Soon, he was firing pucks, either into a net or at the glass, just to arouse a few quiet spectators.

title: 'If the EU Doesn't Want Us, They Should Say it Now'

title: Weather, or Weapons, of Mass Destruction?
description: Which W should concern us the most? Weather or weapons? Mike Townsley of Greenpeace International suggests that question ahead of the first-ever debate on climate change at the UN Security Council on Tuesday. Time is of the essence, Townsely wrote in a discussion paper he forwarded to me over the weekend. The Council must live up to its mandate and address the threat of Weather of Mass Destruction with the same vigor as it is currently pursuing Weapons of Mass Destruction, he said in the paper, to be posted on the Greenpeace website on Tuesday. Townsleys point is that climate change will lead to increased geopolitical tension and conflict because of shifts in where food can grow and water can be accessed, and because of mass migrations from rising temperatures and sea levels. The looming challenges could mean a radical change in how nations cooperate and distribute aid money around the world. Thats something the Security Council could help to address. But, as Townsley points out, the United Nations plans no resolution and ultimately the job of finding enough money to help curb climate change and adapt to its effects will fall to nation states. Instead of more talk, Townsely wants governments to walk the walk by starting to channel massive chunks of their military budgets  including money to replace aging nuclear weapons  into renewable energy projects and efficiency to slash global emissions dramatically by mid-century.Is Townsley right? Do we live in a world where turning swords into ploughshares  or into biomass for making clean electricity  is the highest priority? Or is Townsley being nave in a world still beset by terrorism and the threat of nuclear strikes from rogue states?

title: Rival Suitors for ABN Amro to Wield Carving Knife, Report Says
description: A consortium of three banks that is threatening to gate-crash merger talks between Barclays and ABN Amro are considering an offer that would reportedly lead to the break-up of the Dutch banks assets. The three bidders, the Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander Central Hispano and Fortis, which on Friday said that they have asked ABN Amro to enagage in exploratory talks, are proposing to carve up ABN Amro and give its shareholders a package of shares in each of their institutions, The Guardian reported.

title: Icahn Takes Pitch to Motorolas Shareholders
description: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, continued his campaign to gain a seat on Motorolas board, this time making his pitch directly to the cellphone makers shareholders. In a letter to shareholders filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission Friday, Mr. Icahn said that the company financial woes reflect not only operational failures, but are also symptoms of a passive and reactive board.

title: CA Accuses Its Founder of Fraud
description: Charles B. Wang, the founder and former chairman of Computer Associates, oversaw a decade-long accounting fraud at the software company, according to a report released Friday by the companys directors. Mr. Wang, who owns the New York Islanders and is among the most politically influential people on Long Island, masterminded accounting gimmicks that inflated his companys sales and profits for years, the report says. In 25 years running Computer Associates, Mr. Wang built a fortune of about $1 billion, including a bonus in 1998 of $670 million.

title: A barrel of monkeys
description: Monkey Island, a five-acre island with a 26-bedroom hotel in the middle of the Thames river, is for sale at 7.5 million pounds, or $15 million, Bloomberg News reports. The island, reachable only by walkway, boat or helicopter, is 30 miles west of London near the village of Bray. It has been owned since 1999 by the Al Habtoor Group from Dubai, which has owned and operated hotels in the Middle East for 25 years. The hotel was built as a fishing lodge about 280 years ago and has a Grade 1 heritage listing, which carries the greatest level of restrictions for owners wishing to renovate sites deemed to be historically significant. The hotel has been used as an inn since 1840 and includes a 90-seat restaurant.

title: Institutional Investors Flock to Chinese Bank I.P.O.
description: China CITIC Bank, which is raising up to $5.4 billion in what is expected to be the worlds biggest initial public offering so far this year, is getting a very warm reception from institutional investors. The overseas institutional tranche of the banks I.P.O. has been more than 30 times covered before opening to retail investors Monday, Reuters reported.

description: Despite continuing fallout from subprime loans and clouds over the U.S. economy, three banking giants are expected to report relatively strong first-quarter earnings this week, according to MarketWatch. On tap are J.P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup, which ast week unveiled a restructuring plan that would eliminate about 17,000 jobs worldwide and save the company an estimated $1.7 billion this year.

Babcocks cash and stock bid last month for Alinta, Australias largest energy infrastructure group, beat a higher offer from a Macquarie Bank consortium which was rejected by Alintas board.

When the company said in February that it was considering strategic alternatives, HD Supply was seen as a distraction to Home Depots core business. But with the housing market slowing dramatically in recent months, analysts now say the unit, which is less reliant on the residential housing market, could help the retailer weather the housing storm.

The transaction includes the assumption of about $770 million in debt, the companies said Monday in a statement. AmeriPath, based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., is owned by Welsh, Carson, Anderson and Stowe, a venture capital firm. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter.

Gates, visiting the Middle East, will urge leaders to back Iraqs government and to put aside their doubts about Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis ability to curtail sectarian violence, a senior Defense Department official traveling with Mr. Gates said on the plane trip here.

title: Computer Science Takes Steps to Bring Women to the Fold
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  For decades, undergraduate women have been moving in ever greater numbers into science and engineering departments at American universities. Yet even as they approach or exceed enrollment parity in mathematics, biology and other fields, there is one area in which their presence relative to men is static or even shrinking: computer science.

title: Lets Get Genetical
description: It is possible to get many things at the Four Seasons Hotel in Westlake Village, Calif., but a blood-and-urine panel that analyzes the condition of your DNA is a relatively new development. The panel, offered through the California WellBeing Institute as part of several luxury-lifestyle packages, including a $2,800 executive physical, is boomingly popular: about 50 people signed up in January, the first month it was available.

title: $5.4 Million for US Airways Chief
description: The chief executive of US Airways, W. Douglas Parker, received salary and bonuses of $5.4 million last year, chalked up gains of $9 million by exercising stock options and still holds options and other stock holdings that are currently valued at roughly $30 million.

title: Brooklyn: High School Chess Team Wins Championship
description: The chess team from Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn won its fourth consecutive national championship on Sunday, tying with a high school from Arizona. It was the second time in three years that Murrow and Catalina Foothills High School of Tucson were named co-winners of the National High School Championship. Each school earned 22 points in the tournament, which was held in Kansas City, Mo. Alex Lenderman, a Murrow senior who earned 6.5 points for his team, was named national scholastic chess champion, the tournaments top individual honor.

title: Exercise: A Little Tai Chi Can Go a Long Way Against Shingles
description: Older people who practice tai chi may be better equipped to fight off the virus that causes shingles or, if they do get the disease, may have a milder case of it, researchers say.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about the benefits of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine referred incorrectly to one of the causes of ear infections. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a kind of bacteria, not a virus.

title: With a Founding Mother in the Field of Primatology
description: CHICAGO  On a lunch break at The Mind of the Chimpanzee symposium in March, Jane Goodall walked with me to visit the ape house at the Lincoln Park Zoo. She let out the chimpanzee pant-hoot call to signal our departure.

title: Greetings From Orlando
description: 1. For a superstar hairstylist, Orlando Pita is as modest as a shampoo girls tips. You wont find him bragging about Madonna, Gwyneth, Tilda and Naomi. And hes way too laid-back to boast about how many fashion shows and ad campaigns hes hot-rollered in the more than 20 years hes been at the top of the game. But theres nothing casual about how he approaches his work. Im a stickler for perfection, Pita says, although of course, sometimes, perfection can be a perfect mess.

A brief report yesterday about a memorial service scheduled for April 23 for the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. included erroneous information from participants about who may attend. It is not open to the public; it is by invitation only.

title: Letters
description: Of Genes and Sexuality

title: Storm Leaves a Toll of Flooding and Hardship
description: The storm destined for the books as the northeaster of 07 continued its assault on the New York region and the Northeast yesterday, forcing the evacuation of thousands from flooded homes, disrupting travel, closing schools and trailing a wake of rising rivers, gouged beaches, power failures and widespread damage.

title: Imuss Longtime Sidekick Joins Other Pinch-Hitters
description: Regular listeners of Don Imus got a surprise yesterday when they tuned in Mike and the Mad Dog, the show that is temporarily replacing Imus in the Morning in the aftermath of its hosts firing last week. For four hours yesterday morning, Mike Francesa and Christopher Russo (the Mad Dog) were joined on the air by Charles McCord, Mr. Imuss longtime news reader and principal sidekick, who is apparently continuing in that role.

title: Go West, Young Woman (Ceausescu Ghosts Too)
description: Its been more than 17 years since Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed, freeing Romania from one of Communisms most brutal dictatorships. But evil casts a long shadow, and the terror is not simply eliminated by a firing squad. Waxing West, Saviana Stanescus intriguing and entertaining new play at La MaMa E.T.C., is an attempt at exorcism, and it is perhaps a hopeful sign that the Ceausescus are ridiculed here as bloodthirsty clowns.

title: Home Depot to Display an Environmental Label
description: After squabbling over prices for decades, the nations big-box retail chains are ready to battle in a new arena: the environment.

title: New DVDs
description: BEDAZZLED

title: Almost Human, and Sometimes Smarter
description: CHICAGO  Observed in the wild and tested in captivity, chimpanzees invite comparison with humans, their close relatives. They bear a family resemblance that fascinates people, and scientists see increasing evidence of similarities in chimp behavior and skills, making some of them think on the vagaries of evolution.

title: Bush Leans on Democrats With Talk of Troops Suffering
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  In his confrontation with Congress over war spending, President Bush is calculating that he can weaken the resolve of Democrats with frequent and specific warnings that delays in passing the bill will hurt American troops and their families.

title: Memo Pad
description: MORE TRANS-ATLANTIC COMPETITION Zoom Airlines, based in Ottawa, plans to begin service between Kennedy International Airport and London Gatwick Airport on June 21, with round-trip coach fares starting at about $510, including taxes and fees. Zoom says it will offer both economy and premium- economy cabins with meals. EOS ADDS SERVICE Eos Airlines, the discount all- business-class carrier, expanded its schedule to add a third flight between Kennedy International Airport and Stansted Airport in London. The additional flight will leave from Kennedy on Sundays, Mondays and Fridays and from Gatwick on Sundays, Mondays and Fridays. AMERICAN AIRLINES PROTEST Flight attendants for American Airlines will be picketing at domestic airports today to protest $180 million in bonuses the carrier is preparing to pay to about 1,000 top managers, according to the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, which represents nearly 20,000 flight attendants at American. In 2003, the flight attendants at American agreed to significant cuts in pay as the airline and others in the industry faced serious financial strain.

title: Deal to Make Sallie Mae a Big Debtor
description: Sallie Mae has long profited from making loans to college students. Now, the company will be saddling itself with debt in an effort to generate even more lucrative returns.

title: No Spitting on the Road to Olympic Glory, Beijing Says
description: BEIJING, April 16  For all the expectations and civic pride that Beijing has attached to being the host of the 2008 Summer Olympics, the event is a source of civic anxiety, too. What if traffic is terrible? What if the weather is bad? These are worries for any host city, but Beijing also has a few more:

title: U.S. Approves Improvements for Implants
description: Federal regulators have made business life a bit easier for the heart device maker Guidant by approving revised quality controls for its pacemaker and defibrillator operations.

title: Virginia Tech: The Victims
For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Citigroups acquisition of a hedge fund and the hiring of its leader, Vikram S. Pandit, misstated Mr. Pandits educational background. He has a Ph.D. in finance, not in engineering.

title: Hiccups in Hounds
description: Q. Can animals have hiccups?

title: Defy Another Day
description: I cant understand the term anti-aging.

title: Managers Use Hedge Funds as Big I.R.A.s
description: Many Americans squirrel away as much as they can into retirement investment accounts like 401(k)s and I.R.A.s that allow them to compound their earnings tax free. The accounts also reduce what they owe when tax day rolls around. For the average person, however, the government strictly limits the contributions to about $20,000 a year.

title: Gunman Was Always by Himself
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 17  Cho Seung-Hui rarely spoke to his own dormitory roommate. His professors and teachers were so disturbed by his writings that they referred him to counseling. And when Mr. Cho finally and horrifyingly came to the worlds attention on Monday, he did so after writing a note that bitterly lashed out at his fellow students for their moral decline.

title: Britain: Journalists Vote to Boycott Israeli Goods
description: Britains biggest journalists union, the 40,000-member National Union of Journalists, has voted in favor of a boycott of Israeli goods, citing what it called Israels military adventures. The measure, approved by a vote of 66 to 54 at the unions annual delegates meeting on Friday, called for a boycott of Israeli goods similar to those boycotts in the struggles against apartheid in South Africa. The timing was particularly delicate because a BBC journalist, Alan Johnston, has been held for over a month in Gaza. A Palestinian group claimed on Sunday to have killed Mr. Johnston, but the BBC said it was treating the report as a rumor. The unions Web site says that the delegates criticized Palestinian authorities for failing to carry out their promises to do all they can to free Alan. Last year, the largest British university teachers association voted to encourage individual academics in Britain to sever professional contact with their counterparts in Israel.

title: For Neighbors, a Wall Collapse Occasions More Than Nostalgia
description: For people who knew Chumleys as the bar without a sign in Greenwich Village, its temporary closing after part of a wall collapsed this month brought back memories of drinks in a famous setting, memories of the prize-winning writers whose pictures were on the walls, memories of colorful stories about the bars beginnings as a Depression-era speakeasy.

title: Deadly Rampage and No Loss for Words
description: Television anchors said over and over that the shooting rampage at Virginia Tech was the deadliest in American history, but that was not the only shocking aspect of yesterdays continual coverage.

title: Macao Bank Challenges U.S. Ban as Politically Based
description: SHANGHAI, April 16  The Macao bank that was a stumbling block to international efforts to dismantle the North Korean nuclear weapons program challenged on Monday a United States Treasury Department ruling that bars the bank from access to the American financial system.

title: Day in Court for Queens Home-Care Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  It was Evelyn Cokes first trip to the United States Supreme Court, and for the 73-year-old home-care aide from Corona, Queens, it was certainly eventful, the last step in a five-year battle.

title: The Disquieting Face of Iraqification
description: For a documentary that opens with American troops, on patrol in Baghdad, coming across a corpse killed execution style  with eyes, ears and nose cut off  its striking that the most dismaying scene in Gangs of Iraq doesnt come till some 45 minutes later.

title: Opening Eyes to a Slowly Dimming World
description: THE Alzheimers Association is introducing its first paid campaign, intended to educate the American public about the disease that threatens to overwhelm the Medicare system as the baby boom population ages.

title: Sudan Defying Security Council on Darfur, U.N. Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 17  A confidential United Nations report says the government of Sudan is flying arms and heavy military equipment into Darfur in violation of Security Council resolutions and painting Sudanese military planes white to disguise them as United Nations or African Union aircraft.

title: The Talk
description: Fembot / (fem bot) / n. / in fiction, a powerful, lifelike android with sexy female attributes and blemish-proof skin, e.g., I love that episode of The Bionic Woman where the deadly fembot has her face mask removed. In reality, a powerful, androidlike female with sexy accessories and blemish-proof skin: It all started with those RoboCop shoes, but now shes gone full fembot  shes even getting DNA-based facials.

title: AT&T Drops Offer to Invest in Italian Phone Company
description: MILAN, April 16  AT&T on Monday withdrew its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, the largest Italian telecommunications company, for about two billion euros, or $2.7 billion.

title: Yanks Hand Ball to Prospect Who Earned His Pinstripes
description: It was the middle of March, when spring training drags and teams make the obvious cuts from their rosters. The Yankees were playing the Minnesota Twins at Legends Field, and the right-hander Jeff Karstens had been especially impressive on the mound.

title: Free Tax Advice (No Guarantee on a Refund)
description: AS the tax deadline looms tonight, there are those who think that the pronouncements of the Internal Revenue Service might as well be declaimed in Greek.

title: Gunman Is Described as Quiet and 'Always by Himself'
description: Cho Seung-Hui, who was identified today as the gunman who killed 32 people at Virginia Tech before killing himself, lived a quiet life with his family in a tranquil suburb of Washington before going off to college, where classmates saw increasingly dark warnings about his personality.

title: Intimacy and Sentiment Leave and Then Return
description: Oliver Knussens Requiem: Songs for Sue at Zankel Hall on Friday night remembered both his wife and the kind of horizontal, heart-on-sleeve melodic style that the rest of the evening seemed studiously to avoid. Mr. Knussens musical language here stretches beyond old ideas of tonal agreement and weights its ensemble sound toward winds and keyboard instruments, elements that are anything but Romantic.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 12 about the latest New York Times Scholars misstated the profession of Ernest Abrahamson, who along with his wife, Kathleen, has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to the scholarship program. (The error first appeared in an article on March 14, 2002, about that years Times Scholars.) Mr. Abrahamson is an entrepreneur and the chairman of a manufacturing company; he is not an engineer. Mr. Abrahamson pointed out the error last week.

title: Brooklyn: Teenager Fatally Shot
description: A 16-year-old boy was fatally shot on a street in East New York yesterday afternoon, the police said. The teenager, identified by the police as Henry Talbert of Brooklyn, was shot once near his neck shortly before 4 p.m. in front of 290 Bradford Street. He was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival, the police said. Investigators were still searching for the gunman, who witnesses said fled on foot.

title: In a Harsh, Sexually Charged Universe, Six Dancers Pounce
description: A fair amount has been written about how the dancer injuries in December and subsequent cancellation (after one performance) of Pavel Zustiaks Petit Mort (Now Its Time to Say Goodbye) oddly echoed the subject of the piece, which Mr. Zustiak described as being about the deaths we endure every day. Then Performance Space 122, which commissioned the work, brought Mr. Zustiaks company, Palissimo, and Le Petit Mort back for a weekend run that opened on Friday night. It proved worth waiting for, if rather more opaque than that description suggests.

title: For the Record
description: An article last Tuesday about the possible deployment of 13,000 National Guard members to Iraq gave an incorrect surname in some references for an Arkansas National Guardsman and father of five who was deployed to Iraq in 2004. He is Staff Sgt. Kelly W. Collier  not Sergeant Kelly.

title: Manhattan: Police Seek Students Attacker
description: Officers continued searching yesterday for the man who beat and raped a 23-year-old woman while holding her hostage for 17 hours, the police said. The woman, a student at Columbias Graduate School of Journalism, remained hospitalized yesterday and has been joined by her family, according to a statement by Lee C. Bollinger, the universitys president. The attack, in a building in Hamilton Heights, began at 11:30 p.m. Friday and ended on Saturday afternoon when the assailant set fire to a futon, and the woman fled.

title: Saving Nigerias Election
description: Last weekends state and local elections in Nigeria were a demonstration of how not to hold a democratic election. Ballot boxes were stuffed, some polling places opened only hours before they were scheduled to close, and in some communities no voting took place at all because of a lack of supplies and rampant intimidation.

title: Rangers Lundqvist Is Healthy and in Top Form
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 16  Two of the saves that Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist made against Atlanta on Saturday could have filled a small highlight reel. First, Keith Tkachuk skated in alone and veered left, but Lundqvist dashed across his crease, cut off the angle and stopped his shot.

title: Housing Slump Takes a Toll on Illegal Immigrants
description: HURON, Calif.  Some of the casualties of Americas housing bust are easy to spot up and down Californias Central Valley.

title: E-Mail and Prozac
description: I have a theory: the more e-mail there is, the more Prozac there will be, and the more Prozac there is, the more e-mail there will be. Maybe I should explain.

title: Flirting With Dystopia, Experimenting With Noise
description: Miniature hard drives stashed in bathrooms. Unlisted phone numbers that lead to ominous messages. A small constellation of mysterious Web sites chronicling a grim future 15 years away. This is how Trent Reznor is letting the world  or some fanatical portion thereof  know about Year Zero (Nothing Records/Interscope), the new Nine Inch Nails album, which arrives in shops today. Open the packaging and youll find another secret message: the disc itself changes color with heat, turning white to display the copyright information and a long string of ones and zeroes. In this paranoid world, everything worth knowing is a secret.

title: Gates Says Iraq Shake-Up Could Be Positive
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 16  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today that the resignation of six ministers loyal to the militant Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr from the Iraqi cabinet could be a positive development if their replacements help reduce sectarian tensions.

title: Hazards: Niacin to Pass a Drug Test Can Have Dangerous Results
description: Heard the one about how taking a lot of vitamin B3 can help you pass a drug test, even if you have been using marijuana or cocaine?

title: Treatments: Study Sees Little Benefit in Chondroitin for Arthritis
description: People looking for relief from arthritis pain often turn to the dietary supplement chondroitin, so much so that by some estimates, the market for the supplement is $1 billion a year in the United States.

title: More Than a Handshake Deal for Japanese Baseball Players
description: If Kei Igawa helps the Yankees defeat the Cleveland Indians tomorrow night at Yankee Stadium, Manager Joe Torre will probably offer him a handshake and some words of encouragement. But Igawa, who pitched for the Hanshin Tigers in his native Japan the previous eight seasons, is accustomed to more tangible rewards.

description: A brief report yesterday about a memorial service scheduled for April 23 for the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. included erroneous information from participants about who may attend. It is not open to the public; it is by invitation only. (Go to Article)

title: Back From Oblivion, Little-Heard Opera Gets Spotlight
description: At the start of the 1920s, the Austrian composer Franz Schreker was a respected professor at the Berlin Hochschule and the celebrated composer of influential operas, including Der ferne Klang, which enjoyed enormous success at its 1912 premiere in Frankfurt.

title: Faith, Hope and Vanity
description: Recently, as I lay naked below the waist while a stranger spread hot wax on my nether regions, I began to think about trust. Like most New Yorkers, I am wary of strangers  even friends. If the woman telling me to flip over and spread my cheeks had tried to talk to me on the street, I wouldnt have made eye contact. And yet here we were, making tiny talk as she eyed my bikini line to make sure it was symmetrical. In 15 minutes, shed be determining the sexual fate of yet another woman willing to pay to suspend suspicion in order to be pretty. How did we get here?

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Geres Kiss Ignites ProtestsRichard Gere touched off demonstrations and protests in India when he planted several kisses on the face of the actress and Celebrity Big Brother winner Shilpa Shetty at an AIDS awareness rally in New Delhi, the BBC reported. Public displays of affection remain largely taboo in India. Demonstrators in Mumbai burned effigies of Mr. Gere, and protesters in other cities demanded Death to Shilpa Shetty. Ms. Shetty told Press Trust of India: This was not such a big thing for people to overreact in such a manner. I understand peoples sentiments, but I dont want a foreigner to take bad memories from here. I understand this is his culture, not ours.

title: Nets Could Draw Raptors in Homecoming for Carter
description: The sudden change in Vince Carters demeanor  from relaxed to intense  said it all.

title: Wall Street Journal Wins 2 Pulitzer Prizes
description: The Wall Street Journal won the Pulitzer Prize for public service yesterday for uncovering the unethical practices of business executives who had rewarded themselves millions of dollars by backdating stock options. The articles, by Charles Forelle, James Bandler, Mark Maremont and Steve Stecklow, have led to the federal investigation of more than 130 companies, and at least 70 top executives have lost their jobs.

description: Agent Provocateur (****)

title: New Program Aims to Help the Poor Juggle Education and Jobs
description: Moving to alleviate the citys high poverty rates, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday announced a new program intended to make it easier for poor people to attend public community colleges while holding down jobs.

title: Sabres Capitalize on Power Play to Go Up in Series
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., April 16  The Buffalo Sabres, flashy and frenetic, are hard enough to stop with five skaters and a good goaltender. An opponent that sends two players to the penalty box  at the same time, no less  can expect to pay a steep price.

title: Briton Criticizes U.S.s Use of War on Terror
description: LONDON, April 16  A senior politician in the Labor Party of Prime Minister Tony Blair said Monday that the Bush administrations commonly used phrase war on terror strengthens extremists.

title: In Arctic Foxes, Clues to Effects of Shrinking Habitat
description: If its habitat starts to shrink and shift, several things can happen to a species. It can stay and adapt to new conditions. It can move with the habitat. Or it can do neither and die off.

title: Ex-Aide Says Gonzales Discussed Firings
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  The former top aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales has told Congressional investigators that Mr. Gonzales was inaccurate, or at least not complete in asserting that he had no role in the deliberations about individual United States attorneys who were later dismissed, a Democratic senator said Monday.

title: Bid in Hand, IntelSat Looks for More
description: IntelSat, which runs the worlds largest network of communications satellites, has been put up for sale by the private equity funds that own it, according to people close to the company.

title: New York Acts to Curb Lenders to Students
description: ALBANY, April 16  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature unveiled legislation on Monday that state officials said would make New York the first state to establish tough new restrictions on the relationship between colleges and the companies that make tuition loans to their students.

title: No-Fishing Zones in Tropics Yield Fast Payoffs for Reefs
description: NGIWAL, Palau  Sitting on a bench in a thatched hut in this village on Palaus main island of Babeldaob, Islias Yano, 57, looked over the bay he has fished professionally since he was 15 and recalled the fishing practices of his boyhood.

title: A Trio Celebrating Its 30th Anniversary
description: The Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio began as a byproduct of Jaime Laredos chamber music programming at the 92nd Street Y. That was in 1976, and the trio  Mr. Laredo, the violinist; Joseph Kalichstein, the pianist; and Sharon Robinson, the cellist  has been the core of the Ys chamber programming since.

title: Parsing the Nixon and Kissinger Pas de Deux
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  Robert Dallek sat in the National Archives day after day, mining the 20,000 pages of Henry Kissingers telephone transcripts for historical gold. And every so often, amid the blur of bureaucratic tedium, a little nugget would glitter. One was the Nixon-Kissinger phone call reacting to news of the 1973 coup in Chile that overthrew Salvador Allende, whose Socialist government they had worked covertly to undermine through the C.I.A.

title: Brooklyn: Former Democratic Leader Is Sentenced
description: Clarence Norman Jr., the former leader of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to one to three years in prison for extortion. The sentence, less than the minimum of two and one-third to seven years, will begin after two other consecutive sentences of one to three years that Mr. Norman received after other corruption trials. In four trials on separate corruption charges, Mr. Norman was convicted three times and acquitted once. In the most recent trial, prosecutors described a plan to shake down judicial candidates in exchange for party support. The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said in a statement, This trial showed how Clarence Norman manipulated the judicial selection system and perverted the way judges are elected in this county.

title: Manhattan School Challenges U.S. Rules and Sends Students on a Spring Break Trip to Cuba
description: When the citys Education Department said it would not let students from the Beacon School on the Upper West Side take a spring break trip to Cuba this year, the school turned to a powerful friend for help: Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson, whose stepdaughter went on the trip as a Beacon student in 2005. His call did not make a difference; city officials would not budge.

title: Singers and Composers in a Stylistic Mix and Match
description: Fashion designers like tall, skinny girls to model their clothes so they can design without worrying about the fit. Composers, meanwhile, write vocal music for a voice type, but with no guarantee the part will fit.

title: Two Bands, Different on the Surface but With Quite a Few Shared Ideas
description: These days its hard to tell whats outside from whats in my mind, sang Craig Minowa of Cloud Cult at the Mercury Lounge on Sunday night. He was delivering a line from the bands gently psychedelic new single, Chemicals Collide. His lyrics described a sort of commingling  of essences or enzymes, or maybe both  between romantic partners. He made chemistry sound like a mystical act.

title: Three Southern Women in Their House of Blues
description: Is Ashlin Halfnight for real? With a name that inspires thoughts of things going bump in the night and a rsum that includes stints as a folk musician, minor league hockey player, Harvard undergraduate and New York International Fringe Festival playwright, Mr. Halfnight sounds like a character in a macabre and slightly unbelievable play. The truth is, he only wrote one.

description: BOSTON, April 16  Into the bellowing winds and between the raindrops of a dying northeaster, the runners set out for the 111th Boston Marathon on Monday morning.

description: BAGHDAD, April 16  Moktada al-Sadr, the rebellious Shiite cleric, withdrew his six ministers from the Iraqi cabinet on Monday, in the first major shake-up of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis government since it was installed a year ago.

title: Fight Seen for ABN; Stock Soars
description: LONDON, April 16  The prospect of a bidding war for ABN Amro sent its shares soaring on Monday, making it more difficult for the company, the biggest Dutch bank, to seal a merger deal with its preferred partner, Barclays, and reject an unusual overture from a group of three European banks.

description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 17  Ryan Clark was known as Stack here on the rolling campus of Virginia Tech, an amiable senior memorable for his ready smile and thoughtful ways.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 16  After a flurry of deal making over the last few days, Google and Yahoo, two giants of the online advertising business, are set to encroach on each others turf even more aggressively than before.

description: The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about Field & Stream magazine and its four nominations for National Magazine Awards, misstated the date the 2007 awards will be presented. It is May 1, not May 4.

title: How (and How Not) to Battle Flu: A Tale of 23 Cities
description: When the Spanish flu reached the United States in the summer of 1918, it seemed to confine itself to military camps. But when it arrived in Philadelphia in September, it struck with a vengeance.

title: Hopes for a Renaissance After Exodus in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS  Cities, like most living things, have sensitive spots. Here in the old Gateway to the West, the subject of population loss is one of the touchiest.

title: Albany: Spitzer Asks Judicial Ethics Chairman to Resign
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer called on Raoul Felder yesterday to step down as the chairman of a state commission that oversees state and local judges in the wake of a vote of no confidence by the other commissioners last week. Mr. Felder, left, a celebrity divorce lawyer appointed by George E. Pataki, is the chairman of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct. The other nine members of the commission cast their vote against him last week because they said a new book Mr. Felder wrote with the comedian Jackie Mason repeatedly invokes racial, ethnic and religious invective. Mr. Felder has disputed the characterization of the book and said he would fight any move to oust him before his term ends next March.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (Sundance Channel) BIG IDEAS FOR A SMALL PLANET The centerpiece of The Green, a weekly television and online (sundancechannel.com/thegreen) programming block dedicated to environmental awareness, this 13-part documentary series interviews designers who have come up with green options for everyday living. title: Israel: Little Support for Holocaust Survivors
description: Nearly a third of the estimated 260,000 Holocaust survivors in Israel are living in poverty and struggling to get state medical services or sufficient pensions, according to a report by the Holocaust Survivors Welfare Fund. The report, timed to coincide with Holocaust Remembrance Day, was delivered to Parliament on Sunday. Hundreds of survivors, advocates and students marched outside the building in protest. We keep being very critical of those who have not admitted guilt or deny that there was a Holocaust, but here we are ignoring the people who are living in dire poverty, said Collette Avital, a member of Parliament who advocates for Holocaust survivors. Isaac Herzog, the social affairs minister, asked to take control of the care for Holocaust survivors, now under the Finance Ministry. I feel deeply ashamed, he said.

The witness, Michael DiLeonardo, a Gambino captain, testified that the defendant, Dominick Pizzonia, made the statement to John A. Gotti outside a social club where patrons had been robbed. He told John he was going to go after them, Mr. DiLeonardo said. He was going to kill them.
