The piece is in two parts, the first an adagio of twisting, turning harmonic originality, the second a busy, fast-moving allegro. Orpheus, a small orchestra famous for what it doesnt have (a conductor), produced at the start a near-breathtaking, bass-driven sonority  well tuned, single-minded in its mutual concentration and just plain beautiful to hear.

title: Beam Me Up
description: How lasers work: In dermatology-speak, the word laser is a catchall for devises that use intense beams of focused bright light, those that use intense pulsed light (producing short, quick flashes) and ones that employ radio frequency or electromagnetic energy. To diminish wrinkles, some types of lasers, like Titan and Thermage, send energy deep into the dermis (the lower layers of skin) without damaging the epidermis (the upper layer). That energy creates heat and a slight injury, which sends the body into repair mode, encouraging existing collagen (a building block of skin) to contract and become tighter, and stimulating new collagen and elastin (another building block) to be produced. The result? Smoother, plumper, more youthful-looking skin. Other lasers, like Lyra, Affirm and V-Beam, have specific wavelengths that are attracted only to certain pigments, such as red or brown, and destroy anything within that color range, so they work well on blood vessels, spider veins, sunspots and hair. What a laser procedure is like: Most involve an application of topical anesthesia or a cooling gel, followed by a few passes of the device over the area to be treated. Patients usually experience slight warmth or a mild burning sensation, which dissipates quickly. Aftereffects can be similar to a sunburn  including some redness, swelling or flaking for up to a few days. How to find the right person to perform the procedure: Since you do not need a license to operate a laser, its best to look for a board-certified dermatologist (check the American Academy of Dermatology Web site at www.aad.org) who has lasers as a major part of his or her practice. Be sure to do your research: in the wrong hands, you could be burned or scarred. Adds Dennis Gross, M.D., a dermatologist and dermatological surgeon in New York (212-725-4555), A word-of-mouth recommendation never hurts. How to take care of post-laser skin: Use gentle products, dont scrub and slather on a nonirritating sunscreen  like one with zinc oxide  on a daily basis. Cost: It depends on the doctor, the size of the area to be treated and the strength of the laser.

title: Manhattan: Cultural Development Studied for Ground Zero
description: City officials pledged at a City Council hearing yesterday to work with the state, the Signature Theater and the Joyce Theater to produce a feasibility study in eight weeks on cultural development at ground zero. The cultural affairs commissioner, Kate D. Levin, said she hoped to have a better sense of the artistic programming, construction costs and a timetable in the next two months. The Joyce, which presents dance, will be the sole occupant of a performing arts center at the ground zero site; the Signature Theater was supposed to share the center, but is considering a move into nearby Fiterman Hall because sharing seems too complicated.

A video of the order, posted on the Internet, drew a protest from the Bronx borough president, Adolfo Carrin Jr., who demanded an apology. The mayor of Rendsburg, where the base is situated, invited Mr. Carrin to visit, saying that he could not excuse the two soldiers but that most of the troops there were open-minded and tolerant.

Kraft spent more than $160 million to advertise the brands in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.

description: WASHINGTON, April 16  AARP, the lobby for older Americans, announced Monday that it would become a major participant in the nations health insurance market, offering a health maintenance organization to Medicare recipients and several other products to people 50 to 64 years old.

The citys proposal included plans to build a stadium in Flushing in conjunction with the Mets; the bid was not submitted without plans for a stadium. (The NYC2012 group turned to the Flushing alternative late in the process, after plans fell apart for a West Side stadium in Manhattan.)

description: The recent controversy over allowing severely emaciated girls to walk the fashion runways was mostly played out in letters to the editor and in designer caucuses behind closed doors. The public greeted the news with a shrug, revealing the extent to which most people now regard anorexia nervosa as just another occupational hazard. Models starve themselves the way football players take steroids, jeopardizing their health and longevity for celebrity and wealth.

Borja, the New York City police officer whose death from lung disease was held up as an example of the medical problems affecting thousands of ground zero workers and volunteers, found no record that he worked in Lower Manhattan until Dec. 24, 2001, more than three months after the 9/11 attack.

description: Dr. Elizabeth Nabel, a practicing cardiologist and researcher studying the genesis of plaque in coronary arteries, became director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute on Feb. 1, 2005. Her answers to readers questions about heart disease appear below.

description: WASHINGTON, April 16  The Bush administrations allies in Congress on Monday blocked a bill that would require the White House to disclose the locations of secret prisons run by the Central Intelligence Agency and to reveal the amount spent annually by American intelligence agencies.

It was $5.5 million, not $5 million, from the Ford Motor Company and the Ford Motor Company Fund  not from the company and the Ford Foundation. Also, a picture caption referred incorrectly to Henry R. Muoz III, who raised much of the money for the museum. He is an executive of an architectural firm, not an architect.

title: Brooklyn: Bookseller Sentenced for Plotting to Buy Arms
description: A bookseller was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 13 years in prison for plotting to buy arms for Islamic fighters in Afghanistan. Prosecutors say that the bookseller, Abdulrahman Farhane, 53, met with an undercover federal informant in his bookstore in late 2001 to discuss ways to send money overseas to buy weapons for the fighters. Three other men, including a jazz musician and an emergency room doctor, have also pleaded guilty to terrorism charges in the case and are awaiting sentencing.

description: President Bush has reneged on his promises to Katrinas victims. Shamefully, the president has chosen the interests of bureaucracy over those of American towns on the brink of failure.

description: Mollie Orshansky, a statistician and economist who in the 1960s developed the federal poverty line, a measurement that shaped decades of social policy and welfare programs, died Dec. 18 at her home in Manhattan, a family member said yesterday. She was 91.

description: CAMDEN, N.J. April 16  Gov. Jon S. Corzine on Monday underwent his third operation for the severe leg fracture he suffered in a traffic accident last week, and doctors said afterward that they expect him to be able to walk without crutches in three to six months.

Artists who have recently cut new versions of their famous songs include Randy Bachman of Bachman-Turner Overdrive, Twisted Sister and Foreigner.

description: Fremont General said Monday that it had found a buyer for most of its home loan business, suggesting that the struggling lender might have found a way out of the troubled subprime mortgage industry. Its stock surged more than 25 percent.

description: WPP Group, the global advertising and marketing giant, said Monday it had invested $3.5 million for an undisclosed stake in VideoEgg, the online video platform and advertising network company.

description: Searching for Lauren McCain | 9:36 PM ET

title: More China Trouble for Carlyle?
description: Carlyle Group, the giant Washington-based private equity fund, has reportedly suffered a new setback in China. The weekly business magazine Caijing reported that Chinese government regulators have rejected Carlyles bid to take a 7.99 percent stake in Chongqing Commercial Bank, ostensibly because of a banking rule that prevents foreign investors with total assets of less than $10 billion from becoming a major shareholder in Chinese commercial banks. The rule, which is not consistently applied in China, would virtually disqualify all regional private-equity funds active in the Asia-Pacific area, Forbes.com reported.

title: Bid in Hand, Intelsat Looks for More
description: Intelsat, which runs the worlds largest network of communications satellites, has been put up for sale by the private equity funds that own it, according to The New York Times. And they apparently have the Blackstone Group to thank for giving them the idea.

title: Crunching Numbers on Data Domains I.P.O.
description: Data Domain has filed for an initial public offering of as much as $100 million in stock, despite a choppy market for tech I.P.O.s. The 451 Group, an analyst firm, assesses the outlook for the venture-backed data deduplication specialist, which some have touted as the next Network Appliance.

title: An Oil Mogul and a Family Drama
description: T. Boone Pickens of BP Capital is one of the most complex characters in modern-day capitalism, Portfolio magazine writes in a profile of the self-made oil tycoon, whose son pleaded guilty last year to securities fraud. It describes the hedge fund manager, who earned about $1.5 billion in 2005, as a combination of King Lear, Lazarus, Robin Hood, and Amarillo Slim.

title: Delta Says Creditors Approved Reorganization Plan
description: Delta Air Lines said Monday that unofficial voting results show its reorganization plan has received enough creditor support to be approved. The Atlanta-based carrier, which successfully fended off a hostile takeover bid from US Airways while in Chapter 11 protection, will go to court April 25 to ask a judge to confirm the plan, paving the way for it to emerge from bankruptcy on April 30. The Atlanta-based airline said in a statement that the results show that more than 95 percent of ballots cast were in favor of the plan.

title: Former Atmel Chief to Wage Proxy Battle
description: Semiconductor maker Atmels largest individual shareholder and former chief executive, George Perlegos, said Monday he proposed the company bring in a new board, hire a new C.E.O. and buy back up to $1 billion in shares. Mr. Perlegos said in a statement that he filed a proxy urging shareholders to adopt the measures and has nominated five new members to the board of directors, stating they would in turn seek to bring in three additional directors.

title: Macquarie Powers Up Deal for Canadian Energy Fund
description: Macquarie Bank, the acquisitive Australian financial institution that has been snapping up Canadian assets from roads to nursing homes, is now making a further foray into Canadas energy business. Macquarie Power & Infrastructure Income Fund has offered to buy Clean Power Income Fund, a Toronto-based trust that owns the 99-megawatt Erie Shores wind farm in Ontario along with several hydro and biomass plants across the country.

title: DoubleCick Deal Puts Spotlight on Rivals
description: Googles $3.1 billion acquisition of online advertising firm DoubleClick drove up shares of other Internet ad firms. What was behind the rise? Many investors were betting that Microsoft (which was reportedly also in the running for DoubleClick) and Yahoo would be driven to make deals of their own to keep up with Google.

title: Golden West Deal Helps Lift Wachovia Earnings
description: Wachovia said Monday that its first-quarter earnings rose 33 percent, helped by growth in lending income and the acquisition of Golden West Financial. The Charlotte, N.C., bank said it remained on track to meet its goals from its $24.2 billion acquisition of Golden West, which it acquired in October, though chief executive officer Ken Thompson said its a trying time to be a participant in the mortgage market.

title: Behind Silicon Valleys I.P.O. Drought
description: As more venture capitalists and entrepreneurs are choosing mergers and acquisitions rather than initial public offerings as their exit of choice, the trend has some in Silicon Valley worried, says The San Jose Mercury News. According to industry tracker VentureOne, 40 venture-backed Silicon Valley start-ups were acquired in the first quarter of this year, compared with 53 in all of 1997. Meanwhile,the region was home to 417 companies in 2000, compared with the 280 I.P.Os last year.

title: Nacchio Jury Ends 3rd Day of Deliberations
description: Jurors went home Monday after a third day of deliberations in the $101 million insider trading trial of Joe Nacchio, the former head of Qwest Communications International. Youve put in another long day so Im going to let you go home for the evening, the presiding Judge, Edward W. Nottingham, of United States District Court, said.

title: US Airways Chief Reaps $5.4 Million in 2006
description: The chief executive of US Airways, W. Douglas Parker, who failed in his attempt last year to pull off a merger with a recalcitrant Delta Air Lines, received salary and bonuses of $5.4 million last year, chalked up gains of $9 million by exercising stock options and still holds options and other stock holdings that are currently valued at roughly $30 million.

title: AT&T Drops Offer to Invest in Italian Phone Company
description: AT&T on Monday withdrew its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, the largest Italian telecommunications company, for about two billion euros, or $2.7 billion. In a terse statement, AT&T did not give any reason for the decision to pull back its offer to buy a third of the controlling company, Olimpia. But The New York Times reports that AT&T became disenchanted with the idea following intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company.

title: SoundBite Files for $69 Million I.P.O.
description: SoundBite Communications, a 7-year-old company that provides automated voicemail-message delivery, seeks to raise as much as $69 million in an initial public offering. SoundBites investors include North Bridge Venture Partners and Mosaic Venture Partners, and Cowen and Company and Thomas Weisel Partners are among the offerings underwriters. According to SoundBites preliminary prospectus, it plans to use proceeds from the stock sale to repay $3.5 million in debt as well as for general corporate purposes, including potential acquisitions.

title: As ABN Stock Soars, Hopes of a Barclays Deal Fade
description: The prospect of a bidding war for ABN Amro sent its shares soaring on Monday, making it more difficult for the company, the biggest Dutch bank, to seal a merger deal with its preferred partner, Barclays, and reject an unusual overture from a group of three European banks.

title: Consortium Raises Its Offer for Australias APN
description: A consortium led by Independent News and Media, the Irish newspaper publisher headed by Tony OReilly, raised its offer for APN News & Media, Australias fourth largest media group. The group, which also includes buyout shops the Carlyle Group and Providence Equity, tabled a a new bid Tuesday worth 6.20 Australian dollars ($5.17) per share, compared to the previous offer of A$6.10 ($3.08).

title: Hedge Funds Big Tax Vacation
description: Would you like to avoid paying much of your income tax for decade or so? Many hedge fund managers can.

title: Fishy Gold Fields Bidder Demands Apologies
description: A man claiming to be Edward Pastorini, the mystery man named in a dubious Bloomberg News report as the bidder for gold producer Gold Fields, has demanded apologies from the Financial Timess Alphaville blog and from a writer at The New York Post for doubting the veracity of his existence.

title: Sequoia Gets Its Kicks With Will Ferrell Web Site
description: Who says venture capitalists have no sense of humor? Well, if anyone was saying it, a recent venture by Sequoia Capital would put the kibosh on that notion. The investment firm which has backed YouTube, Google, Yahoo, Oracle and Apple, among others, has partnered up up with funny man Will Ferrell and writer-director-producer Adam Mckay to launch FunnyOrDie.com, a comedy video site that began its beta release Thursday.

title: Rival Boots Bidders Get Look at Books
description: A consortium led by London-based private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners has gained access to the books of British retailer Alliance Boots to begin due diligence, according to reports. The group has the money, the books and advisers and just needs to decide if it wants to proceed [with a bid], a source close to Terra Firma reportedly told The Deal.com.

title: G.E. and NBC Launch $250 Million Media Fund
description: General Electric is launching a $250 million equity fund to invest in media and technology companies, part of a broader push by traditional media companies to get into hot areas such as digital advertising or social networks.

title: Hedge Funds Could Gain from Sallie Mae Deal
description: When Sallie Mae goes private in a $25 billion deal announced Monday, the company will be saddling itself with debt in an effort to generate even more lucrative returns. And some of the biggest winners in the debt-fiesta may be hedge fund traders.

title: CalPERS Plans to Reject Clear Channel Offer
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the largest U.S. public pension fund, said it will vote against the $19 billion purchase of Clear Channel Communications, becoming the third big shareholder to oppose the takeover. The acquisition is not in the shareowners best interest, Calpers said on its Web site Monday . The fund owns 3.34 million shares of Clear Channel, or less than 1 percent of the largest U.S. radio broadcaster.

title: BCE in Buyout Talks With Canadian Funds and K.K.R.
description: BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, said Tuesday it was in discussions with a consortium of Canadian pension funds about a deal to take the company private. The consortium, led by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, the Caisse de dpt et placement du Qubec, and Canadas Public Sector Pension Investment Board, also includes New York-based buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts as a minority partner, BCE said. Last week, The New York Times reported that the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, BCEs largest shareholder, was in early talks with other investors about mounting a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE in what would be the largest buyout in history. BCE said at the time it was not in any current talks with any other parties.

title: Young People and the War in Iraq
description: The younger generation is opposed to the war in Iraq, right? Wrong. Actually, they're divided on the war, far more so than their grandparents, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll in March. Seems younger people are more supportive of the war and the president than any other age group.

title: Whats in a Street Name?
description: We turn once again to the New York City tradition of street co-naming. The City Councils Parks and Recreation Committee will consider an omnibus bill on Thursday that will add extra names to 53 streets, based on recommendations from Community Boards. The list includes the actor Jerry Orbach, whose widow has been waging a public campaign to get a Midtown corner renamed in his honor.

title: The Gun Control Question
description: The New York Times editorial page says the massacre at Virginia Tech shows the need for stronger controls over the lethal weapons that cause such wasteful carnage and such unbearable loss. The Washington Post editorial page says the incident poses many questions, including one that suggests that the Times has it backward: Would the university have suffered the same tragedy if Virginia law did not prohibit the carrying of guns on campus? The Los Angeles Times editorial page thinks everyone should remember that there are times when silence is the best response. (Though the L.A. Times editorial also adds, No newspaper is in a position to criticize anybody for capitalizing on tragedy or taking convenient positions.)

title: A Clash of Alternative Investment Titans
description: Hedge funds and private equity firms have grown colossally over the past few years, often working in tandem to shake up underperforming companies. But as they continue to expand and the lines between the two blur, conflicts between the these investment pools may increase, attendees at the 2007 MARHedge conference in San Francisco told MarketWatch.

title: 2008: Tragic Break in the Routine
description: Monday should have been a normal day for the campaigns. Of course, it wasnt. The New York Daily News rounds up what campaigns have been doing to acknowledge the shootings at Virginia Tech, such as shifting concerts to memorials and canceling fund-raisers and events.

title: Obama Postpones Speech
description: Senator Barack Obama has postponed a foreign policy address he intended to deliver today in Chicago.

title: Financial Gymnastics: A Spinoff, With a Twist
description: There was a time that conglomerates were all the rage. This is not such a time.

title: The Day After
description: At public gatherings and in quiet spots around campus, Virginia Tech students created memorials and consoled one another.

title: C.J. Nitkowski Checks in From Japan
description: There is a nice story in todays Times by David Picker, who examines the concept of fight money in Japan, where managers sometimes reward players with cash for good performances. Our friend C.J. Nitkowski, a 10-year major league veteran, is quoted in the story.

title: Blacksburg or Baghdad?
In Race for Wall Street Funds, Obama Has Early Lead
description: As the focus on presidential fundraising intensifies, it seems Barack Obama has taken the lead in one leg of the race. For the first quarter of the year, the Democratic senator from Illinois has taken on his more established New York rivals in hitting up Wall Street, Bloomberg News notes.

title: Neiman Marcus Said to Consider I.P.O.
description: After acquiring J. Crew Group in 1997, Texas Pacific Group waited nearly nine years to take the clothing retailer public again. Will it see a much quicker turnaround on Neiman Marcus?

title: The Shooting Victims
description: Did you know any of the victims of Monday's shooting at Virginia Tech? Please e-mail us photographs of the victims that we can publish on NYTimes.com. Also share your thoughts and memories by clicking on their names below.

title: Catalina Spurns ValueAct for Hellman & Friedman
description: Breaking an earlier takeover agreement, Catalina Marketing said Tuesday it had accepted a higher $1.7 billion offer from the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman. The deal tops an earlier offer made by Catalinas largest investor, the activist hedge fund ValueAct Capital.

title: Playing the Goldman Breakup Game
description: Mark DeCambre admits up front that Goldman Sachs isnt considering a breakup right now. But that hasnt stopped Mr. DeCambre, who writes for TheStreet.com, from joining the others who have recently speculated about what such a hypothetical and unlikely breakup might mean for the hugely profitable securities giant. The main reason for all the what-iffing seems to be a fascination with Goldmans rather opaque collection of businesses and a desire to compare Goldman with financial companies such as Fortress Investment Group, a hedge fund and private equity firm with some Goldman-like features but a much higher valuation on Wall Street.

title: Jackie Mason Kvetches About Spitzer
description: The comedian Jackie Mason came to the defense of his co-author Raoul Felder this morning and criticized the governor for calling on Mr. Felder to step down as chairman of a state commission overseeing judges because of remarks in their new book.

title: Hellman & Friedman Raises $8.4 Billion Buyout Fund
description: Hellman & Friedman is having a busy week. Just a few days ago, the San Francisco private equity firm agreed to sell portfolio company DoubleClick to Google for $3.1 billion, well above the $1.1 billion that Hellman and JMI Equity paid for the advertising firm just two years ago. On Tuesday, Hellman & Friedman announced that it raised $8.4 billion for its latest private equity fund, giving it plenty of ammunition for more deals. The new fund, which is the firms sixth, represents more than half of the $16 billion that Hellman & Friedman has raised since 1987.

title: Fortresss Very Good 2006
description: In its first annual report since going public, Fortress Investment Group revealed Tuesday just how profitable last year was for the firm, which posted strong returns fueled by rising investment profit and asset-management fees. The private equity and hedge fund manager, which went public in February in a landmark stock offering, reported revenue of $1.52 billion, a 46 percent jump from 2005.

title: Have White-Collar Prosecutions Gone Too Far?
description: Many backlashes bring a counter-backlash, and that may be what is going on with corporate crime. It has become trendy in certain circles to say that the government is cracking down too hard on company executives. James Surowiecki of the New Yorker has noticed this trend as relates to Conrad Black, the former chief of Hollinger International who is now being tried on fraud charges. Mr. Black  whose own defense lawyer has described him as egotistical and arrogant  is not an obviously sympathetic figure, as Mr. Surowiecki understates it. But even he is being defended by journalists, legal commentators, and myriad bloggers, Mr. Surowiecki writes.

title: Reunion.com Connects With Big Funding Round
description: Formed in 2002, Reunion.com is already coming up on its fifth anniversary. But the company, which runs a Web site for former schoolmates to get in touch with each other, only just announced its first round of venture capital funding, a $25 million slug from Oak Investment Partners. Red Herring describes Reunion.com as a social networking site in the Web 2.0 camp, like the much more popular online hangouts MySpace or Facebook.

title: Remembering Virginia Tech Victims
description: Before attending a convocation on the campus, members of the Virgina Tech community reflected on Monday's tragedy.

title: Payback Time
description: Assemblyman N. Nick Perry of Brooklyn was one of several lawmakers to speak today before the Transit Workers Union on the occasion of their lobby day in Albany. And he did not mince words when it came to Judge Theodore T. Jones, the Court of Appeals jurist who slapped the TWU with heavy fines  and sent its leader, Roger Toussaint, to jail  during last years transit strike.

title: Tea Leaves, Ink Blots, Entrails
description: After a much-anticipated hour and a half hearing that bristled with questions, comments and clarifications, the Landmarks Preservation Commission declined to rule today on the New-York Historical Societys controversial proposal to renovate the exterior of its landmark building at 170 Central Park West.

title: Kerry: Imus Shouldnt Have Been Fired
description: Given the events of this week, the controversy over Don Imuss racially charged remarks aimed at the Rutgers womens basketball team seem farther away than just a week or so ago.

title: Agendas in Conflict
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer set out his agenda for the rest of the Legislative session, which runs through June 21, and campaign finance reform was at the top of the list. Slight problem: The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, detailed his own agenda for the rest of the session this week and campaign finance reform was nowhere on his list.

title: Senate, Heal Thyself
description: We asked Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, what he thought of legislation being proposed over in the Senate that would impose term limits on the leadership positions in both houses of the Legislature.

title: Assemblys Member Items
description: The state Assembly just posted its list of member items in the 2007/08 budget here. For the uninitiated, these are legislative pet projects  pork would be another word  that lawmakers dole out to constituents throughout the state.

title: School Is in Session
description: Ladies and gentlemen, let the drinking begin.

title: Love in the Digital Age
description: This winter I was in a class called Romantic Comedy. Shakespeare, you might ask? Umm  no. Were talking Youve Got Mail. I figured this had to be the Rocks for Jocks of the film department, but as it turned out, Rom-Com was no sunset stroll down the beach. We dragged our feet through Freudian readings of Bringing Up Baby and analyzed the shift from modernism to postmodernism by contrasting The Apartment with Annie Hall. All I wanted to do was kick back with some popcorn and take a vacation from my not-so-Moonstruck freezing-cold Dartmouth winter, but unfortunately there would be an exam.

title: Bloomberg: A Day to Grieve and Pray
description: A day after a student killed 32 people and himself at Virginia Tech university, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg refused to wag a finger at the Virginia gun dealers and lawmakers who have been among the most hostile to his national campaign to stop illegal gun sales.

title: Live From Windy  But Not Rainy  Philadelphia
description: This is not a misprint: Its not raining. But a Mets game would not be complete without the requisite fun from Mother Nature: the flags high above center field at Citizens Bank Park have not stopped swirling since I got here five hours ago. From here in the mercifully enclosed press box, it seems as if the winds blowing hard out to right, and any fly ball hit to left should be knocked down. Well see how that affects all the left-handed sluggers  Chase Utley, Ryan Howard, Carlos Beltran, Carlos Delgado  who will be playing tonight.

title: Torre Talks About Massacre
description: At the end of Joe Torres pre-game news briefing before last nights game against the Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium, one of the reporters asked the Yankees manager about the massacre at Virginia Tech on Monday, in which a student with two handguns killed 32 people and himself.

title: Practice Makes Perfect  Sense
description: Since I am working on an article about Derek Jeters defensive troubles for Wednesdays newspaper, I studied everything Jeter did before the Yankees played the Cleveland Indians. I took notes as Jeter fielded 71 of the 72 grounders slapped at him by Larry Bowa, the third base coach and a former terrific shortstop.

title: Abroad: Portland, Oregon
description: Here is how the world works. I am sitting at Stumptown coffee, my very first stop in Portland, when I check my Blackberry for news and see that my friend Lars Nilsson, formerly of Nina Ricci and Blass, has sent me an e-mail from Paris. Lars says that a friend of his, Patrick Long, is coming to one of my talks here and that we should get togetherand by the way, I should try the coffee at Stumptown.

title: Virginia Tech and Darfur
description: With the horror of Virginia Tech, we see up close the horror that has been happening continually in Darfur for four years. One reader, David, wrote President Bush as follows (he copied me:

title: Africa and Win-A-Trip
description: When I visited University of North Carolina recently, I ran into lots of students who were desperate to meet me to bolster their chances of winning the win-a-trip contest. But I also met one student, Loren Berlin, who didnt apply, and she gave me this thoughtful note explaining why. Its provocative, so let me share it in full:

title: Yet Another Flood, and Residents Ask, Why Stay Here?
description: BOUND BROOK, N.J.

title: For School, Several Ties to Shootings
description: CHANTILLY, Va., April 17  Heaven gained an amazing angel was written in black marker on a boulder next to Westfield High School that became a makeshift shrine of plastic flowers and candles for Reema Samaha, one of the victims of Mondays shooting at Virginia Tech. We love you, read a note written on a boulder for another of the high schools victims, Erin Peterson.

title: World Cup Bidding Is Brazil's to Lose
description: Brazil has won five World Cup titles and exports hundreds of players to leagues around the world but has played host to only one World Cup tournament, in 1950 (losing in the final to Uruguay). If statements from FIFA headquarters in Zurich are credible, it will be awarded the 2014 World Cup later this year  probably.

title: Declining Stars, in to Have Their Heads Shrunk
description: Head Case is a new comedy with a relatively languorous pace and no laugh track  the kind of show that, like Larry Davids or Ricky Gervaiss, wants to remind you what a fount of abasement daily existence actually is. It stars Alexandra Wentworth, the actress and comedian (and wife of George Stephanopoulos), who also writes for the show. And it revolves around a therapists office in Los Angeles, a premise fairly easy to imagine taking off in as many predictable directions as there are routes to the Staples Center.

title: Japanese Researchers Rebut Premiers Denials on Sex Slavery
description: TOKYO, April 17  A group of Japanese researchers on Tuesday publicly challenged Prime Minister Shinzo Abes denials that Japans military coerced women into sexual slavery during World War II, citing reports compiled by Allied investigators immediately after the war.

title: The Right to Our DNA (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Drums, Bells and Auto Parts, but Nary a String to Be Seen
description: The stage of Alice Tully Hall was awash on Monday night with objects meant to be struck  from marimbas, vibraphones and timpani to auto parts. The occasion was a joint performance by the percussion ensembles of the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music, which combined to present Charles Wuorinens Percussion Symphony (1976) for the second time this month. An earlier performance at the Manhattan School served as a dry run for Mondays more widely publicized presentation.

title: Correction: Where the Motto Is: Try, Try Again
description: A restaurant review last Wednesday of E.U., in the East Village, referred incorrectly to the beers served there. No beer from Denmark is available. The restaurant serves beer from the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia, which divided in 1993 to create the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

title: For U.S.-Nigeria Go-Between, Ties Yield Profits
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  For years, Andrew Young, the civil rights leader, has been deeply involved in this country through the lobbying and consulting firm he heads, GoodWorks International. Its motto is: We do well by doing good.

title: Judge Is Called Robed Robber or Just the Victim of a Setup
description: Nearly half a decade after their investigation began, prosecutors in Brooklyn concluded their case yesterday against a former State Supreme Court justice accused of taking cash and gifts to manipulate divorce cases.

title: Remaking Old Hits to Earn New Money
description: In 1986, the pop band Wang Chung released the ludicrous but catchy party anthem Everybody Have Fun Tonight. Now two of the musicians behind the band have hatched a plan that might seem even more absurd than the lyric everybody Wang Chung tonight. More than two decades after the song became a smash hit, they are recording it again.

title: In Los Angeles, a Gehry-Designed Awakening
description: LOS ANGELES  The influx of thousands of new residents has reinvigorated this citys downtown in recent years, but most of the development has been clustered on its southern end, near the Staples Center, the sports and entertainment arena.

title: Builder of Sallie Mae Deal Has a Daring History
description: As a financial company, and one that began as a government-created company, Sallie Mae was an unlikely candidate for a leveraged buyout.

title: The Red Bulls Acquire a Striker From Aston Villa
description: The New York Red Bulls announced the acquisition of the 31-year-old Colombian striker Juan Pablo ngel yesterday from Aston Villa of the English Premier League. ngel will move to Major League Soccers Red Bulls after six and a half years with Villa, which paid a club-record transfer fee of about $19 million to obtain him from River Plate of Argentina in January 2001.

title: G.M. Says It Will Make More Vehicles and Buy More Parts in India
description: NEW DELHI, April 17  General Motors has big plans in India.

title: Presenting Some Ballet Classics, or Unreasonable Facsimiles Thereof
description: Les Ballets Grandiva, founded in 1996 by Victor Trevino, is an all-male ballet company with a couple of secret weapons. One is Mr. Trevino himself, who dances under the stage name of Nina Minimaximova. He may be small, but he moves with a captivating power. The other is its resident costume designer, Jose Coronado, whose design workshop is his kitchen. (He doesnt cook.) From the cut of his tutus to the elegance of his silky gowns, he proves to be masterly at creating costumes that enhance the shape of a dancer  no matter how unlikely that shape is.

title: Democracy Inches Along at Home
description: It is an uphill battle, but the House is right to confront the gross injustice that keeps the citizenry of the District of Columbia locked into that definitive grievance of the American revolution: taxation without representation. The 550,000 residents living in the shadow of the Capitols endless exercise in democracy have no voting representative in Congress.

title: New Standards for Citys Jails Are Debated
description: Dozens of correction officials and experts converged yesterday on the first and only public hearing to debate a plan to revise the standards that govern New York Citys jails.

title: Letter From California: On the Court and on the Bounce
description: In my left hand I am holding the throat of Maria Sharapovas tennis racket  a confection of titanium and graphite strung with some durable synthetic fiber. My right hand closes loosely on the grip. This is still a surprise to me: having a racket in my hands, standing on a tennis court, waiting for the ball.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the final night of the Lower East Side club Tonic misidentified the radio station where Daniel Blumin, who spoke about his experiences at the club, was once host of a show. It was WNYU, not WNYC.

title: Delhi Snacks Move Up From the Street
description: NEW DELHI

title: Adoring Yourself and Your Appetizer
description: San Francisco

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (AMC) HUSTLE  California, here they come. Albert, the veteran grifter played by Robert Vaughn, above far right, and his London crew (played by, from left, Robert Glenister, Jaime Murray, Marc Warren and the newcomer Ashley Walters, not shown) cross the pond to begin a new season of scamming in Los Angeles and Las Vegas. Tonight the con artists try to convince a movie memorabilia fanatic (Robert Wagner, in a guest role) that the Hollywood sign is coming up for sale. Yeah, right.

title: Hyundai Hires Agency for Creative Account
description: Hyundai Motor America today chose as its new creative advertising agency a shop with automotive experience for brands like Porsche, Saturn and Isuzu. Hyundai spends about $600 million a year on ads in major media.

title: Clear Channel Is Said to Get Raised Bid
description: Two private equity firms raised their offer for Clear Channel Communications by more than $1.5 billion yesterday, to about $27.6 billion, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about Lonely Hearts referred incorrectly to the suicide of the wife of the central character, the detective Elmer Robinson. She shoots herself; she does not slash her wrists.

title: Redesigning the Mets Home for Greek and Roman Art
description: The week that the Metropolitan Museum of Arts southernmost wing reopened as a restaurant in 1954, with outr birdcage chandeliers and a central pool dotted by whimsical muses, the architect Kevin Roche found himself eating there. I had a nice lunch, Mr. Roche, now 85, said. Thats about as far as I thought about it.

title: Kitty Carlisle Hart, Actress and Arts Advocate, Dies at 96
description: Kitty Carlisle Hart, who began her career in the theater in a 1932 musical comedy revue on Broadway, acted in films and opera and was still singing on the stage, into her 10th decade, as recently as last fall, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.The cause was heart failure, her daughter, Catherine Hart, said. Outgoing and energetic, Miss Carlisle became in her middle years a visible advocate of the arts, lobbying the New York State Legislature and the United States Congress for funding. For 20 years, first as a member and later as chairman of the New York Council on the Arts, she crisscrossed the state to support rural string quartets, small theater groups and inner-city dance troupes.

title: Assessing Damage and Mopping Up as Water Recedes
description: LODI, N.J., April 17  From Mamaroneck and New Rochelle in Westchester County to Bound Brook and Lodi in New Jersey, the New York City region took stock and mopped up on Tuesday from one of the rainiest April storms on record.

title: Before the N.F.L. Draft, All Eyes Are on the Texans
description: From his furniture store hard by Interstate 45 in Houston, Jim McIngvale has a window seat on a states obsession with football and with mans ability to forgive.

title: Word by Word, the World Becomes a Little Less Mystifying for Illiterate Adults
description: Lissette J. and Carlos R. finished high school decades ago but are often stumped reading menus, tabloid newspapers and street signs, and humiliated when nephews and nieces ask for homework help.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a lottery by immigration authorities to select applicants for 65,000 visas for highly skilled foreign workers misstated the requirements employers must meet in order to sponsor the visas, known as H-1B. For most of these visas, employers must affirm to the Labor Department that they will pay the immigrant at least the prevailing wage for the job and that hiring the immigrant would not negatively affect the labor conditions of United States workers in similar jobs. Employers do not have to show that no American workers were available for the job.

title: Manila Says Peace Corps Worker Is Dead
description: MANILA, April 18  A body believed to be that of an American Peace Corps volunteer who had been missing since last week was found today in a mountainous province in the north of the Philippines, officials said.

title: Germany: Army Trainer Dismissed
description: The German Army dismissed an instructor who was filmed in a training exercise telling a recruit to imagine he was firing his machine gun at African-Americans in the Bronx. The Defense Ministry said the instructor, a lance corporal, had been stripped of his rank and pay. The soldier who filmed the scenes with his camera phone is still under investigation.

title: Students Panicked and Then Held Off Gunman
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 17  He never said a word the whole time. Ive never seen a straighter face.

title: Just-War Theory (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Silky, Sweet and Tart, a Triple Threat
description: FOR cooks of a lemon-loving persuasion, a puckery citrus curd is the culinary analogue of a chocolate fanatics fudgy ganache. A cousin of lemon custard but without the milk or cream, lemon curd is a go-to topping, filling, sauce and eat-off-the-spoon treat. Its a mainstay of the pastry cooks repertory, yet subject to countless variations.

title: Corzines Speed Put at 91 M.P.H. Near Crash Site
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 17  In the seconds before Gov. Jon S. Corzine was critically injured in an accident last Thursday, the Chevrolet Suburban he was riding in was traveling 91 miles per hour, 26 m.p.h. over the posted speed limit, according to a crash data recorder retrieved from the vehicle.

title: Army Cost-Cutting in Budget Standoff May Actually Add to Costs
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  As the Army juggles its financial accounts and cuts logistical corners to maintain combat operations during a budget standoff between the White House and Congress, efficiency and economy are likely to be the first casualties.

title: U.S. Missile Deals Bypass, and Annoy, European Union
description: PARIS, April 13  Much of Europe is arguing over a Washington proposal to plant in Poland fewer than a dozen antimissile missiles that might not work, to guard against an Iranian threat that may not exist.

title: For an Agency, Life After Wal-Mart Is Called Kmart
description: HOWARD DRAFT and his agency, Draft FCB, are back in the retail advertising business  and this time, they hope, it will be for longer than a couple of months.

title: Gang-Related Killing of Japanese Mayor Shocks Nation
description: NAGASAKI, Japan, April 18  The mayor of the southern Japanese city of Nagasaki died on Wednesday after being gunned down in what appeared to be a murky gang-related killing, shocking a nation where crime rates are low and shootings extremely rare.

title: First Vaccine Against Avian Flu Is Approved as Interim Measure
description: The first vaccine against avian flu won government approval yesterday, even as federal officials conceded its usefulness in a flu pandemic might be limited.

title: Owner of Bell Canada in Talks to Go Private
description: OTTAWA, April 17  BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, said today that it was talking about going private with three Canadian pension funds and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity group.

title: Yahoos Earnings Are Down 11 Percent
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17  Yahoos top executives have been focused this year on an effort nicknamed Panama, after the vast canal project undertaken in the face of adversity. It is a major overhaul of the companys search advertising system, intended to increase revenue and close a growing gap with Google, the leader in Internet search.

title: Veal to Love, Without the Guilt
description: THE most successful animal rights boycott in the United States started more than 20 years ago and had nothing to do with foie gras.

title: Charges Dropped Against Marine
description: Military prosecutors have dismissed charges against one of four marines charged with murder in the killings of 24 Iraqi civilians, including several women and children, in Haditha, Iraq, in 2005, the Marine Corps announced yesterday.

title: Needless Student Loan Subsidies
description: With Congressional hearings on the student loan scandal scheduled for next week, lawmakers are looking around for ways to root out the kinds of corruption uncovered in recent investigations by New Yorks attorney general, Andrew Cuomo. A good start would be to pass the Student Loan Sunshine Act, an important bill that was introduced months ago.

title: A Reworked New Orleans Panel Adopts a Get-Tough Attitude on Levee Repairs
description: NEW ORLEANS  After years as a symbol of government sloth and corruption, the levee board here, newly revamped, is flexing its muscle and pushing the Army Corps of Engineers to prepare the city better for the next big storm.

title: Gunman Showed Signs of Anger
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 18  Cho Seung-Hui rarely spoke to his own dormitory roommate. His teachers were so disturbed by some of his writing that they referred him to counseling. And when Mr. Cho finally and horrifyingly came to the worlds attention on Monday, he did so after writing a note that bitterly lashed out at his fellow students for what he deemed their moral decay.

title: U.S. Limits Access to Student Loan Database
description: The Education Department last night cut off outside access to a government database that contains the personal financial information of millions of student aid applicants.

title: Two New Markets, With Food to Stay
description: IN the last year, two mega-grocery stores have opened in communities that were previously making do without one: Fairway Market in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and Whole Foods Market at the nexus of a few under-grocered downtown neighborhoods: the East Village, the Lower East Side and NoLIta.

title: Coast Guard to Manage Fleet Modernization
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  After months of criticism and setbacks, the Coast Guard announced Tuesday that it was taking over the management of its $24 billion fleet modernization project, curtailing the role of two military contractors that had been hired to run the job.

title: Citigroup Listens and Listens to Holders
description: Companies are increasingly being urged to listen more closely to shareholders. There could be such a thing as too much.

title: Rookie Shows Some Potential; Yankees Show Some Power
description: Chase Wrights major league debut came on a chilly evening, but his teammates gave him a Yankee Stadium housewarming gift: eight runs in the first two innings last night against the Cleveland Indians. That carried Wright and the Yankees to a 10-3 victory and some intriguing possibilities.

Her coach is Andrew Barranco  not Stephanie Weisenborn, who used to coach her. Joshua is 17, not 14.

title: Elizabeth: Police Announce Gang Arrests
description: Seventeen people said to be members of a Plainfield street gang have been arrested and charged with offenses including racketeering, weapons possession and drug charges, Union County officials said yesterday. Early Monday morning, agents with the Union County prosecutors office and state troopers raided 19 sites in Plainfield, Piscataway and Scotch Plains, the prosecutor, Theodore J. Romankow, said. The gang, known as the Clinton Avenue Posse, was responsible for street violence and drug dealing in the Plainfield area, Mr. Romankow said. Officials said that the police seized nine guns along with heroin and cocaine during the raids.

title: Conrad Spizz, 90, an Opera-Loving Master of Smoked Fish, Dies
description: Conrad Spizz, a tough-talking, cigar-chewing artisan of smoked fish whose work was enshrined behind glass at some of New Yorks best-known food shops, died on April 3 in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 90 and lived in New Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about Reginald H. Fuller, a biblical scholar, misidentified the Cambridge college from which he earned his undergraduate degree. It is Peterhouse, not Queens College.

title: The Sounds of Everyday Life, Punctuated by the War
description: The Iraq war, and the political climate surrounding it, have yet to produce a definitively great piece of theater. (Film has proved more responsive to their complexities.) But the current crises have surely given us plenty of bad theater, particularly at the margins, where young playwrights often seem to be pulling out steno pads and taking dictation from the angriest and most obstreperous parts of themselves.

title: Sudan Flying Arms to Darfur, Panel Reports
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 17  A confidential United Nations report says the government of Sudan is flying arms and heavy military equipment into Darfur in violation of Security Council resolutions and painting Sudanese military planes white to disguise them as United Nations or African Union aircraft.

title: West Bank: Israelis Kill Militant
description: Israeli forces shot and killed a militant belonging to the radical Islamic Jihad group south of Jenin in the West Bank, Israeli security officials said. An army spokesman said troops identified Ashraf Haneisheh, who was wanted by Israel, and shot him after he drew his handgun. Palestinian news reports identified Mr. Haneisheh as a member of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades and said he had been executed by an Israeli undercover special unit. Earlier in the day, Palestinian militants slightly wounded four Israelis in a drive-by shooting near the Jewish settlement of Modiin Ilit. Al Aksa Martyrs claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: Roy Moyer, 85, a Painter and Curator, Dies
description: Roy Moyer, a painter who helped bring works by other artists to museums across the United States, died on April 6 at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: New Jersey Transit Approves Fare Increase of 9.6 Percent
description: With only minor adjustments, New Jersey Transit approved today a proposed 9.6 percent average fare increase on its trains, buses and light rail to help close a $60 million budget gap for next fiscal year.

title: Ruling Limits State Control of Big Banks
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The mortgage lending subsidiaries of national banks are immune from state regulation, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday in a decision that upheld a controversial regulation issued six years ago by the office of the comptroller of the currency, the chief federal bank regulator.

description: WASHINGTON, April 18  A pillar of the Democratic political program tumbled today when Republicans in the Senate blocked a proposal to allow Medicare to negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans, a practice now forbidden by law.

title: Trailer-Park Sales Leave Residents With Single-Wides and Few Options
description: SYOSSET, N.Y., April 11  In the middle of Long Islands Gold Coast, where home prices easily reach $1 million, sits the Syosset Mobile Home Park, where a trailer can be had for under $50,000 and the monthly fee for taxes, water and sewage runs about $500. The children growing up in the parks 80 narrow homes attend Syosset schools, reputed to be among the best in the country.

description: Kmart is changing its creative advertising agency after four years, hiring the agency that recently won  then lost  the creative account of its major competitor, Wal-Mart Stores.

title: Bombings Kill at Least 171 Iraqis in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, April 18  Bombs ravaged Baghdad in five horrific explosions aimed mainly at Shiite crowds on Wednesday, killing at least 169 people in the deadliest day in the capital since the American-led security plan for the city took effect two months ago.

title: Italy: U.S. Soldier Tried for Baghdad Killing
description: Specialist Mario Lozano, the American Army soldier who fired on a car carrying Nicola Calipari, left, the deputy chief of Italian military intelligence, and Giuliana Sgrena, an Italian journalist rescued earlier after a month as an insurgent hostage in Iraq in 2005, went on trial in absentia in Rome. The trial was immediately adjourned until May 14 for technical reasons. Specialist Lozano, 37, is charged with voluntary homicide in the death of Mr. Calipari, who shielded the journalist during the shooting and is regarded as a hero, and with intent to kill in the wounding of Ms. Sgrena and another Italian agent. In interviews, Specialist Lozano has said the car was traveling too fast as it approached a roadblock on the way to Baghdad airport and did not respond to warning shots. In a report, the United States military cleared American soldiers of any responsibility.

title: Maybe Only God Can Make a Tree, but Only People Can Put a Price on It
description: It seems like a Zen koan: how much is a New York City tree worth? Since New Yorks first park was created in 1733, the various incarnations of the modern Parks and Recreation Department have tried to quantify a resource that at best is viewed as inherently valuable, like sunshine, or at worst is chopped down.

title: Limited Immunity Weighed for Ex-Aide to Gonzales
description: A House panel is considering granting limited immunity from prosecution to force testimony by a former aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales about the dismissals of eight United States attorneys. The House Judiciary Committee will meet today to discuss a proposal to grant immunity to the ex-aide, Monica Goodling, who resigned after invoking her Fifth Amendment right against compelled self-incrimination. Ms. Goodling was the attorney generals liaison to the White House and helped coordinate the effort to replace the eight United States attorneys, according to documents turned over to Congress. A two-thirds vote of the panel, which Democrats control 22 to 17, is required to seek a grant of limited immunity from prosecution, so four Republican votes would be needed. Such a grant would bar prosecutors from using any statements that Ms. Goodling makes to Congress.

title: Russia: Sensor Disabled Before Mine Blast
description: A disregard for safety in the interest of profit very likely caused the explosion in a Siberian mine last month that killed 108 people, the biggest mine disaster in Russias recent history, officials said. They said that the mines management deliberately disabled a methane detector, among other safety violations. A buildup of methane, sparked by a short circuit, caused the blast. The governor of the Kemerovo region, Aman-Geldi M. Tuleyev, said the managers defied safety regulations to increase production.

title: Extended Stay Hotels Is Sold for $8 Billion to Equity Group
description: Offering further proof that a real estate slowdown has not hampered property deal making, the Lightstone Group agreed yesterday to purchase Extended Stay Hotels from a private equity giant, the Blackstone Group, for $8 billion.

title: Queens: Man Admits Killing Sister-in-Law
description: A man halted the opening of his murder trial yesterday by admitting that he fatally shot his pregnant sister-in-law on Feb. 21, 2005, and hid her body in the trunk of her car in Jamaica, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Schiovone, 37, of Levittown, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to first-degree manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Schiovone admitted that he shot Susan Ambrosino, 26, of Franklin Square, as they sat in her car. Prosecutors say he shot Ms. Ambrosino because she planned to tell her ex-husband, Mr. Schiovones brother, that Mr. Schiovone was the father of her unborn child. Mr. Schiovone is expected to be sentenced to 30 years in prison.

title: City Reopens Old Rail Line for Staten Island Trash and Freight
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the reopening of the Staten Island Railroad yesterday, an important step in his plan to transform the way the city disposes of the thousands of tons of garbage it collects daily.

title: A Serving of Kalderetang, and a Guy to Explain It
description: Pistahan, 229 First Avenue (14th Street), is a friendly newcomer to a part of town that already has a few examples of its Filipino cuisine, a blend of Latino and Southeast Asian. This spot, whose name means festival, has a counter crammed with dishes like kalderetang, beef stewed in brown sauce, and binagoongan, vegetables in a thick sauce. All are sold to go, around $5 a pint, or to eat at a few cafe tables.

description: CAIRO, April 18  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates called today for Iraq to make faster progress on Sunni-Shia reconciliation, and warned that a collapse of the government could worsen sectarian strife and violence across the region.

Skakel returned to court on Tuesday seeking a new trial. His lawyers argued that they had found new evidence pointing to the possible involvement of some youngsters who were visiting from New York City.

title: Zimbabwe: Aid Groups Status Revoked
description: The government appeared to revoke the legal basis for all nongovernmental organizations to operate inside the country, arguing that some of the groups have provided cover for Western governments seeking to overthrow Robert G. Mugabe, the nations autocratic president. The state-run broadcaster Zimbabwe Television said the revocations would give officials time to screen out agents of imperialism from genuine organizations working to uplift the well-being of the poor. Mr. Mugabe has often accused private nongovernmental organizations of secretly channeling aid to the Movement for Democratic Change, the lone opposition party of note inside the country.

title: Casualties of Chinas Transformed Economy
description: Bracketed by stunning long shots taken from the front of a moving freight train, Wang Bings epic, three-part documentary, Tie Xi Qu: West of Tracks, is an astonishingly intimate record of Chinas painful transition from state-run industry to a free market. Filming between 1999 and 2001, Mr. Wang and his sound engineer, Lin Xudong, painstakingly document the death throes of the Tie Xi industrial district in the city of Shenyang, in northeast China, a once-vibrant symbol of a thriving socialist economy. As factories close and workers lose not only their jobs but also their homes and social networks, the filmmakers patiently observe the end of an era and the fortitude of those left floundering in its wake.

title: South Koreans React to Shooting in Virginia
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 18  South Korea takes great pride in Koreans who have become successful in the United States. So people here were stunned and ashamed to learn that the gunman responsible for the worst mass shooting in American history was a South Korean  Cho Seung Hui, a 23-year-old student at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute.

title: Looking Back in Anger at the Gilded Ages Excesses
description: In the decades after the Civil War, the United States took a sharp right turn and has been wandering in the wilderness ever since, hopelessly lost. Conceived in liberty and dedicated to equal justice for all, it squandered the moral capital painfully accumulated during the war, selling its soul to big corporations and capitalist fat cats. This, in brief, is Jack Beattys thesis in Age of Betrayal, his indignant history of the Gilded Age, a long nightmare of repression, racism and greed from which the country, in his view, has never awakened.

Second, that it manages to do a lot with relatively limited means: a single piano, a few folding chairs and lots of film. Third, that the music is pretty good.
