description: Just days before the start of the playoffs, the N.B.A. indefinitely suspended one of its top referees, Joey Crawford, for inappropriate behavior during Sundays San Antonio-Dallas game.

title: Gardens Dolan Doesnt Regret Deal With Thomas
description: Despite a dismal final month that crushed the Knicks playoff hopes, James L. Dolan said yesterday that he did not regret giving Isiah Thomas, the teams coach and president, a contract extension last month.

title: A Tribute That Is Both Rocking and Soulful
description: I could never keep up with him, Mick Jagger said at the tribute to Ahmet Ertegun  the diplomats son, record-business mogul, jazz fan, prime mover in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, dapper dresser and notorious bon vivant  last night at Jazz at Lincoln Centers Rose Theater. Mr. Ertegun, the chairman of Atlantic Records, who died on Dec. 14 at 83, was remembered by what Mr. Jagger teasingly called a diverse and fascinating group of people such as ourselves.

title: Unsettled Day on Campuses Around U.S.
description: Universities in Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas canceled classes yesterday, searched campuses or evacuated buildings in response to threats, and a Louisiana public school district locked down its middle school and high school.

title: Help Wanted
description: While in Kenya last week, my wife, Ann, a teacher, visited Mukuru-Kayaba Primary School in a Nairobi slum, where the U.S. helps finance a lunch program that keeps kids coming to class. When she returned from the school visit, she remarked to me that there was a poster on the wall of the school showing Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, during their visit to Kenya last August. The poster said: The Obamas know their H.I.V. status. Do you know yours? The senator and his wife had volunteered to be tested while in Nairobi.

title: A Tour of Muslim-Americans America
description: The Muslim Americans, the seventh entry in America at a Crossroads, PBSs omnibus series about the post-9/11 world, ought to have been spellbinding. Just five and a half years ago, the one American Muslim who could reliably be recruited to stand for Islam in the United States was Muhammad Ali, an athlete and a convert who had lost most of his eloquence on the subject. That was pathetic. Plenty of attention has been paid to Irish-Americans, Jewish Americans, Italian-Americans and African-Americans. The Muslim Americans could have been really powerful.

title: Expected Afghan Rebel Foray May Be Late, General Warns
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 17  An anticipated spring offensive by insurgents in Afghanistan has not materialized on a large scale, the commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan said Tuesday, but he warned that violence in the country could still reach the levels of last year and that poppy production would continue to increase.

title: Egyptian Nuclear Engineer Is Charged With Spying for Israel
description: CAIRO, April 17  An Egyptian nuclear engineer who worked for the countrys Atomic Energy Agency has been arrested and charged with spying for Israel, the government authorities said Tuesday.

title: Officials Seek Solace in Business of the State
description: TRENTON, April 17  It seemed a natural and human inclination to Darrell Bethea, the owner of Sweet Heaven, the snack shop and newsstand in the basement of the State House, to consider getting a get-well card for Gov. Jon S. Corzine.

title: Demonstration in Basra Signals Growing Tensions Between Iraqi Shiites
description: BAGHDAD, April 17  In the latest sign of worsening tensions among Shiite factions, several hundred people demonstrated Tuesday to force the governor of Basra to step down, a move that could throw that already unsettled southern city into turmoil.

title: Iraqs Public Health Services Severely Strained, Group Says
description: ROME, April 17  It goes without saying that war is bad for your health. But a compendium of new public health statistics, released Tuesday by the World Health Organization, quantifies just how desperate the situation has become for Iraqis.

title: AIDS Drugs Reach More People, U.N. Report Says, but Not Enough
description: About two million people in the world are receiving drugs for AIDS, an increase of 700,000 in the last year, the United Nations said in a report issued yesterday.

title: Manhattan: Trade Center Foundation Nearing Goal
description: The World Trade Center Memorial Foundation has raised more than $300 million toward its $350 million goal, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday, with more than $165 million raised since he took over as chairman of the foundation roughly six months ago. The money, which includes gifts from across the country and overseas, is to pay capital and planning costs as well as an endowment to operate the memorial and museum. Officials announced yesterday that the foundation board had selected Thinc Design as the lead exhibition design firm.

title: Billy Wagner Starring as Mr. Efficient
description: Even if Billy Wagner will be remembered for being a small guy with a huge fastball, he is doing his best to change his legacy. In Wagners five appearances, he has struck out two batters (Ryan Howard and Pat Burrell) and that was in the same game, April 9 against the Phillies. The strikeouts are not the only numbers that are down; so are his walks (none) and earned run average (0.00), and Wagner said that was hardly a coincidence.

title: Lauren Ashley McCain
description: Lauren Ashley McCain was a victim in Mondays shooting at Virginia Tech. Please share your memories and thoughts here.

title: Matthew Gwaltney
description: Matthew Gwaltney was a victim in Mondays shooting at Virginia Tech. Please share your memories and thoughts here.

title: Bars and Whistles
description: Weekend visitors to Dublin can indulge in the offerings of an ancient city with a cosmopolitan face-lift.

title: Cheap Eats in London
description: At these restaurants, it is possible to eat well in London without spending a week's salary.

title: Bombings Target Shiites in Iraq
description: It was the deadliest day in Baghdad since the U.S.-led security plan for the city took effect two months ago.

title: Do as I Say, Not as I Do
description: In the most recent issue of Newsweek, the California Governor Arnold Schwarznegger talks about the fact that he now owns both biodiesel and hydrogen-powered Hummers, in order to limit CO2 emissions of these normally gas guzzling monsters. He recently appeared on a show where a 65 Chevy Impalas 800-horsepower engine was overhauled to run on biofuel. That was the point of the show, he told Newsweek, To show people that biofeul is not like some wimpy feminine car like a hybrid.

title: Coping
description: Students are mourning their friends and teachers who were killed, and many of them have left the Virginia Tech campus to stay elsewhere.

title: Heading for the Finish, With an Eye on the Sun
description: Heather Gollnick, Ironman winner, test sunscreens.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Ideas from the show house to take home.

title: Currents
description: Visions of nature wrought in meta find a habitat in Chelsea, well-seasoned works to place among the blooms and more.

title: A Killer's Rant
description: Seung-Hui Cho, the gunman responsible for the shootings at Virginia Tech, mailed photographs, video and writings to NBC News.

title: Clear Channel Bidders Up the Ante Ahead of Vote
description: Facing mounting opposition, two private equity firms raised their offer for Clear Channel Communications by more than $1.5 billion Tuesday, to about $27.6 billion, The New York Times reported. The sweetened bid from Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners came 24 hours ahead of a crucial vote by shareholders, who were expected to reject the offer.

title: Bankruptcy Pay in Focus on Capitol Hill
description: A top lawmaker said Tuesday that the House Judiciary Committee is working on legislation to rein in compensation and bonuses paid to executives of bankrupt companies. Rules for bonuses to such executives were revamped in 2005, but many companies have found ways around the restrictions in the revised bankruptcy code, lawyers say.

title: Blacks Co-Defendant Sought 2nd Opinion on Payments
description: A co-defendant of the former media mogul Conrad M. Black was so determined to follow securities law that he spent a lot of money to seek a second opinion on whether certain payments at the heart of the trial had to be publicly disclosed, a defense lawyer said on Tuesday.

title: ABN Amro and Barclays Extend Talks
description: In an effort to keep a rival consortium at bay, ABN Amro and Barclays have extended the period of their exclusive takeover discussions until the end of Friday. The banks said Tuesday that they were continuing their exclusive talks, which were initially scheduled to end Wednesday after 30 days, and were working on a combination agreement. They added that there was still no certainty that the discussions would lead to a transaction.

title: Citigroup Listens and Listens to Holders
description: Companies are increasingly being urged to listen more closely to shareholders. There could be such a thing as too much. In sharp contrast to the Home Depot annual meeting last May that investors decried as unresponsive, Citigroups session yesterday dragged on, writes The New York Times Eric Dash. And on. And on.

title: The Kips Bay Decorator Show House
description: On the Upper East Side, a shiny disco ball of a show house.

title: NeurogesX Shoots for $60 Million I.P.O.
description: The biopharmaceutical firm NeurogesX is seeking to raise $60 million in its initial public offering on the Nasdaq. The company said Tuesday it expects to sell 4 million shares priced at $13 to $15 a share. Morgan Stanley, Pacific Growth Equities, Lazard Capital Markets and Susquehanna Financial Group are underwriting the I.P.O.

title: Universal Music May Be Closer to Winning EU Approval for BMG Deal
description: Vivendis Universal Music Group is closer to winning European Union approval to buy BMG Music Publishing from Bertelsmann after EU antitrust officials backed the deal, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Advanced Semiconductors Shares Rise After Carlye Drops Bid
description: The market cheered the withdrawal of the Carlyle Groups $5.5 billion bid for the worlds largest computer-chip tester, Advanced Semiconductor Engineering. The announcement late Tuesday night that the buyout shop had abandoned its bid sent Advanced Semiconductors shares up 7 percent.

title: Prodi Calls for Italian Bid for Telecom Italia
description: The Italian government, fresh from having dissuaded AT&T from investing about 2 billion euros to buy a 6 percent stake in Telecom Italia, made a call on Tuesday for Italian companies to band together to buy the troubled telecommunications company from the controlling shareholder, Pirelli.

title: Will Yahoos Semel Be Shown the Door?
description: Are Terry Semels days numbered? As Yahoo delivered a disappointing set of first quarter results and the good news that investors expected from companys Panama project  the nickname for the firms major overhaul of its search advertising system  was not yet a reality, some industry watchers speculated that it may be curtains for the chief executive.

title: Sallie Mae Buyout Strikes at Heart of Hedge Fund
description: As DealBook noted earlier this week, news that Sallie Mae has accepted a $25 billion buyout spelled trouble for student-loan business First Marblehead. It also may cause some serious problems for a hedge fund, Second Curve Capital.

title: Another Carlyle Founder Chats Up an I.P.O.
description: Adding more fuel to the fire of speculation that the Carlyle Group may take itself public in the near future, the private equity firms co-founder, Daniel DAniello, said Tuesday that the buyout shop has been considering an initial public offering for some time.

title: Mandriva Gets Funds to Exit Bankruptcy and Seal a Deal
description: Mandriva, a struggling French seller of the Linux operating system, is in the process of raising a minimum of 3 million euros, or $4.1 million, the company said Monday. The funds will be used to exit bankruptcy protection and to complete the acquisition of a server software company, Linbox.

title: J.P. Morgan Reports Record Profit in First Quarter
description: J.P. Morgan Chase said its profit jumped 55 percent from a year ago to $4.8 billion in the first quarter, a record for the firm. It also raised its stock dividend by 12 percent, marking the firms first dividend increase in six years.

title: BCE Deal Talks May Lead to Canadas Largest Buyout
description: The announcement Tuesday that BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, was in buyout discussions with three Canadian pension funds and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is the latest move in what could be the biggest takeover battle in Canadian history.

title: Steel Dynamics Hedges on Ipsco Bid
description: The steel manufacturer Steel Dynamics might have an interest in acquiring the Canadian steel pipe maker Ipsco. At least its chief executive, Keith Busse, did not rule it out when he had the opportunity on Tuesday.

title: Orica Rejects $3 Billion Buyout Offer
description: Orica, a diversified manufacturer, rejected a takeover bid worth 9.95 billion Australian dollars ($8.3 billion) from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and the Blackstone Group as too low. The buyout firms offered 32 Australian dollars a share, 15 percent more than Oricas closing price Tuesday. Shares in the company, which is based in Melbourne, surged to a record on speculation the bidders might raise their price.

title: Lehman Appoints First Asia-Based Vice Chairman
description: Lehman Brothers said it had appointed Kunho Cho as the firms first Asia-based vice chairman. Mr. Cho, who has been with Lehman Brothers since 1989, previously led the companys investment-banking division in the Asia-Pacific region and has been involved in major financing transactions in South Korea, China and Japan.

title: Gambro Unit May Be Up for Sale
description: Swedens billionaire Wallenberg family is leading a group that may sell Gambro Healthcare, an owner of dialysis clinics in 15 countries, Bloomberg News reported. Bloomberg said the Gambro unit, which has 160 clinics that treat about 13,000 patients, might be worth $800 million. Goldman Sachs has reportedly been hired to review potential offers.

title: Ellington Is Buyer of Fremont Loans, Report Says
description: A well-known Greenwich hedge fund is getting into the subprime mortgage business in a big way. The New York Post reports that Ellington Capital Management is in the process of finalizing an agreement with Fremont General to buy $2.9 billion worth of loans and the distressed lenders real estate business, including its mortgage bond investments and loan origination platform.

title: The Professor Who Said Not in My Class
description: Nikki Giovanni is a noted poet, a popular professor at Virginia Tech and one of Oprahs 25 living legends. She also may be the first at the university to express serious concerns about Cho Seung-Hui.

title: Blackstone Sells Extended Stay Hotels for $8 Billion
description: Offering further proof that a real estate slowdown has not hampered property deal making, the Lightstone Group agreed on Tuesday to purchase Extended Stay Hotels from the Blackstone Group for $8 billion. The deal establishes Lightstone as the dominant company in a fast-growing market for travelers seeking long-term accommodations.

title: Farallon to Buy Affordable Residential Unit
description: A hedge fund manager Farallon Capital Management said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the manufactured-home unit of Affordable Residential Communities for $1.8 billion. Farallon already owns 10 pecent of Affordable Residential, which owns and operates about 57,264 home sites in 275 communities in 23 states. Analysts said the deal could help Farallon benefit from the downturn in the subprime lending market.

title: As Vonage Faces Potential Bankruptcy, Deal Rumors Heat Up
description: As Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone service provider, was admitting that its legal woes could lead to bankruptcy, industry watchers were debating the merits of a takeover of the company by Sprint-Nextel.

title: Mom, Dad and Not Much Else
Voices from the Vigil
description: The scene on campus when, one day after the shooting, Virginia Tech students gathered for a candlelight vigil.

title: James Flanigan's Biography
description: James Flanigan, business columnist for The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times and other publications, has covered national and international business and economics for 44 years. He is the author of Smile Southern California, You're the Center of the Universe: The Los Angeles Region and the Transformation of the World Economy, due in 2008.

title: Brent Bowers's Biography
description: Brent Bowers, a longtime small-business editor at The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal, is author of The Eight Patterns of Highly Effective Entrepreneurs, due out in paperback next week (Doubleday).

title: Marci Alboher's Biography
description: Marci Alboher, a former lawyer, is a journalist/author/writing coach. She is the author of One Person/Multiple Careers: A New Model for Work/Life Success (Warner Business: 2007).

title: Updates on Virginia Tech
description: Coverage of Mr. Chos Manifesto Continues Here

title: On Polling: Young People and the Iraq War
Paul B. Brown's Biography
description: Paul B. Brown writes the What's Offline column that runs every Saturday in New York Times and is the co-author of Dream Home Diaries that appears elsewhere on this web site. A former writer and editor of Business Week, Financial World, Forbes, and Inc., Brown is the author or co-author of more than a dozen books, including Sweat Equity: What it really takes to best small companies in America (with Geoffrey N. Smith) and The Map of Innovation (with Kevin O'Connor.) Paul also conceived and wrote Creating a Winner: The real secrets of successful marketing which was the winner of the American Film Institute's award for best business program.

title: Some Korean Americans Feel a Wound
description: An American massacre, not a Korean one: Virginia Tech shooter Seung-hui Cho came to the U.S. when he was 8 years old and, at the time of his death, was 23 and an English major at Virginia Tech, writes Edward Taehan Chang, a professor of ethnic studies at the Universit of California-Riverside, on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. In other words, he probably spoke fluent English and was culturally Americanized. He also writes:

title: 2008: Controlled Gun Debate
description: Dana Milbank of The Washington Post captures the tone here in the capital in response to the Virginia Tech shootings: The nations leaders wanted to act, but they had no obvious course of action. The White House canceled events; Congress canceled some hearings, including the testimony of Alberto Gonzales, the embattled attorney general. Some Democrats called for new gun restrictions, but responses were tepid from the party leadership and dismissive from newer, more moderate members.

title: Lingering by Gowanus, but Not Stuck
description: Even a whale seems to know enough not to stray into the Gowanus Canal, although this one came close, frolicking near its mouth.

title: BlackBerry Outage Frays Wall Street Lifeline
description: Research In Motions BlackBerry service is an indispensable tool for many Wall Street workers, but it came up short this morning when many customers in North America were cut off from their e-mail. It was not immediately clear how many people were affected by the problems, which began late Tuesday, when certain users found themselves unable to receive messages on the devices.

title: Contract . . . Negotiations?
description: In my day job, running a small company, I have to deal with contracts fairly often. Our clients ask us to sign confidentiality agreements; there are frequently complex retainer agreements; and were always managing equipment leases, vendor agreements and the other legal minutiae that come with being in business. (For example, when we moved into our offices six years ago, we signed a 10-year, multimillion-dollar lease.)

title: Totally Thai
description: Banyan

title: The City as Stage
description: Accomplice: New York audiences meet characters at several Manhattan locales.

title: Labor Sets Candidate Forum Dates
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is announcing today that it will sponsor individual candidate forums for its members, beginning with one featuring Senator Chris Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, in Sacramento (corrected, its not San Francisco) on April 29.

title: Searching for a Scapegoat
description: Give the Virginia Tech administration a break: The overwhelming majority of murders that take place on campus (or anywhere else) are not a prelude to a mass killing, writes The Economists Megan McArdle, who is guest-blogging at Andrew Sullivans Daily Dish at The Atlantic Online. Should we really act as if they were, because it might prevent the 0.001 percent that are? She continues:

title: Dial C for Citigroup, and for the Chief
description: Have a beef about Citigroups stock price? Or did you find a strange charge on your bank account? Either way, you can take your idea straight to the top. Charles O. Prince III, Citis chief executive, took investor relations to a bizarre extreme Tuesday when he gave out his e-mail address (princec@citigroup.com) and phone number (212-793-8854) at the banks annual shareholder meeting. As The New York Timess Eric Dash reported, Citis meeting ended up being a marathon session where myriad grievances were aired, including gripes about bank customer service or policies.

title: With No Rival Offers, TXU Agrees to Buyout
description: Texas power company TXU said on Wednesday it would proceed with its planned buyout by private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group after failing to attract a superior offer. TXU, which agreed in February to be bought for $45 billion by the private equity firms and other investors, said that during a 50-day go-shop period, in which it had the right to solicit other bids, it received no offer that could reasonably be expected to result in a superior proposal.

title: Its a Joke. Seriously.
description: Detroit is tied up in knots fretting about the future of the Chrysler Group, which has been put up for sale by its parent, DaimlerChrysler. Not to worry, says Toyotas top executive in North America, James E. Press.

title: Dread Pirate Kerkorian
description: I was scanning the Detroit papers recently and catching up on my Chrysler buyout news when all of a sudden it struck me: Kirk Kerkorian is pushing 90.

title: Should Time Warner Dial Back on Cable?
description: After The Wall Street Journal reported that Time Warner is considering selling off part of its cable holdings to invest more in the Internet, CNNMoney.coms Paul R. La Monica suggested that Carl Icahn, the billionaire financier who tried to break up the company, may deserve some credit if the company chooses this route. An analyst at Prudential Equity Group said she found Tuesdays report from the Journal hard to believe, however.

title: A Warning on Derivatives
description: As credit derivatives multiply, it is getting harder and harder to know who has taken on risks. And if you dont know that, it is impossible to know whether they could manage the risks in times of market stress or panic. Who has taken on the ultimate risk of defaults of subprime mortgages?

title: Mourning The Dead
The Morning After
description: At public gatherings and in quiet spots around campus, Virginia Tech students created memorials and consoled one another.

title: A Deal With Google Ends With Some Bruised Feelings
description: All the entrepreneurs out there dreaming about being acquired by Google should take note: The two founders of Dodgeball, a mobile social-networking service Google bought in 2005, have quit, saying the company wasnt supporting Dodgeball the way we expected.

title: 2008 Candidates on the Abortion Ruling
description: Several of the candidates have already put out statements regarding todays 5-4 Supreme Court decision upholding a nationwide ban on what opponents of the procedure call partial-birth abortion. Notice the differences between comments by Senator John McCain, a Republican who has said he opposes abortion except in cases of rape or incest, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican who has said he is personally anti-abortion but believes women should have the right to receive one. Mitt Romney, a Republican who has sought to persuade social conservatives that his abortion stance is genuine, also released a statement, as did some Democrats.

title: Credit-Default Swaps Go Mainstream
description: We never thought we would see the day when the Internet was buzzing about credit default swaps. But the parade of huge leveraged buyouts  often accompanied by some, ahem, uncanny predeal trading activity  has brought new attention to these once-exotic financial instruments, which serve as a kind of insurance for the holder of a bond or other kind of debt.

title: Commission: Felder Doesnt Speak for Us
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct, stepping up its cold war with its chairman Raoul Felder, said today that Mr. Felder no longer speaks for the commission. He also will no longer sign commission orders or official letters of caution or dismissal sent to judges, according to resolutions passed by the commission at a meeting yesterday.

title: Hometown Connection
description: Money, memories and a town fair link Mexican New Yorkers to the home they  left behind.

title: The N.R.A. and an Anti-Semitic Symbol
description: After Diane Cardwell of The Times wrote about a National Rifle Association magazines broadside aimed at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his gun proposals, a reader raised an issue about the image on the cover (at right), showing the Jewish mayor as an octopus.

title: Do-Over
description: Yesterday, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced the date of a special election to fill the seat of Manhattan Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, who the governor appointed to be commissioner of the Department of Environental Conservation.

title: Clear Channel Accepts Higher Bid
description: Sometimes more turns out to be less. Just as soon as Clear Channel Communications announced Wednesday that its private equity suitors had raised their offer to $39 per share from $37.60 per share  confirming a report in that mornings New York Times  the companys stock started to fall. The shares were down more than 1 percent at $36.28 in the hour before the close of trading.

title: Philadelphia Freedom
description: A dozen or so slices of cheese. Condiments for said cheese. One or two small slices of bread. Two glasses of a Spanish white.

title: Picture Perfect Leader
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans April 18 column, Help Wanted.

title: Q-Poll: Corzine Job Approval Unaffected
description: Governor Corzines job approval was apparently unaffected by his automobile accident last Thursday. Overall, 51 percent of the New Jersey voters surveyed by Quinnipiac University approve how Mr. Corzine is handling his job, and 36 percent disapprove.The voters interviewed Tuesday through Thursday had essentially the same view of Mr. Corzines performance in office as did those interviewed Friday through Sunday.

title: Bloomberg on Seatbelts and Fast Driving
description: The nanny tendencies of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, which he spoofed this past weekend in a send-up of Mary Poppins, were on full display this afternoon in Jersey City.

title: Take Away Mannys Glove?
description: Readers are provided with another reminder of the quirks of Red Sox outfielder Manny Ramirez in a profile in this weeks New Yorker.

title: Minal Panchal
description: Minal Panchal was a victim in Mondays shooting at Virginia Tech. Please share your memories and thoughts on Minal Panchal here.

title: Partahi Lumbantoruan
description: Partahi Lumbantoruan was a victim in Mondays shooting at Virginia Tech. Please share your memories and thoughts on Partahi Lumbantoruan here.

title: That Merrie Olde Operating System
description: This goodie from Norway in 2001 bears watching or rewatching in its English-subtitled YouTube splendor:

title: Blogtalk
description: The Supreme Courts abortion ruling: What will Spitzer do? [The Daily Politics]

title: The Taxman Cometh
description: A spokeswoman for Lieutenant Governor David A. Paterson made the rounds today, giving reporters an opportunity to review the tax returns Mr. Paterson filed jointly with his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson. We didnt have time to check out the city and state returns, but we took a gander at the federal ones.

title: Update: Whale Dies in Gowanus Bay
description: The juvenile minke whale that spent Wednesday and today cruising around Gowanus Bay and frolicking around the mouth of the infamous canal (never venturing in) died in the water shortly after 5 p.m., according to Anthony Ramirez and Ann Farmer, who have been following the story.

title: Where to Sing in Paris
description: I am a musician who would like to visit Paris and sing. Any suggestions?

title: Quinn on the Abortion Decision
description: Christine Quinn, the City Council speaker, was one of the many politicians who issued a statement today about the Supreme Court decision upholding the 2003 Partial-Birth Abortion Act. She called it a dark day for womens health. Her full statement is below:

title: Accusations Amid a Con-Ed Vote
description: A member of the New Yorks Public Service Commission  basically, the body that regulates utilities  says an aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer threatened to have her removed if she didnt back off efforts to investigate Consolidated Edison over last years Queens blackout.

title: Secret Hold Placed on Senate Disclosures
description: Remember secret holds? A privilege of any given senator who wants to stall legislation for whatever reason. Democrats do it. Republicans do it.

title: A Letter to My Mother
description: Dear Mom,

title: BlogTalk: The Supreme Court and Abortion
description: Blogs are in overdrive about the Supreme Courts 5-4 decision today to uphold a nationwide ban on a procedure known by opponents as partial birth abortion.

title: Strengthening Indonesia's Democracy
description: A look at U.S. efforts to foster democracy in Indonesia. A Times documentary on Islam and Indonesia debuts April 19 on PBS.

title: Scandal at Screens!
description: Even in the easy, low-output blogging life we live here at Screens  hammock, corncob pipe, video iPod  there emerges now and then a special kind of blogging  emergency. You try to ignore it, and then you cant.

title: Share the Air: A Capital Idea
description: Our friends at the Prague Stock Exchange would agree that common ownership of property has been proven to limit innovation. So should our airwaves be publicly owned or privately controlled? Bet I surprise you with my view!

title: The Morality Line
description: Over the next few days, well ponder the sources of Cho Seung-Huis rage. Therell be no shortage of analysts picking apart his hatreds, his feelings of oppression and his dark war against the rich, Christianity and the world at large.

title: The Killer in the Lecture Hall
description: Rochester, Mich.

title: Chrysler Plans to Build Engine and Axle Plants in Southern Michigan
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., April 18  The Chrysler Group said on Wednesday that it would spend $1.43 billion to build two plants in southern Michigan that would make parts for Chrysler and Mercedes vehicles, even as the American and German companies prepare for a possible divorce.

title: Upstart Teams Serve Notice to Traditional Lacrosse Powers
description: Perhaps no game better illustrates the bizarre nature of this college lacrosse season than tomorrows matchup between Albany and Syracuse.

title: Package Forced NBC to Make Tough Decisions
description: The package that arrived yesterday at NBC headquarters in New York was almost immediately flagged as suspicious, because it had been mailed from Blacksburg, Va., and bore the return name A. Ishmael.

title: Amid Chaos, One Notably Restrained Voice
description: Brian Williams of NBC Nightly News told PBSs Charlie Rose on Tuesday that the shootings at Virginia Tech proved that viewers still wanted traditional network anchors.

title: So Lucky to Be Loving
description: With a fierce beating of wings, the butterfly has finally escaped her chrysalis and taken flight. That bursting into the light describes the metamorphosis of the cabaret singer Karen Akers from the demure, statuesque ice goddess of more than a decade ago into the warm, funny, vulnerable entertainer she has become in her extraordinary new show, Simply Styne, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: N.J. Transit Approves Fare Increases for Its Riders
description: New Jersey Transit approved a 9.6 percent average fare increase on its buses, trains and light rail yesterday to help close a $60 million budget gap for next fiscal year.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.What is the most versatile piece of furniture I can buy?

title: Canada: Lockout Lifted Against Striking Rail Workers
description: The Canadian National Railway lifted a lockout against striking workers in five cities after a special labor law, passed Tuesday by the House of Commons through a special accelerated process, was approved by the Senate and swiftly signed into law by Governor-General Michalle Jean, the formal head of state. An arbitrator will now impose a settlement. The United Transportation Union began rotating strikes against Canadian National last week after its workers overwhelmingly rejected a tentative contract. That proposed contract had ended a 15-day general strike in February that had caused industrial disruption in Canada and shipping delays to the United States. The dispute focuses on work rules, particularly those concerning older employees.

title: Rolling, Rocking Nights Out for Mom
description: TWO years ago, Jenny Mohammed, a 34-year-old full-time mother from the Bronx, was flipping through television channels while nursing her 6-month-old son, Kai, and landed on a reality show about roller derby. She was so enthralled by the hard-charging women dressed like pinups that she Googled pictures of roller derby girls and put up a shot of one in electric-blue eye shadow on her refrigerator.

title: Denying the Right to Choose
description: Among the major flaws in yesterdays Supreme Court decision giving the federal government power to limit a womans right to make decisions about her health was its fundamental dishonesty.

title: The Little Botox Shop Around the Corner
description: ON a busy section of East 59th Street in Manhattan, a half block from Bloomingdales, two plastic surgeons are preparing to open a new kind of cosmetic medical entity: a Botox-only storefront office. No appointment necessary.

title: Manhattan: Drinking Survey
description: About one in four men in New York City reported binge drinking in a survey that was released yesterday by the city health department. The survey, which gathered information from 10,000 New Yorkers by telephone, was based on 2005 data, the most recent that was available, city officials said. They said the rate of binge drinking  defined as having five or more drinks on one occasion in the past month  was unchanged since 2002. Over all, 14 percent of adult city residents reported binge drinking, lower than the national rate of 24 percent of adults, city officials said. The survey showed that men reported binge drinking three times more frequently than women.

title: A New Band Gives a Pianist a Fresh Context
description: Gonzalo Rubalcaba, a pianist of almost supernatural abilities, has a new band and new songs. On Tuesday night at the Jazz Standard the music was both imposing and not quite cooked. Probably the quintets run at the club this week will make it breathe and cohere before it is recorded in the studio next month. But the music is worth hearing at the very least because you can sense Mr. Rubalcabas playing in a new context.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A film series entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday, about the three-part Chinese documentary West of Tracks at Anthology Film Archives, misstated the opening dates for the first two parts, Rust and Remnants. Rust opened yesterday and Remnants opens today; they did not open last Friday and Saturday. (As the article noted, part three, Rails, opens tomorrow.)

title: EBay Profit Climbs 52 Percent
description: EBay posted better-than-expected profit in the first quarter as several of its newer businesses compensated for disappointing results in its mainstay auction service.

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 9 P.M. (22, 26) FAITH WITHOUT FEAR This America at a Crossroads documentary follows the journey of the Muslim dissident Irshad Manji, left, as she travels through Yemen, Europe and North America on what she sees as a quest to restore humanity and reason to Islam. How, she asks, has a religion of justice become mired in fear? At 10 Struggle for the Soul of Islam: Inside Indonesia explores the countrys long history of moderation in its practice of Islam, and how its Muslim majority is struggling to control the rise of Islamic extremism, which has made Indonesia a flash point in global terror.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Critics Choice column on Monday about new CDs misstated the nationality of Dr. Luke, who produced some of the songs on the Avril Lavigne album The Best Damn Thing. He is American, not Swedish.

title: Thailand: Post-Coup Constitution Ready
description: Thailand unveiled a draft constitution that eliminates direct elections for the Senate while bolstering the power of the unelected judiciary. The document, posted on Parliaments Web site, was drafted by a 35-member committee selected by the junta and will be presented at public forums beginning next week, and then to a national referendum in September. While the 1997 Constitution rescinded by the coup leaders sought to consolidate Thai politics and avoid the fractured coalitions of the 1990s, its proposed replacement seeks to decentralize power by buttressing the power of judges and bureaucrats.

title: Long-Silent Ranger Faithful Lift Up Their Voices
description: For a decade, those April voices had lost their decibels. Wild roars for the Rangers from the slopes of Madison Square Garden simply didnt exist.

title: No Solution in Sight as Bush and Lawmakers Discuss Iraq Spending Measure
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  After weeks of acrimonious sparring over financing the next phase of the war, President Bush and Congressional leaders softened their tone on Wednesday but failed to resolve their differences over a timeline for removing most American combat troops from Iraq next year.

title: Former Knicks Standout Sees Team Turning Page
description: In his new book, The New American Story, Bill Bradley presents his detailed solutions for improving the United States. Regarding his former team, the Knicks, he already sees progress toward a better future.

title: Manhattan: Bicyclists Lose in Court
description: A federal judge has denied a motion by bicycling groups seeking a preliminary injunction barring the city from enforcing regulations on large-scale bicycle rides, city officials said yesterday. The bicyclists, who have sued to overturn city rules that say groups of 50 or more riders must obtain parade permits, claim that the regulations violate their right to free assembly; city officials have argued that the police have the right to enforce regulations to maintain public order and safety. In a decision on Tuesday, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court said he was not convinced that an order barring enforcement was justified before a trial on the lawsuit.

title: A Government of Laws and Seat Belts
description: Our hopes are with Gov. Jon Corzine of New Jersey as he continues the long process of recovery from last weeks horrifying traffic accident. But we are also concerned by the news that at the time of the crash, Mr. Corzines sport utility vehicle was traveling at 91 miles per hour  26 m.p.h. above the parkways speed limit  and that the governor, contrary to New Jersey law, was apparently not wearing a seat belt.

title: Name of High-Pressure Washers Maker Is Drawn Into French Politics
description: PARIS, April 19  Here is one company that is tired of free publicity.

title: Old School Souffl of Charm and Power
description: Anyone fortunate enough to have observed Kitty Carlisle Hart in her mid-90s singing the great American songbook at Feinsteins at the Regency or dropping pearls of show business lore at this or that tribute or benefit, was a witness to one of the most amazing final acts in New York City cultural history.

title: Corrections: Hes Not My Grandpa. Hes My Dad
description: An article last week about men who become fathers late in life referred incorrectly to their children who have different mothers. The children of those men would be half-siblings, not step-siblings.

title: Where the Redwoods Grow, the Oddballs Also Flourish
description: The bride wore lichen. She and the groom hung from a rope suspended between two tree spires. The wedding rings were cast from redwood sprigs, and the minister was also a geologist willing to stand on a branch in midair. The day before the ceremony, as the betrothed pair climbed the trees and prepared the rigging, the bride made a mistake while attaching her descender device. Had she not caught this error, she would have given new meaning to the idea of marriage as a giant leap.

title: Alvin Roth, Bridge Champion, Dies at 92
description: Alvin L. Roth, who was one of the most talented bridge players of all time, winning 26 national championships with 11 different partners, died yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 92.

title: Rangers Sweep Sends Atlanta South
description: As the delay dragged on in the third period last night and the Madison Square Garden crowd chanted nervously, Goal, goal, goal, Rangers center Matt Cullen tried not to let his mind sneak ahead. The longer the replay officials looked at his shot that hit the crossbar and dropped to the goal line, the better Cullen felt. He knew the game and the Rangers first playoff series victory in 10 years were hanging on it.

title: Chauncey Starr, 95, Pioneer in Nuclear Energy, Dies
description: Chauncey Starr, a pioneer in the fields of nuclear energy and risk analysis and an evangelist for the idea of electrification as a boon to humankind and the environment, died on Tuesday at his home in Atherton, Calif. He was 95.

title: Senate Bars Medicare Talks for Lower Drug Prices
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  A pillar of the Democrats program tumbled on Wednesday when the Senate blocked a proposal to let Medicare negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans, a practice now forbidden by law.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about Pulitzer Prizes awarded this year to books published by Alfred A. Knopf misstated the title of a Knopf winner from last year. It was American Prometheus: The Triumph and Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer  not Robert J. Oppenheimer.

title: The Man With the Most Caps, Somehow Seeing All the Cards
description: The diagramed deal, which was originally reported in The Guardian, the British newspaper, arose during the Camrose match between England and the Republic of Ireland in January. The Camrose is contested annually by England, Northern Ireland, the Republic of Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

title: Leadership on Warming (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on April 4 about Arnold Blume, an 81-year-old substitute teacher on Long Island who shares his firsthand knowledge of historical events in class, included an erroneous reference from Mr. Blume to the day in 1945 when he and fellow members of the Army Air Corps assembled for a memorial service for President Franklin D. Roosevelt. The men were in their green dress uniform, not dress blues. (A spokesman for the Air Force, which succeeded the Air Corps, said the dress blues uniform was not introduced to the Air Force until 1949.)

title: Gomez Shares Spotlight in Win
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 18  Scott Gomez had been eclipsed in these playoffs by a younger, hungrier teammate, Zach Parise, but with one shot Wednesday night, Gomez reversed his and the Devils course.

title: Steelworkers and British Unions Seek Merger
description: The United Steelworkers announced yesterday that it would seek to merge with two large British unions, Amicus and the Transport and General Workers Union, in a move that would form the first trans-Atlantic labor group.

title: No More Delay on Darfur
description: Sudans president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, attaches as little value to the promises he makes to the international community as he does to the lives of the many thousands of people who are being murdered in Darfur. A newly disclosed United Nations report highlights his brazen duplicity, describing how the Sudanese government painted false U.N. insignia on an air force plane being used to deliver bombs to Darfur.

title: In Nod to Consumer Tastes, Nissan to Sell Cleaner Cars
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Nissan Motor will offer its flagship Maxima sedan with a cleaner-burning diesel engine in the United States by 2010, the companys chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, said on Wednesday, offering new details of a plan intended to resonate with environmentally conscious consumers and help Nissan meet new emissions rules.

title: Newly Released
description: In this group of new releases the question of the moment seems to be: What if? What if cavemen started showing up in the backyards of a surburban subdivision? (Twin Study by Stacey Richter.) Or if a billionaire sheik decided to introduce salmon to a Yemeni river? (Paul Tordays Salmon Fishing in the Yemen.) Answers to those questions, and others, can be found in these recently published books.

title: Atomic Agency Confirms Advances by Irans Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Iran has now begun enriching small amounts of uranium in more than 1,300 centrifuges at a newly opened underground site at its main nuclear complex, the International Atomic Energy Agencys top inspector said Wednesday.

title: Help for Subprime Mortgage Holders
description: Freddie Mac, the mortgage giant, said yesterday that it would buy as much as $20 billion in subprime mortgages, while a lender, Washington Mutual, offered to refinance $2 billion in loans as the mortgage finance industry made its biggest gesture yet to help borrowers with poor credit histories avoid losing their homes.

title: Present at the Creation, and End, of Nouvelle Society
description: AT a certain point in the evolution of any social group, the dcor changes. Death claims the fixtures of one period, and they are naturally replaced. This is not necessarily cause for general lamentation, and yet there is reason to think that the death on Sunday of Pat Buckley, the fund-raiser, socialite and wife of the conservative writer William F. Buckley Jr., at 80, marked not just the end of one privileged womans journey, but perhaps also of a particularly lively and irreplaceable era in New York.

title: Matrimony Has Its Benefits, and Divorce Has a Lot to Do With That
description: Divorce seems an unusual topic for economists, but decisions to end a marriage weigh costs and benefits and thus reflect economic reasoning. Justin Wolfers and Betsey Stevenson, both assistant professors of economics at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, have led the creation of new studies, which are surveyed in their working paper Marriage and Divorce: Changes and Their Driving Forces.

title: Corrections: Colleges Need a Reply. May I See Your Notes?
description: A front-page Inside summary last week about the Online Shopper column misspelled the authors surname. She is Michelle Slatalla, not Slatella.

title: Teacher Sentenced to Up to 14 Years for Having Sex With Student
description: Lilies that fester smell far worse than weeds, a judge in Manhattan said today, quoting Shakespeare, before sentencing a private school principal to up to 14 years in prison for having a sexual relationship with a student.

title: A Houston Fuss Over Breast-Feeding Strikes a Responsive Nerve
description: HOUSTON, April 18  It is an argument that nobody relishes. Not Jessica Mayo-Swimeley, who says that all she wanted to do was breast-feed her 17-month-old twin son Tobin after his surgery for a brain tumor.

title: Wrights  Hitting Streak Has a Power Shortage
description: MIAMI, April 18  David Wright will not quibble with his batting average, which is .327 after last nights 9-2 victory over the Florida Marlins. In fact, Wright says its not important to me whatsoever. He also has the teams record with a 25-game hitting streak after going 2 for 5 with a run batted in Wednesday night. To Wright, there are much better indicators of success, and he is not feeling too successful these days.

title: Loyalty First?
description: 1. Your determination to fire prosecutors who were not loyal Bushies has its intellectual roots in the theory of the unitary executive, which holds that the president should be able to extend his political control over all executive branch officers, including not only political appointees but also lower-level career officials. Are you familiar with the leading scholarly defenses of this theory, and do you agree with them?

title: Gates Reassures Israel About Arms Sales in Gulf
description: TEL AVIV, April 19  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today that he had reassured Israel about a planned major American arms sale to Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries, saying that the sale would not threaten Israels military superiority and that it is necessary to counter the threat from Iran.

title: But What if You Get Hit by a Taxi?
description: WHEN Steven Lien, a onetime ski-shop proprietor and information technology specialist in Portland, Ore., dreamed up a small-business venture last year, his friends and family were not even polite about what they thought of his prospects.

title: Must Tulips Wither as the Climate Changes?
description: ITS finally spring. Or is it? With so many false springs this year, snow may yet fall on the tulips. Or maybe a northeaster, as happened last weekend.

title: Democracy in Action, Thats Cunningham
description: Merce Cunningham turned 88 on Monday. In recent years he has routinely been described as the worlds greatest choreographer. This doesnt mean, though, that he is just the oldest choreographer who has been great in the past. The dances he has made this millennium suggest, amazingly, that no choreographer alive is more concerned with continuing to extend his range. (I have heard dancers who appeared in his work from the 1950s to the 90s speak with awe of the new complexities that have opened up in his recent work.) He is the only choreographer I can think of who has presented at least one true masterpiece  the world-conquering Biped (1999)  after his 80th birthday.

title: Four Women Are Convicted in Attack on Man in Village
description: Four young women from Newark were convicted of gang assault yesterday in the beating and stabbing of an independent filmmaker in Greenwich Village last summer, the jury rejecting their contention that they were defending themselves against an anti-lesbian attack.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: A Love of Green, Not of Grass

title: Corrections
description: Editors Note

title: Celebrating the Propulsive Power of Music
description: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company is 39 this year and holding. The companys program on Wednesday night at the Skirball Center at New York University affirmed at least one artistic belief that has guided Mr. Lubovitchs long and productive career in modern dance: the power of music to inform and propel a work.

title: Chinas Elite Talk of Democracy in One-Party State
description: BEIJING, April 14  Like the spring showers that give the parched landscape a veneer of green, Chinas authoritarian leaders, approaching the end of their five-year terms in office, have suggested that they would like to see their country become more democratic.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Stones Mild Horses Plan Troubles Animal Lovers

title: Motorola Reports a Loss and a Disappointing Forecast
description: Motorola, the wireless phone maker, reported a loss for the first quarter yesterday and issued a disappointing forecast for the second, leading some analysts to question whether it would be able to return to profitability this year.

title: Kitty Carlisle Hart, a New York Blend of Actress, Singer and Arts Advocate, Dies at 96
description: Kitty Carlisle Hart, a doyenne of New York culture and society and a perennial entertainer who appeared on Broadway and in films and was still singing on the stage as recently as last fall, well into her 10th decade, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.

title: Calendar
description: Street Tree Care

title: U.S. Expands Investigation of Grants in New Jersey
description: A federal investigation into the awarding of grants in New Jerseys state budget has expanded to the Town of West New York, apparently to include the former speaker of the State Assembly, who was also the town mayor.

title: Gates Urges Iraq to Hasten Push to Defuse Sectarianism
description: TEL AVIV, April 18  As a series of deadly bombings rocked Baghdad, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates called Wednesday for Iraqs government to make faster progress on Sunni-Shiite reconciliation but said the attacks would not derail the administrations Iraq strategy.

title: Bronx: Man Dies in Police Custody
description: A homeless man died in his jail cell while in police custody on Monday, the police said yesterday. The man, Dennis Cafila, 55, had been arrested on Saturday at the corner of Seneca Avenue and Faile Street for criminal possession of a controlled substance. He was found dead in his cell at the central booking facility in Morris Heights, and his death did not immediately appear suspicious, the police said. The medical examiner is expected to conduct an autopsy to determine the cause of death.

title: Chinas Economy Still Growing at a Torrid Pace
description: SHANGHAI, April 19  China said today that its economy continued to accelerate at a blistering pace, growing by an annualized rate of 11.1 percent in the first quarter of this year.

title: Congresss Role
description: 1. Can politics truly be kept out of the investigations into the recent dismissal of several United States attorneys if such oversight is being led by a senator who is himself responsible for the election of Democratic senatorial candidates in 2008?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a Supreme Court decision limiting state control of big banks misstated a word in a quotation from Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, who criticized the ruling, which upheld a regulation issued by the office of the comptroller of the currency. Mr. Frank, who heads the House Financial Services Committee, said, The controller has eliminated a whole bunch of state consumer laws with nothing to put in their place. He did not say the court had eliminated the laws.

title: Woman Testifies About Sexual Abuse by a Churchs Youth Ministry Leader
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 18  Justice R. Bruce Cozzens Jr. discreetly handed tissues to the witness on the stand Wednesday. She tried to stifle sobs and wiped away tears while she told of being sexually abused as a teenager by a Catholic youth ministry leader in the early 1990s.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury to Visit U.S.
description: The Most Rev. Rowan Williams, archbishop of Canterbury, left, has announced he will visit the United States in September to meet with bishops of the Episcopal Church, who last month declared an urgent need for such a meeting. The archbishop, spiritual leader of the worldwide Anglican Communion, has been struggling to keep the communion intact despite deep divisions over homosexuality, the authority of Scripture and the meaning of Anglicanism. A communion divided into a liberal segment and a conservative segment would be very, very much impoverished on both sides, he said at a news conference. The archbishop and other Anglican leaders will join the bishops Sept. 20 to 25 at a previously scheduled meeting in New Orleans.

title: Lets Put on a Show for China
description: IT was a smash hit. Boffo! in Hollywood English. Bang ji le in Mandarin Chinese. It was a television show watched by possibly 600 million people worldwide in February at the Lunar New Year in China, ushering in the Year of the Boar.

title: Voter Suppression and Rising Crime
description: 1. Several United States attorneys were terminated because of a supposed lack of aggressiveness in cases of voter fraud. But while studies suggest that voter fraud is relatively rare and isolated, there has been a recent escalation of voter suppression and illegal tactics to prevent voting, especially in minority communities. If some attorneys were terminated because they failed to combat voter fraud, why werent any terminated for failing to prosecute voter suppression?

title: Radio Giant Accepts Offer
description: Clear Channel Communications, the largest American radio company, agreed yesterday to a sweetened takeover bid of $19.4 billion from Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital Partners that may yet fail to win shareholder approval.

title: Opposition Candidates Threaten to Boycott Nigerian Election
description: ABUJA, Nigeria, April 18  Opposition candidates in Nigerias presidential election, now just three days away, have threatened a boycott unless the polling is delayed to ensure what they have called a level playing field for all.

title: Iran Exonerates Six Who Killed in Islams Name
description: TEHRAN, April 18  The Iranian Supreme Court has overturned the murder convictions of six members of a prestigious state militia who killed five people they considered morally corrupt.

title: Gonzales Faces Anger From Both Sides on Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales encountered anger and skepticism from senators today as he insisted that he had nothing to hide in the dismissals of eight United States attorneys, an episode that has cast a shadow on the Justice Department and brought calls for his resignation.

title: Former Judge Convicted of Bribery in Divorce Cases
description: A former State Supreme Court justice was convicted today of accepting bribes to manipulate the outcome of divorce proceedings in a case that led to a broad political and judicial corruption inquiry in Brooklyn. The judge, Gerald P. Garson, 74, could face as many as 15 years in prison if he is sentenced consecutively on the bribery verdict and two lesser charges of which he was also found guilty. A jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn acquitted him of four lesser counts after a four-week trial.

title: Knicks Complete Another Lost Season
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 18  Isiah Thomas began his Knicks coaching tour with an ultimatum and a belief. He had to win to save his job. He was sure he had the players to do so.

title: BlackBerry Shuts Down for Hours
description: OTTAWA, April 18  Technical problems at Research in Motion cut off wireless e-mail service to millions of users of its BlackBerry hand-held devices in the United States for more than 10 hours overnight.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Sunday about the challenges facing Nascar after years of growth referred incorrectly to the finances of International Speedway Corporation, which owns many tracks where top races are run. The companys first-quarter revenue fell 4.5 percent compared with the same quarter a year ago  not 19 percent, which was the decline in first-quarter earnings compared with the same period. The article also referred incompletely to the companys explanation for these declines. Aside from lower attendance and a drop in concessions sales, the company also cited higher expenses.

title: Chinese Political Prisoner Sues in U.S. Court, Saying Yahoo Helped Identify Dissidents
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18  A Chinese political prisoner and his wife sued Yahoo in federal court Wednesday, accusing the company of abetting the commission of torture by helping Chinese authorities identify political dissidents who were later beaten and imprisoned.

title: Citigroup Resignation
description: A Citigroup executive, Dean S. Barr, resigned yesterday as head of the banks hedge funds less than a week after the bank agreed to buy a hedge fund, Old Lane Partners, and name its co-founder, Vikram S. Pandit, to oversee alternative investments including private equity.

title: Closing a Stubborn Folder
description: Q. When I turn on my Windows XP computer, the folder C:\windows\system32 opens automatically every time. Why is this and how do I stop it?

title: Kips Bay, Where Everything Glitters
description: THERE was a celebratory fizz all along Madison Avenue last week, on that stretch of the Upper East Side that makes a kind of decorators gulch, and that serves as a barometer of the rarefied neighborhoods consumer confidence.

title: Software by Microsoft Is Nearly Free for the Needy
description: In an effort to expand its global reach in computing, Microsoft plans to offer a stripped-down version of Windows, Office and other software for $3 to people in developing nations.

title: Harvards Former Lightning Rod Is a Hit in Asia
description: NEW DELHI, April 18  Lawrence H. Summers, the former Harvard president, has maintained a low profile in the United States since he stepped down from the university post last year amid controversy and criticism.

title: Chrysler to Build Two Plants in Michigan
description: Chrysler to Build Two Plants in Michigan

title: Amid the Chaos of Deaths, a Minister Attends to Those Who Are Grieving
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 18  Over the last three days, the Rev. Alexander W. Evans has spent his time in a cluster of small meeting rooms on the second floor of the hotel and conference center at Virginia Tech, listening over and over to a shared lexicon of grief, spoken in so many different voices.

title: Albany: Board Member Claims Pressure
description: A member of the Public Service Commission, which regulates public utilities in New York State, charged yesterday that an aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer threatened to have her removed if she did not back away from efforts to investigate Consolidated Edison over last years blackout in Queens. The member, Cheryl Buley, a commissioner appointed last year by Gov. George E. Pataki, made the accusation against Steve A. Mitnick, an assistant secretary to Mr. Spitzer, as the commission voted unanimously yesterday to proceed with the investigation. The investigation, which was opposed by the utility and by New York City officials, allows the commission to determine whether the company can charge customers some of the costs associated with the blackout. Christine Anderson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Spitzer, said no one from the administration told Ms. Buley to vote against the investigation, which she said the governor supports.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the struggles of St. Louis in the wake of a population decline misspelled the surname of an assistant professor at Washington University who has been involved in municipal planning projects. He is John Hoal, not Haul.

title: Austrias Chancellor Has Clout at the Opera
description: VIENNA, April 18  Alfred Gusenbauer vividly recalls his first nights at the opera. As a son of working-class parents, who came to Vienna from the provinces to study, he spent precious schillings to stand at the rear of the horseshoe-shaped auditorium in the Vienna opera house.

title: A Dozen Questions for Alberto Gonzales
description: With Attorney General Alberto Gonzales testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee today, the Op-Ed page asked four legal experts to step into a senators shoes and list three questions they would ask Mr. Gonzales.

title: 3 Evangelicals Found Slain in East Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, April 18  Three people were found with their throats slit in a publishing house in eastern Turkey that printed Bibles and other Christian literature, the authorities said Wednesday. One victim was a German citizen.

title: Albany: More Trouble for Felder
description: The state commission overseeing judges said yesterday that its chairman, Raoul Felder, no longer speaks for the panel. Last week, Mr. Felder received a unanimous vote of no confidence from the nine other members of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct after they accused him of invoking racial, ethnic and religious invective in a book that he wrote with Jackie Mason. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has also called for Mr. Felder to step down, but he has refused to do so and has disputed characterizations about his book. The commission said yesterday that the staff administrator would speak for the commission, and that the clerk would sign the panels orders. Mr. Felder said he did not oppose any of the steps being taken.

title: Banker Says Hell Smooth His Style, but Waters Are Choppy
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Paul D. Wolfowitz sought Wednesday to quell discontent over his leadership of the World Bank by promising top aides that he would change his management style, but he suffered a blow when one of those aides urged him to resign, bank officials said.

title: The Yankees Bats Give Igawa Breathing Room
description: Technically, Kei Igawa is a major league rookie because his eight years of professional experience before this season were in Japan.

title: Continuing a Celebration of a Composer (and Godfather)
description: The innovative American composer Earle Brown, who died in 2002, would have celebrated his 80th birthday last year. The new-music ensemble Ne(x)tworks observed the occasion by recording a number of his chamber works for Mode Records, a New York label widely admired for its devotion to modern music. The recording was released on Tuesday, and the group celebrated with a retrospective of Mr. Browns music at the Chelsea Art Museum.

title: IPod Audio at Home, Cleaned and Delivered to Speakers Near You
description: Creative Labs Xdock can stream audio wirelessly from an iPod to remote speakers and improve audio quality by cleaning up messy digital noise.

title: In Recruiting Season, Mistrust Is Raised at L.S.U.
description: Now that the womens college basketball season has ended, many coaches are on the road recruiting through mid-May. And, some said in recent interviews, they could face fallout from last months resignation of Pokey Chatman from Louisiana State, following charges of what the university described yesterday for the first time as inappropriate sexual relationships between her and former players.

title: G.O.P. All Ears as Ex-Senator Weighs Bid
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee is not a declared presidential candidate, but he demonstrated his political star power Wednesday by drawing an audience of dozens of House Republicans searching for an alternative to their partys current presidential field.

title: Having Some Fun and Learning at the Same Time
description: A new form of edutainment software has arrived in the form of JumpStart World, an educational theme park for Windows computers that can replenish itself with new content.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 18, 2007

title: Bush Presses Sudan on Darfur, Citing Possible U.S. Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  President Bush invoked the powerful imagery of the Holocaust on Wednesday to intensify pressure on Sudan, warning that the United States would impose stiff economic sanctions and seek others from the United Nations if President Omar Hassan al-Bashir does not bring a quick end to the brutal violence in Darfur.

title: Torre Rewards Wright With a Start in Boston
description: An hour before the Yankees played the Cleveland Indians last night at Yankee Stadium, Carl Pavano had ice on his sore right forearm as he walked past Chase Wrights locker.

title: Editors Note
description: A picture on the front page of The Metro Section on Tuesday with an article about flooding caused by the recent northeaster showed an antiques shop in Ridgefield, Conn., being washed away. The wood siding at the far left of the pink building was out of alignment because the picture was retouched by a Times staff member who took the picture, but who is not a staff photographer. He altered it because a flash created a white spot on the picture when he shot it through the window of a train. Also, the retouching tool left a round circle on the buildings window at right.

title: Officials Knew Troubled State of Killer in 05
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 18  Campus authorities were aware 17 months ago of the troubled mental state of the student who shot and killed 32 people at Virginia Tech on Monday, an imbalance graphically on display in vengeful videos and a manifesto he mailed to NBC News in the time between the two sets of shootings.

title: Professors Violent Death Came Where He Sought Peace
description: Prof. Liviu Librescu faced many trials in his 76 years, growing up and living in Romania. There were the Nazis, who imprisoned his family when he was a child. Then there was the totalitarian regime of Nicolae Ceausescu, which forbade him from working when he refused to join the Communist Party.

title: Spain: Telefnica to Sell British Unit to Macquarie
description: Telefnica, the Spanish phone operator, has agreed to sell its Airwave O2 unit, Britains police and emergency services radio network, to Macquarie Bank of Australia for 1.9 billion ($3.8 billion). The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group and Macquarie European Infrastructure Fund II, both managed by the bank, which is based in Sydney, will each own 50 percent of Airwave, they said in a statement. Marquarie is the worlds largest manager of infrastructure. Telefnica, based in Madrid, which has more debt than any other major European phone operator, is selling Airwave after shedding its phone directory business last year.

title: Fire Victims Gain a Little Immortality Through Art
description: Aisse Magassa slowly rolled her wheelchair to the wall of the old building, carrying a can of spray paint and with four of her little girls squirming behind her. The air was cold, and droplets of rain crashed softly onto the hijab that covered her hair. The brightly painted wall, at 56 East Mount Eden Road in the Bronx, lit up an otherwise drab stretch of auto repair shops and dollar stores.

title: A Sidekick With the Essential Features, but With a Smaller Price

title: Disallowed Goal Deflates the Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., April 18  The puck squirted between the legs of Buffalo Sabres goaltender Ryan Miller and slid into the net. Miller then crashed backward, taking the brunt of the most ferocious and decisive collision of the game Wednesday night.

description: WASHINGTON, April 18  F.B.I. agents last week searched the suburban Washington home of Representative John T. Doolittle, Republican of California, and his wife whose activities are being investigated in connection with her ties to the convicted lobbyist Jack Abramoff, Mr. Doolittles lawyer acknowledged Wednesday.

title: Floridas New Governor Steps Outside the Jeb Bush Mold

title: Pakistan: Chief Judge Challenges His Judges
description: Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, the chief justice suspended by President Pervez Musharraf last month, appeared before the Supreme Judicial Council to defend himself on charges of misuse of power. He has filed a petition in the Supreme Court, the court he once headed, challenging the constitutional authority of the five-judge council, said his lawyer, Chaudhry Aitzaz Ahsan. The council adjourned the hearing until Tuesday.

title: Evolutions and Mutations of a Knob-Tweaking Guitarist
description: David Torn is a guitarist, composer and producer, though the word order may depend on whom you consult. His career, stretching back more than 30 years, could easily be the work of several different people. He has carved a niche at the extreme end of guitar culture, while working extensively (and successfully) in film and commercial music. To call him a hero of the electric avant-garde would be accurate but incomplete.

title: Corzine Is Said to Be Moving Toward Consciousness
description: CAMDEN, N.J, April 19  Gov. Jon S. Corzine appeared to be moving closer to regaining consciousness this morning and doctors say they may soon be able to remove the tube that has helped him breathe since last Thursday, according to an official who has been briefed by the medical staff.

title: A Music Player That Needs Seasoning

description: The American Red Cross yesterday named Mark W. Everson, the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, as its president and chief executive.

title: Russia Plans Tunnel Link to Alaska
description: Russia unveiled a plan to build a tunnel between Siberia and Alaska under the Bering Strait, saying the $65 billion project could be used to export Russian oil, natural gas and electricity to the United States. At 64 miles, it would be twice the length of the Channel Tunnel between Britain and the Continent. While two Ministry of Economy officials endorsed the idea, they made it clear that the Russian government had not signed off on it.

description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Shareholders would have the right to a nonbinding vote on the pay packages of senior executives of public companies under a bill that the House began debating Wednesday.

title: The Great Black Hope
description: If you were drawing breath in 1957, you probably remember the anxiety that gripped America after the Soviet Union launched its first Sputnik satellite. The hand-wringing was so fierce, its amazing that people didnt break their fingers. Oh Lordy, they cried, were losing the space race.

title: Got a Zillion Songs? A Gadget to Help You Take Your Show on the Road
description: A zillion gadgets, it seems, let you pipe music from a portable player through your car stereo. But not all let you control the player with a separate knob and are both neat and easy to install.

title: Its Warm in Florida, to Delight of the Mets
description: MIAMI, April 18  The Mets traded their long underwear for short sleeves, stashed the woolen caps and ditched the parkas. No need for winter clothing here, where, for the first time in two weeks, they could embrace playing baseball alfresco.

description: Colleges and universities are scrambling to review the practices of their financial aid offices as a result of an expanding investigation into the ties between university officials and lenders.

title: Staten Island: Zoos New Reptiles
description: City officials yesterday opened the refurbished reptile wing at the Staten Island Zoo. The city invested $18.8 million in the 16,600-square-foot wing, which has a two-level alligator pool and 120 species of reptiles. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the zoo was home to one of the largest collections of venomous reptiles in the country. The mayor also said that the renovation incorporated energy-efficient features to allow the zoo to cut energy consumption by 20 percent.

description: Joe Borowskis slider bounced through his catchers legs, and the Yankees runners moved up to second and third. Now a base was open for Alex Rodriguez.

There was plenty of space for the two of them and his four children from a previous marriage, who visited every other week. But when his children started to live there most of the time, and the Blanches had a baby in 2000, things got a little crowded.

title: Wave of Bombings Continues in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April 19  Bombs ravaged Baghdad in five horrific explosions aimed mainly at Shiite crowds on Wednesday, killing at least 171 people in the deadliest day in the capital since the American-led security plan for the city took effect two months ago.

title: The Silence of Politicians
description: There are myriad questions from the evolving tragedy at Virginia Tech. One is how such a gravely disturbed student as this killer could raise heightened concern among the authorities over a year ago, yet manage to proceed unhindered to take 32 lives. But no less pertinent is the question of how, after detailed tracking of the guns purchased for the ghastly spree, the lethal empowerment of such a troubled individual can somehow be pronounced entirely legal under the laws of a civilized nation.

description: SOME designers find their inspiration at an early age, and not always while playing dress-up with Barbie.

title: For Governors, a Temptation to Go Faster
description: TRENTON, April 18  There is always another hand to shake, delaying departures. Constituents or colleagues waiting at the next stop to have their photos taken or questions answered. Too many meetings squeezed into too few hours.

title: Moving Day for That Vista Machine
description: BUYING a new computer is a lot like buying or renting a new home. First you have to pick it out and pay for it, and then you have to move your stuff. And as if PC moving day werent hard enough, most people now faced with this task have to migrate from an older version of Windows to the new Windows Vista, which typically stores user files in different folders from previous versions.

title: Bangladesh Says It Wont Let an Ex-Leader Re-enter the Country
description: NEW DELHI, April 18  The army-backed government of Bangladesh on Wednesday barred a former prime minister, whom it has accused of involvement in deaths during a political demonstration, from returning to the country.

title: Afghanistan: Blast Kills 5 U.N. Workers
description: A bomb planted in the road exploded under a United Nations car in the southern city of Kandahar on Tuesday, killing four security guards from Nepal and their Afghan driver. The five men were contractors working for the United Nations Office of Project Services, a support agency that has worked on large projects in Afghanistan, including running elections. The explosion tore apart the vehicle and burned the men inside.

description: By his own admission, Michael DiLeonardo is known as Mikey Scars, a captain of the Gambino crime family, bookmaker, loan shark, murderer of three and a Mafia turncoat.
