description: West Chester, Pa.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about this years Pulitzer Prize winners included outdated information from the Pulitzer board in some copies about the prize for editorial writing. After awarding it to the editorial board of The Daily News in New York, the Pulitzer board updated its Web site to note that it was won by only three writers from the paper: Arthur Browne, Heidi Evans and Beverly Weintraub. The article also referred incompletely in some copies to the reporters for The Wall Street Journal who contributed to the newspapers prize for public service. In addition to Charles Forelle, James Bandler and Mark Maremont, Steve Stecklow worked on the project about the unethical practices of business executives.

title: Mental Health and Guns: Do Background Checks Do Enough?
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Revelations about Cho Seung-Huis 2005 stay in a psychiatric center under a magistrates order have raised questions about whether background checks adequately scrutinize the mental health history of potential gun buyers.

description: A 12-foot-long whale that had surfaced and frolicked near the mouth of the Gowanus Canal on Tuesday, delighting and surprising even the most hardened of Brooklyn residents, died yesterday, officials said.

description: QUICK, true or false: Solar energy systems work only on hot, cloudless days. Rooftop systems come in one configuration  big and ugly. And if you generate more energy than you use, there is no way you can sell it elsewhere.

title: Chinas Economy Still Growing at a Torrid Pace
description: SHANGHAI, April 19  China said Thursday that its economy continued to accelerate at a blistering pace, growing by an annualized rate of 11.1 percent in the first quarter of this year.

description: WASHINGTON, April 18  When Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales takes the witness chair on Thursday before the Senate Judiciary Committee, the dismissal of the United States attorney from New Mexico will be a topic of particular scrutiny, committee members and their staff said.

title: Kyrgyzstan: Opposition Protests Continue
description: About 8,000 demonstrators gathered near President Kurmanbek Bakievs office in Bishkek, the capital, for an eighth day of protests against him, and added a call for new parliamentary elections to their list of demands for sweeping government reforms. They have already demanded new presidential elections. Mr. Bakiev has initiated a number of compromises with the opposition in recent weeks, including appointing a critic as prime minister. Protest leaders are calling for larger demonstrations over the weekend.

title: Online, Students Say Reach Out to Loners
description: Tokens of mourning among college students are proliferating this week as they did in May 1970, when black armbands signaled solidarity with the students at Kent State. But the memento mori today is an intangible illustration, a glossy loop of pixilated fabric, created by an anonymous graphic designer, set off with a Photoshop shadow and seemingly fastened, as if by a brooch, with a conjoined VT: Virginia Tech.

title: New York: Mayors Show Gun-Control Advertisement
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and other members of the national coalition Mayors Against Illegal Guns unveiled a 30-second television advertisement intended to pressure Congress to rescind the so-called Tiahrt amendment, a measure attached to spending bills each year since 2003 that bans the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives from releasing gun-trace data, except to police officials and prosecutors working on a particular crime. The advertisement is to be broadcast in Washington, D.C., as well as in the districts of two members of a House subcommittee that is weighing the measure, Representatives Rodney Frelinghuysen, Republican of New Jersey and the ranking minority member, and Alan B. Mollohan, Democrat of West Virginia and the panel chairman. The advertisement will also be broadcast in the district of Representative Todd Tiahrt, the Kansas Republican who wrote the amendment. Mr. Bloomberg also announced the addition of 27 New Jersey mayors to the group, bringing the total to 214.

description: WE had Passover with all the grandchildren, which was fabulous, the woman in pearls said. She had just finished her shift in the designer room at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Thrift Shop and was filling in the next volunteer, a slight, silver-coiffed woman wearing Ferragamo pumps. Youre not allowed to eat bread at Passover, are you? her friend asked in tones that recalled Katharine Hepburn. No, the first woman said. The silver-haired woman thought for a moment. What about muffins?

title: Checks for Airport Checkers

The agency and airports are trying to head off a push in Congress to require that all 800,000 people employed at airports are physically screened each time they go to work. Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of New York, introduced legislation on March 8 to require that workers with access to airport secure areas be held to the same standard as passengers.

title: The Philippines: Body Said to Be Americans
description: Officials said the body of a woman found buried in mud in the mountainous northern province of Ifugao was that of a missing Peace Corps volunteer, Julia Campbell. They said she had apparently been murdered. Work continues at the site to determine the circumstances, said a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Manila, Matthew Lussenhop. A regional police commander, Chief Superintendent Raul Gonzales, told The Associated Press, There is a probability that there was foul play. Ms. Campbell, 40, a former freelance reporter in New York who contributed to The New York Times in the 1990s and joined the Corps in 2005, was last seen on April 8 as she set off for a hike in the village of Batad, which offers a magnificent view of the centuries-old rice terraces, one of the countrys tourist attractions. Ms. Campbell, from Fairfax, Va., was one of 137 Peace Corps volunteers in the Philippines. Colleagues said that her service was wrapping up and that she was excited about returning to New York.

description: When graffiti was rampant in New York City during the 1980s, a Brooklyn teenager known as Alan Ket was at the top of his game. In broad strokes of aerosol spray, he slashed brash images on subway cars, branched out to vandalize trains in Europe, and became such a fixture in the flourishing graffiti culture that he was asked to speak at several universities.

description: WASHINGTON, April 18  Both sides in the abortion struggle predicted that the Supreme Courts decision on Wednesday would escalate the drive for new abortion restrictions in state legislatures and push the issue of abortion rights  and the Supreme Court  squarely into the 2008 presidential election.

description: Splashed across the headlines recently: A report from Savills, the real estate agency, showing that the price of trophy houses in London costing $10 million-plus had soared by up to 50 percent in the past year. The newspaper reports several reasons to be cautious. First, a series of interest-rate rises has hit affordability, helping push up repossessions. Union Wants Daimler to Keep Chrysler
description: The president of the United Auto Workers said Wednesday he hopes to persuade DaimlerChrysler not to sell the Chrysler Group, even as a German magazine reported that Daimler could make a decision on a buyer in the next four weeks. Ron Gettelfinger, the union head who was speaking to reporters at Chryslers headquarters, said the union believed that it was still an option for Daimler to keep Chrysler, which reported an operating loss of $1.5 billion last year. There is a lot of value in keeping it there right now because of the synergy, even though you dont hear a lot about that, he said. It has worked well.

title: Ebay In Talks for StumbleUpon, Report Says
description: Ebay is in talks to buy StumbleUpon, a Web site rating system that has been the subject of deal speculation for some time, according to the blog TechCrunch.

title: Macquarie Picks Up Airwave O2s Signal
description: Telefonica, the Spanish phone operator, has agreed to sell its Airwave O2 unit, Britains police and emergency services radio network, to the Macquarie Bank of Australia for 1.9 billion pounds ($3.8 billion). The Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group and Macquarie European Infrastructure Fund II, both managed by the bank, which is based in Sydney, will each own 50 percent of Airwave, they said.

title: Gazprom Takes Control of Sakhalin Oil Project
description: Gazprom, the Russian state-run gas company, on Wednesday completed the purchase of its controlling share in the Sakhalin-2 oil and gas project, buying half the stakes owned by Royal Dutch Shell, Mitsui and Mitsubishi for $7.45 billion.

title: Japan Tobacco Closes Gallaher Deal
description: Japan Tobacco has completed its $15 billion acquisition of the Gallaher Group, both sides said Wednesday, in what was the biggest Japanese overseas acquisition ever. Japan Tobacco, the overseas distributor for Winston, Camel and Salem cigarettes, and Gallaher Group, the British-based maker of Silk Cut and Benson & Hedges cigarettes, announced the deal last December.

title: Hedge Funds Sit Tight in Qantas Buyout
description: Some hedge funds apparently are making it hard for a private equity consortium to seal its $11.1 billion deal for the Australian airline Qantas. With just more than two weeks to go until their tender offer expires, the bidders, who include the Macquarie Bank and the Texas Pacific Group, are having trouble winning over shareholders, with the number of shares committed to the deal actually dropping since last week, according to Finance Asia.

title: Rival Offer Reignites Topps Battle
description: Some board members and shareholders of Topps, the baseball card maker, are furious with the company after it shunned a higher bid from its rival Upper Deck in favor of a $385 million deal with Disneys former boss Michael D. Eisner, The New York Post reported.

title: Mirant Sells Caribbean Business
description: The independent power company Mirant said on Wednesday it had agreed to sell its Caribbean business to Marubeni of Japan for about $732 million. Mirant, which emerged from bankruptcy early last year, is also in the process of selling its Philippines assets to Marubeni and Tokyo Electric Power.

title: Highland Makes Fresh Overture to Delphi, Report Says
description: A hedge fund, Highland Capital Management, is interested in making another run at the auto parts maker Delphi, the Wall Street Journal reported. In January Delphi signed a $3.4 billion deal with a group of private equity investors, despite a $4.7 billion rival bid from Highland.

title: TD Banknorth Shareholders Approve Sale to Parent
description: TD Banknorth shareholders have approved a plan by Toronto-Dominion Bank, which already owns nearly 60 percent of the Bank, to acquire the rest of the shares for $3.6 billion. The transaction is expected to close April 20, at which time TD Banknorths shares will be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange, the company said Wednesday. TD Banknorth, which is based in Portland, Maine, will then become a subsidiary of Toronto-dominion Bank, which is based in Toronto.

title: Ford Sells Glass Unit
description: Ford Motor said Wednesday it reached a tentative deal to sell the glass-making operations it took back from its former subsidiary, Visteon. Ford said it had agreed to sell the glass-making unit, which employs about 1,600 workers, to Glass Products, a company formed by an investor, Robert Price. Terms were not disclosed.

title: V.C.s Grab Some Air
description: What are those crazy venture capitalists in Silicon valley up to these days when they are not listening to pitches and signing deals? Kiteboarding, apparently. Bloomberg News takes a look at the sport, which has seduced the likes of Google co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page, as well as a slew of venture capitalists, private equity pros and investment bankers.

title: Citigroups Hedge Fund Head Steps Down
description: A Citigroup executive, Dean S. Barr, resigned Wednesday as head of the banks hedge funds less than a week after the bank agreed to buy a hedge fund, Old Lane Partners, and name its co-founder, Vikram S. Pandit, to oversee alternative investments including private equity. Mr. Barr also resigned as chief executive of the banks Tribeca global management unit, Citigroup said Wednesday in a memorandum to employees.

title: BlackBerry Blackout Brings Angst, Insomnia and Acceptance
description: The recent outage that left five million BlackBerry users without their cherished wireless e-mail triggered some major withdrawal symptoms. People across the country frantically switched the devices on and off and made desperate calls to their help desks in an attempt to figure out what was wrong. I quit smoking 28 years ago, an executive at an insurance company told The New York Times, and that was easier than being without my BlackBerry.

title: Lawmakers Debate Shareholder Vote on Executive Pay
description: A fight is brewing over a bill that would allow shareholders to have the right to a nonbinding vote on the pay packages of senior executives of public companies. The measure, which the House began debating Wednesday, would also give shareholders the right to vote on any golden parachute compensation plans that are awarded to executives while they are negotiating the purchase or sale of a company.

title: Are Tech I.P.O.s on the Rebound?
description: Seven years after the Internet bubble burst, investors say its time to recoup their Silicon Valley losses. Technology firms backed by venture capitalists raised $701 million in seven initial public offerings last quarter, equaling the third period of 2004 as the busiest since 2000, according to Dow Jones VentureOne, which does research on the industry.

title: Icahn Presses on in Bid to Buy Developer
description: Carl C. Icahn turned up the heat on Wednesday in his campaign to take over the board of the troubled developer WCI Communities, a builder of posh retirement communities, mostly in Florida, the New York Post reported. In a regulatory filing, Mr. Icahn urged shareholders to vote for his slate of 10 new directors, who back his buyout offer of $956 million, or $22 a share.

title: Jefferies Buyout Rumors Spark Rise in Stock and Options
description: Stock in the Jefferies Group, the investment bank, rose more than 5 percent and call options surged on Wednesday, fueled by speculation the company is a takeover target, Reuters reported citing options market participants and a stock analyst. Jefferies, a merger adviser and underwriter to mid-sized companies, declined to comment on the chatter. Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance, known as MassMutual, was touted as a possible suitor by one options analyst.

title: Experian Offers $240 Million for Hitwise
description: Experian, the credit information company, announced plans to buy an Internet marketing group, Hitwise, for $240 million, the Telegraph reported Thursday. Hitwise helps clients monitor the performance of their Web sites and target their online advertising spending more effectively. Experians core business is its credit checking service, but the group hopes the acquisition will strengthen its marketing solutions division.

title: MetroPCS Raises $1.15 Billion in I.P.O.
description: MetroPCS Communications, a mobile-phone company that sells flat-rate calling plans in metropolitan areas, raised $1.15 billion in the biggest initial stock sale of 2007, Bloomberg News reported. The company, based in Dallas, sold 50 million shares for $23 each. The price was more than the $19 to $21 range it had predicted.

title: Judge Dismisses the Most Serious Charges Against Dr. Hurwitz
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  His retrial in federal court here isnt over yet, but Dr. William E. Hurwitz is already doing much better than he did the first time. Judge Leonie M. Brinkema has dismissed the most serious charges against him.

title: Merrill, Bank of America Report Higher Profits
description: Merrill Lynch said Thursday that first-quarter profit rose 31 percent, to $2.16 billion, lifted by record investment-banking fees and trading revenue. Merrills chief executive, Stan ONeal, called it a terrific quarter despite a sometimes volatile environment. Including Merrills latest figures, Bloomberg News reported that first-quarter profit at the five biggest securities firms in the nation totaled $9.7 billion, an all-time high. Separately, Bank of America said Thursday that first-quarter profit increased 5 percent to $5.26 billion, helped by growth in fee income.

title: A new art to F1 photography
description: Did anyone notice fewer photos of the winning team in the press after Ferrari won the Bahrain Grand Prix last Sunday? I did. But its no surprise. The job of photographer and photo editor has become exponentially more difficult this season as all of the teams except Ferrari have ceased to use tobacco sponsorship. Bahrain was the first race of the season at which Ferrari chose to display the name of its tobacco sponsor. It is not only the tobacco companies and the teams  except Ferrari and its sponsor  who have decided to fall in line with legislation that is quickly expanding worldwide against tobacco sponsorship, it is also much of the print media  although not so much television. So it is that many newspapers and magazines no longer use images of cars with tobacco sponsors. Moreover, it is clear to me that Ferraris very occasional use of its tobacco sponsors name and logo this year is actually going to seriously backfire against Ferrari, its tobacco sponsor and Formula One in general. It has already started.

title: The Met's New Roman Galleries
description: Michael Kimmelman, the Times's chief art critic, tours the Roman court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is opening after 15 years of renovations.

title: America Underreacts to the Gonzales Matter
Chos Manifesto, Everywhere
description: After the news media spent days dealing with unconfirmed reports, the playing field was suddenly leveled with NBC Newss release of much of Cho Seung-Huis multimedia manifesto.

title: Motorola and Icahn Raise Voices in Proxy Fight
description: Tensions between the management of Motorola, the cell phone maker, and the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn heated up after Motorola reported a loss for the first quarter and issued a disappointing forecast for the second, leading some analysts to question whether it would be able to return to profitability this year.

title: Checking In and Not Checking Out
description: This banal horror retread involves a couple of critters flailing inside a sticky trap for what is, in effect, the big-screen equivalent of a roach motel. Luke Wilson, who could stand a career intervention, and Kate Beckinsale, the reigning queen of the bland B's, play a sniping couple who undergo a little unexpected marital therapy by landing in the wrong place at the wrong time. Having strayed off the Interstate one evening in the middle of nowhere, they end up in a motor inn run by Frank Whaley that, in the real world, would have been repackaged for its self-conscious retro-ugly hipster chic.

title: Portland Fair
description: We went to dinner the other night, Patrick, Jeremiah and I, at 23 Hoyt, one of several local restaurants owned by Bruce Carey, and it was pretty terrific. The place was open and contemporary, the food the kind you want to eat (I had beet risotto, followed by lamb shank, and I ate most of Patricks rhubarb crisp), and the wine, if I remember, was Oregonian. Ive felt in danger several times in the last 36 hours of committing a Gomer Pylism: Wow, its great here. New Yorkers must say that all the time. Well, it is nice here, but this isnt news to the people who live in this part of the world.

title: Fallen Angels With Fuzzy Halos
description: A hackneyed melodrama partly redeemed by a cast convinced that it's performing Tennessee Williams, "Downtown: A Street Tale" follows a bunch of stereotypically damaged people in an abandoned building in New York. Rehashing characters and plots from the "Law & Order" playbook, the director, Rafal Zielinski, supplements his material with religious iconography and more gauzy close-ups than a Barbra Streisand marathon. Prostitution, heroin and mental impairment have never looked so pretty.

title: On The Market
Misadventures of a Paper Boy
description: "A Dios Momo," directed by Leonardo Ricagni, is to melodrama as corn syrup is to sweeteners: efficient but crude.

title: ONeill Stuck Holding the Mic
description: Paul ONeill, the former Yankee, retired at the end of the 2001 season and is now an analyst with the YES Network. But, as ONeill hung around by the batting cage before the Yankees played the Cleveland Indians on Wednesday night, he acted more like a player than a broadcaster.

title: Southwest Airlines Chief Says Buyout Is Unlikely
description: Could private equity try to board Southwest Airlines? One credit analyst says the carrier, known for its quirky, no-frills style, could be a tempting buyout candidate. But Southwests chief executive, Gary Kelly, sounds skeptical.

title: 2008: F. Thompson on the Hill
description: Dozens of Republican House members looking for a promising presidential hopeful flocked to the nearby Capitol Hill Club, seeking a sermon on the Hill from Fred D. Thompson, the Law & Order actor and former Tennessee senator. Little insight about Mr. Thompsons decision-making came out of the meetingor into whether he would ultimately be a viable candidateor into where he stands on the issues. From The Washington Posts Dana Milbank:

title: Cerberus to Quit Delphi Investment Group
description: Confirming earlier reports, Delphi said on Thursday that Cerberus Capital Management is dropping out of a group planning a $3.4 billion investment in the bankrupt car parts maker. Reuters reported that Cerberus may still participate in the reorganization as part of the companys exit financing package, and the other investors in the plan, including Appaloosa Management, are staying in.

title: Does This Abortion Decision Matter?
description: The Los Angeles Times editorial on the Supreme Court decision upholding the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act includes a sentence that suggests Gonzales v. Carhart ultimately doesnt mean very much for either side of the abortion debate: This muddled decision doesnt attack the basic holding of Roe v. Wade, and it will have no effect on the vast majority of abortions performed in this country.

title: Questioning Gonzales
description: Blogtalk Wrap Up | 6:06 PM ET

title: Buehrle Padding His Resum
description: Mark Buehrles no-hitter for the White Sox on Wednesday night was the first of the 2007 season and the 16th in team history. He was nearly perfect against the Rangers in Chicagos 13th game of the season, his first win in three appearances. According to The Associated Press, there have been 32 no-hitters thrown in the month of April since 1898.

title: Clintons Home $weet Home?
description: As she campaigns for president, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton often talks about growing up in Chicago, but she has yet to try capitalizing on her hometown roots, at least as far as fundraising is concerned.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include Broadway revivals of "Inherit the Wind" and "A Moon for the Misbegotten."

title: In Texas, Hedge Funds Win a Round for Secrecy
description: Hedge funds that dabble in distressed assets are celebrating a decision in an obscure Texas bankruptcy case.

title: Catching Aint Easy
description: Despite wearing chest protectors, shin guards, face mask, knee savers and a few other pieces of armor, catchers every so often leave one area of the body exposed.

title: How the Sallie Mae Deal Got Done
description: Ever since Sallie Mae announced on Monday a $25 billion buyout offer by two private equity firms and two banks, one of the questions deal-makers have been asking is this: How did Friedman, Fleischer & Lowe, a relatively small buyout firm, get a cut of one of the biggest financial-services buyouts ever?

title: Nine and a Half Weeks, Albany-Style
description: Thats how much time Gov. Eliot Spitzer has left to carry out the remainder of his agenda, as the governor himself noted today.

title: A New Warning on Real Estate
description: Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.  If an expert puts out a book saying a trend will last for a decade, and it then promptly ends, can you depend on his next book to be a similarly excellent contrary indicator?

title: Should Music Labels Try a Silicon Valley Approach?
description: The beleaguered recorded-music business has to do something to pull itself out of its current predicament, which stems partly from outside forces it cannot control (the Internet) but also from its own clumsy or outdated strategies. According to Fortune magazines Tim Arango, Warner Music Groups rumored deal to buy Front Line Management  the nations largest artist-management firm, with a roster of big-name clients including Christina Aguilera and Aerosmith  may offer a new economic model for the major record companies. He compares this model to venture capital investing, but with the record labels nurturing new talent instead of new technologies.

title: Campaigns and Caucus Readers
description: Were now in an accelerated campaign season, one that is propelling candidates to raise huge amounts of money and to outline positions far ahead of the usual schedule.

title: Waiting for That Second First Hit
description: The Yankees will use Jorge Posada for all three games in Boston this weekend, so today its Wil Nieves behind the plate at Yankee Stadium. Nieves won the backup catchers job during spring training, beating out veterans Todd Pratt and Raul Chavez. Pitchers love throwing to him, according to GM Brian Cashman.

title: Tempers Flare Over Rejected eSpeed Bid
description: The Times of London takes a look at what it calls the vicious feud between London brokerage firm Tullett Prebon and Cantor Fitzgerald, the New York-based firm that rejected Tulletts bid for eSpeed, its electronic bond-trading subsidiary. The account describes a deep and vituperative divide between the companies chief executives and even offers a timeline and a list of players in the trans-Atlantic contretemps. But somehow the article fails to mention one of the most colorful figures in the affair: The hedge fund manager Robert Chapman of Chapman Capital, who has been pushing for a sale of eSpeed.

title: Going Against the Flow
description: A birth control pill designed to eliminate the monthly period may hit the market soon.

title: An Extraordinary Measure
description: I get a lot of unsolicited correspondence from readers, most of whom want to make sure I know how bad Restaurant Xs service is, how good Restaurant Ys veal chop is, how impossible it is to get a human being on the phone at Restaurant Z or what an overlooked dining Mecca some six-square-block area in a far corner of the Bronx is.

title: For Facebook Backer, $1 Billion Sounds Way Low
description: Among Web 2.0 startups, few are more closely watched than Facebook, a social-networking Web site that was originally restricted to college students but has since opened the gates to many others as well. Much of the fascination comes from the decision by Mark Zuckerberg, the companys young founder, not to accept offers to acquire Facebook, including a bid from Yahoo that The New York Times said was worth $900 million. (Others have rounded it up to an even $1 billion.) In a long profile of the oft-profiled Mr. Zuckerberg, Fast Companys Ellen McGirt spends some time pondering how Facebooks founders and its investors  who include PayPal founder Peter Thiel  might eventually cash out their stakes.

title: Public Opinion on Abortion
description: Americans remain sharply divided over the issue of abortion, but a plurality would like to see stricter limits placed on abortions in the United States, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted last month. Democrats and women are more likely to prefer keeping abortion generally available to those who want it.

title: Podcast: Charlie Rangels Memoir
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: Seeking an Explanation in Science
description: Readers respond to David Brookss April 19 column, The Morality Line.

title: Whats Behind the Hate?
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Apr. 19 column, A Volatile Young Man, Humiliation and a Gun.

title: Doolittle Steps Down From House Panel
description: A little less than a week after his home was searched by the F.B.I., Representative John T. Doolittle, a California Republican, has taken a temporary leave of absence from the Appropriations Committee.

title: A Nanny With Flashing Lights?
description: One of the metro desks expatriates in Los Angeles  Randal C. Archibold, now a national correspondent  read with interest about Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs nanny moment  on Wednesday. Asked about Gov. Jon Corzines accident, the mayor had criticized  public officials who use lights and sirens to get to photo opportunities or other non-emergencies.

title: One Less Name
description: Christine Quinn, the City Council speaker, made good today on her pledge to block a proposal to name a city street for Sonny Carson, a Brooklyn anti-drug activist, because he had a history of unabashed bigotry.

title: Trying to Move On in Blacksburg
description: If Mondays massacre was the deadliest ever at a college in U.S. history, then this week may have been the longest ever for a college spokesman.

title: Good for Goodness Sake
description: Most details of my high school graduation are hazy in my memory, but I distinctly remember one speech given by a member of the school board. He turned his back to us seniors onstage and faced our parents in the audience.

title: Mean Grown-Ups
description: Theres an absolutely horrifying article in the current issue of Child Magazine about the food fight now raging between parents of children with life-threatening food allergies and parents of the allergy-free. The latter, apparently, have started to push back against peanut-free school regulations to assert their childrens natural right to eat whatever they darn well please.

title: Too Much News
description: Let us pray  for a slow news day. I sit here at the keyboard with the time almost past for submitting my column. About all I am sure I can produce here is a kind of cop-out apology to you, dear reader.

title: Champagne Interruption
description: We interrupt this class for a special announcement.

title: Vigil in the Village
description: The Greater New York City Chapter of the Virginia Tech Alumni Association is inviting the public to attend a candelight vigil at 7:e0 p.m. tonight in Washington Square Park to honor the victims of the shootings on the Blacksburg campus.

title: Blogtalk: World of Statecraft
description: Nanny Spitzer targets video games. [Serf City] (Two Republican state senators unveiled their own video game crackdown  plan today).

title: Earthly Ideas
description: Between the United Nations reports on climate change released earlier this month and Earth Day coming up on Sunday, the campaigns and activists clearly have global warming on the brain.

title: Happy Endy
description: On July 13, the first 25,000 fans to the Mets-Reds game will receive a bobblehead doll of one of Endy Chavez making his remarkable catch in Game 7 of last years NLCS. Chavez hasnt seen a copy yet, but he was able to see the catch from all angles yesterday afternoon, when he walked into the clubhouse carrying a matted poster of four photographs of his over-the-fence grab of Scott Rolens deep fly. The photos were taken by Times photographers.

title: Almost as Hot as A-Rod
description: At 28 years old Shelley Duncan is far from the gem of the Yankees farm system. He is not considered one of their top 10 prospects and did not receive an invitation to the teams major league spring training this year.

title: Thriller at the Stadium
description: I did not grow up rooting for  or against  the Yankees. As a kid in a National League town in the 1980s, the Yankees were somewhat irrelevant. A good team, usually, with some star players, but they never made the playoffs in the 13 years after I started following the game.

title: The Met's New Galleries
description: Michael Kimmelman tours the Greek and Roman court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is opening after 15 years of renovations.

title: Frugal San Juan
description: With $500 in his pocket, Matt Gross, a.k.a. The Frugal Traveler, sets out to find a 5-star weekend in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Syndromes'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Syndromes and a Century," an unusual Thai film about mood and memory.

title: Blogtalk: The Grilling of Gonzales
description: In recent weeks, few topics have galvanized some of the more prominent lib-blogs than the firings of federal prosecutors  led by Joshua Marshall at TalkingPointsMemo.com  at the hands of Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. His much-anticipated appearance before the Judiciary Committee today was blogged and dissected nearly moment by moment, answer by answer. (Senators on both sides of the aisle did nearly as much dissection as the writers.) The chorus from several wings of the blogosphere was practically in unison  that this hearing was Mr. Gonzales last chance to save his job. And his performance did not go over well, at least in this arena.

title: A Colossus Mistake
description: In H Block at Bletchley Park, the historic code-breaking facility 50 miles from London, visitors can view a rebuilt working model of a Colossus, one of the first electronic digital computers, built during World War II to decrypt Nazi codes. If only they hadnt waited 60 years to put it back together  there might still be a British Empire. And Silicon Valley might be in some bog outside of Bletchley Park.

title: In the Hot Seat
description: In his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales struggled to hold on to his job.

title: Another G.O.P. Congressman Steps Down
description: Well, it seems like the federal corruption investigations team has moved into a more aggressive phase. This news is on top of Congressman John Doolittles decision to step off the Appropriations Committee after investigators raided his house.

title: Bloomberg to Unveil Long-Term Vision for City
description: With New Yorks population expected to grow by one million in two decades, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will call on Sunday for a raft of ambitious and sometimes contentious proposals that are intended to ease traffic congestion, reduce air pollution, build housing, improve mass transit and develop abandoned industrial land.

title: Mom Goes Shopping for a Shiny New Gun
description: Wife, Mom, Bounty Hunter, which makes its debut on the WE network tonight, is the third reality show about bounty hunters in recent years. (Human Bonds had a 10-episode run on HBO in 2004, and Dog the Bounty Hunter is going strong on A&E.) If this keeps up, there may be more TV bounty hunters than criminals.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about debate over gun laws in the wake of the shootings at Virginia Polytechnic Institute misidentified the home state in some copies for Senator Harry Reid, who said lawmakers should not rush to take action. It is Nevada, not Utah.

title: N.J. School Closes After Threat Tied to Columbine
description: Tenafly High School in northern New Jersey was closed today on the eighth anniversary of the massacre at Columbine High School in Colorado after school officials discovered graffiti that seemed to suggest some kind of threat tied to the anniversary date.

title: For the Record
description: An article on March 9 about a fire in a Bronx home that killed one adult and, eventually, nine children misspelled the given name of one victim, a 5-year-old boy. (The error was repeated in articles in some copies on March 10, 12, 13 and 18.) The boy was Abudubacary Magassa, not Abudubary. A reporter who visited the boys school in late March discovered a discrepancy in the spellings, and this correction was delayed for additional research.

title: S.I. Businesswomans Killing in Panama Is a Tangled Tale
description: Toni Grossi Abrams was looking for something new.

title: Ciao, Rosa Castaldi
description: There comes a moment in a Marx Brothers movie when everything comes to a dead stop so the young lovers can sing. Some are nebbishes, like Kenny Baker in At the Circus, while others are just creepy, like Tony Martin in The Big Store, but they are all painful to watch. I dont know how audiences in the 1930s, unable to fast-forward, handled the interludes. Maybe they picked up their knitting, or waited things out in the lobby.

title: Wal-Mart Reports Its Chief Was Paid $29.7 Million in 2006
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the worlds largest retailer, paid its chief executive, H. Lee Scott Jr., $29.7 million last year after sales grew at the slowest pace in more than two decades.

title: Nascent Stars Stretch Out in Three Daunting Concertos
description: Since 1961 the estimable Young Concert Artists organization has been awarding prizes and nurturing the careers of top-notch emerging talents. For the most part this has involved presenting them in recitals. But for the last dozen years or so, the organization has been ending its concert season in New York with a special program, the Irene Diamond Concert, offering several recent winners of Young Concert Artists auditions performing concertos, to let them really show off what they can do.

title: Rock/Pop Listings
description: POP

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Something Old, Something New and Some Things Pettitte
description: The games have blurred for Andy Pettitte. He vaguely remembers taking the mound for the first time at Fenway Park, hearing the taunts in that unusual New England accent, sometime in 1995, his rookie season with the Yankees.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary and headline yesterday about the founder of the Electric Power Research Institute, who was also a leading exponent of nuclear power, misspelled his given name. He was Chauncey Starr, not Chaucey. (Go to Article)

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: A Day of Mourning
description: Grieving and sadness over the nations deadliest shooting rampage reached far beyond Blacksburg, Va., today, as mourners from Colorado to Israel remembered the 32 victims killed on the campus of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute.

title: Bush, on Friendly Turf, Suggests History Will Be Kind to Him
description: TIPP CITY, Ohio, April 19  With his attorney general under fire in Washington and his fight with Congressional Democrats over paying for the war at a stalemate, President Bush came here Wednesday before a friendly audience to give his thinking on Iraq, Congress and the massacre at Virginia Polytechnic Institute.

title: Looking Beyond the Phrasing, to the Spirit
description: DENVER  Its been cold here lately, Dianne Reeves said this month, readying plates of food for a late lunch, so I decided to make some lamb. She laid out the meal on the center island of her kitchen here, including sweet iced tea made from hibiscus leaves brought home from Turkey and cornbread that she has been perfecting, trying to replicate a version she admired at a local restaurant. Explaining how she likes to cook, she said: Its the same thing with how I sing. I work with my ear and try to make it feel right, or I just keep changing it until I like the way it tastes.

title: Owners Lose and Bosses Win in Bad Mergers
description: If its not your money, you may be quite willing to spend more of it.

title: Yanks Valuable, Even at a Loss
description: The Yankees are the most valuable team in Major League Baseball at $1.2 billion, and the only franchise to lose money last year, Forbes magazine said in its annual survey.

title: Steven B. Derounian, 89, Judge and Nassau Ex-Congressman, Dies
description: Former Representative Steven B. Derounian, who represented Nassau County in Congress from 1953 to 1965 and was later a judge, died on Tuesday in Austin, Tex. He was 89 and moved to Austin, in his wifes home state, from Garden City in 1981.

title: Whats On Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) PLANET EARTH 2007: SEVEN WAYS TO HELP SAVE THE WORLD  In honor of Earth Day, ABC News anchors and correspondents will report live from all seven continents throughout the day, supplemented by this 20/20 special in which seven environmental experts discuss the biggest problems facing the planet and some possible solutions. Elizabeth Vargas will report from an African game preserve, Chris Cuomo will travel to Paris, John Quinones will explore the Brazilian rain forest, Cynthia McFadden will journey to China, and Bill Weir will explore the Great Barrier Reef in Australia. Therell even be one live report from the South Pole.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about the singer and actress Kitty Carlisle Hart referred incorrectly to her role in the 1935 Marx Brothers comedy A Night at the Opera. Her singing in the film was followed by at least two other operatic performances before she made her Metropolitan Opera debut, in 1967. One was on Broadway in Brittens Rape of Lucretia; another, in Salt Lake City, was in Carmen. The film role was not as close as she came to opera until her Met debut.

title: People
description: People

title: Wanted: A Third Party to Complete Love Triangle
description: If you love to hate the superrich, The Valet, a delectable comedy in which the great French actor Daniel Auteuil portrays a piggy billionaire industrialist facing his comeuppance, is a sinfully delicious bonbon. His character, the beady-eyed Pierre Levasseur, is a human rodent with an explosive temper and an ego the size of Versailles; his nostrils twitch like rat whiskers when he flashes a sickly smile. A liar, a bully and a cheapskate, he has broken every promise he made to the picketing workers who threaten to close down his factories.

title: House Votes to Give the Capital a Full Voice in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Advancing a debate that harks back to the countrys earliest days, the House passed legislation Thursday to award the residents of the nations capital a full voting representative in Congress.

title: Building a Better Lockdown
description: I WAS at my desk at the F.B.I.s Critical Incident Response Group on April 20, 1999, when a colleague ducked his head into my office and asked if Id heard the news. A school shooting in Colorado. Some place called Columbine. At least 10 dead. Columbine, I remember thinking as I clicked on the bank of TVs on the far wall. Where in Gods name is that?

title: After Falsified Test Results, Kelly Orders Forensic Shakeup
description: With the disclosure that two civilian employees reported false results in testing drug bags in 2002 at the police crime laboratory, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has ordered a shakeup of the Forensic Investigations Division and the creation of an oversight panel, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Putting Up His Dukes, for His Country, His Race and Money
description: If you were drawing breath in 1957, you probably remember the anxiety that gripped America after the Soviet Union launched its first sputnik satellite. The hand wringing was so fierce, its amazing that people didnt break their fingers. Oh, Lordy, they cried, were losing the space race.

title: On a Very Hot Seat With Little Cover and Less Support
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  It did not bode well for Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales when, before he uttered his first word to the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday, Senator Jeff Sessions, Republican of Alabama, looked at him as if he were headed to the gallows and offered this advice: "Be alert and direct and honest with this committee. Give it your best shot."

title: Overlooked by Some, Devils Parise Finds His Place
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 19  From his seat in the living room of his home in Minnesota, J. P. Parise was transported back in time Wednesday night.

title: Union, in Organizing Fight, Tangles With Celebrity Cook
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Paula Deen, the Food Networks ebullient queen of butter-drenched Southern cooking, has found herself in the middle of a dispute between Smithfield Foods Inc. and a union that has long tried to organize one of the companys pork processing plants.

title: Warming and Global Security
description: People who give short shrift to environmental matters pay attention when national security becomes part of the conversation. So the debate over global warming took a useful turn this week as diplomats and retired military officers drew persuasive connections between climate change and the very real potential for regional upheavals.

title: Civil Unions Gain Ground as a Governor Vows Action
description: BOSTON, April 19  New Hampshires governor said Thursday that he would sign a bill legalizing civil unions for same-sex couples.

title: Price War Takes Toll as A.M.D. Posts Loss
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19  After a three-year run, Advanced Micro Devices is back on the defensive.

title: Audit Finds Many Faults in Clevelands 06 Voting
description: CINCINNATI, April 19  An audit of last Novembers general election in the Cleveland area has found that hundreds of votes were lost, that others were recorded twice and that software used to count the ballots was vulnerable to data problems.

title: Gates Assures Israel on Plan to Sell Arms to Saudis
description: TEL AVIV, April 19  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that he had reassured Israel that a planned major American arms sale to Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries would not threaten Israels military superiority and was necessary to counter a threat from Iran.

title: South Africa: Late Commuters Burn Train
description: Commuters in suburban Pretoria set two train cars on fire after losing patience with efforts to repair a fault that had stopped traffic on the trains line, the commuter authority Metrorail said. The train had been stopped by a red signal at the Greenview station, but when technicians arrived to make repairs, some furious commuters threw stones at them, injuring two repairmen and three commuters. Others set the carriages on fire, the authoritys spokesman, Thokozani Zitha, told the SAPA news service. We were able to save a third carriage.

title: Pill That Eliminates the Period Gets Mixed Reviews
description: For many women, a birth control pill that eliminates monthly menstruation might seem a welcome milestone.

title: Lineup Changes, but Not the Way the Mets Hit
description: MIAMI, April 19  After deciding to give the dinged-up Paul Lo Duca a day off, Manager Willie Randolph jotted down three lineups on a legal pad. He thought them over for about 90 seconds, and in the end it proved about 90 seconds too much.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Gonzales Endures Harsh Session With Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, trying to salvage his job, endured withering questioning on Thursday from Senate Judiciary Committee members who expressed grave doubts about his truthfulness and judgment in the firing of federal prosecutors.

title: Chos Mental Illness Should Have Blocked Gun Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Under federal law, the Virginia Tech shooter Seung-Hui Cho should have been prohibited from purchasing a gun after a Virginia court declared him to be a danger to himself in late 2005 and sent him for psychiatric treatment, a government official and several legal experts said Friday.

title: Wolfowitz Backed Friend for Iraq Contract in 03
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Paul D. Wolfowitz, while serving as deputy secretary of defense, personally recommended that his companion, Shaha Ali Riza, be awarded a contract for travel to Iraq in 2003 to advise on setting up a new government, says a previously undisclosed inquiry by the Pentagons inspector general.

title: Leading Democrat in Senate Tells Reporters, This War Is Lost
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  As Congressional Democrats sought to reconcile their differences and send an Iraq spending bill to the White House, Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, said Thursday that this war is lost, a stark assessment that Republicans argued would demoralize American troops fighting in Iraq.

title: Southern Californians Look to Brown Hills With a Fear of Fires
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19  The hills and palm trees have turned sepia, the winds crackle and the skin of many Angelenos, with the texture and appearance of unpeeled onions, needs a slathering of cream.

title: President of Troubled Chicago Transit System Resigns
description: CHICAGO, April 19  The chief executive of the nations second-largest public transit system resigned Thursday as the agency grapples with budget shortfalls, a major railway reconstruction project and complaints from disgruntled riders.

title: Patient Capital for an Africa That Cant Wait
description: Last week, I was touring northern Tanzania when our car passed the small town of Karatu and we suddenly came upon an open field splashed with colors so bright and varied it looked from afar as if someone had painted a 30-color rainbow on the landscape.

title: Tales of Yosemites Fatal Attraction
description: It is 3,000 feet to the bottom and no undertaker to meet you. Take no chances. There is a difference between bravery and just plain ordinary foolishness.

title: Concerts by (and for) Singers
description: IN the folk tradition of Sacred Harp music, the harp refers to the voice  many, many voices, usually, of people who have come together to sing, a capella, in glorious four-part harmony. Together, they are carrying on a style of singing that has survived in American communities for hundreds of years, long enough to enjoy renewed popularity in the 21st century.

title: Seeking the Nixon Behind the Caricature
description: IN a quiet corner of the bar at the Hotel Plaza Athne in New York, Frank Langella raised his hands in victory signs, furrowed his brow and shook his jowls violently: the International Symbol for Richard Nixon.

title: Gonzales v. Gonzales
description: If Attorney General Alberto Gonzales had gone to the Senate yesterday to convince the world that he ought to be fired, its hard to imagine how he could have done a better job, short of simply admitting the obvious: that the firing of eight United States attorneys was a partisan purge.

title: The Dogs? The Inventory? The Water Bed? Flooded Residents Cope
description: WAYNE, N.J. April 19  The worst moment in the past five days for William Borger came at the end of the boat ride that took him from dry land to his house on North Road in the Hoffman Grove section. He needed his blood pressure medicine from the house, where the basement was entirely flooded and the first floor had 13 inches of water. But he needed Gunner and Magnum, his German shepherds, more.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Spidey Swings to Broadway

title: Gates Presses Iraq Premier on Healing Sectarian Divide
description: BAGHDAD, April 19  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived here on Thursday intending to press Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq to move faster on Sunni-Shiite reconciliation at a moment when Mr. Malikis ability to deliver appears limited, at best.

title: No Bridge, No Problem
description: WHO Dave and Doreen Keyes, both 57, both retired, of Bellevue, Wash. WHERE San Juan Island, Wash. WHAT 3-bedroom house

title: Corrections
description: An obituary and headline yesterday about the founder of the Electric Power Research Institute, who was also a leading exponent of nuclear power, misspelled his given name. He was Chauncey Starr, not Chaucey.

title: Chinese Growth Shows Little Restraint, Rising 11.1% in Quarter
description: SHANGHAI, April 19  Chinas economy continues to accelerate at a blistering pace, growing 11.1 percent in the first quarter of this year from the first quarter of 2006, according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics released Thursday.

title: Principal Gets Up to 14 Years in Case of Sex With Student
description: Lilies that fester smell far worse than weeds, a judge in Manhattan said yesterday, quoting Shakespeare, before sentencing a former private school principal to up to 14 years in prison for having a sexual relationship with a student.

title: Trial of Amgen Drug May Dispel Some Safety Concerns
Friends Describe How Killers Mother Tried to Have Police Remove Him Before He Could Kill
description: In the days before a Queens man killed his mother, her companion, a home health aide and himself in an eruption of gunfire on Wednesday morning, his mother had made desperate attempts to have her son forcibly removed from their home, her fears of being attacked only worsened by her anger that the police were not aggressively intervening in a family nightmare, said people who knew her.

title: Adjudging a Moral Harm to Women From Abortions
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  That abortion is bad for fetuses is a statement of the obvious. That it is bad for women, too, is a contested premise that nonetheless got five votes at the Supreme Court on Wednesday.

title: Corzine Is Taken Off Ventilator
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 20  Gov. Jon S. Corzine was taken off the ventilator he has been relying on to breathe for more than a week Friday afternoon, although doctors warned he might need the breathing tube reinserted depending on his pain levels and other potential complications.

title: Profits Up 69% at Google, Exceeding Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19  For much of this year, the buzz around Google has been all about the flurry of new initiatives at the No. 1 Internet search company, from its YouTube video sharing site, to its new software for office workers, to its forays into television, radio and newspaper advertising.

title: Mayor Revises Some Points of School Budget Proposal
description: Ceding ground to the city teachers union, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced changes yesterday to his plan for a new school budgeting system. The changes mean that it will be harder and take longer for the mayor to redistribute senior teachers, who tend to cluster in middle-class neighborhoods, more evenly across the school system.

title: In China, Talk of Democracy Is Simply That
description: BEIJING, April 14  Like the spring showers that give the parched landscape a veneer of green, Chinas authoritarian leaders, approaching the end of their five-year terms in office, have suggested that they would like to see their country become more democratic.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about Mimi Lerner, an operatic mezzo-soprano and educator, misstated the year of her birth. It was 1945, not 1946. (As the obituary correctly noted, she was 61.)

title: Art in Review
description: LEE BONTECOUVacuum-Formed Sculptures and Related DrawingsKnoedler & Company19 East 70th Street, Manhattan Through April 28

title: New York Plans to Sue Drexel U. in Loans Inquiry
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, New Yorks attorney general, notified Drexel University yesterday that he intended to sue it for deceptive business practices, the first time that he has singled out a university for a lawsuit in his broadening investigation of the college loan industry.

title: A Mixed-Up Son of The Graduate
description: The meek, mopey comedy In the Land of Women is the film equivalent of a sensitive emo band with one foot in alternative rock and the other in the squishy pop mainstream: a softer, fuzzier Garden State. Like Zach Braffs Andrew Largeman in that movie, Adam Brodys character, Carter Webb, in Land of Women is a sensitive mixed-up kid, although at 26 he is hardly a kid. An aspiring screenwriter in Los Angeles who has spent years working on a still-unfinished screenplay about his high school days, he makes his living writing soft-core pornography. His life comes apart when his girlfriend Sofia (Elena Anaya), an attractive young movie star, unexpectedly breaks up with him because she wants space. Carter flees to Michigan to visit his ailing grandmother, Phyllis (Olympia Dukakis).

title: R.I.M. Offers a Reason for BlackBerry Failure
description: OTTAWA, April 19  The installation of an insufficiently tested piece of software set off a chain reaction that eventually cut off BlackBerry service to more than five million users in North America users, the devices maker said late Thursday.

title: From Whip to Rod, Ex-Jockey Tries Taming a New Animal
description: EVANS, Ga., April 19  Kevin Wirth was hunting fish with his eyes. He stared into the water of Clarks Hill Lake and did not seem to notice the long ash from a cigarette burning under his nose.

title: A Historic River City Is Losing Its Backwater Reputation
description: APHRODITE CLAMAR-COHEN used to spend weekends at a home on seven wooded acres in the Catskills in Bearsville, N.Y. She loved to get away from Manhattan, but she didnt like the isolation of country life. She was used to walking places and seeing people, and she wanted the same lifestyle on the weekends.

title: Playing a Game of Cat and Mouse Without Breaking a Sweat
description: The glib entertainment Fracture offers an assortment of tasty treats, notably the spectacle of that crafty scene stealer Anthony Hopkins mixing it up with that equally cunning screen nibbler Ryan Gosling. Theyre beautiful slummers, these two, as well oiled and practiced as those great old-studio dissemblers who worked a soundstage to their and Louis B. Mayers advantage. The only difference is that once upon a time Joan Crawford would have whispered dangerous nothings into Mr. Hopkinss ear, not Mr. Gosling.

title: U.S. Releases Cuban Bombing Suspect
description: A 79-year-old anti-Castro Cuban exile and former C.I.A. operative linked to the bombing of a Cuban airliner was released on bail yesterday and immediately returned to Miami to await trial on immigration fraud charges.

title: A Tilt in Wall Streets Pursuit of Private Equity
description: EARLY one recent morning, I was in my fuzzy slippers talking by phone about private equity with a hyper-kinetic senior Wall Street executive who had time to talk only very early in the morning. He said something that woke me up: Of course we are conflicted.

title: Its Politics, You Dummy
description: There should be no easier target for a satirist than the current administration in Washington. Alas, The View From K Street Steak, a new play by Walt Stepp at Altered Stages, misses with just about every shot and proves how elusive the business of getting a laugh can be.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column yesterday, about performances by the Kirov Ballet and Orchestra next year at New York City Center, misstated the title of a work by William Forsythe. It is Steptext, not Septet.

title: Rodriguez Caps Two-Out, Six-Run Rally
description: Joe Borowskis slider bounced through his catchers legs, and the Yankees runners moved up to second and third. Now a base was open for Alex Rodriguez.

title: One Certainty of Draft: Giants Have Holes to Fill
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 19  On the January day that Jerry Reese was introduced as the Giants general manager, he was reluctant to assess the teams specific needs.

title: A Special Appearance for Rembrandts 'Titus'
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has one of the greatest collections of Rembrandts in the United States, but it is borrowing one of his seminal works. Portrait of a Boy in Fancy Dress (1655), also known as Titus, is coming to the gallery from the Norton Simon Foundation in Pasadena, Calif., from May 11 to Sept. 4. While the National Gallery regularly contributes artworks to exhibitions around the world, the Norton Simon almost never lends its holdings. This is the first of what the two institutions say will be a continuing loan program.

title: NBC News Defends Its Use of Material Sent by the Killer
description: NBC News fought back yesterday against a growing backlash over the way it handled the pictures and writings of the student who killed 32 people at Virginia Tech.

title: Times Co., Gannett and Tribune Co. Report Declines
description: Buffeted by an ongoing advertising recession, The New York Times Company and the Gannett Company announced yesterday that their first-quarter profits declined while the Tribune Company reported a loss.

title: Study Supports Use of Anemia Drug From Amgen
description: In an announcement that could dispel at least some of the recent safety concerns over a widely used class of drugs, Amgen said today that its anemia drug Aranesp did not increase the death rate of lung cancer patients in a closely watched clinical trial.

title: A Horse Is a Horse, Except Barbaro
description: The Kentucky Derby will be run in 15 days, and while horses like Curlin, Nobiz Like Shobiz, Circular Quay and Scat Daddy will grow more familiar by post time, news media coverage will be haunted, if not dominated, by Barbaro.

title: For Rodriguez, Each At-Bat Is the Focus, and Thats the Difference
description: Alex Rodriguez was destroying baseballs on a warm morning in Tampa, Fla., two months ago, scorching line drives or making some balls vanish. With each fluid swing in a routine batting practice session, Rodriguez looked content. He performed as if it were any month except October.

title: 2 Subprime Lenders Announce Job Cuts; Call Centers Closed
description: General Electrics subprime lending unit, WMC Mortgage, closed three centers yesterday and cut 771 jobs  about half of its remaining staff  while the Residential Capital home-lending unit of GMAC announced it would eliminate as many as 700 workers, or 5 percent of its American work force.

title: Classical Treasures, Bathed in a New Light
description: The other day, apropos of the Metropolitan Museums fine, new light-washed galleries for Greek and Roman art, a friend e-mailed to me a passage by Virgil. In it Aeneas, fleeing the Trojan War, arrives in Carthage and finds a temple for Juno under construction. He pushes open the temples big bronze doors (which made the hinges groan, Virgil reports) and for the first time he dared to hope for life. Hes astounded by the skill of the craftsmen and by the nobility and precision of a painting of the war. He starts to cry.

title: Natalia Clare, 87, Dancer With Ballets Russes Troupes, Dies
description: Natalia Clare, a member of both of the influential Ballets Russes troupes of the 1940s and 50s and the founder of a prominent Los Angeles ballet school, died April 8 at her residence in Torrance, Calif. She was 87.

title: At Power Lunch, Mayor Presents Wish List, in a Handy Wallet Size
description: The guest list included dozens of the citys most influential power brokers and political donors. The entertainment was a panel discussion moderated by Charlie Rose and featuring Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, and Harold E. Ford Jr., chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council.

title: Empire State Building Seeks Best of the Brightest
description: Think of it as a smackdown between King Kong and Godzilla. Hours before sunrise today, two lighting behemoths faced off at the Empire State Building, vying for a $5 million contract to bring 21st century illumination to New Yorks tallest skyscraper.

title: An Anglophilic Yankee Aristocrat and His Finds Across the Pond
description: He described himself as a galloping Anglophile, hooked on horse breeding, racing, hunting and other pastimes of the English gentry. Yet Paul Mellon (1907-99), the Pittsburgh-born philanthropist and son of the banker and industrialist Andrew Mellon, didnt discover the sport of collecting British art until he was well into middle age.

title: In the Beverly Hills Style: Candidates $400 Coiffure
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Presidential campaigns spend all sorts of money on all sorts of things. Television advertisements. Polls. Big-time consultants. Coaches for the news media. Chartered airplanes. High-priced Beverly Hills haircuts for the candidate.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Spain: Bid Is Made for French Contractor
description: Sacyr Vallehermoso, a Spanish construction company, bid 9.75 billion euros ($13.26 billion) to take over Eiffage of France, a diversified construction company that built the Eiffel Tower, setting the stage for a cross-border struggle for control of the company. The bid came less than 24 hours after a shareholders meeting where Eiffage blocked Sacyrs request for seats on its board, even though Sacyr holds a 33 percent stake. Sacyr offered 12 of its shares for every five of Eiffage, valuing the stock at 104.69 euros, a 6 percent discount to its closing price Wednesday. Sacyrs approach pits the builder against Eiffage, which views itself as a venerable part of the French establishment.

title: Feast of Serious Cinema; Partygoers Welcome
description: A three-ring circus and a temple of high art; a community development project and a political forum; a multipurpose theme park with oases for sports fans and children and a star-packed movie premiere  this is the sixth annual Tribeca Film Festival, which begins on Wednesday and continues for 12 days around the city.

title: In China, Talk of Democracy Is Simply That
description: BEIJING, April 14  Like the spring showers that give the parched landscape a veneer of green, Chinas authoritarian leaders, approaching the end of their five-year terms in office, have suggested that they would like to see their country become more democratic.

title: A Sharp Turn for the Supreme Court on Abortion (9 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Says Tip That May Have Aided Skakel Came After Murder Conviction
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 19  With his former client sitting a few feet away, Michael C. Skakels former lawyer, Mickey Sherman, told a court on Thursday that he was not given information until after the 2002 murder trial that might have spared Mr. Skakel from being convicted in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley in Greenwich.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Virginia Tech: The Killer, the Guns, the Anguish (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: First to the Second Round, Rangers Take Time to Rest
description: The Rangers completed their four-game sweep of Atlanta in the first round of the playoffs in varying degrees of exhaustion, particularly having played Games 3 and 4 on back-to-back nights at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Plot Against Medicare
description: The plot against Social Security failed: President Bushs attempt to privatize the system crashed and burned when the public realized what he was up to. But the plot against Medicare is faring better: the stealth privatization embedded in the Medicare Modernization Act, which Congress literally passed in the dead of night back in 2003, is proceeding apace.

title: Riffing on Modernism: Through the Roof, Brancusi!
description: Many art historians consider Constantin Brancusis Endless Column (1938), designed to memorialize Romanian soldiers killed in World War I, the quintessential example of Modernist sculpture. Made from 17 cast-iron pieces stacked a soaring 96 feet high, it was built, as Brancusi put it, to support the vault of heaven.

title: Killings of Afghan Civilians Recall Haditha
description: After it became clear last year that several marines had killed 24 civilians in Haditha, Iraq, following an attack on their convoy of Humvees, the Marine Corps, which had initially played down the massacre, began an offensive of a different kind.

title: A Portraitists Grandson Creates Her Portrait on Film
description: The fascinating documentary Alice Neel  a biography of this influential, emotionally troubled painter by her grandson Andrew Neel  could easily have been titled Form Follows Function. It achieves the documentary formats basic goal of illuminating history while also demonstrating, through filmmaking choices, how an artists style reveals his or her personality.

title: Tenafly: Threatening Graffiti Closes School
description: Tenafly High School will be closed today, the eighth anniversary of the shootings at Columbine High School in Colorado, after the discovery of threatening graffiti yesterday afternoon prompted an evacuation and search of the school, the Tenafly police said. Early yesterday morning, the police received a phone call saying that graffiti had been found on the inside of a school door. While the threat was vague, the date  April 20, 2007  was not. The school was evacuated and the building searched with the help of a bomb-sniffing dog. Nothing was found and students were sent home at 12:15 p.m., the police said.

title: Knicks May Stick With the Hand They Have
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 19  In a season that was by turns frantic and frustrating, often promising and ultimately disappointing, the Knicks proved to be too flawed, too inconsistent and, in the end, too injured to break their postseason drought.

title: France: Airbus Adds Workers for A380
description: Airbus, two years behind schedule on deliveries of the new A380 airliner, is adding 1,000 employees at its plant in Hamburg, Germany, to keep to the latest production deadlines. Airbus plans to hire 250 engineers permanently in Hamburg, the companys biggest manufacturing site aside from its headquarters in Toulouse, France, and is taking on another 750 temporary workers to complete cabling on its first 25 A380s, a spokeswoman, Barbara Kracht, said.

title: Marie M. Clay, Remedial Reading Specialist, Dies at 81
description: Marie M. Clay, an internationally known educator who developed a remedial reading program known as Reading Recovery, which has been used with millions of children around the world, died last Friday in Auckland, New Zealand. She was 81 and lived in Auckland.

title: Manhattan: Activists Name Off Street-Naming List
description: The name of the radical black activist Sonny Carson, left, was removed from a list of 53 names in a street-naming bill yesterday after a racially charged City Council committee hearing. Mr. Carson, who died in 2002, was an ex-convict who became a community advocate and anti-drug crusader, but he was also known as an unabashed racist. Councilman Albert Vann, a Brooklyn Democrat who put Mr. Carsons name on the list, said that despite Mr. Carsons sometimes hateful attitudes, he had also helped his Brooklyn community, and it should be up to the community to decide whose names adorn its streets. (Indeed, Community Board 3 of Brooklyn voted in favor of naming four blocks of Gates Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant Sonny Abubadika Carson Avenue.) But the Councils Parks and Recreation Committee voted 3 to 1 with one abstention to remove Mr. Carsons name from the list. The vote was followed by a brief scuffle as security officers removed protesters trying to unfurl a banner in the chamber. The amended bill will now go the full Council for a vote.

title: Manhattan: Workers Rescued From Scaffold
description: Firefighters rescued two window washers who were stranded on a scaffold in Turtle Bay yesterday morning, the Fire Department said. Firefighters received a report about 8 a.m. that two workers, who were not named by the department, were stuck on a scaffold outside the 37th floor at 747 Third Avenue, fire officials said. Firefighters used ropes to secure the scaffold to the building and, after cutting out a window, a firefighter stepped onto the scaffold to guide the workers to safety. No one was injured, fire officials said.

title: A Consultant in Deans Run in 2004 Joins With Edwards
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Joe Trippi, a Democratic political consultant who ran Howard Deans upstart presidential campaign in 2004, said Thursday that he had signed on with John Edwards in the 2008 race.

title: Anger of Killer Was on Exhibit in His Writings
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 19  More than anyone else on the Virginia Tech campus, it was the professors and students in the English department who knew of the mental turmoil of Cho Seung-Hui.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 19, 2007

title: Gates to Press Iraqi Leader, but Outcome Is in Doubt
description: BAGHDAD , April 19  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived here on Thursday intending to pressure Prime Minister Nuri al Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq to move faster on Sunni-Shiite reconciliation at a moment when Mr. Malikis ability to deliver appears limited, at best.

title: U.S. Database Exposes Social Security Numbers
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Social Security numbers of tens of thousands of people who received loans or other financial assistance from two Agriculture Department programs were disclosed for years in a publicly available database, raising concerns about identity theft and other privacy violations.

title: Remember Whitewater? The Place Is Still There
description: ITS hard now to remember those shiny days before 9/11 when Congress seemed to believe that the greatest threat to the republic lay in an obscure land deal in northwestern Arkansas called Whitewater. Given all that has passed under the bridge, theres something quaint and nostalgic about so much froth and fury over something that in the end went nowhere, like a slightly gonzo Norman Rockwell cover showing democracy in action.

title: Rare Books, New Worlds
description: You never know what secrets books may hold, which is reason enough to attend the New York Antiquarian Book Fair. This years event, with 200 international exhibitors, opens today at noon at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street and continues through Sunday.

title: Have You Never Been Mellow? Or Pleasant or Sad?
description: O come let them adore her: Norah Jones. Her fans filled the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night for precisely that purpose; at least one had come all the way from Brazil. (Or so he claimed, loudly, between songs.) According to her record company Ms. Jones is the best-selling female artist of the 21st century, and although she may encounter some competition in the next 90-odd years, the point is indisputable: shes a star.

title: Queens: 3 Accused of Defacing Tunnels
description: Three Brooklyn men have been indicted on charges of causing more than $10,000 in damage by spray-painting a subway tunnel on the L line, prosecutors said yesterday. The three  Miles Wickham, 22, of Fifth Street; Michael Baca, 22, of Meeker Avenue; and Raul Mendez, of East New York Avenue  are charged with multiple counts of criminal mischief and making graffiti, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said the men videotaped themselves spraying their graffiti tags and the slogan ACC on tunnel walls between the Halsey Street and Wilson Avenue stations. He said ACC stood for All City Crew or Another Crime Committed.

title: For the Record
description: The headline on a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about opposition protests referred incorrectly in some copies to the country where the protests took place. They were in Kyrgyzstan, not Kazakhstan.

title: From Asia to the Caribbean to New York, Appetite Intact
description: Yearning for a taste of home in 1950s New York, a man from Trinidad hunted for aloo pie, the spicy potato pastry that is a favorite of Trinidadians of South Asian ancestry. But he could not find it in his Brooklyn neighborhood, where, unlike him, most Caribbean immigrants were of African descent.

title: Ex-Chief at Qwest Found Guilty of Insider Trading
description: DENVER, April 19  Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive who transformed Qwest Communications International into a major telecommunications rival, was convicted Thursday of insider trading.

title: For the Record
description: The Books of the Times review last Friday, of Kabul Beauty School, omitted one of the books authors. In addition to Deborah Rodriguez, Kristin Ohlson is also a co-author.

title: France: Muslim Graves Desecrated
description: Fifty-two Muslim graves were desecrated and covered with swastikas and other Nazi graffiti in the World War I military cemetery of Notre-Dame de Lorette, near Arras. Last month, more than 50 Jewish graves were knocked over in a cemetery in the nearby city of Lille.

title: Senecas Vote to Rescind Thruway Pact
description: Leaders of the Seneca Nation have voted to rescind a 1954 agreement that allowed the New York State Thruway to run through the Cattaraugus Indian Reservation south of Buffalo. The agreement is declared null and void, Maurice A. John Sr., president of the Seneca Nation, said yesterday. The nations tribal council passed a resolution on Saturday arguing that the agreement, which allowed construction of three miles of the highway on Seneca land, is invalid because it was never approved by the secretary of the interior. The resolution comes as the Senecas are engaged in a dispute with New York State over the collection of sales tax at reservation stores. The Senecas say federal treaties shield them from state taxes. Mr. John said there was no connection between the issues. A spokeswoman for Gov. Eliot Spitzer said he would meet with Seneca leaders.

title: Japan: Slain Mayors Son-In-Law Seeks Post
description: As Nagasaki struggled to make sense of the shooting death of its mayor, Itcho Ito, his son-in-law announced that he would run in Mr. Itos place in the mayoral election on Sunday. Mr. Ito was campaigning for a fourth term when he was gunned down Tuesday. The police said he was killed by a member of an organized crime group but have yet to figure out a motive. Residents placed flowers on the sidewalk where Mr. Ito was shot, while his family held a private funeral. Later, the son-in-law, Makoto Yokoo, a 40-year-old journalist with no experience in politics, announced his candidacy.

title: In Shadow of a Tragedy, Longing for Normalcy but Enveloped by Grief
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 19  The heart of Virginia Tech was mostly empty.

title: University Explains the Return of Troubled Student
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 19  Officials at Virginia Tech on Thursday defended their decision to allow the gunman in Mondays rampage to return to campus after he was released from a psychiatric facility, even though they were aware of his troubled mental history and potential for violence.

title: Film Venture Is Formed
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19  Robert G. Friedman, who resigned in 2005 as vice chairman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group, and Patrick Wachsberger, chief of the foreign film sales company Summit Entertainment, joined a group of investors led by Merrill Lynch to acquire Summit and make it part of a new movie production and distribution company called Summit Entertainment L.L.C., the executives said Thursday.

title: Lawmaker Tied to Inquiries Gives Up Seat on Committee
