description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Representative John T. Doolittle relinquished his seat on the powerful Appropriations Committee Thursday amid signs that federal investigators were stepping up several linked investigations into corruption on the panel.

title: Banished to the Country, a Too-Good Cop Finds an Action-Movie Parody
description: The wits behind the controlled chaos that is Hot Fuzz, a parody of Hollywood-style action flicks, wield a somewhat heavier comic cudgel than they did in their last big-screen outing, the zombie caper Shaun of the Dead. This time, as they say in the blow-up business, its personal, or at least somewhat personalized, since the more obvious targets here include high-octane producer-auteurs like Jerry Bruckheimer and Joel Silver, who, with their fat budgets and armies of heavily armed bad boys, have helped define the modern action spectacular, reshaping the old kiss-kiss, bang-bang movie experience into the cinema of lock-and-load.

title: Solitude and the Sea
description: THE turtle-grass flats of the Caribbean are a looking-glass world, shimmering films of light and life that hide as much as they reveal. Such a thin slick of fresh water in the mountains might hold a nine-inch trout. But in saltwater, shallow water can yield a bonefish as broad as a bowling pin with the power to strip 100 yards of line. Or a man-size tarpon dressed in silver-dollar scales that gallops across the water like a bronco.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Re A Little Luxe on the Jersey Shore (April 13): My great-grandmother, Esther Teitelman, would have been thrilled to hear Curtis Bashaw has tricked out the Virginia Hotel in Cape May with leopard-patterned rugs and hand-pressed Belgian linen sheets. Ive been told that she owned the hotel around the start of the 20th century, having learned her inn-keeping skills from her parents, who owned a coaching stop outside Vilnius, Lithuania.

title: Hedge Funds Activism Creates New Wealth for Law Firms
description: For corporate lawyers of a certain age, it seems like the 1980s all over again.

title: Chaotic Duo Indignantly Fills Post-Imus Void
description: UNLIKE the sunset-hued office suite at Kaufman Astoria Studios that fit the disgraced talk show host Don Imus like a custom-made Sante Fe serape, the eyesore office assigned to Mike and the Mad Dog, the oddball afternoon sports duo temporarily and unhappily filling in weekday mornings for their fired mentor, is a hodgepodge of bobble-headed sports dolls, discarded books, stray Snapple bottles and a Maltese Falcon statuette with a broken beak.

title: Minnesota Doesnt Plan to Trade Garnett
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 19  The Minnesota Timberwolves need to overhaul their roster, but they will probably not trade Kevin Garnett to do it.

title: New Push Likely for Restrictions Over Abortions
description: DENVER, April 19  Both sides of the abortion debate expect a new push for restrictions as state lawmakers around the country digest the implications of the Supreme Court decision Wednesday upholding a federal ban on a type of abortion.

title: For a Versatile Director, a Season of Trilogies
description: Everybody likes Jack OBrien. At the mention of his name, people audibly soften. He has a wonderful aura about him that makes him incredibly attractive, said the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe. You just want to spend time with him.

title: Organic Milk Supply Expected to Surge as Farmers Pursue a Payoff
description: Dairy farmers are rushing to convert to organic milk production, and it is largely because of a blueberry farmer who lives in Maine with a solar-powered computer and an outhouse outfitted with a stained-glass window.

title: Innocence or Experience? An American Tale
description: The Ski Mom Case: thats the callous label the news media affix to the prosecution of the title character of Stephanie Daley for the murder of her newborn on a class ski trip. Stephanie (Amber Tamblyn), a shy, guarded 16-year-old who is the only child of conservative religious parents, denies responsibility by insisting that she didnt know she was pregnant. Her condition is discovered when she collapses while traipsing through the snow with her friends.

title: Gunman Kills Hostage at Johnson Space Center
description: HOUSTON, April 20  A contract worker brandishing a revolver took control of part of a Johnson Space Center building on Friday afternoon, killed a hostage and then himself after a standoff with the police. One other hostage survived, apparently without serious injury.

title: Hoping to Calm the Waters, Chairman of Siemens Resigns
description: BERLIN, April 19  The corruption scandals at Siemens, the German industrial giant, claimed one of the nations most prominent industrialists late Thursday, as the company said its chairman, Heinrich von Pierer, would resign next week.

title: Big Money in Little Screens
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19  Searching the Web on a mobile phone has been a lot like getting online via dial-up modem circa 1995: slow, tedious and not terribly useful. Typing on tiny buttons, squinting at a list of links and clicking through to a page that wont display properly is enough to test anyones patience.

title: Zimbabwe: Election Redistricting Afoot
description: Zimbabwe plans to redraw its political subdivisions in its major cities, Harare and Bulawayo, before elections next March, the minister for local government was quoted as saying in the government-controlled newspaper The Herald. The redrawn districts would include more rural voters in formerly urban legislative districts, a change that is likely to dilute the votes of opposition supporters who are concentrated in major cities. The government also has plans to set legislative elections for 2008, coinciding with the presidential vote. Outside political analysts say the changes will increase the re-election prospects of President Robert G. Mugabe, who has been the head of government since 1980.

title: N.Y. Governor Unveils Energy Efficiency Initiatives
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed one of the most ambitious energy conservation plans in the nation yesterday, pledging a package of legislative and regulatory measures that he said would allow New York to consume less energy in 2015 than it does today.

title: 2 Miners Trapped in Maryland Under Up to 100 Feet of Rock
description: Two miners were trapped under 45 to 100 feet of rock and dirt near Barton, Md., on Tuesday after a side of an open pit coal mine collapsed, and rescue efforts continued yesterday with workers filling 20 to 30 trucks an hour.

title: Nigeria Frets Over How to Give Voters a Real Say
description: ABUJA, Nigeria April 19  The purple banner across the normally staid front page of The Guardian, a national daily newspaper here, was impossible to miss. So was the bluntness of the message.

title: Playing Chef in a Little Kitchen on the Shore
description: IN the one-man kitchen of a Cape Cod cottage, Gary Sullivan is fixing yogurt parfaits for his partner, Mark Young, and a guest.

title: For the Record
description: An article in the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about plans for a large mixed-used real estate development in downtown Los Angeles misstated the number of housing units that have either been built downtown since 1999 or are under construction. It is more than 15,000, not 1,500.

title: Cross-Cultural Exchange From a Finnish Soprano
description: Karita Mattilas wildly successful operatic career took a night off for a concert recital on Wednesday, albeit in a place the size of most opera houses. At Carnegie Hall in front of a friendly audience, this Finnish soprano spent the first half of the evening in a kind of diplomatic exchange between her country and ours, and then turned to things Spanish.

title: Randolph Will Wear No. 42 at the Braves Game Friday
description: MIAMI, April 19  Willie Randolph was putting on his shoes in his Shea Stadium office last week when he looked up, and there was the No. 42 jersey, just lying in his locker.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Manhattan: School Warns of Information Release
description: Columbia University notified more than 300 students and 2,000 alumni this week that their names and Social Security numbers had been inadvertently placed on a Columbia Web server that was not fully protected. Robert Hornsby, a university spokesman, said the information was removed quickly after a student came across it on a Columbia housing lottery Web site and notified university officials. Mr. Hornsby said that Columbia had been excising unneeded Social Security numbers from its files in recent years, and that although exposure to the information had been limited, subscriptions to a credit-monitoring system for those affected has been arranged.

title: For Phillies and Manuel, a New Philadelphia Story
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Philadelphia still has hopes for the postseason, but after the feeblest start in the major leagues, the Phillies are struggling simply to remain in contention through prom season.

title: Talk Radio Tries for Humor and a Political Advantage
description: Opie and Anthony, a radio show originating in New York that once broadcast the sounds of two people reportedly having sex in St. Patricks Cathedral, did not take long to try to extract some humor from the massacre at Virginia Tech on Monday.

title: Orchestra and Violinist, Alternating at the Controls
description: Like so many works now secure in their public approval, Brahmss Violin Concerto was initially scorned after its premiere in 1879, with the conductor Hans von Blow supposedly declaring that it was not a concerto for violin, but rather one against the violin.

title: Some California Schools Close After Threat
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19  The police in Northern California were searching on Thursday for a man who they said told his family and a local pastor that he planned an attack that would make Virginia Tech look mild. Several schools were closed for the day and students were sent home as a precaution.

title: Defying a Clan Code of Silence on Unspeakable Crimes
description: RAMLA, Israel  The Abu Ghanem women are buried just inside the main gate of the old Muslim cemetery, eight in the last seven years.

title: Maluaka and the Cottages at Canoe Bay
description: Maluaka

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Doctors Try New Surgery for Gallbladder Removal
description: Doctors in New York have removed a womans gallbladder with instruments passed through her vagina, a technique they hope will cause less pain and scarring than the usual operation, and allow a quicker recovery. The technique can eliminate the need to cut through abdominal muscles, a major source of pain after surgery.

title: Isles Try to Put Close Calls and Noncalls Behind Them
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., April 19  Nassau Coliseum was empty at noon Thursday; the angry emotions 14 hours earlier had all but dissipated. The Islanders held what might be their last practice of the season, and the mood was businesslike and somber.

title: Chekhovian Characters Swirl to Rachmaninoff in a Glass-and-Steel Studio
description: It is not surprising that Boris Eifman chose not to set The Seagull in the late-19th-century Russia of the Chekhov play from which the ballet is drawn, though it is disappointing, given the beauty of the Eifman Ballets costumes and the extravagance of its sets. Mr. Eifman likes to turn tradition and the familiar on their heads. And so the new ballet, performed on Wednesday as the centerpiece of the Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburgs 30th-anniversary season at City Center, is set for the most part in a glass-and-steel ballet studio.

title: A Long Island Tribal Leaders Son Is Arrested, Suspected of Drug Sales in Reservation Store
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., April 19  For years, the Shinnecock Indian Outpost has been the face of the Shinnecock reservation, and its owner, Lance Gumbs, a familiar sight. Mr. Gumbs, a tribal leader, could often be seen in the store conducting tribal business by cellphone, while his son Awan, 26, ran the counter, selling tax-free cigarettes and American Indian gifts.

title: Albany: New Budget Math
description: If Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed a $120.6 billion budget, and the State Legislature added $1 billion in new spending before passing it, how big is the enacted budget? The official answer, according to a report issued yesterday by the states Budget Division, is $120.7 billion. The difference is due to the states re-estimating how much federal aid it will have on hand in the new fiscal year, which began on April 1.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Agencies Hear a Call for More Creativity, but Also More Accountability
description: NAPLES, Fla.

description: auto racing

title: A Brutal Passage From India to Misery at Sea, and Back
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Twenty-four Indian men, two of them too young to shave, were sitting under the fake palm trees in the transit zone at the Dubai airport, dressed in track suits like a sports team  but one dejected by loss.

title: Car Bombs, and Pain, Define a War With No Place to Hide
description: BAGHDAD, April 19  Rahid Sabah Abid, a 25-year-old shop owner, left work on Wednesday afternoon and began his homeward journey on a day that seemed then much like any other. He wended his way through the crowded streets of the Shorja market, then boarded one of the minibuses waiting in the Sadriya neighborhood to take him home to his wife and five daughters in nearby Sadr City.

title: Gaza Strip: Abbas Says Reporter Is Alive
description: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said his intelligence services had new information that confirmed that Alan Johnston, the BBC journalist kidnapped in Gaza City on March 12 and not seen since, is alive. Speaking to reporters in Stockholm, he also said he knew which group was holding Mr. Johnston.

title: As Usual, Jets Wont Reveal What Their Draft Plans Are
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., April 19  During the Jets predraft news conference Thursday, Terry Bradway, their director of player personnel, boasted about the teams extensive vetting process. The Jets wrote more than 5,000 scouting reports, evaluated more than 1,000 prospects, conducted more than 200 interviews and had 34 players work out at their practice facility.

title: The Long Hot Summer and the More Perfect Union
description: As delegates to the Constitutional Convention of 1787 put their signatures to the document that would become the charter of the infant nation, Benjamin Franklin pointed to the carving of a sun on the back of George Washingtons chair and observed that he had often looked at the carving without being able to tell whether it was rising or setting. With months of often contentious debate behind them and the Constitution finally assented to by the delegates, however, Franklin pronounced his satisfaction, declaring that he now had the happiness to know that it is a rising and not a setting sun. After all, the delegates had succeeded, with just a few thousand words, in inventing a new form of government that would prove stable enough and flexible enough to sustain the nation  and its liberties  through more than two centuries of social and political change.

title: Experts Shy From Instant Diagnoses of Gunmans Mental Illness, but Hints Abound
description: The video testament that Cho Seung-Hui mailed to NBC during the intermission in his killing spree offers a compelling peek into the troubles that shaped a gunman, experts in forensic psychology say.

title: In Wishing Corzine Well, Sympathy Is Mixed With Resentment
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., April 19  The regulars at Frankie & Johnnies Steakhouse have been asking every night about Gov. Jon S. Corzine, who before last weeks traffic accident would hunker down with a slab of sirloin at the gleaming cherry-wood bar, parked elbow to elbow with his friends and neighbors.

title: Manhattan: Rape Suspect Identified
description: The police last night released the name of a man suspected in the rape of a 23-year-old Columbia University graduate student over the weekend. The man, left, was identified as William Roberts, 30, and a police photo of him was posted on fliers on the Columbia campus, and sent in e-mail messages to students, teachers and staff members. Mr. Roberts was identified through investigative work and tips, the police said. They would not say if he had a criminal record, but The Associated Press reported that he had convictions for attempted murder and assault. On Saturday, the student was forced into her Hamilton Heights apartment by a man who had followed her from the elevator of her building, according to the police. He raped and assaulted her for the next 19 hours, and before leaving, tied her to a piece of furniture and set a fire, the police said. She managed to escape. The police ask anyone with information to call 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477).

description: FOR CHILDREN

description: DANCE

title: World Bank Board to Decide Wolfowitzs Fate
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The World Banks board of directors expressed great concern today about the mounting furor over the charges of favoritism now dogging the leadership of Paul D. Wolfowitz. But the board put off until next week the rendering of a judgment that could force Mr. Wolfowitz to resign as president of the bank.

title: Former Judge Is Convicted of Bribery in Divorce Court
description: A former State Supreme Court judge was convicted yesterday of accepting bribes to manipulate the outcome of divorce proceedings in a case that led to a broad political and judicial corruption inquiry in Brooklyn.

title: Style and Vision Close Out French Campaign
description: PARIS, April 19  Nicolas Sarkozy, the conservative candidate and front-runner for president, evoked his immigrant roots and quoted Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Krcher Reminds French: We Clean Dirt, Not Ghettos
description: PARIS, April 19  There is one French company that is tired of free publicity.

title: Healing 27-Year Rift, Yonkers Settles a Fight Over Housing Segregation
description: YONKERS, April 19  After 27 years of contentious court battles over housing segregation, this citys mayor, Philip A. Amicone, and Herman Keith, a former president of the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter, shared cigars on Thursday as they celebrated the settlement of a lawsuit that had pitted neighbor against neighbor in bitter protests.

title: Hip, Hip Poiret
description:
The king of fashion is dead. Long live the king of
fashion.

title: Modesty at the El Dorado
description: Franoise Bollack and Tom Killian have lived together for almost 30 years  about half of them in an apartment at the El Dorado. Their goal: to inhabit a room without decorating it.

title: But Will it Hurt the Economy?
description: Many countries are fretting the going green and, particularly, curbing greenhouse emissions, will unduly hurt their economic growth. On the other hand, the Stern Report (released in the UK last December) concluded that if the world does not effectively curb emissions it could lead to an economic downturn that would rival the Great Depression.

title: Pulse: Hot and Cool
description: Swamp thing? No, salon thing, Truman and Minhee Cho, the graphic designers, the new skull and bones trunks and more.

description: Mourners from Colorado to Israel remembered the 32 victims killed on the campus of Virginia Tech.

Spidey Swings to Broadway
description: The adventures of Spider-Man have graced comic books, cartoons and live-action films. Now Peter Parker's tale of great power and great responsibility is being developed for the Great White Way.

title: A Celebration of Culture
description: Images from the Museo Alameda in San Antonio.

title: Michael R. Bloomberg
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire founder of Bloomberg L.P., who spent $74 million of his own money in 2001 to gain an office few thought he could win and $85 million more in 2005 to keep it, has become a singular figure in American politics. A nominal Republican who blends a liberal outlook on many social issues with bottom-line pragmatism developed in the private sector, Mr. Bloomberg is frequently mentioned as a potential presidential candidate for 2008 - a notion he generally dismisses but his aides continue to promote.

title: J.P. Morgan Adds Another Financial Institutions Banker
description: J.P. Morgan Chase has hired former UBS investment banker Joe Jiampietro, marking the latest addition to its financial institutions group. Mr. Jiampietro will join J.P. Morgan in July as a managing director in its banks coverage team, the firm said in an internal memo. Earlier this month, J.P. Morgan recruited Tod Perkins, formerly of HSBC Securities, as a managing director in its financial institutions group. The firm also recently brought in Eric Warmstein, who previously worked at UBS, for the financial institutions group as well.

title: Buyout Firms in $22 Billion Battle for Alliance Boots
description: Two giants of the private equity business are vying to acquire Alliance Boots in what would be Europes largest leveraged buyout ever. Hours after Alliance Boots, the No. 1 drugstore chain in the United Kingdom, agreed to be taken private by its deputy chairman and New York-based Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Terra Firma Capital Partners, the investment firm run by the British financier Guy Hands, raised its bid for the company to about 10.9 billion pounds ($21.8 billion) in hopes of trumping their offer.

title: Metabolex Pumps V.C.s for $32 Million
description: Diabetes drug developer Metabolex parlayed a strong partnership with Johnson & Johnson and promising early clinical data on its lead compound into a $32 million Series D round of venture capital from crossover investors, which could position the company for a public offering as soon as next year.

title: Changes at Fidelity Stir Succession Speculation
description: Fidelity Investments said Thursday that one of its top executives was retiring amid a broader reorganization in the upper ranks, leaving unanswered the question of who will succeed 76-year-old Edward C. Johnson III as chairman and chief executive at the mutual fund company. But outsiders say the departure of the executive, Robert L. Reynolds, from the company known for its insularity leaves two women as the likeliest candidates to eventually succeed Mr. Johnson at Fidelity, which has $1.4 trillion in managed assets.

title: R.I.M. Offers a Reason for BlackBerry Failure
description: Research in Motion on Thursday offered its first explanation for why more than five million users of its BlackBerry device in North America were unexpectedly cut off from their service this week. The company said that the installation of an insufficiently tested piece of software set off a chain reaction that eventually left its customers, analysts and journalists guessing about what had gone so wrong.

title: Googles DoubleClick Deal Raises Competition Questions
description: Googles proposed $3.1 billion acquisition of online advertising service DoubleClick may alienate some of DoubleClicks clients, who may fear that its new owners will end up competing with them, Forbes.com reported. DoubleClicks privacy issues could also resurface if it joined with Google, a privacy advocate said.

title: Location, location, location
description: They say location is everything when it comes to real estate. And few locations are better than Londons Hyde Park.

title: A Spanish Eiffel Tower?
description: Sacyr Vallehermoso, a Spanish construction company, bid 9.75 billion euros ($13.26 billion) to take over Eiffage of France, a diversified construction company that built the Eiffel Tower, setting the stage for a cross-border struggle for control of the company. The bid came less than 24 hours after a shareholders meeting where Eiffage blocked Sacyrs request for seats on its board, even though Sacyr holds a 33 percent stake. Sacyr offered 12 of its shares for every five of Eiffage, valuing the stock at 104.69 euros, a 6 percent discount to its closing price Wednesday.

title: Chairman of Siemens Resigns
description: The corruption scandals at Siemens, the German industrial giant, claimed one of the nations most prominent industrialists late Thursday, as the company said its chairman, Heinrich von Pierer, would resign next week. In a statement, Mr. von Pierer said that he was leaving out of a duty to Siemens and its more than 400,000 employees, not because of any involvement in the accusations of bribery that have roiled the company.

title: Owners Lose and Bosses Win in Bad Mergers
description: New academic research offers insights into how equity-based incentives  stock options and restricted stocks  that were supposed to make managers think like owners have instead encouraged them to overpay for acquisitions. According to The New York Timess Floyd Norris, the bosses win, whether or not the owners lose.

title: Ex-Chief at Qwest Found Guilty of Insider Trading
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive who transformed Qwest Communications International into a major telecommunications rival, was convicted Thursday of insider trading.

title: MetroPCS Climbs 19% in First Day of Trading
description: Shares of MetroPCS, whose all-you-can-talk business model provides low-cost cell phone service, bolted out of the gate Thursday in the first billion-dollar initial public offering of 2007.After raising $1.15 billion by selling 50 million shares for $23 each, above the expected $19 to $21 range, stock in the Dallas-based company climbed $4.35, or 19 percent, at $27.35 on the first day of trading on the public markets.

title: Apax Wont Tie Knot With Adidas, Report Says
description: Shares of Adidas/strong>, the worlds second-largest sporting goods maker, fell after AFX News said a private equity group wont bid for a stake in the company. Adidas shares had risen earlier after the Financial Times Deutschland newspaper reported that Apax Partners Worldwide was considering buying a 25 percent stake in the maker of athletic shoes and apparel.

title: Banks Close to Signing Off on European Derivatives Pact
description: Morgan Stanley is poised to sign an agreement with Citigroup, Goldman Sachs Group and JPMorgan Chase on rules for trading loan derivatives in Europe that may triple the $8 billion market within a year.

title: Airvana Files for I.P.O.
description: Mobile broadband technology start-up Airvana on Thursday filed to raise as much as $75 million in a proposed initial public offering. The maker of hardware and software for high-speed networks is backed by Qualcomm, Matrix Partners, Commvest, and Sycamore Networks Chairman Gururaj Deshpande.

title: Superior Offshore I.P.O. On Deck
description: Superior Offshore is on deck to raise about $130 million in its initial public offering on Friday as the underwater oil and gas services firm draws backing from Wall Street. As solar, ethanol and other alternative energy deals have made their mark in the I.P.O. market in recent months, theyve been joined by a steady stream of deals from companies tied to the fossil fuel businesses.

title: ABN Amro Agrees to Meet with New Suitors
description: A consortium of banks on Thursday accepted an invitation to hold merger talks with ABN Amro next week, even though the Dutch bank by then may have recommended a pact with Barclays to form the worlds fifth-largest bank.

title: A Day to Remember
description: Stores in Virginia were selling out of maroon and orange as Hokie Hope Day sent non-Hokies searching for the school colors of Virginia Tech.

title: Union Eyes Bid for Part of Chrysler, Report Says
description: The United Auto Workers union is considering a proposal to seek a majority stake in DaimlerChryslers Chrysler Group in return for cost concessions, the Wall Street Journal reported. The proposal, first floated by a small group of workers, would entail swapping cuts in healthcare benefits and other cost concessions, according to the report.

title: J.P. Morgan Official Withdraws from Treasury Nomination
description: JPMorgan Chase executive Timothy Ryan has withdrawn from consideration to become the U.S. Treasury Departments top international official, the White House said on Thursday. He withdrew himself from this opportunity for personal reasons, White House spokesman Tony Fratto told Reuters.

title: CBOT Reports Upturn in 1Q Earnings
description: Chicago Board of Trade parent CBOT Holdings, which is the subject of a takeover battle, reported a 58 percent jump in first-quarter earnings, on a 34 percent upturn in revenues. Net income at the Chicago futures exchange came in at $55.4 million, compared with the $35.1 million the company posted during the same period last year. Revenues were $187.7 million, up from $140.1 million, reflecting record trading volume and higher average exchange fee rates, the company noted.

title: Hedge Fund Blasts Topps Deal, Again
description: Hoping to convince Toppss shareholders that its current $385.4 million acquisition agreement is inadequate, board member Arnaud Ajdler on Thursday blasted the maker of trading cards and Bazooka bubblegum for selling the company low and not pursuing negotiations with another potential suitor.

title: AMC I.P.O. Could Net Windfall for Owners
description: Movie theater chain AMC Entertainment Inc. set a price range for its planned initial public offering that would yield hefty investment gains to the five private equity firms that control it. AMC, based in Kansas City, Mo., said it expects to offer 39.47 million shares priced between $18 to $20 a share. Assuming a price of $19 a share, the midpoint of the anticipated price range, AMC will have an initial market cap of $2.8 billion.

title: Active Hedge Funds Create New Wealth for Law Firms
description: For corporate lawyers of a certain age, it seems like the 1980s all over again. Proxy fights, once the exclusive domain of investors like Carl C. Icahn, are on the rise. The primary cause, says The New York Times, is easy to spot: The resurgence of shareholder activism is a direct result of the growth of hedge funds, Marc Weingarten, a partner at law firm Schulte Roth & Zabel, told The Times.

title: Merrill Goes for Summit in Hollywood
description: As outside financing from the likes of investment banks, private equity firms and hedge funds continues to wash over Hollywood, Merrill Lynch is aggressively vying for some marquee deals in Tinsel Town.

title: Hachette Gets Jumpstart
description: Hachette Filipacchi Media, owner of auto buff magazines Car and Driver and Road & Track, has agreed to buy Internet ad company Jumpstart Automotive Media for a price that could reach $110 million. The deal includes $84 million in cash and up to $26 million in future payments.

title: H&R Block to Sell Lending Unit
description: H&R Block said Friday that it found a buyer for its subprime lending unit, Option One Mortgage. An affiliate of Cerberus Capital Management will pay a price equal to the value of the tangible net assets less $300 million, or about $970 million. The deal comes amid an increase in defaults among subprime mortgage loans, which are loans made to people with weak credit histories. Cerberus, a hedge fund and private equity firm, is getting the unit at a discount, but some analysts expressed relief Friday that H&R Block was able to unload the unit at all.

title: A Tilt in Wall Streets Pursuit of Private Equity
description: As big private equity firms increasingly begin to resemble Wall Street investment banks  the Blackstone Group is advising on corporate deals and bankruptcy restructurings and that Bain Capital is a major middle-market lender  Wall Street investment banks are looking more and more like private equity shops.

title: Looking for Oil
description: Increasing violence has rippled across energy markets, contributing to higher prices and tighter supplies.

title: 2008: Star Struck and Windswept
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has Jerry Springer. Senator Barack Obama has Tobey Maguire and Rudolph W. Giuliani has Jenny Craig, the weight loss guru (clearly a coup over Mike Huckabee). Forbes has more on which celebrities donated to presidential candidates.

title: A Thompson Trips in the Money Jungle
description: Is one of the Thompson Twins already out of the running for the Republican nomination for president in 2008? Tommy Thompson, a former health and human services secretary and Wisconsin governor, pretty much spiked his presidential chances when he told an audience at Washingtons Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism, Im in the private sector, and for the first time in my life Im earning money. You know, thats sort of part of the Jewish tradition, and I do not find anything wrong with that. The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel editorial page says, His remarks about Jewish people and tradition Monday revealed him simply to be ill-suited to the presidency.

title: On the Hill: A Procedural Chess Match
description: In his Web-only column today, The Timess Carl Hulse writes about how Republicans, in the effort to reclaim their majority next year, have been loading once mundane opposition motions with all sorts of political bombs, which they are then unleashing in press releases to local newspapers, on a special Web site and  presumably  in future 30-second campaign adds. To hear Republicans tell it, some of the most politically vulnerable Democrats in the House have cast eye-popping votes in the opening months of their service in Congress, writes Mr. Hulse. Go to Column.

title: Faith Trumps a Contract
description: We knew that contract negotiations with Greg, our architect, werent going well when he threatened to fire us.

title: The Price of a Break-Up in a Clear Channel Deal
description: Though most analysts are focusing on whether Clear Channel Communicationss shareholders will even accept the $27 billion buyout on the table, the New York Post points out another (and relatively lesser) issue. Should the radio network giant break off its agreement with Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital for another suitor, the company will pay a $200 million breakup fee.

title: Would You Have Walked A-Rod?
description: As soon as Joe Borowskis wild first pitch to Alex Rodriguez pushed the Yankees runners to second and third in the ninth inning on Thursday, I turned to Mike Vaccaro of The New York Post and said, Theyre going to walk him now.

title: Congestion Pricing: A Long, Winding Road
description: Undoubtedly, if Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg carries through on a proposal to bring congestion pricing to Manhattan, as reported by Diane Cardwell and Charles V. Bagli today - he will be taking on one of the most politically combustible issues in the five boroughs. (In his radio remarks this morning, he left little doubt that he plans to forge ahead.)

title: For Gonzales, a Post-Panel Pile-On
description: Has there ever been a worse-reviewed appearance before a Congressional panel than Attorney General Alberto Gonzaless testimony yesterday before the Senate Judiciary Committee? By early afternoon, National Review White House correspondent Byron York had given up hope that Gonzales could salvage his reputation. Calling it a disastrous morning, York wrote:

title: All Amped Up
description: I took my first ride in the Tesla Roadster on Thursday  in Manhattan, not the best environment to test its claimed 4-second blast from 0-60 m.p.h. As an auto reviewer, I usually reject an offer to ride shotgun only. But I couldnt resist the lure of this battery powered, Silicon Valley-bred offshoot of the Lotus Elise, one of my favorite wildly impractical sports cars.

title: Lighting New York's Tallest
description: Two companies are competing to bring 21st century illumination to the Empire State Building.

title: Clear Channel to Sell TV Stations to Providence Equity
description: As it tries to convince shareholders to approve a $27 billion buyout offer, Clear Channel Communications said on Friday it will sell its television group to Providence Equity Partners for about $1.2 billion. The radio giant also said it will sell 161 radio stations, all in smaller markets, to undisclosed buyers for $331 million.

title: Can a Landlord Ask for Personal Information?
description: Q I have been asked to submit an affidavit giving the names and relationship of everyone who lives in my apartment. Not only does this seem unusual, since I have never been asked for this before, but they also want my Social Security number. Must I submit this information if I am a rent-stabilized tenant?

description: Images from some of the films screening at this year's Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Bloomberg: Its Called Capitalism
description: On his weekly radio appearance on WABC this morning [listen], Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spoke hypothetically about the congestion pricing proposal he is all but assured to announce on Sunday. One plan under consideration would charge drivers $8 to enter the busiest parts of Manhattan during the workweek as a way to reduce traffic and air pollution.

description: Joseph P. Nacchio can be a very persuasive man. Perhaps his lawyers should have taken a chance on putting him on the stand.

title: A Pollyanna View

title: Dont Worry About the Yield Curve
description: Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.  A factor that pessimists cite in saying a recession is likely is the inverted yield curve, meaning that long-term interest rates are lower than short-term rates.

description: American forces, struggling to improve security in Baghdad, are turning to an approach with a 4,500-year history in the region: They are building a three-mile wall around the heavily Sunni neighborhood of Adhamiya.

description: A few days ago I drove a Citron 2CV for the first time, and it turned my world upside down.

description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans April 20 column, Patient Capital for an Africa That Cant Wait.

title: An Open Door to Financial-Services L.B.O.s?
description: Until the announcement that a group of banks and buyout firms would take student-loan giant Sallie Mae private, the conventional wisdom was that the debt loads that come with buyouts meant that big financial services companies, which generally are already debt-laden and subject to regulatory scrutiny, couldnt be targets.

title: Clinton Applauds Rutgers Womens Team
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  In a speech at Rutgers University, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton today urged students to stand against cultural norms that she said marginalize or demean women, racial minorities, those of different sexual orientation or other social groups outside the mainstream.

title: Do Home Runs Matter for the Mets?
description: The Mets enter tonights game against Atlanta leading the major leagues in batting average (.303), hits (150), slugging percentage (.459), on-base percentage (.378) and stolen bases (16), and they lead the National League with 87 runs. Three regulars  Carlos Beltran, Jose Reyes and Moises Alou  are batting over .350. So, things are going pretty well for them at the plate.

title: G7 Report Is Said to Call for More Hedge Fund Disclosure
description: Despite efforts to soften their image abroad, hedge funds still have not made many friends among many governments worldwide. In fact, a report by central bankers and finance ministers from the Group of Seven leading nations will urge the funds towards greater disclosure of their strategies and risks, according to Bloomberg News, which obtained a draft copy.

title: To Solve a Cricket Murder
description: Law and Order is going to have a hard time boiling this one down to an hour.

title: Clinton Slams Bush Before Sharptons Group
description: Appealing for black and female votes this afternoon in remarks to the Rev. Al Sharptons political organization, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was full of personal touches: Using housecleaning imagery to swipe at President Bush, criticizing Don Imuss demeaning treatment of the Rutgers womens basketball team, and adopting the southern-fried lilt of a preacher at times.

title: Roll, Skate, Bounce
description: Brooklyn skaters share their memories of the Empire Roller Skating Center, which has been sold and will be closed.

title: Vows: Amanda and Mark
description: Amanda Cody and Mark Donohue met at a friend's Halloween party and have been together ever since.

title: A Killers Media Wish Fulfilled
description: Every day in my Oral Traditions of Musicianship class, before the rigorous business of learning begins, we go around the room and each of us shares with the class how we are feeling on a scale of 1 to 10. If youre a 1, that means youre unconscious and hooked up to a machine that is propelling you through life. If youre a 10, youre so elated you could levitate. (If youre bold enough to claim you are a 10, you actually have to lie down on the floor and prove to the class that you can float. We havent seen any successful 10s yet.)

title: Corzine Is Taken Off Ventilator
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine was taken off the ventilator he has been relying on to breathe for more than a week Friday afternoon, though doctors warned he might need the breathing tube reinserted depending on his pain levels and other potential complications.In a brief written statement issued after 5 p.m., Mr. Corzines staff said he had been on the ventilator since 12:25 p.m. and breathing on his own since. His doctors were not quoted in the statement, nor did they appear at Cooper University Hospital here to answer questions from reporters. They have given few details about the governors condition or treatment during the week he has spent in their intensive care unit.

title: Attitude Off the Beaten Track
description: A recent visit to a widely heralded, highly regarded place for cheese steaks in Philadelphia ended up being more than an opportunity to eat a too-heavy lunch and check out the sandwiches for myself.

title: A-Rods Historic Start
description: Greetings from Fenway Park, where the Dunkin Donuts sign is now written in Japanese, but the sausages still smell terrific.

title: Airfare Cost Depends on Where You Buy
description: Are there differences in the price of air tickets depending on which country a ticket is issued? For example, if I fly from the United States to Japan, will it be cheaper to buy the tickets there rather than in the U.S.?

title: Blogtalk: Harry Reid and the Lost War
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader, told reporters, his fellow senators and President Bush himself that the war in Iraq is lost, prompting loud objections from conservative lawmakers and politicians. (And from the White House, which issued a series of statements today that had been made by Mr. Reid, block by block, against statements made by Mr. Bush and General David Petraeus. Naturally, bloggers joined the fray.

title: Bad Hair Days for Edwards
description: John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat, told reporters in Iowa that he was embarrassed over the disclosure that he had paid $800 on two haircuts while in California earlier this month.

title: Branca on Hand to Honor Robinson
description: As Alex Rodriguez was belting home runs in Boston, another man linked to homers was belting his voice at Shea Stadium on Friday night. Ralph Branca, the Dodgers pitcher on the mound when Bobby Thompson smashed his infamous Shot Heard Round the World homerun to win the 1951 pennant for the Giants, sang God Bless America before the bottom of the seventh inning. Branca was the only former Dodger teammate of Jackie Robinsons on hand as the Mets honored Robinsons 60th anniversary of breaking the color barrier in baseball. Branca is clearly not a professional singer but managed to hold the songs tune.

title: Voyage to the Bottom of the League
description: THE Boston Celtics are one of the most storied franchises in all of sport and, more to the point, a multimillion-dollar operation. They sell tickets, they license merchandise, they serve as a cultural touchstone in one of our countrys most historic and thriving cities. This season, the Celtics paid 12 tall men a total of nearly $63 million to run up and down a court for 48 minutes two or three nights a week for six months and, theoretically, entertain us.

title: Rodriguez Adds to Hot Streak, but Rivera Lets Lead Slip Away
description: BOSTON, April 20  In the breezy days of spring training, the plan seemed so logical to Yankees Manager Joe Torre. His indispensable closer, Mariano Rivera, would be restricted to one inning in 2007. It was better, Torre reasoned, to be careful with an elbow that was fragile last September.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the angry writings of Seung-Hui Cho, who went on a shooting rampage at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, misspelled the surname of a novelist whose books were among those he studied in a class on contemporary horror films and literature. She is Patricia Cornwell, not Cornwall.

title: F.B.I. Names New Leader for Its Office in Newark
description: NEWARK, April 20  The F.B.I. has named Weysan Dun, a 25-year bureau veteran with experience in the Midwest and Washington, to lead the agencys Newark office.

title: U.S. Database Exposed Social Security Numbers
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Agriculture Department for years publicly listed Social Security numbers of tens of thousands of people who received financial aid from two of its agencies, raising concerns about identity theft and other privacy violations.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about universities limited options in dealing with mentally ill students misidentified a university that requires four counseling sessions after suicide attempts. It is the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, not the University of Missouri.

title: Man Is Arrested in Torture of Student at Columbia
description: A 30-year-old ex-convict was charged yesterday in the rape and torture of a Columbia University journalism school graduate student last week.

title: The Attorney Generals Memory (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 10 P.M. (BBC America) WILD AT HEART  Goodbye, city life! When Danny Trevanion (Stephen Tompkinson), an English veterinarian, saves the life of a monkey smuggled illegally into Britain, his new wife, Sarah (Amanda Holden), decides that they and their children  his teenage daughter, Rosie (Lucy-Jo Hudson), and Sarahs 8-year-old daughter, Olivia (Rafaella Hutchinson), and 13-year-old son, Evan (Luke Ward-Wilkinson)  should travel to South Africa to return the monkey to its natural habitat, and, with luck, bond as a family along the way. (Above, from left, Ms. Holden, Ms. Hutchinson and Ms. Hudson.) But that charmingly decrepit game reserve is just too tempting to leave behind. The six-episode first season of this new series follows the Trevanions as they rumble in the jungle.

title: Manhattan: Atlantic Yards Can Proceed
description: A State Supreme Court justice declined yesterday to issue a restraining order temporarily halting the demolition of nine vacant buildings to make way for the Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn. The restraining order had been requested by Develop Dont Destroy Brooklyn, which opposes the scale of the 22-acre project that is to encompass housing, office and retail space and a basketball arena. The group had argued that the developer, Forest City Ratner, should not be allowed to begin demolishing buildings before May 3, the date of a hearing on a lawsuit challenging the states environmental review and approval of the project. Justice Joan Madden said that the plaintiffs had failed to substantiate their argument that the demolition would irrevocably harm the neighborhood, but that she was not judging the suits merits.

title: Why Not Tax the Tall?
description: TALL people should pay more in taxes than short people, a Harvard economics professor, N. Gregory Mankiw, and his student, Matthew Weinzierl, argue in a paper published last week (gregmankiw.blogspot.com)

title: A Growing Buddhist Population Tests the Neighborliness of a City
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind.  The newest Buddhist temple here is a vinyl-sided house on the edge of the prairie. Worship services are so popular that people who arrive late must squeeze into the two-car garage, kneel on the concrete floor and pray between a golden statue of a smiling Buddha and a black Craftsman riding lawnmower.

title: When Money and Marriage Collide
description: NOBODY tells you what a big, unruly role money will play in your marriage.

title: Randolph Honored to Wear No. 42
description: While most teams honored Jackie Robinsons memory by wearing his No. 42 jersey last Sunday, on the 60th anniversary of him breaking baseballs color barrier, Willie Randolph could only watch and wait. The Mets Jackie Robinson Day festivities, postponed because of rain, were rescheduled for last night, and Randolph finally wore No. 42. Five days later, it was sweeter than he had imagined.

title: Adventures in a Gray Lam Electrified Jacket
description: I MARCHED into battle with my electrified mask and saber in hand, trying to summon the spirit of Zorro. I was in a cavernous space on the fifth floor of an office building in Chelsea that houses the Fencers Club, the august capital of American swordsmanship. Having taken just one lesson, I was about to engage in my first fencing bout.

title: World Bank to Broaden Its Inquiry Into Wolfowitz
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The World Banks board of directors expressed great concern on Friday about the furor over Paul D. Wolfowitzs leadership as president, and they said their inquiry into his conduct would extend beyond the allegations of favoritism shown to his female companion at the bank.

title: Colleges Relying on Lenders to Counsel Students
description: Rachel Jones, a senior at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, recently was sitting through a student-loan workshop that university officials had told her was mandatory when an uneasy feeling kicked in.

title: Pentagon Invites Kremlin to Link Missile Systems
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Bush administration is offering Russia a new package of incentives to drop its strong opposition to American missile defense sites in Poland and the Czech Republic, including an invitation to begin linking some American and Russian antimissile systems, according to senior administration and military officials.

title: Dont Give Up on Iraq (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pushing Co-ops to Explain Why You Cant Buy
description: Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers live in the rough equivalent of private clubs  co-op apartment houses with rules that govern everything from admission to elevator-landing dcor. In certain circles, the co-op-application-process horror story is as much a dinner-party clich as the renovation-nightmare saga, the nursery-school-rejection narrative and indignation over excess packaging of food from Fresh Direct.

title: A Procedural Chess Match
description: To hear Republicans tell it, some of the most politically vulnerable Democrats in the House have cast eye-popping votes in the opening months of their service in Congress.

title: Still Soulful, Still Swinging, Still Ready to Bust Loose
description: In a sharp suit, black fedora and sunglasses, with a gold tooth glinting and a well-traveled guitar in his hands, Chuck Brown, 72, was the image of a classic bluesman leading his band at Joes Pub on Thursday night. But he wasnt playing the blues: he was playing go-go, the dance-club music from Washington that has survived long enough to be a tradition of its own.

title: 2008 Democrats Propose a Ceiling on Bush Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Grappling with one of the biggest domestic policy choices that will confront the next administration, the leading Democratic presidential candidates say they would raise a variety of taxes on affluent people but extend President Bushs tax cuts for middle- and lower-income families.

description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Banksy Be Gone

title: Following Jordans Footsteps, but Strictly on His Own Terms
description: Before he chose to play in the game that bears his surname, Jeffrey Jordan spoke to his father, Michael. He wanted to be sure, he said, that this was not mere nepotism, and that he truly belonged on the court tonight at the Jordan Brand All-American Classic, a high school all-star game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Spey Rod Is Long-Range Weapon in Anglers Arsenal
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Steelhead trout, like Atlantic salmon, have been described as the fish of a thousand casts. On the larger steelhead rivers of the Pacific Northwest  the Skagit and Bulkley, among others  hooking a steelhead on a fly may require a thousand very long casts. After all, the longer your cast, the more water you can cover and the better chance you have of a fish seeing your fly.

title: New York Post to Double Newsstand Price
description: The New York Post is doubling its street sale price, to 50 cents from 25 cents.

title: Fears of Fraud Grow Before Nigerian Vote
description: KANO, Nigeria, April 20  An opposition party claimed Friday that soldiers in northern Nigeria had seized a truckload of ballots that had already been filled out in favor of the governing partys presidential candidate, raising fears that Nigerias presidential election on Saturday would be marred by the same kinds of irregularities that plagued state elections last week.

title: She Crashes the Boys Club, Leaving Her Mark
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20  When Doug Ellin was considering whom to cast in the role of Vinces new agent on the HBO hit Entourage, he realized that he had several tall orders to fill.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts last Saturday about the architect Jean Nouvels design for the new Philharmonie de Paris concert hall misstated the year in which his concert hall in Lucerne, Switzerland, opened. It was 1998, not 2000.

title: Devils Benefit From Brodeurs Return to Form
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 20  Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur often had to drop to the ice Friday night, collecting snow on the seat of his black shorts while making one big save after another. The Tampa Bay Lightning made him scramble again.

title: India Debates Its Right to Nuclear Testing
description: NEW DELHI, April 20  A nuclear accord hailed as the centerpiece of Indias deepening friendship with the United States appears to be in jeopardy, as Indian officials argue about whether its limitations on their nuclear activities offend the countrys sense of sovereignty.

title: Gunman Kills NASA Worker and Himself
description: HOUSTON, April 20  A contract worker brandishing a revolver took control of part of a Johnson Space Center building on Friday afternoon, and killed a hostage and then himself after a standoff with the police.

title: Labor Rights Issues Are Stalling Trade Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Hopes for a bipartisan agreement between the Bush administration and Congress leading to approval of several pending trade pacts have dissolved in a burst of charges and countercharges over the issue of labor rights.

title: Andrew Hill, 75, Jazz Artist Known for His Daring Style, Dies
description: Andrew Hill, a pianist and composer of highly original and sometimes opaquely inner-dwelling jazz whose work only recently found a wide audience, died yesterday at his home in Jersey City. He was 75.

title: Health Inspector Calls and Chefs Pride Cracks
description: It was 11:59 a.m., according to the report from the citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. The first lunch reservations at Brasserie La Cte Basque, just off Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, were about to arrive. The inspector introduced himself to the hostess and headed straight for the kitchen, where he found Jean-Jacques Rachou, the restaurants owner and chef, at the stove.

title: Running With Scissors
description: WASHINGTON

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article last Saturday about Jackie Robinson misidentified the birthplace of a teammate, Eddie Stanky. He was born in Philadelphia, not Alabama. The article also misspelled the surname of a Boston Brave. He was Earl Torgeson, not Torgenson.

An article by The Associated Press in some copies last Saturday about the discovery of a mans body under a pile of debris in a home in Woodmere, N.Y., included a quotation about the incident from a man who identified himself as Erik Kinney, a volunteer firefighter. Mr. Kinney has told The A.P. that he never spoke to a reporter, and the news agency says it does not know who at the fire station identified himself as Mr. Kinney.

title: After Surviving Scare, a Texas A&M Second Baseman Has No Fears
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., April 20 (AP)  Parker Dalton studied the faces in the crowded room and nearly burst into tears.

title: A Taliban Leader in Pakistan Says He Would Aid bin Laden
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 20  A Pakistani Taliban leader who has been waging a government-backed campaign to evict Central Asian militants from Pakistans tribal regions said Friday that he would give Osama bin Laden protection in his area if he sought it.

title: China Adds Billionaires With I.P.O.
description: SHANGHAI, April 20  The 52-year-old Chinese farmer turned developer is as plain as the companys English name: Country Garden. But there was nothing ordinary about his companys debut Friday on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

title: Vatican City: Pope Closes Limbo
description: The netherworld of limbo, long speculated in Roman Catholic teaching as the destination of babies who die unbaptized, has been replaced with the prayerful hope that they reach heaven. Pope Benedict XVI signed a theological report, years in the making, that effectively demoted limbo, a place neither in heaven nor in hell, where unbaptized babies would not be in communion with God but would nonetheless enjoy eternal happiness. Many in the church felt the idea, never formally a part of church doctrine, was outdated and caused undue worry for parents.

title: Trenton: Increase in Civil Union Requests
description: The number of applications from same-sex couples seeking licenses for civil unions increased in the second month that they were available, the state reported yesterday. According to figures released by the state health department, 373 couples applied in the period from March 20 to April 20, up from 229 in the first month after the civil union law went into effect on Feb. 19. Despite the increase, the number of applicants still lags behind the number of same-sex couples who applied for domestic partnerships in 2004, when that option became available and 1,700 couples signed up in the first month alone. Of the 373 same-sex couples who applied in the last month, 17 said that they had equivalent partnerships in other states or Canada. Compiled by Karin Roberts

title: The Democrats Base (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota to Increase Imports to Meet Demand for Prius
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 20  The Toyota Motor Company will sell more imported vehicles in the United States this year, Toyota officials acknowledged Friday, even though the company has begun building Camry sedans at a Subaru plant here to replace those built in Japan.

title: Key Verdict Does Not End Corruption Inquiry
description: Four years ago, the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, turned against the single-party system he had navigated for decades, vowing to prove that seats of power at the courthouse were bought and sold for envelopes full of cash.

title: Bombings Leave Moroccans Both Worried and Confused
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco, April 20  In just over a month, six young men have blown themselves up in Morocco, causing intense worry in a nation that has largely escaped local terrorism.

title: China Surges, BlackBerries Fail and Sallie Gets Suitors
description: BLACKBERRY users thumbs were idle; private equity investors got a thumbs up from Sallie Mae; and a jury turned thumbs down on Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest.

title: After Four-Day Delay, Wind Returns and the Louis Vuitton Cup Begins
description: VALENCIA, Spain, April 20 The Americas Cup lifted itself out of the doldrums Friday as some of the worlds fastest yachts finally began racing after four days of delays because of a lack of wind.

title: Student Lender Discloses Ties to Colleges That Included Gifts to Officials
description: Nelnet, a major student loan company, yesterday offered a broad accounting of many often unpublicized relationships it has established with universities and their senior officials, including managing telephone call centers, paying college officials for speaking engagements and giving plane tickets to financial aid officers.

title: A Brief Walk Through Time at Scholastic
description: Wandering through the headquarters of Scholastic in Manhattan is like taking a trip back through time and childish dreams, to a fantastical kindergarten with brightly colored columns and desk dividers and, at the very end, a huge playroom filled with toys like Clifford the Big Red Dog and Goosebumps and Captain Underpants and, of course, J. K. Rowlings books about Harry Potter and his comrades.

title: Good News for Sad Songs: Hits Dont Need Happiness
description: Patty Griffin cheerfully admitted during her set at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night that she doesnt write many happy songs. Hardly any, in fact. Her folk-rock strummers and countryish waltzes are full of lonely travels and painful separations, of forebodings and sad memories.

title: Fish-Killing Virus Spreading in the Great Lakes
description: CHICAGO, April 20  A virus that has already killed tens of thousands of fish in the eastern Great Lakes is spreading, scientists said, and now threatens almost two dozen aquatic species over a wide swath of the lakes and nearby waterways.

title: To Help Housing, Official Urges Development of Vacant Spaces
description: In a steaming real estate market with a growing shortage of low-cost housing, the Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, intends today to urge the city to encourage the development of vacant or partially vacant properties through regular surveys and tax incentives.

title: Germany: U.S. Cites Threat and Increases Security
description: The American Embassy in Berlin said it would tighten security measures at diplomatic and consular facilities in Germany because of a heightened security threat. It also urged Americans in Germany to be more vigilant about their safety. An embassy spokesman, Robert A. Wood, declined to give specifics, but said American officials were responding to recent warnings by German authorities that the country faced an increased threat from terrorism.

title: The Medicare Privatization Scam
description: If private health plans are supposedly so great at delivering high-quality care while holding down costs, why does the government have to keep subsidizing them so lavishly to participate in the Medicare program?

title: A Speedy Spanning of Repertory, From Albniz to Bach
description: Nelson Freire in New York is not exactly a rare sighting, but it would be nice to have him here more often. He is an extraordinary pianist, and at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night he played an enthusiastically received program ranging from Bach transcriptions to Albniz.

title: Memorial Services Held in U.S. and Around World
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 20  Many of the 32 victims of the shooting rampage at Virginia Tech were remembered Friday at memorial services around the state, the nation and the world, at the same time as the family of their killer issued an apology.

title: French Voters Feeling Frustrated Despite a Not-So-Bad Economy
description: THE French presidential election, which has its first round tomorrow, features a dozen candidates, none of whom seem to have much good to say about the performance of the man who is leaving office after 12 years in power, Jacques Chirac.

title: Dont Assume the Worst
description: Cambridge, England

title: Corzine, Still at Risk, Is Breathing on His Own
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 20  Gov. Jon S. Corzine was breathing on his own for the first time in a week on Friday after doctors removed a mechanical ventilator that had been helping him breathe since he was critically injured in a car accident.

title: Young Tourists Pick Somalia, and a 3-Nation Ordeal Begins
description: STOCKHOLM

title: A New Twist on Snooping at Wal-Mart
description: A former Wal-Mart computer technician, who asserted that company employees eavesdropped on board meetings and conducted clandestine surveillance on shareholders, has reversed himself and denied both claims in sworn testimony, the giant retailer said yesterday.

title: Marine Officer to Testify on Iraq Killings in Exchange for Immunity
description: The officer in immediate command of three marines accused of killing civilians in a house-to-house attack in Haditha, Iraq, in 2005 has been granted immunity to testify at his subordinates military hearings, lawyers involved in the case said.

title: Federal Agency Investigating Airline Arrival-Time Promises
description: The Transportation Department said yesterday that it was investigating several domestic airlines for publishing unrealistic flight schedules  including ones that list arrival times the carriers know they cannot achieve  and said as many as eight could be fined for failing to provide accurate flight-delay information.

title: Celebrating Hispanics From Both Sides of a Hyphenated Identity
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 19  It was only a matter of time. A half-century of intense cultural preoccupation with hyphenated American identity has been giving birth to the hyphenated American museum. Such institutions pay tribute to the hyphen, examining the ways Hispanic-Americans or Arab-Americans or African-Americans or other groups have been changed by the encounter of two worlds, and how, in turn, these groups have made their own indelible contributions.

title: For the Record
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the testimony of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales before the Senate Judiciary Committee referred incorrectly to the power of Congress to remove an attorney general from office. Under the Constitution, civil officers of the United States government may be removed upon impeachment by the House of Representatives and trial in the Senate. Congress is not powerless to remove the attorney general.

description: Wandering through the headquarters of Scholastic in Manhattan is like taking a trip back through time and childish dreams, to a fantastical kindergarten with brightly colored columns and desk dividers and, at the very end, a huge playroom filled with toys like Clifford the Big Red Dog and Goosebumps and Captain Underpants and, of course, J. K. Rowlings books about Harry Potter and his comrades.

title: Sometimes Not Just Curtains Fall Onstage
description: Martha Plimpton heard a thud. When she turned and saw her Coast of Utopia co-star Richard Easton prone on the stage floor during the second preview, she presumed he had merely tripped. But Ethan Hawke, who had seen Mr. Easton collapse, said he thought Richard had passed away.

title: Seeking a High-Tech Way to Put Fresh Colors at the Top of the City
description: Before most of Manhattan could shake itself out of bed, the great Empire State Building light-show smackdown  an eerily silent rainbow of shifting color high above the city that continued for 71 predawn minutes yesterday  had its finale an hour before sunrise.

title: Hudson Gives Glimpse of Pitcher He Used to Be
description: Tim Hudson played in the American League until the 2005 season, and he never faced the Mets in an interleague game. So, most of the Mets know Hudson simply as a good pitcher, not as the intimidating right-hander with the all-galaxy splitter from his heyday with the Oakland As.

title: 2nd House Republican Yields Committee Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Representative Rick Renzi of Arizona stepped down suddenly Friday from the House Intelligence Committee, saying he was doing so because he was under federal investigation dealing with a series of financial transactions.

title: Auditioning in a Video Rsum
description: Dr. Ronald R. Rawitt, a New York City psychiatrist, is shy. When he gets nervous, he slips into aha and um mode. As someone who often lectures, this is a problem. It is also an issue because he is looking for work, and he worries that he is not coming off as forcefully as he would like.

title: North Korea: U.N. Inspectors Welcome, if . . .
description: North Korea reiterated that it would allow international nuclear inspectors into the country as soon as it could confirm that funds frozen in a Macao bank had been released. According to the official Korean Central News Agency, Ri Je-son, the director general of North Koreas Atomic Energy Department, delivered that message in a response to a request by the International Atomic Energy Agency to send inspectors. North Korea repeated that it remained committed to a Feb. 13 agreement under which it would allow inspectors in and shut down its Yongbyon nuclear plant in return for energy aid.

description: PORT HARCOURT, Nigeria  There are few safe places left for oil companies in the Niger Delta, the epicenter of this countrys petroleum industry.

description: When Americans think of Indian cinema they most likely think of classic Bollywood: movie stars dripping with old-fashioned glamour, long films with improbable plots improbably interrupted by song-and-dance sequences (and never by kissing).
