description: Seeking black and female votes yesterday, first at Rutgers University and then before the Rev. Al Sharptons political organization, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton used housecleaning imagery to swipe at President Bush and praised the Rutgers womens basketball team as teaching her and others a lesson.

title: Mayors Death Forces Japans Crime Rings Into the Light
description: NAGASAKI, Japan, April 20  The shooting death this week of this citys popular mayor has left people puzzling over the shooters motive and has set off a national outcry about a less savory aspect of Japanese society: its teeming criminal underworld.

title: About Those Haircuts
description: John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat who is seeking his partys presidential nomination in 2008, told reporters in Iowa yesterday that he was embarrassed over the disclosure that he had paid $800 for two haircuts in California earlier this year.

title: Anger and Alternatives on Abortion
description: The Supreme Court decision on Wednesday to uphold a ban on a type of abortion, has huge political implications but, as a practical matter, is unlikely to have much of an effect.

title: Brooklyn: Housing Inspector Finds Body
description: A building inspector found a mans body yesterday in the basement of 542 Bainbridge Street in Ocean Hill, the police said. The victim, identified as Donell Johnson, 22, a tenant of the apartment building, was found face down with a gunshot wound to his head, the police said. Investigators he said that Mr. Johnson was probably murdered because no weapon was found near his body. It was unclear last night how long the body had been in the basement.

title: 2 State Panels to Review Factors That Led to Governors Crash
description: TRENTON, April 20  As New Jerseys attorney general and state police conduct twin investigations into the auto accident that left Gov. Jon S. Corzine in critical condition, one of the most complex and delicate tasks will be to determine Mr. Corzines role in his two-car caravans violation of traffic laws.

title: U.S. Rules Made Killer Ineligible to Purchase Gun
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Under federal law, the Virginia Tech gunman Seung-Hui Cho should have been prohibited from buying a gun after a Virginia court declared him to be a danger to himself in late 2005 and sent him for psychiatric treatment, a state official and several legal experts said Friday.

title: Katrina Tax Break Spurs $11 Billion in Donations
description: A tax break that was part of a relief package to aid victims of Hurricane Katrina spurred $11 billion in donations to charity, the Treasury Department has estimated, more than triple what had been originally projected.

title: Toronto Hecklers Cant Wait to Welcome Back Carter
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 20  The Toronto Raptors hope to use the postseason as a steppingstone to something more. But first, they must prove they are over the Vince Carter era.

title: Top British Drugstore Chain Now Has Competing Bidders
description: LONDON, April 20  Alliance Boots, the largest drugstore chain in Britain, became the target of a 10.8 billion ($21.6 billion) takeover battle Friday after a private equity firm and a medical charity raised their joint bid, hours after the board had accepted a rival offer.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in some copies last Saturday about the discovery of a mans body under a pile of debris in a home in Woodmere, N.Y., included a quotation about the incident from a man who identified himself as Erik Kinney, a volunteer firefighter. Mr. Kinney has told The A.P. that he never spoke to a reporter, and the news agency says it does not know who at the fire station identified himself as Mr. Kinney. (Go to Article)

title: Choreographing From Scratch With No Recipe
description: Theres been plenty of wordplay in preview discussions of The Nothing Festival, which opened at Dance Theater Workshop on Wednesday night with the first of two programs featuring the work of eight choreographers over the next 10 days. So a warning: more coming up.

title: In Boston, Yanks Rotation Often Has Unfamiliar Face
description: BOSTON, April 20  The Yankees have been desperate for pitchers at Fenway Park before. Two years ago, they started Tim Redding here. Last season, they gave the ball to Sidney Ponson. Neither veteran pitched for the Yankees again.

title: Bill Bradley, Ex-Senator, Returns to Producing
description: Sure, win a Rhodes scholarship, help lead a team to a national basketball championship, become a United States senator and run for president. Congratulations.

title: Russia Purges Its Markets of Immigrants
description: Any foreigner in the old Soviet Union knew to search for decent food at the immigrants stalls of the nearest farmers market. The offerings sold in state stores often looked faintly gray, suffering from age or freezer burn. By contrast, the markets like Cheryomushski, near our apartment in Moscow, were full of color and life and fresh vegetables. People from the Caucasus were there, laughing and bargaining and, undoubtedly, making fun of bumbling customers like me. In midwinter, they sold exquisite lemons or fresh cilantro, hand-carried from the south, oranges in artful pyramids and brown eggs, some with tiny feathers still attached. And the butcher carved the meat before your eyes. With an ax.

title: Part Timers Full-Time Polish
description: The Riverside Symphonys performance at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening showed yet again how superb New Yorks pool of freelance musicians can be. The orchestra, as such, plays only a few programs every year, and this was its final concert this season. But its musicians work together in other orchestras, chamber groups and new-music ensembles, and when the music engages them, they produce a tightly focused, fully polished sound that is as good as youll hear from many full-time orchestras.

title: Why Darwinism Isnt Depressing
description: Scientists have discovered that love is truth.

title: Bless the Blackout
description: Some five million of the eight million BlackBerry subscribers were forced to take stock of their (over)reliance on the little mobile devices earlier this week when a large chunk of the wireless e-mail system unexpectedly went down. At least one highly interested group of people could be forgiven for sudden bouts of schadenfreude: the significant others of these BlackBerry dependents who find it nearly impossible to carry on a conversation without having to endure the distracted downward glances and covert typing that say, My interest lies elsewhere.

title: Heat Says Its Ready for the Games That Really Matter
description: MIAMI, April 20  Relieved to be rid of the regular season and all its banality, the players and the coach of the defending champion Miami Heat started projecting a familiar confidence these past few days that bordered on arrogance.

title: Getting Out of Hedge Funds
description: WHEN it comes to hedge funds, do the extremely rich know more than the rest of us?

title: When a Student Is Mentally Ill (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Car of Tomorrow Is Put to the Test Again
description: AVONDALE, Ariz., April 20  Stock-car racing fans in the North Carolina heartland of the sport were asked by a Charlotte newspaper columnist last year to come up with a new name for the Car of Tomorrow, which, after years of development, was scheduled to debut in Nascars Nextel Cup series this season.

title: Media Outlets Ease Off Video of Killer, but Not Because of Complaints, They Say
description: NBC, the network that was sent the videos of the Virginia Tech gunman and used them most extensively, and other cable and broadcast networks backed sharply away from showing the images yesterday.

title: N.B.A. Playoff Preview
description: History sometimes has a tangled sense of humor.

title: U.S. Erects Baghdad Wall to Keep Sects Apart
description: BAGHDAD, April 20  American military commanders in Baghdad are trying a radical new strategy to quell the widening sectarian violence by building a 12-foot-high, three-mile-long wall separating a historic Sunni enclave from Shiite neighborhoods.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about plans for a traveling exhibition of African-American history misstated the academic affiliation of Quintard Taylor Jr., a member of the exhibitions advisory panel. He is a professor of history at the University of Washington in Seattle  not at Washington University in St. Louis.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about closing arguments in a corruption case against Gerald P. Garson, a former State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn, misstated the name of his wife, a Brooklyn Civil Court judge who was in the courtroom. She is Robin Garson, not Rachel.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the struggles of St. Louis in the wake of a population decline misstated the name of a neighborhood that is thriving. It is Lafayette Square, not Lafayette Park.

title: Carlo Maria Badini, 81, an Innovative Leader of La Scala, Dies
description: Carlo Maria Badini, a former superintendent of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan who brought the opera house into the age of television and corporate sponsorship, died in Bologna, Italy, on Thursday. He was 81.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about Chinas talk of democracy misstated the name of the organization with which Bonnie G. Glaser, who commented about the issue, is affiliated. She is a China expert with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, not the Center for Security and International Studies.

title: For the Record
description: A biographical sketch on Wednesday of Michael S. Pohle Jr., one of the victims at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, misspelled the name of the restaurant where he worked. It is Nerv, not Nerve.

title: Sallie Mae Offers a Lesson on Cashing In
description: Arent you just fuming about that Sallie Mae deal?

title: Cousin of Sex Offender Tells of Complaint at Earlier Church
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 20  The cousin of a former youth minister who confessed to the statutory rape of four teenagers testified on Friday in a civil lawsuit against St. Raphaels Roman Catholic Church in East Meadow, saying that years before those crimes, a mother in another parish had complained about the man having sex with her 16-year-old daughter.

title: Helen Walton, Matriarch of Wal-Mart Family, Dies at 87
description: Helen Robson Walton, whose husband, Sam Walton, founded Wal-Mart Stores and relied on her for advice, died on Thursday at her home in Bentonville, Ark. She was 87.

title: Drivers Fee Would Face Uphill Battle
description: A plan to charge drivers to bring their vehicles into the busiest parts of Manhattan, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to propose tomorrow, faces daunting obstacles and even under the most optimistic conditions is likely to be years away, both supporters and opponents of the idea said.

title: Two Cases Are Test for Bushs Unwavering Loyalty
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Time and time again, President Bush has stood by his most embattled but loyal lieutenants despite loud calls for their heads, at times defying the established physics of Washington (rapidly diminishing support in ones own party times the number of instances in which one has failed to convincingly explain away accusations of incompetence or malfeasance equals the certainty of rapid resignation).

title: Crisp Wins Some Fans With a Leap and a Triple
description: BOSTON, April 20  Coco Crisp is in his second official season as part of the intense Yankees-Red Sox rivalry, but Crisp insisted that he had had insight into the Yankee-Red Sox rivalry for more than 15 years. Crisp played for a team called the Yankees in Sportsmens Little League in Inglewood, Calif.

title: Wind-Whipped Blaze Rages in Southern Georgia
description: ATLANTA, April 20  Hundreds of firefighters from across the Southeast placed themselves between houses and wildfires in southern Georgia on Friday, trying to fend off blazes that have blackened 42,000 acres, destroyed 20 houses and forced hundreds of residents to evacuate.

title: Worldly Lights and Darks Versus Childhood Ups and Downs
description: Kimberly Bartosik and Jennifer Allen, two choreographers with seemingly little in common  sprawled bodies bathed in stark lighting in the first act, rainbows and unicorns in the second  shared an evening of work on Thursday at the Kitchen. Publicity material indicated that harmony could be found in their theatrical sensibilities and in the way they build overarching formal architectures for their work. But it was something of a stretch to see how such qualities made either choreographic voice particularly distinctive.

title: The Perils of Being Suddenly Rich
description: In many ways, David Hayden is the ideal entrepreneur. While still in elementary school in a suburb east of San Francisco he published a newspaper, and before graduating from college he had his own construction business. He has seen his Internet start-ups  first Magellan, then Critical Path  soar and he has seen them crash.

title: Masterly Playing From a Master of the Game
description: Some years ago I asked Edgar Kaplan whom he rated as the best bridge player of all time. He replied that the most talented was Alvin Roth, who died on Wednesday at 92.

title: Bush Defends Troop Buildup in Iraq, Claiming Progress in War
description: EAST GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 20  President Bush turned to visual aids on Friday to promote his troop buildup in Iraq, using maps and photographs on a wide electronic screen to assert that in Baghdad, the direction of the fight is beginning to shift.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about questions surrounding the adequacy of background checks for gun buyers in the wake of the massacre at Virginia Polytechnic Institute incorrectly described the meaning of Virginias being a shall issue state. The term refers to the qualifications for obtaining a permit to carry a concealed weapon, not for obtaining a weapon.

title: Parting Thoughts From a Master of the Ephemeral
description: BEACON, N.Y.  If the greatness of Sol LeWitt, the Minimal-Conceptual artist who died this month at 78, has so far escaped you, make haste to this quiet Hudson River town and its main cultural attraction, the massive art space called Dia:Beacon. Here, among the often hulking displays of Minimal Art, youll find an exhilarating show of 14 of LeWitts mind-teasing, eye-filling wall drawings. All were made by people other than the artist, following his written instructions  a habit that has always given LeWitts detractors fits. If this show doesnt persuade you of his accomplishment, it is your loss.

title: For the Record
description: A picture of Representative John T. Doolittle on Thursday with an article about a search of his home by the F.B.I. carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Pablo Martinez Monsivais/Associated Press, not Max Whittaker for The New York Times.

title: Chinas Automakers, With Beijings Prodding, Show Alternative-Fuel Cars
description: SHANGHAI, April 20  Chinese automakers, under pressure from the government to produce more fuel-efficient cars, unveiled an unexpectedly broad array of prototypes for fuel-cell cars, gasoline-electric hybrid cars and electric battery cars at the Shanghai auto show on Friday.

title: World View Podcast
description: Calvin Sims and Elaine Sciolino discuss Frances upcoming elections.

title: The Day Jackie Robinson Was Embraced (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. Is Asked to Investigate Reading Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Education Departments inspector general has asked the Justice Department to investigate Reading First, the Bush administrations $6 billion program to teach poor children to read by third grade.

title: India: Encephalitis Vaccine for 20 Million Children
description: The government is intensifying efforts to combat Japanese encephalitis, an untreatable viral disease spread by mosquitoes that kills one in three children who contract it. India said it would finance the immunization of 20 million children in nine states before July, when the monsoon season brings rains that increase infection rates. It obtained the vaccine, which costs about 25 cents per dose, from the Chengdu Institute of Biological Products, a part of the China National Biotec Corp. PATH, an international nonprofit group, negotiated the lower price on behalf of developing countries.

title: Roosevelt: Schools Chief Resigns
description: Ronald O. Ross has resigned as superintendent of the troubled Roosevelt Union Free School District, state education officials announced yesterday. Mr. Ross, who was appointed in 2004 by Richard P. Mills, the education commissioner, will step down on June 30, the end of the current school year. In recent weeks, Mr. Ross has come under increasing criticism from local residents as the 2,800-student district, the only one under state oversight, has run up a budget deficit of as much as $12.3 million, according to a state audit. Mr. Ross, who earned $200,000 a year, could not be reached for comment.

title: Frank Westheimer, 95, Who Developed Model Valuable in Biochemistry, Dies
description: Frank H. Westheimer, a Harvard chemist whose work in understanding how the body metabolizes alcohol became a model for similar studies in the growing field of biochemistry, died last Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 95. Dr. Westheimers death was confirmed by his family.

title: Some Old-Fashioned Guys for an Old-Fashioned Job
description: Before dawn yesterday, two electricians and a supervisor changed colors on the Empire State Buildings north face during the test of new light-emitting diodes, or L.E.D.s, to provide a visual comparison. To do it, they climbed out office windows to switch the colored filters called gels atop floodlights installed on the parapets.

title: Pacific Miracles
description: The trouble with modernity is how efficiently it obliterates the troves of age-old knowledge otherwise known as wisdom. The good news from Palau, a Pacific island nation near the Philippines, is that some wise old ways have reasserted themselves to the great benefit of that tiny republics fish and reefs, and the people who depend on them.

title: $3 Million Lost to Fraud Ring, Authorities Say
description: More than 1,000 restaurant customers on the East Coast paid a higher price than they thought for their entrees: the theft of credit card information, the Manhattan district attorney said yesterday.

title: Isles Late Comeback Falls Short, and Sabres Advance
description: BUFFALO, April 20  In the end, the Islanders still had a chance. The team that had to win its final four games of the regular season simply to qualify for the playoffs had a chance to tie Game 5 of its opening-round playoff series with nine seconds remaining on a shot from close range by Miroslav Satan.

title: Torre: Gotta Go to Mo
description: This is why were supposed to be cynical in this business.

title: On Top of the World
description: Photographs by James Hill of the people who live in Chukotka, a blistering cold region in the Russian Arctic.

title: Making Detainees Talk in Iraq
description: Beatings of suspects by Iraqi soldiers, which appear to be widespread, are a largely undiscussed dilemma.

title: Michelle Obama vs. Hillary Clinton
description: The Chicago Tribune has a major profile today of Michelle Obama, Senator Barack Obamas wife, capturing not only her personality but also her strategic role in his campaign.

title: Celeb news
description: Remember the swanky bachelor pad in which Daniel Cleaver discovers that Bridget Jones wears big white tummy control knickers? Its on the market for 3.2 million  or about $6.4 million. Owner Antoine Blondeau is selling the 3,900-square-foot three-bedroom duplex overlooking the Thames thats located near Londons Borough market through Savills real estate agency at www.savills.com. The property featured in several scenes in the 2001 comedy starring Hugh Grant and Renee Zellweger.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: April 22
description: From the 2008 campaign contenders, to the killings at Virginia Tech to Attorney General Alberto Gonzales testimony, the past weeks news should keep guests on the news shows busy.

title: The States Take the Lead
description: Those who are impatient with gridlock in Washington are turning to their state capitals, where Main Street takes on everyone from Wall Street to Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: More Earthly Ideas
description: From serious policy proposals to Earth Day gimmicks, the presidential candidates have spent the past week trying to out-green one another. Heres our original Earthly Ideas report from Thursday.

title: No No-Nos
description: As writers, we, of course, do not root for particular players or teams. We root for good things to write about, and as John Maine dismantled the Marlins through six innings on Thursday night, I started wondering whether I would finally get to see a no-hitter. Out of all the potentially superlative individual performances (A-Rod included), I would much prefer watching a pitcher on top of his game. In every no-hitter, there seems to be a little bit of luck involved, the one close play at a base or a great catch by an outfielder. But for the most part, you cannot hold another team without a hit if youre looking like todays starter, Oliver Perez, did in his ugly outing on April 11 against the Phillies.

title: Matsuzaka Meets The Yankees
description: Daisuke Matsuzaka will be introduced to the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry when he starts for Boston on Sunday night at Fenway Park. Matsuzaka, who is 1-2 with a 2.70 earned run average, has already shown that he is poised and is unlikely to be bothered by the extra attention.

title: Giuliani on Immigration
description: At a recent appearance in Des Moines, Rudolph W. Giuliani discussed immigration.

title: Power of a Mother's Love
description: Nicholas D. Kristof tells how one former prostitute overcame the greed of brothel owners in India.

title: In Boston, Theyll Always Remember Mientkiewicz
description: Doug Mientkiewicz said he noticed only one obscene gesture directed at him Friday night, which he considers a victory as a former Red Sox player now with the Yankees. Actually, Mientkiewicz mused, they probably should cheer for him, since hes batting .139.

title: Your Comments on my Sex Trafficking Column
description: Please post your comments on my India column about sex trafficking, or about the related video. I particularly welcome ideas about what we should do about the problem, or experiences related to it. Just hit the comment button.

title: Affordable Europe: Berlin
description: BERLIN is the home of good deals. Eighteen years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the city's depressed economy has kept prices down, and transportation and food are generally more reasonable than in other large European capitals. The city's 20th-century history is visible everywhere to the hardy walker, and there are plenty of green spaces where you can relax and grab a quick kebab or currywurst for lunch.

title: You Say Ross, They Say Rosati
description: Although most wineries are content to produce one ros, or none, Channing Daughters in Bridgehampton offers a handful of rosati, to use the Italian term the winery favors.

title: Less Provocative, but No Less Dysfunctional
description: Reunions with old friends are fraught with danger. Will the magic still be there, or has time, with its corrosion of content and context, damaged the connective tissue?

title: The Iron Archives
description: Since the end of the cold war, historians have mined the Russian archives for insights into the nature of the Soviet empire and its global reach. New documents have shed light on such matters as the Alger Hiss and Rosenberg spy cases and also illuminated the relationships between Moscow and revolutionary movements in other countries  sometimes fueling old debates more than settling them. But after a golden age in the early 1990s, archival access eroded. Today, conversations with nearly two dozen historians point to a worrisome tightening that has kept key archives closed and subjected others to unpredictable re-secretization.

title: Students Recount Desperate Minutes Inside Norris Hall
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 21  The Elementary German class was under way in Room 207, reviewing German translations of computer parlance. A young man peeked in, saying nothing, and withdrew. Students who noticed him thought that either he was searching for someone or trying to locate his class. He did the same thing across the hall in Room 206, and again in Room 204.

title: Affordable Europe: Florence
description: Florence is the land of the Renaissance, the home of the intelligentsia and masterworks, the purveyors of handmade shoes and the finest leather, and the stage for exquisite food and top-flight wine. In other words, it'll cost you. But if you know where to look, you'll see that some euros go farther than others.

title: Eco-Socialites Make Cleaning Green a Priority
description: THERE is nothing like the specter of a bathtub ring to mobilize even the most pedigreed homemaker. Sloan Barnett was counting on it when she invited some 40 friends to her five-story Georgian town house on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She meant to introduce them to her family-owned line of eco-friendly household cleansers, and to persuade them to do their part to save the planet.

title: What to Do While Awaiting That N.F.L. Call
description: UNIONDALE

title: Big
description: In October 1987, Steve Sillett, a 19-year-old college student, made a running leap into a California coast redwood tree and climbed some 300 feet to the top without rope or safety gear, nearly falling to his death several times.

title: The Amis Inheritance
description: Ben Jonson wrote: Greatness of name in the father oft-times helps not forth, but overwhelms the son; they stand too near one another. The shadow kills the growth. This Oedipal principle applies to all sorts of professions, but few more so than the literary one. Its not unheard of for the child of an author to try his hand at writing. Stephen Kings two sons are writers, and so is one of John Updikes. Hilma Wolitzers daughter Meg is a novelist, as is Anita Desais daughter Kiran, whose second book just won the Booker Prize  an award that has so far eluded her mother. But writers offspring tend to go into the family business with far less regularity than, say, the children of doctors or lawyers, and it seldom happens that over the long haul, and in the deepening shade, the younger equals or outstrips the elder  the way that Anthony Trollope, to take a famous example, bested his mother, Fanny.

title: A Global Warming Sign Meant to Make Passers-By Curious
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Military Cites Negligence in Aftermath of Iraq Killings
description: A military investigation has found that senior Marine Corps commanders in Iraq showed a routine disregard for the lives of Iraqi civilians that contributed to a willful failure to investigate the killing of 24 unarmed Iraqis by marines in 2005, lawyers involved in the case said.

title: The Comedians Lair
description: Morning routine: The day starts a little after 6:30 a.m., because after laborious effort weve gotten our baby daughter, Sloane, to wake up three minutes later than she used to. I take Sloane, and we say good morning to different things in the house. My wife, Sandra, makes the babys breakfast, and I go to work. Also, coffee happens.

title: Did You Know? Harvard  New York
description: GETTING into Harvard isnt easy, but statistically, its more likely if you attend public or private high school in New York City. In the last five years, students from the five boroughs have been admitted at a rate five to eight percentage points higher than that of the overall applicant pool.

title: Affordable Europe: Prague
description: The City of a Hundred Spires is becoming one of Europe's top destinations, with passenger arrivals at Prague's Ruzyne Airport having doubled since 2000, according to official statistics. Those ever-increasing numbers mean that prices are among the highest in the former Eastern bloc, though a few surprising bargains have recently appeared in the Czech capital.

title: When the Group Is Wise
description: SEUNG-HUI CHO seemed indifferent to every small act of human kindness, any effort to connect.

title: The Infinite Variety of the Lady Stanwyck
description: THERE are only a few ways to be a movie star, and Barbara Stanwyck, Brooklyn-born 100 years ago, took the hardest and probably the best one: she kept the audience guessing. She wasnt jaw-droppingly beautiful (though her eyes were lovely and her legs were famously good). She didnt have an outsize, force-of-nature personality. And she wasnt an instantly recognizable type  a vamp or girl next door or career woman or high-society madcap, to name a few of the popular personae available to actresses of her era. She played versions of all those roles at one time or another, without getting stuck in any of them. You couldnt tell who Barbara Stanwyck was just by looking at her; it took a little trouble to get to know her, and she had the ability  a stars ability  to make millions of viewers believe she was worth the trouble.

title: Celeste Sharpe, Peter Brown
description: Celeste Andrea Sharpe and Peter Brown are to be married this evening at the Don CeSar Beach Resort in St. Pete Beach, Fla. Judge Robert A. Foster Jr., of the Hillsborough County Circuit Court in Tampa is to officiate.

title: Historical Mayhem, Set to Music
description: Is there anything that cant be saved by Eartha Kitt?

title: Corzines Wild Ride
description: Nyack, N.Y.

title: Gordon Ends Slump and Ties Earnhardt
description: AVONDALE, Ariz., April 21  Jeff Gordon stopped his No. 24 Chevrolet at the start-finish line at Phoenix International Raceway and was handed a Dale Earnhardt No. 3 flag to wave to the crowd. It was a victory-lap celebration for Gordon after he won the Subway Fresh Fit 500 on Saturday night. And this time, a checkered flag would not do.

title: Adventures in Low-Cost Travel
description: UNRESTED and unshowered, I arrived at Luton Airport, in suburban London, around 5 a.m., and did not expect my situation to improve. Id been up all night, wandering around London with friends, and now I was about to fly to Morocco on an airline whose reputation for rock-bottom prices was surpassed only by its reputation for rock-bottom service. Bleary-eyed, I slapped my passport on the check-in counter, picked up the boarding pass (no assigned seating, of course), and began the long, long march to my gate.

title: Jessica Bailey, Brian Inglis
description: Jessica Elizabeth Bailey and Brian Thomas Inglis were married yesterday at Emmanuel Church in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Everett Greene, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Salima Vahabzadeh, Paul Sheppard
description: Salima Vahabzadeh and Paul Kenneth Sheppard, who are vice presidents at investment banking firms in New York, were married here yesterday. The Rev. J. Donald Waring, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Church. Afterward, Hossein Ebneyousef, an uncle of the bride, led a Persian cultural ceremony at the Peter White Studio.

title: Affordable Europe: Istanbul
description: Sure, Turkey lopped off several zeroes from its currency (the lira) in 2005, but that doesn't mean that dining on meze or hobnobbing with sultans has gotten cheaper. If anything, it's just the opposite. Istanbul has emerged as one of Europe's hottest centers of chic, with the designer boutique hotels, flashy night life and cosmopolitan price tags to match. Luckily, pockets of this former Byzantine capital  from lesser-known markets to trendy new restaurants  are dedicated to preserving pre-devaluation bargains, as when $1 was worth more than one million Turkish liras.

title: Just About Letter Perfect
description: WHIMSY is nice in a name, and in a restaurants dcor, but whimsy on the plate can be even better. When accompanied by flawless execution, it moves a restaurant into a higher realm, as it does at Alphabet Soup, an upscale addition to the edible landscape in south-central New Jersey.

title: You Are What You Grow
description: A few years ago, an obesity researcher at the University of Washington named Adam Drewnowski ventured into the supermarket to solve a mystery. He wanted to figure out why it is that the most reliable predictor of obesity in America today is a persons wealth. For most of history, after all, the poor have typically suffered from a shortage of calories, not a surfeit. So how is it that today the people with the least amount of money to spend on food are the ones most likely to be overweight?

title: Brooklyn School Stays on Top, Even as Students Come and Go
description: It is never easy to stay on top. That is particularly true of scholastic chess programs, where the yearly turnover of students means that any school good enough to win a championship one year could lose its best players to graduation.

title: Hello, Stranger
description: Change has come to Tula Springs, La. Readers familiar with St. Jude Parish from James Wilcoxs first novel, Modern Baptists (1983), may have trouble recognizing the place today. Theres a Starbucks in the Piggly Wiggly. The Sonny Boy Bargain Store, rechristened Redds, is now part of the BurgerMat empire. Romance unfolds in chat rooms, and Viagra-touting spam finds at least one willing customer. The globalized marketplace has pressed its thumb on Tula Springs, uncorking a plethora of brands including Vera Wang, Armani, Dolce & Gabbana and Christian Louboutin. Weve come a long way from the Ajax Feed and Seed and bourbon and Tabs at Juniors.

title: The Russell Simmons Guide to Success Through Spirituality
description: RUSSELL SIMMONS, is a hip-hop mogul who personifies what he calls the Nu American Dream. After a misspent youth that included a stint dealing marijuana, he went on to make his fortune producing hit records, music videos, television shows, movies and clothes. He owns mansions, fancy cars and all sorts of expensive toys.

title: Correction: List of Some Schools Presenting the Play High School Musical
description: A list last Sunday of performances of Disneys High School Musical included an incorrect date for the Ventnor Middle School. The school will present the show on May 17 but not on May 16.

title: Sharing Practical Truths, in Child-Size Measures
description: I RECENTLY had a chance to speak to a cafeteria full of high school girls at the Lincoln School in Providence, R.I. Each had been asked to invite a woman she admires, and most brought their moms, making it the first time I spoke to an audience of mothers and daughters.

title: Joanne Cvijic, Christopher Good
description: Joanne Cvijic, a daughter of Nada and Zarko Cvijic of Rockaway Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Christopher Richard Good, the son of Barbara L. Good of Estes Park, Colo., and the late Richard L. Good. The Rev. Elias G. Villis, a Greek Orthodox priest, officiated at the Church of Our Saviour in Rye, N.Y.

title: Meaghan McNamara, Cameron Bruce III
description: Meaghan Creighton McNamara and Cameron John Bruce III were married yesterday at the St. Aloysius Church in Washington. The Most Rev. Kevin J. Farrell, an auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington, performed the ceremony.

title: From the Foxhole
description: A NICE little profit center in education publishing these days, when Teach for America and similar programs are plopping untested teachers into inner city schools, is the foxhole memoir, a first-person account of what its really like there in the trenches. The gold standard is probably Educating Esm: Diary of a Teachers First Year, which is still selling briskly in paperback after five years and has spawned an Esm industry  six more books by Esm Raji Codell.

title: Mayor Proposes a Fee for Driving Into Manhattan
description: Saying that he would not spend his final term in office pretending that all is fine, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made a series of Earth Day proposals this afternoon to improve the environment of New York City, including charging a new congestion fee to drivers who come into parts of Manhattan during peak hours during weekdays.

title: Too Much Complaining About Real Estate Taxes; Raising the Tax on Cigarettes (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Just the Spot for Tea
description: Anchoring the Sound end of Mamaronecks busy main street, the Tea House could not be in a more convenient location. A perfect stop for a restorative, unhurried cuppa and much more, this charming spot is around the corner from the Emelin Theater, down the block from the movie house, and a short stroll across Boston Post Road from the boatyard and from pretty Harbor Island Park.

title: Certifying Coffee Aids Farmers and Forests in Chiapas
description: NUEVO PARASO, Mexico  Miguel Moshn Mndezs troubles have piled up over the past two years.

title: Affordable Europe: St. Petersburg
description: Ignore all those tales of nouveau riche fat cats guzzling Champagne in gilded hotels. Many of St. Petersburg's glories  wondrous architecture, enchanting canals and an enveloping sense of history  are free or relatively cheap. The city even deploys young English-speaking guides in the historic center in the summer to help tourists, at no charge. Grumpy Communist apparatchiks, they are not.

title: Be My Neighbor
description: Kurt Vonneguts Billy Pilgrim (in Slaughterhouse-Five) had a famous dream in which the film of time ran backward: bombs re-coalesced, sucking their exploding fire back into dark capsules that flew upward into the planes bomb bays, while German fighters, as if by magic, closed up the bullet holes they had drilled in the bombers; the bombers flew backward to their bases, and the bombs were returned to America and disassembled and diffused into harmlessness. And Hitler became a baby again. All people became babies, a magic reversion down the ages, back to two perfect people named Adam and Eve.

title: And Ghosts Drink Free
description: OPENING a club in a New York institution like the Chelsea Hotel, a veritable vertical village whose arty flophouse allure Arthur Miller described as the high spot of the surreal, is a double-edged pursuit. While the address is easy to remember, its reputation may set up certain expectations.

title: Israeli Minister Steps Aside Pending Inquiry
description: JERUSALEM, April 22  Israels finance minister, Abraham Hirchson, said Sunday that he was leaving office for three months pending the outcome of a police investigation against him.

title: I Pledge Allegiance
description: This is a book that pivots on a smile. A third of the way through Mohsin Hamids second novel, The Reluctant Fundamentalist, the narrator, a young Pakistani man named Changez, tells an American how he first learned of the destruction of the World Trade Center. While on a business trip to Manila, he turned on the television in his hotel room and saw the towers fall. I stared as one  and then the other  of the twin towers of New Yorks World Trade Center collapsed. And then I smiled. Yes, despicable as it may sound, my initial reaction was to be remarkably pleased.

title: In the Hamptons, Ahead of the Crowds
description: AMAGANSETT, N.Y.

title: Virginia Tech Struggles to Recover From Shootings
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 22  A girl in an orange and maroon bikini basked in the sun less than 20 feet from the dorm in which one of the worst massacres in American history had begun.

title: Missed Signals
description: 1. Symptoms

title: Man Arrested at Shea After Aiming Light at Players
description: A 40-year-old Bronx man was arrested at Shea Stadium on Friday night during the Mets game after being accused of trying to blind Atlanta Braves players with a high-power flashlight, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday.

title: A Playwrights Progress
description: Montclair

title: Philharmonic Leader; Foreign Treasures
description: PHILHARMONIC LEADER

title: Yankees Rodriguez Is Hot. Why? Listen Up.
description: Every time Alex Rodriguez walks to the plate at Yankee Stadium, the smooth voice of Mims, a rapper from Washington Heights, serenades him for each step and for each practice swing.

title: At the Top of the Heap
description: IT has a nice ring to it, doesnt it? National Merit Scholar. Dont even think about it unless you can test in the top 1 percent, have earned spectacular grades and demonstrated leadership potential.

title: A Lot of Money From Not So Many
description: If money talks in politics, then 10 metropolitan areas around the country are talking very loudly.

title: Affordable Europe:  Paris
description: The euro is so high these days that it has even become an issue in the presidential campaign in France: Nicolas Sarkozy, the conservative candidate for president, has vowed to lobby to lower its value against the dollar if he wins the election in May. But until that happens, creative thinking is in order for visitors on a budget.

title: Micro Comic
description: In the epochal Monty Python sketch, Mrs. Premise and Mrs. Conclusion, two frowzy women at a Laundromat, are discussing that most human of all predicaments  the fact that if you flush a parakeet down a toilet, you end up with a flock of soiled birds flying out of peoples lavatories infringing their personal freedom. Mrs. Premise opines: Its a funny thing, freedom. I mean how can any of us be really free when we still have personal possessions. She then asserts that this argument is the whole crux of Jean-Paul Sartres Roads to Freedom,  whereupon Mrs. Conclusion barks, No, it bloody isnt. As it turns out, Mrs. Premise recently met Sartre on holiday in Ibeezer  Mr. S., she says, was a bit moody  so Mrs. Conclusion suggests, Well, well give a tinkle then. The two women call him, and then trot off to Paris to settle their dispute.

title: Bonnie Byalick and Neil Levine
description: WITH the keen eye honed during a 35-year career selling textiles, Neil Levine was flipping through online dating profiles like fabric swatches in 2005, when he noticed a familiar-looking blonde in an off-the-shoulder sweater.

title: Renewal in the Sound
description: Some people refer to Long Island Sound as the Urban Sea, which by itself is enough to make you nervous. An estimated 20 million people live within a 50 mile drive of its shores, and centuries after the first European explorers came to trade with the Indians, people are still moving to the coasts, eating up open space, trampling wildlife habitats and paving over land in ways that reduce natures capacity to filter and clean contaminated runoff.

title: Did Somebody Say Indiana Jones?
description: AHUSH fell over the standing-room-only crowd at the Explorers Club in Manhattan on Feb. 5. In a room whose dark-paneled walls are hung with flags once planted in the far-flung precincts of Everest and Antarctica, the man at the lectern had just finished talking about his anthropological travels through almost 40 countries, across some 500,000 miles, where he recovered from food poisoning and chigger bites in Peru and swam through shark-infested waters off Easter Island.

title: Hitting the Links From the Desk
description: IN a 2005 episode of The Office, the NBC sitcom, the bored employees of Dunder-Mifflin, a fictional paper company, demonstrated their made-up sports. Two accountants battled tedium by playing Hateball, their nickname for a well-known pastime in which paper triangles are flicked across desks. A human-resources employee, meanwhile, procrastinated with Dunderball, a catch-and-throw game that pitted cubicle dwellers against one another.

title: I Came, I Saw III, I Conquered
description: PEOPLE who graduated from college some time ago may fondly recall long winter nights when they lined up at the student union for screenings of The Seventh Seal, The 400 Blows or Citizen Kane. Those days are long gone, as archaic as recorder societies.

title: Oversight of Nursing Homes Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Federal health officials impose only minimal penalties on nursing homes repeatedly cited for mistreatment of patients, Congressional investigators say in a new report.

title: BMWs Shanghai Surprise
description: BMW lit a firecracker at the Shanghai auto show last week, unveiling a design study called the Concept CS that not only signaled an evolution of the companys designs, it suggested a possible future sedan that would be bigger and more expensive than any existing model.

title: Who Should Fix the Chimney in a Brownstone Co-op?
description: Q We live in a co-op in a 100-year-old brownstone with several apartments on four floors. The fireplace in the apartment on the first floor appears to have a leak in the chimney so that fumes escape into the adjacent apartment and the common area. The owner has agreed to stop using the fireplace until it is fixed. Who should pay for this repair?

title: Framing the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Im a Lumber Jack (Omelet, That Is)
description: At Amys Omelette House in Long Branch, the humble egg is a showoff. The menu lists more than 200 kinds of supersize omelets, 10 variations on eggs Benedict, and eggs prepared every which way.

title: Pumping Out the Numbers
description: Hamden

title: A Sons Death Inspires a Mission
description: MERRICK, N.Y.

title: Joanne Wang and David Golann
description: Joanne Jane Wang, the daughter of Julia and Dong-Ping Wang of Stony Brook, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Warner Golann, a son of Jan F. Golann and Steven W. Golann of New York. The Rev. Dr. Paul Sorrentino, a minister of the Conservative Congregational Christian Conference, performed the ceremony at Three Village Church in East Setauket, N.Y.

title: Hip Hip, Poiret
description: The fashion of tomorrow has always seemed to me more lovely than the fashion of today, wrote Paul Poiret in his 1931 autobiography, King of Fashion. By then, the designers illustrious reign had all but faded (he died in 1944 penniless and appropriately bitter), but his heyday in Paris before the First World War would guarantee his legacy. In the simplest of terms, he was a draper rather than a tailor, credited with liberating fashion from an exaggerated corseted silhouette that made a woman look like an hourglass  or as he put it, as if she were hauling a trailer. He was also the father of a certain opium-den chic, prone to heady metallic embroideries and the color red, an Oriental streak that was probably attributable to his belief that in a previous life he was an Oriental prince. Now the king is back.

title: School of Hard Knots
description: I was 36 years old and a new father when I realized I knew how to tie only one knot: the one you tie your shoes with. I could tie two knots if you count the double knot, which most seasoned mariners dont.

title: Paris Match
description: When it comes to food, Paris has long been the capital of nostalgia  a grand lover of itself and its storied culinary ways, but no lover of fads or progress for progresss sake. More than anything, the city has rewarded memory and its tastes: a delicious contract that there will always be a certain amount of butter, cream and wine and a right way of doing things.

title: Fish Story
description: Amnesia plots are a gift to first-time writers; what better way to face down your fear of the empty white page than conjuring a hero whose life is also a complete blank? In Steven Halls first novel, The Raw Shark Texts, a man wakes one morning to find himself with no idea of who or where he is; outside his window lurks a brave new world, unpopulated save for a few random souls whose job it is to deliver dollops of plot exposition before whisking themselves away again. Thus is the first requirement of the Amnesiac genre fulfilled  the one that dictates that a man who is piecing together his life receive only the scantiest help in doing so. It would never do to have some kind soul simply tell him what the hell is going on.

title: A Search for Yield Leads Some Back to Bonds
description: FOR generations, turmoil in the stock market has driven investors to bonds. Not only are bonds less subject to price gyrations, but they also provide more income as you sit out the equity storm. Particularly in foul weather, some bonds belong in virtually every portfolio, many financial advisers say.

title: Ashley Bell, Shamina Singh
description: Ashley Lynn Bell and Shamina Singh affirmed their partnership last evening. Mata Mandir K. Khalsa led a commitment ceremony incorporating Sikh traditions at the Houghton House, an event space at the Aspen Wye River Conference Centers in Queenstown, Md.

title: Picking Up the Pieces as the Floodwaters Subside
description: MANVILLE

title: Seeking Fans, Ballet Scrambles for a Killer App
description: THE New York State Theater was positively surging at a matinee in February. Audience members played clapping games, thumping in their seats like jackhammers. Cheers and shushes erupted when the house lights dimmed. It was the New York City Ballets annual winter performance for local students, and the energy was wildly different from that of many a sleepy matinee.

title: The God Disillusion
description: I love my neighbor as I love myself  which is to say, minimally, if at all, and in between fits of out-and-out loathing. But this is not quite the same thing as Christian charity, and one doesnt skip into heaven through a loophole. If the spirit should finally move me, and I answer the call to care for my fellow man unconditionally, the biggest challenge will be extending my newfound caritas to the religious zealots, for it is the zealots  more than the child molesters, petro-dictators or certain on-air personalities of the Fox News persuasion  whom I despise above all. Is it any wonder that from the Redeemer to Augustine, from Pascal to W. H. Auden, it has been the doubters, more than the believers, who have kept up religions good name? A skeptic in this tradition, Darcey Steinke is also, in her own way, a skeptic about the virtues of the contemporary memoir, now a mostly secular genre in which every human unhappiness is trendily medicalized or assigned its origin in a topical childhood trauma. In her memoir, Easter Everywhere, Steinke has dared to ask, What if my abiding sense of misery isnt due to abuse or balky neurotransmission, but to the absence of God in my life, to an unfulfilled relationship with my own divinity, as vouchsafed to me by the Creator?

title: In the Lives of Three Sisters, Fortune Doesnt Smile Often
description: The spacious yellow kitchen that provides the setting for Crimes of the Heart at the Schoolhouse Theater has seen better days. The flowered wallpaper is fading. Water stains dribble from the ceiling. And theres a cot shoved Cinderella-style into a corner.

title: How Green Is My Taxi
description: EARLIER this month, at the New York International Auto Show, an exhibit celebrated the 100th anniversary of the gasoline-powered taxi in New York City. Across town, Mayor Michael Bloomberg was unveiling the first study of the citys greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Heat Outdone by Running of Deng and the Bulls
description: CHICAGO, April 21  Luol Deng slashed to the basket, all speed and stealth, undaunted by the championship pedigree of the Miami Heat.

title: A Mass by Committee, and a Test of Belief
description: FOR centuries and across cultures, music has maintained a close but fraught connection with religious beliefs and practices. Should liturgical music be performed outside the service? Should secular idioms be a part of the service? Which sound structures will bring listeners closer to God, and which rhythms and harmonies might risk tempting believers away from him? Does it matter whether sacred musical texts are comprehensible to performers or listeners? And a question that comes increasingly into play nowadays: What does it mean to perform, much less compose, in the musical traditions of a faith you do not follow?

title: John R. Drexel III, Socialite and Scion of a Banking Family, Dies at 87
description: John R. Drexel III, scion of a powerful Philadelphia banking family and a prominent socialite in an era when the charity galas and debutante balls of the affluent dominated society-page headlines, died April 13 at his estate in Newport, R.I. He was 87.

title: For Achievers, a New Destination
description: YOUVE heard the threat; you may have made it: If you dont pull up those grades, youre going to a community college.

title: Slackers, Beware
description: YOURE not done.

title: Food for Thought: Satisfying Picky Eaters Is No Picnic
description: CAMPUSES need to be on top of dietary trends. Colleges began removing trans fat, which is linked to heart disease, years before municipalities and McDonalds caught on, and using cage-free eggs long before Burger King and Wolfgang Puck announced new animal-welfare policies. Prodded by student activists, more than 100 campuses, including Dartmouth, Tufts and Connecticut College, have eliminated or cut back on eggs from hens kept in traditional cages in favor of those from chickens with a little more room to flap.

title: For the Dow, Three Record Highs in Five Days
description: The stock market soared last week, propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to a record close on three successive days and ending the week at a new high.

title: Time for Spring Cleaning
description: Okay, Governor Spitzer and New York lawmakers. You finished the budget, took your spring vacation. Now its time to tackle one of the truly disgraceful things about New Yorks political scene  the self-serving system that virtually guarantees legislators jobs for life.

title: Too Much Information
description: When parents sit down to fill out their childs application for federal financial aid, they come across a page with a long list of questions about their income.

title: In Turnabout, Infant Deaths Climb in South
description: HOLLANDALE, Miss.  For decades, Mississippi and neighboring states with large black populations and expanses of enduring poverty made steady progress in reducing infant death. But, in what health experts call an ominous portent, progress has stalled and in recent years the death rate has risen in Mississippi and several other states.

title: Corzine Is Able to Speak but Has Bronchial Infection
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine was able to speak to doctors and family members yesterday for the first time since his initial surgery for the injuries he suffered in a car accident nine days ago, his doctors said. But, they added, the governor had developed a bronchial infection that the medical team was treating with antibiotics.

title: A Surge of Vitality in Downtown New Rochelle
description: THE recent opening of five higher-end restaurants in downtown New Rochelle, including a grill owned by the Yankees pitcher Mariano Rivera, is giving local leaders confidence that the citys long-range plan for revitalizing the area is starting to take shape.

title: High Hopes for Bridgeport
description: JUST about everybody likes a riddle, so here goes: What city, known in part for spectacular green spaces designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, was named by CNNMoney.com in November as one of the 20 housing markets nationwide that are likely to post the biggest home-price gains by 2011?

title: For Everything, a Sleek Package
description: Raymond Loewy: Designs for a Consumer Culture at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton is a beguiling, if oddly insubstantial, retrospective. The French-born industrial designer it celebrates is hardly remembered today, but he literally changed the look and feel of modern American life, reshaping mass-produced objects to make them look more attractive and thus sell better. Among his clients were Coca-Cola, Nabisco and Studebaker; he even revamped the exterior design of Air Force One for President John F. Kennedy with graphics and a color scheme that are still used today.

title: Election in Nigeria Sullied by Chaos
description: DANDUME, Nigeria, April 21  According to the citizens of this small, poor farming town in rural northern Nigeria, hardly one vote was cast in todays historic presidential election.

title: When Conflicts Arise, Lawyers May Be a Source
description: INVESTMENT bankers are often singled out in this space over their conflict-ridden ways. Yet when it comes to deals and conflicts, another group always seems to get off scot-free: the lawyers.

title: The Last Lace-Up
description: ON Tuesday night, a blurry mass of people could be seen flying and shimmying around the 150-foot-long miracle maple rink of the Empire Roller Skating Center in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The bass thumped and the lights were dimmed. Boys wearing baggy jeans and Yankee caps in every color of the rainbow whizzed along the curves. Gamine girls in halter tops and dangling earrings careened backward on the straightaways.

title: Work Search
description: At the private hospital where I am a medical resident, security guards routinely ask to check employees bags when we leave. After working a 24-hour shift, I just want to get home. Do employers have the right to search our bags without any probable cause?  Name withheld, New York

title: When You Meet an Imus
description: I was descending in an elevator from a party last weekend with some very wound-up young strangers. Out of the blue, one of them looked straight at the well-dressed friend I was with, and said, Hey, I saw you on Oprah.

title: Dozens Killed in Mortar Attack in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, April 21 (Agence France-Presse)  Mortar shells exploded in this Somali capital on Saturday, killing dozens of civilians and swelling the exodus from the city, as Ethiopian soldiers fought Islamist insurgents for a fourth day.

title: Tara Abrams, Judd Levine
description: Tara Celeste Abrams, the daughter of Lynn Gale of Redondo Beach, Calif., and Mark Abrams of Irvington, N.Y., was married last evening to Judd Parker Levine, a son of Sharyn and Paul Levine of Merrick, N.Y. Cantor Bernard Zahn officiated at the Arizona Biltmore in Phoenix.

description: Alex Rodriguez may have to break Barry Bondss single-season home run record for baseball to have a more remarkable story this year than Josh Hamilton.

description: AFTER sending the Dow Jones industrial average to new highs last week, shareholders are about to face a seasonal challenge: investing in equities during what has historically been a frustrating six-month stretch for stocks.

description: After the Storm, a Sigh of Relief

description: PARIS

title: Sallie Smith, James Butterworth
description: Dr. Sarah Bland Smith and James Frederick Butterworth were married in Boulder, Colo., yesterday afternoon. They married themselves under Colorado law. David Secunda and Carmela Weber, friends of the couple, led the ceremony at the Sunrise Amphitheater, an outdoor event space.

title: Venerable Italians 3rd Act: Great Food, and Opera, Too
description: THROUGHOUT its 30-year history, La Viola has been a weathervane of Long Islands taste in Italian food. When it opened in Cedarhurst in 1977, it was the kind of Italian restaurant that Long Islanders loved in that era: a formal, special-occasion spot serving continental cuisine. The restaurant was sold in the mid-1980s and later closed. In 1989, a new Viola opened with its original owners, Lino and Elsa Viola, back at the helm.

description: To the Editor:

title: Danube (Both Sides) on Hudson
description: ROMANIA and Bulgaria joined the European Union in January, so in the long run, there may be less economic incentive for their residents to emigrate to New York. Luckily for lovers of mititei and shopska salad, plenty of them are already here.

title: Tibetan Tea Party
description: In 1773, patriots in Boston protested Britains stranglehold over the tea trade by tipping 342 crates of Chinese leaves into the harbor. The British had been trying desperately to offset the costs of purchasing this valuable commodity from Canton, where China had imposed its own unfavorable trading terms. Tea was the lifeblood of the East India Company, but by the late 18th century, it had begun to drain the beast it was supposed to nourish. Kate Teltschers marvelous new book, The High Road to China, lucidly relates how Britain tried to circumvent trade barriers by opening a back door to China through the mysterious land of Tibet.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 21, 2007

title: Junior Achievement on a Major League Scale
description: Dustin Satloff walked into his Upper East Side apartment last Tuesday and called his sales representative in Indiana, his business partner, and a sporting goods store in Connecticut to check on inventory. He also reviewed paperwork from a factory in China.

title: Is High School Musical Enough of a Challenge?; Rejected Whole Foods Was Simply Too Big (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Flight Patterns
description: European starlings have a way of appearing in unexpected places  the United States, for example, where they are not native but owe their origin to a brief reference in Shakespeares Henry IV, Part 1. In 1890, a drug manufacturer who wanted every bird found in Shakespeare to live in America released 60 starlings in Central Park. After spending a few years nesting modestly under the eaves of the American Museum of Natural History, they went from a poetic fancy to a menacing majority; there are now upward of 200 million birds across North America, where they thrive at the expense of other cavity nesters like bluebirds and woodpeckers, eat an abundance of grain  as well as harmful insects  and occasionally bring down airplanes.

title: Bettina Edelstein, William Scott
description: Bettina Edelstein and William Scott were married yesterday afternoon at the Spire Bar & Lounge of the Hotel in Miami Beach. Gary Eisenberg, a friend of the couple and a Florida notary public, officiated.

title: Revisiting The Timess Coverage of the Duke Rape Case
description: THE official declaration of the innocence of three former Duke University lacrosse players accused of sexually assaulting a stripper triggered a flood of critical e-mails to the public editor. Many readers focused their ire on The Timess massive Aug. 25 portrait of the case, or on the papers outspoken sports columnists. Others called on me to agree that a liberal bias favoring the dancer, who was African-American, had corrupted The Timess coverage, or to urge the paper to apologize to the three young white men.

title: Clearing the Air in the Land of Guinness
description: Atlantic City last week joined a growing list of cities and states to ban or restrict smoking indoors, limiting smoking to no more than 25 percent of a casinos wagering area.

title: Melissa Epstein, Jason Mills
description: Melissa Jill Epstein, the daughter of Gail Epstein of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Paul Epstein of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jason Scott Mills, the son of Bonnie Mills and Gerald Mills of Yucaipa, Calif. The Rev. Margaret Duttera, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Adamson House in Malibu, Calif.

title: Monks Who Play Punk
description: IT was 9 oclock on a wintry Saturday night, and in the dimly lighted basement of Our Lady of Good Counsel, a Roman Catholic church on 90th Street and Second Avenue, the chatter of more than 400 young people competed with the din of a rock band. Those not shouting in one anothers ears were dancing, singing, laughing and jumping up and down while trying not to spill their cups of coffee.

title: France Sets Up Left-Right Showdown in Runoff
description: PARIS, April 22  Nicolas Sarkozy and Sgolne Royal, the candidates of the two leading political parties, won the first round of the presidential elections in France on Sunday, giving French voters a clear choice for the runoff in two weeks.

description: Theater

title: Rebecca Schatzkin, Gregory Vincent
description: Rebecca Merrill Schatzkin, the daughter of Dr. Tamara Harris and Dr. Arthur Schatzkin of Chevy Chase, Md., was married last evening to Gregory Lawrence Vincent, a son of Margaret Vincent and Fred Vincent of Philadelphia. Justice Karla Moskowitz of the New York State Supreme Court officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in New York.

title: Correction: Passing the Baton: Be Bold, New York
description: An article last Sunday about potential candidates for music director of the New York Philharmonic misspelled the surname of a guest conductor who has impressed the orchestras musicians. He is Ludovic Morlot, not Merlot. The article also misidentified the work that Gustavo Dudamel, who will take over as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in 2009, conducted in his debut with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. It was Mahlers First Symphony, not his Fifth Symphony. The article also gave an incorrect surname in some references for a conductor who will lead the Dallas Symphony Orchestra. He is Jaap van Zweden, not von Zweden.

title: Speaking to Sharptons Group, Obama Emphasizes Principles
description: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois told several hundred black political organizers yesterday in Manhattan that African-Americans had been complicit in diminishing ourselves by talking about blacks in the same sort of degrading terms that the radio host Don Imus recently used about the Rutgers womens basketball team.

title: Thats Me!
description: To the Editor:

title: Affordable Europe: Brussels
description: Home to the European Union and NATO, Brussels is flush with big-spending bureaucrats in Armani suits. That has pushed up prices everywhere, from monthly rents to moules frites. Luckily, Europe's political capital still suffers from an inferiority complex, which means certain things remain affordable, like Belgium antiques and the 450 varieties of homegrown beer (strawberry brews, anyone?), some of which cost about 1 euro.

title: Jennifer Shepard, Michael Dovey
description: Jennifer Lynn Shepard, the daughter of Faith L. Shepard and Neal F. Shepard Jr. of King of Prussia, Pa., was married last evening to Michael Christian Dovey, a son of Terri A. Duval of Alta Loma, Calif., and John D. Dovey of El Dorado Hills, Calif. The Rev. Mark D. W. Edington, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard in Cambridge, Mass.

title: How the Worm Turns
description: Eureka, Calif.

title: Hoping to Curb Drug Trade at a Housing Complex, the Newark Police Move In
description: NEWARK, April 21  One man, in all seriousness, asked whether President Bush was here.

title: Affordable Europe: Rome
description: Rome may be steeped in history  few other capitals can offer an equivalent array of must-see-sights spanning several millennia  but prices have kept very much up to date (and in some cases seem to have factored in future inflationary tendencies). Budget travelers may be challenged, but there are still ways to see the city without breaking the bank.

title: Budget Approvals Rise, Up Sharply Over Last Year
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Not Reunions, Reinventions (Back and Better. Really.)
description: WAS that a queasy feeling you had recently, when you authorized payment on a $300 ticket for this summers Police reunion concert? What about that weird web of logic that made $249 for a three-day pass to the Coachella Festival next weekend seem an allowable expense, because youd be seeing Rage Against the Machine, the radical-leftist punk-funk band that wrote timely songs challenging the domination of real-life power structures ... until 2000, when it ceased to exist?

title: Never Let Me Go
description: It's always interesting to see what genre authors will get up to when they take a break from an established mystery series and write what their publishers designate a "stand-alone" book. P. D. James, the queen bee of the classic British detective story, surprised her readers with a futuristic thriller, "The Children of Men." Dennis Lehane wrote "Mystic River," a crime novel of such astonishing emotional depth that it put his career on a whole new track. Anne Perry, with three historical mystery series up and running, undertook a Christmas tale so charming that it led to yet another series. Robert B. Parker came out with a cookbook.

title: A Composer Whos Weathered Some Tempests of His Own
description: THREE years after he won the 2004 Pulitzer Prize for Tempest Fantasy, the composer Paul Moravec described that meditation on Shakespeares Tempest as a joyous piece, an optimistic piece that follows the trajectory of Prosperos story. It was, he suggested, an allegory for his own life.

title: Do No Harm
description: Ask people who have spent any time there and they will tell you this: The hospital can be a dangerous place. Families in waiting rooms will fill you in on the long list of delayed procedures. Patients will reel off complications suffered because of medical care. Doctors will warn of drug-resistant infections contracted only on the wards. And nurses, especially the seasoned ones, will urge you to do everything in your power not to land in the hospital in July, when the newest crop of interns are let loose on medical centers everywhere.

title: Theyre Here. Theyre Funny. Get Used to It.
description: AS many times as The Honeymooners has been parodied, its never been done quite like this. While Alice Kramden tends to her kitchen, her housekeeping duties are interrupted by the entrance of her bus-driving spouse  not a big lummox named Ralph, but her secret homosexual lifetime commitment partner companion, a woman named Rhonda. And when Alice pesters Rhonda for a new black-and-white TV set with rabbit ears, Rhonda delivers: She gives her wife an African-American transvestite wearing a white satin gown and, yes, rabbit ears.

title: Barbara Brush, Robert Murillo
description: Barbara J. Brush and Robert Murillo are to be married this afternoon at the Lauderdale Yacht Club in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Bishop Terry G. Villaire of the Catholic Church in America will officiate.

title: Inside the List
description: OUT OF PAKISTAN: Mohsin Hamids second novel, The Reluctant Fundamentalist (its reviewed this week by Karen Olsson), makes a mighty debut on the fiction list at No. 6. Hamids book has made news, in part because of the provocative opinions of its protagonist  a cultivated young Pakistani, working in New York after graduating from Princeton, who finds himself sympathizing with the 9/11 attackers. (He is pleased that someone has so visibly brought America to her knees.)

title: Model Child
description: To whom does a novel belong? There it is  an object of a certain size, shape and weight, its title, its authors name on the cover. So there can be, you would think, little doubt. Black & White, this one says, a novel by Dani Shapiro. So this novel belongs to, is made by, Dani Shapiro. So far, so good. But when I read Shapiros book, she is not with me. I have only her words, black marks on white pages, though in this novel her title should be taken to refer, of course, to the photographic images that have made its protagonist a celebrity, albeit an unwilling one. But art exists just as much in the mind of the reader (or beholder) as it does in the mind of its creator, if not more so. I once heard Margaret Atwood respond to an intricate question of interpretation with regard to the sexual politics of The Handmaids Tale with three simple words, dryly delivered: You tell me. Some might call that evasive; Id say its right on the money.

title: Affordable Europe: Moscow
description: Tourists on a budget face a fairly daunting hurdle when it comes to traveling cheaply in Moscow, one of the world's most expensive cities. It is all too easy to spend hundreds of dollars for a meal in Moscow, and hotels are no bargain either. Still, there are bargains to be had, even in the heart of the city.

title: Bluetooth Plays Matchmaker: M3, Meet MP3
description: FEW people get behind the wheel alone anymore. Many drivers wouldnt dare pull away from the curb without their cellphone, iPod or P.D.A.  mobile devices essential to life on the move, though not necessarily designed for use in cars.

title: A Building Binge for Bank Branches
description: IF youve ever seen a new storefront rising in your neighborhood and secretly hoped for, say, a new cafe or boutique, you might know the sinking feeling when  almost invariably, it seems  the business turns out to be a bank. Now, theres nothing wrong with banks, but, you might wonder: Dont we have enough branches already?

title: Early Retirement
description: A persistent legacy of baby-boom pop culture has been the sarcastic attitude embodied by the early days of Saturday Night Live: shockingly wicked derision that is at once smart and goofy. Thats the voice of Christopher Buckleys Boomsday, in which the Ungreatest Generation (according to the novels young protagonist) comes under attack by Americas under-30s, a generation Buckley suggests might be called Gen-W for its all-purpose, one-word barrier to any unwelcome or annoying circumstance  whatever.

This pre-adolescent era of jolly tastelessness is long distant, Im happy to say. But the news that BBC America has decided to remove The Benny Hill Show from its roster, in the belief that his brand of comedy reflected an older Britain, according to a company publicist, gave me a pang nonetheless.

title: A Grandson Paints a Portrait of a Portraitist

title: A Good Provider Is One Who Leaves

At 36, Emmet Comodas had lived a hard life without growing hardened, which was a mixed blessing given the indignities of his poverty. Orphaned at 8, raised on the Manila streets where he hawked cigarettes, he had hustled a job at a government sports complex and held it for nearly two decades. On the spectrum of Filipino poverty, that alone marked him as a man of modest fortune. But a monthly salary of $50 did not keep his family fed.

When John Corbin was killed, his wife took over at the cannon he had been firing and fought valiantly until she herself was shot.

title: A Heightened Summer Rush for Passports
description: First-time travelers to Europe used to have it easy. Obtaining an American passport might take four weeks, six at the most, but the Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative now means passengers traveling to Barcelona and Athens must compete with those winging it to Jamaica and Acapulco. The result is that getting a new passport can now take up to 10 weeks. As of late January, when the new regulations went into effect, it was estimated by the State Department that 73 percent of Americans did not have passports  a large number when you consider anyone returning by air from Canada, Panama, Mexico and most Caribbean islands now must have one to re-enter the country.

Although a cold, driving rain was falling, people had stuck folded notes and letters into the seam of the double door  none of which, I imagined, would be readable because of the weather. A single frosted globe-lamp was lighted on the parlor floor, as if left on for the anonymous visitors. The next morning, a clear and sunny one, four bouquets of flowers were draped on the stoops flight of steps.

Eye hoop they all have babies! he declares in what Mundy, a writer for The Washington Post Magazine, calls his wonderfully nonestablishment, workingmans burr. What coood be better than a baby?

There has been so much public attention to the obesity issue, she says, decreasing P.E. time is probably not politically correct for schools to do anymore. She cites some legislative bright lights: South Carolina has mandated at least 150 minutes of physical activity a week in elementary schools; California has announced incentive grants to hire about 1,100 new gym teachers. Two dozen states use the Praxis exam to certify phys ed teachers. The questions at left, from the Educational Testing Services practice exams, show what it takes. Answers are here.

When his grandfather opened his shop of the same name at the turn of the last century, there were dozens of tailors on Madrid's Calle de la Cruz, not far from the Puerta del Sol. Today, the street pulses with tapas bars and nightclubs, and Sesea is the only place on the block that recalls that earlier age, dedicating itself solely to the capa espaola.

title: Cold Currency

At 28, I looked as young  and as Chinese  as the students I was supposed to teach, and although I was raised in Singapore and lived in New York, I grew up in a family that spoke Mandarin and practiced Chinese customs. Any delusions I might have entertained about passing incognito, however, were quickly dispelled. Two weeks into my stay, I was negotiating the price on a camcorder battery when the shopkeeper cut me off with: Dont bargain. Youre rich. My branded clothes and spiked hair gave me away as a first-worlder; my relative affluence was not something I could hide. On the other hand, I doubt he knew I was gay.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: BURIED IN THE BITTER WATERS: The Hidden History of Racial Cleansing in America. By Elliot Jaspin. (Basic Books, $26.95.) Using the tools of his trade, computer-assisted reporting, Jaspin discovered a troubling demographic pattern: between 1890 and 1930, United States census data showed 260 suspect counties in which the black population appeared to fall suddenly by more than 50 percent. Jaspin ingeniously investigated the historical background of those statistical anomalies in 12 counties and found unequivocal evidence of mass racial expulsions. These incidents often began when the more familiar form of Jim Crow vigilantism, lynching, failed to satiate the mob's fury. The underlying motivation was usually economic competition. Two waves of intimidation in 1905 and 1909 that drove blacks out of Boone County, Ark., were typical. Ostensibly precipitated by crimes attributed to African-Americans, the expulsions followed closely on the arrival of an influx of unemployed black laborers. Why was this history "hidden"? Jaspin points out that the concept of "racial cleansing" is of recent vintage, and wasn't understood by contemporaries, including the N.A.A.C.P., as a distinct category of persecution. His implied analogy to the Balkan ethnic cleansing campaigns of the 1990s is imprecise, since these American atrocities seem to have been more spontaneous and isolated. But Jaspin passionately defends his use of the term, and he recounts a rancorous struggle with his employers at Cox Newspapers, who eventually published only expurgated versions of the articles that are the basis of this book. For Jaspin, who was later demoted from editor to reporter, this was "a demonstration of exactly how racial cleansings had come to be concealed in a thicket of lies, half-truths and euphemisms."
