title: Marci Etter, Andrew Stern
description: Marci Rene Etter and Andrew Howard Stern were married last evening. Rabbi Leora Kaye officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Laugh Lines: Jay Leno
description: JAY LENO

title: King of Delhi
description: By Central Asian standards, the 19th-century Mughal emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar II had some pretty impressive bloodlines. Put it this way: If the descendants of Tamerlane and Genghis Khan had held family reunions on the same summer Sunday, Zafar would have been expected to show up at each, lamb biryani in hand. Alas, Zafar  King of Delhi, Refuge of the Inhabitants of the World, Generous and Affectionate Killer of the Degenerate Infidels (perhaps these sound better in Persian)  was a case study in how even the finest thoroughbreds can beget an also-ran.

title: Turn on the Tap
description: Stony Brook, N.Y.

title: Still Suffering in Katrinas Wake (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Clings to an Old Ford
description: CANADAS government regularly steps in when major artworks are sold to foreigners. Now a 1905 Ford Model C is caught up in the countrys control over cultural property exports.

title: Cupfuls of Creativity Season Traditional Italian
description: SOLAIA, a new enoteca (wine bar) in Greenwich, is the second Italian restaurant I have visited within the last few weeks. Both have served appetizers of reasonable portions  that is to say, small-to-moderate, not the gargantuan servings that are standard at all too many restaurants. Id like to think this is a trend in the making, as most appetizers elsewhere are so huge they make the entrees that follow almost redundant.

title: Affordable Europe: Vienna
description: In the inner ring  the First District  of this Hapsburgian city, prices can feel frustratingly high. The key to low-cost Vienna is to step beyond the tourist paths of the pedestrian Graben and venture into the neighborhoods where the Viennese actually live.

title: How Diversity Makes a Team Click
description: WHEN consultants at Bain & Company are transferred to the Delhi office, they dont pack just their BlackBerrys and toothbrushes. Each one also receives a copy of a manual written by consultants who are, or have been, posted there. It spells out in precise consultant-speak suggestions for nightclubs, gyms and Hindi teachers. But it goes beyond that, by discussing meeting protocols, dress codes and telephone etiquette.

title: Colleges With Good Bottom Lines
description: To a first-timer, the letters that arrive in spring from financial aid offices can be a head-scratcher: no two packages are alike. Private institutions, especially, interpret family finances in different ways; some have deeper pockets; some fail to meet demonstrated need (the difference between the cost of attending and the amount a family is deemed able to pay, according to a need analysis formula). According to an annual College Board survey, the private colleges below provide aid packages that meet the highest percentage of need. In reviewing offers, remember: loans have to be paid back, grants do not.

title: Affordable Europe: Budapest
description: Straddling the Danube, Budapest is famous for its historic bridges, its immense Great Synagogue (the second largest in the world) and the ornate thermal baths dating back to the Turkish occupation. But it's not all ancient history: the Hungarian capital is also home to some of the best restaurants, clubs and cafes in all of new Europe. Though prices are frequently quoted in euros, the country still uses the forint, which provides some respite for travelers with dollars.

title: Two Rangers Rookies Are Providing Exuberance Amid Experience
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 21  Even when Rangers forward Ryan Callahan sits at his locker, he is in perpetual motion, tapping his skates or nodding his head. The manic energy he plays with is forced to idle until the next practice.

title: Progress on Immigration
description: Two important words to remember in the immigration debate in Congress are triggers and touchback. During last years ill-fated wrangling, the terms made the supporters of comprehensive reform bristle. The first refers to tough border-security benchmarks that the nation would have to meet before other parts of reform would kick in. The second refers to the requirement that illegal immigrants leave the country  even if only touching down briefly over the border  before re-entering on a legal footing.

title: An Enduring Strip of Green in an Ever-Evolving City
description: THE little patch of Bryant Park, which runs along the Avenue of the Americas from 40th to 42nd Streets, just behind the New York Public Library, is now surrounded by its own mini-building-boom.

title: Land Rovers Tadpole Turns Into a Prince
description: IN the Johnny Cash song A Boy Named Sue, the protagonist is inspired by the revelation that his deadbeat dad gave him that awful name because, I knew youd have to get tough or die.

title: The New 5-to-4 Supreme Court
description: AFTER the 5-to-4 decision last week in which the Supreme Court reversed course on abortion, upholding the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act, many court watchers were wondering what to expect next.

title: Bush Administration Gains Support for New Approach on Food Aid
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19  Waiters in white aprons maneuvered through a noisy cocktail party here Tuesday evening, offering heaping platters of jumbo shrimp, lamb chops and crab-stuffed mushrooms to a crowd of people in town for an annual food aid conference dedicated to ending world hunger.

title: A Lesson Before Dying
description: A callow youth, a mystical horse, a Civil War landscape  Robert Olmstead uses these familiar elements to fashion Coal Black Horse, an exciting if periodically overwrought coming-of-age novel. They are all brought together at Gettysburg when his 14-year-old protagonist, Robey Childs, is confronted with the grim aftermath of the fighting, in which there were 50,000 men who were killed, and wounded and missing from the rolls. They were in parts and pieces. They were whole and seemingly unscathed and wandering about as the future dead while others were vapor or grease or but rags of flesh and pulverized bone.

title: Allegra Cummings and Fredrick Redd
description: Dr. Allegra Cummings and Fredrick Redd were married yesterday afternoon at St. Lukes Episcopal Church in East Hampton, N.Y. The Rev. Darwin Price, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony with the Rev. John Best, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Peter Aupperle, Stewart Fishbein
description: Dr. Peter Mark Aupperle and Stewart Mark Fishbein are to be joined in civil union today in Mendham, N.J. Mayor Phyllis Florek of Mendham Township is to officiate at the Black Horse Tavern.

title: Tweens R Shoppers
description: IT is 11:15 a.m. The kids have the day off from school and Im mall crawling The Westchester in White Plains, with my posse: my 11-year-old daughter, Lake, and two of her friends, Annabelle Kirk, 11, and Eve Wulf, 12.

title: Iraq Is the Ultimate Aphrodisiac
description: PRESIDENT BUSH has skipped the funerals of the troops he sent to Iraq. He took his sweet time to get to Katrina-devastated New Orleans. But last week he raced to Virginia Tech with an alacrity not seen since he hustled from Crawford to Washington to sign a bill interfering in Terri Schiavos end-of-life medical care. Mr. Bush assumes the role of mourner in chief on a selective basis, and, as usual with the decider, the decisive factor is politics. Let Walter Reed erupt in scandal, and hell take six weeks to show his face  and on a Friday at that, to hide the story in the Saturday papers. The heinous slaughter in Blacksburg, Va., by contrast, was a rare opportunity for him to ostentatiously feel the pain of families whose suffering cannot be blamed on the administration.

title: Affordable Europe: Copenhagen
description: Prisbillig  that's the Danish word for cheap. Unfortunately, it's a word seldom heard in this Nordic city. One culprit is the powerful krone (or weak dollar). Another is the city's skyrocketing style quotient. An explosion of high-end hangouts and high-style buildings by name-brand architects  including Daniel Libeskind, Jean Nouvel, Zaha Hadid, Henning Larsen and Norman Foster  have helped make the Danish capital one of the planet's 10 most expensive cities.

title: Poetry Lovers, Coming Through (for) the Rye
description: YOUVE heard of singing for your supper. This is about rhyming for your bread.

title: A Rail Line Drives Development in Utah
description: MURRAY CITY, Utah

title: Poolside, Ripples of Discontent
description: In a corner of the small backyard behind his two-story house in Whitestone, Queens, City Councilman Tony Avella has an aboveground pool. He opens it each year around Memorial Day, holds family gatherings around it in summer, and covers it during the off-season with a blue tarp weighed down by detergent bottles filled with water.

title: Is Finger of Blame Unfairly Pointed at One Group?
description: There is always plenty of blame to go around when a team loses in the playoffs. This postseason, some of that blame has been directed at Russian stars: Ilya Kovalchuk of Atlanta, Alexei Yashin of the Islanders, even the Pittsburgh rookie Evgeni Malkin.

title: How About a Sleeping Beauty for Insomniacs (Sponsored by Ambien)?
description: The subscription series Girls Night Out was born at New York City Ballet last winter, but the description in the current brochure is much less sedate. Ladies, with this series you can plan to spend time with your best girlfriends and maybe even make some new ones, the blurb says, continuing with promises of plenty of girl talk with ballerinas. (Is nothing sacred? Do those girls get battle pay?) Oh, and theres also the beauty of the ballet, represented here by Romeo and Juliet and an all-Bach program.

title: Pocketing the Peoples Nickels
description: In 1978 most people bought bottled water only before a big storm, in case the electricity went out. That was the year the General Assembly decided to tack a nickel deposit onto containers of carbonated beverages like soda and beer. The laws purpose was to reduce litter, and it accomplished that.

title: Money Talks
description: Dana Vachons first novel begins with Tommy Quinn scanning the crowd gathered for the engagement party of his friend Roger Thorne. The 24-year-old casts his eyes on the investment bankers, the skinny women and their Botoxed mothers, the New York elite gathered at the Racquet & Tennis Club, a limestone manse sitting like a sphinx on Park Avenue. Quinn applauds himself for being on the most prosperous street in the most prosperous city in the most prosperous nation that ever lived. Standing on the clubs terrace he feels he is flying.

title: The Politics of Prose
description: BARACK OBAMA wrote very bad poetry in college. John McCain once contemplated joining the French Foreign Legion. John Edwards wanted to become a lawyer so he could defend the likes of the wrongfully accused Dr. Richard Kimble on The Fugitive. Rudolph W. Giuliani found the boxing skills his father taught him useful as a young Yankee fan, growing up blocks from the Dodgers stadium in Brooklyn. Hillary Rodham Clinton was a Brownie, a Girl Scout and a Paul McCartney girl, and wanted to grow up to be a teacher or nuclear physicist.

title: Repaying Alexander Hamilton
description: Walk through the historic Great Falls district of Paterson and you will get a feel for what life was like in the early days of industrial America. Theres the raceway, for example, a gradually sloping set of canals on three levels. As the water dropped from one level to another, it turned giant wheels that provided power to the mills.

title: Archie Bunkers Feisty Feminist Flip Side
description: FEMINISM first reared its lacquered head on a hit sitcom in 1966.

title: Should It Be So Hard to Tally Votes Fairly?
description: WITH the 2008 presidential campaign already making headlines, the question is how Westchester is going to vote. I mean that literally  not whether the county will vote Democratic or Republican, but actually how will those votes be cast, on what kind of machinery?

title: Opening a Courthouse, Overdue and Over Budget
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other officials dug ceremonial shovels into the ground in the summer of 2001 to mark the start of construction of a new Bronx courthouse, the building was projected to be finished in less than four years and to cost $325 million.

title: Cats in the Alley
description: THE evening began with a miscommunication. John Gallagher Jr., Jonathan Groff and Duncan Sheik of the Broadway musical Spring Awakening were sitting in a loud bowling alley. Each thought the other had suggested Harlem Lanes. In fact, no one had expressed a desire to bowl. Their publicist thought it would be cool.

title: Andrea Headley, Rama Rai
description: Andrea Jean Headley, the daughter of Shauna and Robert B. Headley of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., was married yesterday to Rama Singh Rai, a son of Carmen Singh Rai of Queens Village, Queens, and the late Latchman S. Rai. The Rev. William D. Eggers, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Hilton Rye Town, a hotel in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: A Fresh Start for the Stanhope
description: AS April showers taper off and the spring real estate season unfolds, there is new hope for the developers of the project that until recently was known as the Stanhope, the former Stanhope Hotel just across Fifth Avenue from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Letting the Architecture Speak for Itself
description: ANNOUNCING yourself to the doorman of a fabled Central Park West building, only to be directed to a rear elevator, far from Central Park, creates a momentary letdown. But disappointment vanishes as soon as Tom Killian and Franoise Bollack open the door to their apartment on the ninth floor of the El Dorado, between 90th and 91st Streets. Yes, their view is west, away from the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir and the Great Lawn. And, yes, their apartment entirely lacks the Art Deco details of the buildings glamorous lobby.

title: From Many Tweets, One Loud Voice on the Internet
description: ONLY connect, the English novelist E. M. Forster admonished mankind. I dont think, however, that he meant that we should connect exclusively, or continuously.

title: Jenny Huang and Roger Hong
description: Jenny Xiao Ling Huang was married yesterday to Roger Hong. Mark J. Wheeler, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Bowers Museum of Cultural Art in Santa Ana, Calif.

As Hotel Prices Rise, a Villa May Be a Bargain
description: EVER dream of vacationing in a European villa, set on a hillside vineyard in Tuscany or on a bluff, perhaps, overlooking the Mediterranean? This may be the year to book it.

description: Mamaroneck Grasps for Way to Avoid a Repeat

title: Affordable Europe: London
description: Unfortunately, the words affordable and London continue to be near antonyms, with the pound equaling a pricey $2. In fact, there are bargains to be had in Britain, even for those Americans arriving with a wallet full of depleted dollars.

title: The Believer
description: Q: As a professor of cultural theory at the University of Manchester in England, you reach some surprisingly sentimental conclusions in your new book, The Meaning of Life. Tell us, What does life mean? Perhaps the two strongest candidates for the answer to the question are happiness and love. But one of the terrible things about the word happiness is that it is so utterly feeble. It evokes the idea of people cavorting around with manic grins on their faces.

title: At Grange Hall, Preservation vs. Development
description: Meyersville

title: Lauren Peck, Aaron Dworkin
description: Lauren Rachel Peck, a daughter of Stephen D. Peck of Washington and the late Gayle S. Peck, was married yesterday to Aaron Philip Dworkin, a son of Susan L. Dworkin of New York and the late Moshe I. Dworkin. Rabbi Deborah Zecher officiated at the Cranwell Resort, Spa and Golf Club in Lenox, Mass.

title: On a Budget in London? Think Small
description: A NEWCOMER to London has to start with the premise that very little is affordable in this city. For starters, there is the 4 subway ride that will take you one stop. And then the check for a modest restaurant meal often looks eerily similar to what you might expect in New York: except the figure is in pounds not dollars, roughly doubling the cost.

title: Kristen Bancroft, Bruce Weinstein
description: Kristen Bancroft and Bruce Weinstein are to be married today at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Daniel E. Walker, a Pentecostal minister, is to officiate.

title: Town Takes Different Tack to Shut Down a Hotel
description: FOUR years ago, the Town of Hempstead began legal action to shut down the Courtesy Hotel in West Hempstead, claiming it was a public nuisance. But with the hotels owners having won three court decisions, the town has come up with a different tactic: to declare the hotel and surrounding area blighted and seize it through condemnation.

title: Correction: A Former Fortress Draws Crowds as a Cultural Capital
description: An article last Sunday about Luxembourg, this years European Capital of Culture, misstated the size of the county. It is 999 square miles, not 100 square miles.

title: Debate Over Etiquette as Earnhardt Takes a Spin in an Opponents Car
description: AVONDALE, Ariz., April 21  When Dale Earnhardt Jr. climbed out of his wrecked No. 8 Chevrolet and jumped into the No. 5 of Kyle Busch to race the final laps last weekend at Texas Motor Speedway, he turned heads, raised eyebrows and lighted up message boards across Junior Nation.

title: Clueless in the Senate
description: For a while last week it looked as if the Senate was finally going to wrestle itself into the digital age (and full public view) and require members to file their campaign fund-raising reports electronically. That is until Senator Unknown, Republican of Nowhere, put a hold on the bipartisan legislation.

title: Lives of the Democrats
description: For a politician, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, turns out to be a terrific writer. But for Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, the opposite is true.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The nonfiction best-seller list on Page 30 of the Book Review today gives an erroneous ranking for Blackwater, by Jeremy Scahill. It is No. 15. (There is no No. 16 on this weeks list.) (Go to List)

title: Correction: The Terrorism Fronts
description: A graphic last Sunday about developments in the war on terror reversed the pictures above two brief news reports. The photograph of a soldier standing with a rifle should have appeared with the report about a meeting of allied countries in Canada to discuss strategy for Afghanistan. The photograph of a soldiers face should have appeared with the report about an assertion by Pakistani generals that they had reclaimed some control of tribal areas bordering Afghanistan.

title: Correction: Chance and Circumstance Review
description: A review on April 1 about Chance and Circumstance: Twenty Years With Cage and Cunningham, by Carolyn Brown, misstated the composer of the music for Suite by Chance, a 1953 Merce Cunningham Dance Company piece. It was Christian Wolff, not John Cage.

title: Affordable Europe: Amsterdam
description: Amsterdam still harbors a strong bohemian and laid-back spirit, which means affordable options rarely found in other European capitals, from well-priced restaurants to free cultural events. And it's an easy city to navigate, thanks to its small size and the efficient Amsterdam Tourist Board (www.amsterdamtourist.nl), which, in contrast to some, is actually tourist-friendly.

title: Kelsie B. Harder, Name Expert, Dies at 84
description: Kelsie B. Harder, whose ruminations about why his parents gave him what sounded like a girls name provoked such enthrallment with proper nouns that he became a leading onomastician  a student of names and their origins  died on April 12 at his home in Potsdam, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Portland, Ore.
description: The 36 Hours column last Sunday about spending a weekend in Portland, Ore., gave an incorrect Internet address for Sip & Kranz, a coffee bar. It is www.sipandkranz.com.

title: Fitting Alaska Into the Bronx
description: AS librarians and collectors, Eric Holzenberg and Henry Raine cared most about space. Between them, they had not only books, but china, clocks, Alaska memorabilia and extra furniture, including a disassembled brass bed that was, like all of their stuff, too nice to get rid of.

title: Health Care Crisis
description: To The Editor:

title: Black Mountain Breakdown
description: Edward Dorn, who died in 1999 at 70, published more than two dozen volumes of poetry in his lifetime, all of them originally with small presses, most now ignored or forgotten except by a not terribly large coterie of longtime readers and other writers. Way More West, at over 300 pages, provides a more than ample retrospective of Dorns achievement.

title: Before Deadly Rage, a Life Consumed by a Troubling Silence
description: From the beginning, he did not talk. Not to other children, not to his own family. Everyone saw this. In Seoul, South Korea, where Seung-Hui Cho grew up, his mother agonized over his sullen, brooding behavior and empty face. Talk, she just wanted him to talk.

title: Paris Chic, on the Cheap
description: WHEN the 24-year-old James Baldwin arrived in Paris on Armistice Day in 1948, he came with big dreams, a little more than $40 in his pockets and no knowledge whatsoever of the French language. He discovered what he called years later a large, inconvenient, indifferent city still suffering from the fuel shortages and food rationing of the war.

title: Graceful Exit
description: Sometimes you can stand up to a political boss and win. Occasionally you can even do it twice.

title: Not Having a Lease Can Be a Good Thing
description: TO lease or not to lease. That is a question that landlords and tenants must answer whenever a market-rate apartment is being rented.

title: Commencement: Whats in the Air at Graduation?
description: IN 1912, for the first time, midshipmen graduating from the United States Naval Academy were awarded officers hats at commencement. No longer in need of their midshipmen caps, they spontaneously lobbed them into the air.

title: Correction: Pulse
description: An item last Sunday in the Pulse column about bags made of recycled vinyl billboards misspelled part of the manufacturers name. It is Vy & Elle, not Vy & El.

title: Amanda Cody and Mark Donohue
description: Amanda Katherine Cody, a daughter of Joy and Matthew Cody of Garden City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Avon Phillip Donohue, a son of Phillip and Ann Donohue of Brooklyn, N.Y. John J. McKenna, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at St. Joseph Church in Garden City.

description: JERSEY CITY

title: A Royal Behemoth Stumbles to Broadway
description: FOUR days before The Pirate Queen opened on Broadway, Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schnberg, the incredibly successful songwriting team, and John McColgan and Moya Doherty, the incredibly successful producing team, were sitting in a room at the Hilton Theater talking about Chicago.

title: Mortgages Mystery: The Losses
description: HAVE you noticed how quickly financial market crises come and go nowadays? Refco, the venerable commodities firm, disintegrated in a week in 2005 and last years demise of Amaranth, a $6 billion hedge fund, took about the same amount of time. It is a measure of how deep and wide the money pools are today that the billions lost at these institutions amounted to no more than a blip on a screen.

title: Authentic, or Expert Fake? Due Diligence May Tell
description: EYEBROWS rose in the collector car world early this year when Christies announced that an important Grand Prix racecar from the 1930s  with the potential to become the most expensive car ever sold at auction, Christies said  would be offered at the Retromobile exhibition in Paris. Presale publicity from the auction house set high expectations, anticipating bids from $12 million to $15 million, which would easily top the $8.7 million price of a Bugatti Royale sold in 1987.

Seeing the Sights on Jamaica Avenue; Poor People
and Criminality (3 Letters)

description: BAGHDAD, April 22  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Sunday that he was ordering a halt to construction of a wall that would blockade a Sunni Arab neighborhood in Baghdad from other areas, saying it reminded people of other walls.

description: YORKTOWN Heights

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (TV Land) 2007 TV LAND AWARDS My how theyve, um, grown. The Brady Bunch reunites to receive the Pop Culture Award  and to mix it up in a song-and-dance routine with Kelly Ripa, second from right above, the ceremonys host  at this fifth annual tribute billed as the ultimate celebration for the TV generation. Other nods go to Lucille Ball (the Legacy of Laughter award, accepted posthumously by her children, Lucie and Desi Arnaz Jr.), Hee Haw, Taxi, Heroes (the Future Classic award) and Roots, in honor of its 30th anniversary. Presenters include Carol Burnett, Valerie Bertinelli, Mackenzie Phillips, Sharon Stone, Morgan Freeman, Kirstie Alley, and Kathy Garver and Johnny Whitaker, a k a Cissy and Jody of Family Affair.

title: A Makeover in Progress, and Modern Art, Too
description: WHEN Emma Dewing and her husband, Kanoa Baysa, who had been renting an apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, decided to buy a home last year but realized they couldnt afford the size they needed in New York City, they refocused their search on towns strung along the commuter rail lines running north from Manhattan.

title: Giuliani Shifts His Tone on Immigration
description: DES MOINES, April 16  Rudolph W. Giuliani is a long way from Ellis Island.

title: In Big Mac Country, Gilded Age Yearnings
description: THE lunch crowd coursed along Fulton Street Mall in Downtown Brooklyn on Tuesday afternoon, a river of people bundled up in trench coats and athletic jackets. Some scurried toward the nearby Dallas BBQ restaurant. Others clutched takeout bags from White Castle. The line inside a corner pizza shop stretched almost to the sidewalk.

description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: MILANESE FEAST

title: Possibly Maybe
description: On the eve of the 2006 hurricane season, the National Hurricane Center forecast a hyperactive summer and fall, with eight to 10 Atlantic cyclones; instead there were five, smack on the 20th-century average. At the beginning of 2006, The Wall Street Journal forecast a bad year for stocks; the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 16 percent that year. (Disturbingly, The Journal has forecast a good year for 2007.) The British government recently said climate change could reduce global G.D.P. by 13.8 percent in the first year of the 23rd century. Not by 13.7 percent, not by 13.9 percent  by 13.8 percent. In response to an astronomers discovery, The New York Times in 2004 declared that the universe might have a peaceful end in tens of billions of years, but cautioned that it could not rule out the cosmoss exploding in a few billion years. Writing of the same discovery, The Washington Post predicted that the demise of the cosmos would require 30 billion years, adding this vital caveat: It remains impossible to predict the fate of the universe with certainty. Oh, so we cant be certain what will happen 30 billion years from now!

title: Who Needs Venice When Zagreb (or Bruges . . .) Beckons?
description: EXPECT to pay $14 for the Eiffel Tower. And more than $100 for a gondola ride through the canals of Venice. No, Europe's tourist capitals don't come cheap. To save some serious money this year, opt for Europe's lesser-known, second-tier cities. You might get a blank stare from less-worldly travelers when you mention Zagreb, but you'll score points in other ways, including your wallet.

title: Hyper-Articulate and Proud of It
description: CAN an excess of intelligence be a crippling force, creatively? Thats one of the questions haunting Poison Friends, a French psychological thriller by the writer and director Emmanuel Bourdieu, opening Friday in New York. In the film, Andr (Thibault Vinon), the brilliant ringleader of a band of Parisian graduate students, loves to quote a favorite dictum of the Viennese critic Karl Kraus, on why certain people write. Because theyre too weak not to write, he says.

description: BAGHDAD

title: Starting With Little Bunt, Mets Offense Goes a Long Way
description: Long before the long balls soared toward the construction cranes at the new stadium rising behind the outfield fence, the Mets began to beat the Braves yesterday with only a little bit of a hit at sunny old Shea Stadium.

title: All Those Who Wanted A-Rod Gone, Raise Your Hand
description: BOSTON

title: A Tennis Champion, and Neurologist, Whos Watching Your Back
description: WHILE traveling with his family in Africa several years ago, Dr. Brian Hainline, a neurologist and sports medicine expert with a practice in Lake Success, met a local medicine man in Korogo, a village in Ivory Coast.

title: Life of the Party
description: Leo Lerman once turned down an invitation from the king and queen of Spain so he could dine with the Cond Nast publishing magnate Donald Newhouse. Another time, he flatly rejected a Narcissus naked Yul Brynner, who was begging him to sleep with him and pathetically murmuring, Why wont you? Why wont you? The first, and probably only, woman Lerman ever saw naked was his great friend Marlene Dietrich, at a time when she was having what he described in a diary entry as an intense affair with Yul. According to Lermans lifelong love and partner, the artist Gray Foy, Dietrich had asked Lerman into her bath to demonstrate the female anatomy. Apparently, Lerman took in the view with respectful attention, if not passion. But he was not always so above-it-all. Meeting a young writer at a New York gathering in the mid-1940s, he complied with good humor when the man jumped on his back in a stairwell and demanded a piggyback ride. That man turned out to be Truman Capote. If you are not one of the sun-seeking stems craning out of the thicket of magazine-world Manhattan, this may raise an echoing question for you: Who is Leo Lerman?

title: In the Eternal City, Priceless Art for No Price at All
description: IT is hard to advise a visitor in Rome to skip the Sistine Chapel just because tickets cost $17 or that the line can last for hours. At the same time, in no other city can one wander, with completely empty pockets, and see at least nine works by various Michelangelos  among them the Piet by the more famous Michelangelo and a number of sly paintings by the only slightly less renowned one, better known as Caravaggio.

title: What Should a Chinese Car Look Like?
description: SHANGHAI

title: Red Sox Pound Yankees Soft Spot
description: BOSTON, April 21  Chien-Ming Wang threw 55 pitches on Saturday. Mike Mussina threw 30. Even Carl Pavano played catch.

title: Dream Catchers
description: MATTERS were simpler 100 years ago, when junior colleges were created to prepare deserving students for the final two years of a university. In fact, the very first public junior college, in Joliet, Ill., was set up in a high school, as the equivalent of grades 13 and 14.

title: Budget Hotel Chain Packs a Lot Into a Small Space
description: It might seem impossible to fit an extra long bed, a living area and work desk, and a Philippe Starck bathroom into a 75-square-foot space, but that is exactly what the owners of a new chain of high-tech, low-budget hotels have done. They are banking that Qbic, whose first hotel opens in Amsterdam next month, will be the next accommodation craze to sweep Europe.

title: Comings and Goings
description: He had six wives, gout, a feud with the pope and a heck of time producing a male heir. And on June 28  498 years after he acceded to the throne of England  Henry VIII will get his own permanent exhibition at the Hampton Court Palace outside of London. Young Henry VIII, the first segment of an exhibition honoring the 500th anniversary of Henrys reign, will feature paintings from the Royal Collection and audiovisual displays that explore the history of the Tudor Dynasty, the themes of war and European expansion, and Henrys personal life, including his relationship with Catherine of Aragon up to the arrival of Anne Boleyn. An exhibition covering the later years of Henry VIII is set to take place in 2008 and 2009 (www.hrp.org.uk). ... The Eurail Group is offering two new regional passes: Czech Republic and Germany, and Poland and Germany. The passes, which allow for 5, 6, 8 or 10 days of travel between two bordering countries within a two-month period, have first- and second-class versions. For example, the price for the second-class, five-day Germany-Poland pass is $320 per person (www.eurail.com). ... This summer, a 19th-century flour mill in Venice will make its debut as a luxury hotel. The Hilton Molino Stucky Venice, housed in a neo-Gothic Revival building along the Canale della Giudecca (above), will offer 380 rooms, a rooftop pool, and a private landing jetty. title: In College, Insurance Can Be Best Policy
description: Quarterback Brian Brohm thought about leaving college early for the N.F.L., but he decided to return for his senior season at Louisville. He is considered a near-certain first-round draft pick in 2008, maybe the best quarterback in the class, perhaps worthy of the first overall pick and the tens of millions of dollars of guaranteed money that comes with the honor.

title: Tech Expressions: Dance Pad
description: With clubs from U.C.L.A. to Cornell devoted to it, and almost 400 Facebook groups on the subject, Dance Dance Revolution is firmly entrenched as a college craze. Born as an arcade game and played with an Xbox or PlayStation 2, D.D.R. demands fast reflexes to keep up with furious on-screen directions. At a party at Northeastern University in Boston, Jenna Short and Dave Landry, above, competed for dance dominance; then Marybeth Miller took a solo turn. Ms. Miller confesses to playing alone in her room  a lot.

title: Jessica Mackta, Brian Smith
description: Jessica Lyn Mackta and Brian Eugene Smith were married yesterday at Asbury Lanes, a bowling alley and nightclub in Asbury Park, N.J. The Rev. Carolyn D. Nicholson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony

title: You and Me and Ali G
description: TOMORROW is the first day of TV-Turnoff Week, and Im conflicted. On the one hand, I want to comply. Its a cause that has my sympathy. On the other hand, television is one of the few places where my 15-year-old son, Asher, and I can hang out together. That might sound blighted, and the penurious nature of our present relations might be all my fault, but it is what it is. Some people have Paris. We have Animal Cops: Houston.

title: Skipping Along to a Victory, Mets' Prez Goes Without Walks
description: Oliver Prez has this superstition about foul lines. He avoids them. Ever since he was a Little Leaguer in Mexico, where he was warned not to step on the fresh chalk, Prez has skipped over foul lines on his way to and from the mound.

title: 36 Hours in Dublin
description: A pint of beer in Dublin will run you 4 to 5 euros, but the famed Irish wit is free. With an economic boom fueled by banks, high-tech companies and tourism, this compact Gaelic city is no longer the land of ramshackle pubs and baked-potato pushcarts. Stylish restaurants, designer hotels and pricey shopping malls abound. But Dublin's wealth has also brought with it an influx of Poles and other Eastern European immigrants, who are helping to keep prices in check, while also giving this ancient city a cosmopolitan face-lift. So expect phone-card kiosks next to old butcher shops and Slavic accents alongside the charming Irish brogues.

title: A Shady Plan by the Mayor Thats Likely to Be Popular
description: Among the list of contentious proposals that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce today in his ambitious effort to steer the city toward a greener future, heres one that is likely to receive little argument: more trees.

description: BAGHDAD, April 21  Gunmen killed the chairman of the Falluja City Council on Saturday, striking a blow to American and Iraqi efforts to develop a functioning representative government in the volatile western province of Anbar.

title: Tabloid Queen
description: Because she wrote a Pulitzer-winning memoir and presided over The Washington Posts evisceration of Richard Nixon, Katharine Graham is probably the best-known woman to have published an American newspaper. But long before there was Katharine Graham, there was Dorothy Schiff. From 1939 to 1976, Schiff owned The New York Post, transforming it from a money-losing broadsheet into a writerly and profitable tabloid, all while preserving the papers liberal tilt. Unlike Graham, she didnt inherit her paper, either, but bought it outright, albeit with inherited money and at the urging of her second husband. Her romance with the paper proved far more enduring than the marriage  and the two that followed, for that matter, and her countless love affairs, which Schiff used as both extramarital diversions and sorbet courses between spouses. (Her most famous paramour, though never confirmed, was Franklin Roosevelt.) Schiff didnt sell The Post until she was 73. A young Australian media magnate, Rupert Murdoch, bought it for $31 million and changed its ideological direction  though not its essential New Yorkness  forever. Or at least for the foreseeable future.

In the beginning is the fetus and the mother, and at the end there are the adults who have spent the past decades fighting about abortion, and who have been altered by their own hatreds, evasions and rivalries.

title: Intelligence on the Vine
description: The new, fourth edition of Wine for Dummies succinctly addresses developments in California, Washington, Argentina, Chile, Greece, Hungary and Spain. Periodically refreshed since 1995, this down-to-earth, entertaining consumer guide remains indispensable for novices and collectors.

title: Everything Conceivable
description: Every industrial convention has its own eccentric flavor, and the 2005 gathering of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine was no exception. That year the annual meeting of American fertility doctors was held in conjunction with the annual meeting of Canadian fertility doctors; the massive conference, which took place in Montreal over five days in October, was attended by emissaries from North America as well as from England, France, Europe, Japan, China, Africa, India, Asia, Israel: anywhere that humans live and wish, as humans usually do, to be fruitful and multiply. So numerous were the babymakers that airport immigration was bogged down and the city's downtown was transformed; the hospitality rooms of the Fairmont Queen Elizabeth were booked for events like "Cocktails with the Middle East Fertility Society." Converging on the downtown convention center, reproductive endocrinologists, embryologists, andrologists, urologists, therapists, and psychologists attended courses in packed seminar rooms. But the real action was in the cavernous exhibition hall, where an array of twenty-first century conception technology was on display, rivaling anything unveiled by the military-industrial complex.

title: The Black Swan: The Impact of the Highly Improbable
description: Before the discovery of Australia, people in the old world were convinced that all swans were white, an unassailable belief as it seemed completely confirmed by empirical evidence. The sighting of the first black swan might have been an interesting surprise for a few ornithologists (and others extremely concerned with the coloring of birds), but that is not where the significance of the story lies. It illustrates a severe limitation to our learning from observations or experience and the fragility of our knowledge. One single observation can invalidate a general statement derived from millennia of confirmatory sightings of millions of white swans. All you need is one single (and, I am told, quite ugly) black bird.

title: Paperback Row
description: EDGAR ALLAN POE & THE JUKE-BOX: Uncollected Poems, Drafts, and Fragments, by Elizabeth Bishop. Edited and annotated by Alice Quinn. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15. ) Although she published only some 90 poems in her lifetime, Elizabeth Bishop (1911-79), one of the most respected of American poets, won the Pulitzer Prize, the National Book Award and the National Book Critics Circle Award. She was gay, an alcoholic, an expatriate and essentially an orphan, but her poems  intimate without being selfrevelatory  hid the harrowing nature of her life. Edgar Allan Poe & the Juke-Box is a collection of previously unpublished poems and prose pieces culled by Alice Quinn, poetry editor of The New Yorker, from Bishops papers at Vassar College. Our reviewer, David Orr, called Quinns notes superb and said some of the poems here can stand alongside anything The New Yorker got its hands on back in the 1950s or 60s.

title: Why Was Imus Fired? Just Do the Math
description: Early on in the Don Imus firing controversy I took an abstinence pledge, vowing never to write anything about it. I now go back on that pledge, not because I have anything to say, but because there isnt anything to say, although almost everybody in the world has been saying a great deal. What I mean is that there are no serious issues that might be appropriately  as opposed to opportunistically  attached to this incident. The story should not be filed under free speech or racist speech or the culture of indecency or double standards; it should be filed under blunders with unexpected consequences, the subject of an earlier column about men and women who say or do something apparently small and even casual and find, sometimes within minutes, that their public lives are over.In Mr. Imuss case, what followed his disparaging of the Rutgers women basketball players was unanticipated not because he had intended no insult, but because intending insults has always been his line of work, and he had no reason to believe that this five-second instance of his ordinary practice would bring everything crashing down. Many commentators have said that Imus should have distinguished between his usual targets  Hollywood celebrities, politicians, sports icons  and 10 innocent and vulnerable young women. But this criticism assumes that behind what Imus said over the years was some kind of social or moral or philosophical calculation. There was nothing at all behind his daily performances; he was just occupying a professional niche  Don Rickles with a network  and doing exactly what he was paid to do.
