description: PARIS, April 23  The French presidential race is on  for the vote of the center.

title: A Medical Journal Punishes a Cardiologist for Allegedly Violating a Cardinal Rule
description: Among medical journals, the release of articles expected to make national headlines is an art form as carefully choreographed as kabuki. Which is why anyone who does not stay in step may be asked to sit down.

title: For Corzine, Solid Food and Playoffs
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine showed signs of improvement yesterday, his doctors and aides said, eating solid food for the first time since he was seriously injured in a car accident 10 days ago, conversing with his family and watching part of the New Jersey Devils playoff hockey game on television.

title: Outcry Over Wall Shows Depth of Iraqi Resentment
description: BAGHDAD, April 23  American and Iraqi officials appeared today to be moving away from a plan to build a wall around a mostly Sunni neighborhood here.

title: Prison Horrors for the Mentally Ill
description: The State of New York took a step toward basic human decency when it agreed to settle a lawsuit brought on behalf of mentally ill prisoners, who often endure horrific neglect and mistreatment. The settlement, which must be approved by the courts, provides for a range of welcome changes, including better care and monitoring for the severely ill people being held in solitary confinement or disciplinary lockdown, typically for 23 hours a day.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Finding the Sweet Spot in a Hall of Fame Swing
description: BOSTON, April 22  Alex Rodriguez has hit 476 home runs over 14 seasons in the major leagues. Kevin Long, the hitting coach who helped fix the flaws in his swing, hit 17 over eight seasons in the minors. Now Rodriguez, the Yankees third baseman, is off to perhaps the hottest start in baseball history.

title: Debates Losing a Bit of Luster in a Big Field
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The last time Jonathan Prince checked, there were nearly 40 requests for John Edwards, the Democratic presidential candidate for whom he works, to appear at a candidate debate or forum.

title: World Stage, Local Pride in the Pacific Northwest
description: SEATTLE, April 21  Its great to be home, Trisha Brown said at the start of a pre-performance talk. Ms. Brown has been a leading light of New York postmodern dance since the 1960s, but the home she meant was Washington State, where she grew up. When you consider that Merce Cunningham, Robert Joffrey and Mark Morris were also born here, and first studied dance here, you cant help wondering if some dance-friendly ingredient flows in the air. You wonder the same again when you recall that Seattles Pacific Northwest Ballet has been among Americas foremost ballet companies since the 1980s, reaching international stature in the 1990s.

title: Manhattans Trash (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa vs. Itself, in Race to Get Ready for World Cup
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 22  The World Cup of soccer is still three years away. But in South Africa, the site of the 2010 games, it already feels disturbingly close at hand.

title: Mozart, Sunny to Savage, Played by a Youthful Ensemble
description: A number of fine training orchestras, including the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, the New World Symphony, the Oberlin Conservatory Orchestra and iPalpiti, have recently played at Carnegie Hall. On Thursday night it was the turn of the UBS Verbier Festival Chamber Orchestra, an offshoot of the UBS Verbier Festival Orchestra, whose members are aged 17 to 29. The violinist Maxim Vengerov performed as soloist and conducted works by Shostakovich and Mozart.

title: Imams at the Airport (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Views Clash Among Neighbors as Builders Destroy Old for New
description: MASSAPEQUA, N.Y.  With the chain saw man working from above and the wood chipper man working from below, removing one of the last trees on the newly cleared lot at Bay Drive and Nassau Street here took all of an hour the other day. The 75-year-old, 100-foot cedar came down in 6-foot chunks that made a slight tremor underfoot when they hit the ground.

title: Nigeria Opposition Rejects Election Results
description: ABUJA, Nigeria April 23  The ruling partys candidate for president, Umaru YarAdua, easily won the election in Nigeria, election officials here announced today. But his chief rivals for the office immediately rejected the results, and international observers said that the polls, which took place amid chaos, fraud and violence, were not credible.

title: The Latest on Virginia Tech, From Wikipedia
description: IMAGINE a newspaper with more than 2,000 writers, researchers and copy editors, yet no supervisors or managers to speak of. No deadlines; no meetings to plan coverage; no decisions handed down through a chain of command; no getting up on a desk to lead a toast after a job well done.

title: The Mayors Ode to Earth Day
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg likes to talk about the big picture, even if it might not be pretty. Yesterday, he warned New Yorkers how their city could suffer by 2030 without his plans for the future. With a million new people coming into town, housing needs would soar. The sky could be as gray and toxic as London in the 50s. Every road into Manhattan would be above capacity  a gridlock nightmare that would make todays traffic jams look tame.

title: The Birth of the Breck Girl Story Line
description: The tale of John Edwards $400 haircuts may have ended  or at least his campaign hopes it ended  when Mr. Edwards told Iowans on Friday that he was embarrassed by the episode. It arguably began four years ago this weekend with a story in The New York Times about the White Houses strategy for dealing with prospective Democratic challengers to President Bush.

title: 9 Tough Tricks, and a Title for Shanghai
description: This years world bridge championships are in Shanghai beginning Sept. 29. And one week ago Shanghai won the Chinese Contract Bridge Association Open Teams championship, beating Qinggong in the 96-board final, 239 international match points to 211.

title: Jefferson Continues to Give Nets a Lift
description: TORONTO, April 22  Not long ago, when Richard Jefferson returned after missing 21 games because of an injured right ankle, he cautioned that he would not magically take the Nets to new heights.

title: Two New Producers, Lots of New Projects
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22  Ashton Kutcher is no Merv Griffin, not yet at least.

title: Evolution, on Broadway and Off
More Staff Cuts Expected at Chicago Tribune and Los Angeles Times
description: The Tribune Company is expected to announce staffing reductions as early as today at its flagship Chicago Tribune as well as its largest-circulation newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, as revenue in the newspaper industry declines.

title: Stock Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: No Giants Gear, Sorry, but Lots of Socks for Sale
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 22  When John Walls, a lifelong Giants fan, read that Jean Strahan, ex-wife of the superstar defensive end Michael Strahan, was having a garage sale at her stately mountainside mansion, he rushed here with his family in hopes of scoring some memorabilia.

title: Have Lenders Lost Students Trust? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg and Principals Union Reach a Deal
description: The Bloomberg administration and the union representing New York City school principals and assistant principals reached a tentative agreement today that would increase pay by 23 percent over nearly seven years, with bonuses of up to $25,000 a year to top-rated principals who agree to spend three years in troubled schools.

title: Police Supervisors Investigated
description: Two police supervisors are being investigated after officers accused them of referring to them as hos or a nappy-headed ho, the police said. One instance took place in the 70th Precinct in Brooklyn on April 15. The supervisor in that case has been transferred and stripped of supervisory duties, said Chief Michael Collins, a police spokesman. Chief Collins said the supervisor was accused of having addressed a group of officers jokingly as hos. The supervisor was identified by Bonita Zelman, a lawyer for the accusers, as Sgt. Carlos Mateo. In the second case, a Queens narcotics detective, Aretha Williams, said yesterday at a news conference that a sergeant recently told her, Dont give me no lip, or Ill have to call you a nappy-headed ho. The police, who did not release the sergeants name, said that case would be reviewed this week. The radio host Don Imus was fired recently by CBS Radio for his on-air description of members of the Rutgers University womens basketball team as nappy-headed hos. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said in a statement yesterday, This language is unacceptable under any circumstances and even more egregious when it comes from individuals in a position of authority. A representative of the Sergeants Benevolent Association contacted last night said he knew nothing about the accusations and declined to comment.

title: A Hostage Situation
description: There are two ways to describe the confrontation between Congress and the Bush administration over funding for the Iraq surge. You can pretend that its a normal political dispute. Or you can see it for what it really is: a hostage situation, in which a beleaguered President Bush, barricaded in the White House, is threatening dire consequences for innocent bystanders  the troops  if his demands arent met.

title: New Jersey Civil Unions (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: PC Games, Once Down, Show Signs of Rebound
description: Navigating the aisles of a GameStop video game store in Midtown Manhattan, Bennett Kirschner passed by the latest titles for consoles like Microsofts Xbox 360, Sonys PlayStation 2 and 3, and Nintendos runaway hit, the Wii  all lit and displayed like best-selling novels.

title: E. Dorrit Hoffleit, Scientist, Dies at 100
description: E. Dorrit Hoffleit, an astronomer who studied the features of stars visible to the naked eye, edited a standard reference on them and was probably the oldest working scientist in her field, died on April 9 at her home in New Haven. She was 100.

title: American Snared in Kazakh Legal Dispute
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, April 22  Mark Seidenfeld, a 39-year-old American, lived for years in this booming alpine city as a prominent telecommunications executive, one of thousands of foreign businessmen who shuttled around town in chauffeured sport-utility vehicles as they managed Kazakhstans transition from Communism to one of the most sophisticated market economies in the former Soviet Union.

title: Israels Finance Minister Steps Down During Investigation
description: JERUSALEM, April 22  Israels finance minister, Abraham Hirchson, said Sunday that he was leaving office for three months pending the outcome of a police investigation against him. The investigation involves suspicions that he embezzled funds before he joined the government, an Israeli police spokesman said.

title: Two Die and Four Are Hurt in Weekend Crashes
description: A Queens woman returning home with her family after a day at Coney Island was killed early yesterday when a man drove through a red light and struck a livery van the family was riding in, the police said.

title: When an Addict Finishes Detox (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan Stanley Names New Chief in Asia
description: HONG KONG, Monday, April 23  Morgan Stanley said Monday morning that Stephen S. Roach, the banks chief economist, would move to Hong Kong from New York and become the chairman of its Asia operations, in the latest sign of Asias growing economic and financial importance.

title: P.G.A.s Digital Evolution
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., April 22  The pine- and palm-tree-shaded headquarters of the PGA Tour, nestled on more than 400 acres that include two golf courses, has recently taken on the buzz of a NASA launch pad. Talk of putts, pars and tee shots has turned to gigabytes, gigahertz and light-emitting diodes.

title: Older Voters Chose Sarkozy, While Young Picked Royal
description: PARIS, April 22  Almost half of French voters over age 70 cast their ballots on Sunday for the conservative candidate for president, Nicolas Sarkozy. Almost 30 percent of those ages 18 to 24 favored Sgolne Royal of the Socialist Party.

title: Democrats Agree to Send Bush Iraq Timetable
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Congressional Democrats agreed today to ignore President Bushs veto threat and send him a $124 billion war spending bill that orders the administration to begin pulling troops out of Iraq by Oct. 1. On Iraq, the American people want a new direction, and we are providing it, said Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, a leader of the Congressional negotiators who came to terms on the legislation that has become a test of wills between Mr. Bush and the new Democratic majority on Capitol Hill.

title: Finding Her Inspirations Long Ago and Far Away
description: The Canadian singer-songwriter Loreena McKennitt respects old ways: old nomenclature, customs, languages, architecture, literature. She has written songs that adapt verse from, or climb inside the heads of, Homer, Dante, Shakespeare and Tennyson. In her love of craftsmanship she seems bigger-souled than your average pop star; her way of praising her band, onstage at Radio City Music Hall on Friday night, was to suggest that its abilities were much greater than needed to play her simple music.

title: Former Media Executives Give New Life to Blank Check Corporations
description: Time was that former media executives were offered consulting contracts, partnerships at private equity firms or book deals. Now, they are being offered a blank check.

title: New Model for Sharing: Free Music With Ads
description: For years, music labels have been trying to prevent fans from downloading their songs on peer-to-peer file-sharing networks. Now, some of them would like to encourage people to listen to music that way  provided they view some advertising first.

title: Braves Bullpen Secures Victory Over Mets
description: The Mets bullpen has been like a life preserver since last season. When the starters have taken on water, so to speak, the Mets have been able to hang on to games with their relievers, who have earned a reputation as one of the best corps in the major leagues.

title: Cold Shoulder Toward Bonds, Perhaps Deserved, Hurts Baseball
description: In a month, maybe two, Barry Bonds is likely to break the most prestigious record in team sports. He will pass Hank Aaron to become the career home run leader and set a mark that may not be surpassed until late in his own lifetime. Bonds hit his 739th career home run Saturday in San Francisco and No. 740 yesterday.

title: His Own Pope Yet?
description: WITH little fanfare, Benedict XVI will tomorrow mark the second anniversary of his formal installation as pope, a threshold at which his immediate predecessors had established themselves in the public mind. Yet he remains an enigma to many who thought they knew him well, and something of a blank slate to a world curious to see what this new pontiff would be like.

title: TurboTax Software Slows Just as the Big Deadline Nears
description: When thousands of users of TurboTax software from Intuit found themselves mired in a computer slowdown as they tried to file returns at the deadline last week, the company faced a storm of anger over the inconvenience and potential penalties.

title: In Dallas, Commercial Radio Without Commercials
description: Facing increasing competition from satellite radio and iPods, Clear Channel Communications is trying something radically different at a commercial radio station in Texas: getting rid of the commercials.

title: A Maestro of Investments in the Style of Buffett
description: CHICAGO  Warren E. Buffett is hardly a man of mystery.

title: With Only Days to Stump, 3 Seek Brooklyn Council Seat
description: The campaign posters have just begun appearing in store windows along the major thoroughfares of the Flatbush and Crown Heights neighborhoods in Brooklyn. The campaign sound trucks that typically snake through the streets before an election are nowhere to be found.

title: Looking Ahead
description: QUARTERLY REPORTS A decline in oil and gas prices is expected to translate into lower profits for the big oil companies. Earnings are scheduled to be reported by BP (Tuesday), ConocoPhillips (Wednesday), Exxon Mobil (Thursday) and Chevron (Friday). Lower oil prices may help the profits of transportation companies, including the airlines JetBlue (Tuesday), UAL (Wednesday) and US Airways (Thursday).

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Disturbia Rules the Box Office

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 22, 2007

title: Obama Outlines His Foreign Policy Views
description: CHICAGO, April 23  Senator Barack Obama said today that even though the global image of the United States has been sullied by the war in Iraq and a foreign policy based on a flawed ideology, America must repair its standing in the world and resist the temptation to turn inward.

title: Devils Spread Load to Eliminate Lightning
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 22  On days like this, it is hard for Devils center Scott Gomez to picture himself gone. For seven years, the Devils have been the only team Gomez has known. He has been around long enough to have grown almost blas about goaltender Martin Brodeurs brilliance and the teams closeness and the franchises postseason success.

title: Rancor Rises Over Santa Barbara Newspaper
description: LOS ANGELES, April 22  An ugly conflict involving a wealthy local publisher turned even uglier Sunday as The Santa Barbara News-Press published a front-page article suggesting that the papers former editor had kept child pornography on his work computer, a claim that the editor promptly denounced as malicious.

title: Hallelujah Indeed: Debating Handels Anti-Semitism
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 20  It is a rare musicological debate that quickly rises to broader public attention. Two classic examples in recent decades took place at conventions of the American Musicological Society in Boston, and both involved not only volatile issues but also combative personalities. In 1981 Joshua Rifkin and Robert Marshall locked horns over the size of Bachs choruses, Mr. Rifkin arguing that Bach would typically have used only one singer per part. In 1998 bellicose defenders of the authenticity of the disputed claim that the book Testimony represented the actual memoirs of Dmitri Shostakovich as related to and edited by Solomon Volkov met with ferocious opposition from Richard Taruskin and others.

title: New Measures of Poverty (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Boris Yeltsin, Russias First Post-Soviet Leader, Is Dead
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the burly provincial politician who became the first freely elected leader of Russia and a towering figure of his time when he presided over the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the demise of the Communist Party, has died at the age of 76, the Russian government said today.

title: Read Fortunes Portfolio or Portfolios Fortune
description: Maintaining a brand name in the business world is not always easy, especially when the name is also a common word. Last week two rival business magazines  Fortune and Portfolio  saw their names bump up against each other a bit.

title: Voting Sets Up Left-Right Duel to Lead France
description: PARIS, April 22  Nicolas Sarkozy, the conservative, and Sgolne Royal, the Socialist, won the first round of the presidential election on Sunday, setting up a classic left-right contest next month between two candidates with competing visions of how to govern France.

title: Words as Weapons
description: Just days after Don Imus was taken off the air for a slur hurled at members of the Rutgers womens basketball team, a police sergeant conducting a roll call at a precinct in Brooklyn is reported to have called the three female officers in the room hos as he gave them an order to stand up.

title: Parry OBrien, Pioneer in Shot-Putting Technique, Dies at 75
description: Parry OBrien, who revolutionized shot-putting technique, won three Olympic medals (two gold) and became the first man to reach 59, 60, 61, 62 and 63 feet, died Saturday during a masters swimming race in Santa Clarita, Calif. He was 75 and lived in Rancho Belago, Calif., west of Palm Springs.

title: Francona Uses His Power of Suggestion to the Benefit of the Red Sox
description: BOSTON, April 22  From his position inside the first-base dugout at always cozy and often crazy Fenway Park, Red Sox Manager Terry Francona has watched hundreds of pitchers search for outs. Francona knows how uncomfortable it can feel in a park where the 37-foot-high fence in left field feels as if it is barely behind shortstop.

title: After 44 Years, Pitcher Gains a Partner in the Record Book
description: BOSTON, April 22  Paul Foytack was watching the N.B.A. playoffs Sunday night, but he switched to the Yankees-Red Sox game during a commercial. He saw Manny Ramrez hit a home run before shifting back to the basketball game. That is how Foytack missed history. History that he was a part of.

title: U.S. Says Wiccan Symbol Can Appear on Veterans Headstones
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  To settle a lawsuit, the Department of Veterans Affairs has agreed to add the Wiccan pentacle to a list of approved religious symbols that it will engrave on veterans headstones.

title: Spitzer Plans to Introduce Gay Marriage Bill
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer will introduce a bill in the coming weeks to legalize same-sex marriage in New York, his spokeswoman said Friday, a move that would propel New York to the forefront of one of the most contentious issues in politics.

title: The Greater (and the Lesser) Considered at the Ad Summit
description: NAPLES, Fla.

title: Deadlines, War Money and Pork
description: President Bush is taking every opportunity to rail against the troop withdrawal deadlines in the war-spending bills that Congress is readying for passage. He warns that Congressional attempts to set deadlines will harm the troops in Iraq, because a political fight over timetables will delay money needed for the frontlines.

title: Brooklyn: Boating Victim Identified
description: A man who died on Saturday afternoon after falling from a boat into Jamaica Bay was identified by the police yesterday as Charles Rosenberg, 37, of Hewlett. Mr. Rosenberg fell from a boat about 400 yards from the Canarsie Pier, the police said. Mr. Rosenberg and another man, who was not named by the police, fell into the water about 4 p.m., the police said. The other man was rescued by another boat and was taken to Peninsula Hospital Center, where he was in stable condition on Saturday. Police rescuers pulled Mr. Rosenberg from the water, and he was later pronounced dead at Staten Island University Hospital, the police said.

title: Can You Say My Wife Doesnt Understand Me in French?
description: In Lust in Translation, a global survey of how adultery varies from place to place, Pamela Druckerman quotes this advice for women who cheat on their men: Try not to look too happy. If you never sang in the shower, dont start now.

title: Virginia Tech Students Return to Classes
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 23  Classes resumed at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute campus today, on a morning marked by a moment of silence, the release of balloons, and the tolling of bells, one for each of the 32 people shot to death on the campus a week ago.

title: For the Record
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: New CDs
description: ARCTIC MONKEYS Favourite Worst Nightmare (Domino)

title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Virginia Tech Struggles to Recover From Shootings
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 22  A girl in an orange and maroon bikini basked in the sun less than 20 feet from the Virginia Tech dorm in which one of the worst massacres in American history had begun.

title: After Deadly Week, Canada Debates Role in Afghanistan
description: SARNIA, Ontario, April 20  The sound of bagpipes and drums and the slow footsteps of 1,200 mourners marked the beginning of the journey from church to cemetery here on Friday for the body of Cpl. Brent Poland, who was killed in Afghanistan on April 8.

title: Fire at Orphanage in Sarajevo Kills 5
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, April 22  A fire in a downtown orphanage in Sarajevo, Bosnias capital, killed five babies and injured 19 others on Sunday, the chief prosecutors office said.

title: Five Home Runs, One Big Sweep for Red Sox
description: BOSTON, April 22  At 76 years old, George Steinbrenner does not roar the way he used to. But as the Yankees stagger into Steinbrenners territory for a series with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, the principal owner cannot be pleased.

title: Mayor Bloomberg Proposes Charging to Drive in Parts of Manhattan
description: As part of his plan to create what he called the first environmentally sustainable 21st-century city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed charging drivers who travel below 86th Street in Manhattan. A similar system is in place in congested parts of London and Singapore.

title: Virginia Tech Students Return to Classes
description: Classes resumed after a moment of silence and the tolling of bells in memory of the victims of the massacre.

title: Living at St. Andrews
description: Grand

title: 39 Steps to Cross the Atlantic
description: With four actors playing its 150 roles, the prize-winning London adaptation of the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock thriller "The 39 Steps" is bound for Broadway after a stop in Boston, Theatre.com reported.

title: A Joint Venture Beyond Cars
description: One of the auto industrys most powerful leaders found inspiration in a competitors backyard during a visit to Detroit this week.

title: For One UBS Media Banker, Business Gets Personal
description: One UBS media banker has gotten a crash course on what its like being on the other side of the business. Aryeh Bourkoff, who on May 1 officially moves from the analyst side to his new position as vice chairman of technology, media and telecommunications investment banking at the bank, has scored a producer credit on a film directed by his mother that will show at the TriBeca Film Festival this week.

title: No Extension for Qantas, Bidders Say
description: The private-equity consortium that is struggling to complete a takeover of Qantas Airways in Australia said Sunday that its bid would not be extended beyond May 4. The consortium, whose bid of 10.82 billion Australian dollars ($9.06 billion) has been opposed by two major investors, also announced a range of incentives aimed at achieving the revised 70 percent minimum share target it unveiled on April 12 when it extended the bid two weeks.

title: A Maestro of Investments in the Style of Buffett
description: When investors gather in Omaha, Neb., in two weeks for the Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, the chairman, Warren E. Buffett, will face what has become the annual question: who might someday succeed him in each of the two roles he plays  chief executive and chief investment officer?

title: A New Life in Media for Blank Checks
description: Time was that former media executives were offered consulting contracts, partnerships at private equity firms or book deals. Now, they are being offered a blank check.

title: China Citic Banks $5.4 Billion in I.P.O.
description: China Citic Bank sold $5.4 billion of stock in the worlds biggest offering this year, according to Bloomberg News. The bank, one of the 10 largest in China, sold shares in Shanghai and Hong Kong on Friday, raising the maximum it targeted,the report said, adding that the sale values the state-owned company at $28.9 billion.

title: Calpine Bondholders Agree to Reduce Claims
description: Calpine, the bankrupt power generator, said it had reached a preliminary settlement with a group of bondholders that would eliminate a large group of duplicate claims filed in its bankruptcy case. The settlement, which requires United States bankruptcy court approval, will reduce $12 billion in claims tied to bonds in a Calpine unit to a single claim of $3.5 billion, the company said. Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif., also said it would seek approval from HSBC Bank, the indenture trustee on the bonds.

title: McDonalds Sells Latin American Units to Investors
description: McDonalds said Friday it had agreed to sell virtually all of its 1,600 restaurants in Latin America and the Caribbean to an Argentine businessman who has run McDonalds outlets in Argentina for 20 years.

title: Getting Out of Hedge Funds
description: In an echo of Nick Carraway in F. Scott Fitzgeralds The Great Gatsby, The New York Times asks: When it comes to hedge funds, do the extremely rich know more than the rest of us? The Times refers to a report from Bloomberg Markets that says that while institutions are increasing their holdings in hedge funds  and some of the largest hedge funds are planning to sell shares to an eagerly awaiting public  the wealthiest Americans have been bailing out.

title: Fortress Drives off With Interpool
description: the Fortress Investment Group, the private equity and hedge fund manager that went public in February, has agreed to buy Interpool for $2.4 billion. Through several of its private equity funds, Fortress is bidding $27.50 in stock and debt for Interpool, a transportation equipment and services company based in Princeton, N.J. Interpool said that the deal represents a 6 percent premium over its closing price on Friday of $25.59.

title: Caldwell Takes Stake in Winnipeg Exchange
description: Caldwell Investment Management, one of Canadas best known investors in stock and commodity exchanges around the world, is buying a small stake in the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, possibly as a prelude to going after more of the privately owned bourse.

title: Terra Firma Is Said to Plan Bid on British Hospitals
description: Terra Firma, the British private equity group trying to trump the 10.6 billion pound ($21.2 billion) takeover bid accepted by the directors of the British drugstore chain Alliance Boots, is also bidding to buy Bupas hospitals, The Guardian said.

title: UniCredit Denies Merger Talks With Societe Generale
description: UniCredit, Italys biggest bank, said Friday it was talking with Frances Societe Generale about growth opportunities, but denied rumors the banks were discussing a merger. Market rumors about the banks intensified throughout the day, sending the shares of both surging, and set off a chain reaction that lifted other bank stocks.

title: Cerberus Buys H&R Blocks Subprime Lender
description: H&R Block said Friday it would sell its subprime lender, Option One Mortgage, to a private equity firm, Cerberus Capital Management, sending the tax preparers shares up as much as 8.2 percent. The sale price depends on the value of the mortgage assets when the sale closes, but will likely be below $1 billion and perhaps as low as $700 million or $800 million, one analyst told Reuters.

title: Chinas Simcere Rises 11% in N.Y.S.E. I.P.O.
description: Shares of a Chinese drugmaker, the Simcere Pharmaceutical Group rose as much as 11 percent in its stock market opening in the United States on Friday, a day after pricing at the top of the forecast range. The American depositary shares opened at $15 and climbed as high as $16.05 in morning trade on the New York Stock Exchange. Simceres results break a recent string of disappointing initial public offering results from China triggered by a sell-off in February.

title: When Lawyers Bring Conflicts to the Table
description: When it comes to throwing brickbats, DealBook doesnt discriminate.

title: Southern California Takes Silver in the Latest V.C. Race
description: Southern California is starting to muscle out New England for second place behind Silicon Valley as a magnet for venture capital. A report scheduled to be released Monday by the research and consulting firms Ernst & Young and Dow Jones VentureOne underscores Southern Californias attractiveness, especially to financiers of the healthcare and biotechnology industries in San Diego County and information technology firms in Los Angeles.

title: China Adds Billionaires With I.P.O.
description: After more than two decades of spectacular economic growth, China has a rising number of entrepreneurs who are forming private companies, going public and getting extremely rich. But the family of Yang Guoqiang, a dirt-under-the-fingers property tycoon, may be the richest yet.

title: Another Buyout May Sink Intelsat, Critics Say
description: Speculation last week that Intelsats owners are seeking a sale to private equity firms has raised concerns among industry watchers about the future of the satellite services operator, The Deal.com says.

title: British Airways May Make a Play for Iberia
description: British Airways is considering a bid for Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana of Spain along with a group of private equity investors to protect its interest in the carrier. British Airways said it had approached a number of private equity companies. The airline has not made a final decision on the future of its 10 percent Iberia stake and may sell the holding, the company said.

title: Morgan Stanley Appoints Asia Chairman
description: Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, who predicts China will overtake the United States as the worlds dominant economy within two decades, will become the firms Asia chairman, leading a push to arrange more takeovers and stock sales in the region. Mr. Roach, 61, will take up his post in June and move to Hong Kong in September, Morgan Stanley said in an e-mailed statement. He replaces Alasdair Morrison, who retired this month.

title: Chrysler Employee Group in Buyout Maneuvers
description: A group of Chrysler workers that has proposed an employee-led buyout of the company is apparently looking to hook up with one of the possible bidders for DaimlerChryslers United States unit. The Los Angeles Times reported that billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, who has thus far been shut out by DaimlerChryslers board, is planning to meet with the group, which calls itself the Employee Buyout Committee.

title: Consumer Group Cries Foul on Googles DoubleClick Deal
description: A consumer group asked the Federal Trade Commission on Friday to investigate and block Googles proposed $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick unless the companies improve consumer privacy protections.

title: More Cuts Expected at Top Tribune Papers
description: Tribune, which has agreed to be taken private in an $8.2 billion deal, is expected to announce staffing reductions as early as Monday at its flagship Chicago Tribune as well as its largest-circulation newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, as revenue in the newspaper industry declines.

title: As I.P.O.s Boom, New York Markets Defend Their Turf
description: With the surging market for initial public offerings expected to pick up even more momentum this year, stock exchanges in the United States are campaigning to win the new listings, The Associated Press reports. The Nasdaq Stock Market and the New York Stock Exchange said the first quarter turned out to be one of the best on record for public offerings since the dot-com boom that ended in 2000. There were 64 offerings that raised $12.1 billion during the period.

title: AstraZeneca to Buy MedImmune for $15.2 Billion
description: AstraZeneca, the British drugmaker, agreed Monday to buy MedImmune, an American biotechnology company, for $15.2 billion to gain flu vaccines and an antiviral treatment for babies. Shareholders in MedImmune, which makes the flu vaccine FluMist, will receive $58 a share, a 21 percent premium over the closing price on Friday of $48.01 a share.

title: Foot Locker Steps Up With $1.2 Billion Bid for Rival
description: Rampant deal speculation surrounding Foot Locker came true Friday, but not necessarily in the way that many had expected. The sneaker retailer, which has long been rumored to be a takeover target, made an unsolicited $1.2 billion bid for Genesco, a company that owns the teenager-focused Journeys sneaker chain and the Johnston & Murphy brand of dress shoes.

title: Congress Gets Ready for the Veto
description: Its not often that Congress devotes so much time and energy to legislation that is doomed.

title: Waiting Is the Hardest Part
description: Building a dream house is not for those who buy their morning coffee at Dunkin Donuts because Starbucks takes too long.

title: David Halberstam
description: Mr. Halberstam came into his own as a journalist in the 1960s covering the Vietnam War.

title: Putting the F Back in F.D.A.
description: Seeking to explain some prominent recent lapses in the governments food safety operation, The Washington Post finds no failures of imagination, no series of missed signals or any of the other usual explanations.

title: Barclays Agrees to Buy ABN Amro in $91 Billion Deal
description: ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by Barclays of Britain in a $91 billion deal that would be the largest financial-services merger in history. To fend off a rival group of bidders seeking to break up the 183-year-old bank, ABN Amro and Barclays struck a separate agreement Sunday to sell the LaSalle Bank of Chicago, a unit of ABN, to the Bank of America for more than $21 billion.

title: A Too-Sweet Deal for Educational Lenders
description: No more classes, no more books, no more subsidization of private student-loan lenders: Why continue to subsidize these firms? asks a Washington Post editorial. Currently, universities can participate in the public-private program, in which private lenders pony up the principal and collect low-interest payments from students while receiving a government subsidy that, in effect, increases the interest these companies receive. Or universities can choose to have their students borrow money directly from the government. Either way, Congress sets the general interest rates students pay on most loans. And the Congressional Budget Office and the Office of Management and Budget have both concluded that the governments direct lending program is significantly cheaper for taxpayers. The editorial continues:

title: Bidders Raise Offer for Affiliated Computer
description: The group staging a management buyout of Affiliated Computer Services, the technology services provider, raised their bid on Monday to $62 from $59.25 a share, saying that the companys board had rejected an earlier proposal.

title: Rival Suitors For ABN Amro Postpone Meeting
description: Most of the players may be in Europe, but a bank in Chicago was stealing much of the focus Monday as ABN Amro agreed to a $91 billion merger with Barclays.

title: 2008: Prep Time
description: Candidates in the 2008 field this week have a fairly busy schedule, and some of them  those who are sitting senators  have a separate, full week of work, too.

title: Hotel Frenzy
description: The current construction craze along Las Vegas strip is driven by a 95 percent weekend occupancy rate.

title: Edwards Still Paying the Barber
description: Haircuts never over: Maureen Dowds mockery of John Edwards as an aspiring metrosexual in chief for his $400 haircuts (a $400 haircutters house call, to be precise) has prompted a blogburst of reactions. The Washington Monthlys Kevin Drum breaks down the  four different schools of thought about this in the liberal blogosphere.

title: Goldman Unit to Acquire Icahns Nevada Casinos
description: Chalk up another deal for Carl C. Icahn. American Real Estate Properties, a unit of Mr. Icahns American Real Estate Partners, said Monday it was selling its Nevada gaming operations to Whitehall Street Real Estate Funds, an affiliate of Goldman Sachs for $1.3 billion.

title: Dutch Unions Throw Support Behind Barclays Bid
description: Dutch unions would rather see Barclays succeed in its bid to buy the Dutch bank ABN AMRO as fewer job cuts are expected compared to those expected under a rivals bid, Dutch union groups said on Monday.

title: The Birth of the Breck Girl Story Line
Wendy Heller on Handels Messiah
description: On April 8, The New York Times published an article by Michael Marissen, a professor of music at Swarthmore College, arguing that Handel's "Messiah," and the "Hallelujah" chorus in particular, rejoices in the misfortune of Judaism with an over-the top triumphalism. On April 20, Mr. Marissen presented a longer version of the argument in a paper at a session of the American Handel Festival 2007 at Princeton University. Dissenting responses to the paper were offered by the Handel specialists Wendy Heller, addressing the musical aspects of the argument, and Ruth Smith, addressing the theological aspects. The Times has invited Ms. Heller and Ms. Smith to respond briefly to the earlier article as well. Ms. Heller's response follows.

title: Defining Boris Yeltsin
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the first elected leader of the Russian Federation whose death was announced today, always gave historians fits.

description: Voters in the tiny Buddhist nation chose among dummy parties in a rehearsal for multiparty elections next year.

title: Movin on Up
description: With the budget battles now a few weeks in the past, Gov. Eliot Spitzers favorability and job approval ratings have bounced back up in the latest Siena poll. Two-thirds of New Yorkers view Mr. Spitzer favorably, and 55 percent say he is doing an excellent or good job as governor. The bad news? 62 percent of the respondents said this years budget shows that nothing has really changed in Albany.

title: Revolving Door: Texas Pacific, Carlyle, Jefferies
description: The Texas Pacific Group is already working on one big deal in Spain, and there is likely to be mas where that came from. The United States-based private equity firm, which offered $4.5 billion for the Spanish airline Iberia late last month, said Monday it had named a senior adviser in Spain whose prime objective is identifying possible investment opportunities. The firm, also known as TPG, said Alfonso Cortina would be based in Madrid and serve as its main represenative in the Spanish market. Mr. Cortina, who was chairman of the Spanish-Argentinean oil company Repsol YPF until 2004, is also a European adviser to Rothschild, the investment bank.

title: Business Objects to Buy Cartesis for $300 Million
description: In a deal that seems to have won only praise from analysts, Business Objects, a French-American software company, said it would acquire Cartesis for about $300 million in cash, bolstering its presence in financial enterprise software. Business Objects, which makes so-called business intelligence software, has felt pressure to cut a deal since Oracle bought a rival, Hyperion Solutions, for $3.3 billion last month.

title: Sebastien Bourdais revisited
description: I guess this should become a season-opening ritual. Last year I mentioned the great season start for Sebastien Bourdais, in what would become his record-equaling three-straight championship titles. This year, Sebastien got off to a rough start in the first race, but he went on to win the next two, last night taking the Houston title for the second time. He again leads the series.

title: Edwards Finds Campaign Treasure in Fortress
description: John Edwards, one of the Democratic contenders for the presidency in 2008, has long expressed support for legislation to plug tax loopholes for United States companies with offshore headquarters. But The Washington Post suggests that his time as a consultant for Fortress Investment Group, which houses many of its funds in the Cayman Islands, could make it tougher for him to maintain his image as a champion of the poor  especially now that Mr. Edwards (who is already trying to live down a pair of $400 Beverly Hills haircuts) has scooped up a pile of campaign cash from Fortress employees.

title: Scrushy to Settle with S.E.C. for $81 Million
description: HealthSouths founder, Richard Scrushy, will settle a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit for $81 million, closing the book on an investigation of the former executives role in a $2.7 billion accounting fraud. The settlement marks another step toward the end of the accounting fraud at HealthSouth, one of many that cropped up in the wake of Enron in the early 2000s. The scandal nearly forced the healthcare giant into bankruptcy.

description: There are about 40 million people between the ages of 10 and 19 in the United States, so adolescent medicine might be expected to be booming, Jan Hoffman writes in an article in Science Times. title: Washington: Governor to Approve Paid Family Leave
description: Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat, is expected to sign a measure that would make Washington the second state, after California, to grant paid leave to workers after the birth of a child. The bill, passed by the Democratic-controlled Legislature on Sunday, would provide up to $250 a week to new parents starting in October 2009. Parents of adopted children could also receive benefits. The bill was amended to remove a section that would have extended the benefits to people caring for a seriously ill relative. The program is expected to cost $19.7 million in 2010 and $21.4 million in 2011, legislative staff members said. The bill did not designate a financing source but instead created a task force to make recommendations by January 2008. Californias paid family leave program, which started in 2004, provides up to $882 per week for a total of six weeks and offers benefits for those caring for an ill relative.

description: Through the first two full years of David Wright's career, he was a complete hitter. In the second half of last season, he became a singles hitter, and now even the base hits seem to be disappearing.

She ekes out a few more dollars pushing a battered shopping cart through the streets of South Jamaica, filling it with cans and bottles she plucks from the garbage and cashes in for the deposits.

title: Raptors Mitchell Finds That a Little Quality Time Is the Key
description: TORONTO, April 23  Twirling a toothpick in his mouth, Raptors Coach Sam Mitchell competed against T. J. Ford, his starting point guard, in a 3-point shooting competition after practice Monday afternoon. After grimacing and growling following his game-ending miss, a grinning Mitchell ambled toward reporters.

title: Brooklyn: Development for Former Navy Site
description: The site of the Navy brig, a former naval prison next to the Brooklyn Navy Yard in Fort Greene, will be turned into a mixed-income housing complex with town houses, co-op apartments, rental apartments, supportive housing, a day care center and perhaps even an environmentally friendly dry cleaner, city officials said yesterday. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development announced that a partnership between the Dunn Development Corporation and L&M Equity Participants Ltd., two development companies specializing in low-priced housing, would redevelop the 103,000-square-foot site between Flushing and Park Avenues with 434 housing units.

title: Gov. Corzine Is Moved From Intensive Care
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 23  After 10 days in critical condition with severe chest injuries he suffered in a car crash, Gov. Jon S. Corzine was moved out of intensive care late Monday afternoon and upgraded to stable condition, his doctors at Cooper University Hospital here said.

title: A Body in Motion Tends to Stay in Motion
description: Peter Kyle danced with Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis Dance and with the Mark Morris Dance Group before forming his own company in 2005, and his long apprenticeship with master choreographers shows in his work. At the Joyce SoHo on Friday night, Peter Kyle Dance presented three well-made new works, and while none of them are likely to change the face of the art, they constituted an enjoyable evening.

title: Spain: New Bid for Airline
description: British Airways said it was in discussions with several private equity investors about entering a joint bid for Iberia Lneas Areas de Espaa, increasing the chances of a bidding war for the Spanish carrier. The Texas Pacific Group, the American buyout firm, made a $4.6 billion approach for Iberia last month. One person with knowledge of the negotiations, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said British Airways, which already owns a 10 percent stake in Iberia, was considering either joining the Texas Pacific bid or backing a bid from one of two other private equity firms, which were not named. British Airways, which has ruled out a bid on its own, said in a statement that any bidding group in which it was involved would probably include one or more Spanish partners.

title: Governing Party Wins in Nigeria, but Many Claim Fraud
description: ABUJA, Nigeria, April 23  The governing partys candidate for president, Umaru YarAdua, easily won the election in Nigeria, election officials here announced Monday. But his chief rivals for the office immediately rejected the results, and international observers said that the voting, which took place amid chaos, fraud and violence, was not credible.

title: U.S. Employees Selling Transit Passes Illegally, Investigators Say
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  To save gas, cut air pollution and unclog roads, the federal government gives its workers about $250 million a year in bus and subway passes. But many of the employees drive to work anyway and sell the transit passes on the Internet for cash, according to Congressional investigators.

title: At Least the Boss Was Satisfied by Gonzaless Answers
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  President Bush said Monday that the Congressional testimony of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales last week, roundly panned by members of both parties, had increased my confidence in his ability to do the job.

title: South Korea Says Food Aid Depends on North Korea
description: South Korea, facing criticism after it agreed Sunday to send 400,000 tons of rice to North Korea despite the Norths prevarication on a Feb 13 international agreement to shut down its main nuclear reactor, warned that North Korea might not get all the aid if it continued to refuse to live up to its commitment. We emphasized that the speed and timing of the aid shipments could be changed depending on the Norths sincere implementation of the Feb. 13 agreement, Lee Jae-Joung, the unification minister, said in a statement. The agreement signed Sunday contained no such preconditions. South Korea is to send the first shipment of rice in late May. Critics from the political opposition and conservative civic groups in Seoul had urged the government not to promise any aid until after the North had made a move to shut down the nuclear reactor.

description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the burly provincial politician who became a Soviet-era reformer and later a towering figure of his time as the first freely elected leader of Russia, presiding over the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the demise of the Communist Party, died yesterday in Moscow. Wolfowitz, signaling anew that he will fight for his job as World Bank president, has enlisted a prominent lawyer who defended President Bill Clinton against accusations of sexual misconduct to help convince the banks board that Mr. Wolfowitz has done nothing to justify being ousted.
