title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a military report that found that senior Marine Corps commanders had contributed to a willful failure to investigate the killing of 24 unarmed Iraqis by marines in the town of Haditha in 2005 misstated a word in a quotation from Brian J. Rooney, a lawyer for an officer punished in the Haditha matter. Mr. Rooney said his client, Lt. Col. Jeffrey R. Chessani, had promptly reported what he knew about the killings and I dont know how thats untimely, inaccurate and incomplete. He did not say untimely, accurate and incomplete.

title: In Las Vegas, Too Many Hotels Are Never Enough
description: LAS VEGAS  Stephen A. Wynn, the hotel and gambling impresario, still remembers the first time he was asked if he and other developers had lost their minds building so many casino hotels here. It was the mid-1970s, when Las Vegas had about 35,000 rooms.

title: Brooklyn: Man Killed in Shooting
description: One man was killed and another wounded yesterday when they were shot in a sport utility vehicle in Bedford-Stuyvesant by gunmen who pulled up alongside them and began firing, the police said. The driver, Isaiah E. Jacob, 21, of Brooklyn, was shot once in the torso and killed, and his passenger, who was not identified, was in stable condition late yesterday at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center with two gunshot wounds, the police said. They said two gunmen in a sedan pulled up beside the S.U.V. around 12:20 p.m. at Marcy and Lafayette Avenues. There were no arrests yesterday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the troubled life of Seung-Hui Cho, the gunman in the Virginia Tech massacre, misspelled the name of the roommate of Emily Hilscher, who was shot to death in a campus dormitory. She is Heather Haugh, not Haughn.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Wednesday about the writer Hans Koning misspelled the surname of the star of a movie made from his novel A Walk With Love and Death. She is Anjelica Huston, not Houston.

title: An Old Knick Captain Is Ready to Go Fishing
description: It didnt feel like fate phoning, only the New Orleans Hornets. Not initially, not until Gale Reed told her husband, Willis, You could go home.

title: Product Tips You Can Use, by Way of Cellphone
description: FROM time to time, Philips Electronics has used its sense and simplicity campaign to clear away marketing that bothers consumers. Last year it paid Hearst $2 million to remove the subscription cards from four of its magazines for a month, and several times it has bought up blocks of commercials on television shows and used them to give air time back to the programmers (like CBSs 60 Minutes and NBCs evening news).

title: In U.S. Absence, States Take Lead in Student Loan Cases
description: State attorneys general around the country are stepping up their scrutiny of college lending practices in the absence of federal enforcement action, following a pattern that experts say has prevailed in some other major consumer investigations in recent years.

title: CBS Radio Show Hosts Suspended After Phone Prank
description: CBS Radio suspended two hosts from an FM station in New York City yesterday after an Asian-American advocacy organization complained about the broadcast of a six-minute prank phone call to a Chinese restaurant that was peppered with ethnic and sexual slurs.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article yesterday about a deadly orphanage fire in the Bosnian capital of Sarajevo referred incorrectly in some copies to the location of Ljubljana, the city in the dateline, where the article was reported and written. It is in Slovenia, not Slovakia.

title: Wiping Out a Parasite, Not a Spirit of Adventure
description: Keith Aronowitz first noticed the crater on his elbow after returning from Bolivia. For a week or two, he simply ignored it. Then his friends began to worry.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the challenges facing Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York who turned 75 this month, referred incorrectly to the resignation he has submitted to the Vatican, in accordance with church law. He offered to resign as archbishop  not cardinal, a lifetime position. The article also misspelled the given name and surname of the president of the College of New Rochelle, who praised the cardinals dedication to education. He is Stephen Sweeny, not Steven Sweeney.

title: Nissan Will Offer Buyouts
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, April 24 (Bloomberg News)  The Nissan Motor Company said Tuesday that it would offer buyouts to workers in Japan for the first time in eight years after slumping domestic sales forced it to cut earnings and sales goals.

title: A Deal on the Minimum Wage
description: Congressional negotiators have finally reached an agreement on a bill to raise the federal minimum wage. But in getting to that important point, some Democratic lawmakers have shown the same disturbing tendency as their Republican kin to turn pressing issues into pretexts for more tax cuts.

title: New DVDs
description: JANE EYRE

title: Medicine and the Drug Industry, a Morality Tale
description: It was in 1949 that Elvin Stakman, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, issued the membership their marching orders: Science cannot stop while ethics catches up.

title: Seeking Landmark Status, and Hoping to Lose a Label of Unrest
description: The bass players widow looked down Dean Street and remembered her neighbors by the work they did: a teacher, a letter carrier, a doctor, another jazz man. A subway conductor, a church lady. Across the street, there is a mansion, once a doctors home.

title: Nixon and Kissinger
description: The current war in Iraq is mentioned only once in Robert Dalleks engrossing new book, Nixon and Kissinger, and yet the reader cannot help regarding his account of the Nixon White House and its handling of the Vietnam War as a kind of parable about the presidency of George W. Bush and its determination to stay the course in Iraq.

title: Poland Wants Benefits From U.S. Defense Plan
description: WARSAW, April 24  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates was told by his Polish counterpart today that Poland supports proposals to base 10 American missile interceptors on its soil  but only so long as Polands security is enhanced by the move, along with that of Western Europe.

title: In Its Match With China, India Penalizes Its Own Team
description: KHAWASPUR, India

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Il Barbiere di Siviglia, at the Metropolitan Opera, misidentified the nationality of the baritone Russell Braun, who sings Figaro. Although he was born in Germany, he is Canadian.

title: Palestinian Tries to Step Down as Interior Chief
description: JERUSALEM, April 23  The Palestinian interior minister, Hani al-Qawasmi, submitted his resignation on Monday, five weeks after a unity government was sworn in, but was persuaded to stay on by the prime minister, Ismail Haniya of Hamas, Palestinian officials said.

title: On the Scales: Swedes Are Tracking a Rise in Fatter Children, Too
description: Swedish children, like their American counterparts, are growing fatter, researchers say.

title: In New Rochelle, a Push Not to Let a Melee Derail Growth in the Thriving Downtown
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 19  Ever since 200 police officers were called in to break up a melee of unruly teenagers this month at New Roc City, the slick youth-oriented entertainment complex here, city officials as well as developers busy redesigning the once-moribund downtown have cast the episode as an anomaly.

title: Bush Accuses Democrats of Playing Politics With Iraq Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney aggressively challenged the motives of Congressional Democrats today as the House and Senate prepared to consider a war spending bill that would order troops to be withdrawn from Iraq beginning later this year.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about Carlo Maria Badini, a former superintendent of La Scala opera house, who died last week at the age of 81, misstated the year he was born. It was 1925, not 1915.

title: Hamas Military Wing Fires Rockets at Israel
description: JERUSALEM, April 24  The military wing of Hamas fired a barrage of rockets and mortar shells from Gaza into Israel today for the first time since the Palestinian faction committed to a cease-fire in November.

title: Warner Music Chairman Sued
description: A dispute between two top figures in the corporate media establishment spilled into public view yesterday when Richard Snyder, the former chairman of Simon & Schuster, sued Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chairman of the Warner Music Group, saying he had not compensated him for his role in Mr. Bronfmans $2.6 billion acquisition of the music company three years ago.

title: Wrights Swing Adding to Power Shortage
description: Through the first two full seasons of David Wrights career, he was a complete hitter. In the second half of last season, he became a singles hitter, and now even the base hits seem to be disappearing.

title: Running Like a Clock ... and Fast
description: On overseas trips, many American business travelers do what is almost unthinkable back home: they take the train. And they board in increasing numbers, as high-speed rail service expands in Europe, China and Japan.

title: Modernity Drills Through Rock Toward an Alpine Hamlet
description: THE KAISERTAL, Austria, April 19  Years from now, if Sarah Leitner ever wants to regale her children with stories about her daily walk to school, she will not have to embellish, even a little: this plucky 8-year-old must hike a mountain to get to her home in this remote Alpine valley.

title: Breast Cancer Not Linked to Abortion, Study Says
description: There is no association between abortion and an increased risk for breast cancer, scientists reported yesterday in a large study.

title: Manhattan: Riding Academy to Close
description: The Claremont Riding Academy on the Upper West Side will shut down at 5 p.m. on Sunday, the owner, Paul Novograd, said yesterday. The academy, which opened as a livery stable in 1892, has been a riding academy since the 1920s, Mr. Novograd said. He said the increased popularity of the parks bridle path among pedestrians had made it very difficult for riders. The closing of the academy, which is on West 89th Street, was first reported in The New York Post. Homes will be found for the approximately 45 horses that are stabled there, Mr. Novograd said.

title: Rangers to Face Sabres. Thats Buffalo, Right?
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 23  As the Rangers staged a practice finally knowing who their second-round playoff opponent would be, they had to dig deep into their memories to begin preparing for Buffalo. They have not played the Sabres since Dec. 1.

title: Editors Note
description: Thanks for taking the time to read this e-mail. We welcome feedback from our readers. Send comments and suggestions to playemail@nytimes.com. We look forward to hearing your opinions.

title: New U.S. Ambassador Starts Job
description: It was Zalmay Khalilzads first day on the job as the American permanent representative to the United Nations. Mr. Khalilzad, the former ambassador to Iraq who replaced John R. Bolton after he resigned the United Nations post in December when he failed to obtain Senate confirmation, will travel immediately, joining a Security Council mission departing New York today for Serbia and Kosovo. The United States supports a United Nations plan for granting near-independence to Kosovo, but Russia, a veto-bearing member of the Council, is seeking to renegotiate it and called for the trip so ambassadors could see conditions on the ground. Mr. Khalilzad will become head of the Council for May, when the United States occupies the rotating presidency of the 15-member body. Richard A. Grenell, the spokesman for the American mission, quoted Mr. Khalilzad as saying his priorities would be Iran, Iraq, Lebanon, Sudan and United Nations reform.

title: Japans Fund for Wartime Sex Slaves Leaves Much of Its Mission Unfulfilled
description: TOKYO, April 24  When the fund set up by Japan a dozen years ago to compensate the aging victims of its wartime sexual slavery closed down on schedule last month, it left much of its mission of redress and reconciliation unfulfilled, because many of the victims refused to accept its money.

title: In the Right Office, Trust and Candor
description: Cues that a family medicine or pediatric practice is welcoming to adolescents can be discerned well before the first visit. Some practices set aside office hours for teenagers. Some have a different waiting area, with bigger chairs, age-appropriate reading material  and no toddler toys.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Prison Sentences in Munch Thefts

title: Camden: Mother Questioned After Abduction Report
description: A 25-year-old woman was being questioned by the Camden police yesterday afternoon after she told investigators that her daughter had been abducted, leading to a statewide Amber Alert, the police said. Around 11:30 a.m., the woman, Lakeesha White of Camden, told the police that she had stopped her car to help an older person cross the street and that a man jumped into the car and sped off with her 7-year-old daughter in the back seat, said Teresa Sicard Achambeault, a police spokeswoman. Detectives issued the alert and found Ms. Whites car several blocks away about 1 p.m. The police later discovered that the girl had been in school all morning, Ms. Sicard Achambeault said.

title: Queens: New Center for Domestic Violence Victims
description: City officials announced the start of construction yesterday on the citys second Family Justice Center, which provides services to victims of domestic violence and their children. The center, in Kew Gardens, will provide multilingual services including assistance with police reports, emergency shelter and lawyers.

title: Manhattan: Survey on Apartment Vacancies
description: The vacancy rate for rental apartments in nearly every Manhattan neighborhood remained below 1 percent for all of 2006, according to data released yesterday by the rental brokerage firm Citi Habitats Inc. Last year was the first time in the five years that Citi Habitats has been collecting this data that the vacancy rate was below 1 percent throughout the whole year. In the West Village, the vacancy rate shrank as low as 0.49 percent. Prices for studio, one-bedroom and two-bedroom apartments throughout Manhattan jumped by about 9 percent from the previous year, and prices for three-bedroom apartments rose by nearly 14 percent. Citi Habitats surveyed 60,000 units for its report.

title: China Yields to Inquiry on Pet Food
description: BEIJING, April 23  China on Monday has given American regulators permission to enter the country to investigate whether Chinese suppliers exported contaminated pet food ingredients to the United States earlier this year, leading to one of the largest pet food recalls in American history.

title: Officials Revise Scope of Numbers Breach
description: The Agriculture Department has again lowered the number of people whose Social Security numbers were disclosed in a public database posted on the Census Bureaus Web site. The department, which was alerted to the problem two weeks ago, now says about 37,800 numbers were exposed. Initially, it had said 100,000 to 150,000 people were affected, before lowering the number to 63,000. It says the current number reflects a complete review of all records posted in the database. The department will provide credit monitoring for one year for the people whose Social Security numbers were exposed.

title: Mickelson Hires Harmon as Swing Coach
description: Phil Mickelson dropped his swing instructor, Rick Smith, and hired Butch Harmon, who helped Tiger Woods and Greg Norman become the worlds No. 1 golfers.

title: Killing and Suicide in Houston Is Third Such Shooting in 4 Days
description: HOUSTON, April 23  A 48-year-old man who was facing eviction from a fashionable apartment complex here shot and killed the manager of the complex on Monday before killing himself.

title: Border Patrol Agent Charged With Murder
description: BISBEE, Ariz., April 23  A Border Patrol agent who shot and killed a Mexican immigrant along the Arizona-Mexico border in January was charged Monday with first-degree murder and three related offenses.

title: Line Up and Pick a Dragon: Bhutan Learns to Vote
description: THIMPHU, Bhutan, April 22  Can Desperate Housewives, free trade and multiparty elections deliver happiness?

title: Recovering Ancient Protein
description: Until now, when it has come to dinosaurs, our imagination has always turned to stone. Nearly everything we know about their fleshly contours, their life habits and their inner workings has been the result of studying their fossilized skeletal remains. But scientists have recently recovered a protein from the femur of a Tyrannosaurus rex.

title: Ex-Officers of Apple Await Suit
description: Two former Apple executives expect to be sued this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission over the companys backdating of employee stock options, several people involved in negotiations between the former executives and the government said yesterday.

title: With Long Arms and Passport, Rookie Finds a Role
description: DEERFIELD, Ill., April 23  Thabo Sefolosha and Luol Deng were bouncing the ball to each other and shooting with their feet, playing on an imaginary soccer field instead of the Chicago Bulls practice court.

title: Welcome, Teenagers! The Doctor Will See You Now
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bush, Blacksburg and Baghdad (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Former HealthSouth Chief Settles With S.E.C.
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 23  The former chief executive of HealthSouth, Richard M. Scrushy, reached a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday, agreeing to pay more than $81 million. The amount includes the forfeiture of $77.5 million and $3.5 million in fines.

title: Democrats Back Date for Start of Iraq Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Congressional Democrats agreed Monday to ignore President Bushs veto threat and send him a $124 billion war spending bill that orders the administration to begin pulling troops out of Iraq by Oct. 1.

title: A Shortage of Pitchers Forces the Yankees to Turn to a Prized Prospect
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 23  The Yankees did not plan it this way. But then, they did not expect to lose so many starting pitchers to injuries, either. So Phil Hughes, the 20-year-old right-hander who may be the best pitching prospect in all of minor league baseball, will make his Yankees debut Thursday.

title: Obama Outlines His Foreign Policy Views
description: CHICAGO, April 23  Presenting himself as a presidential candidate who can speak directly to the world, Senator Barack Obama on Monday outlined his approach to foreign policy, vowing to double foreign aid, expand and modernize the military, and rebuild fractured alliances.

title: The Man Who Made Mapplethorpe
description: Tall, handsome and rich would be one way to describe Sam Wagstaff, a legendary figure in the international art world of the 1970s and 80s. Urbane is another. Iconoclastic, certainly. And glamorous, without a doubt. But the word that keeps cropping up in Black White + Gray, a new documentary about Mr. Wagstaff by a first-time director, James Crump, that will be shown at the Tribeca Film Festival next week, is visionary.

title: Mr. Spitzer and Gay Marriage
description: The news that Gov. Eliot Spitzer will soon introduce a bill to legalize same-sex marriage  what he calls a simple moral imperative  is welcome and could give new national momentum to this important cause. Mr. Spitzer would be the first governor in the nation to introduce a gay marriage bill. But if he is going to make a real difference, rather than simply checking off a box to fulfill a campaign promise, he will have to fight for the law vigorously.

title: Jury Selection Is Slow Going in Padilla Terrorism Trial
description: MIAMI, April 23  Finding an impartial jury in the trial of Jose Padilla is proving to be a slow process, as expected, as the second week of juror selection began Monday.

title: Ethiopian Rebels Kill 70 at Chinese-Run Oil Field
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 24  Separatist rebels stormed a Chinese-run oil field in eastern Ethiopia today, killing more than 70 people, including nine Chinese workers, in one of Ethiopias worst rebel attacks in years.

title: Report Says the Backup Samples From Landis Test Positive
description: Tests on seven backup urine samples taken from Floyd Landis at the 2006 Tour de France have revealed traces of synthetic testosterone, according to a report yesterday by Lquipe, the French sports newspaper.

title: The Holocaust Denied, and the Denier Defended
description: The very idea of denying the Holocaust is so ludicrous that any attempt at writing a serious play on the subject would seem futile. Yet Peter Sagals Denial, at the Metropolitan Playhouse, is an engrossing legal drama that examines the moral and ethical dilemmas inherent in the First Amendment.

title: Bronx Girl, 5, Found Hanged in Apartment Bedroom
description: The police and the city medical examiners office yesterday were investigating the death of a 5-year-old Bronx girl who was found on Sunday dangling from a closet door with a jump-rope around her neck.

title: Museum Plans to Move to Its Symbolic Home, Littler Italy
description: Joseph V. Scelsa has heard the talk about how Little Italy is little more than a tourist destination whose boundaries are being squeezed by NoLIta to the north, SoHo to the west and Chinatown and TriBeCa to the south.

title: Avoiding All That Heat About the Environment
description: Earth Day has come and gone, and with it the usual gestures: some trees planted, some litter picked up, some green oratory delivered by public figures. All well intended, probably, but all well short of matching the scope of the environmental problems that loom.

title: Virtue Is Not Its Own Reward and Other Lessons for a Life in Art
description: Edward Albee likes to tell about the time when, at 18, having fled his adoptive parents stiflingly conservative household to begin a more expansive self-education in Greenwich Village, he knocked on W. H. Audens door. Mr. Albee, frequently referred to as Americas greatest living playwright, thought himself a poet then.

title: Scrushy to Pay $81 Million to Settle S.E.C. Lawsuit
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 23  The former chief executive of HealthSouth, Richard M. Scrushy, reached a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday, agreeing to pay more than $81 million. The amount represents the forfeiture of $77.5 million and $3.5 million in fines.

title: A Difficult Annual Times Meeting for Sulzbergers
description: The New York Times Company annual shareholder meeting traditionally has been a tame affair, where the Sulzberger family, which owns a controlling interest in the company, applauds the achievements of its journalists and, in turn, basks in the applause of investors.

title: If Checker Cabs Could Fly: Hop in, the Meters Running
description: THE idea of cheap little jets that resembled sport utility vehicles and could be produced by the thousands seemed far-fetched  and some even said preposterous  when the two pioneers in the field, Eclipse Aviation, in Albuquerque, and Adam Aircraft, near Denver, were gearing up for production six years ago.

title: Remedies: Dark Chocolate Similar to Blood Pressure Drugs
description: Eating dark chocolate may be almost as effective at lowering blood pressure as taking the most common antihypertensive drugs, a review of studies has found. Tea, on the other hand, appears to be ineffective.

title: Judge Excludes Defendants Statements in Sex Abuse Case
description: A Manhattan judge ruled today that three days of statements made by Peter Braunstein, a fashion writer accused of sexually molesting a former colleague at Fairchild Publications, should be excluded from his criminal trial.

title: Composers Near and Far, Speaking a Language of Now
description: Contemporary composition dropped in on the New Juilliard Ensemble for one of its regular check-ups on Friday, and Joel Sachss young musicians played music by five far-flung composers at Alice Tully Hall. Represented (in order of appearance) were Finland, Iceland, Ireland, Tajikistan and the United States.

title: Bloomberg Reaches Deal With Principals
description: The Bloomberg administration and the union representing New York City school principals and assistant principals reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday that would offer bonuses of up to $25,000 a year to select principals who agree to spend three years in troubled schools.

title: Top Hedge Fund Managers Earn Over $240 Million
description: James Simons, a 69-year-old publicity shy former math professor, uses complex computer-driven mathematical models to make bets on stocks, bonds and commodities, among other things.

title: Our Allies, Risking Death (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Volvo Chooses a Two-Agency Creative Team
description: The Volvo division of the Ford Motor Company today chose a team of two agencies to handle its worldwide creative account. The agencies, Arnold Worldwide and Nitro, will share an assignment with spending estimated at $150 million to $200 million.

title: Microsoft, Trying to Avoid a European Fine, Defends Demand for Royalties
description: Microsoft, seeking to avoid another multimillion-dollar fine in its antitrust battle with the European Commission, filed documents with competition officials yesterday defending its demand to be paid royalties for releasing some software code to competitors.

title: The Neocon Paradox
description: Neoconservatives have been airing an explanation for the failure of the Iraq war thats so obvious youll wonder why you didnt think of it yourself: the war wasnt neoconservative enough.

title: Terror in the Weather Forecast
description: Toronto

title: $8 Fee for Cars? Bravo, or Fuhgeddaboutit! (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Propeller Puzzles
description: Q. I have heard of planes with five-bladed propellers. How do engineers decide how many blades to have?

title: Mining the Tensions Found Amid Stillness and Action
description: Watching one of Barbara Mahlers dances is like witnessing two personalities tangled in a longstanding feud. The surface is all cool restraint, a lid that seems to suppress a multitude of seething emotions. But an eruption, in Ms. Mahlers crisply arranged choreography, is a rare thing. Her rigid style is a tough shell to crack.

title: AstraZeneca Acquires a Biotech Company
description: AstraZeneca said yesterday it had agreed to acquire MedImmune for $15.6 billion, in perhaps the most emphatic sign yet of the push by big drug makers into biotechnology.

title: Treating the Awkward Years
description: Robert T. Browns patients may be obese or anorexic; sexual innocents or infected with chlamydia; male or female; jocks or goths; abusers of alcohol, Ecstasy or over-the-counter drugs; tattooed, pierced, pimpled; surly and stressed; or just mortified by their molting, rebelling bodies.

title: Pedicab Limit Withstands Mayors Veto
description: New York Citys freewheeling pedicab industry will be regulated for the first time after a City Council vote yesterday to override a mayoral veto.

title: Next Week
description: If the National Football League draft on Saturday is a high-level version of playground pick em, then at least one college star may feel like the kid no one wants. Bryan Curtis looks at the draft and the falling fortunes of last seasons Heisman Trophy winner, Troy Smith. Also, if the only horse race you bet on all year is the Kentucky Derby, Joe Drape tells you how to maximize your investment.

title: Senators Discuss Preventing College Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Lawmakers began weighing ways Monday to prevent more tragedies on college campuses in a hastily convened Senate hearing a week after the shootings in Virginia. The hearing explored the adequacy of campuses mental health resources, security plans and communications systems.

title: Prognosis: Predicting Heart Disease Among the 20-Somethings
description: Apparently, it is never too soon to think about the risk of cardiac disease. A study published today has found that mildly elevated levels of cholesterol or slightly above normal blood pressure from ages 18 to 30 are strong predictors of having coronary artery calcium at ages 30 to 35. Coronary artery calcium, a form of arterial plaque, is a predictor of later heart disease.

title: Russia Cool to U.S. Call for Cooperation on Missile Defense
description: MOSCOW, April 23  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pressed the Kremlins top leaders on Monday to accept a detailed new plan for cooperation on missile defense in Europe that he said would make Russia a full partner in the American effort by sharing information, jointly developing new technology and even combining the two countries defensive radar systems.

title: At Trial, Pain Has a Witness
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va. William E. Hurwitz, the prominent doctor on trial here for drug trafficking, spent more than two days on the witness stand last week telling a jury why he had prescribed painkillers to patients who turned out to be drug dealers and addicts. But the clearest explanation of his actions  and of the problem facing patients who are in pain  came earlier in the trial.

title: For Writers, a Voice Beyond the Page
description: Seven years ago, Moniru Ravanipur, a novelist and short-story writer, was put on trial in her native Iran. Her supposed crime: threatening national security while attending a political conference in Berlin, where she openly discussed her countrys reform movement.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on April 12 about the $500 million asking price for the building at 229 W. 43rd Street that houses the headquarters of The New York Times  nearly three times the amount a developer paid for it in November 2004  included an outdated reference to an Upper East Side mansion with a high price tag. The 25-room building, which is listed at $59 million, is no longer owned by Robert C. Guccione, the founder of Penthouse magazine.

title: Turkish Partys Pick for President Worries Secularists
description: ISTANBUL, April 24  Turkeys ruling party on Tuesday chose a presidential candidate with an Islamic background, a move that will extend the reach of the party  and the emerging class of devout Muslims it represents  into the heart of Turkeys secular establishment for the first time.

title: Writing Poems in Human Calligraphy
description: There were no cutting-edge eruptions, just the quiet pleasure of well-made art, in four dances performed by Kun-Yang Lin/Dancers on Friday night at Queens Theater in the Park.

title: Memo Pad
description: AIRLINE EMPLOYMENT  The number of employees working for domestic airlines in February rose 0.2 percent over February 2006, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics. But the increase was not because of hiring by the major carriers. Despite record passenger demand, the network carriers had 2.2 percent fewer workers than the previous February. Instead, regional carriers are adding employees (up 5.9 percent over February 2006) as are low-cost carriers (up 5 percent). Compared with February 2003, the number of employees at the big network carriers declined 23.3 percent, to 262,400, from 342,300. Meanwhile, employment at low-cost carriers rose 8.3 percent, to 71,400, from 65,900, and employment at regional carriers rose 22.4 percent, to 599,000, from 489,000 in 2004. That was the first year regional carriers reported unified employee statistics.

title: Carbon Gas Is Explored as a Source of Ethanol
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23  A New Zealand company said Monday that it had secured financing from an investor in Silicon Valley to produce ethanol from an untapped source  carbon monoxide gas.

title: Projections Show Troubles Still Loom for Benefit Plans
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Two seemingly inexorable forces, rising medical costs and the looming retirement of the baby boom generation, are set to overwhelm the Medicare program by 2019, the Bush administration reported Monday.

title: Maine Has Last Word in Solving Rockies
description: John Maine exuded confidence even before the Mets faced the Colorado Rockies at Shea Stadium last night. While listening to his iPod in the clubhouse, Maine worked on a crossword puzzle  in blue ink.

title: First Mission to Explore Those Wisps in the Night Sky
description: Two hundred seventy thousand feet above the ground, higher than 99.9 percent of the earths air, clouds still float around  thin, iridescent wisps of electric blue.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) SAVED BY THE SUN Gas prices are through the roof, oil supplies are dwindling, and global warming is on everyones radar. Could solar energy be a cleaner solution? In this Nova special, above, scientists explain advances in technology that may make this once-futuristic energy source viable. Proponents and critics discuss the possibilities.

title: Boeing Videos Feature New Dreamliner
description: Boeing is using new technology not only to build its 787 Dreamliner aircraft but also to promote it: The company has commissioned a series of large-format videos running on the aircrafts Web site to promote the 787 to potential passengers and airline customers, aviation enthusiasts and others.

title: Europe Approves More Sanctions Against Iran
description: BRUSSELS, April 23  In the latest effort to force Iran to curb its uranium enrichment activities, European Union foreign ministers on Monday approved a second phase of United Nations sanctions. Included in the package were a ban on Iranian arms exports and the freezing of the assets of 28 additional individuals and organizations.

title: Bees Vanish, and Scientists Race for Reasons
description: BELTSVILLE, Md., April 23  What is happening to the bees?

title: 9 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Suicide Bombing in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Tuesday, April 24  A devastating suicide car bombing on Monday killed nine American soldiers and wounded 20 others near a patrol base in Diyala Province, the military announced early today.

title: Toyota Tops G.M. in Sales for First Time
description: HONG KONG, April 24  Toyota sold more cars and trucks around the world in the first three months of 2007 than any other manufacturer, surpassing General Motors for the first time and ending one of the longest runs of dominance in all of global industry.

title: Obamas Rise Strains Loyalty on Clinton Turf
description: Only a few months ago, the vast majority of black elected officials in New York were expected to support the presidential candidacy of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. But no longer.

title: Kleiner Perkins to Expand With Two Offices in China
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23  The technology investment firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is opening offices in Shanghai and Beijing and plans to invest a $360 million fund in Chinese Internet, energy, media and communications start-ups.

title: France: Building Concern Rejects Bid
description: Eiffage, a French construction company, said its board had rejected a takeover bid of 6.6 billion euros ($9 billion) from a Spanish rival, Sacyr Vallehermoso, for the two-thirds of Eiffage it does not already own. Eiffage, which is based near Paris, challenged the strategic sense of the approach and accused Sacyr of violating merger rules by collaborating with other investors in making its bid. Sacyr, based in Madrid, made the hostile bid for Eiffage, the company that built the Eiffel Tower, after Eiffage blocked Sacyr, its largest shareholder, from taking a board seat. Eiffage decided not to cooperate with Sacyr after the pair held 14 rounds of talks. Eiffage said. None of the meetings allowed the companies to identify a common strategy, synergies or even a road map for future joint projects, Eiffage said in a statement.

title: Virginia Tech Struggles to Return to Normal
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 23  For the most part, the campus of Virginia Tech looked like any other on Monday, a week after the nations worst mass shooting. Students, laden with overstuffed book bags, shuffled across the sidewalks and greens, cradling cups of coffee and bottles of water. Books were open on desks, and chalk scratched across boards.

title: If You Want to Know if Spot Loves You So, Its in His Tail
description: Every dog lover knows how a pooch expresses its feelings.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A television review last Tuesday of the documentary Gangs of Iraq on PBS omitted a word in a quotation from a motivational speaker shown addressing Iraqi police trainees. He said, I am not here to impose my American will upon you  not I am here. A listing of credits with the review carried outdated information from PBS about the programs producer and erroneously credited another executive. The producer is Marcela Gaviria  not Martin Smith, who was correctly identified in the article as the PBS correspondent. Sherry Jones is a senior producer  not an executive producer, the position held by David Fanning.

title: Indonesia Court Clears Mining Company
description: MANADO, Indonesia, April 24  An Indonesian court today acquitted the Newmont Mining Corporation and one of its senior executives of criminal charges of polluting a bay here with toxic waste from a now-defunct gold mine.

title: Weight-Loss Drugs: Hoopla and Hype
description: Lose 8 to 10 pounds per week, easily ... and you wont gain the weight back afterward.

title: Government Challenged on Lynch and Tillman
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  House Democrats burrowed into the histories of Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch and Cpl. Pat Tillman in a hearing today, holding up the episodes as egregious examples of officials twisting the truth for public relations in wartime.

title: ABN Amro to Be Acquired for $91 Billion
description: LONDON, April 23  ABN Amro agreed today to be acquired by Barclays for 67 billion euros, or $91 billion, creating one of the worlds largest banks in a carefully crafted deal that reduces  but does not eliminate  the chances of another suitor coming in with a higher bid to buy and break up the bank.

title: Upscale Snacks, Famous Clients, and a Health Dept. Warning
description: Just like Jeopardy!, shooting free throws and parenthood, running a restaurant is one of those things that looks much easier on TV. That would be one conclusion to draw, anyway, given Graydon Carters recent experience with the Waverly Inn and Garden.

title: A Whirlwind Before the N.F.L. Draft
description: After flying more than 5,000 miles over six days last week to visit five N.F.L. teams, the former Arkansas left tackle Tony Ugoh learned something.

title: Resistance: Bacterium Linked to Ulcers May Lower Risk of Asthma
description: Helicobacter pylori, the main cause of peptic ulcer disease, might have a beneficial effect in reducing the risk of asthma and allergies, a study published yesterday suggests.

title: Use of Wiccan Symbol on Veterans Headstones Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  To settle a lawsuit, the Department of Veterans Affairs has agreed to add the Wiccan pentacle to a list of approved religious symbols that it will engrave on veterans headstones.

title: Its Not a Sequel, but It Might Seem Like One After the Ads
description: LOS ANGELES, April 23  If the Walt Disney Company and its Pixar Animation Studios unit have their way, by the time Ratatouille is released on June 29, millions will have learned not only to pronounce the movies title  Pixars Web site insists on the somewhat un-French rat-a-too-ee  but to love the idea of a rodent in the kitchen.

title: A Substitute No More, a Soprano Gets Her Own Spotlight
description: The romance of the last-minute substitute has given Erika Sunnegardh a mini-fame of sorts in the opera world. In a much-publicized charge to the rescue a year ago, Ms. Sunnegardh, a Swedish soprano, replaced Karita Mattila in a Metropolitan Opera Saturday broadcast of Fidelio. She also did something of the kind a few weeks ago at Turandot, stepping into the title role for Andrea Gruber, who was ill. Saturday night was to be Ms. Sunnegardhs first bona fide appearance in the Mets revival of that Puccini potboiler, so it seemed wise to check on the progress of this rags-to-relative-prosperity career.

title: India: Space Program Goes Commercial
description: India successfully placed an Italian astronomical satellite in orbit and became one of just a handful of countries conducting commercial space launchings. The 775-pound satellite blasted off from southern Sriharikota atop a domestic PSLV-C8 rocket. India is planning to use the rocket for the launching of a spacecraft to the moon next year.

title: Boris Yeltsin, the Early Years
description: I MET Boris Yeltsin shortly after I arrived in Moscow as the United States ambassador in April 1987. He was then the head of the Communist Party organization in Moscow, and while he would become a household name around the world within five years, at the time few outside the Soviet Union had heard of him.

title: In the Bronx, a Team Perhaps Thrown Into Panic
description: Its too soon for the Yankees to panic, but I think they need to panic. They need to do something, and panic seems to be as good a something as anything.

title: The Double Bass Has Its Long-Necked, Solo Moment
description: How does a double bassist assemble an audience-friendly recital? Faced with a dearth of repertory, the performer has three options: borrow music written for other instruments, commission new works or take on the added chore of composing. Edgar Meyer explored all three avenues in the concert he shared with the pianist Emanuel Ax at Zankel Hall on Friday night. The program was decidedly eclectic, in keeping with Mr. Meyers status as a formidable player whose interests range from chamber music to bluegrass and beyond.

title: U.S. Command Shortens Life of Long War as a Reference
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  When the Bush administration has sought to explain its strategy for fighting terrorism, it has often said the United States is involved in a long war against Islamic extremists.

title: Rodriguezs Record Cant Improve Yankees
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 23  Alex Rodriguez smashed two more home runs on Monday and already has 14 this season. No player in baseball history has hit so many in the first 18 games. No player has ever hit more in April. Rodriguez is batting .400, about as hot as a hitter can be, yet the Yankees are reeling.

title: Music of the Spheres and the Pain of Earthly Matters
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonics programming team was thinking theatrically for the orchestras Saturday evening concert. Before Stefan Asbury conducted the opening work, Vaughan Williamss Fantasia on a Theme of Thomas Tallis, the lights at the Brooklyn Academy of Music were extinguished and a vocal quartet from the New York Virtuoso Singers walked to the front of the stage, bearing candles, to sing Talliss setting of Psalm 2, on which the Vaughan Williams work is based. Later the orchestra gave a performance of Holsts Planets to the accompaniment of photographs provided by NASA.

title: As Draft Nears, Eagles Say McNabb Is Their Future
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23  Donovan McNabb has had a season-ending injury in each of the last two seasons.

title: Who Pays for Driving in Manhattan?
description: To pursue the future, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had to return to the past. Consciously or not, he went as far back as the first century. In the process, he discovered that it was possible to wow an audience with lines that have been around for 2,000 years.

title: Candidates in France Focus on Centrist Voters
description: PARIS, April 23  The French presidential race is on  for the vote of the center.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Picture captions on April 18 with an article about the London Book Fair and the importance to the publishing industry of the fairs International Rights Center misidentified the section of the fair shown in two photographs. It was the exhibitors area, not the International Rights Center.

title: CBS Radio Show Hosts Suspended After Prank Call
description: CBS Radio suspended two hosts from an FM station in New York City today after an Asian-American advocacy organization complained about the broadcast of a six-minute prank phone call to a Chinese restaurant that was peppered with ethnic and sexual slurs.

title: That New Car Bouquet Is Intoxicating, Not Toxic
description: Do you love the smell of a new car? Ever wondered what the heady mix of aldehydes, ketones and other volatile organic compounds from the dashboard and other interior components might be doing to you?

description: Two more home runs tonight from Alex Rodriguez. Thats 14 in 18 games. Try to absorb some of these numbers:

title: Alex Rodriguezs Hot Start
description: The Yankees Alex Rodriguez became the first player in major league history to hit 14 home runs in the first 18 games of a season.

title: Want to buy in Spain?
description: The Spanish property market is going through a tough time right now. Residential property inflation has slowed to 7.2 percent  down from 9.1 percent  with prices stagnant or falling in many parts of the country.

title: Treating the Awkward Years
description: Robert T. Brown's patients may be obese or anorexic; sexual innocents or infected with chlamydia; male or female; jocks or goths; abusers of alcohol, Ecstasy or over-the-counter drugs; tattooed, pierced, pimpled; surly and stressed; or just mortified by their molting, rebelling bodies.

title: Buffalo's Totems
description: A chain saw artist is turning dead elms, oaks and maples from last October's storm into living monuments to Buffalo icons.

title: The Billion-Dollar Hedge Fund Club
description: The latest ranking of the top-paid hedge fund managers has reignited a debate about just what these guys (and on this list, they are all guys) are doing, and whether it is worth all that money.

title: Foot Locker May Raise Bid for Genesco
description: After the object of its desire rejected its $1.2 billion bid, the sneaker maker Foot Locker said it was not ruling out the possibility of raising the price. Foot Lockers target, Genesco, which makes footwear and accessories, rejected the $46 a share bid Monday saying that it undervalued the company.

title: Carrefour Buys Brazilian Discounter
description: Carrefour, the French retailer, said it had agreed to buy a Brazilian discounter, Atacado, for about $1.09 billion in a deal that would make it the largest food retailer in Brazil. Atacado operates 34 discount hypermarkets in Brazil, 17 of which are located in So Paulo state. Atacados property portfolio consists of 2.3 million square feet.

title: Mexico City Legalizes Abortion Early in Term
description: The vote sets the stage for court battles and social clashes between Mexicos religious conservatives and liberals.

title: Eiffage Says Non to Spanish Bid
description: Eiffage, a French construction company, said its board had rejected a takeover bid of 6.6 billion euros ($9 billion) from a Spanish rival, Sacyr Vallehermoso, for the two-thirds of Eiffage it does not already own. Eiffage, which is based near Paris, challenged the strategic sense of the approach and accused Sacyr of violating merger rules by collaborating with other investors in making its bid.

title: Anglo American Buying Stake in Brazilian Project
description: A Brazilian iron and steel company, MMX Minerao e Metlicos, plans to sell a large stake in one of its mining projects to the British mining company Anglo American, according to a regulatory filing. According to the preliminary agreement between the two companies, Anglo American will acquire 49 percent of the MMX unit Sistema Minas-Rio for $1.15 billion. Sistema Minas-Rio is the companys most ambitious mining project, with total investments of more than $2.4 billion.

title: MedImmune Deal Came With Surprising Price Tag
description: Carl Icahn and the other investors who pressed MedImmune for a sale are probably quite happy with the result: a $15.2 billion bid from the British drug giant AstraZeneca. At $58 a share, AstraZenecas offer is 53 percent above where MedImmunes stock was trading when the company put itself on the block, according to Jason Zhang, an analyst at Prudential. The bid was far higher than many on Wall Street had expected. Shares of MedImmune, which already announced that it had hired Goldman Sachs to look for potential buyers, surged 18 percent Monday in heavy trading.

title: Startup Partners with Time Warner for Public Broadband
description: In a victory for a small wi-fi start-up called Fon, Time Warner will let its home broadband customers turn their connections into public wireless access spots, a practice shunned by most Internet service providers in the United States.

title: Suit Says Bronfman Didnt Pay Up in Warner Deal
description: A dispute between two top figures in the corporate media establishment spilled into public view Monday when Richard Snyder, the former chairman of Simon & Schuster, sued Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chairman of the Warner Music Group, saying he had not compensated him for his role in Mr. Bronfmans $2.6 billion acquisition of the music company three years ago.

title: Kleiner Perkins Expands in China
description: The technology investment firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is opening offices in Shanghai and Beijing and plans to invest a $360 million fund in Chinese Internet, energy, media and communications start-ups, The New York Times reported.

title: Its Delightful, Its De-Lovely, Its Cole Porters Caddy
description: Two of my greatest passions are road trips and Broadway musicals. Even though I grew up as an airline child, I would far rather drive than fly when the time allows, and I much prefer to take back roads if they can get me there fast enough. Last week, on the way back from the start of Toyota production  at Subarus plant in Lafayette, Ind., my two passions collided when I saw the road sign for Peru on Route 24.

title: Brocades Post-Deal Agenda: More Deals?
description: Brocade claims its post-merger integration with former rival McData is well under way. The analyst firm The 451 Group looks at whether the bulked-up storage-area network vendor can hold off Cisco Systems as it attempts to broaden its product base. The report concludes that Brocade, which has a market capitalization of about $4 billion, will make further acquisitions in the Ethernet market to ensure it can be competitive with Cisco in this space.

title: Halberstams Fans
description: In the introduction to the 25th anniversary edition of his Pulitzer-winning book on Vietnam, The Best and the Brightest, David Halberstam mused about one thing that always worries journalists: If my byline disappears, have I disappeared as well?

title: Apples Ex-C.F.O. Reaches for Settlement with S.E.C.
description: Apples former chief financial officer, Fred D. Anderson, is preparing to settle with the Securities and Exchange Commission over the dating of an option grant to senior officials in January 2001, The New York Times reported Tuesday.

title: Alliance Boots Backs K.K.R.s Sweetened Bid
description: The British drugstore chain Alliance Boots said Tuesday it was recommending an improved offer from the buyout shop Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina, after the group raised its bid to 11.1 billion pounds ($22.2 billion), topping a rival offer from the financier Guy Hands.

title: Salesforce Launches Start-Up Incubator
description: Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce.com, a provider of online customer management software, is opening the companys first incubator for start-ups that are developing online software that complements that of Salesforce, BusinessWeek reports.

title: A Prickly Exchange over Bid for Affiliated Computer
description: Following a prickly letter from Affiliated Computer Services founder and chairman about the lack of progress on his talks for a management buyout of the technology services provider, the board had a barbed response of its own.

title: Buyout Firms Are Everywhere, But Still an Enigma
description: Private equitys clout has never been greater, but the industry is still poorly understood by most people in Europes five biggest economies, according to a poll conducted as part of The Financial Timess special report on private equity. About 62 per cent of those surveyed said they are not at all familiar with private equity.

title: Is Icahn Revving Up for More Auto Deals?
description: Carl C. Ichan is in the money. So wheres he going to spend it? BusinessWeek thinks it has tehe answer: the auto industry.

title: Union Negotiations May Hold Up Chrysler Sale
description: A deal to sell the Chrysler Group likely will get tied up in the upcoming contract negotiations between Detroit automakers and the United Auto Workers, according to the Detroit Free Press. That means a final deal to sell Chrysler is unlikely to be made before Sept. 14, the day the labor contract expires, complicating both the talks for a new labor agreement and negotiations with DaimlerChrysler to sell its United States operations.

title: Weighing in on the Next Buyout Targets: Cramer
description: The market pundit Jim Cramer apparently wants to help the little guy get into the private equity action.

title: Rival ABN Amro Bidders Still in the Race
description: The rival group considering a bid for ABN Amro may be down, but analysts say its not out.

title: Hot Summer Box Office May Lift Theatre I.P.O.s
description: An initial public offering from the movie theater operator Cinemark Holdings raised $532 million Monday, at the top of the range the company expected. That might set a good tone for Cinemarks rival, AMC Entertainment, which hopes to raise $800 million in a stock sale next month.

title: A Difficult Annual Times Meeting for Sulzbergers
description: The New York Times Company annual shareholder meeting traditionally has been a tame affair, where the Sulzberger family, which owns a controlling interest in the company, applauds the achievements of its journalists and, in turn, basks in the applause of investors.

title: Candidates, Meet Your Corporate Twins
description: With all the hype and analysis surrounding presidential candidates quarterly fund-raising reports, Slates Dan Gross has decided to cut to the chase and start matching the contenders with the actual corporations he thinks they resemble most. Try to figure out which candidates are the steady but staid juggernauts, the rock-star upstarts and, well, Halliburton.

title: Evercore Insiders to Cash In Stock
description: Evercore Partners employees, including senior managers, will sell about $82 million of stock in the investment banking boutique, whose shares have risen more than 50 percent since it went public eight months ago. Financial News, citing regulatory filings, reported that Evercores chairman, Roger Altman, plans to sell as much as $20 million in stock and the co-chief executive, Austin Beutner, is selling $14 million of shares.

title: Notes on the News
description: A few stories that struck us in our travels around the Web:

title: Is Faith Supreme in the Highest Court?
description: Theyre justices, not popes: Jan Crawford Greenburg, ABC Newss legal correspondent and the author of Supreme Conflict: The Inside Story of the Struggle for Control of the United States Supreme Court, objects to those who have attributed the majority decision in Gonzales vs. Carhart to religious belief, rather than legal analysis. She notes that Geoffrey Stone, former law school dean and provost at the University of Chicago (where Greenburg attended law school), wrote on the University of Chicago law school faculty blog: All five justices in the majority in Gonzales are Catholic. The four justices who either are Protestant or Jewish all voted in accord with settled precedent. It is mortifying to have to point this out. But it is too obvious, and too telling to ignore. Greenburg responds on Legalities, her ABC News blog:

title: 2008: Trouble at Home
description: The Timess Raymond Hernandez finds that Senator Barack Obama has unlocked Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons support from black leaders in New York, forcing her to campaign in her own state.

title: Terra Firma Gives Up in Alliance Boots Fight
description: Rival suitors for Alliance Boots have thrown up their hands and ceded Britains largest drugstore chain to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina, the companys deputy chairman. Still, Terra Firma Capital Partners, a private equity firm led by Guy Hands, Wellcome Trust and HBOS managed to force the winners into raising their bid to 11.1 billion pounds ($22.2 billion).

title: Comverse Ex-Chief Starts Namibian Scholarship Fund
description: When youre a fugitive executive awaiting extradition from Namibia on charges of fraud, how do you curry favor with the locals? If youre Jacob Kobi Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology, who is accused of profiting from backdated stock options, you set up a local scholarship fund.

title: Hollywood Meets Hedge Funds, Courtesy of Milken
description: As Hollywood and hedge funds enjoy an ever closer relationship, a conference that began this week at the Beverly Hilton may help to strengthen those ties. The gathering, held by the Milken Institute, a think-tank founded by the former junk-bond king, Michael Milken, features more than 100 sessions and 300 speakers.

description: I will be going to India this July for 5 weeks, with New Delhi as my starting point. Any suggestions on where to go and what to see? Im open-minded and adventurous!

description: Tour condos in downtown Atlanta and Florence, Ore., and a log-style home in Walker, Minn.

description: Shareholders in The New York Times Company, led by a Morgan Stanley fund, withheld 42 percent of their votes from directors at Tuesdays annual meeting. description: A number of you have commented on my blog that the way to address prostitution is to legalize it and encourage unions of sex workers, thus empowering prostitutes and enabling sensible regulation and health outreach programs. In the context of countries like India and Cambodia where Ive written about sex trafficking, that would be a bad mistake. Let me explain why.

title: Oracle to Buy Maker of Software for Utilities
description: Oracle is still hungry. The database software giant, which has been making a steady stream of acquisitions as its organic growth has stalled, said Tuesday it would buy Lodestar, which makes software applications used by energy companies. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Modern in Milan
description: Tour a newly renovated four-bedroom, three-bath apartment in Italy's capital of finance, commerce and design.

title: From Joysticks to Buyouts: Private Equitys Image Guy
description: Doug Lowenstein ran the Entertainment Software Association, which represented the videogame business, for more than a dozen years. Now he is the head of the new Private Equity Council, a lobbying group charged with improving the image of buyout firms. What could one job possibly have to do with the other? Mr. Lowenstein says there are indeed parallels between the two industries. His explained the common threads in a keynote speech at this weeks Private Capital Symposium in New York, sponsored by The Deal.

title: Spitzer on the Warpath
description: Wasting no time after his campaign finance reform proposal blew up yesterday, Gov. Eliot Spitzer started his promised Senate-bashing tour in the upstate district of Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno this morning, meeting with the editorial board of The Troy Record.

description: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has released a new Web video ad against Representative John Doolittle, the Republican Congressman who has temporarily stepped down from the House appropriations committee while under federal investigation.

title: Politics Follow Mayor to Mexico
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is in Toluca, Mexico, an industrial town of about 700,000, about 45 minutes outside Mexico City. He was observing a program known as Oportunidades, an antipoverty program that provides cash incentives to poor families who agree to take certain steps to improve the health and education of their children.

description: As the big salaries and bonuses at Wall Street firms continue to grab headlines, one article on Tuesday caught our attention. description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed lawsuits against two former Apple executives on Tuesday, charging them with fraud related to the backdating of stock options. Jobs, may face separate charges  a prospect raised by the claims of the companys former chief financial officer.

description: The City Councils decision on Monday to ban the use of metal bats in public high school baseball games  overriding a veto by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg  continues to elicit opinions on the Web world.

description: Some state lawmakers are grumbling that City Council members have been trying to steal their thunder. description: I cant believe Im almost done with college. I dont know how to feel about it, and its truly overwhelming.

description: In a spirited town hall meeting with voters in Henniker, N.H., today, Rudolph W. Giuliani was challenged on his Republican credentials and pushed to be more specific in what it means to be on the offense in the war on terror.

title: The McCain Shake-Up
description: On the eve of his official announcement tour to declare his candidacy for president, Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, has replaced his finance director. Carla Eudy, a long-time adviser, is out and Mary Kate Johnson, a former Bush fund-raiser, is in.

description: After months of controversy, how many minutes did it take today for the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission to announce its unanimous ruling that the New-York Historical Society can renovate the exterior of its 1908 building?

description: With their eyes on green-minded voters, European politicians are among the people clamoring the loudest for efforts to combat global warming. That makes it all the more surprising that the European Parliament might be one of the worlds most polluting elected bodies.

title: The Interstate Prison Trade
description: Unrest at a prison in Indiana sparked headlines when the governor announced a full-scale riot, but it was quelled soon after. Remaining were two injured employees, fire damage and a very interesting issue to examine.

title: Left Behind
description: The Mets were so deficient against left-handed pitching last season that they were dominated by guys like Eric Stults, Hong-Chih Kuo, Michael OConnor and Paul Maholm. Nothing against them, of course, but were not talking Johan Santana, Sandy Koufax or Steve Carlton here.

description: Video clips of police and protestors during a march by the War Resisters League during the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York City.

description: Alex Rodriguez doesnt speak much to the news media before games anymore. It seems to be part of another new strategy for dealing with reporters. As hot as he is these days, Im sure hes sticking to whatever works.

title: Officials Quell an Uprising at a Prison in Indiana
description: NEW CASTLE, Ind., April 24  Inmates at a medium-security state prison here rioted Tuesday, injuring two guards and several inmates.

description: GALKAYO, Somalia  Beyond clan rivalry and Islamic fervor, an entirely different motive is helping fuel the chaos in Somalia: profit.
