description: Charlie Rose is a talk show host known for long and rambling questions. President Bush is famous for his short, Texas-terse answers.

title: AT&T Earnings Beat Forecasts Despite Slow Market for Mobile Phones
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24  AT&T, the worlds largest telephone company, reported first-quarter earnings on Tuesday that handily beat Wall Street expectations. But some investors and telecommunications industry analysts said they were not sure that AT&T could continue its pace, particularly as growth is slowing in the mobile phone business.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the massacre at Virginia Tech included erroneous information from a law enforcement official about the origin of chains the gunman, Seung-Hui Cho, used to secure doors in a classroom building where most of the killings took place. (The error was repeated in a front-page article on Sunday about Mr. Chos life.) Although officials now say the chains were not bought at Home Depot, they have declined to say where the chains were obtained.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about an increase in the infant death rate in some Southern states misstated the given name of an obstetrician at the Mississippi Department of Health who said officials could not yet explain the rise in the rate in that state. He is Dr. LeDon Langston, not William.

title: In Mexican Town, Maybe a Way to Reduce Poverty in New York
description: MEXICO CITY, April 24  For a few days every other month, the narrow sidewalks of Tepoztln, a scenic mountain town south of here, fill with hundreds of women from surrounding villages, many tugging along children by the hand or carrying infants slung at their waists in rebozos.

title: Out With the Old, in With the New
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Warns of Continued Losses
description: PARIS, April 24  Alcatel-Lucent, the telecommunications equipment giant, warned investors Tuesday of continued losses and weak sales, casting doubt about the long-term outlook for the company four months after completing a trans-Atlantic merger.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Bad News for Superman

title: Letters
description: Second Thoughts About Veal

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies on Monday about Manager Terry Franconas power of suggestion in helping the Red Sox batters succeed in Sunday nights game against the Yankees, referred imprecisely to a home run hit by Mike Lowell in the third-inning. The ball left Fenway Park; it did not land in the Green Monster seats.

title: Off to Work She Should Go
description: Phoenix

title: Sri Lanka: Rebels Kill 6 Soldiers in Second Air Raid
description: An air raid by Tamil separatist rebels on a government military base on the northern Jaffna peninsula killed at least six soldiers and wounded 13 others. The military said it averted a larger attack on the base, at Palaly, by firing at the oncoming aircraft. The rebels unveiled their aerial capacity for the first time last month, when they bombed a military base outside the capital, Colombo, and killed three soldiers.

title: Qaeda-Linked Group Claims Responsibility for Killing of 9 G.I.s
description: BAGHDAD, April 24  An insurgent umbrella group that includes Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia claimed responsibility on Tuesday for a suicide bombing the day before that killed nine American soldiers and wounded at least 20, one of the deadliest attacks against American forces in more than four years of war.

title: Rescuers Search for Victims of Texas Tornado
description: HOUSTON, April 25  More than 500 rescue workers searched today through the rubble of Eagle Pass southwest of San Antonio where a fierce tornado Tuesday evening killed at least 10 people on both sides of the Texas-Mexico border.

title: New Planet Could Be Earthlike, Scientists Say
description: The most enticing property yet found outside our solar system is about 20 light-years away in the constellation Libra, a team of European astronomers said yesterday.

title: Exploring a Unified Theory of Beethovens Grosse Fuge
description: With Gidon Kremer presiding, sometimes onstage with his violin and sometimes merely in theory, the Kremerata Baltica played a program devoted mainly to transcriptions at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening. The musicians began with a favorite of string orchestras, though one approached gingerly: an expansion of Beethovens Grosse Fuge, originally for string quartet.

title: Bush and Gonzales (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Vote Defeats Proposal for Leaving Afghanistan
description: TORONTO, April 24  Canadas Parliament on Tuesday narrowly defeated a proposal by opposition lawmakers that the Conservative government withdraw Canadian troops from Afghanistan at the end of its current commitment in February 2009.

title: F.D.A. Says Livestock Were Fed Pet Food With Suspect Chemical
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  Melamine, the chemical suspected in the deaths of pets around the country, was in food given to hogs and chickens in several states, and the Food and Drug Administration is trying to determine if the animals entered the human food supply, F.D.A. officials said Tuesday.

title: Recalling Kirstein, Endearing Monster
description: Everyone was Lincoln Kirsteins friend. Or so it has seemed to Nancy Lassalle, a longtime ballet patron and associate of Mr. Kirsteins who has coordinated activities for a wide-ranging centennial celebration that begins tonight with a tribute by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater.

title: Whats Really Squeezing the Middle Class?
description: There are two different stories people tend to tell when theyre trying to explain why the middle class is feeling squeezed.

title: Dont Blame Hip-Hop
description: Hip-hop has been making enemies for as long as it has been winning fans. It has been dismissed as noise, blamed for concert riots, accused of glorifying crime and sexism and greed and Ebonics. From Run-D.M.C. to Sister Souljah to Tupac Shakur to Young Jeezy, the story of hip-hop is partly the story of those who have been irritated, even horrified, by it.

title: Pakistan: Courts Stalled Over Ousted Justice
description: The Supreme Judicial Council, the five judges conducting an inquiry into misconduct allegations against Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, the chief justice suspended by President Pervez Musharraf last month, again put off a hearing on the case, this time until Monday. Earlier, the Supreme Court adjourned a hearing on Mr. Chaudhrys complaint of bias on the part of some of the council judges. Mr. Chaudhry wants his old court to hear the case against him, but the justice handling the petition said he could not decide on it because he had supported Mr. Chaudhrys suspension. He called for a broader panel.

title: U.S. Wonders if Drug Data Was Accurate
description: The Food and Drug Administration is examining whether Eli Lilly & Company provided it with accurate data about the side effects of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa, a potent medicine that has been linked to weight gain and diabetes.

title: Spitzer Visits Bruno Turf to Push Campaign Reform
description: TROY, N.Y., April 24  Gov. Eliot Spitzer traveled Tuesday to the district of the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, on the first stop of a statewide tour to blast Senate Republicans for scuttling his plan to overhaul campaign finance regulations.

title: Child Welfare Agency Is Under Fire Again
description: NEWARK, April 24  The girl, identified in a lawsuit as S. A., is 8 now, with a loving adoptive mother. But throughout most of her life, the people who were supposed to protect her failed to do so, according to the suit filed on Tuesday against New Jerseys child welfare agency.

title: PowerPoint Politicking on the Job
description: It is not surprising that the Bush administration, which believes that government was meant to serve the party and not the people, is increasingly haunted by the Hatch Act. This is the nearly forgotten 1939 law that forbids federal workers from politicking during tax-paid office hours.

title: Historical Debate Follows Japanese Leader to U.S.
description: TOKYO, April 25  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will have a hard act to follow when he makes his first trip as Japans leader to the United States this week.

title: Newark: City Budget Approved on Time
description: The Newark Municipal Council yesterday unanimously approved a $720 million budget for 2007, making it one of the first in two decades to be passed on time and without a tax increase. Although the city is facing a $180 million shortfall next year, Mayor Cory A. Booker said he did not want to increase property taxes, which rose 8.3 percent last year, or about $322 for the average homeowner. The city actually cut the municipal tax levy this year by 7.8 percent to offset an increase in county and school taxes. To plug the looming deficit in 2008, Mr. Booker has been warning residents that he may have to cut services, reduce the municipal payroll and raise property taxes.

title: Chase Says It Will Move if City Balks
description: JPMorgan Chase is threatening to move thousands of employees from Midtown to Stamford, Conn., if New York officials do not give it a larger subsidy package to build a 50-story skyscraper near ground zero, according to real estate executives and government officials involved in the talks.

title: Presidential Pick in Turkey Is Sign of a Rising Islamic Middle Class
description: ISTANBUL, April 24  Turkeys ruling party on Tuesday chose a presidential candidate with an Islamic background, a move that will extend the reach of the party  and the emerging class of devout Muslims it represents  into the heart of Turkeys secular establishment for the first time.

title: Shedding Light on Heat: Making a Perfect Chili Paste
description: IT has a reputation for being one of the mysteries of international cuisine, but chili paste is really about as easy to make as applesauce. Take dried chilies, soak them until they are soft, combine them with a spice or two (or not) and pure.

title: McCain Officially Enters Presidential Race
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 25  Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, began his second bid for the White House today by embracing the war in Iraq but distancing himself from six years of White House rule. He criticized the way the war in Iraq was fought, how returning veterans had been treated and spending policies that he said saddled Americans with debt.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the New England Journal of Medicines response to a possible breach of confidentiality by a medical researcher, Dr. Martin B. Leon, misidentified the online news wire that first reported the matter. It was heartwire (www.theheart.org), not heartline. The article also included incorrect information from theheart.org about the role of Dr. Leon in its report. While Dr. Leon was initially cited as the reports only source for the Journals action, heartwire said Monday that an unidentified individual had provided details that were later confirmed by Dr. Leon.

title: Columbia Sprinter Faces Olympic Choice
description: Erison Hurtault is in demand. A senior at Columbia University, he has a New York investment bank offering him a full-time job, the Commonwealth of Dominica trying to put a relay baton in his hand and several people trying to persuade him to do both.

title: Suggested Reading
description: Four and a half years ago, after home run No. 600 but before Balco, David Grann wrote about Barry Bonds for The Timess Sunday magazine. According to Grann, the antihero machinery was already in full gear. PLAY Magazine offers this profile from our suggested reading list.

title: Foie Gras Makers Struggle to Please Critics and Chefs
description: TOM BROCK produces foie gras at a Southern California farm, but even he used to feel squeamish when he had to force-feed the geese with an 8- to 10-inch steel tube to fatten their livers.

title: Equity Firm Wins Bidding for a Retailer, Alliance Boots
description: LONDON, April 24  A private equity firm and an Italian billionaire won the takeover battle Tuesday for Britains largest drugstore chain, Alliance Boots, in Europes biggest private equity buyout.

title: Against Left-Handers, the Mets Are All Right
description: The Mets addressed last seasons woes against left-handers by signing Moises Alou to balance the lineup. Alou has done his part, batting .333 against them, but his success is only a small part of why they entered last nights game against Colorado with the majors best average against left-handed pitching (.357).

title: 2 Rangers Games Only on Versus
description: Many Rangers fans will not be able to watch Game 1 of the Eastern Conference semifinals against the Buffalo Sabres tonight because it will be seen only on Versus, which is available in far fewer homes in the New York market than MSG is.

title: Yeltsins Legacy Is Like Russia Itself (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Shareholders of Times Co. Hold Out 42% of Board Vote
description: Shareholders of The New York Times Company gave voice yesterday to their growing displeasure with the companys management and financial performance by withholding votes representing 42 percent of the Class A shares at the annual meeting.

title: Embattled North Korea Celebrates Its Military
description: SEOUL, April 25  Columns of soldiers accompanied by missiles and rockets marched through Pyongyang today under the eyes of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, in a bold display of defiance by a country that has been engaged in a nuclear standoff with the United States.

title: The Supreme Courts Catholic Majority
description: The five justices who turned the Supreme Court around last week and upheld the ban on partial birth abortion had much in common.

title: Bush Presses Schools Plan During Trip to New York
description: President Bush fought with the Democrats over war financing yesterday morning. But in the afternoon he came to Harlem to seek common cause with the rival party, on its home turf, on his signature education initiative, No Child Left Behind.

title: Terrorism Police Arrest 6 in London-Area Raids
description: LONDON, April 24  The British counterterrorism police raided homes around dawn on Tuesday, arresting six men, including one said to be a well-known advocate of radical Islam who once called the London bombings of 2005 praiseworthy.

title: Ethiopian Rebels Kill 70 at Chinese-Run Oil Field
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 24  Separatist rebels stormed a Chinese-run oil field in eastern Ethiopia on Tuesday, killing more than 70 people, including nine Chinese workers, in one of Ethiopias worst rebel attacks in years.

title: Recipe: Roast Rabbit With Green Garlic Sauce
description: Adapted from Melissa Kelly, Primo Restaurant, Rockland, Me.

title: Hispanics Reshaping U.S. Catholic Church
description: The influx of Hispanic immigrants to the United States is transforming the Roman Catholic Church as well as the nations religious landscape, according to a study of Hispanics and faith released today.

title: Drop in Sales of Previously Owned Homes Is Steepest Since 1989
description: A rebound in residential real estate remains elusive.

title: Outside the Box: Rethinking All Geometric Limits of Form and Frame, Floor and Ceiling
description: The provocative Brian ODoherty/Patrick Ireland retrospective at New York Universitys Grey Art Gallery highlights the decade when Minimalism morphed into Conceptualism. What youll discover here is a manifesto, albeit a high-minded one, that represents the decade (1966-1976) when artists thought they could change the world not by filling it with new stories, but by emptying it of them.

title: Britains Anti-Terror Chief Offers Somber View
description: LONDON, April 25  In a somber and wide-ranging assessment of the threat facing his country, Britains top counterterrorism police officer, Peter Clarke, said Al Qaeda has survived a prolonged multi-national assault and its supporters had established an inexorable trend towards more ambitious and more destructive attack planning.

title: From Brothers Death, a Crusade
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  One Friday afternoon in March 2000, Alison Malmon, a freshman at the University of Pennsylvania, got word that her brother, Brian, a 22-year-old on leave from Columbia, had committed suicide.

title: Auto Rivalries Make Madison Avenue a Frantic Street
description: THE frenetic competition in the automotive industry is taking its toll on the advertising industry.

title: A New Alliance in the Fight Against Childhood Obesity
description: AS television food moments go, it was one of the odder ones: former President Bill Clinton and Rachael Ray tossing together a bowl of turkey Bolognese with whole wheat pasta in her television kitchen.

title: AT&T Earnings Top Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24  AT&T Inc., the worlds largest telephone company, reported first-quarter earnings on Tuesday that handily beat Wall Street expectations. But some investors and telecommunications industry analysts said they were not sure that AT&T could continue its pace, particularly as growth is slowing in the mobile phone business.

title: Questions on Officials Ties to Lenders
description: Sara Martinez Tucker, the under secretary of education, was relatively new to her job when she announced in January that the Department of Education would allow Nelnet, a student loan company accused of overbilling the government, to keep $278 million in payments that auditors had declared improper.

title: For N.F.L. Draft, the Biggest (XXXXXXL) Sleeper
description: GALVESTON, Tex., April 21  On the edge of the Texas Gulf is a 370-pound football player who can execute a perfect forward flip.

title: Shes Not Buttering Him Up
description: WASHINGTON

title: Russian Energy Giant to Bundle Carbon Credits With Gas Sales
description: MOSCOW, April 24  Gazprom, the Russian energy giant, has made handsome profits selling natural gas to Europe.

title: Sales of Existing Homes Plunge Steeply
description: Sales of previously owned homes suffered their biggest drop in nearly two decades last month, raising concerns that a rebound in the housing market is still far off.

title: Congressman, Teacher, Soldier, and Hes Back in Town for a Visit
description: MANKATO, Minn.

title: Panel Hears About Falsehoods in 2 Wartime Incidents
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  House Democrats burrowed into the histories of Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch and Cpl. Pat Tillman in a hearing on Tuesday, holding up the episodes as egregious examples of officials twisting the truth for public relations in wartime.

title: Into the Shadowy World of Sex With Animals
description: The director Robinson Devor apparently would like viewers who watch his heavily reconstructed documentary, Zoo, to see it as a story of ineluctable desire and human dignity. Shot on Super 16-millimeter film, with many scenes steeped in a blue that would have made Yves Klein envious, Zoo is, to a large extent, about the rhetorical uses of beauty and metaphor and of certain filmmaking techniques like slow-motion photography. It is, rather more coyly, also about a man who died from a perforated colon after he arranged to have sex with a stallion.

title: Appeals Court Allows Net Phone Company to Continue Signing Up New Customers
description: Vonage, the Internet phone company embroiled in a bitter patent suit with Verizon, is still in business, at least for now.

title: A Test for the Roberts Court
description: The campaign finance system is like an overburdened dam: it holds back a flood of special-interest money, but there is a constant struggle to keep it from springing leaks. The Supreme Court hears arguments today in a case that could determine whether a major new leak opens up, one that would allow corporations and unions to pour unprecedented amounts of money into political campaigns. It is important that the court continue to keep this money out.

title: Move Over G.M., Toyota Is No. 1
description: DETROIT, April 24  A quarter century ago, people in this city not only bashed the surging Japanese car companies with words, they also vented their frustration by swinging sledgehammers at Japanese cars, a way for some to raise money for charity (three swings for $1 at one event).

title: OSHA Leaves Worker Safety in Hands of Industry
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  Seven years ago, a Missouri doctor discovered a troubling pattern at a microwave popcorn plant in the town of Jasper. After an additive was modified to produce a more buttery taste, nine workers came down with a rare, life-threatening disease that was ravaging their lungs.

title: U.S. Says Fire Dept.s Exam Is Biased, Opening Way to Suit
description: A federal civil rights investigation has determined that the written entrance exam for the New York City Fire Department discriminates against black and Hispanic applicants, officials said yesterday.

title: Snarled Wires Halt Some Metro-North Trains
description: The rush hour turned nasty this morning for tens of thousands of commuters in Connecticut after the overhead wires that provide power to Metro-North trains collapsed.

title: Syrian Rights Lawyer Sentenced to 5 Years
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Apr. 24  Anwar al-Bunni, a prominent human rights lawyer, was sentenced Tuesday by a Syrian court to five years in prison for spreading false information damaging the country, his lawyers said.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Building Owners Costs Rose in Last Year, but So Did Revenues
description: The cost of operating the apartment houses that hold the citys more than one million rent-stabilized apartments rose by 5.1 percent in the last year  less than in the previous year, the Rent Guidelines Board reported yesterday. And while building owners costs grew at a faster rate than their income, their revenue after operating expenses were paid still increased.

title: Making the Most of Beer, on Film
description: American history seen through a beer mug is the subject of a new film, The American Brew, produced by Florentine Films-Sherman Pictures. It begins in colonial days, when beer was safer to drink than water. It highlights the heyday of German immigration 100 or so years ago and the subsequent rise of industrialized beer plants in Milwaukee and other cities, and continues to the current craft-brewing movement. The film is enlivened by old advertising images like those above and left.

title: Paul Erdman, 74, Author of Finance-Based Novels, Dies
description: Paul E. Erdman, a writer of best-selling novels of financial intrigue who began his literary career in the comfort of a Swiss jail, where he was being held in connection with the collapse of the Swiss bank he ran, died on Monday at his ranch in Healdsburg, Calif. He was 74.

title: A Skeptical Vietnam Voice Still Echoes in the Fog of Iraq
description: The news reports streaming out of Vietnam in the fall of 1963 were unsettling to President Kennedy, and in a White House meeting the talk turned to a particularly irritating young reporter named David Halberstam.

title: From Africa to America: A Resolute Pilgrims Progress
description: Rosevelts America, the story of an African refugees progress in the United States, shows up tonight on PBS in the wake of other, more high-profile examples of that genre, including the feature documentary God Grew Tired of Us and Dave Eggerss fictionalized memoir, What Is the What? It actually predates them, though, having been shown in theaters in 2005, and it has one significant point in its favor: its only a half-hour long.

title: Billionaires Start $60 Million Schools Effort
description: Eli Broad and Bill Gates, two of the most important philanthropists in American public education, have pumped more than $2 billion into improving schools. But now, dissatisfied with the pace of change, they are joining forces for a $60 million foray into politics in an effort to vault education high onto the agenda of the 2008 presidential race.

title: Port Authority Is Reviving Plans for Bus Station Tower
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is resurrecting plans to build a skyscraper over the north wing of the bus terminal on Eighth Avenue between 42nd and 41st Streets.

title: At World Bank Meeting, Frustrations Boiled Over
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  At a meeting between Paul D. Wolfowitz and his top managers at the World Bank last week, Mr. Wolfowitz made an unusual confession. I understand that Ive lost a lot of trust, and I want to build that trust back up, he said, according to people present.

title: Staten Island Considers New Plans to Keep Its Youth From Leaving
description: To reverse the flow of younger people leaving Staten Island, the borough should entice developers to build more affordable apartments close to the ferry, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Must Be Italy, Theres Straw on the Bottles
description: AT this point in his justly storied career, Keith McNally could probably open a lemonade stand on a runway at La Guardia and have normally proud New Yorkers groveling for tarmac. So the crowds at his new restaurant, Morandi, didnt throw me.

title: Michael Smuin, 68, Dancer and Eclectic Choreographer, Dies
description: Michael Smuin, a choreographer who worked for major ballet companies and led his own, marshaling eclectic dance forms, robust athleticism and striking theatricality to create works that appealed to broad audiences, died yesterday in San Francisco. He was 68.

title: States Seek Limits on Robocalls in Campaigns
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  State investigators here are still trying to figure out who sabotaged Scott Kleebs campaign for Congress last November with a barrage of automated telephone calls to voters. The unauthorized calls, officials said, distorted Mr. Kleebs views and even used a recording of his voice  sometimes arriving in the middle of the night  with the greeting: Hi, this is Scott Kleeb!

title: Little Help for Watersheds in the West
description: DENVER, April 24  The Wests already stretched water supplies received no relief in March, as near-record high temperatures and below-normal precipitation wilted crucial watershed lands from the Pacific Northwest to the Sierra Nevada and the deserts of New Mexico.

title: Sexual Tormentor Testifies, but Victims Cant Bear to Listen
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 24  A former church youth director who confessed in 2003 to the statutory rape of four teenagers took the witness stand on Tuesday in a civil trial, but the two victims who are suing him were not present. They had left the courtroom here earlier, saying they could not bear to see him again.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies on Monday about Bostons 7-6 victory over the Yankees referred incorrectly to Derek Jeters hitting, and referred imprecisely to a home run by Manny Ramrez as part of a third-inning string of four consecutive homers by Red Sox batters. Jeters fifth-inning home run gave him at least one hit in 52 of his last 54 regular-season games in which he had an official at-bat  not 53 of 55 games. And the home run by Ramrez went out of Fenway Park, not high into the Green Monster seats.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL When the six finalists return to hear their fates after last nights vote, they will be surrounded by some established winners  of Oscars, Golden Globes, Emmys and Grammys, no less  in a two-hour Idol that concludes a two-night charity drive. The original Idol, Kelly Clarkson, above, joins the singers Gwen Stefani, Josh Groban, Pink and Annie Lennox and the actors Keira Knightley, Forest Whitaker, Daniel Radcliffe and Hugh Grant. (Mr. Grant recently starred in the Idol-based film American Dreamz.) The show will solicit donations for charities that help children living in poverty in Africa and the United States. Just in case that sounds too serious, Borat will be there too.

title: When the Wine Is Green
description: YOUVE taken your hybrid car out to run some errands. Youve stocked up on organic produce and nontoxic cleaning supplies at the supermarket. Youve stopped at the Home Depot to take advantage of its new Eco Options plan, picking up energy-efficient light bulbs, paint that is low in pollutants and wood harvested according to the principles of sustainable forestry. Youve dropped off the recycling. One more stop to make, the wine shop.

title: Corzine Takes Steps as Recovery Continues
description: TRENTON, April 26  Gov. Jon S. Corzine took a few steps with the help of a walker this morning and could be released from Cooper University Hospital in Camden as soon as Monday, said his chief of staff, Tom Shea.

title: Connected, and Willing to Tell All
description: S. N. Behrman came to the attention of theatergoers in the late 1920s and 30s as a writer of high comedies about good people from great stock. Behrman tended to view fortune not as a barrier to tolerance or vulnerability but as an impetus to higher moral calling. He was a conscientious objector in Depression-era class wars. As plays like Dinner at Eight cast an eye at the snobbish and trifling habits of the well-to-do, Behrman functioned almost as a press agent for the upper classes.

title: Mommy Books: More Buzz Than Buyers
description: In the last few months, Monique Moen, a former actress and now a stay-at-home mother in Los Angeles, has bought several books: Slaughterhouse-Five by Kurt Vonnegut; A Room of Ones Own by Virginia Woolf; Mistress of the Art of Death, a historical thriller by Ariana Franklin; and the latest James Patterson novel.

title: A New Low-Fare Airline on a Web-Only Approach
description: The extreme low-fare airline, already well established in Europe, will try for a comeback in the United States on May 22 with a well-financed start-up, Skybus Airlines, beginning service that day and promising at least 10 seats on every flight priced at $10 one-way  before taxes.

title: CBS Rejects Commercial That Seems to Mix Daly and Alcohol
description: CBS Sports is refusing to show a commercial for Maxfli, the golf ball maker, in which John Daly, whose fondness for alcohol is well known, drives a golf cart on a municipal course while carrying what appears to be beer.

title: Betraying a Democratic Legacy
description: Last Saturdays presidential election should have marked a major consolidation of democracy in Nigeria, Africas most populous country and biggest oil producer: the first free choice of one elected civilian leader to succeed another. Instead, it was an ugly travesty  not just procedurally flawed, but completely lacking in basic democratic plausibility.

title: Cuomo Says U.S. Is Lax on Student Lenders
description: WASHINGTON, Apr. 25  New York States attorney general accused the federal Education Department today of being lax in regulating the student loan industry and said that criminal charges might result from his months-long investigation of ties between universities and the student loan industry.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption last Wednesday with a music review of Sequitur, at Merkin Concert Hall, included outdated program information about the violinist shown. She was Miranda Cuckson  not Andrea Schultz, another Sequitur violinist.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday, about a campaign by Sharp Electronics to teach homeowners about solar energy, referred imprecisely to the companys agreement with the Google search engine. Sharp pays to appear high on the list of advertisements on Google search pages, not at the top of the search results.

title: Farmer, Cookie Maker, Ecologist and, Yes, the Future King
description: Tetbury, England

title: Shareholders Withhold Votes for Times Directors
description: Shareholders of The New York Times Company withheld 42 percent of their votes for board members at their meeting today in a symbolic gesture of protest against the companys investment strategies and governance practices.

title: Another Go at a Womens League, but Not Going It Alone
description: It has been nearly four years since players have kicked a ball in anger in a top-tier womens professional league in the United States. The Womens United Soccer Association ceased operations after the 2003 season, having raced through $40 million in seed money  which was supposed to last for five years  in only one season.

title: Defendants, on Video, Point Fingers in Death of a Gay Man
description: They told the police that they thought it would be easy to rob the gay man. It was not easy.

title: Michigan Landlord to Offer Free Space
description: DETROIT, April 24  Michigans largest commercial landlord is offering free space as an incentive to attract business into the economically challenged state.

title: ... Leads to a Game of Wits in a Sinister Underworld
description: The surfaces gleam as luxuriously in Johnnie Tos exemplary gangster thriller Triad Election as those in a similarly slicked-up Hollywood film, but the blood on the floor here seems stickier, more liable to seep and to stain. A dark, brutal look at the shadows darkening the Hong Kong triads, the film picks up the narrative line expertly coiled and kinked in Mr. Tos companion piece made the year before, Election. As in the earlier film (released in Hong Kong in 2005), this new work (2006) involves a Machiavellian game of chess between rivals, each of whom would be king, each of whom sacrifices legions of pawns.

title: Group Proposes Detailed Plan to Reduce Poverty by Half
description: With a large increase in the minimum wage and a handful of other measures to raise the income of low-end workers, the United States could cut the number of people living in poverty by half within a decade, a report from a liberal research group says.

title: Wall St. Firm Will Settle Sex Bias Suit
description: For years, sex discrimination lawsuits against Wall Street firms were almost guaranteed to include details of crude antics, pornography and strip clubs.

title: Inquiry on Political Influence
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  The agency in the Justice Department that handles complaints about political influence in the Civil Service will investigate whether the White House has improperly tried to use government agencies for political purposes, its spokesman said Tuesday.

title: Time-Traveling Lessons for a Teenager on the Verge
description: Echoing the tragic events last week at Virginia Tech, Sherman Alexies latest novel, Flight, features a young, edgy outcast named Zits on the verge of colossal violence. Mr. Alexie is no stranger to this brand of gutsy writing. With 17 volumes of fiction and poetry to his name, he has established an impressive literary reputation as a bold writer who goes straight for the aorta. He is in the business of making his readers laugh and cry. And his most recent novel is no exception.

title: Rosie ODonnell to Leave The View in June
description: Rosie ODonnell, who raised both the profile and ratings of The View this season by using it as a forum for her rants on the Iraq war, Donald Trump, Oprah Winfrey and even her own castmates, will leave the show in June after failing to reach a contract extension, she announced on the program this morning.

title: A Soft Spot for the Anti-Artisanal
description: I BELIEVE in God, organic produce and sustainable foods. I believe that an apple purchased in a Greenmarket will always be better for me than one purchased at a supermarket, even though it may look like a potato with a skin condition.

description: An obituary yesterday about Boris N. Yeltsin, the former Russian leader, referred incorrectly to Anatoly B. Chubais, who along with Mr. Yeltsins daughter Tatiana had persuaded Mr. Yeltsin not to outlaw the Communist Party, as Mr. Yeltsin later revealed in his memoir Midnight Diaries. Mr. Chubais was a former deputy prime minister, not a former prime minister.

title: U.S. Takes Step to Address Airliner Attacks on Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  New nuclear reactors need not be designed to withstand suicide attacks by big airplanes, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission decided Tuesday.

title: Japans Atonement to Former Sex Slaves Stirs Anger
description: TOKYO, April 24  Facing calls to compensate the aging victims of its wartime sexual slavery, Japan set up the Asian Womens Fund in 1995. It was a significant concession from Japan, which has always asserted that postwar treaties absolved it of all individual claims from World War II.

title: Toyotas Rise Is a Milestone in Global Industry
description: HONG KONG, April 24  Toyota sold more cars and trucks around the world in the first three months of 2007 than any other manufacturer and surpassed General Motors for the first time, ending one of the longest runs of dominance in all of global industry and marking another milestone in Americas long decline from unchallenged industrial preeminence.

title: Manhattan: Housing Law Struck Down
description: Justice Marilyn Shafer of State Supreme Court yesterday struck down the Tenant Empowerment Act, a 2005 New York City law giving tenants in subsidized rental buildings the right of first refusal to buy their buildings if the owners decide to sell or quit rental assistance programs like Mitchell-Lama. Justice Shafer said she reluctantly concluded that the city cannot limit rights granted to building owners by the State Legislature in allowing them to withdraw from Mitchell-Lama. The Legislature itself could choose to protect middle- and low-income tenants in those buildings, she pointed out. In failing to do so, or to permit the City of New York to do so, the State Legislature has failed the residents of the City of New York, she wrote in her opinion.

title: Board Divided on Renewing Contract for Siemens Chief
description: FRANKFURT, April 24  Klaus Kleinfelds future as the chief executive of Siemens, the scandal-ridden engineering giant, was left hanging Tuesday as the companys supervisory board wavered over the extension of his contract.

title: No Charges for Apple Over Options
description: Federal securities regulators said yesterday that they would bring no civil charges against Apple over the backdating of executive stock options. But they stopped short of removing the cloud that for nearly a year has hung over the companys chief executive, Steven P. Jobs.

title: Appeals Court Allows Net Phone Company to Continue Signing Up New Customers
description: Vonage, the Internet phone company embroiled in a bitter patent suit with Verizon, is still in business, at least for now.

description: BEIJING, April 24  China announced new regulations on Tuesday to reduce government secrecy and grant citizens greater access to official information, but the regulations include broad exceptions that raise questions about how much new openness will be tolerated.

title: Poland Ties U.S. Missile Plan to Security Pledges
description: WARSAW, April 24  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates was told Tuesday that the Polish government supported proposals to base 10 American missile interceptors on its soil, but only so long as Polands security was enhanced along with that of Western Europe.

title: Police Chief and Wife Accused of Bilking a Volunteer Group
description: TRENTON, April 24  With 24 years on the job as chief of police in Clayton, N.J., Norman Frank Winters was already the stuff of local legend with his work promoting drug education and planning alcohol-free after-prom and after-graduation events for schools.

title: A Basketball Coachs Ultramodern Milan Loft
description: Andrea Trinchieri balances two worlds  the heritage of Italy and the sleek modernity of a New York City loft.

title: 2 N.Y. State Troopers Shot; 1 Dies of Injuries
description: The police surrounded a farmhouse in a rural hamlet in the Catskill Mountains today in search of a man suspected of killing a state trooper and wounding two others in what began as a routine traffic stop on Tuesday afternoon, officials said.

title: Corzine Leaves Hospital Bed for First Time Since Crash
description: TRENTON, April 24  Gov. Jon S. Corzine, freed from a catheter tube in his back, was able to sit upright in a chair on Tuesday for the first time since his car accident nearly two weeks ago, according to a statement released by a spokesman.

title: What You Get for ... $400,000
description: Atlanta

title: Youthful Exuberance Carries Day for Raptors
description: TORONTO, April 24  Shortly before 9:25 p.m. Tuesday, red confetti fell from the rafters at the Air Canada Center. An old-school hip-hop tune blared from the loudspeakers, fans waved red flags, and the Toronto Raptors dancers performed on the court.

title: Al Qaeda-Linked Group Says It Killed 9 Soldiers in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April 24  An insurgent umbrella group that includes Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia claimed responsibility today for a suicide bombing that killed nine American soldiers on Monday and wounded at least 20, one of the deadliest attacks against American forces in more than four years of war.

title: Long Islanders Long Road to the Major Leagues
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 22  It did not matter that Kauffman Stadium was half-empty Sunday, or that the wind was whipping around the field. Ross Gload said he was simply happy to be there, wearing what he called a kids uniform and playing the game he loves.

title: Democrats Ramp Up Their White House Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  In a vivid display of their new power, Democrats across Capitol Hill approved a flurry of subpoenas today to fuel a series of investigations of the Bush administration.

title: A Low-Key Gangsters Rise in Sunny Hong Kong ...
description: Election, the first installment in Johnnie Tos two-film Hong Kong gangland serial, is a densely plotted, pulpy procedural with a familiar enough premise. The power struggles and succession battles that plague organized crime are a staple of American popular culture  what else have we been watching on The Sopranos for the past eight years?  but Mr. Tos Hong Kong mobsters conduct their business a bit differently, on democratic rather than dynastic principles.

title: Virginia Tech Sets Out to Preserve Objects of Grief, Love and Forgiveness
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 24  The shrines arose spontaneously in the past few days on the Virginia Tech campus, makeshift memorials of letters and flowers to those who died in the shooting rampage on April 16. And, remarkably, there were 33 of them.

title: Spitzer Seeks Overhaul of New Yorks Abortion Law
description: ALBANY, April 25 Gov. Eliot Spitzer plans to introduce legislation to overhaul the states pioneering but antiquated abortion law, shoring up a womans right to an abortion in New York State.

title: Rival Bid for ABN Amro Is $98.5 Billion
description: LONDON, April 25  Royal Bank of Scotland, the British bank, and two other European lenders today offered 72.2 billion euros, or $98.5 billion, for ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, triggering one of the biggest takeover battles in the banking industry.

title: Warren E. Avis, 92, Founder of Car Rental Company, Dies
description: Warren E. Avis, a Michigan car dealership owner who, frustrated at waiting for taxis outside airports, founded a chain of car rental agencies and turned it into the nations second biggest, died yesterday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 92.

title: A Growing Interest in Composite Decks
description: When Rick Denniston was designing his ocean-view vacation home in Gualala, Calif., 113 miles north of San Francisco, he knew he wanted to build a deck or two to watch gray whales and their calves migrate along the northern California coast each winter and spring.

title: Trying to Break the Jinx of Chicagos Block 37
description: CHICAGO  When Joe Mansueto was pondering whether to relocate the main offices of his financial services company to a new office tower under construction in the Loop, the history of the site gave him second thoughts. But Mr. Mansueto, chief executive of Morningstar Inc., which is now several blocks west, finally decided to make the move.

title: Panel Says Historical Society Can Alter Landmark Building
description: After months of controversy, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission ruled unanimously yesterday that the New-York Historical Society can renovate the exterior of its landmark building at 170 Central Park West.

title: Queens: Proposed Water Bill Increase Is Criticized
description: Officials and city residents yesterday criticized a proposed 11.5 percent increase in city water and sewer bills. In the first of five public hearings scheduled to take place over three days, speakers told the New York City Water Board, which sets the rates for the city, that the increase would hurt working families, especially those on fixed incomes. The senior citizens are going to be in trouble, Nancy DiCroce, 76, of Howard Beach, said at the meeting, which was held at the citys Department of Environmental Protection office in Flushing. The increase, which would go into effect in July, would add $72 to the average annual water and sewer bill for a single-family home in the city, bringing the average bill to $699. The departments deputy commissioner, Anne Canty, said she hoped that the increase would not be too much of a burden but was what the system really needs right now.

title: With ABN Amro, Barclays Sees Asia Growth Atoning for Cuts Elsewhere
description: NEW DELHI, April 24  Job cuts in Europe and the United States may be offset by growth in Asia if Barclays and ABN Amro complete their nearly $91 billion deal.

title: Manhattan: Transit Worker Killed by Train
description: A transit worker was accidentally killed by a train in the Columbus Circle station in Manhattan late last night, the police said. The worker, whose identity had not been released, was hit around 11:25 p.m. and declared dead at the scene. Trains were stopped for at least half an hour while investigators were at the scene. It was not immediately clear why the worker was on the track, the police said.

title: Bulls Energy Overwhelms the Heat
description: CHICAGO, April 24  The deficit looks eerily familiar to the Miami Heat. Even the words coming out of a losing locker room sound the same.

title: In Seeking Taxes, New York Challenges India and Mongolia in U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  New York imposes property taxes on the portion of foreign countries United Nations missions that are used not for diplomacy but as housing for staff members. The State Department has instructed foreign countries to pay those taxes. The question for the Supreme Court on Tuesday was what happens when they refuse.

title: Bronx: Girls Death Ruled Accidental
description: The death of a 5-year-old girl who was found hanged on Sunday in her Eastchester apartment has been ruled accidental by the city medical examiner, a spokeswoman said yesterday. The spokeswoman, Ellen Borakove, said the girl, Monet Fulgham, had accidentally hanged herself with a jump-rope. Ms. Borakove said the investigation showed that Monet was playing with a jump-rope that was attached to a closet door.

title: Attack by Hamas Casts Doubt on Future of Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, April 24  The military wing of Hamas fired a barrage of rockets and mortar shells from the Gaza Strip into Israel on Tuesday for the first time since Hamas committed to a cease-fire in November.

title: For Indian Victims of Sexual Assault, a Tangled Legal Path
description: As a Cherokee woman charging rape by a non-Indian, Jami Rozell could not go to the tribal court, which handles only crimes by Indians against Indians in Indian country. So after five months of agonizing, she went to the district attorney in Tahlequah, Okla., and testified at a preliminary hearing.

title: Chvezs Bunt to Pitcher Goes Long Way for Mets
description: Swinging away with runners in scoring position last night left the Mets frustrated and empty. So Endy Chvez tried something different. He bunted.

title: Dining Briefs
description: This week, the Dining section introduces Dining Briefs, short reviews that include first looks at new restaurants, quick updates on places that have been reviewed or overlooked, and critiques of bars and lounges that offer noteworthy drinks and food. The feature will provide an informed opinion on places around New York City that are worth consideration even if they don't receive a full review in Frank Bruni's Restaurants column or in Peter Meehan's $25 and Under. Dining Briefs will alternate every other week with $25 and Under.

title: A Famously Sharp Eye, and Appetite, for Artistic Masterpieces
description: The title of the documentary The Collector undersells its subject, the influential New York art gallery owner Allan Stone, who died in December after a long career spent introducing the world to his discoveries.

title: New Rules for Confining the Mentally Ill
description: New York State would more closely scrutinize its use of solitary confinement for mentally ill prison inmates under the proposed terms of a legal agreement scheduled for review by a federal judge on Friday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Monday about an increase in debate requests for presidential candidates referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of a debate promoted by advocates for the homeless. The debate has been proposed for January 2008 during the 11th Annual Homelessness Marathon, a nationwide radio broadcast originating in San Francisco. The advocates did not propose it for this past February in Fresno, Calif., during the 10th marathon broadcast.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about a new documentary on the photography collector Sam Wagstaff misstated the name of the museum that was charged with obscenity in 1990 when it showed work by Robert Mapplethorpe, Mr. Wagstaffs protg and lover. It was the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati  not the Cincinnati Museum of Art.

title: Indonesian Court Acquits Newmont Mining
description: MANADO, Indonesia, April 24  An Indonesian court acquitted Newmont Mining Corporation, the American mining giant, and one of its senior executives on Tuesday of charges of polluting a bay here with toxic waste from a now defunct gold mine, in a case that became a litmus test of foreign investor confidence in Indonesia.

title: Judge in Sex Attack Trial Excludes Writers Statements to Detective
description: A Manhattan judge ruled yesterday that three days of statements made by Peter Braunstein, a fashion writer accused of sexually molesting a former colleague at a fashion publication, should be excluded from his criminal trial.

description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the success Ashton Kutcher and Jason Goldberg have had with their Katalyst Films production company referred incorrectly to the assets of Merv Griffin, another successful producer to whom Mr. Kutcher was compared in the article. Although Mr. Griffin did indeed once own the Beverly Hilton hotel, he sold it in 2003.

title: Preserving Fossil Fuels and Nearby Farmland by Eating Locally
description: JESSICA ABEL may have gone to extremes when she collected seawater from Long Island Sound and boiled it down to make two cups of salt. But people who are determined to eat only food made within 100 miles, give or take, sometimes find themselves reaching for creative solutions.

title: Yankees Find Themselves in Last Place They Expected
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 24  Mike Myers stood on the pitchers rubber, aimlessly kicking the dirt with his right foot, over and over. His eyes darted away from the fielders converging on him, away from the manager coming to take the ball. Myers was a portrait of isolation.

title: A Veteran Actor Who Defies Pigeonholing
description: Put Farley Granger in a grocery checkout line, and when the time comes to select paper or plastic, he might well choose both. Mr. Granger, in his star-studded personal life and in his nearly 60 years as an actor, has made an art form of keeping one foot in each of two worlds. Film and theater. American and Italian. Gay and straight.

title: Police Yet to Determine Motive in Virginia Tech Shooting
description: BLACKSBURG, Va. April 25  The police in Virginia said on Wednesday that they have still not determined a motive for Seung Hui Chos shooting rampage last week at Virginia Tech in which he killed 32 people at two buildings before turning the gun on himself.

title: Mexico City Legalizes Abortion Early in Term
description: MEXICO CITY, April 24  The Mexico City legislature approved a bill Tuesday to make abortion legal during the first three months of pregnancy, a watershed vote that set the stage for court battles and social clashes between religious conservatives and liberals.

title: Astronomers Find Planet Outside Solar System
description: The most enticing property yet found outside our solar system is about 20 light years away in the constellation Libra, a team of European astronomers said today.

description: An unusual land rush is stirring in Midtown Manhattan: many companies are signing long-term leases for much more office space than they need.

description: MOSCOW, April 25  Russia today buried Boris N. Yeltsin, the countrys first democratically elected president, after a somber, symbolic funeral service that was attended by Russias political elite, current and former world leaders, and his family and close friends.

title: Hughes Did Not Hear First Call to the Mound
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 24  When the Yankees called Phil Hughes on Monday to tell him he was going to the major leagues, Hughes was in a mall eating lunch with his teammates. He did not feel his cellphone vibrate.

title: Haitian-Born Candidate Wins Again in Brooklyn
description: In a highly unusual second special election yesterday to fill a vacant City Council seat in central Brooklyn, Mathieu Eugene was once again the winner. The election paves the way for him to become the first Haitian-born member of the Council.

title: House Nearing Vote on Setting Timetable for Iraq Pullback
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The House is moving tonight toward voting on a $124 billion war spending bill that would require American troops to begin withdrawing from Iraq by Oct. 1, and its approval would set the stage for the first veto fight between President Bush and majority Democrats.

description: WASHINGTON, April 24  President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney aggressively challenged the motives of Congressional Democrats on Tuesday, as the House and Senate prepared to consider a war spending bill that would order troops to be withdrawn from Iraq beginning later this year.

description: PARIS, April 24  Virgin Atlantic Airways ordered 15 fuel-efficient Boeing 787 planes Tuesday as part of an environmental partnership with the company that includes joint research into biofuels for use in jet engines.

description: The typically slow winter months for traditional retailers did not seem to put a chill on the shopping at Amazon.com.

title: Halberstam on Journalism
description: Perhaps the best thing any young reporter could do after meeting David Halberstam was to imagine him sitting alongside, watching every interview, mulling over every verb or quotation or fact. Mr. Halberstam, who died in an automobile accident on Monday, counseled thousands of young reporters. And most who listened came away with some bit of advice that sounded positively oracular.

title: Sabres Choose to Let Skates Do Their Talking
description: BUFFALO, April 24  Known for their speed on the ice, the Buffalo Sabres have chosen to take a more cautious approach off it in a budding war of words with the Rangers.

description: Jordan Palmer shops for his clothing at Goodwill stores, which seems a fitting way to introduce a quarterback prospect for whom the N.F.L. draft is a hand-me-down experience.

description: The New York Philharmonic, hunting for a successor to its music director, Lorin Maazel, has decided to divide up its leadership by adding the new position of principal conductor, orchestra officials said yesterday.

title: McCain Replaces His Finance Director Just Before Official Tour to Declare Candidacy
description: On the eve of his official announcement tour to declare his candidacy for president, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, has replaced his finance director, a move that came after the campaign reported it had raised less than the partys two other leading candidates.

title: Renney, Rangers Cool Hand, Is Smoothing the Rough Edges
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 24  Tom Renneys steady, silver-eyed gaze is now matched with a head of silver hair and neither ever seems to be in disarray. Renney also wears perfectly pressed shirts and crisp ties, and they, too, look just as pressed and crisp after a Rangers game as they did before the contest began.

title: 2 Music Concerns Resolve Dispute
description: The Warner Music Group, the recording company, said yesterday that it would receive $110 million as part of a settlement with Bertelsmann, the German media giant, that resolves claims that Bertelsmann had contributed to widespread copyright infringement by supporting Napster, the file-sharing service.

title: Sporting Goods Maker Is Said to Be Acquired
description: In a deal that tosses sports equipment into its bulging locker of products, the Jarden Corporation will acquire K2, the maker of K2 skis and Rawlings baseball gloves and bats, for about $1.2 billion in cash and stock.

title: Pentagon Intelligence Chief Proposes Ending a Database
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  The Pentagons new intelligence chief intends to dismantle an antiterrorism database that civil liberties groups have criticized for gathering information about antiwar groups, churches and student activists, Defense Department officials said Tuesday.

title: Riches at Receiver
description: Keyshawn Johnson will be at the National Football League draft Saturday as a television analyst, but he may be able to offer some historical perspective as well. Johnson, the Carolina Panthers receiver, was the last receiver to be selected with the first pick over all, by the Jets in 1996. He and Irving Fryar were the only receivers drafted first over all since 1970.

description: For design-conscious Manhattanites who couldnt make it to Milan for the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the contemporary furniture fair, there is always Manhattan.

description: Council Election in Brooklyn: We have made history today. The road we have traveled has not been an easy one. But we never quit.  Dr. Mathieu Eugene, after winning his second special election.

title: Morgan Stanley Will Settle Sex Bias Suit
description: For years, sex discrimination lawsuits against Wall Street firms were almost guaranteed to include details of crude antics, pornography and strip clubs. A bias settlement announced yesterday had no such lurid accusations, but sought to tackle a subtler, if arguably systemic, form of discrimination that has long troubled Wall Street.

title: Board Divided on Renewing Contract for Siemens Chief
description: Klaus Kleinfelds future as the chief executive of Siemens, the scandal-ridden engineering giant, was left hanging Tuesday as the companys supervisory board wavered over the extension of his contract.

title: Rival Bidders Offer $98 Billion for ABN Amro
description: ABN Amro, the Dutch financial services group, was at the center of one of the priciest bidding wars in history Wednesday, when a group including the Royal Bank of Scotland offered 72.3 billion euros ($98.1 billion) for the bank, in hopes of trumping a bid from Barclays of Britain.

title: Ocean Power Raises $100 Million in Nasdaq Listing
description: Ocean Power Technologies, which develops systems that generate electricity through the energy of ocean waves, raised about $100 million in its first stock listing in the United States. The New Jersey-based company said Wednesday it sold 5 million shares, to be listed on the Nasdaq, at $20 each. Shares of Ocean Power already traded on the AIM market of the London Stock Exchange.

title: Chase Says It Will Move if New York Balks on Subsidies
description: JPMorgan Chase is threatening to move thousands of employees from Midtown to Stamford, Conn., if New York officials do not give it a larger subsidy package to build a 50-story skyscraper near ground zero, The New York Times reported.

title: Sporting Goods Maker K2 to Be Acquired for $1.2 Billion
description: In a deal that tosses sports equipment into its bulging locker of products, Jarden will acquire K2, the maker of K2 skis and Rawlings baseball gloves and bats, for about $1.2 billion in cash and stock, the two companies announced Wednesday.

title: War at Home: The Clock is Ticking
description: The showdown between the Democratic-controlled Congress and the Bush administration over the emergency war spending bill is front and center again, as top-ranking Republicans like Vice President Dick Cheney seized the moment to denounce Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, and he replied in kind.

title: No Charges for Apple Over Options
description: Federal securities regulators said Tuesday that they would bring no civil charges against Apple over the backdating of executive stock options. But they stopped short of removing the cloud that for nearly a year has hung over the companys chief executive, Steven P. Jobs.

title: Greek Shipper Holds $200 Million I.P.O.
description: OceanFreight, a Greek shipping company, raised about $200 million in its initial public offering on the Nasdaq. It said part of the proceeeds would go toward the acquisition of seven drybulk carriers.

title: S.E.C. Examining Sallie Mae Trades
description: The student loan provider Sallie Mae, which last week agreed to a $25 billion buyout, said Tuesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating trading in its stock by at least two members of its board of directors.

title: Chicago Merc Posts 42% Rise in 1Q Earnings
description: Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, which is trying to outmaneuver a rival to buy the Chicago Board of Trade, said first-quarter earnings climbed 42 percent, as trading volume at the futures exchange continued to set records. Net income was $130 million, or $3.69 a share, up from $91.4 million, or $2.61 a share.

description: French

title: Alien Snatches New Funding from V.C.s
description: Nine months after canceling a proposed public offering, a radio frequency identification systems developer, Alien Technology, has returned to its existing stakeholders for a new $33 million round of venture funding.

title: Goldman To Acquire Myers for $1.07 Billion
description: Goldman Sachss private equity arm, Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, agreed to buy a polymer products maker, Myers Industries for about $1.07 billion, including debt, Myers said Tuesday. Goldman is paying $22.50 per Myers share, a 5 percent premium over Myers closing price Monday, valuing the company at about $790 million. The deal also includes about $276 million in debt.

title: Cinemark Bow Gets Tepid Reception
description: Cinemark Holdings, the theater chain, failed to wow the critics in its first day of trading Tuesday following its $532 million initial public offering. The company, backed by the buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners, sold 28 million shares at $19 a share, the top end of its expected price range. But the stock drifted after the debut, trading down as much as 6 percent during the day, to close flat at $18.91.

title: Web Video Search Service CastTV Gets Funding
description: CastTV, a Web video search start-up backed by the Netscape co-founder Marc Andreessen, has scored a $3.1 million round of funding led by Draper Fisher Jurvetson. CastTV, which has not started its service yet, also said it had signed a two-year deal with a major media company it did not name to power its online search.

title: Wi-Fi Upstart Meru to Test Public Markets
description: Business Wi-Fi startup Meru Networks will test Wall Streets recent finicky appetite for telecom stock when it files for an initial public offering perhaps later this year, the Red Herring reports.

title: A Fat Wallet Doesnt Mean Better Hedge Fund Picks
description: Wealthy investors say they are no better than anyone else at finding the worlds best hedge funds, those loosely regulated portfolios that can enrich the people who run them and those who invest in them. Three out of four wealthy investors polled by U.S. Trust, a company that has served high net-worth families for more than 150 years, said hedge funds are difficult to investigate and that it is difficult to find a good fund.

title: WPP In Talks for 24/7 Real Media, Report Says
description: An Internet ad firm 24/7 Real Media is on the auction block and has already been talking to Martin Sorrells WPP Group, the worlds second-largest ad company, among other potential suitors, The New York Post reported.

title: Photobuckets MySpace Move May Mean Sweeter Deal
description: Photobucket, an online photo and media sharing web site that is reportedly exploring a sale of itself, has apparently ended a spat with the News Corporations social networking site MySpace. And the maneuver may drive up the companys price-tag.

title: Text: Senator John McCains Declaration of Candidacy
description: The following are remarks from Senator John McCain declaring his candidacy for the Republican nomination for president as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: With ABN Amro, Barclays Sees Growth in Asia
description: If ABN Amro and Barclays seal their $91 billion merger pact, the newly formed behemoth will be making a big push into Asia, following a stream of Wall Street investment banks which have headed aggressively into India and into smaller Asian markets like Vietnam while bolstering their operations in China.

title: Block Trade Spurs Talk of a New Sainsbury Bid
description: Shares of J Sainsbury, one of Britains largest supermarket companies, jumped after a 1.4 billion pound ($2.8 billion) block of stock was acquired, spurring speculation an investor is targeting the company or its real estate, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Valeo Says It May Consider a Buyout
description: Locked in a proxy fight with its biggest shareholder, a French car parts maker, Valeo said it was open to offers by several private equity firms, Reuters reported. Valeo said a request for eight board seats from Pardus Capital Management, an investment company in New York, was excessive, but the companys executive chairman, Thierry Morin, said the firm will continue talks with the company.

title: Merrill to Invest $3 Billion in Japanese Bank
description: Merrill Lynch will invest $3 billion in Resona, providing the Japanese bank with additional cash to repay debt from a previous state bailout. The investment will be in the form of preferred shares of Resona convertible into common stock.

title: Goldman May Buy Korean Financial Firm, Report Says
description: Goldman Sachs is in talks to buy a South Korean asset management firm whose biggest owner is Australias Macquarie Bank, Reuters reported Wednesday citing sources it did not identify. Goldman wants to buy Macquarie-IMM Investment Management, in which the Australian investment bank controls 65 percent, with the Korean investment firm IMM owning the remainder.

title: Google Lays Claim to Most Visitors
description: By a statistical hair, Google passed Microsoft as the worlds most visited family of sites last month, according to data from comScore.

title: GlaxoSmithKlines Earnings Are Little Changed
description: LONDON (AP) -- Pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline PLC said today that its first-quarter profit was virtually flat as the company faced greater competition from generic versions of its drugs in the United States.

title: G.O.P. Signs of a Rotten Core
description: The Wall Street Journal editorial page says this months F.B.I. raids of the home of Rep. John Doolittle of California and the family business of Arizona Rep. Rick Renzi, both Republicans, are the residue of the G.O.P.s lost, arrogant Congressional majority [$], which allowed its principles to atrophy. If the Republicans hope to retake Congress in 2008, theyd do well to eliminate the habits that created these scandals in the first place.

title: 2008: First Day of the Rest of the Campaign
description: Todays the big day for Senator John McCain. Hes set to officially announce his candidacy in New Hampshire, the state that handed him a victory over then-Gov. George W. Bush in the 2000 G.O.P. primary. Since that time, hes gone from presumed Republican heir to, as The Washington Posts Dan Balz puts it, the candidate with the most to prove. But Mr. McCain is finding the silver lining in his diminished fortunes, writes Dan Nowicki of The Arizona Republic. Now he gets to run as the underdog again.

title: A Resurgent Al Qaeda
description: In what The Timess Alan Cowell described as a rare overview of the development of terrorism threats and of police and secret intelligence service counter-measures since Sept. 11, 2001, a top British official said today that Al Qaeda was alive and well despite major efforts to destroy it.

title: Buyout Firms Talk of I.P.O.s, Again
description: As the Blackstone Group prepares to go public, its rivals are continuing to evaluate the possibility of initial public offerings. The heads of three buyout firms shared their thoughts at the Milken Global Conference in Los Angeles by evaluating the pros and cons of initial public offerings, according to The Financial Times.

title: Chavez Comes Up Big by Going Little

Willie Randolph raved and raved and raved about Chavez  his speed, his defense, his compact swing  but would mistakenly refer to him as Sanchez and, when referring to Duaner Sanchez, would call him Chavez.

description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Senator John McCain of Arizona is about to reveal the not-so-secret news that he is running for president of the United States. A stage for the official announcement at noon has been set up here overlooking the Portsmouth Naval shipyard.

title: Adviser Backs Icahn for Motorola Board
description: Carl Icahn is on a roll. Building on a string of successful efforts to push for change at various companies, the billionaire financier has won the endorsement of an influential advisory firm in his face-off with Motorola. Institutional Shareholder Services, which gives voting recommendations to institutional investors, on Wednesday urged the cellphone companys shareholders to elect Mr. Icahn as a director  despite Motorolas ardent desire to keep him out of the boardroom.

title: Ruth Smith on Handels Messiah
description: On April 8, The New York Times published an article by Michael Marissen, a professor of music at Swarthmore College, arguing that Handel's "Messiah," and the "Hallelujah" chorus in particular, rejoices in the misfortune of Judaism with an over-the top triumphalism. On April 20, Mr. Marissen presented a longer version of the argument in a paper at a session of the American Handel Festival 2007 at Princeton University. Dissenting responses to the paper were offered by the Handel specialists Wendy Heller, addressing the musical aspects of the argument, and Ruth Smith, addressing the theological aspects. The Times has invited Ms. Heller and Ms. Smith to respond briefly to the earlier article as well. Ms. Smith's's response follows.

title: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
description: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly to maximize value, he told Fortune magazines Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Deltas creditors committee in January. But its also kind of fun, too.

title: Obama, Clinton Criticize Giulianis 9/11 Remarks
description: The two most prominent Democratic presidential contenders struck back today at Rudolph W. Giulianis comments in New Hampshire on Tuesday night, when he warned that America would be more vulnerable to another terrorist attack if a Democrat takes the White House.

title: Change of Plans After a Shooting
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer cut short his schedule today in the New York City area  including canceling his appearance at a NARAL lunch  to fly back to Albany after  two state troopers were shot in the Catskills. One of the troopers is reported to have died.

title: On Chrysler Auction, Iacoccas Not So Neutral
description: If Lee Iacocca, the legendary former chief of Chrysler, has a guess about which bidder will win his old company, hes keeping it to himself. Who knows? was his diplomatic response to Fortune when asked about the auction for the automaker. But he couldnt resist editorializing a bit on the process: Private equity funds scare me, Mr. Iacocca said. Do they really understand the car business?

title: New Details on Virginia Tech Shooting
description: Seung-Hui Chos shooting rampage at Norris Hall lasted nine minutes, Virginia Techs police chief, W.R. Flinchum, said today. During that time, he fired more than 170 rounds, killing 30 people and himself, the official said. Twenty four were injured, according to earlier reports.

The union, which has been raising questions about the benefits of private equity deals to workers and investors, wrote that Warner Musics new owners hollowed out a once-proud music company, harming its image in the music industry and potentially reducing its long-term value.

Instead, he made a brief appearance then headed back north after two state troopers were shot in the Catskills, one fatally. His wife, Silda Wall Spitzer, gave a version of the speech instead.

description: If President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney believe the belligerently partisan and misleading things they have been saying about Congresss war spending bill, their grip on the few options left in this disastrous war is even more tenuous than wed guessed. The sooner Mr. Bush and his allies drop the pretense that military victory is still possible in Iraq and their charges of defeatism against those who know better, the closer the nation will be to rescuing what can still be rescued from the debacle.

title: Missile-Defense Plan No Threat to Russia, Rice Says
description: OSLO, April 26  Brusquely dismissing protests by Russian officials, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said here on Thursday that a missile-defense system the United States plans to install in Poland and the Czech Republic would pose no danger to the security of Russia.

description: HOUSTON, April 25  A fierce tornado southwest of San Antonio killed at least 10 people on both sides of the Mexican border Tuesday night, injured many others and destroyed or damaged hundreds of homes.

description: LONDON, April 24  The premise behind the political plays often presented by the 240-seat Tricycle Theater in North London is that complex events and situations can at times be understood better when dramatized onstage than when recounted as news in dailies and on television.

description: FRANKFURT, April 25  The embattled chief executive of Siemens, Klaus Kleinfeld, said Wednesday that he would step down when his contract expired in September, the latest casualty in a widening corruption scandal that has shaken corporate Germany.

description: WASHINGTON, April 26  Hours before the Senate approved a bill that would set a timeline for troop withdrawal from Iraq, Gen. David Petraeus, the commander of American forces there, said a failure to prevail against terror and sectarian violence in Iraq would leave matters much, much worse in the country.
