title: New Haven: Ex-Police Official Indicted
description: The former head of the New Haven Police Departments narcotics division was indicted yesterday on charges including theft, bribery and fraud, federal prosecutors said. The former lieutenant, William B. White, 63, and three bail bondsmen were arrested last month in a federal sting operation. Prosecutors said Mr. White routinely received money from the three men: Robert Jacobs, 79, who runs a local bail bonds service, and his two sons, Paul, 48, and Philip, 47. According to prosecutors, the bondsmen would bribe Mr. White to track down criminals who had posted bail bonds but failed to appear; their failure to appear would have caused the bondsmen to lose money. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Pelfreys Grip on His Rotation Spot Is Becoming Tenuous
description: The Mets have seen Mike Pelfrey dominate. They have seen him pump fastballs past major league hitters and befuddle them with his sinker. They have seen him turn over tough lineups. They just have not seen him do it recently. Not for a while, actually.

title: Surplus Is Larger Than City Thought
description: New York Citys revenues are running $1.3 billion ahead of projections for this fiscal year, bringing the current budget surplus to $4.4 billion, according to new figures released yesterday in advance of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs executive budget announcement today.

title: Apple Zooms Past Rivals, With 88% Profit Growth
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25  Apple Inc. surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts for its usually tepid second quarter, delivering an 88 percent increase in profit on strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod music players.

title: Is Yankee Prospect Holding Space for Clemens?
description: Joe Torre mentioned Dwight Gooden as an example of a pitcher who was so good, so young. Fans of another generation might come up with Bob Feller. Nobody is expecting Phil Hughes, two months short of his 21st birthday, to be that kind of prodigy, but Hughes will have pressure on him nevertheless when he makes his major league debut tonight.

title: For the Curious, Its Open House Season
description: The 2007 season of show houses and house and garden tours runs through fall, with several events every weekend. Visitors  dreamers, planners, would-be master builders and just plain oglers  can peer into rooms that have been painstakingly restored to period detail, fancifully concocted with the latest whimsy and stuffed with owners collections of artworks great and tchotchkes small. They can gaze at the flowers, trees, mosses, grasses, ferns and fountains that have transformed backyards into seasonal Edens, smell the scent of blooms and feel the soft breeze.

title: A Narrow Window Into the Future
description: THE last time I needed a white shirt, I bought it at the mall.

title: A New Season Begins With a Celebration of a Master
description: Monday will be the 24th anniversary of the death of George Balanchine. For many dancegoers, the ending of a career so bountiful seemed the worst calamity to have befallen the art form since the death of Diaghilev in 1929. But far more Balanchine ballets are performed today than during his lifetime, by companies from San Francisco to St. Petersburg. Meanwhile, New York City Ballet preserves the main corpus of his choreography, while the School of American Ballet guards the flame of his academic teaching.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wolfowitz Escalates Battle to Stay at Bank
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Escalating his campaign to remain president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz accused the banks board on Wednesday of treating him shabbily and unfairly, and appealed for more time to defend himself against allegations of favoritism and other matters.

title: Moneyball Author Looks at Steroidball
description: As Barry Bonds moves ever closer to Sadaharu Ohs all-time home run record  if you factor in age and injuries, Bonds, 42, may not get to the magic number of 868 until some time around his 50th birthday  the riddle of just how many of his long flies may have made it over the wall thanks to the Clear and other substances remains unsolved. Michael Lewis, a PLAY Magazine contributor and the author of the best-selling Moneyball, tells us that he does not expect that question to remain unanswered for long.

title: A Finnish Composer Possessed of a Joyful, Mischievous Spirit
description: The Finnish composer Kimmo Hakola is less well known to American listeners than several of his compatriots, but if the four imaginative, spirited scores performed at the Miller Theater on Tuesday evening are a fair representation of his work, that is bound to change.

title: To Many in the Department, a Link to a Proud Tradition
description: Collectively, patches worn by New York City firefighters form a quilt, a tapestry intertwining the history of the city and that of the Fire Department, an institution with century-old standing in some of the citys oldest neighborhoods, the affluent and the afflicted alike.

title: All Eyes on Yankees Pitching Prospect
description: Although the Yankees game against Toronto last night was rained out, the postponement will not delay the major league debut of the right-hander Phil Hughes, who is considered one of the top pitching prospects in baseball.

title: For the Record
description: A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on April 6, about performances and discussions at the Flea Theater in Lower Manhattan, misidentified the curator who chose the works performed. She was Nina Winthrop  not Yasuko Yokoshi, who had been scheduled to be the moderator, but who was repalced by Ms Winthrop.

title: Shot Putter Follows Her Fathers Footsteps
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26  For Michelle Carter, a resilient 21-year-old senior at the University of Texas, this is just another weekend on the go. Her genes help.

title: 3 Officers Indicted in Drug Raid Death
description: ATLANTA April 26  A Fulton County grand jury has indicted three current and former police officers who were involved in botched drug raid that led to the death of an elderly Atlanta woman in November.

title: The Scottish Play, Told With Sound and Fury and Puppets
description: A puppet regime has seized control of the stage of the New Victory Theater. Plotting bloody murder, it slaughters men, women and children in pursuit of power until condign vengeance wreaks its ruin.

title: The Sabres Grab Control From the Rangers in a Flash
description: BUFFALO, April 25  The Sabres entered the second round of the N.H.L. playoffs Wednesday night bearing the high expectations of their city, which is festooned with Go Sabres banners and replete with neon signs dedicated to the teams Stanley Cup hopes, the desperation for a championship worn on its sleeve.

title: Studies Find More Genes Underlying Diabetes
description: Four reports published today have tripled the number of variant genes known to underlie type 2 diabetes, providing researchers with a clutch of novel insights into the biology of a disease that affects 170 million people worldwide.

title: Control and Dependence, With Rock n Roll on the Box
description: The poster in front of the Joyce Theater, where the Stephen Petronio Company performs this week, reveals much about the choreographers desire to attract younger audiences: the names of musicians, including Rufus Wainwright and Antony, appear above the dancers. The list reads like the potential soundtrack of Williamsburg: The Movie.

title: Iran: Nuclear Negotiator Meets With Europes Chief Diplomat
description: Iran met with the European Union over its uranium enrichment program, the first face-to-face talks between the top negotiators for the sides since the United Nations Security Council expanded sanctions on Iran in March. The talks, in Ankara, Turkey, continued late into the evening. At their conclusion, after five hours, Irans nuclear negotiator, Ali Larijani, said, There are ideas on the table, still in discussion, the Anatolian news agency reported. We have time to continue also tomorrow. Within two weeks, we will have more meetings. Javier Solana, the European Unions foreign policy chief who is negotiating on behalf of the permanent members of the Security Council, called the talks productive. A press conference is scheduled for today.

title: Up, Up and ... Never Mind
description: Smoketown, Pa.

title: Witness Says Sex Offender Filled Role of a Father
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 25  The witness recalled his troubles as a shy teenager with an alcoholic father and few friends, who cut classes and drank. Then a church youth director, Matthew Maiello, came into his life and steered him on a righteous path, he testified, transforming him with a sense of purpose, achievement and self-worth.

title: Guns and More Guns
description: By now, the logic is almost automatic. A shooter takes innocent lives, and someone says that if the victims had been armed, this wouldnt have happened. The only solution to a gun in the wrong hands, it seems, is a gun in the hands of everyone.

title: U.S. Officer in Iraq Accused of  Aiding the Enemy
description: BAGHDAD, April 26  The American military has charged a top commander at its main detention center here with nine violations of military law, including aiding the enemy, a rare and serious accusation that could carry a death sentence.

title: Lifting the Veil on Seventh
description: IN the parlance of wedding gown designers, a buildup is the art of transforming a strapless dress by adding a neckline and long sleeves for a more conservative bride. But the term could also be used to describe the changes taking place at Priscilla of Boston, the venerable bridal house that has outfitted the wedding parties of Nixons, Johnsons and Grace Kelly.

title: James Richards, Veterinarian and Expert on Cat Care, Dies at 58
description: Dr. James R. Richards, a prominent veterinarian who was a recognized authority on cat care, died on Tuesday in Johnson City, N.Y. He was 58 and lived in Dryden, N.Y.

title: Putin Suspends Arms Pact Over Missile Dispute
description: MOSCOW, April 26  President Vladimir V. Putin said Thursday that Russia would suspend its compliance with a treaty on conventional arms in Europe that was forged at the end of the cold war, opening a fresh and intense dispute in the souring relations between NATO and the Kremlin.

title: Obama, Gospel and Verse
description: Sometimes you take a shot.

title: New Hope at the Beauty Counter: Bling in a Jar
description: FOR most people, bathing in diamonds and gold is as likely an occurrence as washing the car with truffles. And yet it now appears that the endless search for smoother and younger-looking skin and the tireless acquisition of conspicuous signs of wealth have collided at the cosmetics counter. The result is an array of topical products almost too precious to be anywhere near a sink drain.

title: In TV Games, Preschoolers Learn as They Pedal
description: Game controllers come in many forms  so why not an exercise bike? The Smart Cycle from Fisher-Price is a child-size stationary bicycle that hooks up to a TV. The idea is to get your preschooler off the floor and pedaling to drive over letters on the screen while avoiding potholes.

title: Medicares Troubling Prospects
description: This years report from trustees of the Medicare program pushes back the projected date of insolvency by a year  to 2019  but in no way lessens the need to put the system on a sounder financial footing. The trouble is that the reports projections will now force the administration and Congress to propose solutions under rules that are perversely skewed to rule out the most progressive financing.

title: F.C.C. Suggests Ways to Curb TV Violence
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Concerned about an increase in violence on television, the Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday urged lawmakers to consider regulations that would restrict violent programs to late evening, when most children would not be watching.

title: Vanek Makes Sure His Return to Playoffs Is Not Just a Repeat
description: BUFFALO, April 25  Buffalo Sabres wing Thomas Vanek takes nothing for granted anymore. Not after what happened during last years playoffs. So on the morning before the Sabres played the Rangers in Game 1 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series, Vanek suggested he could be benched.

title: Wendys Shares Rise on Possibility of Sale
description: Wendys International Inc., which underwent jarring structural changes in the last 12 months, announced yesterday that more may come  including the possible sale of the company. Shares rose 12.6 percent in after-hours trading to $36.80.

title: Solid Reports for the Economy
description: Businesses placed more orders last month for heavy-duty items like machinery and electrical equipment, easing concerns that capital investment might be slowing.

description: For design-conscious Manhattanites who couldnt make it to Milan for the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the contemporary furniture fair that ended on Monday, there is always Manhattan, an excellent resource for Italian design from furniture to accessories to kitchen, bath and hardware supplies.

title: Rosie ODonnell Will Say Goodbye to The View
description: Rosie ODonnell, who raised both the profile and the ratings of The View this season by commandeering it as a bully pulpit for her opinions on the Iraq war, Donald Trump, Oprah Winfrey and even her own cast mates, will leave the show in June after failing to reach a contract extension, she announced on the program yesterday morning.

title: Alan Ball, 61, a Key Member of Englands Only Cup Winner, Is Dead
description: Alan Ball, a crafty 5-foot-6 soccer midfielder who at 21 was the youngest member of the team that won England its only World Cup, in 1966, died yesterday in Warsash, Hampshire. He was 61.

title: Brooklyn: 53 Face Drug Charges
description: After executing 19 search warrants early yesterday in the Cypress Hills Houses in East New York, the police said they had arrested 53 people, including 23 women, on charges of selling crack cocaine or heroin. The sweep was conducted at a public housing project that has long been plagued by illegal drugs. Eighty people were arrested there on similar charges in 2002. Inspector Steven Powers said that the arrests yesterday followed more than 100 drug purchases by undercover agents, and that some of the dealers had been paying tenants rent in exchange for using their apartments for drug sales. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that crime had spiked in the Cypress Hills Houses, but that the arrests would provide residents with better, safer lives.

title: A High-Definition Projector That Competes on Price
description: HDTVs are becoming cheaper every day, but high-definition projectors have long been priced with King Midas and his cohort in mind. The Epson PowerLite Home Cinema 1080, however, costs about as much as a large-screen TV and lets you project a 100-inch HD picture on any wall.

title: Stalled Train May Have Played Part in Track Workers Death
description: The subway train that struck and killed a track worker near the Columbus Circle station on Tuesday night had been diverted to the express track, where the accident occurred, because a stalled train was blocking a local track, according to two people briefed on the investigation.

title: New Bank Courts in Queens Neighborhood Where Many Have Long Trusted Only in Cash
description: By yesterdays opening, the building on 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens  once home to a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet  seemed distinctly banklike. Four tellers waited at their stations, deposit slips were lined up in neat stacks, and easy-listening music was playing over the sound system. The only thing missing was customers.

title: No Motive Yet for Rampage, Police Report
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 25  After sifting through evidence for 10 days and conducting scores of interviews, the Virginia police said Wednesday that they were no closer to determining a motive for Seung-Hui Chos shooting rampage last week at Virginia Tech.

title: In Los Angeles, Lakers Are Losing to Impatience
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif., April 25  A relentless, pounding anxiety permeates the Los Angeles Lakers training center. Phil Jackson senses it. Mitch Kupchak feels it. Kobe Bryant exudes it.

title: Now, Blu-ray Storage for Mac Users, and Someday Maybe a Movie
description: Blu-ray discs can hold 50 gigabytes of data, making a regular DVD seem cramped. They can also make life easier for digital photographers, video editors or anybody else who needs to stash big files on a recordable disc.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. What is the best way to clean and maintain wood?

title: Dean of Admissions at M.I.T. Resigns
description: Marilee Jones, the dean of admissions at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, became famous for urging stressed-out students competing for elite colleges to calm down and stop trying to be perfect. But today she admitted that she had fabricated her own academic educational credentials, and resigned after nearly three decades at the university.

title: American Idol Is the Price We Pay for a Menu of So Many Channels
description: Kinga Tompos, a graduate student at DePaul University, said she did not believe the news when she first heard it in the student center. But when she found out it was true, she was ecstatic.

title: Two Phones, One Calendar
description: Q. Is there a way for two Treo 600 smartphones to synchronize with a single Microsoft Outlook profile? My wife and I would like to keep track of each other and our kids lives in one calendar on our PC, and have it sync with each of our mobile phones.

title: Corzine Takes His First Steps Since Car Crash
description: TRENTON, April 25  With the assistance of a walker, Gov. Jon S. Corzine took his first steps on Wednesday since he was seriously injured in a car accident two weeks ago, administration officials said.

title: Damage to Metro-North Wires Delays Morning Travelers
description: Tens of thousands of rail commuters in Connecticut were stranded yesterday morning after the overhead wires that provide power to Metro-North trains were damaged, disrupting service for about five hours.

title: Texas Legislators Block Shots for Girls Against Cancer Virus
description: HOUSTON, April 25  A revolt by lawmakers has blocked Gov. Rick Perrys effort to make Texas the first state to require sixth-grade girls to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.

title: Coming From Behind, Curlin Emerges as a Favorite
description: The racing card at Gulfstream Park on Feb. 3 was loaded with big races and quality horses. They ran six stakes races that day and the competition included the 2006 Horse of the Year, Invasor, and the highly regarded 3-year-old Nobiz Like Shobiz. But the horse that made the biggest impression on Steve Asmussen was a maiden winner named Curlin.

title: Another Dubious Firing
description: Congressman Rick Renzi, an Arizona Republican, was locked in a close re-election battle last fall when the local United States attorney, Paul Charlton, was investigating him for corruption. The investigation appears to have been slowed before Election Day, Mr. Renzi retained his seat, and Mr. Charlton ended up out of a job  one of eight prosecutors purged by the White House and the Justice Department.

title: The Medium, the Message, the Drama of TVs Q & A
description: The conversations between David Frost and Richard Nixon that are the basis of Peter Morgans Frost/Nixon, newly on Broadway, took place over 28 hours 45 minutes during 12 days in March 1977. Distilled into four 90-minute segments and broadcast later that year, the interviews were shot in California, near Nixons San Clemente estate, in a rental house whose appointments seemed a threat to whatever dignity the former president might have hoped to reconstruct.

title: Ride With the Big Boys
description: Summer is biking season in Europe, and not just for the desperate 200 or so who form the Tour de France peloton. Anybody with a bike and a good pair of padded shorts can see the Continent from the comfort of a tiny leather perch. The U.K.s Graham Baxter is one of just seven operators of official Tour de France trips, and its "Live the Dream" packages allow riders to bike the Alpine stages the same day as the pros. Ciclismo Classico offers up Italy immodestly. The cycling tour outfit is featuring its Trips No One Else Has, which includes, among its many offerings, bike trips alongside celebrity chefs. There's also an eight-day trip that follows the worlds second-biggest bike race, the Giro dItalia, beloved among cycling fans, and this year known as the Giro of Climbs for its grueling mountain stages.

title: South Korea: Chip Maker Misses Expectations
description: Hynix Semiconductor, the maker of memory chips, reported a 45 percent increase in first-quarter profit, but the gain was less than some analysts expected after a glut drove down chip prices. Net income rose to 418 billion won ($451 million), from 289 billion won a year earlier, missing analysts estimates by more than 20 percent. Hynix joins Samsung Electronics, Micron Technology and Nanya Technology in reporting lower-than-expected results for the latest quarter because prices for computer memory chips have tumbled more than 60 percent.

title: Bohdan Paczynski, Pioneering Astrophysicist, Dies at 67
description: Bohdan Paczynski, a leading astrophysicist whose unconventional ideas led to new methods of studying distant stars and hidden planets, including a sweeping nightly survey of the entire sky, died last Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 67.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) 30 ROCK Batten the hatches! Jacks mother (Elaine Stritch, left, in a take on her Monster-in-Law role) blows into town on the news of his impending wedding to Phoebe (Emily Mortimer). Meanwhile, Liz deals with the difficulties of her long-distance relationship with Floyd while trying to locate Tracy, who is missing in action. Sean Hayes (Will & Grace) shows up as Kenneth the Pages country cousin.

title: U.S. Is Lax on Loans, Cuomo Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  New Yorks attorney general on Wednesday accused the federal Education Department of being lax in regulating the student loan industry and said that criminal charges might result from his continuing investigation into ties between universities and lenders.

title: Star of a 70s Singing Family, Still Spreading the Puppy Love
description: Intimacy and proximity are not the same thing. When television stars deign to appear in nightclubs, the mere fact of their showing up is supposed to be proof enough that they are living, breathing, feeling creatures who care deeply about their fans. The luckiest ones might even be able to touch them.

title: Haunted by That Troublemaker in the Attic
description: As much as you would like to ignore her, theres just no getting around the mad lady in the attic.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to plant a million trees in New York City over the next 10 years misstated the role of carbon dioxide, which trees absorb, in ozone layer depletion. In fact, it has no effect. (Go to Article)

title: Justices, 5 to 4, Overturn 3 Texas Death Sentences
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned death sentences in three cases from Texas, all by votes of 5 to 4 and all with Justice Anthony M. Kennedy providing the margin of victory to his four more liberal colleagues.

title: 400 Who Fled North Korea Stage Protest in Bangkok
description: SEOUL, April 25  More than 400 North Korean refugees have gone on a hunger strike in a detention center in Bangkok to protest poor sanitary conditions and delays in their resettlement in South Korea, human rights advocates and officials said Wednesday.

title: Parapet Collapse Forces Evacuation at Atlantic Yards
description: The rooftop parapet of a building at the site of the planned Atlantic Yards project collapsed today, forcing the evacuation of 350 people from a neighboring building, the authorities said.

title: Triathlon Finds a Fountain of Youth
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.

description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Territorial Out in the Hall
description: IN the annals of hallway malfeasance, the Nanny Incident looms large.

title: Schools Records No Longer Accepted
description: The N.C.A.A. announced that it will no longer accept academic records from Gods Academy Prep, a secondary school in Dallas that opened last year in a recreation center. An N.C.A.A. review of the school found a lack of formal instruction or organized curriculum structure, according to a news release. The school was opened in August 2005 in Irving, Tex., by a summer basketball coach and quickly blossomed to 40 students, all of whom were basketball players. The school sent two players to Division I schools last year: Jeremy Mayfield to Alabama-Birmingham and Tommy Moffitt to the University of Texas-Arlington. Two players from the school signed letters of intent to Division I schools this year, Marcus Brister to Iowa State and T. J. Clark to Morehead State. Their status will be reviewed.

title: Suspect in N.Y. Troopers Death Is Presumed Dead
description: MARGARETVILLE, N.Y., April 25  One New York State trooper was killed and another was wounded near this tiny Catskill Mountains town on Wednesday morning as they tracked down a suspect who the authorities said had shot and wounded another trooper the day before.

title: Singapore Makes a Pitch to Draw the Wealthy
description: SINGAPORE, April 25  This affluent city-state of 4.5 million people is aiming to be a sanctuary for the worlds wealthy and their money, Asias answer to Geneva and Zurich.

title: F.C.C. Moves to Restrict TV Violence
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Concerned about an increase in violence on television, the Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday urged lawmakers to consider regulations that would restrict violent programs to late evening, when most children would not be watching.

title: Hollywoods Shortage of Female Power
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25  A few days after the annual ShoWest movie convention last month in Las Vegas, where the studios trotted out clips from coming horror films and a battle-heavy science-fiction spectacle, Transformers, the producer Cathy Schulman got an unusual call.

title: Penalties for Product Piracy Advance
description: Endorsing a set of common criminal penalties across the European Union for the first time, the European Parliament approved legislation that would impose jail sentences and fines on counterfeiters of drugs, toys and other goods in the 27-country bloc. The legislation, which still must be approved by national governments, aims to protect consumers from unsafe products like fake Viagra pills or imitation condoms, while preventing the infringement of intellectual property in the music and film industry. .

title: In Pomp and Symbolism, Yeltsin Is Buried From a Cathedral
description: MOSCOW, April 25  Boris N. Yeltsin, Russias first democratically elected president, was buried Wednesday after a somber, symbolic funeral service attended by Russias political elite, current and former world leaders, family and close friends.

title: Poll Finds Majority See Threat in Global Warming
description: Americans in large bipartisan numbers say the heating of the earths atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment now or will soon and think that it is necessary to take immediate steps to reduce its effects, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds.

title: After Saudis First Steps, Efforts for Reform Stall
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  It was a scene to warm the heart of any democrat. Here in this autocratic kingdom, elected city councilmen vowed to stand up for poor fishermen and ask the government to ensure that a large section of seafront on which a new university is planned be left accessible to local residents.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,317 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Study Says Hispanics Alter U.S. Catholicism
description: The influx of Hispanic immigrants to the United States is transforming the Roman Catholic Church as well as the nations religious landscape, according to a study of Hispanics and religion released yesterday.

description: LONDON

title: Bloomberg Tells Gore He Should Run in 08
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he hoped former Vice President Al Gore would run for president in 2008, saying I think it would be good for the country.

title: Looking Perfect, One Pixel at a Time
description: December may be more than seven months away, but that is barely enough time for purists to lose 20 pounds, grow out bad haircuts, clean up those blemishes, and get the photos to the printer in time to mail out holiday cards.

title: Terrorists Reel in a Pawn From Small-Town Iraq
description: The Sirens of Baghdad completes Yasmina Khadras trilogy of histrionic, disturbing novels about Islamic fundamentalism. All three of these books (the other two are The Swallows of Kabul and The Attack) owe as much of their impact to the brutal realities they crystallize as they do to the authors narrative talents.

title: Flexing Muscles, Democrats Issue 3 Subpoenas
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  In a vivid display of their new power, Democrats across Capitol Hill on Wednesday approved a flurry of subpoenas to fuel a series of investigations of the Bush administration.

title: Israeli Premier Accused of Impropriety in Previous Post
description: JERUSALEM, April 25  The state comptroller released a report Wednesday accusing the beleaguered prime minister, Ehud Olmert, of improperly helping an associate during his term as minister of trade and industry in a previous government.

title: Rival Bid for ABN Amro Is $98.5 Billion
description: LONDON, April 25  Royal Bank of Scotland, the British bank, and two other European lenders on Wednesday opened the biggest takeover battle in banking industry by offering 72.2 billion euros, or $98.5 billion, for ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank.

title: In Comments About Apple Chief, Questions of Motive
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25  When Fred D. Anderson abruptly left Apples board last October as questions about the companys stock options practices grew, a former federal regulator said it looked as if the board threw Fred under the bus.

title: Zambia: 500,000 Anti-Malarial Bed Nets on the Way
description: The United States and the Global Business Coalition on H.I.V./AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria have jointly donated $2.9 million to distribute more than 500,000 insecticide-treated mosquito nets in Zambia. The nets will help protect those who sleep under them from contracting malaria, which kills up to 50,000 Zambians a year, mostly children. The nets, enough for a tenth of the countrys population, will be handed out before November, the beginning of the malaria season.

title: Do the Right Fit
description: The first step in preparing for a bike tour isnt, as you might expect, to get fit, but to get fitted. If your bike doesnt fit properly, youll have all kinds of problems, says Gabe Mullens, a program manager for Specialized Bicycle Components and a veteran of many tours. Problems range from debilitating knee injuries to shooting leg pains, sore backs, numb groins, fatigue (from inefficient pedal strokes), and generalized whininess. Most bike shops have computerized fitting systems. Or if youre persnickety and adept with a yardstick, you can fit yourself. Coloradocyclist.com has instructions and downloadable worksheets.

title: Johnson Has No Baggage and a Seat in First Class
description: Calvin Johnsons favorite is the one-handed, behind-the-back grab from his freshman year at Georgia Tech. It is an Internet hit, too, a did-he-just-do-that beauty from a career that has wrapped surpassing brilliance on the field in a quiet cocoon of politeness.

title: Entrepreneurs Can Earn Their Stripes in the Minor Leagues, Too
description: Branch Rickey is renowned for allowing Jackie Robinson to break baseballs color line in 1947 by signing Robinson to play for the Brooklyn Dodgers. But he was also celebrated for another significant contribution to the game.

title: The Forgotten and Offbeat, With Dashes of Ludwig Van
description: The violinist Midori has long been a highly visible agent for outreach, putting much time and effort into fostering music education and assisting young performers in their professional growth. Those noble goals also play a part in her work onstage. Without abandoning the standard works that form the core of her repertory, Midori has recently become a compelling advocate for new music and older pieces that have fallen into neglect.

title: Court Asked to Limit Lawyers at Guantnamo
description: The Justice Department has asked a federal appeals court to impose tighter restrictions on the hundreds of lawyers who represent detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and the request has become a central issue in a new legal battle over the administrations detention policies.

title: Id Like to Get Off the Stage Right Now
description: LOS ANGELES

title: In French Race, 2 Rivals Feel Scorn of an Also-Ran
description: PARIS, April 25  The defeated third man in the race for the French presidency seems to be calling the shots ever since he lost on Sunday.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Too Warm Too Soon? Too Bad

title: Police Identify Suspects Body in Trooper Slaying
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 26  The New York State police have identified a body found inside a charred farmhouse in the Catskill Mountains as that of Travis D. Trim, the 23-year-old man suspected of killing a state trooper this week and wounding two others.

title: Anne Pitoniak, 85, Actress Who Played Strong Older Women, Dies
description: Anne Pitoniak, who began her stage career in late middle age, but received a Tony nomination for her Broadway debut, in  night, Mother, and had an enduring career playing strong-willed older women, died on Sunday at home in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: Alone, Awash, Then Borne Aloft by Helping Hands
description: Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Dentist Appointment at Tiffanys
description: ON a recent afternoon, in the dental office of Dr. Jeff Golub-Evans on the Upper East Side, Anne Keane, a 26-year-old executive assistant from Little Silver, N.J., donned a pair of orange sunglasses, revved up the offices loaner iPod, and lay back to get her teeth buffed with a paste made from 2 milliliters of pulverized diamonds.

title: The Danger Downwind
description: IN 2005, the Environmental Protection Agency took its first important step toward reducing mercury pollution from coal-fired power plants. Its Clear Air Mercury Rule is intended to bring about a 70 percent reduction in mercury emissions over the next 20 years.

title: McCain Announces for President, With a Critique of the Current One
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., April 25  Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, formally began his second bid for the White House on Wednesday with a thinly veiled critique of the Bush administration, pledging that he would restore competence to foreign and domestic policy and welcome compromise with Democrats.

title: Trenton: Nuclear Decision Is Appealed
description: New Jersey officials asked a federal appeals court yesterday to overturn a decision by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that the possibility of a terrorist attack on the Oyster Creek nuclear plant should not be a consideration in deciding whether to extend its license. Oyster Creek, the countrys oldest operating plant, is seeking to extend its license for 20 years beyond its 2009 expiration date. In reviewing the potential environmental impact of continued operation, the N.R.C. did not take terrorism into account, and state officials claim that the commission erred. They have appealed the decision in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

title: Enter This Door at the Risk of a Loss of Sanity
description: Do you ever wonder why things look better with the skin off? Its a question that in real life would have you edging out of the room, especially when the guy goes on to say the bones are calling to him. But when it was asked in The Elder Scrolls IV: Shivering Isles, I thought, this is someone I need to have a chat with.

title: Brooklyn: Driver Charged in Death
description: A man from Princeton, N.J., was arrested and charged with driving without a license after his vehicle killed a motorcyclist in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said. Shiraz Sanjana, 47, was driving north on Ocean Avenue near Avenue R shortly after 2 p.m. when he suddenly made a U-turn and hit Syed Adil Zaidi, 21, of Brooklyn, who was going south on his motorcycle, the authorities said. Mr. Zaidi was was declared dead on arrival at a local hospital. Mr. Sanjana was charged with aggravated unlicensed operation of a motor vehicle and driving without a license.

title: As War Grinds on, So Does the Sparring (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Flashy but Well Within the Lines
description: STYLE, at least when it comes to mens wear, is all about balance. As much as stylish men want to stand out, they also strive for understatement.

title: For the Record
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday, about weight-loss products, included an outdated reference to the drug Alli, known clinically as orlistat. The Food and Drug Administration approved it on Feb. 7 for over-the-counter sale; its approval is no longer conditional.

title: Panel Suggests Junk Food Ban in Schools to Help Fight Obesity
description: Junk foods like potato chips, doughnuts, chocolate-covered ice cream and sugary drinks should be banned from elementary, middle and high schools, according to a report released yesterday by the Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: A Collaboration Recalls an Isolated Rural America
description: The music headed for the hills when Ricky Skaggs and Bruce Hornsby led Mr. Skaggss band, Kentucky Thunder, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture auditorium on Tuesday night. Those hills would be the increasingly mythic Appalachians that spawned old-timey and bluegrass music, a place where fiddlers held forth on porches and string bands played Saturday-night barn dances  not where satellite dishes pick up American Idol and Country Music Television.

title: At a Womens Event in China, Seeking a Slam-Foiling Lead
description: Your opponents have an uncontested auction into six hearts. Your partner doubles, and you are on lead. What message is partner trying to transmit?

title: Officials Raid Illegal-Document Operation
description: CHICAGO, April 25  Federal authorities charged 22 people on Wednesday with being part of one of the nations largest operations to produce counterfeit identification documents.

title: Music Legends Trial Starts in Death of a B-Movie Star
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25  Phil Spector, the mastermind behind hit songs like Da Doo Ron Ron, The Long and Winding Road and Youve Lost That Lovin Feelin, went on trial on Wednesday on charges that he shot to death a struggling actress.

title: Sun and I.B.M. to Offer New Class of High-End Servers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25  Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. plan to introduce specialized high-end server systems on Thursday that provide fresh evidence of a new era in computing.

description: Artists Garbage Fetches Millions

description: TOKYO, April 25  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will have a hard act to follow when he arrives in Washington on Thursday for his first trip to the United States as Japans leader.

title: B.C.S. Format Receives a Reprieve, for Now
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 25  The annual Bowl Championship Series meetings, which gather all of the Division I-A college football conference commissioners, ended here Wednesday with little significant action.

description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Jack Valenti, Confidant of Presidents and Stars, Dies at 85
description: Jack Valenti, who became a confidant of President Lyndon B. Johnson and then a Hollywood institution, leading the Motion Picture Association of America and conceiving of a voluntary film-rating system that gave new meaning to letters like G, R and X, died today in his home in Washington. He was 85.

title: Canada: Lights Out for Inefficient Bulbs
description: Canada will ban inefficient light bulbs within five years, the natural resources minister, Gary Lunn, said. The decision follows a similar move by Australia and by Canadas most populous province, Ontario. Regulations for the ban, which will not be available until later this year, will require bulbs to meet minimum efficiency standards. While that will remove traditional incandescent bulbs from store shelves, it may also affect other technologies, like bulbs filled with halogen gas.

title: U.S. Is Detaining a Senior Officer
description: BAGHDAD, Thursday, April 26  The American military said Thursday that a senior commander at Camp Cropper, its main detention center here, was being investigated for possibly aiding the enemy.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: For the Record
description: An architects rendering yesterday of planned renovations for the exterior of the landmark New-York Historical Society building was published in error. A rendering of the design approved by the Landmarks Preservation Commission appears today on Page B6.

title: Arrest After Bombs Sent to Fund Companies
description: CHICAGO, April 25 (Bloomberg News)  Federal authorities on Wednesday arrested a man suspected of mailing pipe bombs and threatening letters to two mutual fund companies three months ago in an attempt to manipulate stock prices.

title: Myanmar and N. Korea Resume Ties
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 26  United in their hostility toward America, two of the worlds most repressive nations, Myanmar and North Korea, restored diplomatic ties with one another today after more than two decades of estrangement.

title: Giuliani Broadens His Message on Terrorism
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., April 25  In his two months on the campaign trail, the central animating theme of Rudolph W. Giulianis presidential campaign has been that his performance as New York mayor on Sept. 11, 2001, makes him the best candidate to keep the United States safe from terrorists.

title: War Bill Passes House, Requiring an Iraq Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The House on Wednesday narrowly approved a $124 billion war spending bill that would require American troops to begin withdrawing from Iraq by Oct. 1, setting the stage for the first veto fight between President Bush and majority Democrats.

title: A Little Reality, a Lot of Fantasy
description: ONE room was dominated by a giant Pinocchio figure, clad in black, white and gold mosaic, lampshades dangling from his nose. Next door was a Lewis Carroll scene of neo-Classical-style plinths bearing gargantuan white gold mosaic replicas of a tea tray, cake plate, dish and teapot.

title: Durable-Goods Picture Shows Surprising Strength
description: As the housing market dragged yet again last month, business picked up much of the slack and helped keep the economy on track.

title: Baseball Looks to Create a Possible Portal to Cuba
description: Major League Baseball officials are quietly preparing to re-establish a relationship with Cuba if the United States lifts its trade embargo.

title: Blurring the Line Between Grace and Goofy Charm
description: The dancers easy innate classicism was the first great pleasure of a program presented by Configuration Dance on Tuesday night at Ailey Citigroup Theater. Yuri Zhukovs funny, charming No Time Jazz was a close second, along with two oddball acrobatic pas de deux. It is too bad the company, based on Cape Cod, Mass., and founded in 2000 by Joseph Cipolla and Catherine Batcheller, performs so infrequently in New York City.

title: Supreme Court Revisits Campaign Finance Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The Supreme Court put defenders of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law on the defensive today in a spirited argument that suggested the court could soon open a significant loophole in the measure.

title: Sustainability, Then and Now
description: HOW can an industry that gobbles up natural resources  and owes its historic success to persuading people to replace old things with new ones, regardless of whether or not they need them  be ecologically responsible?

title: Democrats Seek Way to Respond to Bush Veto of Iraq War Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The Senate narrowly passed a $124 billion war spending bill early this afternoon after an emotional debate about the best way forward in Iraq. The vote will send the measure to President Bush, who has vowed to veto it because it would require American troops to begin withdrawing by Oct. 1.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Square Off for First Time
description: ORANGEBURG, S.C., April 26  The eight Democratic presidential candidates used their first joint appearance Thursday to assail President Bush for threatening to veto legislation that would set a deadline for bringing troops out of Iraq, even as they sought to highlight differences among them on the depth of their opposition to the war and what they would do to end it.

description: Cherry Blossoms

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Monday about Parry OBrien, the shot-putting champion, misstated the year he last broke the world record, and the distance. It was 1959, not 1966, and the record distance was 63 feet 4 inches, not 63-3.

description: April 25, 2007

title: Agency Building New Jersey Schools Says Funds Are Too Low for All Projects
description: TRENTON, April 25  The Schools Construction Corporation, embattled for the last two years for its failure to complete projects, said on Wednesday that it had the money to build or rehabilitate 32 schools in poor districts rather than the 59 projects that New Jersey officials outlined last summer.

title: Brooklyn: Mortgage Fraud Alleged
description: Ten men were charged yesterday with defrauding more than a dozen mortgage lenders in a scheme involving false identities and credit ratings, federal prosecutors said. Some of the men received loans through a mortgage brokerage firm they ran and then used false identities and credit ratings for others who bought and resold the properties, prosecutors said. The prosecutors, with the United States attorneys office in Brooklyn, said the goal was to obtain mortgages without repaying the money. The men stole an estimated $7 million, said James Margolin, an F.B.I. spokesman.

title: In Milan, Fantasy Spars With Reality
description: MILAN

title: Run on Wall Street Sends Dow Above 13,000
description: Far from being the cruelest month, April has turned out to be one of the most profitable in recent memory for investors in the stock market.

title: The Robot in Your Pool Doesnt Need Sunscreen
description: Hot dogs? Check. Sun hat? Check. Robotic pool cleaner with built-in filter that takes about 90 minutes to pick up leaves, hair and sand? Check.

title: Higher Graduation Rates in City, but More Work to Do
description: Half of New York Citys high school students graduated on time in June 2006, up from 47 percent the year before, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Education Department.

title: Government Keeps a Secret After Studying Spy Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  Concerned about the growing dependence of the nations spy agencies on private contractors, top intelligence officials have spent months determining just how many contractors work at the C.I.A., D.I.A., F.B.I., N.S.A. and the rest of the spook alphabet soup.

title: U.N. Criticizes Iraq Government on Detainee Abuse
description: BAGHDAD, Thursday, April 26  The United Nations accused the Iraqi government on Wednesday of failing to seriously address problems of detainee abuse, including torture, and to ensure the timely and fair prosecution of detainees.

title: Justices Raise Doubts on Campaign Finance
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The Supreme Court put defenders of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law on the defensive on Wednesday in a spirited argument that suggested the court could soon open a significant loophole in the measure.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the London Marathon referred incorrectly to the performance of Ryan Hall, an American making his marathon debut. He led the race near Mile 22; he was not the leader for almost 22 miles.

title: Hooked on Violence
description: Two days after the massacre at Virginia Tech, a mentally disturbed man with a .40-caliber semiautomatic handgun opened fire in a house in Queens, killing his mother, his mothers disabled companion and the disabled mans health care aide. The gunman then killed himself.

title: Trees Lost to a Buffalo Snowstorm Live as Objects of Art and Civic Pride
description: BUFFALO  Rick Pratt used a 12-inch chain saw to give Millard Fillmore his version of the presidential treatment. Quick, precise jabs sheared chunks from a length of century-old silver maple, followed by several long strokes and another round of short slices. As the sawdust settled, the cheeks, nose and chin of Americas 13th president were revealed.

title: Firefighters Symbol of Pride Gets Image Upgrade
description: Firefighters wear them with pride, on their sleeves, a variation on the blue uniform that distinguishes one assignment from another. Some are faded, even blackened: arm patches that identify each house, each company, as unique.

title: Room With a View of an Architects Retired Ideas
description: Architectural models are often shoved into back rooms or even relegated to the scrap heap, given that architects dont necessarily want to show off their rough drafts.

title: British Antiterrorism Chief Warns of More Severe Qaeda Attacks
description: LONDON, April 25  In a somber and wide-ranging assessment of the threat facing Britain, its top counterterrorism police officer, Peter Clarke, said Tuesday night that Al Qaeda had survived a prolonged multinational assault and that its supporters had established an inexorable trend towards more ambitious and more destructive attack planning.

title: In Park Plan, a New Life for Spaces Long Closed

title: U.N. Report Criticizes Iraq on Detainees Treatment
description: BAGHDAD, April 25  The United Nations accused the Iraqi government on Wednesday of failing to seriously address problems of detainee abuse, including torture, and to ensure the timely and fair prosecution of detainees.

title: Not Light, but Worth a Look for Those Who Like Sleek, Loaded Notebook Computers
description: It would be impossible to build one computer to please everyone, but Toshibas new Satellite A205-S4617 notebook sure takes a whack at it. It is powered by an Intel Core 2 Duo processor running at 1.66 gigahertz and has 2 gigabytes of RAM, which is what you need to run all the features of Windows Vistas Home Premium edition.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about efforts to solve the mystery of collapsing honeybee populations misstated the institution where a project to sequence honeybee genes was completed late last year. It is Baylor College of Medicine, not Baylor University. (The two became separate institutions in 1969.) And a map with the article, showing the extent of the problem in the United States, reversed the labels for Kansas and Nebraska, two states where collapsing populations have not been reported.

description: TRENTON

title: In Europe, Growing Frenzy for Takeover Deals
description: FRANKFURT, April 25  Most years, the United States handily beats Europe for bragging rights in deal making, based on the total value of mergers and acquisitions.

description: A music review on Monday about the UBS Verbier Festival Chamber Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the name of another training orchestra that recently played there. It is the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, not the East-West Divan Orchestra.

title: For the Record
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about Torontos 89-83 playoff victory against the Nets referred imprecisely in some copies to the Raptors postseason history. It was the teams first playoff victory in five years  not the first ever. (The first was in 2001, against the Knicks.)

title: For the Record
description: The Saturday Profile, about Saifa Benaouda, a Swedish Muslim who went to Somalia last December as the country was becoming a magnet for Islamic extremists, referred incorrectly to Daniel Maldonado, an American Muslim convert in Somalia arrested on the Kenya border and deported to the United States in February on terrorism-related charges. Mr. Maldonado pleaded guilty in Houston federal court last Thursday to receiving training from a foreign terrorist organization. He is not currently on trial.

description: ALLEN PARK, Mich., April 25  When it comes to the N.F.L. draft, practice has not made perfect for the Detroit Lions.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Toyota passing General Motors as the No. 1 automaker misstated an earlier period when G.M. lost the top spot because of a strike. It was overtaken by Ford in the late 1990s, not the 1980s. (G.M. also faltered because of a strike in the 1970s, and Ford claimed the top spot.)

description: ALBANY, April 25  Gov. Eliot Spitzer said Wednesday that he planned to introduce legislation to overhaul the states pioneering but antiquated abortion law, shoring up abortion rights in New York.

title: A Young Offshoot of High Design
description: WHEN the newly married Charles and Ray Eames set up house in Los Angeles in 1941, they turned the bathroom in their cramped apartment into a plywood laboratory. They continued their experiments for the next few years, opening an office nearby, and in 1945, the same year they introduced their famous LCW molded plywood chair, they designed a collection of plywood animals  a bear, a frog, a seal and an elephant.

title: Selling Out One Thing the Devils Cant Do
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 24  The Devils played their first three home playoff games before a total of nearly 6,300 empty seats, but goaltender Martin Brodeur could have sworn Continental Arena was packed to the rafters.

description: Third Avenue Management said it had promoted Yang Lie to director of research, a new position at the investment advisory firm. Ms. Lie, who joined the firm in 1996, had been a senior portfolio manager for its private and institutional advisory business, the firm said. Third Avenue is a value-oriented investment adviser with about $28 billion in assets under management.

title: Man Arrested for Bomb Threats to Mutual Funds
description: Federal authorities on Wednesday arrested a man suspected of mailing pipe bombs and threatening letters to two mutual fund companies three months ago in an attempt to manipulate stock prices. The man, John P. Tomkins, of Dubuque, Iowa, is accused of mailing the packages to Janus Capital Group in Denver and American Century Investments in Kansas City, Mo., according to the United States attorney in Chicago, Patrick J. Fitzgerald.

description: Lawyers for Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technologies, who faces charges of options fraud and is regarded as a fugitive, won a fresh delay Wednesday of attempts to extradite him to the United States.

description: When the former chief financial oficer of Apple, Fred D. Anderson, suggested that he had been misled by his former boss, Steven P. Jobs, over the improper back-dating of options, the shot echoed through Silicon Valley.

title: Tribune Launches Tender Offer
description: The first step in Samuel Zells two-step plan to buy out Tribune began Wednesday when the media company launched a $4.3 billion tender offer for more than half of its shares.

title: San Francisco and Shanghai Groups Team up on Venture Fund
description: Two leading business groups in San Francisco and Shanghai are teaming up to invest in Chinese start-ups, adding to the growing ranks of venture capitalists looking to tap Chinas booming economy.

title: Computer Sciences Buys Rival in $1.3 Billion Deal
description: Computer Sciences, an information technology company, has agreed to buy a rival, the Covansys Corporation, for $1.3 billion, or $34 a share. More than 70 percent of Covansys resources are based in India and the deal will nearly double the size of Computer Sciences workforce in India to about 14,000, the companies said.

title: Former Hollinger Director Testifies
description: Hollinger Internationals former chairman, Conrad Black, and his top deputy, David Radler, were so close they could seamlessly interrupt each other during board meetings while discussing complex business strategies and operations, according to testimony Tuesday in Mr. Blacks fraud trial.

title: Proxy Firms Square Off in Icahns Fight for Motorola Seat
description: The same day that Carl C. Icahn won the backing of the influential proxy adviser Institutional Shareholders Services in his fight to gain a seat on Motorolas board, the cell phone maker got an ally of its own.

title: Alcoa Considers Spinoffs to Refocus on Aluminum
description: Alcoa said on Wednesday that it may shed the units that make Reynolds wrap and electrical components to focus on its core metal production businesses. Shares in the aluminum producer rose 5 percent, to $35.76, Wednesday, closing in on a four-year high  and rumors have begun spreading that private equity may take an interest in some of the divisions.

title: Limbo 41414 Rings Up Fresh Funding
description: Limbo 41414, which gained attention for its mobile phone auction technology, on Wednesday snagged $7 million in funding that will help it become a wireless entertainment company.The companys third round of investment was led by New Enterprise Associates, which joined previous investors Azure Capital Partners and Draper Fisher Jurvetson. To date, Limbo, based in Burlingame, Calif., has raised a total of $15 million.

title: MySQL Still Sees I.P.O. Ahead
description: MySQL, purveyor of the open-source database of the same name, is on the road to becoming a publicly traded company, bolstered by $50 million in revenue in 2006. Its still in the pipeline, the chief executive, Marten Mickos, told CNet News.com, referring to the plan to hold an initial public offering.

title: Barclays Trades Said to Prompt Investigation
description: Barclays, the British bank engaged in a takeover battle for ABN Amro, used confidential information it gleaned serving on creditors committees to trade securities of bankrupt companies, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Buyout Fears May Have Prompted Siemens Shake-Up
description: Fears of a private equity buyout may have played a role in the abrupt ouster Wednesday of the chief executive of Siemens, the engineering giant, which has been hit by a corruption scandal.

title: A New Investigation into R.I.M. Stock Options
description: Research in Motion, maker of the BlackBerry wireless device, said the Justice Department is looking into its stock option accounting problems.

description: Melena Ryzik of The Times hits the red carpet at the opening night of the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Shares in Chinese Mining Company Gain 59% in Opening
description: Shares of China Molybdenum, a specialty miner, rose 59 percent above their initial offer price Thursday. China Molybdenum ended at 10.82 Hong Kong dollars ($1.39), above its initial public offering price of 6.80 Hong Kong dollars. The gains compared to a 0.6 percent rise in Hong Kongs blue-chip Hang Seng Index.

title: Judges Approval Clears Delta for N.Y.S.E. Listing
description: A federal bankruptcy judge gave his final approval Wednesday to Delta Air Lines plan to emerge from bankruptcy, clearing the way for the company to resume trading next month on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Entrepreneurs Earn Their Stripes in the Minor Leagues
description: Two men hoping to identify, recruit and develop entrepreneurs in underserved and overlooked regions of the country have used baseball as a model. Specifically, baseballs modern farm system, the web of independent minor league teams around the country that serves as the training ground for young players hoping for a shot at the major leagues.

title: Citigroups Offer for Nikko Shares Expires
description: Citigroup wrapped up its bid to take over the scandal-tainted broker Nikko Cordial on Thursday in a buyout valued at up to $13.35 billion, which would make it the biggest foreign takeover of a Japanese company.

title: NYSE Chief Rebuts Analysts Downbeat Report
description: NYSE Euronexts chief executive, John Thain, disputed claims by a Goldman Sachs analyst that new regulations in the United States might erode market share at his trans-Atlantic stock exchange and benefit its rival, the Nasdaq. Shares of NYSE Euronext fell 5.5 percent in New York after the report from Goldmans Joshua Carter was published. In an interview with The Financial Times, Mr. Thain said some of the new rules, known as Regulation National Market System, would actually help NYSE Euronext.

title: The News in Quotes: Death and Life

Bonacic, a Republican whose district includes Margaretville, where two state troopers were shot, urging Gov. Eliot Spitzer to reinstate the death penalty.

The Childrens Investment Fund, an activist hedge fund whose agitations prompted the start of ABNs takeover talks with Barclays, called the competing offer for ABN compelling on Wednesday. But the Financial Timess Lex column wonders how Royal Bank of Scotland will finance the bid.

title: Citadels Next Venture: Funding New Hedge Funds
description: Citadel Investment Group, the giant hedge fund, has hedged its businesses over the years, expanding from convertible arbitrage into options market-making and, now, an incubator for other hedge funds. Financial News takes a look at Citadel Alternative Asset Management, the new fund of hedge funds business that will also seed new managers.

Still Gonzo for Gonzales

Retaining Gonzales means Bush has slipped behind the barricades. Novak continues:

title: Guantanamos Legal Void
description: Bush tries to kill all the Gitmo lawyers: We should not forget this central point: The Justice Department is trying to do everything possible to prevent Guantanamo detainees from having any rights at all, writes Yale law professor Jack Balkin at the group legal blog Balkinization. It wants to get as close as it can to what it the Bush Administration sought before [the Supreme Court decisions in] Rasul and Hamdan  a law-free zone. But the more the Justice Department tries to eliminate procedural protections and basic elements of fairness for the detainees, the more it undermines its argument that the detainees have a remedy that is just as good as habeas. Balkin continues:

description: Carol Waselenchuck and her daughter-in-law, Jami Waselenchuk, landed a meeting with two of Senator Bill Nelsons legislative aides and his deputy chief of staffand the first topic was shoes. Five thousand pairs of them in Washington, a few thousand more back in Florida.

title: Kohlberg and Goldman in $8 Billion Harman Buyout
description: Rumors of a rift between Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs seemed to have been greatly exaggerated. The two firms announced Thursday that they are teaming up on an $8 billion deal to take Harman International Industries private, an alliance that would seem to undercut the notion, making the rounds on some Web sites of late, that Kohlberg felt threatened by Goldmans well-funded private equity arm.

title: Will Bristols C.E.O. Move Douse Takeover Talk?
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the giant pharmaceutical company that has long been the subject of takeover chatter, said Thursday it named James Cornelius to be its chief executive officer until 2009. Mr. Cornelius has been serving as Bristol-Myerss interim chief executive since September, when his predecessor was pushed out in what was widely seen as a tacit admission that the drugmaker was on the block. The companys decision to make Mr. Cornelius its long-term chief could quell rumors that Bristol-Myers is heading for a sale, although some analysts were doubtful on that front on Thursday. I dont think this is going to end speculation about the companys independence, one analyst told Bloomberg News.

title: McCain on Gonzales
description: Throughout the day on Wednesday, as he rolled through New Hampshire on the formal kickoff of his presidential campaign, Senator John McCain of Arizona was asked if he believes that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales should step down. He was asked twice as he held forth in his bus, the Straight Talk Express, and at a brief news conference in Manchester, N.H. Each time he told reporters Ask me tomorrow, broadly hinting that he might make news on the subject.

The appointments, announced Thursday, settle a proxy fight that was brewing ahead of the companys annual shareholder meeting on May 25.

That could be setting up a contentious battle with the City Council, which might be inclined to spend the money while the Bloomberg administration is warning that steps need to be taken to pay down future debt.

But there were school conferences in the morning, which I attended with my fourth grader, Julia. Most were back to back, but at one point  between math and science, I think  we had a break, which we spent at a narrow table in a second-floor hallway, she doing homework, I staring off into space.

title: Britain: Army Mulls Future of Prince Harry in Iraq
description: The army said it was reviewing its decision to allow Prince Harry, the younger son of Prince Charles and the third in line for the throne, to serve with his army unit in Iraq. Prince Harrys deployment to Iraq is, as weve always said, under constant consideration, a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Defense said. But, she added, it is still our intent that Harry will deploy as a troop leader. British news outlets have reported that the Defense Ministry has grown increasingly nervous about the security implications of such a move. Eleven British soldiers have been killed in Iraq in the past month, including two whose armored reconnaissance vehicle  the same kind Harry would be using  was hit by a roadside bomb.

title: Glimpsing the Future (and a Babe)
description: In Next, a crummy action and speculative-fiction hybrid, Nicolas Cage plays a guy who can see into the future two minutes at a time. Its too bad that Mr. Cage couldnt tap into those same powers of divination to save himself from making yet another inexplicably bad choice in roles. Once one of the more enthralling actors in Hollywood (Leaving Las Vegas), Mr. Cage these days seems all too content to waste his and the audiences time in tacky genre throwaways, not that The Wicker Man or at least the hilarious highlights reel of same that eventually made it onto YouTube didnt provide some serious yuks.

title: Romney Says Rivals Changed Minds, Too
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., April 26  Mitt Romney directly engaged two of his better-known rivals for the Republican presidential nomination on Thursday, telling an interviewer that Senator John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani had both changed their positions on important issues over the years, just as he had.

title: ImClones Profit Slides but Its Drug Gains Sales
description: ImClone Systems, the biotechnology developer controlled by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, said yesterday that profit fell 87 percent because the company received less money from a marketing partner.

title: The Drama of Daytime: Friendships, Feuds and Fury
description: Regis Philbin is back. Rosie ODonnell is leaving.

title: Correction: Playing Chef in a Little Kitchen on the Shore
description: The Away column last Friday about a vacation home in Truro, Mass., misstated the name of a restaurant where one of the homeowners once worked. It was Finally Michaels, not Finely Michaels. The column also misspelled the name of a former Boston supper club where the homeowners parents worked. It was Blinstrubs, not Blimstroms.

title: A Sandy Beach, a Sunny Climate and Canadian Wine
description: VINEYARDS, orchards and an almost inexhaustible supply of sun are luring second-home buyers to Naramata, a British Columbia village some 50 miles north of the United States border.

title: Estonia: Excavation Near Soviet Monument
description: Estonia began excavating the earth surrounding a Soviet-era war memorial in the capital, Tallinn, a step toward relocating it to a military cemetery. The monument, the Bronze Soldier, commemorates the victory over Nazi Germany but is viewed by many Estonians as a symbol of the Soviet occupation that followed. Proposals to remove the monument have brought strong reactions from ethnic Russians in Estonia and from the Russian government.

title: Mans Best Friend, Just the Way We Like to Design Him
description: Who knew that mans best friend is a freak of nature? Dogs That Changed the World will not change the way you love your canine companion, but it may change the way you look at him.

title: Ford Narrows Its Quarterly Loss
description: DEARBORN, Mich., April 26  The Ford Motor Company narrowed its first-quarter loss after eliminating thousands of jobs and cutting millions of dollars in spending, but the companys chief executive acknowledged today that we still have a long way to go to turn around this business.

title: The Pointillist Contagion in Italy
description: Painted measles is what one hostile critic called the efforts of the Italian followers of French Neo-Impressionism. The occasion was the first Brera Triennale in Milan in 1891. The reference was to the tiny dots of color that covered their canvases. The technique, also called Pointillism, was formulated by the Parisian Georges Seurat in the early 1880s as he assimilated the latest scientific theories about color, light and perception.

title: Mankinds Appetite for Destruction in the 20th Century
description: The grainy black-and-white image of a mans emaciated corpse lying face up, his limbs splayed as in a crucifixion, is the first picture flashed in Passio, an austere fusion of silent film and modern sacred music that has its debut New York performance this evening at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The music for this event, presented by the Tribeca Film Festival, is the 70-minute St. John Passion (Passio) written by the Estonian minimalist composer Arvo Prt in 1982 and sung by the Trinity Choir in voices so pure they suggest a seraphic chorus beyond the human sphere.

title: Bush Eases Tone on Iraq Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  President Bush adopted a more conciliatory tone toward Congress today, saying he was confident that he and the lawmakers could find a way forward on the Iraq war financing bill.

description: He may be known as a deal maker, but Joseph R. Perella has also shown himself to be one of the financial industrys sharpest recruiters.

description: William B. Lawless Jr., a former justice of the New York State Supreme Court and dean of the University of Notre Dame School of Law, died Monday near his home in San Rafael, Calif. He was 84.

title: Russia Rebukes Estonia for Moving Soviet Statue
description: MOSCOW, April 27  Estonian government workers removed a Soviet-era war memorial from the center of the Estonian capital, Talinn, early this morning, after a night of protest and violence that killed one, injured dozens and left a swath of shattered windows and overturned cars in the city center, Estonian officials said.

title: Bryant Pulls One Back for the Lakers

title: With Elias Out Sick, the Devils Have No Remedy
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 26  The pads in Patrik Eliass dressing room stall were untouched Thursday morning, a freshly laundered pair of red socks draped over the center hook. Elias, the Devils captain, had gone home, still ailing from the flu.

title: With Trade Rumors Swirling, Vilma Tries to Stay Grounded
description: The conversation began like an Abbott and Costello routine, with Redskins running back Clinton Portis turning to Jets linebacker Jonathan Vilma during a promotional appearance in Miami and asking, Did you hear that youre going to Washington?

title: Queens: Guns Seized by the Police
description: A man and woman from Whitestone were arrested Wednesday after police officers seized 30 handguns and an assault rifle from their home, the police said yesterday. Keith Boyer, 45, and Roberta Boyer, 39, both of 148th Street, were charged with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. Mr. Boyer was also charged with reckless endangerment. The police said they also recovered three silencers and 5,000 rounds of ammunition. Officers searched the home after receiving a 911 call reporting a man with a gun at the location, the police said.

description: Researchers said yesterday that they had identified seven new genes connected to the most common form of diabetes  the latest result of an intensifying race between university researchers and private companies to find genes linked to a range of diseases.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 26  Jason Kidd is questionable for Game 3 of the Nets first-round playoff series against the Toronto Raptors on Friday night.

description: ATLANTA, April 26  After the fatal police shooting of an elderly woman in a botched drug raid, the United States attorney here said Thursday that prosecutors were investigating a culture of misconduct in the Atlanta Police Department.

Eisenhower. After lunch and a garden stroll, Mr. Bush said, I told the prime minister he needs to get over to the United States quickly.

description: The bullet that killed a New York State trooper on Wednesday during a gunfight inside a farmhouse near Margaretville, N.Y., came from the gun of a fellow officer, not the suspect they had cornered, the state police said today.

title: Man Said to Be Aide to bin Laden Detained by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  A man described as a senior Al-Qaeda commander who was involved in assassination plots against President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan and in attacks in Afghanistan was taken into American custody and transferred to the military prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, the Pentagon announced today.

description: Things are messed up around Yankee Stadium, the Yankees announced last night.

description: BEIJING, Friday, April 27  China named Yang Jiechi, a former ambassador to the United States, as its foreign minister on Friday, shuffling its diplomatic team as its rising economic power has given it greater sway in world affairs.

title: Upper West Side Cultural Adventure
description: The Upper West Fest, presented by Symphony Space, will feature music, dance, lectures, film screenings and other cultural events tomorrow through May 20 at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, as well as other Upper West Side locations including the JCC in Manhattan, 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street; Barnard College, Broadway and 117th Street; the Childrens Museum of Manhattan, 212 West 83rd Street; the International Youth Hostel, 891 Amsterdam Avenue, at 103rd Street; the Bard Graduate Center for Studies of the Decorative Arts, Design and Culture, 18 West 86th Street; and the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street. Admission ranges from $9 to $120; some events are free. Information: upperwestfest.com. Symphony Space information: (212) 864-5400; symphonyspace.org. title: Penn Relays Begin
description: The Penn Relays, the oldest and largest track and field carnival of its kind, began at Franklin Field in Philadelphia yesterday with 19,000 athletes from 260 colleges, 975 high schools and 100 clubs competing. With a crowd of 23,996 watching on a chilly day, the distance medleys were won by Tennessee among college women (11 minutes 9.16 seconds) and Southern Regional of Manahawkin, N.J., among high school girls (11:45.54).

title: In an Absolut World, a Vodka Could Use the Same Ads for More Than 25 Years
description: FOR 25 years, Absolut vodka ran the same humorous campaign celebrating its distinctive bottle, becoming renowned for the consistency of its pitches to consumers. Now, seeking to recapture lightning in a  well, you know  the brand is changing advertising approaches for the second time in 15 months.

title: North Korea and Myanmar Restore Ties
description: Two of the worlds most repressive nations, Myanmar and North Korea, restored diplomatic relations after more than two decades of estrangement. The agreement was signed without fanfare during a three-day visit to Myanmar, formerly Burma, by Deputy Foreign Minister Kim Yong-il of North Korea. Myanmars deputy foreign minister, Kyaw Thu, said it would be up to the North Koreans to decide whether to open a diplomatic mission in the remote new capital, Naypyidaw, 200 miles north of Yangon, the largest city and former capital. Relations between the nations have been quietly warming over recent years as both sought allies under pressure from the West.

title: After Fatal Clash, Questions About Police Tactics and a Suspects Mental State
description: It was dusk Wednesday when the roaring fire ended an extraordinary day of tragedy and the massing of police manpower, armor and technology in a quiet corner of the Catskill Mountains.

title: Mstislav Rostropovich, Cellist and Conductor, Dies at 80
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist and conductor who was renowned not only as one of the great instrumentalists of the 20th century but also as an outspoken champion of artistic freedom in the Soviet Union during the last decades of the cold war, died yesterday in Moscow. He was 80 and lived in Paris, with homes also in Moscow, St. Petersburg, London and Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: Progress Is Seen on Trade Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  A trip on Air Force One and a talk between President Bush and Representative Charles B. Rangel as they traveled to Mr. Rangels home district in Harlem this week has suddenly lifted prospects for bipartisan agreement on trade legislation in Congress, officials on both sides said Thursday.

title: New Hampshire Senate Votes to Allow Same-Sex Civil Unions
description: BOSTON, April 26  A vote in the New Hampshire Senate on Thursday cleared the way for the state to become the fourth to allow civil unions for same-sex couples, and the first to do so without a court order or a pending lawsuit.

title: Their Defense in Question, Rangers Look to Regroup
description: BUFFALO, April 26  The Rangers practiced without their top defenseman, Michal Rozsival, on Thursday, and Rozsivals defensive partner, Marek Malik, also took the day off to rest. The team was absorbing the blow of a loss in the opener of their playoff series with Buffalo, a team that seemed to thrive on every defensive mistake the Rangers made in a 5-2 victory Wednesday night.
