description: Valerie Oltarsh went to work for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in 1994.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 20 through April 24 with 1,052 adults throughout the United States.

title: Bloombergs Budget Includes Tax Cuts and a Record Surplus
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed a $59 billion budget yesterday that maintains tax cuts he promised earlier this year and includes a record-setting $4.4 billion surplus carried over from this year that he says will be used to help cover revenue shortfalls expected in 2009 and 2010.

title: Keeping the Old Off Off Broadway Spirit Alive
description: Like all the performing arts, theater is both enduring and ephemeral. Its influence can be profound, but the act itself exists in time, and is consumed by its passing. Of the many thousands of plays written over the past couple of millenniums, only a fraction have survived, and even then they are only blueprints for three-dimensional structures that have been dismantled. The great actors from the ages before film and video are now known to us only by description.

title: Emily Sunstein, 82, a Biographer and Scholar, Dies
description: Emily W. Sunstein, an independent scholar known for writing biographies of an unconventional mother and her unconventional daughter  Mary Wollstonecraft and Mary Shelley  died on Saturday in Philadelphia. She was 82 and had lived in Philadelphia for many years.

title: When Modern Dance Became More Modern Still
description: In the fall of 2003 a boisterous crowd filled the Brooklyn Academy of Music as the Merce Cunningham Dance Company concluded its 50th anniversary season.

title: Their Kingdom for a Bike: Its Polo on Two Wheels
description: You do not have to be a king to play polo. You do not need a 300-yard grass field, a long-handled mallet or a helmet. In fact, you do not even need a horse.

title: Igawa Sent to Bullpen to Find His Control
description: Joe Torre was profoundly disappointed in Kei Igawas start on Monday at Tampa Bay. Torre, the Yankees manager, believed Igawa had been making progress since a rocky debut on April 7, and he was startled by the lack of command Igawa showed in an ugly loss to the Devil Rays.

title: Studies Reveal an Immune System Regulator
description: Scientists working independently in Cambridge, England, and Cambridge, Mass., have discovered an unexpected regulatory network that affects the entire immune system.

title: Lebanon: Sunnis Bodies Found After Kidnapping
description: The police found the bodies of a 25-year-old Sunni man and a 12-year-old Sunni boy whose abduction on Monday had already prompted concerns of rising sectarian tensions. The bodies were found in a field southeast of Beirut after an anonymous call to a television station. Their families are members of the pro-government party of the Druse leader Walid Jumblatt, an opponent of Hezbollah, the militant Shiite organization. Local reports said the two were kidnapped by members of a Shiite clan to avenge the killing of a relative in January. Mr. Jumblatt appealed for calm.

title: Wie Wont Try to Make Mens Open Field
description: Michelle Wie, 17, who vowed to try again this year after failing to qualify for the 2006 United States Open, was not among the 8,544 golfers to submit qualifying applications for this years tournament, according to the United States Golf Association.

title: Change the World, and That Diaper (9 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) ALL THE KINGS MEN (1949) Turner Classic Movies presents two dramas written and directed by Robert Rossen, starting with this adaptation of Robert Penn Warrens Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about the rise and fall of a rural politician in the 1930s South. At the Oscars, the film was named best picture and Broderick Crawford, above, best actor for his portrayal of Willie Stark, a rural idealist turned corrupt  if popular  governor, a role seemingly inspired by Huey P. Long, the former governor and senator from Louisiana (a connection Warren denied). All the Kings Men was selected for preservation in the National Film Registry after the Library of Congress deemed it culturally significant in 2001. At 10, Paul Newman and Jackie Gleason sidle up to the pool table in The Hustler (1961), the tale of Fast Eddie Felson, a small-time hustler with a self-destructive streak who challenges Minnesota Fats to a world championship match. George C. Scott plays the gambler with his money on Fats; Piper Laurie is Sarah, the wilted flower with eyes only for Eddie.

title: Manhattan: Cosmetics Warnings
description: City health officials warned yesterday that some brands of imported eye makeup contain high levels of lead and could pose a health hazard to users. The products, which are called kohl, kajal and surma, often do not have a list of ingredients on the package, officials said. Sara Markt, a health department spokeswoman, said consumers should not buy products if they are uncertain about the content. Among the products the city found to contain lead are Hashmi Surma Special, Hashmi Kajal and Hashmi Kohl Aswad, all made in Pakistan, and Pure Kohl From the Waters of ZamZam. You should be looking for some sign that the product is approved, or there are listed ingredients, she said. Officials issued the warning after investigating several recent cases of children and pregnant women reporting lead poisoning, she said.

title: Corporal Tillman Haunts the Pentagon
description: Despite multiple investigations and hand-wringing by the Pentagon, the full truth has not emerged about the death of Cpl. Pat Tillman, the football star turned infantryman who was accidentally gunned down by other Americans in Afghanistan. Details dribble out about how quick Army brass were to burn his battle uniform, concoct tales of heroism and go into a full public relations blitz.

title: Jim Moran, 88, Automobile Dealer and Philanthropist, Dies
description: Jim Moran, who became a billionaire by selling cars and building one of the largest closely held companies in the United States, died on Tuesday in Hillsboro Beach, Fla. He was 88.

title: Why Wont Companies Invest More?
description: To the Federal Reserve, it is puzzling that business investment is not stronger. To business executives, it is only natural. They see relatively few opportunities for investment, and ample reason to send cash to shareholders.

title: Bringing the Mountain Bike to Metropolis
description: Ever since the mountain bikers arrived, the freaky Goth people with vampire teeth dont hang around much anymore.

title: Young Mozart, Classically Serious and Silly
description: There are many operas ideal for avant-garde stagings. But Mozarts Finta Giardiniera has such a ludicrously complicated plot that you are thankful for period sets and costumes, and a simple, intelligent production, like the one offered by the Juilliard Opera Center on Wednesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater.

title: A Look at Operas Past and Possible Future
description: The Italian girl in search of her beloved arrives in a foreign country, alone, spunky and resolved to get what she wants. In the end she manages to extricate her lover from unwanted entanglements and go off with him into the sunset. She is also the heroine of a comic opera that was a considerable hit in its day.

title: The Revenge Plot Is Familiar, but the Accent Is Not Danish
description: In a recent radio interview on WNYC, the choreographer Boris Eifman spoke of the new relationship he has created between what happens onstage and his audience. Speaking on The Leonard Lopate Show, Mr. Eifman responded to those who dont enjoy his work by saying: It means that they are not really open to receive this energy.

title: Climate Panel Sees Need for New Steps on Emissions
description: Substantial new efforts will be needed worldwide to stem accelerating growth in greenhouse-gas emissions linked to rising global temperatures, according to a summary of a report being prepared by hundreds of climate scientists and economists working under the auspices of the United Nations.

title: $5 Million for 5 Cents
description: A 1913 nickel, the best specimen of only five that are known, was bought on Wednesday by an anonymous collector in California for $5 million, said Ronald J. Gillio, the dealer who arranged the sale. It is the second-highest price ever paid for a single coin, after the $7.59 million paid for a 1933 $20 gold piece in 2002. The 1913 nickel, with the head of Liberty on one side and a large V on the reverse, once belonged to the financier Louis Eliasberg, the only person known to have assembled a complete collection of every United States coin by date and mint mark.

title: Lively Currents From Balanchines River of Ballets
description: Balanchine is a lost man, Lincoln Kirstein said around the end of 1939, only he said it in French: Balanchine  cest un homme perdu.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on April 18 about Westfield High School in Chantilly, Va., from which the killer in the Virginia Tech massacre and two of his victims graduated, referred incorrectly to the academic background of Steve Webb, who visited friends at the high school a day after the killings. He transferred to an alternative educational program in the district; he did not drop out of school.

title: Murdoch Is Taking MySpace to China
description: SHANGHAI, April 26  Rupert Murdochs News Corporation is bringing MySpace.com to China, a latecomer that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up.

title: Reflections on the New Abortion Ruling and the Roberts Court
description: One of the sage pieces of advice a colleague imparted when I first started writing about legal issues was not to put much predictive stock in Supreme Court oral arguments. The comments by individual justices sometimes reflect where they are heading, but often do not.

title: White House Calls Political Briefings Legal
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The Bush administration insisted Thursday that a series of meetings between senior White House political aides and officials at government agencies to discuss Congressional elections did not violate a law that prohibits the use of federal departments for political purposes.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Chief, in Book, Assails Cheney on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  George J. Tenet, the former director of central intelligence, has lashed out against Vice President Dick Cheney and other Bush administration officials in a new book, saying they pushed the country to war in Iraq without ever conducting a serious debate about whether Saddam Hussein posed an imminent threat to the United States.

title: Off the Page and in the Air, Drawing Transformed
description: The artist named Gego, who is the subject of a small, out-of-this-world survey at the Drawing Center in SoHo, was born Gertrud Goldschmidt in Hamburg, Germany, in 1912. The daughter of a Jewish banker, she studied for a career in architecture and engineering. But in 1939, as the political heat began to build, she left for Venezuela. Apart from short visits to Europe and elsewhere, she stayed there until her death in 1994.

title: Iran: Nuclear Negotiators Cautiously Upbeat
description: Iranian and European officials said progress had been made in talks on Irans nuclear program but said they had fallen short of the breakthrough needed to restart formal negotiations. We have not made miracles, but we have tried to move the dossier forward a little bit, Javier Solana, left, the foreign policy chief for the European Union, said in Ankara, Turkey, at the end of two days of talks with Irans negotiator, Ali Larijani. The fact that we are again together, I think its in itself a very important development. Mr. Larijani had hinted that the Europeans seemed to be offering a new formula for conditions for talks to resume, but a spokeswoman for Mr. Solana said no new offers were on the table. On CNN Turk, Mr. Larijani said: There were new ideas rising up. These ideas need time to grow and develop. But you can say this was a good first step. The two agreed to meet again in two weeks.

title: Human Risk Played Down in Bad Feed
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The potential risk to humans who might have eaten meat contaminated with melamine is extremely low, and the Food and Drug Administration believes that only 6,000 hogs may have eaten the reconstituted feed.

description: Two major chemical companies reported first-quarter profit declines yesterday on softening demand and higher raw material costs.

title: Exxon Mobil Earnings Rise 10 Percent
description: HOUSTON, April 26  Despite a winter of relatively soft oil and natural gas prices, Exxon Mobil on Thursday reported another surge in profit for the first quarter of the year because of stronger earnings from its refining, marketing and chemicals businesses.

title: No More Plastic Bags (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping the Faith With Shakespeare
description: The most compelling production of Antony and Cleopatra that I can recall took place not in a theater but in a classroom. From a distance of nearly 40 years, I can still hear the basso profundo of Melvin Plotinsky at Indiana University declaiming some of Shakespeares most stirring lines, interspersed with brilliant commentary that began at 10 a.m. sharp and concluded precisely 45 minutes later. At that point, the thoroughly intimidating Professor Plotinsky would reach into the pocket of his suit jacket, pull out a silver cigarette case and exit stage left, leaving me slack-jawed with amazement.

title: An Earnest Trooper Gone Too Soon
description: Ralph J. Phillips, the fugitive who killed a New York state trooper last year, did not know David C. Brinkerhoff. But Mr. Brinkerhoff knew Mr. Phillips. Mr. Brinkerhoff, a 29-year-old state trooper who was shot and killed on Wednesday, spent days tracking Mr. Phillips near the Pennsylvania border last fall, his first big assignment as part of the agencys elite Mobile Response Team.

title: Even Closer Scrutiny for the Red Soxs Matsuzaka
description: BALTIMORE, April 26  Five hundred feet from the nearest reporter, the most analyzed pitcher in the world threw a ball, breathed and then threw some more. As Daisuke Matsuzaka of the Boston Red Sox worked in the rare solitude of the center-field bullpen here Wednesday, he was meticulous about his routine. Even from 500 feet away, that was obvious.

title: An Autistic Womans Lessons for the Cynical
description: In Snow Cake Sigourney Weaver peels off layers of urbane sophistication to play Linda Freeman, a high-functioning autistic woman living in a rural Ontario town called Wawa. With her face scrubbed clean of makeup and wearing an expression that shifts between infantile delight and childish indignation, Ms. Weaver gives a technically accomplished performance. She is so far outside her comfort zone that you scan her body language for signs of the haughty female warrior lurking behind Lindas blank innocence. But that person is nowhere to be seen.

description: JAZZ

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline in Business Day on Wednesday about the drop in sales of existing homes in March to 6.12 million units, on a seasonally adjusted annual basis, misstated the historical context of those sales. While the drop of 8.4 percent was indeed the steepest monthly decline since January 1989, when sales fell by 12.6 percent; the sales did not fall to the 1989 level. (The sales rate for 1989 was 3.29 million units.)

title: Lifetime Gets Second Chief in 2 Years
description: The Lifetime Channel, which has struggled with its ratings, announced its second new chief executive in two years yesterday with the appointment of a longtime ABC network executive, Andrea Wong.

description: THE Mayberry-meets-M.I.T. appeal of the Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill region of North Carolina blooms in spring and summer, when families can bask in the region's generous outdoor spaces, its culture and its barbecue.

title: Best Available Player Should Fill a Hole for the Giants

title: Manhattan: Help for Troubled School
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has joined the board of a holding company that owns a troubled commercial college in New York City, and will head a new educational oversight committee, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Kennedy, above, an environmental lawyer, is a director of the EVCI Career Colleges Holding Corporation, which owns Interboro Institute, a two-year business college that has come under scrutiny for improprieties involving student financial aid. In 2005, state education officials directed Interboro to reduce its size so it could better deal with the issue. The company said the problems were isolated, but its stock plummeted and it was sued by investors. Mr. Kennedy said visits to the college convinced him that it was an extraordinary school that outperformed virtually every school in the nation in helping disadvantaged minority students. EVCI also announced an agreement for a $17 million financial package with a private equity firm.

Sometimes an ensemble will plug along through decades and personnel changes but keep going because its name is a marketable franchise, even if its sound is deteriorating. And sometimes  rarely  a venerable group decides to leave the scene while it is still playing well and its reputation is fully intact.

title: The Disciples of Andr, Monsieur Literary Dash
description: Ornamented with passages from Racine and long, earnest conversations at restaurant tables, Emmanuel Bourdieus Poison Friends is atmospherically and unmistakably French. But Andr Morney (Thibault Vinon), its charismatic central figure, represents a type that can be found in seminar rooms and campus cafes around the world, as well as in the novels of Iris Murdoch. Witty, cynical and erudite, Andr enthralls two younger, less confident students with his self-assurance and his merciless commitment to criticism. It is not just that he seems to have read and formed a perfectly coherent opinion about everything, or that he enjoys an easy rapport with a pompous and severe literature professor (Jacques Bonnaff). To his acolytes, Eloi (Malik Zidi) and Alexandre (Alexandre Steiger), Andr is the heroic embodiment of literary dash and sophistication, a classroom Lord Byron who has already arrived in the exalted realm of knowledge and creativity they aspire to inhabit.

title: Selig Says Miller Should Be in Hall
description: Commissioner Bud Selig said yesterday that he believed that Marvin Miller deserved to be in the Baseball Hall of Fame, a surprising endorsement considering that Miller created the Players Association that was in protracted conflict with the owners for many years.Selig put in a word for the retired Miller as he spoke of the need for adjustments in the Halls reconstituted veterans committee. Every two years, the committee votes on players who were not elected over a 15-year period by the Baseball Writers Association of America. Every four years, the committee considers executives, umpires and managers.However, in five ballots dating to 2003, the committee has failed to elect a single person. In the most recent results, Miller received 63 percent of the votes; 75 percent is needed. The veterans committee is controlled by the Hall of Fame, not Major League Baseball, but Selig has input as a member of the Halls board of directors. Selig made his remarks at a meeting of the Associated Press Sports Editors in New York.

title: Theater Listings
description: I LAND What does the phrase hula dancing bring to mind? For some its the Elvis Presley movie Blue Hawaii. Or plastic flowers, cellophane skirts, perhaps even a coconut brassiere. It is unlikely to suggest the image of Hiiaka, the patron goddess of Hawaii, dancing for her sister Pele, the goddess of volcanic fire, to introduce a sacred ritual. But thats where it all started, according to this solo show, written and performed by Keo Woolford, whose first name, he says, is pronounced like O.K. backwards. To Mr. Woolford, left, hula is more than Hollywood kitsch. It is an important aspect of his identity and that of his home state. His show, he said after a recent preview performance, is not a history lesson or educational device, though it does much to counteract the perception that Hawaii is merely a vacation fantasy land. As Mr. Woolford reveals his journey, from growing up in Hawaii to starring in The King and I on the West End to performing with the Hawaiian boy band Brownskin, his sense of humor is apparent throughout. Created with and directed by Roberta Uno, and produced by the Ma-Yi Theater Company, I Land features plenty of dancing too  a combination of hula, hip-hop and even a dose of disco  choreographed by the hula kuma (teacher) Robert Cazimero and Ana (Rokafella) Garcia. But the shows serious underpinnings are clear. We wanted to open this window, so that you would actually ask yourself the question, What do I now know about this world that I assumed I knew everything about?  Ms. Uno said. (Through May 13, the Culture Project, 55 Mercer Street, at Broome Street, SoHo, 212-352-3101, theatermania.com; $38; $25 for students; $35 for 65+.) STEVEN McELROY

title: Wrestling a Jazz Giants Masterwork Into Shape
description: Epitaph, Charles Minguss two-hour suite for 31 musicians, is famous for its unwieldiness. It is long, intensive and complicated. Parts of it were performed at a doomed Town Hall concert in 1962, and all of it was played posthumously in 1989, after the sheet music was found among Minguss papers, at a successful but still nerve-racking concert at Lincoln Center. On Wednesday night Epitaph, made still bigger by new material, had its third New York iteration, at Jazz at Lincoln Centers Rose Theater. It started shakily, but by the end it had made its case.

But if buyouts keep getting bigger and public shareholders grow more resistant to approaches from private equity funds, it would not be surprising to see stub equity crop up more often.

title: TheStreet Picks Up Stock-Picking Social Network
description: TheStreet.com has acquired the half of Stockpickr, a social network and stock-recommendation site, that it didnt already own. In announcing the deal, TheStreet.com characterized Stockpickr as a forum where people who want to learn how the rich get richer meet to compare and exchange investment strategies and techniques.

title: In Nikko Bid, Citigroup Wins the Day
description: Citigroup said on Friday that its takeover bid for Nikko Cordial succeeded after Nikko shareholders tendered a majority of the brokerage firms stock. The result came after the close of a contentious tender offer for the Japanese company. Some big Nikko shareholders wanted Citigroup to offer more for the firm.

title: In Starting Coverage, BofA Analyst Skips Official Meetings
description: A Wall Street analyst has raised eyebrows among competitors and customers because he did not speak to the senior management he wrote about prior to launching coverage of seven well-known pharmaceutical companies, The New York Post reported Friday.

title: China Citic Bank Starts With a Surge
description: Shares in the China Citic Bank rose 21 percent in their Hong Kong debut and surged more than 59 percent in Shanghai on Friday during its $5.4 billion offering, the worlds largest this year.

title: Siemens Struggles to Regain Equilibrium
description: With a bribery scandal widening and its two top executives leaving, Siemens struggled on Thursday to maintain an air of somewhat normal operations, laying out ambitious growth and profit goals, even as the German engineering firms credit rating was put on watch and regulators in Washington expanded their investigation.

title: Murdoch Is Taking MySpace to China  as a Start-Up
description: Rupert Murdochs News Corporation is bringing MySpace.com to China, a latecomer that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up.

title: Sun-Times Group Reaches Settlement on Tax Issues
description: The Sun-Times Media Group said late Thursday that it reached agreement with Canadian authorities on an accord that will remove a significant portion of the companys massive potential tax liabilities related assets sales under Conrad Black.

title: Investors Track Down Fugitive Hedge Fund Manager
description: Hedge fund managers on the run from angry investors, beware. An Australian hedge fund manager who went on the lam after being accused of leaving investors out of pocket for as much as $20 million, was tracked down in Canada by group of what The Australian calls vigilante investors.

title: Technitrol Withdraws Offer for Rival
description: Technitrol on Thursday withdrew its offer to buy rival electronics-parts-maker Bel Fuse, after its target refused to discuss the offer.

title: Crossing Party Lines, Mack Backs Clinton
description: As presidential candidates vie for the backing  and cash of Wall Street bigwigs, one banking chieftain has publicly thrown his lot in with Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Wrestling With Action
description: Tailor-made for those who like their violence multifaceted and their women monosyllabic, The Condemned tosses a selection of action movies Con Air, The Running Man, Series 7: The Contenders  into a blender and serves up the resulting mush. A simpleminded vehicle for the wrestling star Steve Austin, the movie will slide into foreign markets with no need for elaborate subtitles or cultural translation. The language of pain is universal.

title: Tribune Auction Earns Banks $150 Million
description: The investment banks that handled the recent auction of Tribune are set to collect nearly $150 million in advisory and financing fees, or a quarter of the total $590 million it will cost real estate magnate Samuel Zell to purchase the 40 percent of the media company.

title: Rival Group Launches Hostile Bid for ABN Amro
description: A group led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group said on Friday it will make an unsolicited offer for ABN Amro Holding, escalating the fight with Barclays  for control of the biggest Dutch bank.

title: Hedge Fund Increases Stake in Mair
description: Hedge fund firm Schultze Asset Management has increased its stake in Mair Holdings to 5.9 percent and asked the Minneapolis-based company to hold off on future acquisitions until its value can be correctly determined.

title: Satoil to Acquire North American Oil Sands
description: Statoil, Norways largest oil and gas company, on Friday made a $2 billion cash offer to acquire North American Oil Sands, its third significant acquisition in the Americas in less than a year.

title: EMC Files for VMWare I.P.O.
description: Storage technology maker EMC plans to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering of stock in VMWare, the fast-growing maker of virtualization technology that it acquired 2004 for $635 million.

title: Deutsche Hires 8 Bankers for Asia Region
description: Deutsche Bank, Germanys biggest, hired eight investment bankers and equity market specialists in Asia after slipping in advising on mergers in the region.

title: Carlos Slim and Macquarie Team Up for Toll Roads Bid
description: Billionaire Carlos Slims Impulsora del Desarrollo y el Empleo en America Latina and Macquarie Infrastructure Group teamed up to bid for a package of four Mexican toll roads worth at least $2.3 billion.

title: Founding Family to Take Sobeys Private
description: Sobeys, Canadas second- biggest grocery chain, said its founding family agreed to take the company private by paying C$1.06 billion ($950 million) for the 28 percent stake it doesnt already own.

title: Cott Adopts Hostile Takeover Defense
description: Cott, whose stock is fizzing up because of rumors of a merger with Cadbury Schweppes drinks division, said Wednesday that its board has approved a shareholder rights plan to discourage a hostile takeover.

title: Dow Chemical Chief Defends Strategy
description: The chief executive of Dow Chemical, which has been rocked by revelations of a secret plan to take it private, on Thursday launched an impassioned defense of his strategy, saying he had earned the right to run the company.

title: G.E. Should Shed NBC, Citi Analyst Says
description: Some Citigroup analysts have big plans for General Electric, the worlds second-largest company by market capitalization after ExxonMobil.

title: Midlife Harmonies
description: In "Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace," Bruce Leddy's ensemble dramedy about a seven-man college a cappella group reuniting after 15 years to perform at a classmate's wedding, midlife crisis is the prevailing refrain. At a Hamptons rehearsal weekend, an office technician (David Harbour) frets about age; a divorced lawyer (Reg Rogers) bemoans bachelorhood; a fired money manager (Alexander Chaplin) fears for his marriage. Also on hand are three wives, a girlfriend and a fetching Swedish nanny.

title: Victories Beyond the Basketball Court
description: Short, sweet and sentimental, "Something to Cheer About" tells the story of Indiana's Crispus Attucks Tigers, who, in 1955, became the first all-black high school basketball team to win a state championship. Like last year's "Glory Road," Betsy Blankenbaker's documentary celebrates a victory over much more than just rival teams.

title: A Personal Portrait of War
description: Lance Cpl. Jos Antonio Gutirrez, the subject of this nonfiction film, was a Guatemalan immigrant who became the first American soldier killed in the invasion of Iraq. Official accounts presented a classic tale of an up-by-your-bootstraps immigrant  a young man who fled poverty and violence in his native land, then enlisted in the Marines in hopes of earning his green card more quickly.

title: Perella Weinberg Feels the Pressure of Great Expectations
description: Boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners may be just a year and a half old, but it is already acting  and spending  like a member of the Wall Street establishment. Joseph R. Perellas outfit has raised $1.1 billion, hired more than 22 brand-name bankers as partners and set up shop in the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: The News in Quotes: Hardball, Gadflies and Bus Bulbs
description: Spitzer and the Raises: The governors agenda is to hold up legislative raises in order to use that as a chip for something else.  Senator John A. DeFrancisco, the Republican judiciary committee chairman, on a judicial reform bill that would give raises to state judges.
Video Should be here

title: A Dull First Debate
2008: The Reviews Are In
description: The morning after the first Democratic presidential debate in Orangeburg, S.C., the reviews are in  especially from the candidates themselves. Releases from John Edwards, who has sought to beat the other candidates to the policy punch by offering several broad proposals, highlighted reviews from analysts about the substance and detail of his responses.

title: A Statues Place Revives Post-Soviet Tensions
description: At the end of a week of mourning for Boris Yeltsin, the man who tried to sweep away remnants of the Soviet Union, including its anthem, the former Soviet republic of Estonia took another step in that direction today.
politics

title: Minor Threat
description: Los Angeles Times columnist Rosa Brooks advances an argument that is usually verboten among mainstream opinion-slingers: International terrorism does not represent an existential threat to the United States. The 9/11 attacks were appalling and tragic, but they did not threaten the survival of the nation, Brooks writes. The year 2001 aside, total deaths (not just of Americans) caused by international terrorism worldwide have never exceeded  or even approached  2,000 a year. Sept. 11 was an outlier: On 9/11, a group of brutal, extremist Islamic thugs got very lucky. She continues:

title: More From the Democratic Debate
description: Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny filed this post:

title: Lay of the Land
description: Although Paul believed the charrette was a cross between a class trip and a boondoogle, our architect, Greg Huddy, had  as I had suspected  a full agenda planned for our site visit.

title: Notes on the News
description: Slam Dunked George Tenet, the former C.I.A. chief, said that his famous slam dunk remark about Iraqs W.M.D.s was made after President Bush urged his team to add punch to the public presentation. I told the president that strengthening the public presentation was a slam dunk, a phrase that was later taken completely out of context, Mr. Tenet writes.

title: Matsuzaka Gets Cable, He Knows
description: When Daisuke Matsuzaka was first introduced as a member of the Boston Red Sox at a press conference at Fenway Park last December, he made a humorous comment about the fierce rivalry with the Yankees.

title: Hiking into Spring
description: Trails in New York, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Pennsylvania perfect for stretching your legs after winter.

title: Another Big Start For Perez
description: Last year, when the Mets rolled to a hot start on their way to wrapping up the division by July, they were 13-7 through their first 20 games. Perhaps youve noticed, but thats what the 2007 Mets are at the same point, and they should be 16-7 after this weekends series in Washington.

title: A Full House at Goldman Chiefs New Digs
description: If you were hoping to share an address with Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein and hedge fund manager Daniel Loeb, it may be too late (at least for awhile). Curbed is reporting that all the units at 15 Central Park West, the new luxury condominium where both Mr. Blankfein and Mr. Loeb have bought penthouses, have sold out, as of yesterday. The developments Web site also indicates that all the one-, two-, three- and four-bedroom units have been sold.

title: The New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival Expands, a Symbol of Determination
description: New Orleans, April 26The 38th annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival is doing something you dont see much around this shrunken city these days: expanding. Theres a lot in New Orleans now thats about getting it back where it was, said Quint Davis, who has produced every Jazzfest. He was behind the wheel of a golfcart at the New Orleans Fair Grounds as he oversaw last-minute preparations on Thursday afternoon.

title: Going Long  Very Long  on Hedge Funds
description: At more than 7,000 words, Tom Wolfes recent epic in Portfolio magazine might have served as the coda to the medias recent obsession with writing about hedge funds. But it didnt. The Financial Times on Friday produced its own treatise on hedge funds in the form of a special package of articles that, to be fair, was likely planned long before the publication of Mr. Wolfes voluminous word portrait and another package on hedge funds that was recently played off the cover of New York magazine.

title: The Bard of the Blue Room
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may be no Shakespeare, but then the Bard never had to write about smoking, trans fat or traffic. The mayor unveiled his latest attempt at verse today during his weekly call-in radio show on WABC in honor of the fifth annual Poem in Your Pocket day:

title: Bo Collins Gets Back in the Game
description: Past performance, investors are reminded at every turn, is not necessarily an indication of future results.

title: Coffee Talk With Bill Richardson
Living the Coachella Dream
description: A brief audio-visual look at the history of the in California  and what to expect this year, including big-name reunions by Rage Against the Machine and the Jesus and Mary Chain.

title: Podcast: Remembering David Halberstam
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: Logic Behind the Legalese
description: A few blogs ago, I ridiculed the 15-screen installation process for a simple Netgear driver. Above all, I expressed derision for the stupid legalesethe license agreementthat everybody has to click past, every time they install any software, whether or not it makes any sense. (For example, Netgears driver works only with Netgears network adapter, so why is the company so worried that it will be pirated?)

title: Slam-Dunking Mr. Slam-Dunk
description: Reacting to The New York Times article today about George Tenets new book, Jason Zengerle of The New Republic has a theory about why the book portrays President Bush in a largely positive light while several other senior officials come in for a trashing.

title: Campaign Cash: Q&A With the Chairman
description: Now that the first-quarter campaign reports of the 2008 presidential candidates have been filed and made public, we asked Robert Lenhard, the chairman of the Federal Election Commission, to take part in a question-and-answer session with us, and with you, Caucus readers.

title: Spitzer Introduces Marriage Bill
description: Updated. As expected, Gov. Eliot Spitzer introduced a bill today to legalize same-sex marriage in New York. (Gay City News had the early word this morning.) Mr. Spitzers staff had been trying to put the legislation together in time for Mondays Tuesdays lobby day by gay-rights groups. And it looks like they succeeded.

title: How to Keep the Locals Happy
description: When dealing with neighborhood restaurants beloved by the people who live nearby, a restaurant critic often hears pleas like these: Dont go! Please dont go! Youre going to like it, and then Ill never get a reservation at 8 p.m. on a Friday night. How can I persuade you not to go? Do you like cashmere? Have I mentioned my lovely new villa in Umbria?

title: A Venture Investors E-Mail Solution: Delete
description: Last week, BlackBerry addicts across the country suffered through (or secretly enjoyed) a mobile e-mail blackout. This week, the ValleyWag blog highlighted the opposite problem: People who get so much electronic correspondence that they declare e-mail bankruptcy. It seems to be especially common among the Silicon Valley and venture capital set. ValleyWag identifies several entrepreneurs and tech luminaries who have found that their inboxes were so hopelessly overstocked that they needed to wipe the slate clean. Copyright lawyer and Stanfard Law School professor Lawrence Lessig, a frequent writer about technology issues, famously did it in 2004. And on Monday, Fred Wilson, a partner at Union Square Ventures, did much the same on his blog, A VC.

title: J.P. Morgan Adds Homebuilding Banker
description: J.P. Morgan Chases investment banking arm has hired Margaret Whelan, a former research analyst from UBS, as a managing director. Ms. Whelan will be a senior partner in the group that works with homebuilding companies, J.P. Morgan said in an internal memo. At UBS, Ms. Whelan had been global head of homebuilding equity research.

title: Everyone Can Learn From Einstein
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans April 27 column, China Needs an Einstein. So Do We..

title: All We Have to Fear is the President Himself
description: Readers respond to Frank Richs Apr. 22 column, Iraq Is the Ultimate Aphrodisiac.

title: Like Herding Poodles and Sheep
description: Did you hear about the company thats selling sheep as poodles in Japan at cut-rate prices? Its all over Google News right now, and also ran in two British tabloids. From Britains Metro:

title: AT&T Chief Executive to Retire
description: Edward E. Whitacre Jr., who led an aggressive acquisition strategy that built AT&T into the worlds largest telephone company, said Friday he will retire as AT&Ts chairman and chief executive on June 3. The announcement comes just a few months after AT&T completed its $86 billion purchase of BellSouth, which was the largest deal of 2006. Mr. Whitacre will be succeeded by Randall L. Stephenson, currently the companys chief operating officer, who is expected to focus on execution and integration at the company, The New York Timess Matt Richtel reported. Investors and analysts said they were not surprised by the change in command.

title: Not All Quiet on Atlantic Yards Front
description: Updated. The folks at Develop Dont Destroy sent along a note about the statement below from the Empire State Development Corporation saying that work would temporarily halt after the partial collapse at the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn yesterday. The Atlantic Yards critics report that as we write this (11:30 am) Ratner contractors are still doing demolition and abatement work at 189, 191, 193 Flatbush. Sometimes ceasefire news take time to travel. (See the update below; the developer says the work going on now is needed to secure the site so demolition work can be put on hold.)

title: Coachella: Desert Heat and Fleabag Motels
description: Indio, Calif., APRIL 27: I dont like trying to predict which performances will break through the blur and distinguish themselves at big, bustling festivals. But I especially wouldnt want to do so at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, which starts in about two and a half hours, as soon as the sun rises a little more over the desert valley and the temperature reaches 100 degrees.

title: For Hedge Funds, a Billion-Dollar Image Problem
description: Obviously what we make is absolutely obscene, said Marc Lasry, founder and managing partner of Avenue Capital Group, speaking about his fellow hedge fund managers a recent panel sponsored by the Milken Institute. Im not saying its wrong, trust me, but its still obscene, he said, according to the Associated Press. And the eye-popping sums earned by hedge fund managers could work against the industry as it tries to burnish its image and avoid greater regulation from Washington.

title: A Debate Post-Mortem
description: Governor Bill Richardson sat down with The New York Times and reflected on his performance during Thursday's debate.

title: The Future of Hydrogen
description: Seventy years after the Hindenberg disaster, hydrogen has come a long way. The Times recently tested hydrogen vehicles from three manufacturers.

title: All That Glitters Is Gold, Again
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Apr. 27 column, Gilded Once More.

title: Troopers Death Was Friendly Fire
description: Preston L. Felton, the acting New York State Police Superintendent, said during a news conference this afternoon that Trooper David C. Brinkerhoff was apparently killed by friendly fire during a gunfight on Wednesday between state troopers and a suspect holed up in an unoccupied farmhouse.

title: Renzi: Demise Reports Greatly Exaggerated
description: Some people have been waiting around, wondering if a letter would drop today following a report that Representative Rick Renzi, an Arizona Republican, could resign as soon as Friday.

title: Congestion Pricing, Asthma and Tikkun Olam
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, speaking in forceful and personal terms, went this afternoon to a neighborhood plagued by high asthma rates to argue for his plan to reduce the citys air pollution. The proposal includes a surcharge for vehicles entering congested sections of Manhattan.

title: On the McCain Trail in Iowa
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  The presidential campaign of Senator John McCain of Arizona took on a decidedly military cast today, from more discussion of the war in Iraq to vivid memories of the war in Vietnam.

title: China Frees U.S.-Based Activist
description: Yang Jianli, a democracy activist and Boston resident, was released from a Chinese prison after serving a five-year sentence.

title: Blogtalk: Tenets Book
description: While not quite Harry Potter, former C.I.A. director George Tenets new book has generated lots of buzz, three days before its scheduled release. Mr. Tenets contention that the White House ignored any evidence countering its view that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction leading up to the Iraq War provided liberal bloggers lots of new talking points on an old subject. For the most part, conservative blogs ignored the issue today.

title: A Shame of a Name
description: The Eater web site today calls into question the poetry and catchiness of FR.OG as a name for a restaurant, and the Eater folks have a pretty good point, even if you delete the odd mid-word punctuation mark, which signals that the all-capitalized syllable is a sort-of-quasi-acronym for FRench OriGine.

title: Consumers Keep Spending
description: The decline in housing values is supposed to make Americans less willing to spend. But so far it has not.

title: The Problems of Upgrades and Code-Shares
description: Last October, I bought a ticket from American Airlines to travel from Los Angeles to Hong Kong. I tried to upgrade to business class using American AAdvantage miles, but was told that this was not possible because I was on a code-share flight operated by Cathay Pacific, a partner in the Oneworld Alliance. I now wonder, what is the alliance in Oneworld? It seems that airlines are making it more and more difficult for frequent fliers to take advantage of the loyalty we show them.

title: Vows: Alicia and Matthew
description: Alicia Vitarelli and Matthew Pantaleno got to know each other as colleagues on a television news program.

title: The Education of a Racehorse
description: Behind the scenes with Nobiz Like Shobiz, a top contender for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Selling to Islam
description: Is the advertising world ready to market big name brands to Muslim Americans?

title: Odds and Ends from RFK Stadium
description: It looks like Lastings Milledge is going to be out longer than anticipated. Milledge, diagnosed with sprained ligaments in his right foot during a recent trip to New York, will be out four to six weeks, Omar Minaya said tonight. This doesnt hurt the Mets much now, but if something were to happen to Moises Alou or Shawn Green, the teams options are slim. Ben Johnson, next in line after Milledge for a promotion, is out with a sprained shoulder. After him, its Ricky Ledee or, if the Mets are feeling extra bold, the prospect Carlos Gomez.

title: Dr. Hurwitz Convicted on 16 Counts of Drug Trafficking
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  After deliberating for seven days in federal court here, a jury late this afternoon found Dr. William Hurwitz guilty on 16 counts of drug trafficking. Dr. Hurwitz, whose legal battles over his opioid prescriptions made him a hero to some chronic-pain patients, was not convicted on the other 29 counts against him.

title: Should Immigration Be a Police Issue?
description: Communities across the New York region are debating whether their local police should be involved in immigration issues. For example, in Morristown, N.J., the mayor has proposed to enroll the police in a small but growing federal program that trains local officers to help enforce federal immigration laws. The program is known as 287(g), for a section of the 1996 Immigration and Nationality Act that allows local officers, after being trained, to identify, process, and when appropriate, detain immigration offenders they encounter during their regular, daily law-enforcement activity.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Living In article in the Real Estate section this weekend, about Pleasant Plains, Staten Island, incorrectly describes the borders of the neighborhood. As correctly shown on the map with the article, Pleasant Plains is bordered on the south by the waterfront, on the west by Cunningham Road, on the north by the Korean War Veterans Parkway and on the east by a vague line created by Lemon Creek, Bayview Avenue and Lenevar Avenue.

title: AT&T Chief Who Weathered a Sea Change Is Retiring in June
description: When Edward E. Whitacre Jr. joined Southwestern Bell in 1963 as a facilities engineer, the land-line telephone was the state of the art and the Bell operating companies were dominant.

title: Steroids Are a Stain That Is Hard to Erase
description: The red-stained sock had its nice little run, but by late yesterday afternoon it was being dismissed as a significant news event by Joe Torre.

title: Eleven Soldiers Face Charges of Attacking 2
description: A soldier stationed at the Fort Drum Army base in upstate New York and his wife were attacked by nearly a dozen fellow soldiers at the couples off-base apartment this week in retaliation for a restraining order the wife recently filed against another soldier, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Federal Official Resigns in Escort Service Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The head of the Agency for International Development, Randall L. Tobias, resigned abruptly on Friday for what he said were personal reasons, but an administration official said Mr. Tobiass name had come up in an investigation of a suspected Washington prostitution ring.

title: More Like an Air Ball
description: WASHINGTON

title: Reese Recalls Lessons From Home as First N.F.L. Draft Approaches
description: TIPTONVILLE, Tenn., April 24  Jerry Reese, only a polite grade-school boy then, would steady the shotgun and shoot the hog between the eyes. He slit its throat with a butchers knife, then wrestled it into a tub of hot water, softening the coarse hair so it could be shaved off with a blade. He lifted the hog onto a hook, cut its belly, dissected it and split it into usable parts.

title: The A-B-Cs of Calculating Financial Aid
description: THIS week, members of the Class of 2011 are coming down to the wire in deciding which colleges they will attend and, more often than not, their choice is influenced by which offers the most generous financial aid package.

title: Japans Leader Walks Thin Line With Remarks on Sex Slavery
description: TOKYO, April 28  In his first visit to the United States as Japans leader, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe quickly got on a first-name basis with President Bush and secured an invitation to the ranch in Crawford, Tex., for the next time.

title: Keeping His Word, Spitzer Asks for Same-Sex-Marriage Law
description: ALBANY, April 27  Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed legislation on Friday that would make New York the second state in the country to legally sanction same-sex marriage, fulfilling a longtime pledge to supporters of gay rights.

title: Coppin State (0-36) Avoids Loss, but Again Fails to Win
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 25  With rain pelting the field, the game was called with Coppin State leading Lehigh, 4-3, in the bottom of the fifth inning. Perhaps the Eagles were only two outs away from the inconceivable  a victory for college baseballs worst team.

title: Weighing Jobss Role in a Scandal
description: In June 2001, Fortune magazine put Steven P. Jobs on its cover. This, I realize, is not exactly breaking news; the magazine put Mr. Jobs on its cover with shameless regularity.

title: Citigroup Goes Global in Ad Effort
description: For years, Citigroup has promised its customers better service and its investors better results. Now, Citigroup is pitching a new message: Lets Get It Done.

title: Penn State Football Players Charged in Fight
description: Six Penn State football players were charged yesterday for what the authorities said were their various roles in an off-campus fight.

title: Japan Court Rules Against Sex Slaves and Laborers
description: TOKYO, April 27  In two landmark rulings, Japans highest court on Friday rejected compensation claims filed by former wartime sex slaves and forced laborers from China but acknowledged that they had been coerced by the Japanese military or industry.

title: A Glacial Pace on Warming
description: Weeks after the Supreme Courts momentous ruling that the federal government could and probably should regulate greenhouse gases, pressure for decisive action continues to build.

title: Elias Says He Feels Ready to Return Saturday
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 27  Only five Devils participated in an optional skate Friday afternoon, and one of them was Patrik Elias, their captain and top scorer.

title: From Many Faiths, a Mass
description: Contemporary music is often like fusion cuisine, as composers spice up their scores with unexpected ingredients. So when Chanticleer, the San Francisco-based male a cappella choir, commissioned five composers of diverse ethnicities, faiths and compositional leanings each to write a section of a new Mass, it seemed that the resulting work might offer stimulating contrasts.

title: Turkish Military Issues Threat as Voting Is Derailed
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Saturday, April 28  A revolt by Turkeys secular opposition on Friday derailed the first round of voting on a presidential candidate with a background in political Islam, and in a harsh warning, the military hinted that it might act against the government if it strayed too far from secularism.

title: Project Halted in Brooklyn for Inquiry Into Accident
description: One day after the partial collapse of a building being prepared for demolition to make way for the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the state and the developer announced that work would be stopped pending the outcome of the citys investigation into the accident.

title: Top Tier Candidate? Maybe Not, but Dodd Is Still Enjoying the Ride
description: ORANGEBURG, S.C., April 27  Senator Christopher J. Dodd has a magnificent handshake, maybe the best in the Democratic presidential field. He grips with a brisk clench, makes masterly eye contact and tops it off with a light pat on the wrist from his nonshaking hand. It is the grip of a pro, a (perish the thought) political pro, which he is, the silvery-haired son of a senator, accomplished lawmaker, backslapper and armsqueezer.

title: World View Podcast
description: Calvin Sims and Steve Weisman discuss Paul Wolfowitz

title: With A.M.D., Riding Waves of Volatility
description: IF the semiconductor industry were a seesaw, Intel would be anchored close to the middle, experiencing relatively gentle ups and downs. Advanced Micro Devices would be on one of the ends, clinging with both hands.

title: Its Maple Syrup Time, So Why the Whiff of French Fries?
description: WESTMINSTER, Vt.  Ah, early spring in Vermont. As temperatures warmed and the maples yielded up their annual crop of syrup, the hills and forests of the state were dotted with the familiar sights, sounds and smells of sugaring time.

title: South Carolina, and a Fish Fry, Gain Political Heft on 08 Path
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., April 27  Seldom has a slice of white bread and a piece of fried fish carried such weighty significance in American politics.

title: San Francisco Bay Area Reacts Angrily to Series of Immigration Raids
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27  It was not the typical Bay Area morning. Before dawn on March 6, dozens of federal immigration agents conducted surprise raids in San Rafael and nearby Novato, two comfortable Marin County suburbs where the idea of early morning excitement usually involves a trip to Starbucks.

title: Florida: Campuses Evacuated After Threat
description: All six campuses of Broward Community College and two university campuses in South Florida were evacuated and searched by the police after a note threatening an attack was found. The note, mentioning the Virginia Tech killings and threatening a similar attack at the community college, was written on a poster board and found at a Hollywood construction site, said Capt. Tony Rode, a spokesman for the Hollywood police. Florida Atlantic University officials evacuated two campuses that share space with the community college. Earlier this week, the police arrested a man they say admitted writing a note threatening to bomb a Hollywood middle school and another one threatening to set fire to an apartment building. The man, Larry Boynton, 52, is considered a person of interest in the college threat, Captain Rode said.

title: Dells Founder Is Rethinking Direct Sales
description: Michael S. Dell, the chairman and chief executive of Dell, who built his business by selling direct to his customers, is now thinking about changing the way the company markets its computers.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about quarterback JaMarcus Russells emergence as a star at Louisiana State University referred imprecisely to one of his statistics. Russell had 342 passes during his senior season, not in his collegiate career. (His career number was 797.)

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,328 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Investigation of Seattle Pension Fund Manager Widens
description: Federal prosecutors in Seattle are conducting a criminal inquiry into Quellos Investments, a prominent money manager for pension funds, over its design and sale of questionable tax shelters to wealthy investors. The inquiry signals a widening of a federal investigation into tax shelters promoted by banks, accounting firms and law firms in recent years.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 27, 2007

title: Rewriting the Ad Rules for Muslim-Americans
description: For years, few advertisers in the United States have dared to reach out to Muslims.

title: After Violent Night, Estonia Removes a Soviet-Era Memorial
description: MOSCOW, April 27  Estonias government removed a Soviet-era war memorial early on Friday morning after a night of protest and violence that killed one person, injured dozens and left a swath of shattered windows and overturned cars in the center of the capital, Tallinn, officials there said.

title: The Abstinence-Only Delusion
description: Reliance on abstinence-only sex education as the primary tool to reduce teenage pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases  as favored by the Bush administration and conservatives in Congress  looks increasingly foolish and indefensible.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 10 P.M. (Showtime) EDMOND  (2005) After a tarot card reader tells him, You are not where you belong, a nebbishy businessman walks out on his marriage and unleashes his long-suppressed rage  and sexual desires  in this explosive adaptation of David Mamets 1982 one-act play. Stephen Holden, writing in The New York Times, said that William H. Macy, above, a master at playing sticks of human dynamite in mild-mannered camouflage, gives the nerviest screen performance of his career.

title: After Complaints, Colorado Moves to Improve Veterans Lives
description: DENVER, April 27  Federal reports that criticized conditions at Colorado veterans nursing homes have caused an outcry here. Legislators have scrambled to allocate new money to the homes, the state agency that operates them has promised improvements and the Veterans Affairs Department moved up its annual inspection of a home suffering from especially serious disrepair.

title: Far Past Time to Go
description: It is hard to figure out what Paul Wolfowitz is telling himself as he wages an unseemly fight to hang on to his job as head of the World Bank.

title: Former C.I.A. Chiefs Memoir Irritates Some High-Ranking Readers
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  In January 2002, George J. Tenet, the man who oversaw all American spy agencies, was asked by a visiting Italian intelligence official what he knew about United States officials making contact with exiled Iranian opposition figures.

title: After a War Bill Veto, Then What? (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Rejecting a Stiff Suit for More Comfortable Clothing
description: When Christopher Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, the early-music movement was often equated with dry playing and odd sounds from obdurate period instruments. On Thursday night, while watching and listening to the group in a delightfully engaging concert at Zankel Hall, it was striking how much freedom this movement now affords.

title: Well-Known Secret: Greys Anatomy Spinoff for ABC
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27  Like a doting parent trying to hide a childs Christmas bike under the bed, ABC has been pretending to hope that no one notices what could be its biggest winner in next falls television season, a spinoff of its hit nighttime soap opera Greys Anatomy.

title: China: A New Envoy to the United States
description: China named Yang Jiechi, who was ambassador to the United States from 2001 to 2005, to become foreign minister, shuffling its diplomatic team as its rising economic power has given it greater sway in world affairs. Mr. Yang, 56, formerly a vice minister, is fluent in English and well known for a courteous but cautious manner. He replaces Li Zhaoxing, another English speaker and former ambassador to Washington, who is 66. No reason was given for the replacement, but Mr. Li had passed the retirement age for ministerial officials. Mr. Yang assumes the helm at a time when China has greatly expanded its diplomatic activities around the world, especially in Asia and Africa, and as its economic growth and increased military spending have raised concerns in some quarters that it may begin to challenge Washington for leadership in world affairs.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Group Raises Pressure on ABN
description: LONDON, April 27  A group of three European banks led by the Royal Bank of Scotland increased pressure today on the board of ABN Amro to consider its takeover bid.

title: Mayor Promotes Clean-Air Plan in an Area Hit Hard by Asthma
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, speaking in forceful and personal terms, went yesterday to a neighborhood plagued by high asthma rates to argue for his sweeping plan to reduce the citys air pollution, which includes a surcharge for vehicles entering congested sections of Manhattan.

title: The White House Scales Back Talk of Iraq Progress
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The Bush administration will not try to assess whether the troop increase in Iraq is producing signs of political progress or greater security until September, and many of Mr. Bushs top advisers now anticipate that any gains by then will be limited, according to senior administration officials.

title: The Dow May Be at Its High, but Its Performance Is Still Lacking
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average rose above 13,000 this week, well above the highest point it reached in 2000 before the technology stock bubble burst and the country went into a recession in 2001.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary last Saturday about Frank H. Westheimer, a chemist who did research on enzymes, misspelled part of the name of an enzyme he studied. It is alcohol dehydrogenase, not dehydrogenate.

title: Visit by Anglican Bishop Draws Episcopal Anger
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The Anglican archbishop of Nigeria, a fierce critic of the Episcopal Church for its acceptance of homosexuality, is arriving next week to install a bishop to lead congregations around the country that want to break from it.

title: Economic Growth Slows to Weakest Pace in 4 Years
description: Economic growth during the first three months of the year was the slowest since early 2003 when the country was still emerging from a recession, the government said today.

title: The Ratings System, Built to Endure
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27  As David S. Goyer readied his new movie for release this weekend, he joined the long list of filmmakers who have been frustrated, flummoxed or downright infuriated by what may turn out to be Jack Valentis most enduring legacy, the film rating system.

title: Bush and Congress Easing Tone of Debate on War Bill
description: With the $124 billion war spending bill, and its timetable for withdrawing American troops, headed for a presidential veto early next week, both President Bush and Democratic leaders yesterday toned down the talk of the last several weeks and hinted at a willingness to compromise.

title: Moral Plots and Subplots in the Latest Ruling on Abortion
description: Life today is lived on slippery slopes. Which ones seize our attention and crystallize our fears? What moral outrages or absurdities, lurking at the bottom, stir our energies? How steep is the incline? Where can we throw up a railing, dig a trench, clear a landing, keep our footing? Questions like these determine a great deal of public moral debate.

title: Blue Cross Agrees to Settle Doctors Claims
description: The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association and more than 30 Blue Cross health plans across the country agreed yesterday to pay $128 million to settle lawsuits brought by doctors who said that they had been underpaid on insurance claims.

title: The Very Voice of History in WNYC Archives
description: The voice crackles out of computer speakers.

title: Warriors Have Toppled Bay Area Pecking Order
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 27  The bridge linking the Golden State Warriors last heyday to their current renaissance starts with Don Nelson and ends with Don Nelson, with nothing but potholes in between.

title: New Transportation Commissioner Is Named
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday appointed a new transportation commissioner charged with putting in place the transportation-oriented initiatives that are part of the mayors program for keeping the city environmentally sound.

title: United Nations Group Ends Mission to Kosovo Without Clear Plan
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, April 28  A United Nations Security Council fact-finding mission completed a two-day trip to Kosovo on Saturday, amid an increasingly tense debate between Russia and the United States over the provinces future.

title: Filipino Suspect Says He Killed American
description: MANILA, April 27 (AP)  A woodcarver suspected of beating a Peace Corps volunteer to death surrendered Friday and confessed on television, saying he had erupted in rage when she bumped into him as he was fuming over a feud with a neighbor.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article Thursday about the formal start of Senator John McCains campaign for the Republican presidential nomination misspelled the surname of the United States attorney general, whom Mr. McCain urged to resign, in two of four references. The attorney general is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez. (Go to Article)

title: A Nation Bound by Colorful Dinnerware
description: American Fiesta, a new one-man show written and performed by Steven Tomlinson, is as topically ambitious a theatrical effort as you will experience Off Broadway right now. It clips along with the energy of someone whose very metabolism seems to run on a hunger to understand himself and the world better.

title: Cooper-Hewitt Is Determined to Expand, Despite a Host of Critics
description: Given the recent travails of its parent, the Smithsonian Institution, the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum may seem relatively hardy.

title: Comrades Shot Killed New York State Trooper
description: The bullet that killed a New York state trooper during a shootout Wednesday morning in a farmhouse in the Catskill Mountains came from the gun of a fellow officer, not the suspect they had cornered, the state police said yesterday.

title: Hazy Clouds of Sound, Halfway Intelligible Vocals
description: Was that blood? Probably not, but it wasnt easy to tell. Bradford Cox was onstage at the Mercury Lounge on Thursday night, leading his Atlanta-based band, Deerhunter, through an impressive and slightly disconcerting set. The place was packed, though it got a bit less packed as the night wore on.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a Congressional hearing in Brooklyn at which speakers urged the Environmental Protection Agency to address contamination and medical problems in areas outside Lower Manhattan resulting from the Sept. 11 attack included incorrect information about the hearing from a spokeswoman for the E.P.A. Although the agency itself was not invited to testify, the agencys inspector general, who operates independently, was. (He declined the invitation.)

title: At a Well-Attended Regional, a Record-Setting Performance
description: The most popular regional is held in Gatlinburg, Tenn., in April. This years, which ended on April 15, set a record, with more than 10,000 tables in play during the events seven days. This is better than at some nationals, which run for 10 days. Also, Robert Hampton of Blythewood, S.C., collected 230.18 master points, the largest number won at any regional.

title: Football Potential Is Seen in a Basketball Big Man
description: The grainy video of Glen Davis playing high school football may be surprising to those who know him only as a burly Louisiana State basketball player called Big Baby.

title: With Return of Sea Lions, a Rebirth at Bronx Zoo
description: Having a home renovated is never easy. But at least Adrienne, Cleo and Indie, who normally live in the Bronx, were fortunate enough to have been on an extended vacation in Brooklyn during the noise and dust of their construction project.

title: That Car in the Next Lane? Its Radioactive
description: Something in the silver Mercedes sport utility vehicle was potentially dangerous, at least if the police lieutenants radiation detector was any guide. The devices alarm went off as the lieutenant, who works with the Police Departments counterterrorism unit, was driving to work yesterday around 8 a.m., heading west on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn near Cropsey Avenue.

title: Theyll Keep the Smoking Sign On
description: IN a classic example of basic marketing  if everyone is zigging, it may be a good time for you to zag  Extended Stay Hotels is embracing smokers. The chain, which operates 682 North American properties under, among others, the Extended Stay America, Homestead Studio Suites and Crossland Economy Studios brands, recently announced it planned to keep its smokers welcome policies in place, Hotels magazine reports.

title: Four Students Held in Plan for Shooting at a School
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27  With anxiety running high in classrooms across the nation after the Virginia Tech attacks, the authorities in Sacramento arrested four secondary school students on Thursday, including one carrying a loaded gun.

title: On Night of Firsts, a Second Win Over the Yankees for Matsuzaka
description: There were 14 million baseball fans in Japan still sipping their coffee or yawning through a Saturday morning when Daisuke Matsuzaka faced the Yankees last night. They wanted to see Matsuzaka, so forfeiting some sleep was worth it. Or so they thought.

title: Car Bomb Kills at Least 45 Near Shrine in Karbala
description: BAGHDAD, April 28  A suicide car bomber struck near a sacred Shiite shrine in Karbala today, killing at least 58 people and wounding 169 in the second attack in two weeks against the citys holy sites, Iraqi police officials said.

title: James Davis, 90, Leader of Longtime Gospel Group, Is Dead
description: James B. Davis, the leader of the Dixie Hummingbirds, one of the longest-lasting and most influential groups in gospel music, died on April 17 in Philadelphia. He was 90 and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Credibility Issues Undid Duke Case, Report Says
description: The North Carolina attorney generals investigation of the Duke lacrosse case found that the accuser had insurmountable credibility issues, including frequently changing statements that were contradicted by physical evidence, photographs, other witnesses and her own previous assertions.

title: Theres Something Here, Emanating From Nothing
description: Tere OConnors provocative Nothing Festival was intended to get dance back to basics, without the worries of marketing, fund-raising or suitable production values. In addition, the eight choreographers Mr. OConnor chose were to begin their new dances from scratch, without prompts like music or theme.

title: C.I.A. Held Qaeda Leader in Secret Jail for Months
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The Central Intelligence Agency held a captured Qaeda leader in a secret prison since last fall and transferred him last week to the American military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, officials said Friday.

title: 4 Iraqis Held on Suspicion of Smuggling Iranian Arms
description: BAGHDAD, April 27  The American military said Friday that it had detained four Iraqi men suspected of helping smuggle deadly homemade bombs from Iran to Iraq and taking guerrillas from Iraq to Iran for training.

title: Urban to Core, Storm Evacuees Give Farm a Try
description: SIMMESPORT, La.  Faced with the televised devastation of New Orleans and the despair of Hurricane Katrina victims, many people have sent them charitable checks.

title: U.S. Objected to Scuttling of Bribery Inquiry in Britain
description: LONDON, April 27  The British government confirmed Friday that it received two diplomatic protests from the United States in January after it canceled an inquiry into allegations of bribery by Britains top military contractor to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia.

title: Guilty Plea Widens Baseballs Steroids Scandal
description: A former Mets clubhouse assistant pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court in San Francisco to distributing performance-enhancing drugs to dozens of former and current Major League Baseball players for a 10-year period, the latest blow to a sport that has been battered by the issue of steroid use.

title: In a Switch, Consistency From Prez Isnt Enough
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  In pondering their 4-3 loss to the Washington Nationals on Friday night, the Mets faced a philosophical dilemma fit for baseballs sages: If Oliver Prez, the king of inconsistency, pitches well but the team loses, is it a good night?

title: A Lack of Interest (and Candidates) in New Systems School Parent Councils
description: The stage was set for the candidates forum. Andrew Baumann, one of nine candidates on the ballot for a school parent council in southwest Queens, was the first person to arrive.

title: A Governors Postpartisanship: Old-Fashioned Politicking?
description: LOS ANGELES, April 27  In a sunny and joyful world  the sort that Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, prefers to inhabit  postpartisanship means that lawmakers come together without ideological bickering, score legislative victories and happily return to their districts in time for dinner.

title: Gaza: Palestinians in Border Fight; 1 Dead
description: A Palestinian security officer was shot dead in a clash with local residents at the Rafah border crossing in southern Gaza, Palestinian officials said. The officer, Abdulrahman Abu Teir, 24, was killed after armed members of a family tried to barge into the terminal without waiting in line, witnesses said. Palestinian security forces control the passenger crossing into Egypt, under the supervision of European monitors, but Israel determines when it will be open. The crossing was opened Thursday for the first time since April 19, but it was too crowded to operate, a spokeswoman for the European monitoring mission said. Up to 5,000 Gazans arrived at the crossing yesterday. It remained open all day, the spokeswoman said, because the unrest occurred outside the terminal itself.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Thursday about receiver Calvin Johnson on the eve of the N.F.L. draft misattributed a quotation about the influence of his familys values on Johnson. It was Johnsons father, Calvin Sr.  not Johnson himself  who said the family wouldnt tolerate a lot of being foolish. The article also referred imprecisely to Johnsons leaping ability. He performed an 11-foot-7-inch standing long jump, not just a long jump.

title: With Jets Providing Accompaniment, a Rare City Treasure Stands Exposed
description: SAN DIEGO  Playing the organ in cold churches never daunted Carol Williams in England, where she grew up and decided to become a concert performer.

title: A Record Labels Legacy Is Celebrated and Reimagined
description: The legacy of Blue Note Records cuts a wide swath through music history, from the boogie-woogie bustle of Meade Lux Lewis to the folk-stirred pop of Norah Jones. But the labels core identity rests on a remarkable body of recordings made in the 1950s and 60s. Its only natural that Legends of Blue Note, a concert presented by Jazz at Lincoln Center on Thursday night, would focus chiefly on that era, if only as a ratification of its enduring appeal.

title: A Dow Breakthrough and a Housing Breakdown
description: Blue chip stocks surged all week as many big companies reported better-than-expected results, though mixed economic data might quiet the enthusiasm next week. No such hesitation was evident among cash-rich equity buyers, though, as acquisitions continued apace, one with a new feature.

title: After 2 Solid Periods, Defense Betrays Rangers
description: BUFFALO, April 27  For two periods, the Rangers followed the precise, defense-first plan they had drawn up, only to have it torn to shreds in 24 seconds. Two passes  one errant, one perfect  turned a one-goal lead into a Buffalo Sabres comeback.

title: Corzine Says He Will Leave the Hospital Soon
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 27  Gov. Jon S. Corzine told the states top two legislators on Friday that he expected to be released from the hospital on Tuesday or Wednesday and that he would continue his recuperation at Drumthwacket, the governors mansion in Princeton, instead of at the Hoboken condominium where he lives.

title: Liberia: Diamond Ban Lifted
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved the lifting of a 2001 blockade of the sale of so-called blood diamonds from Liberia that fueled wars in West Africa. Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, the Liberian president, had pressed for an end to the embargo as necessary to revive the economy of her impoverished nation, and Emyr Jones Parry, left, Britains ambassador to the United Nations, said the decision reflected confidence that the country now met the standards of the Kimberley Process, an industry initiative certifying the origins of diamonds entering international trade. The Council lifted similar restrictions on Liberian timber sales in June.

title: With Kidd at Full Speed, Nets Cruise to Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 27  Jason Kidd virtually glided down the court Friday night, his knee tightly braced, the ball serving as an extension of hands that possessed an uncanny intuition.

title: Italy: Berlusconis 2004 Acquittal Upheld
description: A court in Milan upheld the acquittal of the former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, on corruption charges. The court upheld a 2004 decision that cleared Mr. Berlusconi, who is Italys richest man. He had been accused of paying a $434,000 bribe to a Rome judge in 1991 to rule in his favor during the takeover battle for an Italian food conglomerate. The prosecutors had challenged the earlier acquittal and had asked for a five-year sentence.

title: Sprinting Wonder Intends to Pick Up Speed
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27  Tyson Gay was in eighth grade in Lexington, Ky., when his running career began.
