description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Palestinian Militants Killed Near Gaza Border Fence
description: JERUSALEM, April 28  The Israeli army shot four Palestinian militants near the border fence in Gaza this morning, killing three and seriously wounding one, an army spokeswoman said. The armed militants were spotted trying to plant an explosive device, she said. A spokesman for the military wing of Hamas said they were members of Hamass Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades on a jihad mission.

title: Leader of the Pride Revives What Some Call Circus Art
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan

title: Obama at Home (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Paper Trail in Wolfowitz Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  Arriving as president of the World Bank in the summer of 2005, Paul D. Wolfowitz told colleagues he was eager to tackle issues like poverty in Africa and corruption in aid to poor countries. But almost immediately he became consumed instead by frustrating negotiations with bank officials over the status of his companion, an employee at the bank, documents released this month show.

title: Barbaros Trainer Thinks of What Might Have Been
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27  The racing season at Keeneland closed under a gunmetal sky Friday. A year ago, Michael Matz prepared to make the 75-mile drive to Churchill Downs in Louisville, where he would train the great and fragile Barbaro to victory in the Kentucky Derby. This year, Matz made only consolation plans, a flight home to suburban Philadelphia. He may get no closer to the Derby on May 5 than his television.

title: With 32 More Fire Marshals, Plans to Expand Services
description: With fire deaths down across the city, the decision by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to allocate $1.4 million of the citys 2008 budget for the Fire Department to hire 32 more fire marshals might seem to come at a curious time. But fire union officials say staffing levels will still be low.

title: Ex-Hollinger Audit Panel Member Testifies
description: CHICAGO, April 27  A former audit committee member of Hollinger International began testifying Friday in the criminal trial of Conrad M. Black, the former chairman, with prosecutors portraying her as a talented economist who had been duped while the defense suggested she had failed to carry out her financial duties.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in The Arts last Saturday with an article about India Now, a film series at the Museum of Modern Art, included erroneous information from the museum about the actress shown in a scene from Dor, a film in the series. She was Gul Panag  not Ayesha Takia, one of the movies stars.

title: Mexico: 2 Arrested in Texas Drug Case
description: Law enforcement officials said they had arrested two drug dealers who disguised themselves as Mexican soldiers last year, crossed into Texas and confronted sheriffs deputies and police officers. The suspects, scar Alonso Candelaria Escajeda and Ivn Gndara Trejo, were caught Thursday in Ciudad Jurez, across the border from El Paso. The American authorities initially thought the men were soldiers, and the January 2006 incident strained relations between the countries.

title: Somali Capital Now Calm After Month in Which 1,000 Were Killed
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 27  An eerie calm slipped over Mogadishu, Somalias capital, on Friday for the first time in a month.

title: Scolded by Nascar, Stewart Backs Off Criticism
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., April 27  Three days after accusing Nascar of using bogus caution flags to create more competitive racing and likening the sport to professional wrestling, Tony Stewart emerged from a meeting with Nascar officials Friday morning and said he had it all wrong.

title: 3 Banks Press ABN to Consider Rival Bid
description: LONDON, April 27  The board of ABN Amro was dealt a double challenge on Friday, as a consortium of three European banks submitted official notification that they are preparing an unsolicited bid and, separately, an investor association said that it was taking ABN Amro to court.

title: Cutting Shrek Down to Size
description: Well leave it to the ethicists to determine whether Shrek, an animated ogre who is hugely popular with the preteen and preschool set, is too hobbled with conflicts of interest to serve as a health adviser to his fans. Shrek is appearing in public service ads urging youngsters to exercise as an antidote to the worsening childhood obesity epidemic. Yet he is also the star of a soon-to-open sequel whose image is being used to promote all sorts of candies, cookies, soft drinks, sugary cereals and other high-calorie junk foods.

title: An Ugly Month Gets Even Uglier for Rivera
description: Even on his worst days, Mariano Rivera rarely suffered the indignity of handing the baseball to Manager Joe Torre in the middle of an inning. But this has been an April of indignities for the Yankees closer, and Rivera had another such moment Friday night.

description: WASHINGTON, April 27  When the United States first asked Poland and the Czech Republic to base missile defenses on their soil, the proposed interceptors and radar were cast as a prudent hedge against Iran and a guarantee that Europes security was indivisible from that of America, which was moving ahead with defenses for its own territory.

title: Providing a Stage for Young Stutterers
description: Standing in a crowded rehearsal room at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts this week, Taro Alexander, founder of the Our Time Theater Company, clapped out a rhythm and told his troupe of performers, When I say Our Time, you say love!  Soon enough, the word love rattled the walls, followed by peace, positivity and acceptance.

title: Recalling Former Bat Boy Who Made News
description: Dave Magadan did not remember Kirk Radomski. But as soon as Magadan, the batting coach for the Boston Red Sox, learned that Radomskis nickname was Murdoch, he immediately recalled the former Mets clubhouse attendant and bat boy.

title: When Needed Most, Pettitte Cant Steady the Sliding Yankees
description: The season is too young to be slipping away from the Yankees. But it has gotten ugly quickly, with the team on its longest losing streak since 2000. The voices in the organization that grumble about Manager Joe Torre, whose contract expires after the season, will grow louder if the losses keep mounting.

title: Jailed 7 Years for Contempt, Adviser Is Headed for Prison
description: A federal judge lifted a seven-year-old civil contempt sanction on the financial adviser Martin A. Armstrong yesterday, allowing him to begin serving a five-year sentence for conspiracy to commit fraud.

title: Is Congress on the Mend?
description: THE failure of Congress to fulfill its responsibilities as the first branch of government  to engage in responsible and deliberative lawmaking, to police the ethical behavior of its members, and to check and balance the other national political institutions  contributed to the demise of the Republican majority in last Novembers midterm election. So how well is Congress performing under its new Democratic leadership?

title: G.M. Chiefs Compensation Rises Despite Cut in Salary
description: DETROIT, April 27  General Motors nearly doubled the compensation for its chief executive, Rick Wagoner, last year, even though he voluntarily reduced his salary to aid the automakers restructuring effort, G.M. disclosed Friday in its annual proxy filing.

title: Saudis Round Up 172, Citing Plot Against Oil Rigs
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 27  Saudi security officials said Friday that they had broken up a vast terrorist ring, arresting 172 men who planned to blow up oil installations, attack public officials and military posts, and storm a prison to free terrorist suspects.

title: Making the Flight, Without the Stress
description: In my vast experience with relationships, it is not money, nor sex, nor raising children that causes the bitterest disputes between couples, but how early you really need to get to the airport.

title: Mstislav Rostropovich, 80, Dissident Maestro, Dies
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist and conductor who was renowned not only as one of the great instrumentalists of the 20th century but also as an outspoken champion of artistic freedom in the Soviet Union during the last decades of the cold war, died yesterday in Moscow. He was 80 and lived in Paris, with homes also in Moscow, St. Petersburg, London and Lausanne, Switzerland.

description: The fate of 30 Rock looks dire. Alec Baldwin said on The View yesterday that he wanted to quit that NBC sitcom to write a book about parental alienation.

description: The Oakland Raiders selected quarterback JaMarcus Russell of Louisiana State with the first overall pick of the 2007 National Football League draft at Radio City Music Hall today.

description: MOSCOW, April 27  A Russian military helicopter crashed in the mountains of Chechnya on Friday, killing at least 18 service members and marking the most lethal day for Russian authorities in the volatile North Caucasus region since late 2005.

title: Fewer Penalties for Rangers but Same Result
description: BUFFALO, APRIL 27  The most hated man in the National Hockey League sported a Mohawk and a scowl before Game 2 of the Eastern Conference semifinal series between the Rangers and Sabres.

description: Economic growth slowed to its weakest pace in four years during the first three months of 2007, underscoring how the persistent slump in the housing market continued to serve as a drag on the American economy.

title: A Fatal Wound From a Colleagues Weapon Is Rare, but Always a Risk
description: The accidental shooting of David C. Brinkerhoff, the New York state trooper who was killed by a bullet from a fellow trooper confronting a suspect inside a Catskill farmhouse on Wednesday, puts Trooper Brinkerhoff in a small minority of police officers killed in the line of duty.

title: Judge Wants Common Sense Used in McGreeveys Divorce
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., April 27 (AP)  A judge handling the contentious divorce of former Gov. James E. McGreevey and his estranged wife urged them on Friday to use common sense during their split.

title: Passion for Seeing What the Body Can Do
description: Just naming the nine programs in the La MaMa Moves! festival must have been exhausting; its hard to imagine the other logistics that the co-curators, Nicky Paraiso and Mia Yoo, must have dealt with in putting together this 50-company event. The first program, New Virtuosity, on Thursday night at La MaMas Annex Theater, augured well for the rest of the festival, and wasnt an altogether inappropriate title for an evening of impassioned, first-rate dancing.

title: Rolling Homes Arent Just for the Rich
description: Recreational vehicles are not just toys for the rich, says Bruce D. Hertzke, 55, chairman and chief executive of Winnebago Industries, a big maker of R.V.s and motor homes. Blue-collar workers, who have saved for retirement and travel make up a big chunk of the companys business. Mr. Hertzke spoke recently about those customers, about feeling the pain of high gas prices and about how some people save the fancy trimmings for their R.V. instead of their house. title: Top Pick Could Be Building Block, or on Trading Block
description: This years N.F.L. draft may not have the glamour provided last year by Reggie Bush, Matt Leinart and Vince Young. But in his role as a draft linchpin, Al Davis, the Oakland Raiders owner, is milking his turn as a star for as long as possible.

title: AT&T Chief to Retire in June
description: Edward E. Whitacre Jr. announced today that he would retire as chief executive and chairman of AT&T, effective June 3.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about start-up companies pursuing the idea of advertising-supported digital music misspelled part of the name of a company that was being formed to sell such ads. It is Rebel Digital, not Rebal.

title: An Ex-C.I.A. Chief on Iraq and the Slam Dunk That Wasnt
description: Since the publication of Bob Woodwards 2004 book, Plan of Attack, George J. Tenet, former director of central intelligence, has become best known for two words: slam dunk  that is, for reportedly telling President Bush that intelligence about weapons of mass destruction in Iraq was a slam dunk case! Those words have been quoted countless times, most notably by Vice President Dick Cheney, who, during a Meet the Press appearance last year, suggested that the administration had made a choice to go to war based on the slam dunk intelligence provided by the C.I.A.  intelligence that later turned out to be wrong.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article Thursday about the formal start of Senator John McCains campaign for the Republican presidential nomination misspelled the surname of the United States attorney general, whom Mr. McCain urged to resign, in two of four references. The attorney general is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez.

title: East Coast Bollywood
description: Increasingly, Bollywood movies have the confidence to leave India behind, at least physically. "Ta Ra Rum Pum," about the rise and fall of RV, the "best, best, best racer in the world," may take place entirely in New York, but that doesn't stop it from being a classic example of Bollywood family values.

title: Transdimensional Romance
description: A transdimensional romance for the CW network crowd, "The Invisible" proves that it's tough to be in love and in limbo at the same time. A retread of the 2002 Swedish film "Den Osynlige" (based on a novel by Mats Wahl), this latest recycling of foreign-grown frights shows less interest in horror than in healing. Seems there's nothing like a near-death experience to repair those stubborn emotional wounds.

title: Coachella: 55,000 Fans and Painfully Long Lines
description: Indio, Calif., April 27The five gentlemen crammed into the Mitsubishi? Yes, they were going. The four hipsters wearing over-sized sunglasses and multiple wristbands? Definitely going. It was easy to pick out the people who are here to attend the three-day Coachella festival  it sometimes appeared as if everyone in town is. Today an estimated 55,000 fans streamed onto the lush polo fields that house the festivals stages and tents, there to see the likes of Bjork, the Jesus and Mary Chain and whatever band Perry Farrell is playing with these days.

title: Road Map to the Derby
Jazzfest: Homegrown
description: New Orleans, April 27At the Jazz and Heritage Festival, even the peanut vendor sounds like New Orleans. Pea-nutttttts! sang Hassan Abdullah, in the two-note phrasea rising third with the second note sustained and a raw break in the voicethat also announces some Mardi Gras Indian chants (Mightyyyyyyykootie fiyo) and New Orleans R&B songs.

title: Coachella: Scarlett Johansson Joins Jesus and Mary Chain
description: Indio, Calif., April 27, 8:30pm  Coachella has long operated like a music festival is supposed to: the rock stars perform on stage and the Hollywood celebrities watch from a restricted VIP area (equipped with a bar and a shaded lounge ). But that isnt always the case. As rumored, Scarlett Johansson joined a reunited Jesus and Mary Chain for a performance of Just Like Honey, which played as the credits rolled during Ms. Johanssons film Lost in Translation. And about the same time, Nine Inch Nails mastermind Trent Reznor (who co-headlined the festival with Coldplay two years ago) turned up in the VIP area with a female companion. (Of course, he is a celebrity this week: Nine Inch Nails new album, Year Zero, made its debut at No. 2 on the Billboard sales chart.) Mr. Reznor had also been spotted strolling backstage, where he traded greetings with one of the festivals other stars: Paul Tollett, the head of the concert promoter Goldenvoice, which organizes the event.

title: Proposed Tax Levies in New York School Districts
Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day Thursday about online services for photo retouching misstated the given name of a proprietor of one such service, Touch of Glamour. He is Boris Kobrin, not Bruce.

title: Comparing Six Hydrogen Vehicles
description: Writer Don Sherman compares hydrogen-fueled vehicles from Ford, Toyota, General Motors, BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Honda.

title: Coachella: Reunions, Installations and Bjork
description: Scenes from Day 1 of the 2007 Coachella music festival in California.

title: Breaking for Laughs
description: The catalytic plot point in the Jamie Kennedy comedy "Kickin' It Old Skool" also serves as a sort of metaphorical review of the movie. A young break dancer named Justin tries a particularly dazzling move at an elementary school talent show, and at first it's very entertaining to watch. But alas, the kid misses the gymnastic final back flip, smashes into the floor and ends up in a coma.

title: Secrets in the Snow
description: Of Gregory Jacobs's thriller "Wind Chill," let us first give thanks for what it isn't: a procession of teenage corpses, and, to avoid the more vulgar expression, torture-tainment. That said, let us give thanks for what it largely is: a moody, spooky tale, rendered with laudable economy.

title: 2008: White House Allies Split
description: The Chicago Tribune reports that, though President Bush has been careful not to show support for a specific Republican contender, his allies appear to have split their support between the campaigns of Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney.

title: Aprils Poli-Book Best Seller List
description: For the first time in several months, the No. 1 spot on our political best seller list no longer belongs to Senator Barack Obamas The Audacity of Hope. Its slipped down a notch, to make way for the tale of a former child soldier in Sierra Leones civil war.

title: Raiders Make Russell Top Pick at N.F.L. Draft
description: The Raiders just took JaMarcus Russell with the first pick in the draft. It looks like Al Davis wanted him all along. Eight of the last ten No. 1 overall picks have been quarterbacks.

title: Will Browns Pick Quinn?
description: The Browns pick third and they sure could use a running back. Adrian Peterson, perhaps. Brady Quinn of Notre Dame is another possibility. Quinn, who is from Ohio, has appeared all over the top 10 in mock drafts in recent weeks. Will he freefall, like Aaron Rodgers a few years ago, or will the Browns grab him here? Quinn has a high football I.Q., so it would make sense to take him here.

title: Jazzfest: Louisiana Pride and Heartbreak
description: New Orleans, April 27  The aftermath of Hurricane Katrina is still on musicians minds at Jazzfest, both locals and visitors. The longtime Cajun rocker Zachary Richard sometimes has a touch of Jackson Browne in his songwriting, and he ended his set with a song about Louisiana tenacity: Seven generations weve been stuck here in the mud/ But the only way that Im leaving Lousiana is if Im swept away in a flood, he sang, on the way to a gospelly chorus that repeated The levee broke and listed places devastated in the flood. As the song ended, he vowed, Were going to fix that damn levee.

title: Browns Fans Think Cleveland Went Fishing
description: OK, the Browns didnt take Quinn or Peterson. That means theyre there for Tampa Bay to pick. The fans here sure didnt like the Browns pick of left tackle Joe Thomas of Wisconsin, who skipped New York this weekend to go fishing with his father. Unflattering chants aimed at Cleveland swept through Radio City Music Hall after Commissioner Roger Goodell announced Thomass name. I see the concerns of the Browns fans. Cleveland now has a good left tackle but no quarterback to protect.

title: Okoye in the Cards?
description: Arizona probably would have taken Gaines Adams but now they must go to Pan B. Adams was just drafted by Tampa Bay. Peterson and Quinn are still out there, but the Cardinals have Matt Leinart and Edgerrin James. If they want to boost their defesinve line, Amobi Okoye looks like a good fit here.

title: Redskins on the Clock
description: Like the Cardinals last season, stopping the run was problematic for the Washington Redskins. Will they go for need or the best player available (and then possibly make a trade)? Amobi Okoye, Adrian Peterson and Brady Quinn are still available. What do you think theyll do?

title: Quinn and Minn Make Sense
description: The Redskins just picked LaRon Landry, safety from Louisiana State. Its a pick that makes little sense. Dont the Redskins already have Shawn Springs in their defensive backfield? Well, all that means is that Brady Quinn is still available for Minnesota at No. 7. Everyone hear at the draft is beginning to wonder, How far will Quinn fall? I say the Vikings pick Quinn. But aside from the top two picks, I havent gotten any right! Ah, the joys of covering the NFL Draft live on the Internet

title: A Near Miss
description: By the way, did anyone notice that the Redskins used nearly all of their allotted 15 minutes to pick LaRon Landry with the sixth pick? Didnt they learn anything from Minnesota a few years ago? The Redskins representatives looked like they were scrambling before submitting their pick with seconds remaining. Minnesota is up now. I wonder if theyll blow it again. Oh, wait, they just picked

title: Trade Rumors Begin to Swirl
description: Boy, did Adrian Peterson look relieved to be drafted by Minnesota at No. 7.  The Falcons wont pick Brady Quinn at No. 8, so he will probably fall into Miamis lap at No. 9. So, what will Atlanta do here? Your guess is as good as mine? They wanted LaRon Landy, who is now off the board. Maybe someone will trade to grab this pick and beat Miami to the chase. It would be the days first deal, and this place would explode with cheers and boos if one is announced.

title: Quinns Moment Is Moments Away
description: Brady Quinn!!! Brady Quinn!!! Fans will be shouting his name in a matter of minutes. The Miami Dolphins have to take him here. What a steal. Quinn was projected as a top-three pick in many mock drafts. In fact, I think I just heard some fans already begin to scream his name . Quinn has been groomed for this moment. He spent the past week making appearances on talk shows, hoping, I guess, to boost his profile (could it be any higher?). Soon he will take center stage.

title: Quinn Begins to Plummet
description: I was right! Not about the Dolphins taking Brady Quinn at No. 9. As predicted, the fans started chanting Quinns name after Miami picked Ted Ginn Jr., wide receiver, Ohio State. Only they were mocking Quinn, not cheering for him. (I just got their motivation wrong. A minor detail.) Nearly everyone expected Quinn to land in Miami. What a shocker! How far will he fall? Quinn is becoming a main story line this afternoon. I sort of felt sorry for him. Hes sitting in the green room, and the cameras were all over him after Ginns name was called. His girlfriend was at his side.

title: Quinn Now Behind Closed Doors
description: Where on earth will Brady Quinn end up? He is this years Aaron Rodgers, a quarterback who was supposed to get picked in the top 10 but plummeted. Rodgers went to the Green Bay Packers in 2005 with the 24th pick of the first round. Look at the next 11 picks: None of these teams really need a quarterback. Quinn could fall to Kansas City at No. 23. Amazing! The Buffalo Bills at 12 and the St. Louis Rams could reach for Quinn. But they have J.P. Losman and Marc Bulger, respectively.

title: Only 15 and a Half Hours Left
description: The draft is now about two and a half hours old. Only 15 and a half more hours to go! The atmosphere here is much more relaxed. During the first 10 picks, the tension in the air was palpable. But things settled down ever since the 10th pick. Former Buffalo Bills star Bruce Smith, not Commissioner Roger Goodell, announced the 11th pick (linebacker Patrick Willis to the 49ers). The fans have settled into their seats, and the beer lines are even vacant (err, beer is off limits at this event). Goodell is now circulating around Radio City Music Hall, chatting with reporters.

title: Jets Are Making Major Moves
description: The Jets just made a huge trade.

title: J-E-T-S Get R-E-V-I-S
description: A trade during the N.F.L. Draft always gets the fans attention. A trade involving the Jets? Well, lets just say the fans here went bananas when it was announced that the Jets had acquired the 14th overall pick from Carolina. About 10 minutes later, Commissioner Roger Goodell announced the Jets had selected Darrelle Revis, a cornerback from Pittsburgh. The fans really got into it then, cheering and pumping their fists. I bet Coach Eric Mangini and GM Mike Tannenbaum were doing the same  behind closed doors, of course.

title: Broncos Deal to Get Jarvis Moss
description: Another trade! The Jaguars give up their first-rounder (17th over all) to Denver in exchange for the Broncos first-rounder (21st), third-rounder (86th) and sixth-rounder (198th). What a steep price to move up four spots in the first round. And with the 17th overall pick in the N.F.L. Draft, the Denver Broncos select  Jarvis Moss, defensive end, Florida).

title: Hall the Way to No. 18
description: The Bengals got Leon Hall, cornerback, Michigan, with the 18th pick. This is one of the best values in the draft so far. This is a player many so-called experts figured would be gone by the 10th pick.  By the way, whatever happened to that quarterback from Notre Dame, Brady whats-his-name? Quinn is now the forgotten man in the draft. Once Miami passed on him at No. 9, we all knew it would be a long wait for Quinn. But everyone was buzzing about him until about the 14th or 15th pick. Now no one is mentioning his name. Look for Kansas City to grab him at 23. Of course, Ill probably be wrong about that, too. I was hyping Quinn at No. 3. Im now wearing a hat, sunglasses and a fake mustache.

title: Posluszny a Possibility
description: 6:45 to go before the Giants pick. I say they take Paul Posluszny, a linebacker, from Penn State. Please, oh, please, let me finally be right.

title: Giants Get Their Man
description: Did I write Posluszny? I meant Aaron Ross from Texas. Honestly, it was just a type-o. My fingers just sort of slid over those keys and accidentally typed Posluszny.  The pick makes sense on some levels. Ross is a cornerback, and the Giants need a cornerback. But I think they need a linebacker more. Look for them to pick a linebacker with their second-rounder.

title: 22 Picks Later, Quinn Off the Board
description: FINALLY  The Cleveland Browns just made a trade with the Dallas Cowboys for the 22nd pick, which they used on Brady Quinn. The fans here cheered when Quinns name was announced, and Quinn bolted out of the green room in record time. He looked so relieved, and he kept pointing to the sky and exhaling as he walked on stage. Quinn is still on stage now, with family members and friends. He is carrying a Browns jersey with 1 on the front. The pick makes sense for Cleveland but it came at a premium. In return, Dallas gets the Browns second-rounder this season (36th over all) and their first-rounder in 2008.

title: Tight End for Panthers?
description: The Giants and Jets have picked, and Brady Quinn is off the board. Things have definitely quieted down here at Radio City. The Panthers are up at No. 25. This is where the Jets would have picked had they not traded up to get Darrelle Revis, a cornerback, with the 14th overall pick. So lets take a look at which cornerbacks are available now. Daymeion Hughes of California, Tanard Jackson of Syracuse and Marcus McCauley are still around, but none of them are considered first-rounders.

title: Torre on the Hot Seat
description: Jeff Karstens threw one pitch today and got drilled on the right leg with a line drive. He fell to the ground immediately, gamely stayed in for one more hitter, and then had to leave. It has been that kind of season for the Yankees.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 29
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is set for a busy Sunday. Shell be on ABCs This Week with George Stephanopoulos, CBSs Face the Nation, and CNNs Late Edition with Wolf Blitzer.

title: A Song Says 1,000 Words
description: I dont know who picks the music they play in between each pick. While the talking heads on television are analyzing picks, they play music with themes here at Radio City. It was Frank Sinatras New York, New York when the Giants were on the clock. They played Elton Johns Philadelphia Freedom until the Eagles just traded the 26th pick in the first round to the Dallas Cowboys. I cant identify what theyre playing now, but it sounds a lot like the Red Hot Chili Peppers. Are they from Dallas? The Cowboys had dealt their 22nd pick to Cleveland, which used it on Brady Quinn. Speaking of Quinn, I wonder how Charlie Frye must be feeling right now. His theme song today could be Billy Joels Movin Out.

title: 2008: California, Here They Come
description: SAN DIEGO  Heres an early report, from where the Democratic presidential candidates are speaking this weekend at the famously rowdy  and always entertaining  California Democratic Party convention.

title: Coachella: A Slightly Dizzying Feeling
description: Indio, Calif., April 28  The polo field at Coachella is vast, so you never have a sense of how crowded it is. Your purchase on scale disappears. (As it does in Palm Springs. Didnt I pass that enormous drive-through Del Taco three minutes ago? No, that is another enormous drive-through Del Taco, similarly placed on a similar block.)

title: Dirty 30 Gets Makeover
description: I just got back from interviewing Tom Brady, Joe Montana, Dan Marino, Peyton Manning and Jeremiah Trotter. Well, I didnt exactly speak to them. But I did speak to guys wearing their jerseys. The second balcony at Radio City is teeming with fans from every team. It sort of feels like the United Nations (even though I have never actually been inside the U.N.). The second balcony is where the diehards sit, and I quickly gravitated to the Philadelphia Eagles fans. I expected them to be rowdy, like they were a few years ago when the Eagles picked Donovan McNabb over Ricky Williams. The fans in that draft were known as the Dirty 30.

title: McCain on Reids Lost War
description: ELKO, Nev.  Sometimes, this week, as Senator John McCain traveled the nation on the official rollout of his presidential campaign, it was almost as if he were campaigning against Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader.

title: So Far, The Longest Draft Ever
description: The first round just ended  six hours and eight minutes after Roger Goodell declared the draft open for business. I keep looking up at the ESPN stage, where Keyshawn Johnson and Chris Berman, et al, are seated. Man, those guys look tired. It was the longest first round in the history of N.F.L. drafts. For some reason the fans cheered when Goodell announced this. Goodell said this was not a record he hoped to break. At this rate, we will all get home early Sunday morning.

title: Saturday Evening Manager
description: Down here in Washington, life with the Mets is slightly more placid than it is in Tylers neck of the woods. The only hot seat for Willie Randolph is the heated seats in his rental car. But it doesnt necessarily mean that Randolph is immune to second-guessing. He made a few decisions in Fridays game that I suppose could be argued both ways.

title: Bears (No, Chargers) on the Clock
description: More bad news for Philly fans. The Eagles just picked Kevin Kolb, a quarterback from Houston. The pick makes sense only if Donovan NcNabb goes down (and he is injury-prone). But if McNabb stays healthy, Kolb does not get any playing time, remaining inexperienced. The Eagles fans were practically expressionless when the pick was announced.

title: Picker Picks Correct Pick!
description: Well, I finally got a pick right. I suggested that the Chargers would take a safety with the fifth pick in the second round, and they did! Eric Weddle of Houston. Too bad I didnt mention Weddles name. Truth be told, I dont know much about the guy. But he should be able to help the Chargers since they really need help at this position. That makes three correct picks (JaMarcus Russell and Calvin Johnson being the others).

title: Harris and Ugoh Still Around
description: So, who are the best players available? In my opinion, its David Harris (linebacker, Michigan) and Tony Ugoh (offensive tackle, Arkansas). Both players trained together in Paramus, N.J., before the Combine. Teams looking for a value pick should draft one of these guys. I thought Ugoh should have been picked at the end of the first round.

title: Ugoh Was Right For Indy
description: Tony Ugoh was just taken by the Colts, who traded their first-rounder in 2008 to Minnesota to move up. Thats a hefty price but Ugoh was a steak at that position (10th in the second round). I just spoke with Alan Herman, Ugohs agent. Herman text-messaged Ugoh about 15 minutes ago, telling him to hang in there. I saw his reply: Im not disappointed. Herman noted that the difference between being selected in the second round instead of the first was a four-year deal instead of a five-year deal. But that means Ugoh, if he is really that good, can become a free agent and strike a long-term deal after four years (instead of five).

title: Jets Move Up, and Harris is Happy
description: The Jets just traded up to get David Harris, an inside linebacker from Michigan. Its a great value (and its the second time they made a trade). There had been rumors that the Jets might trade Jonathan Vilma, who seemed constrained by Eric Manginis 3-4 defense last season. Its more likely Harris will play alongside Vilma next season, beefing up the interior defense.

title: Giants On The Clock
description: The Giants are on the clock. They need a linebacker most but the fans here are chanting for Brian Leonard, a fullback/halfback from Rutgers. With Tiki Barber gone, Leonard, who is from Gouverneur, N.Y., might make sense. What do you think?

title: A Deal That Stands Out
description: A noteworthy trade was just made. The Raiders sent their fourth-round pick to Detroit for wide receiver Mike Williams and quarterback Josh McCown. This is significant for two reasons. The acquisition of Williams sets the stage for a potential trade of Randy Moss. The Packers and Patriots are possible destinations for Moss. Also, McNown will now be the starter on opening day for the Raiders if they think JaMarcus Russell is not ready.

title: Win-a-Trip Winners
description: So we finally have the winners of my second annual Win-a-Trip contest.

title: Dodd Criticizes Thursdays Debate
description: SAN DIEGO  Count at least one of the Democratic presidential candidates a critic of the way the first candidate debate was conducted.

title: Irans Proposal for a Grand Bargain
description: In Sundays column I lay out the attempts to reach a grand bargain between the U.S. and Iran, before Bush administration hard-liners killed the effort in 2003. Here Im providing more background and the full documents.

title: Well take Smith and a side of coleslaw
description: Its time for another update on the scene at Radio City. If youre watching ESPN, it looks like theres tons of life here. Actually a lot of the fans have left. Only the diehards are still here, and even some of them have begun to sleep in their seats. Commissioner Roger Goodell is no longer in sight (I bet you he went to Carnegie Deli for a corned beef sandwich). The concession stands are closing up. But we still have about 90 minutes to go, and anything could happen in that time.

title: Bazuin to Bears?
description: There have not been many shockers in the draft so far. Sure, Ted Ginn Jr. seemed like a reach by the Dolphins with the ninth overall pick. And who could have predicted Brady Quinns freefall to the 22nd pick? But by this stage in the draft  late second round, early third round  its very tough to predict picks. Heck, it was tough to get things exactly right in the first round. But here is a name to look out for in the third round: Daniel Bazuin, a defensive end from Central Michigan. Bazuin is 6-foot-3 and 266 pounds, and he ran the 40-yard dash in 4.81 seconds. I bet the Bears could even pick him at the end of round two.

title: Bazuin to Bears!
description: The Bears did take Bazuin. I heard it just now from his agent. The pick has not been announced but it will be soon.

title: One Right, So Heres Another
description: I finally nailed a pick (the Bears taking Dan Bazuin from Central Michigan with the 62nd selection)! I would be celebrating if I had Champagne on me. I watched Bazuin train for the N.F.L. Scouting Combine a few months ago, so I had a good feeling he would be picked on the first day. Bazuin told me in February that he thought he could go on the first day. At the time, he was slated as a late fifth- or sixth-round pick. It just goes to show you what a good performance at the N.F.L. Combine (and some confidence) can do for a players stock.

title: Coachella: Capturing the Buzz
description: Indio, Calif., April 28Some music fans revel in the concept of losing themselves in an isolated oasis, a hundred miles from anywhere, where the only thing to do is rock and relax. Others, however, suffer a sort of separation anxiety this far from home. I just need to check some soccer scores, said 18-year-old Oliver Record, a fan from San Francisco, as he waited on line in the 100-degree heat to enter a cooling tent. The tent, sponsored by AT&Ts music webcast unit, also allows fans to log onto computers and recharge their mobile phones. Inside, it resembled a darkened office, with more than a dozen fans busily tapping away on Internet-connected laptops.

title: E=MCompensatory2
description: The first two rounds took 9 hours and 20 minutes. Thats insanely long! I could have watched Gone With the Wind three times since the Raiders first pick in round one. In the third round, each team gets five minutes to make a pick. But the third round this year is longer than you might think. Four teams  San Diego, San Francisco, Indianapolis and Oakland  have compensatory picks at the end of the round. Whats a compensatory pick? I had to double-check myself. When a team loses a free agent, the league awards that team a compensatory pick, based on that players value, as determined by the league. Confused? Youre not alone. Lets say the Colts lose Edgerrin James to free agency. The league might award Indianapolis an extra third-round pick. Thats exactly what happened this season. If a player has little value, in the leagues eyes, a seventh-round pick (or maybe none at all) might be awarded.

title: Jazzfest: Whats That Funky Smell?
description: New Orleans, April 28I have a new favorite New Orleans funk band: Ivan NevillesDumpstaphunk. After Jazzfest on Friday night, I took in a full-length Dumpstaphunk club set at the Howlin Wolf in New Orleans Warehouse district.

title: Telefnica Gets Controlling Stake in Telecom Italia
description: MADRID, April 29  Telefnica of Spain and a group of Italian investors agreed on Saturday to pay 4.1 billion euros ($5.6 billion) for a controlling stake in Telecom Italia. The deal will allow Telefnica to expand into the Italian market and extend its presence in Latin America.

title: Drifter
description: When Mary Morris gets on a riverboat in La Crosse, Wis., with two strangers and a rat terrier, she sets out on a journey that has always called to her. Her 102-year-old father, who grew up in towns along the Mississippi, has just died; her only daughter is off to college; and Morris is left dealing with her grief and anxiety, and trying to understand why she has always fled her past.

title: Taliban Insurgents Release Hostage After 3 Weeks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 28  Taliban insurgents released a French woman aid worker in southern Afghanistan today, one of a group of five people taken hostage three weeks ago and threatened with death by the Taliban.

title: Letters
description: The Power of Green

title: Unfamiliar Names on Familiar Streets (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Places to Eat and Get Off Your Feet
description: LACROSSE and baseball share their opening seasons with another popular sport and pastime: spring shopping. Straw hats and strappy sandals mark new beginnings, and White Plains, with its major department stores, is Westchesters material mecca. A serious shopper can burn a lot of calories walking the length of The Westchester, pulling clothes on and off in tight dressing rooms, parading around the shoe department in one pair of cute flats after another. So shoppers need nourishment, and the self-contained universes of Bloomingdales, Nordstrom and Neiman Marcus can provide it.

title: Ill Make You Broadway Stars, He Says, and They Just Bark
description: WILLIAM BERLONI, Broadways esteemed animal trainer, is about to leave his mark on yet another show. Legally Blonde: The Musical, which opens tonight at the Palace Theater, features a 47-pound spotted English bulldog as Rufus and a six-pound blond Chihuahua as Bruiser, both trained by Mr. Berloni.

title: Mimi van Wyck, Ham Morrison
description: Mary Lynn van Wyck, the daughter of Mary Lynn and Bronson van Wyck of Tuckerman, Ark., was married last evening to Ray Hamilton Morrison III, the son of Kiwi Hilliard of Oyster Bay, N.Y., and Mr. Morrison Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla. The Right Rev. Marc Andrus, the bishop of the Episcopal diocese of California, officiated at Fenwick Hall Plantation on Johns Island, S.C.

title: 36 Hours in Key West, Fla.
description: IT'S tough to slap an itinerary on Key West. The whole point of this two-by-four-mile island, after all, is to kick off your shoes and let it all hang out. But here's the rub: do Key West wrong and you might not relax. Witness lower Duval Street, that cacophony of sound, sunburn and daiquiris. (Hemingway used to drink there, but he might think twice today.) So where is the strange, laid-back island that everyone fell in love with? It's still there, if you know where to look. It's found biking through Old Town at dusk, when the porches light up and jasmine fills the air. Or kayaking across the quiet, teal-blue ocean, or catching an old-timer's tale, drifting across a lonely bar. Done right, Key West is still a place where time stands still.

title: A Congressmans Rise, Twice-Told Tales and a Fabled Gateway
description: CHARLES RANGEL is the man who brought you Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. No, no, no! she protested each time he urged her to run. But in the end, she recalled, like so many women before me, I just couldnt say no.

title: Miniature Works as the Main Attraction
description: The delicate touch and dense composition of the more than 130 works in the Sixth International Miniature Print Biennial at the Center for Contemporary Printmaking in Norwalk make for a smart, stylish exhibition.

title: Allison Hays and Farooq Sheikh
description: Dr. Allison Gamboa Hays and Dr. Farooq Hameed Sheikh are to be married today at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Kim Kirkley, an interfaith minister, is to officiate.

title: Under African Skies
description: Its no wonder Karen Blixen fell madly in love with Denys Finch Hatton in 1918. He was arrestingly handsome, intelligent, athletic and courageous. He was a war hero, a pilot and a lover of opera. The younger son of the 13th Earl of Winchilsea (who was also the Eighth Earl of Nottingham), he was equally at ease in the African bush and on the country estate. Immortalized in Out of Africa (written under Blixens pen name, Isak Dinesen), he was her artistic muse, but before that he was her escape from the drudgery of a loveless marriage, a failing Kenyan farm and a debilitating bout of syphilis, thanks to her husband, a feckless baron. Who wouldnt want a swashbuckling lion slayer stopping in between safaris to recite poems and embrace her under the mosquito netting?

title: Still Waiting for Answers
description: Surely no one beyond a handful of the most self-deluded Republicans in Congress was surprised at the disclosure by George Tenet, the former intelligence director, that there was never a serious debate in the Bush administration about whether Iraq actually posed a threat to the United States.

title: Martha Reiss, Edward Acworth
description: Martha Rosemary Reiss and Edward Buxton Acworth were married yesterday in New Orleans. The Rev. Julie D. Thompson, a Presbyterian minister and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Maison Dupuy Hotel.

title: Bluefish Hoping to Draw More Fans This Season
description: BRIDGEPORT

title: The Post-Money Era
description: Money is the great corrupter of American politics, turning candidates into the puppets of soulless corporations and selfish millionaires  unless, of course, you happen to be on the side that has more of it. Which is why Democrats who have long railed against the venality of their better-financed opponents now find themselves trumpeting their own superiority in presidential fund-raising. There are probably several reasons why Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama each managed to raise more than $25 million during the first quarter of 2007, easily surpassing their Republican rivals: outrage over the war in Iraq, the new primacy of the Internet (Obama hauled in 50,000 donations online) and a shift at the highest brackets. (According to a new Pew poll, there are now about as many affluent Democrats as there are Republicans.) Whatever the reasons, though, it seems likely that the nominees of both parties will ultimately decide to spurn federal matching funds in the general election, leaving them free to raise as much as they want  and effectively destroying the last vestiges of the system that has governed campaigns for the last 30 years. To put it another way, that distant rumble youre hearing is the sound of the dam that once held back a torrent of campaign cash, tumbling down onto itself.

Who Put the Cold in Cold War?
description: Back in the mid-1970s, Natan Sharansky and his fellow Soviet dissidents bitterly amused themselves by conducting mock trials of Henry Kissinger, the architect of the dtente policy that left them feeling abandoned. Sharansky, as judge, would sentence Kissinger to exile in the Soviet Union without benefit of the Jackson amendment, which pressured the Soviets to permit Jews to emigrate. One can scarcely imagine the punishment he would have meted out to George Kennan (1904-2005), the diplomat-scholar who laid the foundations for the cold war policy Kissinger later executed, and who, we learn from John Lukacss elegant and elegiac biography, sharply opposed the American insistence that the Soviet Union facilitate emigration of its citizens in accord with some American preferences. Sharansky would not have been surprised to learn that Kennan also felt fairly at home in Berlin in the years before Americas entry into World War II, and regretted our involvement in the war (though he later wrote that the Holocaust was sufficient reason to fight Germany).

In his inimitable way, Churchill recalled that in those days he felt as though he were walking with Destiny, and that all my past life had been but a preparation for this hour and for this trial. title: Up Front
description: In her cover review of Hermione Lees biography of Edith Wharton, Claire Messud draws our attention to Whartons beloved chateau in the South of France, a region that also has a fond personal connection for Messud. Born in the United States to a Canadian mother and a French father, she spent her childhood in Canada and Australia but made many holiday visits to her paternal grandparents, who lived outside Toulon. By that time, Whartons mansion in nearby Hyres had been turned into a restaurant and, as Messud recalled in an e-mail message, she has wonderful memories of running in those gardens while my parents and grandparents finished their interminable lunches on the terrace. In her teens, Messud read Whartons novels with great avidity and cites both Wharton and Henry James as influences on her own fiction  which wont surprise readers of her much-praised recent comedy of manners, The Emperors Children. There was, Messud added, great romance in her familys visits to Paris, and when she read Wharton she conflated the Paris of my childhood and the Paris that appears in her fiction. Only the better part of a century and a considerable difference in fortune separated them, after all!

title: The Confessor
description: At this late hour of his life, Charlie Hess said the question Why? didnt matter anymore. After all the years he spent in the F.B.I. tilting at the criminal mind, all his years in private practice running lie-detector tests, his time extracting secrets as a C.I.A. agent in Vietnam, he was no longer interested in Why? What counted were simple, incontestable facts: who, when, where, what. Names, dates, locations; cause and manner of death  these were his goals as he tried to flesh out the transgressions of a man who, by his own account, killed 48 people. Robert, can you remember what year that was? Was the body north or south of the highway? Where did you get the ice pick? Why? was bottomless and slippery and often fraught with useless moral overtones. Why? didnt close cases. Why? was for intellectuals, and Charlie Hess had seen enough of them to say there were two kinds of people: intellectuals and those who got things done.

title: Inside the List
description: QUOTATION MARKS:  A few weeks ago in this space, to help correct a blind spot in the new Yale Book of Quotations, readers were asked to send in favorite quotations from the works of young writers  young being defined here as those born after 1950. The response was fairly large: more than 400 people e-mailed us or posted lines on our Web site. But the response was also a little ... scattered. Many of the quotes werent from writers at all, or were from quite old (or quite dead) ones. So the plan to print a page of them is out the window. But this doesnt mean we cant draw a few conclusions from the submissions. One of them is: Dave Eggers, Zadie Smith, David Foster Wallace and Jonathan Safran Foer have close readers. Their books easily drew the most submissions. Another is this: Foer may be the whiz-kid Rod McKuen of his age. People are clearly taken with his warmhearted observations on life and love. The submissions from his work included these, all from Everything Is Illuminated: a) From space, astronauts can see people making love as a tiny speck of light, b) Live so that you can always tell the truth and c) This is love ... isnt it? When you notice someones absence and hate that absence more than anything? More even, than you love his presence?

title: Comings and Goings
description: Smile at a stranger in Russia and he might think youre an idiot. Gesture O.K. to someone in France, and it might come across as an insult. Shake a womans hand in India and risk a comeuppance. These are some of the lessons one can glean from the Culture Smart! book series, which explores local customs and etiquette and is now available in the United States. The compact editions, published in England since 2003, cost $9.95 in stores and cover dining, business rituals and etiquette, gift-giving and general local culture. There are 49 titles, including Argentina, Vietnam, China and Japan. In June, editions on Austria, Chile, Guatemala and Indonesia will hit the stores (www.culturesmartguides.com or www.randomhouse.com). ... Moms celebrating Mothers Day in New York are the focus of a package offered by the Paramount Hotel (www.nycparamount.com) and Exhale Spa. The one-night package, which costs $513, includes a deluxe room for two, 30-minute fusion massage, facial, lavender paraffin manicure, Exhale products and a four-course meal in the Mezzanine Restaurant (only on Mothers Day, May 13, from noon to 10 p.m.). The experience is available by phone reservation only at (212) 764-5500.... Hertz customers may now rent a 2008 Ford Shelby GT-H Mustang convertible (below) at some airports. The vehicle, part of the companys Fun Collection, has a starting rate of about $140 a day. Other cars in the collection include Mazda Miatas, Jeep Wranglers and H3 Hummers (www.hertz.com).... Participating hotels and resorts, including the Majestic in Barcelona and the Derek in Houston, will donate 10 percent of the proceeds of a designated room or suite toward a specific charity. Some properties, like Peter Island Resort in the British Virgin Islands, are offering an entire villa. For more information, visit www.phggiftts.com.

title: Gertrude of Arabia
description: The British occupation of Iraq may have seemed like ancient history to the Americans who arrived in Baghdad in 2003. The Iraqis soon showed them otherwise. There were British cemeteries, British-built schools, hospitals, railroads and clubs; I once stumbled on a battered old billiard table donated in the 1920s by King George V. Above all, there was the painfully familiar record of the British struggle to build a nation. And at its center was a stiff-backed officer whom even today the Iraqis call, as if she had been a revered schoolmistress, Miss Bell.

title: Love in a Time of Dystopia
description: It must be human nature to want to imagine hell, and to want to describe it to those with less vivid imaginations. From van Eyck to Dante, from Jonathan Edwards to Jean-Paul Sartre, artists have been only too happy to tell us exactly how hot the flames will be, and how exquisite our tortures. But its mostly in the past century that a new circle of hell has emerged, in narratives ranging from Mad Max to The Twilight Zone to Cormac McCarthys novel The Road  and, now, The Pesthouse. This updated descent into the inferno involves a road trip through the ruined wasteland the earth has become. Hell is other people, all right, but in these parched, futuristic landscapes, the devils are more likely Hells Angels than Sartres French neurotics. The whole planet is a toxic dump site, and people have reverted to behaviors so basic that the writer can skip the cultural details and take us straight to the heart of what it means to be human.

title: Notes From an Ex-Senator
description: Whatever happened to Bill Bradley? During his two decades in the Senate, this former Rhodes scholar and star forward for the New York Knicks accumulated an impressive record of accomplishment, particularly on economic issues. Intelligent, collegial and taller than Abe Lincoln, Bradley seemed just about the best the Democrats had to offer. But when he finally sought the presidential nomination, he displayed poor timing. The year, 2000, was inopportune  his main rival was a sitting vice president with near identical views  and Bradley lost. After Al Gore locked up the nomination, Bradley kept an indecorously long silence before endorsing him, and about a month before the general election he came out with a book, The Journey From Here, that was sprinkled with thinly veiled criticisms of his partys standard-bearer. Quite apart from the sour grapes, the book seemed strangely narcissistic. Mere weeks before Election Day, what need had voters for policy pronouncements from a candidate no longer in the race?

title: Land Preservation to Cost $3 Billion, Report Says

They decided to pay $17.75 million each for 296 acres of pine barrens at the headwaters of the Peconic River. And the state is negotiating to acquire 100 acres in the same area.

But Bjork being Bjork, Volta is no hip-hop album.

title: A District Attorney Who Warns but Also Strikes

title: Cellphone Aside, Step Up for Soup
description: Brian Moscetti, the owner of the Soup Shoppe in Basking Ridge, is an easygoing guy. But even he has rules, or at least one rule, when it comes to ordering soup: no cellphones (or no soup for you!).

title: Family Secrets
description: Early in Mark Sloukas novel The Visible World, the protagonist, a child of Czech refugees from World War II, speaks of an entire universe and its times, its stained-glass windows and its vaulted ceilings he used to sense beneath the world I had known  so very familiar to me, so very American. In this thoughtful and evocative if sometimes sentimental novel, Slouka  himself the son of Czech immigrants  explores a problem surely familiar to us all, but perhaps especially acute for children of transplanted parents. How do you come to understand a history that has shaped you, but that you have not experienced? How do you fathom a world from which in a sense you come, but which you do not know? How do you penetrate the personalities and pasts of your parents if you have grown up far from the sites of their memories?

title: Literary Misblurbing

Eventually, he found it in a preview item he had written a few months earlier, which included the sentence Frazier works on an epic scale, but his genius is in the details. title: The Cure for Rich Candidates

title: Turning to Churches or Scripture to Cope With Debt
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Doug Sweeney, a police officer, watched his credit card balance grow to $13,000, thinking he would never be able to pay it off. Rene Santiago had $40,000 in student loans. Susan Hancock owed $14,000 in credit card debt and could not point to anything in her home to show for it.

title: Portrait of a Lady
description: In her short story "The Fullness of Life," Edith Wharton wrote that a woman's life is like "a great house full of rooms," most of which remain unseen: "and in the innermost room, the holy of holies, the soul sits alone and waits for a footstep that never comes." In spite of the many books written about Wharton and her work  including R. W. B. Lewis's Pulitzer Prize-winning 1975 biography  it is Hermione Lee's determination to provide an unprecedented tour of all the rooms in Edith Wharton's mansion. The text is unquestionably authoritative, impressively  indeed, almost alarmingly  exhaustive (it includes lists of Wharton's neighbors, of fellow hotel guests, of the ads surrounding her published stories, of the wines in her cellars); and it seeks, with meticulous care, to approach the soul in her innermost sanctum.

title: Change Agent
description: The flight was to last a day, a night and another day, whereupon I would reach Australias southwest shore. Were I a resident of the Antarctic peninsula, this would make for a sensible vacation spot. I am not, but my girlfriend has relatives who retired in the vicinity, and they were paying for the trip. If somebody offers to pay, Ill go pretty much anywhere  Guantnamo, Los Angeles, Hell. Being a cheapskate isnt all fun and games.

title: Rescue Me
description: You can tell Barbara Gowdys new novel is a literary thriller because it doesnt feature a cop, a private investigator, a young lawyer, a bounty hunter, a medical student or an infectious-disease specialist caught up in a hunt for a serial killer, a missing dame, an escaped con or vial of germs. And its still exciting.

title: Document Dispute at Center of Wolfowitz Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  Arriving as president of the World Bank in the summer of 2005, Paul D. Wolfowitz told colleagues that he was eager to tackle poverty in Africa and corruption in aid. But almost immediately he became consumed by frustrating negotiations with bank officials over the status of his companion, an employee at the bank, documents released this month show.

Her dozen or so companions in the dank room lifted their arms, palms upward, eyes closed in meditation.

title: Whats 2 by 3, Plastic and Offers a Concierge Service?
description: WHEN Gabriel Levy couldnt remember the best route from Marin County to the San Francisco 49ers stadium last December, he didnt ask a pedestrian, pull out a map or reach for a gadget with G.P.S. technology. He just dialed the phone number for the concierge service offered with his credit card, and the woman who answered steered him in the right direction.

Loretta and James Vertucci, the owners, have a Shelf of Fame where teacups used by visiting celebrities like Yoko Ono have been retired and displayed; there is also a collection of teapots for sale.

But until recently, getting around within Latin America  even in popular countries like Mexico  was a hassle often involving multiple plane changes or long bus rides over rough roads.

title: Dear Virtuoso, I Wrote This One Just for You
description: PEOPLE who pay the least attention to classical music probably know Mozarts clarinet concerto and quintet, two indelibly beautiful works. But how many remember the name Anton Stadler? He was Mozarts fellow Freemason in Vienna, a clarinetist for whom the works were written. The history of music is littered with Stadlers, great virtuosos whose artistry inspired the repertory we live with today. An outstanding example of such an artist, Mstislav Rostropovich, died last week.

title: Desperado Housewife
description: For me, getting married has always been like throwing up. Ive done it as alone as possible, feeling sick, drastic and doomed. My first one was before a justice of the peace in Philadelphia. I was 19 years old, marrying a 35-year-old Frenchman. I wore my work apron from Kelly & Cohens diner. We did it between shifts. We did it for our twin, tremulous hearts that somehow reached through age, country and political differences to touch each other. We moved to Paris. He was a composer and a real live Communist. I felt that because I loved him so much, and knew myself so little, I would have to make myself his enemy, his opposite, or else be swallowed whole. For the next two years, my obsession with him grew, and so did my need to see myself as separate from him, until finally all there was to do was leave.

title: Menudo Hopefuls Strut, Preen and Even Try to Sing
description: In the universe of boy bands of the 1980s, Puerto Ricos Menudo was particularly ruthless.

title: Steak Frites: Seeking the Best of a Classic
description: STEAK frites is enough of a Paris institution that Le Relais de Venise  an institution in itself  serves nothing else. You go, are handed a menu with almost no choices on it, and are asked whether you want your steak cooked rare or some other, presumably perverse, level of doneness. (They're good about asking and they even tolerate well-done requests without scoffing, a sure sign they're accustomed to serving Americans.)

title: Bosnians in America: A Two-Sided Saga
description: CHICAGO  Like many Bosnian refugees, Mirza Mahic had a harsh adjustment to the United States. Back home in Tuzla, his parents were engineers who owned a weekend house and vacationed on the Adriatic Sea. In Chicago, where they were resettled in 1995, the family of four suddenly found itself on public assistance, in a cramped one-bedroom apartment infested with mice. Young Mirza, then 12, cried every day and begged to quit school.

As they shuffled into an auditorium at St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan on West 12th Street, returning members had to meet no fewer than 11 new members, appointed by Borough President Scott Stringer in one of the largest reshufflings of a boroughs community boards in recent memory.

It is on a strip where the 99 Gallery backs up to the Everything 79 shop, which is down the street from a used furniture store where tired men sit all day on faded couches.

title: Missing Person
description: Westerners who write novels about the third world have a difficult job these days. For one thing, they have to compete with third-world novelists writing authoritatively about their own countries. It is far harder to affect the jaded knowingness of Graham Greene when you're worried that Zakes Mda will let everyone know you're talking nonsense. At the same time, Western writers must still navigate the same old obstacles: the third world is full of things that have no common Western names, and an author can easily spend so much time explaining unfamiliar phenomena that the novel degenerates into a "Lonely Planet" guide with fake people in it.

title: The Couple Who Travel Together ...

With this in mind, many brides and bridegrooms are registering for gifts they can take on vacation. Some even register for the vacation itself. (It is not unusual for groups of friends to chip in on expensive presents.) So if you are stuck for what to give the couple who have nearly everything and also happen to be travel enthusiasts, there are plenty of items to buy that will provide hours of pleasure away from home.

Before there was a Woodward and Bernstein, there was Halberstam, still not yet 30 in the early 1960s, calling those in power to account for lying about our progress in Vietnam. He did so even though J.F.K. told the publisher of The Times, I wish like hell that youd get Halberstam out of there. He did so despite public ridicule from the dean of that eras Georgetown punditocracy, the now forgotten columnist (and Vietnam War cheerleader) Joseph Alsop.

Dinah Lenney is paying respects in a Hackensack, N.J., funeral home to her father, Nelson Gross, who was an unsuccessful candidate for the United States Senate in 1970, an assistant secretary of state under Richard Nixon and, more recently, a millionaire developer and restaurateur. Gross had been kidnapped and robbed by three teenagers, who later stoned, beat and stabbed him near the Hudson River. His body lay there for a week, Lenneys stepmother, Noel, an equestrian and Guggenheim heiress, tells her on the day of the funeral, adding, The animals got to him.

title: 21st-Century Religious Travel: Leave the Sackcloth at Home
description: ITS not often you meet a god. But on a pouring day last summer in Dharamsala, home to the Tibetan exile community in India, I did. In a monastery outside town, I was shown into a vast, bare room. At the front sat the 17th Karmapa Lama, third-ranking leader in Tibetan Buddhism  a figure considered almost a god by many Tibetans. The Karmapa fled Tibet when he was a boy, but in exile he had become a man, in his early 20s, with a broad, shaved head and meaty arms beneath his flowing monks robes.

title: Islamic Democrats?
description: At 2 in the morning, a few days after I arrived in Cairo last month, a text message beeped into my cellphone: Mahmoud Ghozlan, MB Guide Bureau, is being arrested NOW. Ghozlan was only the latest prominent member of the Muslim Brotherhood, an Islamist organization that commands deep loyalty in Egypt, to be hauled off by the dawn visitors of President Hosni Mubaraks security apparatus. In recent months, leaders of the organization, businessmen thought to be financial backers and other members of the brotherhoods Guidance Bureau have been arrested on a variety of charges. Forty members of the group have been indicted under Egypts emergency laws and put under the jurisdiction of a military tribunal, which is likely to give them long jail sentences.

title: Correction: Have Spatula Will Travel

Lowell Harriss at Columbia, and finance under Jan Ginter Deutsch and Henry Wallich at Yale, we were taught that the stockholder was the ultimate owner of a public company, the ultimate boss, the ultimate trustor to whom the highest standards of fiduciary duty were owed.

(Which brings to mind a reputed P. T. Barnum line. But never mind.) Excerpts follow. TOM KUNTZ

title: Phil Spectors Greatest Hair
