title: So, Do I Make the Cut?
description: BOGIE, a 12-pound Shih Tzu, is an experienced navigator of the many hoops that humans and pets must jump through for acceptance into Manhattan apartment buildings.

title: Everybodys a Liberal
description: Since the 1960s, political debate in the United States has been dominated by ideologies of the right: fusionist conservatism, libertarianism, the religious right, neoconservatism. Center-left political thought, when it has not simply rationalized the demands of Democratic Party constituencies, has tended to be academic and remote from politics. In recent years, however, center-left intellectuals including Bruce Ackerman, William Galston, John E. Schwarz and Michael Tomasky have sought to define a body of principles that could inform a practical liberal politics. The newest addition to this literature, Paul Starrs Freedoms Power: The True Force of Liberalism, is a brilliant and ambitious attempt to provide a public philosophy for 21st-century American liberalism.

title: Good Golly
description: The cover of The House on Boulevard St. is a Roy Lichtenstein-style cartoon, a portrait of the poet David Kirby with a furrowed brow, above which floats a word balloon: Need a subtitle ... No wait I got it ... New and Selected Poems.

title: McCain Tries to Recapture Vigor of His Last Campaign
description: TEMPE, Ariz., April 28  Several times this week  while wrapping up a town hall meeting in Des Moines, or a conference call with bloggers from Sioux City, Iowa  Senator John McCain and his listeners were told that there was time for just one more question. Can I do two more? Mr. McCain would ask.

title: Unstoppable
description: WHEN is a bicycle not like other bicycles? To begin with, when it has no brakes, or at least no visible brakes, or possibly just a front brake. That means you cant ride this bike very well on your first try, and certainly not very gracefully, easily or safely.

title: Museum Sheds Light on Fakes and Imitations
description: Did you know that 10 percent of the worlds products are fakes and cheap imitations  going way beyond the purses, jeans and watches you see on the street? Earlier this month, a museum devoted entirely to the subject of plagiarism opened in Solingen, Germany, near Cologne.

title: A Disciplined Business
description: Peter Acworth is 36 and trim, with a pale, boyish face. He grew up in the English Midlands, the son of a sculptor and a former Jesuit priest, and came to the United States in 1996 to get a Ph.D. in finance at Columbia University. He had already worked for Baring Brothers in London and was on track to do analytical research on Wall Street. Then, after his first year, he read in a British tabloid about a fireman who sold pornographic pictures on the Internet. He had made a quarter of a million pounds over a short period doing nothing very clever at all, Acworth told me not long ago, pointing to the clipping framed in his office in downtown San Francisco. So I basically just ripped off that idea.

title: Bush Asks Florida Graduates to Back Immigration Change
description: MIAMI, April 28  President Bush used a speech to mostly Hispanic graduates of Miami Dade College on Saturday to press for an overhaul of immigration law, calling for changes that resolve the status of those who are already here without amnesty, and without animosity.

title: Sweet Victories
description: THERE were mini-croissants and pancakes, champagne and orange juice, and almost as many reasons for voting as there were candidates, as a well-heeled group of French expatriates gathered at brunch in Midtown last Sunday to watch the returns in the first round of Frances presidential elections.

title: After a Dark Era, a City Looks West and Sees a Future
description: MAYBE it is the cobblestone byways that meander through Vilnius and appear more suited for horses than horsepower. Perhaps it is the unexpectedly historic architecture or the hulking castles that whisper of medieval derring-do. While modernity certainly intrudes  it would not be a European capital without its Prada and Ermenegildo Zegna stores, now would it?  somehow or other, this Lithuanian city, despite its many recent changes, often has the feel of an old-world diorama sprung to life.

title: No Savings in Cutting Out the Middle Men
description: More than 10 times in the past week, relief pitchers have given starters reasons to hate them. In fact, its an interesting dynamic that such feelings dont develop. Pitchers, though, are part of a close-knit fraternity. They understand these things.

title: Laura Keller, Alan Isenberg
description: Laura Rachael Keller, a lawyer, is to be married today to Alan Isenberg, a television news producer. Melvin Grant, a marriage officer for the Bahamas, is to officiate there at the One & Only Ocean Club, a resort on Paradise Island. Afterward, Rabbi Michael Siegel and Cantor Alberto Mizrahi are to perform a religious ceremony.

title: In the Air, a Very Public Failure
description: LAKEHURST, N.J.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the billionaire businessman Philip F. Anschutz referred incorrectly to the Corporate Library, a research firm that focuses on corporate governance. It is a for-profit business, not a nonprofit.

title: When State Laws Do Not Apply
description: EARLIER this month, Countrywide Home Loans, one of the nations biggest mortgage lenders, paid Connecticut $500,000 as a penalty for violating the states lending laws. But if other national lenders were to engage in the same practices today, consumers would have little recourse.

title: The Frozen Chosen
description: Sitka, Alaska

title: On the Road, Hope for a Zero-Pollution Car
description: LAKEHURST, N.J.

title: Stars and Stripes, Wrapped in the Same Old Blue
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: These Are the Saves to Remember
description: With the Islanders trailing, 4-3, and only 15 seconds from elimination in Game 5 of their opening-round series against Buffalo, Isles wing Miroslav Satan accepted a pass at the top of the right face-off circle and turned on the afterburners.

title: Jenelle DeCoteau and Greg Baker
description: Jenelle June DeCoteau, a daughter of Patricia and Collis A. DeCoteau of Miami, was married yesterday to Howard Gregory Baker, the son of Carolyn Saunders Baker and Howard L. Baker of Tinton Falls, N.J. The Rev. Norbert M. Cooper, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Palms South Beach hotel in Miami Beach.

title: Fields of Memory
description: A fun game for poetry nerds: read the first line or sentence of a favorite poets first book, and imagine it as a summary of the writers entire career. This works more often than you might think. Muriel Rukeysers Breathe-in experience, breathe-out poetry suggests her lifelong commitment to poetry as a praxis; Sylvia Plaths Two girls there are: within the house / One sits; the other, without conjures a psyche in crisis; Theodore Roethkes My secrets cry aloud inaugurates a career of passionate self-disclosure.

title: Catalytic Converters
description: The Middle East is abuzz with talk of Shiitization. Since the war in Lebanon last summer, newspapers, TV news channels and Web sites in Egypt, Saudi Arabia and elsewhere have reported that Sunnis, taken with Hezbollahs charismatic Shiite leader Hassan Nasrallah and his groups resistance to Israel, were converting to Shiite Islam. When I recently visited the semi-arid plains of eastern Syria, known as the Jazeera, Sunni tribal leaders whispered stories of Iranians roaming the Syrian countryside handing out bags of cash and macaroni to convert families and even entire villages to Shiite Islam.

title: Fort Myers, Fla.: Embassy Suites
description: THE BASICS

title: Unfamiliar Perspectives on Familiar Images
description: FOR most people, a downpour in the middle of a weekend getaway in Montauk would count as an unqualified bummer.

title: Bills Put Debit Card Into Their Playbook
description: Buffalo Bills General Manager Marv Levy said his club, which has not made the N.F.L. playoffs in seven seasons, was rebuilding the old-fashioned way: through conservative accounting.

title: Borders Spell Trouble for Arab-American
description: Abe Dabdoub calls the day he was sworn in as an American citizen last year the proudest moment of his life, little suspecting that his new identity would set off a bureaucratic nightmare at the hands of the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Help Wanted
description: HE was a co-author of a five-volume history of Staten Island, but he was no ivory-tower academic. He also traipsed around cemeteries throughout his borough and copied, by hand, thousands of inscriptions from tombstones. His name was Charles W. Leng, and he was the first official historian of Staten Island.

title: The Real Manhattan
description: THE Manhattan is back.

title: Letters
description: A Spirit of Neighborliness

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 28, 2007

title: Young, Gifted, and Not Getting Into Harvard
description: ON a Sunday morning a few months back, I interviewed my final Harvard applicant of the year. After saying goodbye to the girl and watching her and her mother drive off, I headed to the beach at the end of our street for a run.

title: A Lineup of I Dunnits With Stylish Stories to Tell
description: Theres no point wondering whodunit  Jeffrey Hatchers new play tells us the answer to that question right off the bat. The fun at TheaterWorks in Hartford is finding out how they dun it, and why.

title: Searching the Alps for Haute Comfort Food
description: THE first thing to do with a tartiflette is to ease your fork through the crust of cheese. If the casserole is done right, that cut will release a whiff of milky steam infused with a suggestion of onion and garlic.

title: The Outsider Insider
description: Lincoln Kirstein was, for most of the 20th century, America's mightiest cultural swizzle stick. He was a skilled critic, historian, art collector and diarist, and a not-bad poet and novelist. But his real gift was for flushing out and nourishing the talent he spotted all around him. Throughout his long life he functioned, as one contemporary put it, "like a setter pointing out the coveys of genius."

title: George Kennan
description: When George Kennan was born, in 1904, there were about eighty-one million Americans. When he died, one hundred and one years later, there were about two hundred and eighty million: so many more, and a different people, and a different country. When this book is published I fear that to the vast majority of Americans his name will be unknown. This is, and will remain, regrettable. He was an extraordinary man, who not only represented but incarnated some of the best and finest traits of American character. Evidences of that make up the substance of this book.

title: The Visible World
description: One night when I was young my mother walked out of the country bungalow we were staying in in the Poconos. I woke to hear my father pulling on his pants in the dark. It was very late, and the windows were open. The night was everywhere. Where was he going? I asked. "Go back to sleep," he said. Mommy had gone for a walk. He would be right back, he said.

title: Troublesome Young Men
description: It had been a brilliant summer. On that point everyone agreed.

title: A Far Country
description: In the valley of the village they would one day name Saint Michael in the Cane, the men and women waited, turning the November soil and watching the sky.

title: Legendary Lansbury
description: Photos from the stage and screen career of Angela Lansbury.

title: The Week Ahead: Apr. 29 - May 5
description: THEATER

title: Overpass Collapse
description: A tanker truck accident near the approach to the Bay Bridge caused the collapse of a heavily used freeway overpass near downtown Oakland, Calif.

title: Tristan, Past and Present
Paperback Row
description: IN SEARCH OF MEMORY: The Emergence of a New Science of Mind, by Eric R. Kandel. (Norton, $17.95.) A renowned scientist, Kandel has made it his lifes work to show how memory and learning are encoded in the brain. (In 2000 he won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.) This panoramic autobiography revisits the Vienna of Kandels childhood  driven out by the Nazis, he and his family fled the city for the United States in 1939  and gives an extraordinary overview of developments in neuroscience during the 20th century. If there is another book that does a better job of demonstrating how biological research is done, or of telling the story of a brilliant scientists career, I dont know it, Sherwin B. Nuland wrote in the Book Review.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE GRAND SURPRISE: The Journals of Leo Lerman. Edited by Stephen Pascal. (Knopf, $37.50.) Lerman, a contemporary of Truman Capote, was a larger-than-life figure in the magazine world who also gave great parties.

title: Into the Sunset
description: The only remaining public riding stable in Manhattan closes.

title: California Democrats Cheer Talk They Sought 4 Years Ago
description: All the presidential candidates who spoke at the California Democratic Party convention were praised as they denounced the war.

title: McCain Lands at Home for Last Tour Stop
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  It was the end of the beginning. When Senator John McCains four-day kick-off tour wrapped up here on Saturday at City Hall  where he launched his first race for Congress more than 20 years ago  it was not only old friends who turned out.

title: Finalist Essay: Emily Learner
description: iTunes Store New Music Tuesday. Delete.

title: Finalist Essay: Amelia Knopf
description: I've always been acutely aware that the world is much bigger than what I know about it. When I was a little girl, I would lie in my bed and think 'I am in my bed, in my room, in my house, on Japonica Way, in Louisville, Kentucky, in the United States of America, on Earth, in the Milky Way.' I would also hold the corners of my eyes at a 45-degree angle because I wanted so desperately to be Chinese or something, anything, anyone but me. When I was eight I thought life abroad was surely nothing but glamour and glory.

title: Finalist Essay: Aparna Kesarwala
description: When I hear "Africa," I imagine feeling smaller. Anyone who has met me would laugh at those words, as I'm already pretty small (I like to say I'm 5'2", but that's about 1/2" of wishful thinking), but I believe that "smaller" is a rare and important feeling. Even though I've never been there, it's easy to imagine feeling smaller in Africa: all I have to do is envision looking up at a Great Pyramid or the ice fields of Kilimanjaro, or hearing the stampede of the annual wildebeest migration or the thunder of Victoria Falls. I certainly hope to revel in each of those moments someday.

title: Winning Essay: Leana Wen
description: "Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere."  Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Finalist Essay: Erin Featherman
description: I've read so much about the world, but I haven't had the opportunity to experience very much of it. As a student at Columbia University, I am certainly a minority in terms of worldliness. I simply can't afford to travel because I am paying for college on my own.

title: Finalist Essay: Jennifer Monti
description: Is my name familiar? I applied for this post last year, and I appeal again because my commitment remains firm. I am nearing the end of medical school, year two, and the importance of health as the basis for all other activity cannot be overstated. Constancy of purpose is required, in medicine or in international pursuits of economic growth and peace. No meaningful discoveries are made on a whim in the laboratory or the clinic. Likewise, we cannot abandon developing communities because they are no longer in the spotlight, or the embarrassment of inaction has drained from the face of things. I am in it for the long haul, for my patients, for my community, and for all the potential patients I can reach.

title: Finalist Essay: Laura Ciaccia
description: I am not a journalist, nor an international relations student, nor a writer. I am a scientist, someone who does not look at the world beyond the laboratory with a trained eye. My global experiences have been limited to my grandfather's stories about Italy, two brief visits to Western Europe, and listening to KEXP's African music show on Monday evenings. Unfortunately, there is no Scientists Without Borders.

title: Finalist Essay: Reija Matheson
description: I had the chicken pox when I was three years old. My three sisters and I had it together. I remember very little about it, only being hot and scratchy on our old living room sofa. I remember more clearly my bout with strep throat at Christmastime in kindergarten and my next visit to a doctor for an infectious disease (mononucleosis) seventeen Christmases later.

title: Finalist Essay: Mary Kathryn Covert
description: With a can of Natural Light in one hand and a half-empty bottle of Crown in another, my toothless Great-uncle Jack loafs in his monstrous easy chair. I don't remember his ever having teeth, and I've been going to his trailer for a long time. Even now, as a senior in college, I treasure every tale of napalm, the South when it actually stood for something, and chasing women from Pachuta to Pelahatchie.

title: Finalist Essay: Nicole Gagnon
description: Although my body looks 'normal,' something is not right. When my peers were beginning to toddle, I was still struggling to sit up. Twenty-three years later there has been no miracle cure. I have instead learned to embrace the person I have become: a resilient young woman with a physical disability.

title: Finalist Essay: Nida Kamal
description: As a business student at the University of Chicago I have been taught that without economic freedom there is no political freedom  i.e. capitalism brings developments in human rights, the rights of women, religious freedoms, and public health. At a very basic level, tempered capitalism provides individuals with tools to control their material well being. I have no fantasies of fixing Africa with capitalism, but I am simply interested in understanding how Africa can incorporate the civil and political benefits of capitalism without increasing indebtedness and poverty. Finally, I would like to use the knowledge gained during this trip to bridge the gaps between Africa and my home community as a Muslim, American woman.

title: Finalist Essay: Paul Zenke
description: It happened gradually, but soon the conveniences that I once took for granted disappeared. First, our cable TV was cut, then we started getting most of our groceries from the Shell gas station, charging them to my grandpa's gas card, then finally the bank took our house.

title: Coachella: Days Two and Three
description: Highlights from the second and third days of the 2007 Coachella music festival.

title: Were Baaaack!!!!
description: The 5th Downs N.F.L. Draft Day blog is back (or maybe we never left). Oakland is on the clock with the first pick in Round 4

title: Why We Travel
description: "Each evening after we helped the monk, he said hed like to give us tattoos. He thought it would do us good, protect us, bring us luck."

title: L.A. Story
description: We already have our first brouhaha. Gene Washington of the N.F.L. opened the festivities by announcing the Raiders as the Los Angeles Raiders. Say what? When he announced the pick minutes later, Michael Bush of Louisville, he carefully referred to the O-a-k-l-a-n-d Raiders. Good thing he didnt mistakenly say they had selected Reggie Bush.

title: Finalist Essay: Sarah Bass
description: "If you could visit any country in the world, where would you go?" I posed this question one morning to the students in my English class. I picked up a marker, prepared to make a list on the board.

title: Finalist Essay: Steven Chen
description: A few days ago, I was faced with the toughest challenge of my teaching career.

title: Finalist Essay: Terrence Kneisel
description: How many visits have you made to third-world countries? How many visits have you made to the third-world country within the richest country in the world?

title: Finalist Essay: Thomas Szalay
description: I was photographing Somali refugee students in my classroom studio when one of my colleagues told me about Win a Trip to Africa with Nick Kristof. Teaching photography at West High School, in Salt Lake City, and making photographs and friendships with my students from nations across the globe is what defines me now. I want to find out more about my students, and visiting the continent where many of my students immigrated from is a good place to start.

title: Randy Moss Traded
description: A huge (HUGE!) trade just happened. The Raiders dealt Randy Moss to the Patriots for New Englands fourth-round pick (110th over all). More on this soon

title: Jazzfest: Thank God I Made It
description: New Orleans, April 28Hurricane Katrina has given New Orleans gospel groups a whole new reason to praise the Lord. You hurt me Katrina, but Im still standing, preached Bishop Paul S. Morton, who had the Rev. Jesse Jackson among his listeners in Jazzfests gospel tent. (He also asked the crowd: If you are not from New Orleans, please dont forget about us.) The Johnson Extension, another gospel group, sang about trouble and trial on the way to a richly harmonized chorus of Thank God I made it!

title: Finalist Essay: Tracey Luszcz
description: I love the school where I work. When I began, 8 years ago, the school was a mess. We had fire drills every day, children threw desks at the teachers, anything but learning went on in the classroom. When our current principal arrived the next year, things changed drastically. He immediately dubbed our school "The Pride of Newark", empowered teachers to teach, and radically changed the unspoken policy of our school being the dumping ground for "problem students". That year I began our photography program.

title: Winning Essay: Will Okun
description: Let's not mince words: I am charismatic, handsome, muscular, stylish, articulate, hilarious, intelligent, tenacious and innovative. Oprah wants me on the show, non-profits are desperate for my endorsement and young people hang on every word I speak.

title: Finalist Essay: Buudoan Tran
description: Four years ago, I was sitting down to write a letter like this one to Teach for America, knowing that my parents would certainly not approve. For my Vietnamese parents, a teacher was the most valued player in their children's future success, but teaching was the least appropriate vocation for a son or daughter's career. I had earned a full academic scholarship to the University of Georgia, and the scholarship included a travel-study stipend that I pointedly did not use to work in a chemistry lab abroad. Instead, I stumbled upon an opportunity to teach English to mentally and physically disabled children in the Albanian capital of Tirana.

title: Finalist Essay: Corinne Dedini
description: Twenty-four years old, two job offers: Teach for America (poor kids) or St. Gregory College Prep (rich kids). The daughter of a third-generation farmer, I'd vowed to get out of the mud and into the city; in my statement of vocation for graduate school, I'd declared that I was "called to make a difference in a society where the American dream is dying."

title: Finalist Essay: Maia Merin
description: In early September I received a shipment of books from the New York Department of Education. Terrell, one of my students, dragged the box off the cart and into the classroom. Desperate to expend some of his teenage male energy, he began to rip at the tape. I sighed. This was a distraction from the lesson and the classroom erupted. Books spilled out of the box and on to the floor. My students reached in and began to read titles out loud. The Protestant Reformation. Queen Elizabeth. The Great Triangle Shirtwaist Factory. The Making of the Brooklyn Bridge. Martin Luther. The Progressive Era. The Roaring Twenties. At lunch, Terrell helped me load the books on the book case. He asked me, "When do the books on Africa come?" I asked myself the same question.

title: Finalist Essay: Matthew Green
description: My students are highly skilled complainers. It's one of the many reasons I love teaching journalism - to help them turn their wealth of complaints into good articles. Of course, they complain about having to do that too.

title: Finalist Essay: Michelle Balmeo
description: "You can bring a friend. But only one."

title: Finalist Essay: Ravina Daphtary
description: I should start this essay in all honesty and admit that teaching was never my first choice. A long time ago, my calculus teacher (who was failing me at the time) sat on a gurney after having given blood and woozily told me I would make a good teacher; I was "spontaneous." I dismissed the idea with a sardonic comment, and decided that, given his weakened state, we would discuss my grade instead. The conversation never resurfaced, and the idea, which I secretly entertained for the remainder of that day, eventually dissipated.

title: The Lowdown on the Moss Trade
description: I thought the second day of the draft would be more boring than waiting for the B train to come on a Sunday morning. But were off to a blazing start.

title: Around the neighborhood
description: A roundup of real estate-related news:

title: Brownout: DeOssie Who?
description: With the 17th pick in the fourth round (116th over all), the Giants drafted Zak DeOssie, an outside linebacker from Brown. Brown? Does the school really have a football team?

title: Nurburgring, Nordschleife, BMW Sauber and the meeting of two worlds
description: If you want your jaw to drop, if you want to see an extraordinary meeting and mlange of two worlds, to more fully understand what the past meant and what the present meanswatch this absolutely amazing moment of Nick Heidfeld driving around the old Nurburgring this weekend in todays Formula One car. Try to find the video footage; I just watched it at this site where BMW Sauber made it available, but there may be other places.

title: A Busy Morning in Washington
description: Where to start? The biggest news this morning is that Orlando Hernandez is flying to New York this afternoon to have his right shoulder examined. Hernandez, who threw a bullpen session yesterday, arrived at RFK Stadium this morning complaining of tightness. Omar Minaya said no specific tests had been ordered, but its unlikely that Hernandez will make his scheduled start tomorrow against the Marlins. Assuming he cant pitch, they would almost ask Aaron Sele (who threw only 21 pitches Saturday night) to go because Mike Pelfrey threw a bullpen session this morning in preparation for Tuesdays start.

title: Like Father, Like Son
description: Here is some interesting info on Zak DeOssies father, Steven DeOssie. He was a linebacker and a long snapper for Boston College and then three N.F.L. teams, the Cowboys, Giants and Patriots. He played on the Giants team that went to the 1990 Super Bowl. During his career in the N.F.L., he had numerous problems with substance abuse.

title: Karstens Has Perspective on Injury
description: Jeff Karstens sat alone on the Yankees bench during batting practice this morning, a purple-gray bruise covering the lower part of his right leg. He rubbed the bruise now and then, staring impassively out at the field.

title: Heisman Hopeless?
description: ESPN just made an interesting point. There are some big-name quarterbacks still out there. Remember Troy Smith? Didnt he win some kind of award this season? The Heisman Trophy winner is still on the board, but his two top receivers at Ohio State (Ted Ginn Jr. and Anthony Gonzalez) were picked in the first round.

title: Something Phishy in Philly
description: The Eagles selected C.J. Gaddis, a safety from Clemson, with the 22nd pick of the fifth round. They took Brent Celek, a tight end from Cincinnati, three picks later. This just gives me another opportunity to pan the Eagles for taking a quarterback with their first pick in the second round yesterday, quarterback Kevin Kolb of Houston. I think the Eagles really wasted a pick there. Their fans booed the Gaddis pick, but I think they are just still fuming about trading with Dallas to get a quarterback.

title: Hall to Houston?
description: Houston is on the clock right now. Look for them to take Gabe Hall, an offensive lineman from Texas Tech. Hall, a Texas native, would love stay at home and play for the Texans. I heard that the Dallas Cowboys called him today, but that just might be to set up a signing through free agency. Hall played tackle in college but he is big enough (6-foot-4, 313 pounds) to slide to the guard position. The knock on Hall is that he is not physical enough.

title: Win a Trip With Nick Kristof
description: Leana Wen, a medical student from Washington University in St. Louis, and Will Okun, a teacher from Chicago, will travel with Times columnist Nick Kristof on a reporting trip to Africa.

title: Close, but Not Close Enough
description: I was close. Houston went for help along the offensive line, and they stayed in the neighborhood. Only they went with Kasey Studdard of Texas, not Hall. Keep an eye out for Dallas, which owns the 26th pick in the sixth round (200th over all). They might use it on Hall.

title: Kevin Browns Biggest Fan
description: Im always impressed by how many Yankees fans wear players uniforms or T-shirts to the games. Every time I look down from my press box seat here, it seems like every third fan has a different shirt.

title: Packers Unearth Some Value
description: Were getting to the bottom of the barrel now. Only 54 picks before the draft is declared done. The Green Bay Packers had three consecutive picks in the middle of the sixth round, 191 to 193. Were they able to find value? They picked Korey Hall (linebacker, Boise State), Desmond Bishop (linebacker, California) and Mason Crosby (kicker, Colorado). Crosby is the only player of the three I had heard of. He was the third kicker taken in the draft, and he can consistently hit from beyond 50 yards. So, yes, Id say they found value with such a late pick. And there are other value picks out there, such as Jacob Ford, a defensive end from Central Arkansas.

title: Young, Gifted and Not Getting Into Harvard
description: Its very moving meeting all these bright young people who wont get into Harvard. Recent news articles make it sound unbearably tragic. Several Ivies, including Harvard, rejected a record number of applicants this year.

title: Talking Heads Keep On Talking
description: Things on this end are dragging. Were going into our 49th hour (at least it feels that way). I see lots of people either napping or kicking back in their chairs. The liveliest people here are the talking heads on television. These guys must drink a lot of caffeine. There are two networks covering the draft, ESPN and NFL Network, which was launched in November 2003 and began covering the draft last season. They both have stages at Radio City, recognizable on-air personalities and plenty of airtime to fill. But it is sort of an odd scene since they are competing against each other for viewers. ESPN is clearly the top dog here. But both broadcasts are being shown on oversized screens (without sound). According to an NFL official, preliminary ratings indicate this will be the second-highest-rated draft ever, behind last years draft.

title: Mr. Lucky to Get Drafted
description: There are only seventeen picks left! Our long journey is almost over. I am relieved and saddened at the same time. The big question now is: Who will be Mr. Irrelevant? The title (and a free trip to Disneyland) goes to the last player drafted in the seventh and final round. Detroit holds the final pick (255th over all). Its a compensatory selection (see my E=MCompensatory2 entry from yesterday for an explanation of compensatory picks).

title: Were Done? Already?
description: The 2007 N.F.L. Draft is officially over. The last player picked was Ramzee Robinson, a cornerback from Alabama who went to the Detroit Lions.

title: Coachella: Giving In to the Beat
description: Indio, Calif., April 29More beats than drones yesterday. CocoRosie: spacey juvenilia with a beatboxer. Ghostface Killah: crew-ness is all. The French DJ duo Justice: a techno psychic-friends network, with instant-cartharsis breaks. Red Hot Chili Peppers: heard in the night air, those rhythm-guitar bits feel interestingly thin and fragile these days for a Big Rock Band; then the guitar breaks come in, all trumped-up. LCD Soundsystem: a juicier, ampier version of the all those trebly basslines and cowbells on the new record, Sound of Silver. Tisto: rock-festival trance, performanced-up.

title: The Nation's Top Horse Trainer
description: Todd Pletcher has won a lot of races, but never the Kentucky Derby. Will this be his year?

title: Under FIRE: Campus Speech Regulations Once Again
description: Last week saw the end of a little drama that had been playing out on the campus of the University of Rhode Island for some months. On April 26 the student senate turned back a committee recommendation to derecognize the College Republicans because the group refused to apologize for one of its actions. What the College Republicans had done was invite applications for the First Annual White Heterosexual Male Scholarship, otherwise known by the acronym WHAM. Applicants were asked, first, to certify that they were indeed white, heterosexual, American and male and then to answer two questions: In 100 words or less, what does being a White Heterosexual American Male mean to you? As a White Heterosexual American Male, what adversities have you had to deal with and overcome?Many of the 40 or so who sent in applications recognized the satirical intention (to ridicule and parody raced-based scholarships and other forms of campus affirmative action) of the obviously bogus scholarship and wrote in the same spirit. But the student senate was not amused, and in February the Student Organizations Advisory and Review Committee demanded that the College Republicans: A) not award the $100 scholarship, B) apologize in writing for having violated the anti-discrimination section of the senates bylaws, and C) seek permission from the senate before mounting any programs in the next 12 months. The group cheerfully agreed to A  why not?  and declined to comply with B and C.

title: Coachella: Sponsored by
description: Indio, Calif., April 29One thing that sets Coachella apart from most other major live music events is the relative invisibility of the festivals sponsors. There are no logos emblazoned on the stages scattered across the grounds - all part of the promoters belief that alternative rock fans may recoil from the whole affair if they sense how much they are in the crosshairs of cachet-starved advertisers. But Madison Avenue is still more than eager to establish a beachhead here. During the day - while many fans at the polo field are scrambling to find shelter from the sweltering weather - a sunny ranch house, one dusty mile down the road, had been turned into a luxury lounge for guests of DKNY Jeans and the Los Angeles radio station Indie 103, hosts of one of the buzzed-about daytime parties that have become a constant of the festival. An ever-revolving crowd that included fashion designers, musicians and an iTunes executive or two drifted in. Hipsters inside snacked on grilled turkey burgers or played Guitar Hero II on an Xbox 360; outside, DKNY created a swag paradise, handing out free bikinis and swim trunks to guests and inviting them to take a dip in the pool, which sat atop a small pond with a rock waterfall. Others sunned themselves on white mattresses. Members of the buzzy Los Angeles band the Like stopped by, and organizers whispered that they expected one or more of the Reid brothers from the Jesus and Mary Chain. (Better hurry boys, theyre running low on trunks).

title: The Amnesty Sideshow
description: We have all seen how presidential candidates shift positions to impress primary voters. Its usually as measured and boring as dance instruction: O.K. everyone, now dip to the right  or left  then back to center. But on the volatile topic of immigration, Republicans are lurching, falling over themselves to convince voters that where they stand is not where they stood.

title: California Democrats Cheer Talk They Sought 4 Years Ago
description: SAN DIEGO, April 29  When John Edwards attended the California Democratic Party convention as a presidential candidate four years ago, he was heckled with shouts of No war as he struggled to defend his support of the Iraq invasion. That tense weekend in Sacramento crystallized how divided Democrats were over a war that overshadowed the presidential race of 2004.

title: Albany: Governor Unveils Plan to Help Local Governments
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday that he would introduce legislation to lower costs for local governments, including changing a controversial law requiring multiple contractors for public construction projects. The law, called the Wicks Law, requires multiple contractors for projects costing more than $50,000, a threshold that has not been increased since the 1960s. The governors proposal would increase the threshold to $1 million for projects upstate and $2 million for projects in New York City and would adjust the numbers annually for inflation. Other proposals include steps aimed at giving local governments more flexibility in procurement and allowing them to use administrative proceedings, rather than court action, to handle housing code violations. This bill will promote fiscal savings for our taxpayers, increase flexibility for our municipalities and ensure the long-term economic stability of our state, the governor said.

title: It Aint That Pretty, That Life of Zevons
description: One self-imposed epitaph Warren Zevon delivered after learning he had terminal cancer was this: Its a damned hard way to make a living, having to die to get em to know youre alive. Like so much of what he said, wrote and sang, it was quotable, savagely funny and true.

title: Bloggers Cast Doubt on Foxs Generosity
description: In hailing its generosity to poor children, American Idol has drawn some complaints that it has acted a bit stingily.

title: Israeli Leader Clings to Office Despite Harsh Report on War
description: JERUSALEM, April 30  A government commission excoriated Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert today for severe failures in the first five days of last summers war against Lebanon. It accused him of deciding hastily to go to war, neglecting to ask for a detailed military plan, refusing to consult people outside the army and setting over-ambitious and unobtainable goals.

title: As Blogs Proliferate, a Gadfly With Accreditation at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  The daily press briefing was routine. Marie Okabe, a spokeswoman for the secretary general, read a five-minute update on Somalia, Darfur and the Security Councils actions, and about 30 journalists quietly listened.

title: A Little Bit of Country Infuses a Pop Instinct
description: Were about to get country on you, Brandi Carlile said on Friday night, during the encore portion of her second sold-out Bowery Ballroom show. She was speaking some truth  the next song was Johnny Cashs Folsom Prison Blues  but the warning came belatedly. Ms. Carlile and her band had just wrapped up a long set suffused with country feeling, though it wasnt always patently clear.

title: A Vestige of the Past Shutters Its Stalls
description: The horses relaxed upstairs in their wooden stalls as the radio played, munching on hay and oblivious to history, controversy and other human concerns. Downstairs, in an old office lined with dusty saddles, Paul Novograd pulled out a black-and-white photo from the 1930s. It was a picture of his father.

title: Prosecutors Begin to Lay Out Case Against Prison Chief in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, April, 30  A senior commander at the American militarys main detention center here testified Monday that his predecessor, Lt. Col. William H. Steele, gave computer programs and other gifts to the daughter of a high-value detainee, breaching military law and Iraqi cultural norms.

title: Indias Economic Progress (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: When Is Patience a Virtue? When the Trump Split Is Bad
description: They say that things come in threes. If so, I know what will arrive soon: another deal where a good player finds a line of play that works even though the breaks are bad and gains points over someone who unwisely assumes that everything will be for the best in the best of all possible worlds  as in both Saturdays column and todays.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,329 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:

title: Yahoo to Buy Ad Company in Bid to Compete With Google
description: Yahoo plans to acquire Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace, in part to bolster its position as a seller and broker of ads outside its own sprawling network of Web sites, the companies chief executives said yesterday.

title: Garden & Gun Magazine Has an Awkward Debut
description: Garden & Gun, a glossy new lifestyle magazine from Charleston, S.C., says it is for those who love an adventure-bound, art-loving, skeet-shooting lifestyle. In reality, the magazine is less about guns than it is about gardens, Southern tradition and land conservation. The gun part of the title, said Rebecca Darwin, the magazines publisher, is a metaphor for the sporting life.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 29, 2007

title: Nets Get Healthy Boost From Kidd and Carter
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 29  In creating a strikingly familiar sequel to their script of two nights earlier, the Nets Jason Kidd and Vince Carter might have been putting the preliminary touches on their legacy as a backcourt tandem.

title: Truth in Co-ops: Just Tell Me Why Im Not In (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombian Seeks to Persuade Congress to Continue Aid
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 29  Faced with allegations of government ties to paramilitary death squads and criticism from prominent Democrats, President lvaro Uribe of Colombia is heading to Washington this week to try to unlock frozen American aid and salvage a trade agreement with the United States.

title: Trump Donation to Schwarzenegger Draws Criticism
description: SACRAMENTO, April 29 (AP)  Donald Trump gave $10,000 to Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California to help pay off campaign debts a little more than a month after Mr. Schwarzenegger appeared as a guest star on Mr. Trumps television program The Apprentice: Los Angeles, according to a campaign filing.

title: 5 Britons Convicted in Terror Plot
description: London, April 30  A British court today found five men guilty of a conspiracy to use fertilizer bombs to blow up targets  including, perhaps, a nightclub, a shopping mall and an electric power grid  after a yearlong trial and record jury deliberations of nearly a month.

title: After Virginia Tech, Testing Limits of Movie Violence
description: LOS ANGELES, April 29  If the horror at Virginia Tech has changed the chemistry of Americas popular culture, those who count box-office receipts at Lionsgate would be among the first to know.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Monday about the prosecution of an American business executive in Kazakhstan on charges he stole $40,000 from his company omitted the company's name and misidentified its owners. The company is Arna Inc., and it is owned by GIMV, a Belgian investment company; the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development; and Murat Zhunussov, a Kazakh investor. Arna is not a Kazakhstan subsidiary of Golden Telecom, a Moscow-based Internet and telecommunications company.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front page article Friday on the resignation of Marilee Jones, M.I.T.'s dean of admissions, misidentified Leslie Perelman, a faculty member who commented on her resignation. He is the director of Writing Across the Curriculum at M.I.T., not the director of the M.I.T. program in writing and humanistic studies.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption Friday with a front-page article about fear among Pakistanis in Lodi, Calif., after the arrest last year of two local men on terrorism charges misstated the name of a boy pictured with Raheela Hayat, whose brother, Hamid Hayat, was found guilty in the case. He is Jalal Hashim Usman, not Hamid. In some copies, the caption misstated the boys relationship to Hamid Hayat. He is his nephew, not his son.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article April 20 about House passage of legislation that would entitle the residents of the District of Columbia to a full voting representative in Congress incompletely described where members of Congress met after fleeing Philadelphia in 1783, one of the events that led to the creation of the district as a home for Congress. They reconvened first in Princeton, N.J., and later in Annapolis, Md., and Trenton, N.J., before moving to New York in 1785. They did not go directly from Princeton to New York.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about changes at The Philadelphia Inquirer, using information supplied by the newspaper, misstated the source of a photograph of two Amish women taken after last year's shooting at a schoolhouse. The photograph, which hangs near the office of Brian P. Tierney, the publisher, was in The Daily News, not in The Inquirer.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A book review in Science Times last Tuesday about Hooked: How Medicines Dependence on the Pharmaceutical Industry Undermines Professional Ethics, by Howard Brody, misstated part of the publishers name. It is Rowman & Littlefield, not Bowman.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a television review last Monday about The Real Wedding Crashers, on NBC, omitted the first word of the title of a forthcoming book on weddings by Rebecca Mead. The title is One Perfect Day: The Selling of the American Wedding.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Wednesday, about the Supreme Court abortion ruling, misidentified the state involved in a similar abortion case in 2000. It was Nebraska, not Kansas.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Tuesday, about Boris Yeltsin, misspelled the given name of his wife. It is Naina, not Raina.

title: One Call to Tell the World All About You
description: Services that merge mobile phones and the Web are bringing the culture of exhibitionism to more personal locations, encouraging people to share the details of their lives around the clock through pictures, video and text.

title: Correction
description: A poem by Kurt Vonnegut on April 20 carried an incorrect description of its history. It had appeared in The Cornell Daily Sun in 2005; it was not unpublished.

title: Ticket to Ride
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Cycling in Croatia
description: Cycle past coastal villages that teeter on limestone peninsulas, and inland, through Istrias uncrowded interior where medieval villages perch on fortified hilltops.

title: Hurwitz Jurors Explain Their Verdict
description: Since the verdict in the Hurwit trial on Friday, Ive interviewed three of the twelve jurors, and they told pretty much the same story. They said that the jury considered Dr. William Hurwitz to be a doctor dedicated to treating pain who didnt intentionally prescribe drugs to be resold or abused. They said he didnt appear to benefit financially from his patients drug dealing and that he wasnt what they considered a conventional drug trafficker.

title: Frankenstein in Seattle
description: "Young Frankenstein," the latest musical to be adapted from a Mel Brooks film comedy, will hold its pre-Broadway tryout in Seattle from Aug. 4 through Sept. 1 at the Paramount Theater, Variety.com reported.

title: New Law to Protect Critics From Being Misquoted
description: The European Commission has passed legislation that would keep bad reviews from looking good, the London newspaper The Independent reported.

title: Lovely in London
description: Queenstown

title: Langella to Play Nixon in Ron Howard Movie
description: Frank Langella will recreate the role of Richard M. Nixon when the Peter Morgan play Frost/Nixon is adapted for the screen under the direction of Ron Howard, Variety.com reported.

title: Bondage Fetish Leads Banker to Profitable, if Disciplined, Business
description: The New York Times magazine takes a look at how a former banker with a bondage fetish and a Ph.D. in finance created Kink, arguably the countrys most successful fetish porn company. Kinks founder, Peter Acworth, is a former a Barings Brothers employee, and Kinks vice president for marketing, Reena Patel, is a former Merrill Lynch-er with an M.B.A. Ms. Patel told the magazine that while the image of pornographers is still a bunch of sleazy guys that are drunk all day, the business has changed.

title: Yahoo to Buy Online Ad Company Right Media
description: Weeks after Google spent $3.1 billion to buy the Internet advertising company DoubleClick, a rival search giant is reaching into its wallet in a bid to compete. Yahoo has agreed to pay about $680 million to acquire the rest of Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace, in part to bolster its position as a seller and broker of ads outside its own sprawling network of Web sites, The New York Times reported.

title: China Tightens Bank Credit Again
description: For the second time this month, China has ordered banks to hold more of their deposits in reserve as it seeks to prevent credit and investment growth from destabilizing the economy. The Peoples Bank of China said on its Web site on Sunday that big banks would have to hold 11 percent of their deposits in reserve at the central bank beginning on May 15, up from 10.5 percent now.

title: In Alternative Energy, Signs of a Bubble
description: Money is flowing into alternative energy companies so fast that the warning signs of a bubble are appearing, according to a report on investment in clean technology by a New York research firm, Lux Research. The report also suggests that companies that make equipment to cleanse air or water, or that process waste, have been overlooked by investors.

title: Biosite Board Calls Inverness Offer Superior
description: A diagnostic test maker, Biosite, said Thursday that its board had determined that a $1.6 billion buyout offer from Inverness Medical Innovations is a superior proposal to an earlier $1.55 billion offer from Beckman Coulter.

title: Tribune Executives Opt Out of Bonus Pool
description: Several top officers of Tribune have joined the chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, in limiting or declining their slice of a transaction bonus pool related to the companys $8.2 billion bid to go private.

title: Investors Decline to Ride Ocean Powers Wave
description: When it comes to alternative energy, investors clearly arent jumping on every concept. Shares of Ocean Power Technologies, which makes systems that extract energy in ocean waves and convert it to electricity, have been sinking since its initial public offering last week.

title: K.K.R. Adviser to Join Sun Board
description: Michael Marks, a senior adviser with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, has joined the board of Sun Microsystems as part of a $700 million investment the firm made in the storage and software company earlier this year.

title: Sainsburys Faces Pressure to Spin Off Property Arm
description: After fending off a proposed $19 billion buyout from private equity suitors led by CVC Capital Partners, the British supermarket chain J Sainsbury now finds itself under pressure from shareholders to split up its businesses.

title: In Brocade Case, Firm May Face Conflict of Interest
description: A judge in United States district court raised concerns Friday that the law firm Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati might have a conflict of interest in litigation over options backdating at Brocade Communications Systems. The conflict of interest, it seems, is the law firms own chairman, the famed Silicon Valley lawyer Lawrence W. Sonsini.

title: Proxy Firm Urges a Rejection of the Clear Channel Deal
description: As Clear Channel Communications bidders Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners scramble to persuade shareholders to back their $19.4 billion bid for the company, a proxy advisory firm has dealt the potential deal another blow.

title: Enron, the Supreme Court and Shareholders on the Brink
description: The investment banks that helped Enron managers conceal the truth about Enron could get off, but Ben Stein writes in the New York Times that the Supreme Court could correct what he suggests is the mistreatment of shareholders.

title: Investigation of Seattle Pension Fund Manager Widens
description: Federal prosecutors in Seattle are conducting a criminal inquiry into Quellos Investments, a prominent money manager for pension funds, over its design and sale of questionable tax shelters to wealthy investors. The inquiry signals a widening of a federal investigation into tax shelters promoted by banks, accounting firms and law firms in recent years.

title: Jailed 7 Years for Contempt, Armstrong Is Headed for Prison
description: A federal judge lifted a seven-year-old civil contempt sanction on the financial adviser Martin A. Armstrong on Friday, allowing him to begin serving a five-year sentence for conspiracy to commit fraud.

title: Cramer Sees Gold in Investment-Bank Stocks
description: Goldman Sachs is the most undervalued of the five major United States investment banks, but all of their stocks are good investments, James Cramer, the former hedge fund manager and host of CNBCs Mad Money, wrote in his column in New York magazine. He argued that Goldman and the rest of the quintet   Bear Stearns, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley  are reaping the benefits of a global merger boom. They also have lucrative asset management arms as well as in-house hedge funds and private equity funds.

title: Marie-Josee Kravis Testifies in Hollinger Trial
description: A former audit committee member of Hollinger International, began testifying Friday in the criminal trial of Conrad M. Black, the former chairman, with prosecutors portraying her as a talented economist who had been duped while the defense suggested she had failed to carry out her financial duties.

title: The Great Conciliator?
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silvers profile in the capital during the Spitzer administration has, at times, seemed lower than his voice, which registers so far down on the bass clef that we have to lean in to hear.

title: Citigroup Wants to Get It Done
description: Cititgoups new tagline, Lets Get It Done, could double as a rallying cry for the banks chief Charles O. Prince III.

title: Rival ABN Amro Bidders Line Up Financing
description: The European bank consortium seeking to top ABN Amros agreed sale to Barclays has lined up much of the financing needed to pay for its approximately 72.27 billion-euro ($98.66 billion) bid, in what could ultimately represent a record amount for fund raising, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Malaysian Mogul in Mobile-Phone Deal
description: T. Ananda Krishnan, the second-richest person in Malaysia, plans to buy full control of Maxis Communications, Malaysias No. 1 mobile-phone operator, which is valued at $9.6 billion.

title: Eni Buys Gulf Of Mexico Assets for $4.8 Billion
description: Eni, the European oil company, agreed to buy Dominion Resources exploration and production assets in the Gulf of Mexico for $4.8 billion to triple its output from the region. The purchase will raise Enis production in the Gulf to 110,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day by the second half of 2007, from 36,000 barrels a day now, the Rome-based company said Monday.

title: Indian Lenders Shares Fall on Planned Stock Sale
description: Shares of ICICI Bank, Indias most valuable lender, were set for the biggest drop in three years on concern a planned 200 billion rupee ($4.9 billion) stock sale will cut returns for investors as profit growth slows, Bloomberg News reported. ICICI slumped as much as 9.6 percent on the Bombay Stock Exchange.

title: Porsche Launches Offer for Volkswagen
description: Porsche said the offer period for its low-ball 35.9 billion-euro ($48.9 billion) bid for Volkswagen, intended to stave off a hostile takeover, will run for four weeks, starting Monday.

title: Citi Executives Said to Be Wary About Activist Funds
description: Is Citigroup next?

title: HSBC Sells London HQ in Record Deal
description: The London headquarters of HSBC Holdings was bought by the Spanish real estate company Metrovacesa for 1.09 billion pounds ($2.2 billion), a record for a British building.

title: Congress and Bush in Showdown on War Bill
description: For only the second time in President Bushs tenure, Congress is preparing for a veto.

title: Cable & Wireless Says Spinoff Talk Is Premature
description: Cable & Wireless, Britains second-biggest phone company, said it has no immediate plans to sell or spin off its businesses after the Observer said the company might split itself in two. Any discussion of spinning off our businesses is premature, the company said Monday. Cable & Wireless is focused on building its British and international units and the strategy is progressing well.

title: Dresdner Reportedly Adding Hedge Fund Specialists
description: Dresdner Kleinwort reportedly plans to double the number of hedge fund specialists in its investment bank over the next three years as the bank, owned by the insurer Allianz, seeks to raise hundreds of millions of euros in revenue from the rapidly growing industry.

title: Texas Pacific Adds Partners for Iberia Bid
description: Vista Capital, a private equity joint venture of Banco Santander of Spain and the Royal Bank of Scotland, entered the fray circling the Spanish airline Iberia, saying on Friday that it would join with the Texas Pacific Group, raising the possibility of a bidding war.

title: New Enterprise Finds Profits Under the Radar
description: As perhaps the most prominent longtime venture capital firm with roots outside the Silicon Valley or Boston, New Enterprise Associates is accustomed to defying expectations. So with a string of solid exits in the past year and more likely on the way, the 21-year-old firm is comfortable harvesting technology winners without relying on any chart-busting deals in emerging media or other more flashy segments, according to The Deal.com.

title: Consortium Buys Control of Italys Phone Giant
description: Telefnica of Spain and a group of Italian investors agreed on Saturday to pay 4.1 billion euros ($5.6 billion) for a controlling 18 percent stake in Telecom Italia, allowing the Spanish telecommunications giant to expand into the Italian market and extend its presence in Latin America.

title: Galpagos Goat Wars
description: The Galpagos Islands, which inspired Charles Darwins theory of evolution, are the scene of a war between man and goat.

title: Big Profits at Top Law Firms
description: More than half of the 100 top-grossing law firms in the United States had profits per equity partner of $1 million or more last year, according to American Lawyer. It was the first time that more than half the Am Law 100 has cracked the $1 million mark in profits per partner, the magazine said. At more than $4.4 million per partner, Washington-based Wiley Rein ranked first, thanks to $245 million in fees it earned for its work on the settlement of patent litigation between NTP and Blackberry maker Research in Motion. It was followed by Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and Cravath Swaine & Moore, both of which pulled in more than $3 million per partner, American Lawyer said.

title: Public Infrastructure and Private Money: A Love Story
description: Banks and investment firms have recently been pouring money into roads and other public infrastructure. BusinessWeeks Emily Thornton smells romance in the air. She writes:

title: Where Was Perle After 9/11?
Songs of Loss and Survival
description: A look at some of the performers at the 2007 Jazzfest in New Orleans.

title: Sadr Urges Wall Protest by Paint
description: A three-mile wall around a neighborhood of Baghdad became a symbol of the American occupation that Sunnis and Shiites could united against, with Iraqs Shiite leader playing the unlikely role of champion of the Sunnis.

title: 2008: The Echoes of War
description: The running theme of the war in Iraq underlines many campaign appearances of the candidates from both the Republican and Democratic fields.

title: The View From On High
description: Do you have a view?

title: Giuliani as Leader and Consoler
description: Reason contributing editor Julian Sanchez has a question: What exactly did Rudy Giuliani do on Sept. 11, 2001, that qualifies him to be president of the United States? Im not so much interested here in the broader question of whether hed make a good president, but why this, in particular, seems to be given such incredible weight, Sanchez writes on his personal blog, Notes From the Lounge. He adds, [T]they seem to half mean it in the theatrical sense of the word: the image of a strong, calm leader he projected to the city and the nation. He continues:

title: Notes on the News
description: Against a Kiss Now that Richard Gere has apologized for a public display of affection in India that earned him an arrest warrant, the Christian Science Monitor takes a closer look at a nations struggle to come to terms with its views of women and sexuality.

title: Jazzfest: Renew Orleans
description: New Orleans, April 29The heart of Sundays program at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival was the midafternoon set by the New Orleans Social Club, an all-star group of musicians who gathered in Austin six weeks after Hurricane Katrina to make a benefit album, Sing Me Back Home(Burgundy).

title: Inquirer Editor to Leave for Buyout Firm
description: Another journalist has left newsprint for financial fine print. The Philadelphia Inquirer said Monday that its managing editor, Anne Gordon, will leave the paper to become a partner at Dubilier & Company, a private equity firm based in Stamford, Conn.

title: No Menus or Fliers, Please
description: Or, as the illiterate signs on more than one building have it  no menus. (And dont get us started on flyer.)

title: Pick a Car, Any Car
description: If youre searching for a new car, there should be plenty on dealers lots to choose from. April appears to have been one of the worst sales months in recent years, not only for Detroits automakers but for their competitors as well. Nearly the major automakers are expected to post declines when they report the months results on Tuesday, so many dealers are undoubtedly eager to bulk up their April numbers before closing the books tonight. (Edmunds.com forecasts that Toyota and Nissan will come out slightly ahead when the numbers are adjusted for the fact that April 06 had two more selling days than April 07.)

title: The Codey Administration(s)
description: Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey will be leaving the hospital this afternoon and will speak briefly with reporters beforehand. He has indicated hell take up to a week to decide when he will resume his duties. (Update: Hes out.)

title: Colony, Arnault Win Seats at Carrefour
description: Shareholders of Carrefour, the global retailing company, granted board seats to representatives of Bernard Arnault and Colony Capital at the companys annual meeting on Monday. But they also complained about the companys lack of disclosure over its internal troubles, the Financial Times reported.

title: The Velvet Glove Approach
A New Home for the Yankees
description: Plans for an $800 million home for the Yankees were unveiled on Wednesday.

title: In-Flight Annoyances
description: On a flight to speaking engagement last week, this is what I encountered:

title: Supreme Court Sides With Microsoft in Patent Case
description: WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Supreme Court sided with Microsoft Corp. today in a case that restricts the reach of United States patents overseas.

title: Waiting for Word From the Boss
description: Theres a good chance that George Steinbrenner will issue some kind of statement about Joe Torre today. Its an off day at the end of a 9-14 April, after five losses in six games to the Boston Red Sox. Steinbrenner will want to show the fans that hes still with it, that hes still riled up about the awful start to the season.

title: Amazon Giveth and Taketh Away
description: As with most things on Wall Street, last weeks surge in Amazon.coms stock created some big winners and big losers. In the winners column: Bill Miller, the mutual-fund manager from Legg Mason whose legendary 15-year streak of beating the S&P 500 ended last year when some of his value funds top stock picks  including Amazon  failed to pay off. As recently as January, Mr. Miller doggedly defended his Amazon pick, writing in a letter to shareholders of his fund that investors wrongly believe todays low operating margins [at Amazon] are going to be the norm for years.

title: Park to Start as El Duque Goes to the D.L.
description: The Mets placed Orlando Hernandez on the disabled list today, retroactive to April 25, with bursitis in his right shoulder. Chan Ho Park, who was 3-1 but had a 7.29 earned run average for Class AAA New Orleans, was recalled to start tonight against the Florida Marlins at Shea Stadium.

title: Spitzer Still in Fighting Mood
description: Appearing today at an Albany middle school, Gov. Eliot Spitzer seemed in high spirits, even somewhat defiant, in response to questions about his prodigious campaign fund-raising and whether or not it conflicts with his message of tighter campaign finance limits.

title: Soviet Memorial Is Reinstalled
description: Three days after its controversial removal from the center of Talinn, Estonias capital, the statue of a Red Army soldier is standing upright again at its new location: the Defense Forces Cemetery in another part of the city.

title: Of Taxes, Tribune and a Real Estate Magnate
description: In 1996, Congress passed a minimum-wage bill with a provision to help small companies set up employee stock ownership plans. Eleven years later, the real estate mogul Samuel Zell is using that provision to the utmost in his buyout of the newspaper company Tribune, which creates an entity that is shielded for years from paying income tax. Newsweeks Allen Sloan sees some irony at work here. He called up John Breaux, the former United States senator who sponsored the 1996 provision, to ask him about the Tribune deal, and Mr. Breaux said: I wanted to encourage employee ownership. I wasnt trying to encourage tax avoidance.

title: I Believe in Them
description: An Update: The Yankees principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner issued a statement today saying that the teams performance is clearly not acceptable to me or to Yankee fans. But the boss backed his general manager, Brian Cashman, and Manager Joe Torre by saying, I believe in them.

title: 1967 Maytag Commercial
description: For a familiar advertising character, the lonely Maytag repairman, a new life is beginning at 40 as he gets a major personality makeover.

title: Yahoo Vice President Jumps to Venture Firm
description: Andrew Braccia, who had been vice president of consumer Web search at the Internet giant Yahoo, has apparently caught the venture capital bug. Mr. Braccia is joining Accel Partners, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm whose investments include the social-networking site Facebook and the mobile ad network AdMob. Accel said Monday that Mr. Braccia will help it look for new investments in consumer Internet and software companies, with a focus on search, digital media and online advertising.

title: More G.E. Musings: Who Would Buy NBC?
description: There was a big reaction (both in the markets and on DealBook) to Fridays report on General Electric from analysts at Citigroup, who suggested that a partial breakup of the conglomerate could help its stock break out of its multiyear rut. Some DealBook readers, like Motley Fools Nathan Parmelee, commented on the irony that the report came from Citi, a financial giant that some shareholders and investors have also said could benefit from a breakup.

title: Monday Motorsports
description: In Nascar, Jeff Gordon passed Number 3 for sixth place on the all-time Cup wins list, and the classy fans at Talladega couldnt have been happier. Really, theyre excited. Its Miller Lite theyre showering onto Gordons car  the Champagne of beers.

title: 2007 Maytag Commercial
description: For a familiar advertising character, the lonely Maytag repairman, a new life is beginning at 40 as he gets a major personality makeover.

title: They Want to Break Free
description: Readers respond to David Brookss April 29 column, Grim Old Party.

title: Keep Asking Why
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Apr. 30 column, Working the Truth Beat.

title: Their Profits and Ours Dont Add Up
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Apr. 30 column, Another Economic Disconnect.

title: A New Pecking Order for Private Equity
description: Who is the worlds biggest private equity firm?

title: A Deal Made in the Mountains, Now Stuck in the Mud
description: Allen & Companys annual conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, is known as a wellspring of media deals. (See the agreement between BET founder Robert L. Johnson and The Weinstein Company.) It appears we can add another offer to that list: the bid by the investment firm Tornante to acquire Topps, the baseball card maker.

title: In Britain, a Failed Plot and 7/7
description: As a British court sentenced five men to life sentences for plotting terrorist attacks using fertilizer bombs, the nations domestic intelligence service took what the BBC described as an unprecedented step.

title: Bridging the Divide in Wartime
description: Nothing can divide a nation more than war does  as we can see for ourselves today. But the most effective way to keep that division from widening and leaving permanent scars is for a president to reach out to the opposition party and bring it aboard. Various presidents have successfully done this.

title: The Illusion of a Nation Divided
description: We seem to be a rather polarized country. According to views often expressed in the media, especially online, Republicans revel in the idea of torture and detest our Constitution, while Democrats want to bring the troops home from Iraq only to accomplish the dastardly double-trick of surrendering our country to the terrorists and kicking off a genocide in the Middle East.

title: Whos Drinking Evian?

title: The D.C. Madams List
